column2: An improved tracking-differentiator filter based on Taylor's formula
column3: Abstract Because of the ability of tracking and filtering the reference signal (RS), and the ability of obtaining the generalized derivative of the RS, nonlinear tracking differentiators (NTDs) have been widely applied in many of the engineering fields. However, there are phase delays when applying NTDs. These phase delays will affect subsequent performance. In order to improve the accuracy of NTDs, a new phase compensation method based on Taylor's formula is proposed in this paper, which could reduce the phase delays significantly. Some simulation results are provided to demonstrate the effectiveness of the method.
column5: Keywords Tracking differentiator Filtering Phase delay Taylor's formula Compensation method 1 Introduction In many of the actual engineering projects, we usually encounter the requirements for extracting true signals of given signals with noise, these need filtering technologies. There are many filtering methods proposed by others, such as adaptive filter [1], the Kalman filter and its improving algorithms [2–4], and tracking-differentiator filter [5]. The most widely used tracking-differentiator is proposed by Han–Wang in [6]. It is a nonlinear tracking differentiator which can successfully track the input signals (ISs) and obtain the generalized derivatives of the ISs. Because of its rigid proof in mathematics and good effect of tracking for application in engineering, it has been also widely used in many other fields. The effectiveness has been confirmed by engineering practices [7]. To make such differentiator popular, the main idea of [6] and the corresponding control method, which called active disturbance rejection control (ADRC), was translated from Chinese into English in [8]. For the purpose of engineering applications, numerical analysis is essential to verify the proposed algorithm, so the discrete form of NTD (as DNTD) is necessary, which has been done by Han–Yuan in [9]. Han–Yuan used time zone method to determine the synthesis function of the second-order discrete optimal control system. It has been found that DNTD could not only track but also filter the input signals. Wu et al. [5] studied the filtering performance of DNTD, but they found that there existed some phase lags on the output results of DNTD. Wu et al. suggested a compensation method by predicting, and obtained a better outcome than that of the former DNTD. Laterly, Guo–Zhao [10] gave a rigorous proof under some additional conditions of NTD proposed by Han–Wang [6], which can be regarded as the theoretical support of the following analysis. After that, researchers proposed various improvements to obtain more accurate estimation and fewer phase lags, see [11–16]. Unfortunately, those results showed that phase lags still remained. Guo–Zhao had proved the weak convergence for the high-gain nonlinear differentiator based on finite-time stable systems [11]. Compared with the existing ones, its numerical experiment gave some good properties, such as fast tracking speed, accuracy, smooth, anti-chattering, less phase delays, and so on. However, such excellent method still has small phase delays, and the improved methods are always with more complex forms. So the finding of effective compensation method has stimulated much interest. Motivated by the previous works, we emphatically try to analyze the reason on the phase lags of DNTD. During this work, we intend to find a new phase compensation method which can reduce the phase lags for DNTD. Finally, we discover a new way on the compensation method by applying the idea of Taylor's formula, which has been analyzed by Wang in [17]. As a matter of fact, using Taylor's formula, Wang proposed a new idea to reconstruct signals which are with a sequence of observations. Inspired by Wang, we will apply Taylor's formula to do some compensation for the phase lags of DNTD. This paper is organized as follows. The problem is stated in Section 2, and the detailed compensation method based on Taylor's formula is provided in Section 3. Section 4 demonstrates the effectiveness of the proposed method by numerical simulations. The comparison is carried out for noise free as well as noisy measurements. The comparative study suggests that, if the design parameters are chosen properly, the new compensation method outperforms the other methods. Readers can refer to [5,12]. The conclusions are given in Section 5. 2 The statement of the problem In this section, we will try to analyze the reason on the phase delays of NTDs first. And then we will demonstrate the existing problem by a simple example for DNTD introduced by Han–Yuan [9]. 2.1 The analysis on the reason of phase delays The essence of the tracking-differentiators in [6] for tracking the IS is carried out by constructing the dynamical systems of time optimal control systems which are with the proper tracking speeds. Therefore, there exists the fast or slow of tracking. That is to say, the phase delays are inevitable. So it is necessary to find a solution for compensating the phase delays. In the following, we will show the results of phase delays for a certain kind of NTDs. 2.2 The discrete form of nonlinear tracking differentiators For the purpose of engineering applications, especially for convenience of calculation, the DNTD, one of the implementation of NTD proposed by Han–Wang [6], is obtained by Han–Yuan [9]. For intuitionists, the DNTD is represented as follows: (1) x 1 ( k + 1 ) = x 1 ( k ) + hx 2 ( k ) , x 2 ( k + 1 ) = x 2 ( k ) - hrsat ( g ( k ) , δ ) , where h is the sample step, r is a​ parameter that could control the speed of the tracking. g(k) and δ are given as follows: (2) δ = hr , (3) g ( k ) = x 2 ( k ) − sign ( z ( k ) ) r ( h − 8 | z ( k ) | r + h 2 ) 2 , | z ( k ) | > δ 1 , x 2 ( k ) + z ( k ) h , | z ( k ) | ≤ δ 1 , where δ 1 = hδ, e ( k ) = x 1 ( k ) − v ( k ) , z(k) = e(k) + hx 2(k),​ and sat(·) is a saturate function (4) sat ( x , δ ) = sign ( x ) , | x | > δ , x δ , | x | ≤ δ , where r and h are design parameters. We can determine the optimal design ​parameters to obtain the desired results through amounts of simulation experiments. 2.3 The existed problem—the phase delays of DNTD A simple example is introduced here to illustrate the existed problem of phase delays. Example 1 Let v be an input signal without noise, i.e., (5) v = sin ( t ) . With the given design parameters, the tracking result and the differential result are shown in Fig. 1 respectively. The results in Fig. 1 indicate that DNTD works well on the layout of tracking and differential performance, but there exist significant phase delays. If we choose h = 0.01, r = 100 or r = 1000, the estimation will be more accurate which is shown in Fig. 2 . But after local amplification, there are still phase delays in both of them. The phenomenon of phase lags also exists in most of other improvement methods of NTD (see [11–16]). Because of phase lags, the accuracy of these differentiators is degraded no matter how the parameters are chosen. To get rid of the possible phase lags, we will give a compensation method based on Taylor's expansion in the next section. 3 The compensation method for pahse delays method based on Taylor's formula In this section, we will consider the method on the compensation for phase delays by using Taylor's formula. So, we introduce Taylor's formula briefly, and then describe our method based on Taylor's formula. 3.1 Taylor's formula and its inspiration Here we use Lagrange Taylor's expansion in the following of this paper. Assume that f is a function that satisfies the conditions of the Taylor's formula. If we know the value of f(x) at x, we can use above Taylor's formula to estimate the value of f(x) at x + Δx as follows: (6) f ( x + Δ x ) = f ( x ) + f ′ ( x ) 1 ! Δ x + f ″ ( x ) 2 ! ( Δ x ) 2 + ⋯ + f ( n ) ( x ) n ! ( Δ x ) n + f ( n + 1 ) ( ξ ) ( n + 1 ) ! ( Δ x ) n + 1 . Especially, for the function of time t, let y(t) be the true signal, v ( t ) be the observed signal which is often the true signal with noise, x 1 be the tracking or filter of v ( t ) , and x 2 be the differential signal of v ( t ) . In order to make the phase delays can be seen clearly, we set h = 0.1 and r = 1 in Example 1. The results with local enlarged are plotted in Fig. 3 . In Fig. 3, the solid line is the input signal, because of the noise free measurement, it also denotes the true signal. The dash line is the tracking signal of the input signal. Because of the phase lags, the value of tracking signal x 1(t 1) does not reflect the real value y(t 1) at time t 1. As shown in Fig. 3, the tracking value x 1(t 1) equals the real value at time t 2, some time before t 1, i.e., the output signals of DNTD have lags with t 1 − t 2. With these findings and the inspiration of the Taylor's formula, we have the thought of doing compensations for the phase delays of DNTD. 3.2 The new compensation method of DNTD According to the considerations above, the basic compensation method is divided into the following steps: Firstly, we should deal with the input signal v ( t ) with the nth-order cascade of DNTD (suppose that every parameter r in (1) is the same) and get the output signal x 1i (t) (the tracking signal of v ( i ) ( t ) ) and the ith-order differential signal x 2i (t) from DNTD i at t. The relations of the signals can be seen from Fig. 4 , where x 1i is the filter and approximation of y (i−1), i = 1, 2, ⋯, n. Similarly, x 2i is the differential and approximation of y (i), i = 1, 2, ⋯, n. Secondly, according to Eq. (6), and the output signals of DNTD have lags with time t 1 − t 2, we can obtain the compensating signal which is also the approximate value y ˆ ( t 1 ) of the real value y(t 1) as follows: (7) y ˆ ( t 1 ) = y ( t 2 ) + y ′ ( t 2 ) 1 ! ( t 1 − t 2 ) + y ″ ( t 2 ) 2 ! ( t 1 − t 2 ) 2 + ⋯ + y ( n ) ( t 2 ) n ! ( t 1 − t 2 ) n + y ( n + 1 ) ( ξ ) ( n + 1 ) ! ( t 1 − t 2 ) n + 1 . That is to say, we could use the Taylor's expansion at t 2 to approximate y(t 1). But with the phase lags, as shown in Fig. 3, x 1(t 1) equals y(t 2). So if we know the lag time Δt = t 1 − t 2 = r F h accurately (where r F is the compensated step), we could compensate the delay very well. In this paper, we set r t , r d as compensated steps for tracking and differential respectively. The compensated steps are design parameters, which should be chosen properly according to the values of r (design parameter in DNTD) and h (sample time). Then, Eq. (7) is changed into the following form: (8) y ˆ ( t 1 ) = x 11 ( t 1 ) + x 12 ( t 1 ) 1 ! ( t 1 − t 2 ) + x 13 ( t 1 ) 2 ! ( t 1 − t 2 ) 2 + ⋯ + x 1 n ( t 1 ) n ! ( t 1 − t 2 ) n . Finally, based on the analysis above, we use Eq. (8) as our suggested compensation method. This compensation method,​ based on Taylor's formula,​ is ​not only with a simple form, but also works well for signals with or without noises. The performance can be seen through the numerical simulations in next section. Notice that the compensation method in [5] is with the following form: (9) y ˆ ( t 1 ) = x 11 ( t 1 ) + r W hx 12 , where r W means the compensated step. In order to compare the results, we set the same compensated step, i.e., r W  = r F . So the method of [5] also can be considered as the first-order expansion of Taylor's formula, and it can be regarded as a specific form of our suggested method. As to the range of estimating error with our proposed method, it can be measured by the Lagrange remainder R n (x) in Taylor's formula. We assume that M is the upper bound of |f (n+1)(ξ)| in [x, x 0] or in [x 0, x]. Then (10) R n ( x ) ≤ M ( n + 1 ) ! | x − x 0 | n + 1 . It should be mentioned that Feng–Li [12] introduced two special high-gain tracking differentiators which are also based on the Taylor's expansion, but these methods are different. The difference is that we use Taylor's formula for the compensation of DNTD, while Feng–Li uses Taylor's formula in the tracking-differentiator. Our method is simpler than others, and it can also be used in other improved tracking differentiators where phase delays exist. In the next section, we will provide several numerical simulations to demonstrate the effectiveness of the proposed method. 4 Numerical simulations In this section, several numerical simulations for different cases of signals are presented to illustrate the efficiency of our method. For simplicity, we first introduce some notations. DNTD denotes the discrete nonlinear tracking differentiator. DNTDT1 represents the compensation method based on the first-order Taylor's formula (which can also be seen as the extension of the compensation method in [5]). DNTDT2 means the compensation method based on the second-order Taylor's formula. From [12], TD1 signifies the tracking-differentiator which named TD1 in [12]. We will carry out our simulations by choosing the proper parameter r, the sample time h and the compensated steps r t , r d respectively. In the following, suppose that Error is the difference between the true signal and the estimated signal. 4.1 Case for noise free signals In this section, we first give the following example. Example 2 Consider an observation v ( t ) which is with the form of the sinusoidal function, i.e. (11) v ( t ) = sin ( 2 t ) . By straightforward calculation, we obtain v ′ ( t ) = 2 cos ( 2 t ) , so we can judge the results of compensation by using the reference value v ′ ( t ) of differential signal. When we choose h = 0.01, r = 1000, r t  = 2.06, r d  = 1.5, and the initial state of DNTD to be (0, 0), the simulation results are shown below. Fig. 5 represents the tracking results, and Fig. 6 indicates the differential results. From Fig. 5, we know that DNTDT1 and DNTDT2 could compensate phase delays and improve tracking accuracy significantly, which can be seen clearly in Fig. 5(b). What's more, it is easy to see that the tracking error of DNTDT2 is less than that of DNTDT1. That is to say, DNTDT2 performs better than DNTDT1 in this case. From Fig. 6, we can also obtain the same conclusion. These results indicate that, the proposed compensation methods based on Taylor's formula could decrease phase delays in DNTD observably when we deal with noise free signal. In addition, DNTDT2 works better than DNTDT1, which indicates that compensation method based Taylor's formula outperform the method proposed by Wu et al. [5]. 4.2 Case for noisy signals Example 3 Consider an observation v ( t ) which is the sinusoidal function with white noise η t . (12) v ( t ) = sin ( 2 t ) + 0.0001 η t . Here we suppose that η t obeys the standard normal distribution. We also use the real signal, y(t) = sin(2t), and the real deviative of y(t), y′(t) = 2 cos(2t), to judge the compensation effect. Let h = 0.01, r = 200, r t  = 2.0, r d  = 1.5, and the initial value in DNTD to be (0, 0). The results on filtering, differential and their errors are shown in Figs. 7 and 8 respectively. Figs. 7(b) and 8(b) indicate that both results from DNTDT1 and DNTDT2 based on Taylor's expansion are superior than the results only from DNTD. It means that the new compensation method can also process noisy signals very well. To summarize, Examples 2 and 3 have verified the efficiency of our proposed compensation method. They also show DNTDT2 works better than DNTDT1 in most cases. So in the next example, DNTDT2 is chosen for comparison with TD1. Example 4 In this example, v ( t ) is defined the same as that in Example 3. For given ε > 0, following [12], we set ε = 0.1, then results of TD1 will be determined. If sample time h = 0.01, by trial and error, the design parameters are chosen as: r = 185, r t  = 2, r d  = 1.5. The initial value in DNTD is (0, 0). Then the simulation results are shown in Figs. 9 and 10 respectively. As shown in Figs. 9 and 10, we can obtain more efficiency results on tracking and differential than those of TD1 if the design parameters are chosen properly. 5 Conclusions In this paper, a new compensation method based on Taylor's formula for DNTD has been presented. We discuss the phase lags phenomenon which often occurs in DNTD, and propose a compensating method to improve DNTD's tracking, filtering and differential performance. Compared with the compensation method of Wu et al. [5] and TD1 in [12], the method proposed in this paper improves the tracking accuracy greatly, and obtains a more accurate approximation for differential signals. From the simulations, we could obtain better approximate results if we adjust the design parameters properly. So the adjustment of the design parameters is very important, and this is the key issue we want to consider in the future.

column2: Comparative study of electronic and optical properties of graphene and germanene: DFT study
column3: Abstract We have performed a first-principle study of the electronic and optical properties of optimized structure of germanene and graphene by means of density functional theory, using the full potential linearized augmented plane wave (FP-LAPW) method based to Gradient Generazed approximation (GGA). Moreover, the enhanced absorption coefficient, reflectivity and refraction index are also study in both directions. In general, the calculated results indicate that the graphene and germanene are similar electronic structure with zero band gap at K point, further the absorption coefficient and reflectivity of germanene is higher in visible light than graphene; germanene holds great potential solar cell applications.
column5: Keywords Graphene germanene Superlattices Electronic properties Band gap engineering 1 Introduction Graphene has attracted great interest recently due to its exceptional electronic properties and potential application in nanotechnologies [1,2]. Graphene describes near the Dirac points linear dispersion relation with a Fermi velocity of about 106 m s − 1. Already in the first experimental studies obtained a high charge carrier motilities from 15 000 cm2 (V s) −1 for graphene on SiO2 substrate to 20,000 cm2 (V s) −1 for graphene suspended [1]. After discovery of graphene drive researches in nanomaterial on 2D materials, especially on elemental ones. A novel two-dimensional (2D) materials beyond graphene after the successful synthesis of silicene in 2012 [3]. In 2014 several research groups have reported the growth of germanene, a new member of the graphene family. Germanene shares very peculiar and interesting electronics properties with silicene and graphene. The method for synthesising germanene is similar to silicene and graphene is to deposit a layer of germanium atoms onto a substrate in high temperature and in an utra-high vacuum. The germanene a two-dimensional germanium layer result by deposition of germanium onto the Au (111) surface at 200 °C similarly to the formation of silicene on Ag (111), this result has been proved experimentally with scanning tunneling microscopy (STM) and DFT calculation [4]. By using the density functional theory (DFT) buckled hexagonal sheets of germanium are more stable than their planar arrangements [5]. The spin-orbit gap in germanene is around 24 meV is much larger than in graphene inferior to 0.05 meV, Because of low buckled structure and greater spin orbit coupling which makes germanene the ideal candidate to exhibit the quantum spin Hall effect at experimentally accessible temperatures [6]. Germanene has many aspects very similar to graphene, but in contrast to the planar graphene lattice, the germanene honeycomb lattice is buckled and composed of two vertically displaced sublattices. Since the fact that both of C and Ge atoms have four electrons in the valence band, which makes the properties of germanene very similar to those of graphene. Furthermore, compared to graphene, germanene is more preferable for the present novel functional electronic devices such as room temperature field effect transistors [7]. Different from sp2 hybridization that is energetically more favorable for C atoms in graphene, germanene is contributed by sp2 and sp3 hybridization leading to slightly buckled structure. The electronic and optical properties of germanene have been determined from ab initio calculations it is quite similar to graphene a zero band-gap semi metallic, and a linear dispersion near to K and K' points and massless particles of their charge carriers [8,9]. However, the gapless characteristic of germanene limits its utilizations in nanoelectronic and optoelectronic devices [10]. In order to compare graphene and germanene electronic and optical proprieties. The electronics and optical of germanene has been investigated by attaching a hydrogen atom to each germanium atom named germanane; germanane has a direct average band gap of 3.2 eV [11]. In this manuscript, we compare the electronic and optical proprieties of graphene and germanene structures by using DFT calculation with GGA approximation. 2 Computational details Structural optimization and calculations were performed using DFT based ab-initio approach implemented in provided by Wien2k [12]. The WIEN2K computational code allows performing electronic and optical structure calculations of solids using density functional theory. It is based on the full-potential linearized augmented plane wave (LAPW) + lo method, one of the most accurate schemes for band structure calculations. the LAPW + lo approach, each unit cell is divided into two regions: the muffin tin sphere around each atom and the interstitial region outside the spheres [13,14]. The radii of the non-over lapping muffin tin spheres are chosen as Rc = 1.13 a.u. In our calculations, the DFT step is carried on using generalized gradient approximation (GGA) [15]. A vacuum layer of 20 A was used in the direction normal to the interface, representing the isolated slab boundary condition. The k-point was set to 500 for the structural optimizations and for the electrical properties calculations. The optical properties of a material are directly connected to the complex dielectric function: (1) ε ω = ε 1 ω + i ε 2 ω The complex dielectric tensor was calculated, in this program, according to the well-known relations [16]. (2) ε 2 ( ω ) = 4 π 2 e 2 m 2 ω 2 ∑ i j ∫ 〈 i , M , j 〉 2 f i ( 1 - f i ) δ ( E f - E i - ω ) d 3 k Where M is the dipole matrix, i and j are the initial and final states, respectively, f i is, the distribution of fermi as a function of the state and E i is the energy of an electron in the i-th state with a wave vector k. ε 1 ω Is the real part of the dielectric function and can be obtained from ε 2 ω using the Kramers–Kronig transformation [16]: (3) ε 1 ω = 1 + 2 π p ∫ 0 ∞ ω ' ε 2 ω ' d ω ' ω ' 2 - ω 2 With ω and p are respectively the frequency and principal value, respectively. The coefficient of absorption alpha is given by [17]: (4) α ω = 2 ω c ε 1 2 ω + ε 2 2 ω - ε 1 ω 1 2 with c is velocity of light in free space The optical reflectivity R ω spectra derived from the Fresnel’s formula for normal incidence [17]: (5) R ω = ε ω - 1 ε ω + 1 2 The variation of the refractive index n (ω) versus the energy or wavelengths may be calculated using the formula: (6) n ω = ε 1 2 ω + ε 2 2 ω + ε 1 ω 2 1 2 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Electronic propriety The geometric structures of the graphene and germanene are shown in Fig. 1 . After full optimization, The Fig. 1(c) shows a plane structure of the side view of graphene, Fig. 1(d) show the bulk structure of the side view germanene, the bulked distance Δ is 0.75 Å. We have calculated the total and partial DOS of graphene and germanene. It has shown that is graphene and germanene structure are similar, with gapless semimetal and sp2 hybridization, which is shown respectively in Fig. 2 (a) and (b). As shown in Fig. 2(a) the major contribution is provided by 2p-states of carbon atom, with a small contribution from 2s-states of carbon. A very significant peak at around 1.78 eV in valence region and at −2.48 eV valence region, which mainly due to contribution of 2p states of carbon. Fig. 2(b) of germanene shows significant peak at around 4.65 eV in the valence region and −1.78 eV in the conduction region due to the contribution of 2p states of germanium atom. Fig. 3 show the band structure of graphene and germanene show all metallic in character giving zero gap with linear dispersion at the K point. Although our result is in agree with experimental Refs. [18,19]. At low values of energy, the electrons behave like massless relativistic particles, described by the Dirac-fermion system. Since graphene is sp2 hybridized, the coupling between the nearest neighbor atoms is very strong and electrons can easily tunnel from one atom to another, which may explain the larger velocities of electrons in graphene compared to germanene 3.2 Optical properties The plots for the absorption coefficient for graphene in comparison to germanene is shown in Fig. 3(a) and (b). The absorption coefficient of graphene in (xx direction) shows peaks at about λ = 283 nm. Whereas germanene the peak appears in visible region indicating the absorption in visible region more than graphene. The absorption coefficient for the perpendicular polarization to graphene is nearly zero. The absorption coefficient of germanene in (zz direction), two peaks appear at wavelengths λ = 200 nm and λ = 300 nm and goes on decreasing visible light (Fig. 4 ). The Fig. 5 gives the comparison of reflectivity for graphene and germanene sheet for both directions of electric field using Eq. (4). The reflectivity of graphene in (xx direction) is of 12% at the wavelength λ = 283 nm, in the range of visible light the peak of reflectivity is 7.8% at the wavelength λ = 560 nm. Further, the reflectivity of germanene is higher than graphene; the peak is 28.3% at the wavelength 403 nm. In (zz direction), reflectivity of graphene is less than germanene (Fig. 6 ). The value of static refraction index (value of refraction index at zero energy) in case of parallel polarization 1.95 for graphene and minimum at energy of 5.2 eV for germanene static refraction index 3.3 and minimum at 6.5 eV as shown in figure. While in case of perpendicular polarization, the static refraction index of graphene is 1.32 and 1.12 for germanene. Refraction index is minimum at energy of 8.9 eV for graphene and 12.4 eV for germanene. 4 Conclusions We have compared the electronic and optical of graphene and germanene structure, with GGA approach. The optical properties are different in parallel and perpendicular electric field direction, so the graphene and germanene are anisotropic materials. In addition, the band gap is similar and the optical properties (absorption, reflectivity and refraction index) of germanene is more important than graphene structure. Germanene absorption is higher in visible light than graphene; that holds great potential solar cell applications.

column2: An accurate approach for the computation of polar harmonic transforms
column3: Abstract Polar Harmonic Transforms (PHTs) can be used as a feature extraction technique by exploiting their orthogonal basis that generate a set of rotation invariant features. PHTs have distinct traits as compared with other transforms and moments. This is because of their less redundant information. Applied to digital images polar harmonic transforms suffer from various numerical and statistical errors. In this paper a computational framework based on two different numerical integration schemes which reduce the numerical errors in the computation of the transforms. Extensive experiments are carried out in order to assess the accuracy of the proposed technique in face recognition problem. Two standard face databases are employed, i.e., ORL and JAFFE, which contain images with different variations. Furthermore, the rotation invariant trait of the proposed approach is evaluated using different rotation angles. The proposed approach attenuates the numerical errors as well as provides numerical stability to PHTs of high orders.
column5: Keywords Radial moments Image descriptors Invariance Accuracy Fast calculation Face description and recognition 1 Introduction Moments and transforms are known to be excellent image descriptors. Through image moments and transforms we can easily found many simple properties of image which include area (or total intensity), its centroid, and information about its orientation symmetry structure. Moments and transforms have a wide range of applications in image analysis, such as, invariant pattern or object recognition, image reconstruction, content-based image retrieval, watermarking, data-hiding, optical character recognition, pattern classification, face recognition, map matching, palm print verification and edge detection. The capability of image moments and transforms of feature representation have been widely used in object identification techniques in several areas of computer vision and robotics. Information about the different types of geometrical features of the image is provided by the set of moments and transforms computed from digital image. Moreover, the moment and transform descriptor are simple to use and can be designed to provide fast, efficient and versatile system to calculate numerical features for many applications. The accuracy of pattern recognition process can be enhanced by using the appropriate feature extraction method. One of the oldest moment and transform based shape descriptors, which are used to generate a set of invariants that have been used in many pattern recognition processes, are Geometric moments (GMs). The major disadvantage of GMs is that their information redundancy is very high. On the other hand, orthogonal radial moments and transforms are free from these drawbacks because each moment and transform describes distinct information of an image. Among the orthogonal radial moments, Zernike moments (ZMs), Pseudo Zernike moments (PZMs) and orthogonal Fourier Mellin moments (OFMMs) are generally used to represent an image with minimum amount of information redundancy. Orthogonal transforms include polar harmonic transforms (PHTs). PHTs consist of polar complex exponential transforms (PCETs), polar cosine transforms (PCTs) and polar sine transforms (PSTs). The main advantage of PHTs is low computational complexity over ZMs, PZMs. and OFMMs. Transformations are numerically instable at low frequency transformation and numerically stable at high frequency of transforms. The radial function of moments (ZMs, PZMs, OFMMs) are polynomial in r, whereas the radial function of transforms are harmonic in nature, i.e., they are basic waves. Moment invariant was first introduced by Hu [1] in 1962. He employed the results of the theory of algebraic invariants and derived his seven famous invariants to rotation of 2-D objects. At that time, hundreds of papers have been devoted to various improvements, extensions and generalizations of moment invariants and also to their use in many areas of application. Moment invariants have become one of the most important and most frequently used shape descriptors. Even though they suffer from certain intrinsic limitations, which prevent direct utilization for occluded object recognition, they frequently serve as first choice descriptors and as a reference method for evaluating the performance of other shape descriptors. Despite a tremendous effort and huge number of published papers, many open problems remain to be resolved. Teague [2] present orthogonal Zernike moments to image analysis, ZMs possess many useful characteristics as they provide good quality of image representation due to less sensitive to noise. Due to the orthogonal property ZMs possess minimum information redundancy as they belong to a set of orthogonal and complete polynomials defined inside a unit circle. They are found to be robust to image noise. These features of ZMs, are very useful in image description, but they also suffer from various errors which affect their accuracy. Bhatia and wolf [3] introduce class of circular orthogonal moments called Pseudo Zernike moments (PZMs), which exhibit similar properties to ZMs. Another important orthogonal rotation invariant moment known as OFMMs was first introduced by Sheng and Shen [4]. Apart from the characteristics of moments they suffer from various errors which affect their accuracy as well immunity to noise. The two major errors which arise in moment computation are geometric error and numerical integration error. These errors are also found in all ORIMs. The researchers observed that geometric error basically arises when a rectangular or square image is mapped geometrically inside the unit circle. This mapping allows only those pixels into computation of moments whose center fall inside the unit circle while discard the rest. As a result, the total pixel area used for the moment computation becomes unequal to the area of the circular region. The second error, that is, numerical integration error is caused when double integration in moment computation is approximated by zeroth order summation. Many algorithms have been developed till now for the removal of these errors. In term of noise sensitivity OFMMS have better performance than ZMs and PZMs for small images. Ping and Sheng [5] introduced Chebyshev-Fourier moments (CHFMS). Polar harmonic transforms (PHTs) are recently proposed by Yap et al. [6], which are similar to ORIMs. They observe that PHTs can be used to generate rotation-invariant features. The computation of PHTs kernel function is simple as compare to ZMs and PZMs. PHTs are numerical stable so numerical stability issue is nonexistent. The authors compared the kernel generation complexibility of PHTs with popular ZMs and PZMs. They observed that kernel generation is much less complex as compare to ZMs and PZMs. PHTs are one of such image descriptors, which are robust to image noise, invariant with respect to rotation, and after certain geometric transformations they can be made scaling and translation invariant [7]. The computation complexity of PHTs is also very low as compared to ORIMs [8]. Due to the orthogonal property, PHTs exhibit many useful characteristics such as they possess minimum information redundancy and immunity to noise. PHTs are popular with various applications such as Fingerprint classification [9], Pattern recognition [10], Character recognition, Image reconstruction [11], Image retrieval, Image data mining, face recognition [12] Texture classification, Corneal surface modeling, Biomedical imaging such as MRI or PET cans(using the 3D formulation), etc. [13,14]. The accuracy of these applications depends on the accuracy of the moment values. Therefore, the accurate computation of transforms is the major task for these applications. PHTs suffer from various errors. These errors affect the accuracy of results. Many approaches have been proposed to remove these errors till now, which reduced the errors but not completely. We propose two novel methods for the accurate computation of PHTs. The first method is based on grid division method and second method developed using wavelet integration. In the first approach, when we take average value of all sub regions, the errors involved tend to reduce simultaneously. In this approach we avoid all those sub regions whose center falls outside the circle. The angular polynomials of transforms are computed recursively, which takes less time as compare to direct method. Another important advantage of using this method is that its calculations are simple as compare to previous methods. This method gives accurate results as the pixels are divided into sub regions which means every small region will be covered whose center falls inside the circle. For high order transforms, as the reconstruction error decreases in reconstructed images, the distortion present at the center of circle also decreases and hence accurate reconstructed image is obtained. The method also increases the speed of computation which is affected by computation of angular polynomials. The second method using wavelet integration is also effective technique for the computation of polar harmonic transforms. The PHTs have well established applications in face recognition problems. To strengthen our claim of accuracy some experiments are performed on different face databases. The experiments reveal that the proposed methods give high recognition rate as compared to the existing approaches. The rest of the presented paper is ordered as follows: Section 2 provides an overview of concept of the PHTs, while their computational framework is discussed in Section 3. Section 4 presented detailed of the experiments. Conclusions are presented in Section 5. 2 Polar harmonic transforms (PHTs) The kernel functions of polar complex exponential transform (PCET), polar cosine transform (PCT) and polar sine transform (PST) define a set of orthogonal complex functions defined inside a unit circle over the polar coordinate space. The kernel function for each transform can be decomposed into radial and circular components. For an image function f ( r , θ ) expressed in the polar coordinates (r), the PHTs of order p with repetition q can be defined as follows: (1) M p q = λ ∫ 0 2 π ∫ 0 1 f ( r , θ ) H p q * ( r , θ ) r d r d θ , where H p q * ( r , θ ) is the complex conjugate of the basis function H p q ( r , θ ) . The generic form of H p q ( r , θ ) is following (2) H p q ( r , θ ) = R p ( r ) e j q θ , where R p ( r ) is the radially defined kernel function. For the considered class of harmonic transforms the function R p ( r ) is defined as follows (3) R p ( r ) = e i 2 π p r 2 F o r t h e P C E T t r a n s f o r m , (4) R p ( r ) = cos ( π p r 2 ) F o r t h e P C T t r a n s f o r m , (5) R p ( r ) = sin ( π p r 2 ) F o r t h e P S T t r a n s f o r m , The set of admissible values of (p, q) for the aforementioned transforms are different and they take the following values (6) { | p | ≥ 0 , | q | ≥ 0 a n d λ = 1 π , P C E T p ≥ 0 , | q | ≥ 0 a n d λ = 1 π i f p = 0 , λ = 2 π i f p ≠ 0 , P C T p ≥ 1 , | q | ≥ 0 a n d λ = 2 π , P S T Since the integration in Eq. (1) does not have an analytical solution for N × N image, its zeroth order approximation, given below, is normally used (7) M p q = λ ∑ i = 0 x i 2 + y k 2 ≤ 1 N − 1 ∑ k = 0 N − 1 f ( x i , y k ) H p q * ( x , i y k ) Δ x i Δ y k where (8) x i = 2 i + 1 − N D , y k = 2 k + 1 − N D , i , k = 0 , 1 , ... , N − 1 and Δ x i = Δ y k = 2 D For inner circle mapping D = N and for outer circle D = N √ 2 . The image function is reconstructed by using inverse transforms. The function reconstruction for PHTs are given as (9) f ˆ ( x i , y k ) = ∑ p = p min p max ∑ q = q min q max M p q H p q ( x i , y k ) , i , k = 0 , 1 , ... , N − 1 where p min , p max , q min , q max are the respective minimum and maximum values of PHTs, orders and repetitions as mentioned in Eq. (1). The closeness of the original image function f ( x , y ) with the reconstructed image function f ˆ ( x , y ) refers to the capability of the method to translate an image in a high compact manner. The closeness is measured by fidelity criterion which can be expressed as a mean square reconstruction error (MSRE) represented by ε which can be defined as follows: (10) ε = ∑ i = 0 N − 1 ∑ k = 0 N − 1 ( f ( x i , y k ) − f ˆ ( x i , y k ) ) 2 ∑ i = 0 N − 1 ∑ k = 0 N − 1 f 2 ( x i , y k ) The approximation of Eq. (1) represented by Eq. (7), is computationally more suitable for a square image. This approximation generates two kinds of errors, which are numerical integration error and geometric error. The reason behind numerical integration error existing is the integration using summation which generates zeroth order approximation. Fig. 1 (a) represent the square image contained in outer circle unite. Geometric error arises exists because of using the condition x i 2 + y k 2 ≤ 1 . This condition permits the pixels whose centers included in unit circle to take part in computation. While the pixels do not satisfy the above condition are discarded. Therefore, mapping from the square domain into the circular domain is not achieved perfectly, which leads to approximates the circular boundary of the unit circle in a zig-zag pattern as seen in Fig. 1(b) and Fig. 1(c). Fig. 1(b) shows an 8 × 8 image and Fig. 1(c) shows the approximated circular disk utilized in the traditional methods. 3 Framework used for PHTs computation 3.1 Grid division We rewrite the Eq. (1) for the purpose of accurate computation using the division of pixels into sub regions as follows: (11) M p q = λ ∑ i = 0 x i 2 + y k 2 ≤ 1 N − 1 ∑ k = 0 N − 1 f ( x i , y k ) h p q , i k where (12) h p q , i k = ∫ a i a i + 1 ∫ b k b k + 1 H p q * ( x , y ) d x d y Where a i = 2 i − N D , b k = 2 k − N D , i , k = 0 , 1 , ... , N The integration of the kernel function given in Eq. (12) can be approximated by using the division of the pixel [ a i , a i + 1 ] , [ b k , b k + 1 ] into n × n sub regions with equal weights. The discrete approximation of Eq. (11) using grid division is given by, M ˆ p q = λ D 2 ∑ i = 0 N − 1 ∑ k = 0 N − 1 f ( x i , y k ) ∑ l = 1 n ∑ m = 1 n w l w m v * p q t l + 2 i + 1 − N N , t m + 2 k + 1 − N N (13) t l + 2 i + 1 − N N 2 + t m + 2 k + 1 − N N 2 ≤ 1 where w l = w m = 2 / n , and t l is the center point of the sub grid. For example t 1 = 1 when n = 1 , t 1 = − 1 / 2 , t 2 = 1 / 2 when n = 2 , t 1 = − 2 / 3 , t 2 = 0 , t 3 = 2 / 3 when n = 3 , and t 1 = − 3 / 4 , t 2 = − 1 / 4 , t 3 = 1 / 4 , t 4 = 3 / 4 when n = 4 and so on. The computation of transforms includes only those pixels and sub regions whose center falls inside the circle. The recursive method is used for the computation of angular polynomials which also enhances the speed of calculations. If we divide each pixel into 3 × 3 sub regions, i.e., n = 3, then pixel is divided into 9 parts. Similarly, if we divide each pixel into 5 × 5 sub regions, i.e., n = 5, then pixel is divided into 25 parts. In the experimental section we have used n = 5. This method is motivated by the research of Pawlak [15] and Wang and Liao [16]. 3.2 Wavelet integration Let f x be an 1-D function, then its Wavelet numerical integration in the interval a , b is given by [17] (14) ∫ a b f x d x ≅ ( b - a ) 2 T ∑ l = 1 2 T f a + b - a ( l - 0.5 ) 2 T where T = 2 j and j = 0,1 … … J . The integer j indicates the level of the wavelet and the maximum level of resolution is the integer J . In the proposed method we use j = 2 , j = 3 for the computational efficiency. The 2-D formulation of the numerical integration of f x , y is expressed as (15) ∫ a b ∫ c d f x , y d x d y ≅ b - a ( d - c ) 4 T 2 ∑ l = 1 2 T ∑ h = 1 2 T f a + b - a ( l - 0.5 ) 2 T , c + d - c ( h - 0.5 ) 2 T We now accurately compute the PHTs by resorting to Wavelet numerical integration of the double integration given in Eq. (11) (16) M ˆ p q = λ D 2 ∑ l = 1 2 T ∑ h = 1 2 T ( ∑ i = 0 N - 1 ∑ k = 0 N - 1 f ( x i , y k ) v p q * ( ( 2 i T - N T + l - 0.5 D T ) , ( 2 k T - N T + h - 0.5 D T ) ) ) (17) w h e r e ( 2 i T - N T + l - 0.5 D T ) 2 + ( 2 k T - N T + h - 0.5 D T ) 2 ≤ 1 The constraint given in Eq. (17) is an important over the constraint x i 2 + y k 2 ≤ 1 used zeroth order approximation for inscribe circular disk. This constraint also allows those grids to take part in computation whose centres fall outside the circle. The radial polynomials and angular polynomials are computed recursively using the method given by Singh and Kaur [15]. 4 Experimental Analysis All algorithms in the experimental phase are carried out in Microsoft VC++6.0 under windows environments on a PC has 3 GB memory with 3.0 GHz CPU. The experiments are used to assess the accuracy performance of the proposed approach under the following issues 1. The reconstruction capability of the transforms. 2. The effective of the proposed technique under face recognition applications. 4.1 The face databases used in the experiments a) ORL database ORL database [18] included 400 face images related to 40 subjects. There are 10 different facial sample assigned for each subject. Each image of this database with 256 gray levels and size 92 × 112 pixels. The face images of this database contain different variations such as: facial expression (close/open eyes, smiling/ not smiling), facial details (with glasses/without glasses), illumination, and pose of slight tilt/yaw upto ± 20°. The face images in this database were taken against a dark homogeneous background. b) JAFFE database JAFFE database [19] consist of 213 face images distributed on ten Japanese female subjects. Each subject has seven kinds of facial expression which are sadness, fear, surprise, disgust, neutral, happiness, and anger. There are two-four samples for each facial expression per subject. Figs. 2–4 show some subjects of the database. 4.2 Reconstruction aspects For our experiment, we use 64 × 64 Lena image due to its contrast gray value. Different method under different value of pmax(moment order = 10, 20, 30, 40, 50, 60 and 70) using PCTs and PSTs for both inner and outer circle mapping are used to assess the accuracy of the proposed method under image reconstruction aspect. For reconstruction aspects we have given results for PCTs and PSTs. The performance of the proposed methods is same for PCETs also. The reconstructed images gained by using the proposed technique are compared with direct method, Gaussian numerical integration method [7]. Fig. 5 and Fig. 6 shows the original 64 × 64 Lena image and it’s reconstructed image using the direct method and proposed method respectively. Now in Fig. 6 column 2 shows the reconstructed image using direct method. Results are gained by estimating PHTs under zeroth order approximation. Increasing moment order pmax leads to increasing the reconstruction error. MSRE is low at pmax = 20. After pmax > 20 the MSRE is increasing in direct method column. The column 3 in Fig. 6, shows the reconstructed image resulted by using Gaussian 5 × 5 numerical integration method [7]. The results of column 3 are improved as compare to direct method. MSRE is decreases with increase in pmax ≤ 50, after pmax > 50 the value of MSRE little increases. Columns 4, 5 and 6 shows the reconstruction image results of our proposed methods. The numerical stability trend of PCTs can be observed from Fig. 7 . We can clearly see from this figure that the proposed methods outperform the traditional approach in terms of the stability. Similarly, now we will analysis the experimental details of the reconstruction image of PSTs under inner circle. Furthermore, the accuracy of the proposed technique is compared with the accuracy of direct method and Gaussian 5 × 5 numerical integration method. Fig. 8 shows the results of image reconstruct error using PSTs for inner circle. Image is reconstructed using different techniques under various orders of moments, column 2 shows the results of direct method, direct method stable up to pmax = 30 after this image is totally destroyed. In column 3 we can clearly seen the better results, in which we arrange the order moments in ascending form, the reconstructed error is decreases which leads to reduce the white spots. Columns 4, 5, 6, shows the results of our proposed methods. We can clearly seen from Fig. 9 that our proposed method provides better stability at higher order moments as compare to direct method and similar to Gaussian 5 × 5 numerical integration error. Our proposed method gives better quality of reconstructed image than other methods. 4.3 Face recognition using proposed approach In order to assess and compare the recognition accuracy of the proposed methods in face recognition application experiments have been carried out over two standard face databases, namely, JAFFE and ORL which contain different variations using PCTs. The experiments are performed for direct method, 5 × 5 Gaussian integration, n = 5 grid division method and j = 3 for wavelet integration method. The dataset of JAFFE database is constricted by randomly selecting one face image from each of the basic seven expression groups (anger, disgust, happiness, neutral, fear, sadness, surprise) of each subject for training and remaining all for testing, i.e., the total number of training face images is 70, while it is 143 for testing out of a total of 213 images. The dataset of ORL database is constructed by randomly selecting five random images for training and rest five images are used for test for each subject in ORL database. Thus, there are 200 face images for training and 200 face images for testing, out of a total of 400 face images. The results of the first experiment which examines the recognition accuracy of the different approaches on ORL and JAFFE database are presented in Tables 1 and 2 , respectively. As presented in Table 1 the maximum recognition rate achieved using the proposed methods are comparable with the Gaussian integration approach, however, the proposed method performs much better than the direct method. The same trend is also observed on JAFEE database, where the proposed method outperforms the traditional method. This is due to the fact that the proposed methods remove the numerical integration and geometric errors from PHTs which leads to improve its performance as a feature extraction descriptor and hence produce distinct features have the ability to distinguishing the face images under different variations. The rotation invariant trait of the proposed method has also been investigated. For this purpose a two experiments have been carried out, in both experiments the same datasets that have been utilized in the previous section has been adopted except that the test face images have been rotated with 30 ∘ , 45 ∘ , and 180 ∘ while the training face images are taken without rotation angle, Figs. 3 and 4 show two face images and their rotated versions used in the above mentioned experiments. The results of these experiments are presented in Tables 3 and 4 for ORL and JAFFE database respectively. It observed that the recognition rates of the proposed method slightly effected at rotation angle 30 ∘ while it remain stable at 180. The maximum effect in the recognition rates is takes place at rotation angle 45 ∘ where the recognition rates have dropped approximately less than 1%. The same conclusion is observed also in [20,21]. However, at this rotation angle the maximum change in the positions of the face image pixels is occurred which leads to unrecognizing the face image by other rotation variant methods therefore, the proposed methods are rotation invariant and achieved high recognition rates even in presence of rotation variation. 5 Conclusion PHTs are the effective region based shape descriptors. Their coefficients extracted from a set of orthogonal and complete basis function. The magnitude of PHTs is invariant to rotation and by using some transformation it can be made translation and scale invariant. PHTs are orthogonal, therefore they possesses distinct characteristics which are low information redundancy and good image reconstruction capability. PHTs are more robust to noise than other orthogonal rotation invariants techniques. The accuracy of PHTs is severely influence by the numerical integration and geometric errors. These errors decrease the quality of reconstructed image of PHTs magnitude. The proposed technique reduces these errors and to provide numerical stability at higher order moment. The results of the extensive experimental carried out in this work refer that the suggested technique provides accurate computation of PHTs which leads to improve the quality of reconstructed image and invariance properties of PHTs magnitude.

column2: Effect of the synthesis conditions on the structural, morphological and optical properties of Bi2Te2.7Se0.3 nanoparticles
column3: Abstract Beside their promising utility as thermoelectric generators, Bi2Te3 and related compounds have several applications in electronic and optoelectronic devices. In this work, Bi2Te2.7Se0.3 nanoparticles (NPs) were successfully prepared via physical vapor deposition technique at different conditions of flow rate and temperature. The x-ray diffraction patterns show that, the NPs crystallize in a rhombohedral crystal structure with preferable growth along the (015) plane. Field-emission scanning electron microscope (FE-SEM) investigation shows that the NPs size depends significantly on the synthesis conditions of flow rate and temperature where it decreases with the decrease in the former or with the increase in the later. The effect of deposition conditions on the final morphology can be interpreted through the accompanied variation in the concentration of the gaseous precursors in the hot zone. The optical properties were studied using Kubelka-Munk theory. Optical band gaps of 0.52, 0.58, 0.53 eV were determined for the samples synthesized under different conditions.
column5: Keywords Bi2Te3 Physical vapour deposition Optical Chalcogenide Kubelka-Munk theory 1 Introduction Bi2Te3 and its based solid solutions are layered structure with rhombohedral unit cell (space group:R-3m) such that the bismuth and tellurium atoms are arranged in parallel layers following the sequence Te(1)-Bi-Te(2)−Bi-Te [1] which is continually repeated [1]. In addition to their efficiency as thermoelectric materials [2–5] which culminated in the fabrication of thermoelectric generator and thermo-coolers, these compounds have several applications in electronics, microelectronics, optoelectronics and electromechanical devices [6]. For example, such compounds are used as photoconductive targets in TV cameras, IR spectroscopy, IR detectors and sensors [7–10]. Also, Bi2Te3 is a narrow band gap semiconductor and thus it could be exploited in other applications like temperature controller in laser diode [11] and optical recording system [12]. According to the presence of point defects, Bi2Te3 can exhibit either p- or n- type conduction but n-type is the most common as a result of considerable amount of anti-site point defects through the occupying of Te site with bismuth site [6].There are several strategies that were introduced to improve the thermoelectric performance of Bi2Te3 like doping, nanostructuring and nanocomposites [13]. Indeed, a great enhancement was achieved especially in nanostructures which can be attributed to the increase of density of states (DOS) and the decrease in the thermal conductivity through the scattering of the phonons across the boundaries [14]. Doping with antimony (Sb) [15] and selenium (Se) [16] is adopted strategy in order to enhance the physical properties of Bi2Te3. There are various techniques that are used for the synthesis of Bi2Te3 based compounds such as thermal evaporation [17], co-sputtering [18] molecular beam epitaxy [19], solvothermal method [20],etc. In this work, Bi2Te2.7Se0.3 compound has been synthesized by physical vapor deposition (PVD) method. Although, this compound has fuelled an intense research as an efficient thermoelectric material, few papers that focused on studying the effect of deposition on its structure, morphology and optical properties which have been presented here. 2 Experimental method Bi2Te2.7Se0.3 NPs were synthesized from a bulk alloy as a source material using the physical vapor deposition (PVD) technique and the procedures can be summarized as the following: (i) The source material was placed in the hot zone at a certain temperature (T) to transform the solidus material to gaseous phase. (ii) Argon gas (Ar) was used as a carrier gas to transport the NPs formed in the gaseous phase to the cold zone. (iii) The Bi2Te2.7Se0.3 NPs were deposited on glass substrates placed in the cold zone at temperature not higher than 200 °C. (iv) After furnace cooling to the room temperature, the deposited NPs were extracted from the cold zone for carrying out the various investigations and measurements. Noteworthy, three samples of deposited Bi2Te2.7Se0.3 NPs were synthesized at different conditions of temperature and flow rate, specifically, (1035 °C, 270 SCCM), (825 °C, 270 SCCM) and (825 °C, 225 SCCM) and denoted in the following as sample A–C, respectively as a matter of facilitation. The samples were characterized using the x-ray diffraction (XRD) (Brucker Axs-D8 Advance diffractometer with Cu-Kα radiation at λ = 0.154178 nm). The surface morphology and structure were demonstrated using scanning electron microscope (SEM) model: Quanta FEG250 for imaging the surface morphology. To study the optical properties of the synthesized samples, A Jascov-570 UV–vis-NIR spectrophotometer was employed to record the reflection spectrum over the wavelength range 200–2500 nm at both normal incidence and room temperature. Diffuse reflectance spectrum was obtained using a diffuse reflectance accessory model ISN-470, and the reflectance was converted by the instrument software to F(R) values according to Kubelka-Munk method. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Structure and morphology 3.1.1 Effect of deposition conditions on the structure Fig. 2a shows the XRD pattern of the synthesized samples A–C. The data confirm that the NPs for all samples crystallize in polycrystalline rhombohedral structure with preferential orientation along (015) direction. With respect to the sample (A), all peaks can be indexed to Bi2Te3 compound with preferable growth through (015) plane. The peaks can be indexed using standard reflection data of JCPDS card no. 85–0439. The sharpness of the peaks confirms the good crystallinity of the products. No additional peaks correspond to Te, Se, Bi or other impurities were observed indicating to the high purity of the sample. The x-ray pattern of sample (B) reveals that the phase is Te-rich Bi2Te3 indicating the simultaneous co-existence of Bi2Te3 and Te atoms (denoted by *). Additional small peak corresponding to Bi (denoted by ♦) could be observed. Noteworthy, the strong appearance of Te peaks here can be attributed to the decrease in temperature in the hot zone. Where, once the thermal decomposition of the bulk alloy occurs, the elements begin to evaporate with different evaporation rate [21]. The decrease in temperature with fixing the flow rate of argon leads to a reduce in the concentration of the gaseous precursors in the hot zone and hence, the chance of Bi atom to meat and react with Te atom in the hot zone decreases which make limitation for the growth of Bi2Te3 phase. This hypothesis is also assured if we take in consideration that the nucleation and growth of Te atoms is faster than Bi2Te3 [22]. The x-ray data of sample (C) illustrates a decrease in the intensity of the Bi and Te peaks as shown in Fig. 2a. The reason for the lack of Te and Bi phases here can be attributed to the increase of the concentration of gaseous precursors in the hot zone compared to sample (B) due to the decrease in the flow rate which leads to the increase of the chance of Bi and Te atoms to react and form Bi2Te3 compound. The average crystallite size (DXRD) was calculated using Debye–Sherrer’s equation [23] D = 0.9 λ/β cos θ where, θ is the glancing angle, λ is the wavelength of Cu kα radiation (λ = 1.5406 Å) and β is the full width at half maximum. Also, The dislocation density(ρ) which assess the proportion of defects through the samples is calculated using this formula ρ = 1/(DXRD) 2 [24]. It is well known that as the crystallite size becomes smaller the lattice strain (ε) becomes larger and the x-ray diffraction peak becomes broader [25]. The strain is calculated using this formula ε = β cosθ/4 [26]. All the previously mentioned x-ray parameters are tabulated in Table 1 . According to the XRD parameters, one can observe that with decreasing temperature or flow rate the DXRD increases and this can be attributed to the resultant decrease of the density of species in the hot zone. Also, the ρ decreases with the decrease in either temperature or flow rate as a result to the crystallization process becomes more slower. In addition, as it is expected [25], a decrease in the lattice strain was found with the decrease in either temperature or flow rate due to the decrease in the dislocation density. 3.1.2 Effect of deposition conditions on the morphology Field emission scanning electron microscope (FE-SEM) images as shown in Fig. 1 (a–c) show that the synthesis conditions of temperature and flow rate have a significant effect on the final morphology of the products. To be specific, the images illustrate that the Bi2Te2.7Se0.3 consist of spherical NPs, but both of the average size and size distribution depend on the synthesis temperature and flow rate. The histograms depicted as insets in Fig. 1(a–c) reveal that the particles of sample (A) have much larger average size (∼600 nm) compared to that of sample (B) (∼228 nm). This can be attributed to the high synthesis temperature (1035 °C) which led to a high evaporation rate of the source material and thus a high concentration of the gaseous precursors in the reactor during the synthesis process. Also, due to high temperature in the reactor, the tiny particles coalesce in large particles due to the repining effect and growth continuation. In contrast, as the temperature was fixed at 825 °C (samples (B) and (C)), the decrease in the flow rate from 270 to 225 SCCM results in an increase in the particle size from ∼228 to 379 nm. This can be interpreted as the following: by decreasing the flow rate, the time of survival of the gaseous precursor in the hot zone becomes larger and tiny particles will coalesce to each other leading to the formation of larger particle size [27–28] 3.2 Optical properties Diffuse reflection spectrum of the samples under study were recorded at room temperature as shown in Fig. 3 a, then converted to absorption spectrum, as shown in Fig. 3b, by employing Kubelka–Munk theory [29–30] using the formula: F(R) = α = (1-R)2/2R, where α is the absorption coefficient, R is the diffuse reflection factor and F(R) is the Kubelka-Munk function. Using the calculated optical absorption coefficient through Kubelka–Munk theory, the optical band gap of Bi2Te2.7Se0.3 specimens were determined using Tauc’s law [31–32] [F(R)hν]n = β(hν-Eop ) in which hν, β, and Eop are the incident photon energy, proportionality constant, and optical band gap, respectively. The exponent n equals 2 or 1/2 for direct or indirect transitions, respectively. By extrapolating the linear portion of the plots of [F(R)hν]2 and [F(R)hν]1/2 versus hν (see Fig. 3c), the optical band gap (Eop) could be determined as shown in Fig. 2c.The calculated optical band gaps are 0.52, 0.58, 0.53 eV for samples (A)–(C), respectively. These values are larger than the values calculated for the bulk Bi2Te3 (0.15 eV) and this can be ascribed to both of the incorporation of Se instead of Te [33] in its lattice and the quantum confinement effects resulting from the nano-sized dimensions [34]. Kadhim et al. reported an optical band gap of 0.43 eV for Bi2Te3 which increased to 0.73 eV with Se incorporation [33]. Also, Zimmer et al. [35] determined a direct optical band gap of 0.6 eV for Bi2Te2.7Se0.3 thin film. It is worth mentioning that, in this work, the maximum value of the optical band gap (0.58 eV) was obtained for sample (B) and this can be attributed to both of the smaller particle size than samples A and C and the extra existence of unreacted Te atoms in it. The refractive index (n) of Bi2Te2.7Se0.3 samples at hand were calculated as presented elsewhere [36], and the corresponding average values of refractive index are 2.12, 1.88 and 1.9 in the visible regions and 1.82, 2 and 1.87 near infrared for samples (A)–(C), respectively (see Fig. 3d). The free carrier concentration (N) was estimated optically according to Drud's model as presented elsewhere [37]. The corresponding value of N for Bi2Te2.7Se0.3 samples were found to be equal to 3.59 × 1019, 1.75 × 1020 and 3.14 × 1019 cm−3 for the samples A–C, respectively. 4 Conclusion Bi2Te2.7Se0.3 nanoparticles (NPs) were successfully prepared using physical vapor deposition (PVD) technique at different conditions of temperature and flow rate. XRD patterns confirm that the structure of the NPs is polycrystalline in nature and having rhombohedral crystal structure. The effect of deposition conditions on the internal structure and morphology was studied in detail. It was found that a significant decrease in the particle size can be obtained with a decrease in the temperature or an increase in the flow rate. Optical band gaps of 0.52, 0.58, 0.53 eV for the samples were calculated using Kubelka-Munk model. The difference in the value of the optical band gaps can be ascribed to the difference in both of the particle size and the proportion of unreacted Te atoms within the material. So, to obtain Bi2Te2.7Se0.3 NPs with desired purity, structure and morphology, the deposition conditions should be optimized. Our samples can be employed in several applications in optoelectronic devices.

column2: Tunable structure of nanowire-grid polarizer for deep ultraviolet region
column3: Abstract As the performance of nanowire-grid polarizer is determined by the characteristic size of nanowire, the polarizer for full ultraviolet (UV) region requires the characteristic size less than 50 nm, which is challengeable to the current fabrication level. In this letter, two pieces of nanowire-grid polarizers sandwiching a layer of polymer-dispersed liquid crystal (PDLC) was proposed as a tunable structure of nanowire-grid polarizer for high performance in deep ultraviolet region with 100 nm of nanowire period. In this structure, the transmittance of transverse electric (TE) mode (T TE) and transverse magnetic (TM) mode (T TM), and also the transmission extinction ratio (Ex) could be tuned by the optical path of the PDLC layer. Assuming the refractive index of PDLC layer could be varied from 1.5 to 1.6 as its applied voltage changed from saturation voltage to zero, we calculated the T TM and Ex, which varies periodically as the PDLC layer refractive index increasing. For a given incident wavelength, the maximums of T TM and Ex could be attained easily by tuning the applied voltage on PDLC layer. The simulation results show that the tunable structure has a short starting wavelength than that of single layer and double-layer structure nanowire-grid polarizer at a given transmission or extinction requirement with same characteristic size of nanowire, because of the constructive interference of TM polarization and the destructive interference of TE polarization in these two layers of nanowire, similar to a Fabry-Perot cavity, which makes it excellent to be applied in deep UV region.
column5: Keywords Optical polarizer Nanowire-grid Extinction ratio Tunable structure 1 Introduction Nanowire-gird polarizer is an optical polarization device based on metallic nanometer structure. It has been widely applied in many fields, such as liquid crystal display [1,2], polarized LED [3,4], projection display [5], polarization control [6,7], and optical communication [8] for its advantages of high polarization performance and high degree of integration. In the last ten years, more and more attention has been paid to nanowire-grid polarizer, whose applied fields have been expanded to ultraviolet [9,10] and THz [11–13] regions from visible [14,15] and near-infrared [16,17] regions. It is the characteristic size of nanowire that determinates the starting application wavelength of nanowire-grid polarizer. Therefore, the smaller characteristic size, the shorter wavelength the polarizer could be applied in. The polarizer used in near-infrared and visible regions could be realized easily by nanowire-grid of 100 nm characteristic size, which could be fabricated by nanoimprint lithography technique [18]. Limited by the bottleneck of lithographic process, the smaller characteristic size of nanowire-grid for deep UV region is not easy to fabricate in current technological conditions; therefore, more excellent polarizer in UV region requires novel structure [19,20] or novel material [21]. In reference [15], Yang proposed a double-layer nanowire-grid structure and fabricated it on the two surfaces of substrate, which could achieve higher extinction ratio than single layer nanowire-grid structure in visible and infrared regions. However, in deep UV region from 200 to 400 nm, the transmittance and the extinction ratio fluctuate sharply, as the two layers of nanowire form a similar Fabry-Perot cavity, which is sensitive to incident wavelength. Therefore, some wavelengths could obtain high transmittance and high extinction due to the constructive interference, while other wavelengths could not satisfy this conditions, then the T TM and Ex drop sharply. To cover the full wave band of UV region, novel structures of nanowire-grid polarizer should be proposed when the characteristic size of nanowire could not be reduced distinctly in the short term. In this letter, a tunable structure composed of two nanowire-grid polarizers and a PDLC layer was proposed to reduce the starting application wavelength of polarizer and enhance the extinction from starting wavelength in UV region based on a similar Fabry-Perot resonator. We will calculate and compare the polarization properties of single layer structure, double-layer structure and tunable structure of nanowire-grid polarizer in details with the software FDTD solutions using the Finite-Difference Time-Domain (FDTD) algorithm. Simulation results indicate that the tunable structure could achieve the maximum of T TM and the minimum of T TE simultaneously by tuning of the applied voltage on PDLC layers easily, which result in the maximum extinction ration (Ex) of tunable structure. Comparing with single layer and double-layer, the tunable structure has a shorter starting application wavelength, from which the polarizer could be applied suitably. This advantage will make it feasible to be applied as a novel polarizer in deep UV region. 2 Structure design Traditional structure of nanowire-grid polarizer, shown in Fig. 1 (a), has a single layer of metallic nanowire-grid fabricated in the central of substrate. Different from double-layer structure shown as Fig. 1(b), which has two layers of nanowire located in the upper and lower part of polarizer, respectively. The tunable structure is demonstrated in Fig. 1(c), which is composed by two independent single layer nanowire-grid polarizers and a sandwiched layer of PDLC. Additionally, two layers of Indium Tin Oxide (ITO) film are coated on the surfaces of nanowire-grid polarizers to ensure the applied voltage could be imposed to the PDLC layer. In order to calculate the transmittance and transmission extinction ratio, we assume the period of two nanowire-grid layers is 100 nm, and the width of nanowire is 50 nm; the nanowire is square shape and in the central of substrate; the material of nanowire and substrate are Aluminum and fused silica, respectively; the thickness of nanowire-grid layer and substrate are 100 nm and 5 μm, respectively. In double-layer structure, the two layers are aligned in X direction and the space interval h is set to 5 μm in the silica substrate. In tunable structure, the nanowire-grid layers have the same structure parameters as single layer structure, while the thickness of PDLC layer and ITO layer are set to 5 μm and 50 nm, respectively. 3 Simulation and comparison To compare the polarization properties of single layer and double-layer structure nanowire-grid polarizer, we simulated their T TM and Ex with parameters set in preceding text by FDTD algorithm with periodic boundary conditions in X and Y directions and perfectly matched layer (PML) boundary conditions in Z direction. The mesh is set to 10 nm in whole simulation region for accurate result. The calculation results of T TM and Ex for both single layer and double-layer structure are showed in Fig. 2 . In Fig. 2(a), from 254 nm to longer wavelength, the double-layer structure has a higher transmission extinction than that of single layer; but less than this wavelength in deep UV region, the double-layer structure does not have any obvious advantage, as the extinction fluctuates dramatically around that of single layer structure. Similarly in Fig. 2(b), the transmittance of TM polarization (electric field parallel to the X direction) also fluctuates acutely and periodically as the change of incident wavelength around that curve of single layer structure, while significant portions are under this curve due to the extra absorption of the additional layer of metallic nanowires. However, when the wavelengths satisfy the constructive interference conditions for the TM polarization, their transmittance could reach to or even be higher than that of single layer structure. Therefore, in order to improve the polarization performance of double-layer structure in UV region, a tunable structure should be designed to make sure any wavelength could satisfy the conditions of constructive interference and attain higher T TM and Ex simultaneously. To understand the periodic fluctuation of Ex, we consider the double layers of nanowires as a similar Fabry-Perot resonator, the refractive and transmission efficiency of single layer structure is R and T respectively. Then, the transmission of double-layer structure T d could be calculated by Eq. (1), (1) T d = T 2 ( 1- R ) 2 + 4 R sin 2 ( φ 2 ) where φ is the phase difference of the two successive light beam in F-P cavity, which could be presented as Eq. (2), (2) φ = 4 π λ n h cos θ + 2 δ where n indicates the refractive index of substrate sandwiched by two layers of metallic nanowire; h is space interval of two nanowire-grid layers; θ is the incident angle; δ is the initial phase shift caused by refraction on the surface of metallic nanowires, which is determined by the metal material, and also influenced by the incident polarization. Therefore, the initial phase shift is different for TE polarization and TM polarization. As stated above, the double layers structure is a wavelength sensitive device. The transmission enhancement only occurs in a series of wavelengths which could satisfy Eq. (3), (3) φ = 2 m π where m is an arbitrary integral number. For the wavelengths that could not meet Eq. (3), especially when (4) φ = 2 m +1 π the double-layer structure has limited enhance effect or even has negative effect on the T TM and Ex. Comparing with double-layer structure, the tunable structure is feasible to tune the refractive index of PDLC layer in order to ensure that the φ of TM polarization (φ TM) in Eq. (2) could satisfy the Eq. (3) and TE polarization (φ TE) satisfy the condition described in Eq. (4). Therefore, the maximum of Ex could be achieved by the constructive interference of TM polarization and the destructive interference of TE polarization in the tunable structure. We simulated the polarization properties of tunable structure with the parameters assumed in preceding text. As mentioned in Ref. [22], PDLC is mixture of polymer and liquid crystal (LC), and its refractive index could be calculated by Eq. (5), (5) n P D L C = f * n L C + ( 1- f ) * n P where np and nLC denote the refractive index of the polymer and the nematic LC, f is the occupation ratio of LC in the PDLC. Based on the known parameters (ne = 1.679, no = 1.511, f = 0.6, np = 1.49 at 20 °C), the maximal refractive index of the polarized and oriented PDLC that we calculated is 1.60 without the applied voltage, while the minimum is 1.50 with the saturation voltage. Then, we could calculate the Ex and T TM of tunable structure at particular incident wavelength 200 nm as the refractive index of PDLC changing from 1.5 to 1.6, the result shows as Fig. 3 . In Fig. 3, the curves of transmittance could be considered as the product of a sinusoidal function and a rising or a declining amplitude function, the former is caused by Fabry-Perot resonance and the latter is caused by the absorption of interlayer between two nanowire-grid layers. According to Eq. (2), the curves of transmittance and Ex has a same period, determined by incident wavelength and space interval h of two nanowire-grid layers, which should be designed according the variation range of nPDLC . The peak values of Ex and T TM appear on the same refractive index because the TM and TE polarization have different initial phases δ caused by the two metallic nanowire-grid layers in tunable structure. In the case of normal incidence, the initial phase difference 2δ of TM and TE polarization in Eq. (2) is π by design, which makes T TM reaches maximum while T TE reaches minimum. Therefore, the fluctuation of T TM and Ex are synchronous, and their peaks will appear at the same refractive index of PDLC layer as shown in Fig. 3. To confirm the improvement performances of the tunable structure, we calculated the maximum value of Ex and T TM for tunable structure at a series of wavelengths from 210 to 280 nm in deep UV region, and drew up the curves in Fig. 4 . It is obvious that this tunable structure could achieve a higher extinction ration than that of double-layer structure in the whole ultraviolet region by tuning the refractive index of PDLC layer, which could be applied to enhance the Ex of double-layer structure and expand the applied region to shorter wave band from 254 nm to 216 nm when the minimum extinction requirement is set at 20 dB. As the increasing of wavelength, the extinction of tunable structure increases smoothly without drastic fluctuation, which is another advantage of tunable structure polarizer. 4 Conclusion In summary, a tunable structure of nanowire-grid polarizer, as an improved version of double-layer structure, is proposed and demonstrated to shorten the starting application wavelength into deep UV region with the same characteristic size of nanowire. The results of simulation indicate that double-layer structure is a similar Fabry-Perot resonator, which is sensitive to the incident wavelength and fluctuate drastically in extinction and transmittance, especially in UV region. Comparing with double-layer structure, the tunable structure could tune the optical path between these two layers of metallic nanowire to satisfy the condition of constructive interference, resulting in the maximum transmittance of TM polarization and the maximum transmission extinction ratio. Therefore, the tunable structure has shorter starting application wavelength and higher Ex, which makes it valuable to be applied in deep UV region that could not realize by single layer or double-layer nanowire-grid polarizer with the same characteristic size. Acknowledgements This work is partly supported by the Fundamental Research Funds for the Central Universities (20103186553) and the National Natural Science Foundation of China (61377007, 61405152, 61575152 and 61775174).
