column2: Noise-like pulse erbium-doped fiber laser for supercontinuum generation
column3: Abstract Two kinds of noise-like pulse bunches are observed in an erbium-doped fiber ring laser for the first time. Picosecond- and submicrosecond-scale pulse bunches with energy of 0.32 nJ and 7.1 nJ, respectively, are generated and used in super-continuum generation. Using a 50-m dispersion-shifted fiber (DSF) a 20-dB bandwidth of over 750 nm is obtained.
column5: Keywords Fiber laser Supercontinuum Noise-like pulse PACS: PACS number(s): 42.55.Wd 42.65.Re 42.62.Fi 1 Introduction Noise-like pulse (NLP) erbium-doped fiber (EDF) lasers were first reported by Horowitz et al. [1]. The temporal signal of an NLP bunch consists of low-coherence femtosecond pulses with randomly varying amplitude, duration and position within an envelope of tens of picoseconds. The spectral width of an NLP bunch is very broad and can exceed the excitation bandwidth of EDFs. NLP bunches with energy as high as 15 nJ [2] or a spectral width of 120 nm [3] were achieved in EDF lasers. However, the temporal envelopes of all the NLP bunches obtained to date range between 10 ps and 1ns. Super-continuum (SC) generation can be realized using either pulsed or CW laser sources [4]. Astonishing results have been achieved using photonic crystal fibers or microstructured fibers with high nonlinearity and special dispersion profile. However, the fabrication of such fibers requires expensive equipment and material which are not commonly available. By taking advantage of their smooth and broad spectra, NLPs have been proposed as pump pulses for supercontinuum generation in nonlinear fibers [5–8]. Compared with schemes using ultra-short pulses, pulse distortion during amplification and signal-to-noise ratio are not a concern. Besides, special design of the fiber dispersion profile is not necessary. The theory of SC generation using NLPs was studied by simulations, and a 956-nm (1178–2134 nm) spectrum was obtained in experiment [5]. A 951-nm (1127–2078 nm) SC was realized [6–7] by using an NLP EDF ring laser, and a short-term spectral stability of ± 0.05 dB was measured [7]. Recently, SC generation in a 0.75-km conventional single-mode fiber was demonstrated using an NLP figure-eight fiber laser [9]. In this letter, an EDF laser operating in the NLP regime is designed for SC generation. NLP bunches with two kinds of unreported time scales are observed. Picosecond-scale NLP bunches with a temporal width of only 3.1 ps (bunch energy of 0.32 nJ), and submicrosecond-scale bunches with 7.1 nJ energy are generated and used in SC generation. A 20-dB spectrum over 750 nm is achieved by using the submicrosecond-scale NLP bunches. It should be noted that the wavelength region longer than 1750 nm cannot be measured in the experiment and the resulting SC is ∼100 nm broader in the short-wavelength edge than those of previous reports using NLP sources [5–7]. Besides, the SC media is only a 50-m conventional DSF rather than a special fiber [4–7], which shows the efficiency of the proposed NLP fiber laser as a SC source. 2 Experimental setup and principles The EDF laser generating picosecond-scale NLP bunches is shown in Fig. 1 . A 124-cm EDF (80 dB/m absorption ratio at 1530 nm) is pumped by a 976 nm laser diode with a maximum power of 600 mW through the wavelength division multiplexer. The nonlinear polarization evolution (NPE) plus polarization selection technique is used as the modelocking mechanism. A polarization-dependent isolator sandwiched by two polarization controllers realizes the polarization selection and the unidirectional propagation. A 134-cm DSF and a 4.6-cm polarization maintaining fiber (PMF) with birefringence BPMF  = 2.2 × 10−4 are used to optimize the cavity. A 10/90 optical coupler is used as output. The cavity frequency is 34.3 MHz and the net group velocity dispersion (GVD) is ∼0.004 ps2. A 140-m highly nonlinear fiber (HNLF) with a GVD of −0.7 ps2/km and the nonlinear parameter of 20 W−1/km is added later in the cavity to generate submicrosecond-scale NLP bunches. The output of the laser is amplified by an EDFA and then input into a 50-m DSF for SC generation. It is noted that the major difference between the proposed NLP laser and a conventional ultrafast fiber laser [10–11] is the inclusion of the PMF to increase the cavity birefringence which focuses the fiber laser on the NLP regime. Large cavity birefringence was believed to cause NLP output [1]. Although Zhao et al. [2–3] claimed the NLP operation as an intrinsic regime, simulations in ref. [12] showed that the cavity birefringence is beneficial for NLP generation. In the experiment, when the PMF is not included in the cavity, modelocking results besides NLPs, such as multipulses and bound states, have been observed. The PMF makes it possible for the NLP operation to be the only working regime other than CW generation and eliminates all the otherwise possible mode-locking outputs. Furthermore, the combination of the PMF, PDI and the NPE establishes a weak band-pass filtering mechanism [13] which flattens the output NLP spectrum. The 3-dB bandwidth of such filter is (1) Δ λ ≈ λ c 2 2 ∑ n L n B n − 1 where, λ c is the central wavelength, L = ∑ n L n is the total cavity length, and B n is the birefringence of the fibers. To demonstrate the role the PMF plays in spectrum flattening, Fig. 2 shows the output NLP spectra when PMFs with different lengths are spliced in the cavity. The central wavelength and the shape of an output NLP spectrum can be changed slightly by tuning the two PCs. Each of the spectra in Fig. 2 is the flattest one that can be obtained. Since the research focus is on the shape of the spectra, we have some of the spectra shifted horizontally by several nanometers so that all the spectra are distinguishable. It should be noted that, although PMF is beneficial for NLP generation, it doesn’t mean the longer the better. Actually, there is no result other than CW when the PMF is longer than 11 cm. When the PMF is cut back to 10.2 cm, the NLP spectrum is very coarse as a result of the polarization mode dispersion induced by the PMF. It’s assumed that the average birefringence of the fibers in the cavity except for the PMF is B a v e = 5 × 10 − 7 . According to Eq. (1), we can find that the filter bandwidth is 50 nm, 76 nm, 85 nm and 100 nm for the 10.8−, 6.4−, 5.6− and 4.6-cm PMF, respectively. The filter bandwidth is increased and the top of the filtering curve is flattened by decreasing the PMF length. Therefore, the output spectrum becomes flatter, and the spectrum wings grow. Although the filtering effect is weak because of the low-coherence nature of NLPs, the top flattening effect can be observed. The increase in PMF length will enlarge birefringence, which is beneficial for NLP generation. However, the longer PMF will reduce the filter bandwidth, which is harmful to NLP generation. In our experiments, the flattest supercontinuum was generated with the PMF of 4.6 cm. In the rest of the experiment, the length of the PMF is kept at 4.6 cm. The autocorrelation (AC) signal of a picosecond-scale NLP bunch is a coherent femtosecond-scale peak resident on the shoulders of a picosecond-scale pulse. For example, the inset of Fig. 2 shows the normalized AC signal corresponding to the spectrum of the 4.6-cm PMF, which is a 122-fs spike on the top of a 1.26-ps pulse assuming a Gaussian pulse shape. In SC generation using NLP bunches [5], after the first few meters of propagation, the NLP bunch is compressed and the spectrum slightly broadens. Then it breaks into short pulses and dispersive waves. Those short pulses form the spectrum in the longer wavelength region due to nonlinear effects, and the dispersive waves spread out to shorter wavelength region. Thus, the majority of the energy is red-shifted, and a relatively uniform continuum is formed at the short wavelength region. 3 Results and discussion Fig. 3 (a) shows the optimum NLP output from the laser. The FWHM of the spectrum is 75 nm and the output power is 11 mW. Since there is always only one NLP bunch in one cavity round-trip, the output pulse bunch energy is 0.32 nJ. The inset shows the corresponding AC signal which is a 92-fs spike on a 2-ps pulse. To our knowledge, this laser outputs the shortest NLP bunches ever reported in fiber lasers. By tuning the PCs in the cavity, the optimum SC with a 20-dB spectral width over 612 nm, shown as the black curve of Fig. 3(b), is generated. The SC extends several hundreds of nanometers in the region longer than 1750 nm [6]. Unfortunately, limited by the instruments the whole spectrum cannot be measured. As is seen in Fig. 3(b), the NLP spectrum peak near 1550 nm is consumed by SC generation process. And the spectrum in the short wavelength region is very flat. The dip near 1500 nm can be overcome by increasing the power of the NLP bunches input into the SC media [5]. However, for a fixed input power, increasing the length of the DSF deepens the dip and extends the flat part of the SC to an even shorter wavelength. Accordingly, the length of the DSF is chosen to be 50 m based on the maximum power input into the DSF so that the dip is tolerable. The AC signal corresponding to the NLP laser output is shown in the inset of Fig. 3(b). The SC seed in Fig. 3(b) deviates from the optimum NLP output in Fig. 3(a). Its spectrum has a stronger peak near 1550 nm where the GVD of DSF is near zero, resulting in stronger phase matching required in four wave mixing [4]. Then the EDFA boosts the power from 12 mW to 132.8 mW (3.9 nJ pulse bunch energy) for SC generation. Although this input power is one order of magnitude lower than that in Ref. [5], the much higher pulse bunch energy and the larger peak power resulting from the shorter pulse bunch width enable the picosecond-scale NLP bunches to generate SC with almost the same broadness in the wavelength region shorter than 1750 nm. Furthermore, since fiber nonlinearity is crucial to the spectral broadening in SC generation, using a 50-m DSF instead of a HNLF implies that this NLP fiber laser is more efficient in SC generation than previous NLP sources. The output power of the SC is 25.6 mW. It is believed that a broader bandwidth and a larger spectral density can be achieved if a more powerful EDFA is used. The submicrosecond-scale NLP bunches, as shown in the upper row of Fig. 4 (a), are generated by inserting a 140-m HNLF into the fiber laser. In the cavity, an NLP bunch suffers the saturation absorption. Since the pulse bunch energy spreads to submicrosecond scale due to the large GVD of the HNLF, the peak power of the small pulses become weaker. The HNLF provides the nonlinear phase shift required by the NPE. The repetition rate is 1.41 MHz. Sub-nanosecond pulses are randomly hopping in the submicrosecond pulse bunch. The output power is 10 mW (7.1 nJ pulse bunch energy). The spectrum, shown as the blue line in Fig. 4(b), has a peak with the FWHM of 20 nm centered at 1559 nm plus a small peak resulting from the Raman effect in the HNLF. The bandwidth of the filtering effect is estimated to be 15 nm. The submicrosecond pulse train is amplified to 152.8 mW, 108.4 nJ and input into the 50-m DSF. In Fig. 4(b), the SC (black line) has a 20-dB spectral width over 750 nm, which is much wider compared with that (red line) generated using the picosecond-scale NLP bunch. Given the fact that the pump powers used in the laser and the EDFA are the same for the picosecond- and the submicrosecond-scale NLP bunches, the latter one is more efficient in SC generation. The lower repetition rate resulting from the longer laser cavity results in the higher pulse bunch energy after amplification in the EDFA and increases the efficiency. The output power of the SC is 24.4 mW. The pulse train after the DSF is shown in the lower row of Fig. 4(a). The NLP fiber laser and SC system are robust enough to generate stable optimum spectra for over several hours. 4 Conclusion In conclusion, noise-like pulse bunches with two unreported time scales are generated and used for SC generation. These noise-like pulse bunches are more effective in supercontinuum generation than those in previous reports using noise-like pulse sources. Especially, supercontinuum with flat spectrum over 750 nm was experimentally observed using submicrosecond scale noise-like pulse bunches. Acknowledgements The authors acknowledge the support from the National Natural Science Foundation of China (Grant No. 61665002, 61463014), the Natural Science Foundation of Hubei Province (Grant No. 2015CFB609), the Youth Foundation of Hubei Provincial Department of Education (Grant No. Q20151903), and the Scientific Research Staring Foundation of Hubei University for Nationalities (Grant No. MY2015B013).

column2: Statistical characteristics of a Gaussian beam reflected by a retro-reflector in atmospheric turbulence
column3: Abstract The statistical characteristics of a retro-reflector reflecting a Gaussian beam is analyzed, which shows that the retro-reflector can be approximately characterized by an ABCD ray-transfer matrix, and a monostatic system in atmospheric turbulence with a retro-reflector as the target is processed with ABCD ray matrix theory. Analytical expressions are developed for the basic statistical moments, the degree of coherence and the scintillation index of the retro-reflected wave are calculated in terms of three fundamental statistical moments, and then the backscatter amplification effect associated with these properties are discussed. As comparisons, the results of both monostatic and bistatic cases of a plane mirror are also presented. All the results are based on the weak turbulence with von Karman spectrum.
column5: Keywords Atmospheric turbulence Retro-reflector Degree of coherence Scintillation index 1 Introduction A retro-reflector can reflect the incident wave back along the coming path, so it is widely used as a cooperative target to strengthen the intensity of the reflected wave in the monostatic systems, such as the lidar system [1], the laser ranging system and so on. n these applications it is inevitable to involve the problem of light propagation through the turbulent atmosphere in which case the wave front is usually distorted and the performance of the systems [2] may be greatly influenced, therefore, the research of the reflected wave from a retro-reflector in turbulence is necessary. The atmospheric turbulence may cause the decay of coherence, scintillation of intensity, beam wandering and spreading and so on, which were firstly studied with geometrical optics in the early time in the last century [3,4]; however, the strict condition required for the approach limits its range of application. Later several different theories [5,6], such as Rytov Method, the Markov Equations, Huygens principle and Feynman integral had been developed for light propagation through atmospheric turbulence and all led to analytic results with varying degrees of success, but also were restricted by different difficulties. The most widely used one of these theories is Rytov Method which was introduced by Tatarskii [7] and has been a classical theory until today in condition of weak turbulence [8]. In 1980’s, Yura and Hanson revealed that the Huygens–Fresnel integral to study the optical wave propagation through a complex paraxial optical system can be formulated with an ABCD ray matrix [9]. Subsequently, this method was combined with Rytov Method by L. C. Andrews to solve problems in the optical system in atmospheric turbulence [10] and was further extended to solve the double-pass wave propagation when the target is a mirror or a phase screen. An interesting phenomenon called the backscatter amplification effect or enhanced backscatter was discovered in 1970’s, and later was found widely existing in the double passage problems. In 1980s’ with local Green’s function Banakh and Mironov had studied extensively this subject and gained results including amplification effect associated with the MCF and the average intensity of the reflected waves from an unbounded plane mirror, a point reflector or a diffuse target for plane wave or spherical wave incidence [11]. L. C. Andrews and his partners also investigated the amplification effect for reflected wave from a mirror or a retro-reflector [12], by dividing the perturbation caused by the turbulence into two parts associated with the folded path and the reciprocal path [13], respectively. But their numerical results were restricted in several special situations. In this paper we firstly prove that the retro-reflector can be approximately seen as an ABCD optical element, and then the ABCD ray-matrix theory is developed for the double-passage propagation with a retro-reflector as the target. In terms of three basic statistical moments, several second-order and forth-order statistical moments of interest are derived and numerically calculated. Amplification effect associated with the scintillation index is discussed. 2 Property of the retro-reflector A retro-reflector is a solid tetrahedron composed of a base surface and three right-angle surfaces perpendicular to each other, which can reflect the wave back to the incidence direction. However, not all the wave incident on the retro-reflector can be reflected back. When the wave incidents on the optical surface normally, the effective reflecting area is shown in Fig. 1 , the aperture of the reflector is hexagonal [14]. In practice, most retro-reflectors are cut around the inscribed circle. It can be seen that the aperture of the retro-reflector is circular or approximately circular. In the condition of normal incidence, the performance of the retro-reflector reflecting a wave is rotational symmetrical [15], so it can be characterized by an ABCD ray-transfer matrix. If a ray incidents on the retro-reflector in position x 1 in direction x 1 ' , the position and the direction of the output ray are (1) x 2 x 2 ' = − 1 0 0 − 1 x 1 x 1 ' The ray matrix of the retro-reflector without considering the edge effect is (2) A inf B inf C inf D inf = − 1 0 0 − 1 Assuming that the retro-reflector has a Gaussian aperture with effective aperture radius W R , and by introducing the notation α R = 2 / k W R 2 , a finite retro-reflector can be modeled as a connection of a Gaussian lens and an infinite retro-reflector. (3) A B C D = 1 0 i α R 1 − 1 0 0 − 1 = − 1 0 − i α R − 1 3 Wave propagation by ABCD ray matrix In a monostatic system shown in Fig. 1, wave propagates forward and backward through the same path, for convenience, the coincident paths are unfolded into the same direction as shown in Fig. 2 . The optical field of a Gaussian-beam wave of unit amplitude at the emitting aperture of a transmitter can be expressed by [6] (4) U 0 r , 0 = exp − 1 2 α k r 2 where α = 2 / k W 0 2 + i / F 0 , k is the optical wave number, W 0 is the effective beam radius, F 0 is the phase front radius of curvature, r is a vector transverse to the propagation axis. The Gaussian–beam turns to a plane wave if α = 0 , or a spherical wave if α = ∞ . Propagating through a complex paraxial optical system characterized by an ABCD ray-matrix in the absence of turbulence, the field of the Gaussian-beam can be described by the generalized Huygens-Fresnel integral (5) U 0 r , L = − i k 2 π B exp i k L ∫ ∫ − ∞ ∞ d 2 s U 0 s , 0 exp i k 2 B A s 2 − 2 s ⋅ r + D r 2 = 1 p L exp i k L exp − 1 2 β L k r 2 where A–D are the ray-matrix elements for the overall propagation path, 1 / p L is complex on-axis amplitude of the beam (6) p L = A + i α B (7) β L = α D − i C A + i α B = 2 k W 2 + i 1 F While in the presence of the turbulence, the field at the plane z = L can be written as (8) U r , L = U 0 r , L exp ψ r , L where U 0 r , L is the field in Eq. (4), ψ r , L is the complex phase perturbation caused by turbulence, in Rytov approximation it can be written as (9) ψ r , L = ψ 1 r , L + ψ 2 r , L + ⋯ = χ r , L + i s r , L where ψ 1 and ψ 2 are the first- and second-order perturbation terms, χ and s denote the log- amplitude and the phase of the complex perturbation, respectively. In Rytov theory, all the second- and fourth-order statistical moments can be expressed in terms of three basic field moments as (10) E 1 0 , 0 = ψ 2 r , L + 1 2 ψ 1 2 r , L = − 2 L π k 2 ∫ 0 1 ∫ ∫ − ∞ ∞ Φ n κ , ξ d 2 κ d ξ (11) E 2 r 1 , r 2 = ψ 1 r 1 , L ψ 1 ∗ r 2 , L (12) E 3 r 1 , r 2 = ψ 1 r 1 , L ψ 1 r 2 , L where E 1 0 , 0 only depends on the length of the path, while E 2 r 1 , r 2 and E 3 r 1 , r 2 only depend on ψ 1 . To calculate ψ 1 , the spectral representation is introduced (13) ψ 1 r ,L = i k ∫ 0 L ∫ ∫ − ∞ ∞ exp i γ κ ⋅ r − i κ 2 γ 2 k B z , L d ν κ , z d z where B z , L is the matrix element B, representing the general distance in the optical system from L to z , and γ = p z / p L is the ratio of the complex on-axis amplitude of the beam at the plane z = L in the absence of a random medium to that at arbitrary position z along the propagation path, d ν κ , z is the spectrum of the fluctuation of the refractive index of the atmosphere. (14) n 1 r , z = ∫ − ∞ ∞ exp i κ ⋅ r d ν κ , z where n r , z = 1 + n 1 r , z . Eq. (11) can be extended to the double- passage propagation as: (15) ψ 1 r ,L = i k ∫ 0 L ∫ ∫ − ∞ ∞ exp i γ 1 κ ⋅ r − i κ 2 γ 1 2 k B z , 2 L d v κ , z d z + i k ∫ 0 L ∫ ∫ − ∞ ∞ exp i γ 2 κ ⋅ r − i κ 2 γ 2 2 k B z ' , 2 L d v κ , z ' d z ' The first integral term represents the phase fluctuation in the forward propagation, 0 ≤ z ≤ L , the corresponding ABCD ray-matrix is (16) A 1 B 1 C 1 D 1 = 1 z 0 1 = 1 L 1 − ξ 0 1 where ξ = 1 − z / L . The last integral term represents the phase fluctuation in the backward propagation, z ' = L − z , then the corresponding ABCD ray-matrix will be (17) A 2 B 2 C 2 D 2 = 1 z ' 0 1 − 1 0 − i α R − 1 1 L 0 1 = − 1 − i α R L η − L 1 + η + i α R L η − i α R − 1 − i α R L where η = z ' / L , which leads to (18) p L = 1 + i α L , p z = 1 + i α z and (19) p 2 L = − 1 − α α R L 2 + i L α R + 2 α , p z ' = − 1 − α α R L 2 η + i L α R η + α + α η Then the ratios of the complex on-axis amplitude can be expressed as (20) γ 1 = p z p 2 L , γ 2 = p z ' p 2 L In addition (21) B z , 2 L = − L 1 + ξ + i α R L ξ , B z ' , 2 L = L − z ' = L ( 1 − η ) By substituting Eqs. (18)–(21) to Eq. (15), the expression of ψ 1 can be derived, and further Eqs. (11 and 12) can be specialized as (22) E 2 ( r 1 , r 2 ) = 2 π k 2 L ∫ 0 1 ∫ ∫ − ∞ ∞ Φ n ( κ , ξ ) e x p i κ ⋅ ( γ 1 r 1 − γ 1 * r 2 ) − i κ 2 2 k [ γ 1 B ( ξ ) − γ 1 * B * ( ξ ) ] d 2 κ ξ + 2 π k 2 L ∫ 0 1 ∫ ∫ − ∞ ∞ Φ n ( κ , ξ ) e x p i κ ⋅ ( γ 2 r 1 − γ 2 * r 2 ) − i κ 2 2 k [ γ 2 − γ 2 * ) L ( 1 − ξ ) ] d 2 κ ξ + 2 π k 2 L ∫ 0 1 ∫ ∫ − ∞ ∞ Φ n ( κ , ξ ) e x p i κ ⋅ ( γ 1 r 1 − γ 2 * r 2 ) − i κ 2 2 k [ γ 2 B ( ξ ) − γ 2 * L ( 1 − ξ ) ] d 2 κ ξ + 2 π k 2 L ∫ 0 1 ∫ ∫ − ∞ ∞ Φ n ( κ , ξ ) e x p i κ ⋅ ( γ 2 r 1 − γ 1 * r 2 ) − i κ 2 2 k [ γ 2 ( 1 − ξ ) − γ 1 * B * ( ξ ) ] d 2 κ ξ (23) E 3 r 1 , r 2 = − 2 π k 2 L ∫ 0 1 ∫ ∫ − ∞ ∞ Φ n κ , ξ exp i γ 1 κ ⋅ r 1 − r 2 − i κ 2 k γ 1 B ξ d 2 κ d ξ − 2 π k 2 L ∫ 0 1 ∫ ∫ − ∞ ∞ Φ n κ , ξ exp i γ 2 κ ⋅ r 1 − r 2 − i κ 2 k γ 2 L 1 − ξ d 2 κ d ξ − 2 π k 2 L ∫ 0 1 ∫ ∫ − ∞ ∞ Φ n κ , ξ exp i κ ⋅ γ 1 r 1 − γ 2 r 2 − i κ 2 2 k γ 1 B ξ + γ 2 L 1 − ξ d 2 κ d ξ − 2 π k 2 L ∫ 0 1 ∫ ∫ − ∞ ∞ Φ n κ , ξ exp i κ ⋅ γ 2 r 1 − γ 1 r 2 − i κ 2 2 k γ 2 L 1 − ξ + γ 1 B ξ d 2 κ d ξ As the wave propagates forward and backward through the same path, phase fluctuations caused by turbulence are also correlated, meaning that the integral terms in Eq. (15) are correlated. The statistical moments E 2 r 1 , r 2 and E 3 r 1 , r 2 both contain four terms, the first two terms of which are the self-correlations of the forward and backward propagation and the last two terms are the cross-correlation of the forward and backward propagation. In most applications the atmospheric turbulence can be considered as isotropic, Φ n κ , ξ does not depend on the direction. Eqs. (10), (22) and (23) are integrated on the variable for direction, leading to (24) E 1 0 , 0 = − 4 π 2 k 2 L ∫ 0 1 ∫ 0 ∞ Φ n κ , ξ d κ d ξ (25) E 2 r 1 , r 2 = 4 π 2 k 2 L ∫ 0 1 ∫ 0 ∞ κ Φ n κ , ξ exp − i κ 2 2 k γ 1 B ξ − γ 1 * B * ξ J 0 κ ⋅ γ 1 r 1 − γ 1 * r 2 d κ d ξ + 4 π 2 k 2 L ∫ 0 1 ∫ 0 ∞ κ Φ n κ , ξ exp − i κ 2 2 k γ 2 − γ 2 * 1 − ξ J 0 κ ⋅ γ 2 r 1 − γ 2 * r 2 d κ d ξ + 4 π 2 k 2 L ∫ 0 1 ∫ 0 ∞ κ Φ n κ , ξ exp − i κ 2 2 k γ 1 B ξ − γ 2 * L 1 − ξ J 0 κ ⋅ γ 1 r 1 − γ 2 * r 2 d κ d ξ + 4 π 2 k 2 L ∫ 0 1 ∫ 0 ∞ κ Φ n κ , ξ exp − i κ 2 2 k γ 2 1 − ξ − γ 1 * B * ξ J 0 κ ⋅ γ 2 r 1 − γ 1 * r 2 d κ d ξ (26) E 3 r 1 , r 2 = − 4 π 2 k 2 L ∫ 0 1 ∫ 0 ∞ κ Φ n κ , ξ exp − i κ 2 k γ 1 B ξ J 0 γ 1 κ ⋅ r 1 − r 2 d κ d ξ − 4 π 2 k 2 L ∫ 0 1 ∫ 0 ∞ κ Φ n κ , ξ exp − i κ 2 k γ 2 1 − ξ J 0 γ 2 κ ⋅ r 1 − r 2 d κ d ξ − 4 π 2 k 2 L ∫ 0 1 ∫ 0 ∞ κ Φ n κ , ξ exp − i κ 2 2 k γ 1 B ξ + γ 2 L 1 − ξ J 0 κ ⋅ γ 1 r 1 − γ 2 r 2 d κ d ξ − 4 π 2 k 2 L ∫ 0 1 ∫ 0 ∞ κ Φ n κ , ξ exp − i κ 2 2 k γ 2 1 − ξ + γ 1 B ξ J 0 κ ⋅ γ 2 r 1 − γ 1 r 2 d κ d ξ In this paper, the propagating path in turbulence is set as horizontal and normal to the optical surface of the finite reflector with a size parameter Ω R = 2 L / k W R 2 . Atmospheric turbulence is characterized by von Karman spectrum with structure constant C n 2 = 2.46 × 10 − 15 m − 2 / 3 , outer scale L 0 = 10 m and inner scale l 0 = 1 cm . The wavelength is chosen as λ = 1.38 μm , the wave type may be plane, spherical or collimated Gaussian beams with beam parameter Ω = 2 L / k W 0 2 . Eqs. (24–26) are numerically computed and further several statistical moments of interest are expressed in terms of the basic moments. 4 Spatial coherence properties Spatial coherence property is an important second-order statistical moment, which directly reflects the degree of distortion of the reflected field. The Degree of Coherence is defined as (27) γ r 1 , r 2 , 2 L = Γ 2 r 1 , r 2 , 2 L I r 1 , 2 L I r 2 , 2 L 1 / 2 = exp E 2 r 1 , r 2 − 1 2 E 2 r 1 , r 1 − 1 2 E 2 r 2 , r 2 Since r 1 and r 2 are two arbitrary points on the receiving plane, it is difficult to obverse the pattern of Degree of Coherence, a limit is usually set as r 1 = − r 2 and the function γ can then be written as (28) γ r 1 , − r 1 , 2 L = γ ρ , 2 L = exp E 2 r 1 , − r 1 − E 2 r 1 , r 1 where ρ = r 1 − r 2 = 2 r 1 . Fig. 3 shows the Degree of Coherence versus the separation distance, it can be seen that the backscatter amplification effect also influences the spatial coherence of the reflected field. The retro-reflector increases the Degree of Coherence whereas the mirror decrease it, which means that field reflected by a retro-reflector is less distorted by turbulence. The coherence length is introduced to reflect the falling speed of the Degree of Coherence, which can be obtained when γ ρ 0 , 2 L = e − 1 . Fig. 4 shows the coherence lengths normalized by ρ P versus the parameter Ω R , where ρ P is the plane wave coherence length, ρ P = 1.46 C n 2 k 2 L − 3 / 5 . For a large reflector, the coherence length of backscattered wave from a mirror is the lowest in all cases and on the contrary that for a retro-reflector is the highest, and for a small reflector, the situation is inversed. The point of transition is where the amplification effect for reflected wave from a mirror becomes zero. However, the tendency of coherence length for a retro-reflector seems to be different, ρ 0 for reflected wave from a large retro-reflector is larger than that from a small retro-reflector. In fact, further calculation shows that coherence length of plane wave from an infinite large retro-reflector is infinite, which cannot be true. It can be found in the case of a plane wave reflected by an infinite retro-reflector the two rays propagating through r 1 and r 2 = − r 1 propagates through the same paths in opposite directions, so field at the two symmetrical points remain highly coherent. Therefore, γ r 1 , − r 1 , 2 L can not reflect the real distribution of spatial coherence. Another limit for the separation points is introduced to calculate the coherence length for the retro-reflector case, r 2 = 0 . The results are shown in Figs. 5 and 6 . The curve of coherence length varying with Ω R is similar to the one in Fig. 4 for a mirror but higher than the latter. The curves of coherence length are mainly increasing with the increase of Ω , except for the coherence length of wave from a point which does not change with Ω . 5 Scintillation index In practical applications, for example a lidar system, scintillation index is an important factor that influences the performance of the system. Calculating the scintillation index of the backscattered wave from different targets in atmospheric turbulence is of great significance. Scintillation index can be expressed with the basic statistical moments (29) σ I 2 r , 2 L ≅ 2 Re E 2 r , r + E 3 r , r Fig. 7 presents the curves of on-axis scintillation index with L , including both the theoretical and simulated results. The simulated curves and the theoretical ones agree well when L is small, and diverge as L gets very large. Fig. 8 shows the curves of on-axis scintillation index with Ω R and Fig. 9 shows the curves of on-axis scintillation index with Ω . Calculation shows that on-axis scintillation index in the cases of a mirror and retro-reflector are the same, so the curves are for both mirror and retro-reflector. The curves in the figures are all V-shaped, which means that the minimum σ I 2 0 , 2 L occurs in the case that the size of reflector is a little smaller than the first Frensel zone Ω R = 2 ∼ 3 and the width of beam is similar as the first Frensel zone Ω = 1 ∼ 2 . The left side of each curve are higher than the right side, meaning that a small reflector ( Ω R ≪ 1 ) causes less scintillation than a big one ( Ω R ≫ 1 ) does, and a narrow beam Ω ≪ 1 products less scintillation than a wide one ( Ω ≫ 1 ) does. For limited inner and outer scales, the scintillations indexes become smaller. The inner scale influences the scintillation index much whereas the outer scale influences it little, which is different from the cases of mean intensity and the coherence length. Amplification effect also influences the scintillation index, similar as the intensity amplification factor, the scintillation amplification factor is defined as (30) N s r = σ I 2 r , 2 L / σ I 2 r , 2 L i n c o h (31) σ I 2 r , 2 L i n c o h ≅ 2 Re E 2 r , r + E 3 , i n c o h r , r where E 3 , i n c o h r , r is the sum of the first two terms in Eq. (26). Fig. 10 shows the on-axis scintillation amplification factor N s 0 . It is mainly Ω that influences N s 0 whereas the size of reflector has little effect on N s 0 especially for narrow beams Ω > 10 . The scintillation amplification factor of plane wave is around 1.5 while that of spherical wave is exactly 2.0. It can be found that the limited inner and outer scales slightly increase N s 0 for a limited reflector whereas for a spherical wave the inner and outer scales have no effects on N s 0 . Fig. 11 shows the scintillation amplification factor at the receiving plane as a function of the normalized transverse distance from the optical axis in different cases. For a plane wave reflected by a infinite mirror, the amplification effect exists on the whole receiving plane as a constant, for other kind of wave reflected by a mirror, the amplification effect reduces slowly as the transverse distance gets bigger. For a wave reflected by a retro-reflector, the amplification effect reduces much faster as the transverse increases. Another difference from the case of mirror is that as the transverse increases the amplification effect for a retro-reflector may become negative. 6 Conclusion Under the assumption of the weak scintillation theory and within the framework of a rotationally symmetric complex ABCD paraxial optical system, analytical expressions are derived for the basic statistical moments for the reflected wave from a retro-reflector. Some statistical moments, including mean irradiance, degree of coherence and scintillation index, are obtained in terms of the basic moments. Amplification effect related to these moments is discussed in the paper. The calculated results show that the reflected wave from a retro-reflector has a higher intensity and a bigger intensity amplification factor than that for a plane mirror. And the coherence length of the retro-reflected wave is larger than that of the mirror-reflected wave. As the scintillation index is concerned, the reflected wave from a retro-reflector is the same as that from a mirror on the optical axis but lower at other position on the receiving plane. In a word, the reflected wave from a retro-reflector has a better property than that from a mirror in every way. The properties of the reflected field are mainly discussed as function of the reflector size parameter Ω R and the beam width parameter Ω . Variations mainly happen near the first Frensel zone ( 0.1 < Ω R < 10 , 0.1 < Ω < 10 ), for example, that the extreme value of the scintillation index amplification factor occurs when Ω R ≃ 1 and Ω ≃ 1 . It can be seen that the phase perturbation in Eq. (13) is just the first-order complex phase perturbation associated with the folded-path integrals, and the final forms of E 2 r 1 , r 2 and E 3 r 1 , r 2 are equivalent to the ones in reference [13], which also proves the validity of our derivation. However, derivation in this paper is much easier to understand and is more consistent with the method used in the case of mirror reflection. Acknowledgments This paper is supported by Scientific Research Program for Key Laboratory Funded by Shaanxi Provincial Education Department (Grant No. 16JS040) and National Natural Science Foundation of China (Grant No. 11504286).

column2: Comparative research on characteristics of light absorbers of metal-dielectric and metal photonic crystal transmission grating
column3: Abstract Using nanofabricated Si3N4 nanohole array photonic crystal grating, an Au metal-dielectric resonance grating by spin-coating Au on the Si3N4 nanohole array photonic crystal grating is investigated. Optical properties and related characteristics of metal-dielectric grating light absorber and meal grating light absorber are compared and analyzed. We simulate transmittances corresponding to different grating periods of the metal-dielectric photonic crystal transmission grating in visible-infrared light region and display electric field distributions in the vicinity of nanoholes at different incident wavelengths by using finite-difference time-domain (FDTD) software with broadband light source 400 nm–1100 nm.The mechanism of absorption generation in the metal-dielectric and metal transmission grating is analyzed and discussed in this paper. The Au structure of metal photonic crystal transmission grating is also investigated for light absorber. The metal-dielectric photonic crystal transmission grating structure absorbs more than 90% of the incident light at absorption point wavelength.
column5: Keywords Absorber FDTD Transmission Surface Plasmon resonance Electric field distribution 1 Introduction In 1902, R. W. Wood observed anomalous absorption in metal structure [1]. Then, related researches about light absorption in structured metal arise gradually in 1960s, 1970s and 1990s [2–4]. Recently, a multiplexed metal structure light absorber based on the two different size gold square in each unit cell has been proposed [5]. The principle of absorbers and filters in this paper is the excitation of surface Plasmon polaritons [8]. When light is incident to the interface of metal and dielectric, free electrons distributed on the metal surface will be excited and generate oscillation, which results to form surface Plasmas. Large photon energy are transformed to free electrons’ oscillation energy due to electronic oscillation generated on the metal surface and the energy of reflectivity declines sharply, which results to strong absorption of incident light power. However, it is rare to propose the transmitted device as an absorber that can absorb optical frequency electromagnetic wave. In many applications, optical absorber has a good prospect that it can be applied in areas such as solar cell, sensor, optical filter, optical waveguide, THz imager and thermal radiation detection [9–14]. Compared with the traditional absorbers, the characteristic of this structure is transmission grating rather than reflective grating. In this letter, the relationship between wavelength and transmission of the two structures and each electronic field distribution is investigated respectively. Transmittance of this structure is approximately close to zero at a certain wavelength in the range of 600 nm–900 nm, which means light power can be absorbed completely when light is incident through the transmission grating at a certain wavelength. Electric field distribution is simulated to discuss the absorption generation. The intensity of electric field at absorption wavelength in transmission grating is much lower than other wavelength because there is no resonance existing so that much light is reflected and rare light is transmitted. The peak transmission is caused by surface Plasmon resonance. We compare and analyze optical characteristics of the light absorber of metal-dielectric photonic crystal transmission grating and the light absorber of Au nanohole array transmission grating under the incident light source in visible-infrared region. 2 Methods and calculation The range of incident light wavelength is set as 400–1100 nm due to both of two photonic crystal grating investigation going under visible-infrared light region. Fig. 1 (a) shows the light absorber structure of metal-dielectric photonic crystal transmission grating. The device is made of a nanohole array grating etched through a gold film and a silicon nitride film deposited on a glass substrate. The diameter of the nanoholes is 240 nm. The thickness of silicon nitride is 250 nm and the thickness of gold film is 60 nm [5]. We choose nanohole grating to be convenient for observing obvious surface Plasmon resonance phenomenon by observing the intensity of electronic field. We take a series of examples of different periods of nanohole arrays such as 250 nm, 300 nm, 400 nm, 500 nm, 600 nm respectively, which is suitable for light diffraction. Columns of nanoholes are corresponding to grating lines that provide angular dispersion and diffraction for measuring the resonance spectra of the device. Fig. 1(b) shows structure of metal (Au) nanohole array transmission grating. The gold film thickness, nanoholes’ size, period of nanoholes arrangement and the change of period is the same as the structure of Fig. 1(a) for comparison convenience. Difference of 1(a) and 1(b) is whether silicon nitride layer exists or not. Both of these two fabrications can be accomplished by electron beam lithography. We use finite-difference time domain (FDTD) software (Lumerical Solutions, Inc.) to simulate and calculate the two structures. Designed light absorber of metal-dielectric photonic crystal transmission grating and Au nanohole array transmission grating is both in the visible and near-infrared wave region. A Johnson-Christy material model based on measurement data is used for the electric permittivity of the gold film [6]. The optical constant of the magnesium fluoride is obtained from [7]. The condition boundary is set as periodic boundary conditions in the lateral direction. In the directions of propagation and transmission, the simulation domain is terminated with perfect matching layers. The incident light is normal incidence from the glass substrate into the device with a broadband light source 400 nm–1100 nm. Fig. 2 shows the calculated power transmittance of metal dielectric structure with different grating periods. Fig. 3 shows the transmittance in Au nanohole array transmission grating structure with periods of 250 nm, 300 nm, 400 nm, 500 nm, 600 nm. In Fig. 2, it’s clearly that the whole transmittance in the nanohole period of 500 nm or 600 nm is obviously lower than the transmittance in the period of 250 nm, 300 nm, 400 nm. There is a peak value and minimum value in every curve. It can be seen that the transmittance minimum value is found at the region of wavelength 600–800 nm. The total trend of transmission is lower. We calculate the minimum value of transmittance is 0.2855 at 602.02 nm, 0.0876 at 642.242 nm, 0.0085 at 804.04 nm, 0.0075 at 783.838 nm and 0.0017 at 682.828 nm corresponding to the grating periods of 250 nm, 300 nm, 400 nm, 500 nm and 600 nm respectively. These values of absorption points are very close to 0 which means rare of light pass through the grating because most of light is reflected at absorption. Most of light pass through the grating because reflectivity is too small caused by surface Plasmon resonance to maximize the transmittance resulting to peak value. In general, the wavelength of light absorption point moves towards longer wavelength because of the lowest point of transmittance towards to longer wavelength. Especially, the transmittance decreases and the lowest point of transmission becomes smaller when the period of grating increases. Metal-dielectric grating structure absorbs more than 90% of incident light at the absorption point. Fig. 3 shows the transmittance in Au nanohole array transmission grating structure with periods of 250 nm, 300 nm, 400 nm, 500 nm, 600 nm. From this picture, the wavelength of light absorption point moves towards to longer wavelength. Compared to Fig. 2, the lowest point of transmittance in metal grating structure is higher than the metal-dielectric grating structure, which means metal grating structure absorbs less light than metal-dielectric. The lowest transmittance point with period of 250 nm, 300 nm, 400 nm, 500 nm, 600 nm is 0.3021, 0.2096, 0.0127, 0.0017and 0.0012 respectively corresponding to the wavelength of 626.913 nm, 610.797 nm, 680.802 nm, 783.838 nm, 935.433 nm respectively. We calculate the electric field intensity distribution in the middle plane over the nanohole Au layer (20 nm above the surface of gold metal layer) in the unit cell of the metal-dielectric absorber structure with the a certain grating period. We take the lowest total transmittance curve of period 500 nm as an example. Fig. 4 (a) shows the electric field intensity distribution calculated with the light wavelength of 643 nm, a peak wavelength in the visible wavelength region of the wide absorption band. It can be seen that the center of the hole exhibits local field enhancement and electric field interference between holes. The surface Plasmon resonance generates on the metal. Fig. 4(b) shows the electric field intensity distribution at the wavelength of 783 nm—the absorption point wavelength. The electric field intensity of center of hole is weaker than Fig. 4(a). The electric field intensity distribution in Fig. 4 shows clearly that the Plasmon resonance mode in the structure of Fig. 4(a). The electric field intensity distribution in the middle plane over the nanohole Au layer (20 nm above the surface of gold metal layer) in the unit cell of the gold metal absorber structure with the period of 500 nm is also calculated. Fig. 5 (a), (b) shows the electric field intensity distribution calculated at wavelength of 700 nm (peak point), 794 nm (absorption point) respectively. Compared with Fig. 3, the electric field at absorption point is weak in nanoholes and the electric field at peak point exhibits good surface Plasmon resonance and local field enhancement. 3 Discussion and analysis In this paper, we simulate two structures of grating as light absorber by analyzing their transmittance and both of two optical characteristics are researched respectively. For exploring the relationship between optical property and different periods of nanohole array grating lines, transmittances under different periods of the two grating is measured. The transmittance in the nanohole photonic transmission grating generates a minimum transmittance at a certain wavelength closed to 0 resulting to the light absorber could be made. The transmittance in different periods of nanohole grating lines is various. In Fig. 2, transmittance in both structures keeps a tendency of reduction and the minimum of transmission is lower with the increasing of periods. The reason why transmittance is decreasing with increasing of periods is not clearly explained in recent year researches, but it is related with the depth of nanoholes according [15]. Especially when the grating period is 500 nm, the transmittance in whole wavelength 400–1100 nm keeps low related to the metal and dielectric material properties. As it is seen that absorption at certain wavelengths clearly improves with longer grating, which we can infer that the performance of light absorber is better with the increasing of grating period. It is significant for light absorber or filter fabrication. The reason why it appears is inferred that the reflectivity of light incident onto the interface of metal and dielectric increases due to the unit cell area of light touching increasing for distance between each nanoholes grating line increasing, which result to transmittance decreases. There is always existing transmittance peak in every curve of Figs. 2 and 3 because of surface Plasmon resonance and their peak value also moves to longer wavelength just like the adsorption point. It is beneficial for fabricating different certain wavelength light absorber or opical filter. The electric field distribution can express the reason of adsorption point generation. Peak wavelength is in the frequency range of surface Plasmon polaritons so that photon power is absorbed completely caused by surface Plasmon resonance and the reflectivity is almost eliminated. Compared with Figs. 4 and 5 respectively, the center electric field intensity of (a) exhibit strong local field enhancement in the hole, it means surface Plasmon resonance occurs at peak points. The position where surface Plasmon resonance generates is on the interface of metal and dielectric. In Figs. 4(b) and Fig. 5(b), electric field intensity of absorption point at the center of nanoholes of transmission grating structure exhibit week electric field. We infer that reflection is strong at adsorption wavelength resulting to light transmission declining sharply and adsorption wavelength frequency is far away from frequency of surface Plasmon polaritons so that no surface Plasmon resonance generates in the nanoholes. These values of absorption points in transmittance picture are very close to 0 which means most of light is absorbed by the device and rare light can be transmitted. Compared with metal-dielectric photonic crystal transmission grating and Au metal nanohole transmission grating, the integral transmittance of gold metal structure is higher than metal-dielectric structure including the absorption wavelength point. Metal-dielectric grating structure absorbs more than 90% of incident light compared with gold metal grating structure. The metal-dielectric nanohole photonic crystal transmission grating is more suitable than Au metal nanohole transmission grating for being applied in light absorber and optical filter. 4 Conclusion In summary, using FDTD software, we have calculated the transmittance of the light absorber structure of metal-dielectric photonic crystal transmission grating and a light absorber structure of Au metal nanohole transmission grating verse grating period in the visible-infrared light region. The electric field intensity distribution of the two structures under a certain wavelength with the grating period of 500 nm is analyzed combined with optical characteristic transmission. The advantage of metal-dielectric nanohole photonic crystal grating is obvious compared with Au nanohole photonic crystal grating. The integral transmittance of gold metal structure is higher than metal-dielectric structure including the absorption wavelength point. Metal-dielectric grating structure absorbs more than 90% of incident light compared with gold metal grating structure. The demonstrated light absorber of metal-dielectric photonic crystal transmission grating can be applied for future applications in enhanced optical sensing and imaging. Acknowledgements Thanks Meishan Wang of school of Information and Electrical Engineering, Ludong University for firs principle calculations. This work was supported by the National Natural Science Foundation of China with Grant Nos. 61308089 and 6144005, Public Technology Applied Research Project of Zhejiang Province (No. 2013C31068).
