column2: Global calibration of non-overlapping cameras: State of the art
column3: Abstract Multi-camera vision systems (MVS) have a larger field of view than a single camera and are often applied to acquire geometric information of large-scale objects or scenes. Data integration from multiple cameras is a very important part for vision systems which is usually solved by using a global calibration method. After installing the MVS, in some cases, cameras do not have a common field of view (CFV) or only a narrow CFV. Accurate global calibration of cameras with non-overlapping field of view (FOV) is a very challenging task. A variety of global calibration of non-overlapping multi-camera methods (GCNM) have been proposed to estimate the relative positions and orientations of cameras based on different types of media or techniques such as large-range measuring devices, large-scale calibration targets, optical mirrors, motion model, laser projection, visual measuring instruments, etc. However, the GCNM is not yet a completely solved problem. Choosing which type of GCNM method to use is highly dependent on the specific vision system. Thus, in this paper, we present a comparative review of different GCNM methods and analyze accuracy, range, defects, and applications. Researchers and developers can take it as background information for their future works.
column5: Keywords Global calibration Multi-camera vision systems Non-overlapping FOV 1 Introduction The visual system has the characteristics of non-contactness, rapid acquisition, high flexibility and high precision, so is widely used in various fields. The multi-camera vision system (MVS) is often used because it has larger measurement range than a single sensor. Camera calibration is an important task in 3D computer vision, especially when metric informations are required for applications involving accurate dimensional measurements. The global calibration of MVS is carried out to calculate the relative poses of the camera frames and the global coordinate frame (GCF). The measurement accuracy of MVS, as one of the most important technical indices, is directly influenced by the global calibration accuracy. In many applications of MVS, vision sensors may have no common FOV because some tasks require different cameras should shoot different parts of the object. As two adjacent cameras usually have no overlapping FOV or only a very small common FOV, the global calibration of MVS becomes an intractable problem. Most of the global calibration methods in the literatures are designed to calibrate the cameras with a common field of view. These methods rely on matching features in all sensor FOVs, which are not suitable for solving the case of non-overlapping FOVs. In order to overcome the limitations of non-overlapping FOV, many methods have been developed in recent years. Most of the non-overlapping FOV global calibration methods can be divided into 6 categories. • The first is based on large-range measuring devices; • The second is based on large-scale calibration targets; • The third is based on optical mirrors; • The fourth is based on the motion model; • The fifth is based on laser projection; • The seventh is based on visual measuring instruments. The rest of the paper is organized as follows: Section 2 resumes the fundamentals of global calibration with non-overlapping views, and reviews a wide range of global calibration methods, Section 3 performs a comparative analysis according to the application requirements and discusses advantages and disadvantages, and finally, main conclusions are found in Section 4. 2 Methods of global calibration for non-overlapping cameras In most large-scale vision systems, a single camera can hardly cover all objects to be measured. Multiple cameras have the advantage of covering larger range. However, in MVS, it often happens that cameras have no common FOV. For example, as shown in Fig. 1 , four cameras are used to set up a vision system where there is no common FOV between every two cameras. Calibration of the system consist of two parts, firstly, intrinsic parameters of every camera need to be calibrated. A highly flexible technique to easily calibrate a camera has been proposed by Zhang [107] and widely used in various vision tasks. Secondly, the relative position parameters between different cameras should be calibrated accurately, which is the main purpose of global calibration. Theoretically, each camera's coordinate system needs to be transformed into the world coordinate system O w X w Y w Z w . In practical applications, one of the cameras (such as camera 2 as shown in Fig. 1) can be chosen as the basis of other cameras, after calculating the relative position of the other cameras relative to the base camera in the MVS, the position of each camera can be located. This is achieved by calculating the translation matrix T c i c 2 and the rotation matrix R c i c 2 . Eventually, the measurement data from each camera is fused to a common coordinate system. 2.1 Methods based on large-range measuring devices In order to ensure the accuracy of the global calibration, a high-precision measuring device can be adopted [7–11,13,108,109]. The most common large-range measuring devices are theodolites, laser trackers, and laser range finder. Lu and Li [8] develop a high precision global calibration method for large-scale visual measurement system using two theodolites. This method places a calibration target into the field of view of a camera, uses a theodolite coordinate measurement system (TCMS) to measure the 3D coordinates of the markers on the calibration target, and then calculates the positional relationship between the calibration target and the camera, and resolves the transformation matrix between the camera and TCMS. Lu used the visual system for straightness measurement of seamless steel tubes. The measurement test showed that the system could achieve a measurement accuracy of 0.06 mm in the range of 1500 mm. Another global calibration method is the use of laser tracker which has a higher accuracy and can replace the theodolite in many cases. Zhao et al. [108] described a global calibration method based on laser tracker. If the corresponding relationship between the 3D coordinates and the image points of all spots on a calibration board is known, the pose of the camera relative to the laser tracker can be resolved. The method achieves the measurement accuracy of 0.45 mm in the 8000 mm × 6000 mm working range. Kitahara et al. [7] presented a camera calibration technique for a large-scale space, such as a soccer stadium. Because there is not an enough large calibration board to cover the entire measurement space, they solved this global calibration problem by moving a calibration board to cover the whole area of the 3D space. Each position of the calibration board can be sensed by laser tracker and cameras simultaneously. Kitahara’s method provides a measurement error of less than 0.1 mm in large-scale space (e.g. 70m × 50 m with 25 m height). Laser range finder (LRF) is another high-precision measuring equipment for large-scale measurements. Liu et al. [10] proposed an external parameter calibration method for multiple cameras based on this device. The cameras capture the laser spots projected on the planar object and the LRF measures the distances between the different spots. The external parameters between different cameras can be computed according to the co-linearity of the laser spots captured by all the cameras at each LRF position and the distances between the laser spots. To solve the problem of non-overlapped views, the calibration of all the cameras can be achieved by pair-wise calibration. Liu’s method can method can achieve 0.3‰ relative error when the distance between the two cameras is around four meters. The method does not need any expensive high-precision 3D measurement equipment and high accuracy target, except a LRF and a planar object. It is simple to carry out and can achieve high accuracy, but this method will still be subject to certain light effects. Ortega et al. [11] presented a method of calibrating an outdoor distributed camera network having small or inexistent overlapping fields of view using LRF data. This method relies on a LRF data acquired and registered along the complete area of the network using SLAM methodologies. The method has a large measurement range and can be applied in person and robot detection localization, but has a lack of deeper evaluation of the precision and accuracy. With large-range devices such as theodolites, laser trackers, and LRF, 3D points of a plurality of calibration targets in a non-overlapping field of view can be easily obtained. Then the global calibration methods with high accuracy can be developed and already used in industrial visual inspection system. 2.2 Methods based on large-scale targets A calibration target is a workpiece with high precision and can be used for feature extraction and precision verification in camera calibration [14,15,19–21,23,25–28,32,81]. Planar calibration target is the most widely used calibration target, whose plane consistency is good, and features are easy to extract. Liu et al. [21] proposed a method to calibrate the vision system with non-overlapping field of view using a compound target consisting of two planar calibration targets which are fixed together, as shown in Fig. 2 . One vision sensor from MVS is selected as the global coordinate frame (GCF). The compound target is placed in front of the vision sensors for several (at least four) times. Using the constraint that the relative positions of all sub-targets are invariant, the transformation matrix from the coordinate frame of each vision sensor to GCF can be solved. The method does not require any high-precision 3D measurement device and shows that the RMS error of eight point pairs is 0.15 mm. This method has a high flexibility and can be applied to a variety of measurement environments. However, since the distance between the cameras is greater than the field of view of each camera, the pose change of the calibration target can not be too large so that the camera can view the corresponding sub-target, which results in instability of the calibration results. What is more, calibration images are also prone to defocusing. 1D target has the advantage of simple structure, light and portable. It can be manufactured to a large length, much larger than the size of 2D target. It has no occlusion, thus can be easily captured by multiple vision sensors. It is suitable for the calibration of MVS distributed in both large and small measurement fields [16,22,28,33]. Liu et al. [14] proposed a global calibration method for cameras with non-overlapping field of view based on 1D targets. The rotation matrix between adjacent cameras can be solved based on the collinearity of the feature points on the 1D target. The translation vector can be calculated according to the known distance of the feature points on the 1D target. The transformation from the coordinate frame of each vision sensor to a global coordinate frame can be obtained by repeating the pair-wise calibration on different pair of vision sensors. RMS error of this method is within 0.060 mm. Franca et al. [17] also used 1D target for global calibration. The cameras are divided into binocular sets. The fundamental matrix of each binocular set is then estimated, allowing to perform a projective calibration of each camera. Then, the calibration is updated for the Euclidean space. In order to achieve high accuracy, the length of the 1D target should be proportional to the distance between the sensors. With the number of images more than 50, the error obtained in the estimation of the intrinsic and extrinsic camera parameters was around 0.5%. The non-absolute linearity of the 1D target and the extraction error of the calibration point will affect the overall calibration accuracy. In order to solve the problem of non-overlapping fields of view, 1D targets can be connected for global calibration. Xie et al. [27] proposed a method to calibrate the relative position and orientation relationship between two cameras with non-overlapping field of view. Firstly a rough estimation of the relative pose of the two cameras was given using the invariant constraints on the angle and distance between two short 1D bars, then changing the distances between light spots on the two 1D bars respectively to refine the estimation of the relative pose parameters and the structure parameter of the targets. The experimental calibration shows that the system calibrated by this method reaches an accuracy of 0.108 mm when measuring a distance section of 1040 mm. This method provides a flexibility and tight space advantage compared to other calibration methods. If there are more cameras, only two cameras can be calibrated at a time, which makes the calibration method complicated to be realized. 2.3 Methods based on optical mirrors Mirror-based method has been successfully used for the calibration of extrinsic parameters by using the reflection characteristics of the optical mirror [12,34–52,83]. This method overcomes the limitation that all cameras must observe the common target directly and allows the camera to observe the target indirectly through the mirror. Sturm and Bonfort et al. [36] used a plane mirror to estimate the target's pose with respect to the camera for the case where the camera has no direct view of the object. The views of the reflected object are treated as if they were direct views. The method computes a camera pose from the camera’s calibration and the given point correspondences, and then gets the pose of virtual cameras relative to the object, followed by estimating the positions of the planar mirrors. The result shows that the approximate diameter of the reconstructed part of the platter was 80 mm, resulting in a 0.3% relative error in the reconstruction. Robot pose estimation plays an important role in robot vision system with non-overlapped views. Transformation between a camera and the body of the robot need to be calibrated. Hesch et al. [37] proposed a method of estimating the six-degrees-of-freedom transformation between a camera and the body of the robot. The method requires calibration between a camera and robot body using planar mirror. The robot maneuvers in front of a planar mirror, allowing the camera to observe fiducial features on the robot from several vantage points. The measurements collected are processed in a maximum-likelihood estimator, which produces estimates for the camera-to-robot transformation, as well as for the mirror configuration in each of the images. One of the key advantages of the method is its ease of use. But this method requires that the coordinates of the points on the robot-body frame must be known a priori. Lebraly et al. [39] proposed a calibration method for two non-overlapping cameras embedded on a vehicle, for visual navigation purpose in urban environment. The method does not require knowing the scene geometry and uses visual markers stuck on the mirror surface in order to initialize nonlinear equations. After the minimization, the standard deviation of re-projection error is 0.14 pixel. These results are satisfying for mobile robot applications. Xu et al. [40] used planar calibration plates and planar mirrors to calibrate a system consisting of four non-overlapping field-of-view cameras. The proposed method involves calibrating the intrinsic and extrinsic parameters, solving a set of transformation relationships between the other cameras, including the mirrored virtual camera, and the global central camera chosen. Through global calibration by this method, a displacement of 1100 mm by a high-accuracy motor-driven moving platform is measured, with the standard deviation 0.074 mm. Agrawal et al. [42] proposed a method of external parameter calibration based on a single reflection of a spherical mirror whose radius is known. The position of the spherical mirror and the external parameters can be solved at the same time. The method does not require knowing the position of the spherical mirror and that the boundary of the spherical mirror is visible in the image, simply by using the projection of the 3D reference point. Therefore, the method is simple and practical. Note that the 2D projections are confined to a significantly smaller pixel area for the spherical mirror, which may affect the calibration results to some extent. For small systems with a small number of cameras, the mirror-based approach is relatively simple to use. But for large-scale measurement systems, this method faces some challenges. First, as the distance from the camera increases, the image of the reference object becomes smaller, resulting in a decrease in accuracy. Second, the placement of the mirror is a problem often overlooked, and sometimes theoretically it is difficult to ensure that multiple cameras can, directly and indirectly, observe the target. 2.4 Methods based on structure from motion (SFM) SFM has been used to calibrate multiple cameras [53–73]. This method tracks the movement of people on the ground or other targets, to establish the corresponding relationship of different camera field of view. All motion-based methods are inspired by Caspi and Irani [53], and assume that the motion of the target can compensate for the lack of image correspondence points, with the exception of the use of target motions. Esquivel et al. [59] proposed a method for calibrating non-overlapping dual cameras based on the motion consistency of rigid links. This method uses two internally calibrated non-overlapping cameras to synchronously capture a sequence of images for calibration of the camera's external parameters. The method calculates the motion of the camera independently, and uses the similarity transformation to arrange all reconstructions. However, this method is not suitable for calibrating cameras that do not meet motion compliance requirements. Each camera captures an individual sequence which is afterwards processed by a SFM algorithm resulting in positions and orientations for each camera. The unknown relative transformations between the rigidly coupled cameras are estimated utilizing the rigidity constraint of the rig. Lébraly et al. [65] proposed a method for the calibration of non-overlapping cameras embedded on a vehicle, for visual navigation purpose in urban environment. The calibration procedure consists in manoeuvring the vehicle while each camera observes a static scene. Lébraly carried out a study of the singular motions and a specific bundle adjustment which both reconstructs the scene and calibrates the cameras. Solutions to handle the singular configurations, such as planar motions, are exposed. The method provides errors below 0.5 mm for the translation, and about 0.01° for the rotation. Anjum et al. [66] developed a method to estimate relative position of non-overlapping cameras. The method estimates the missing trajectory information in the unobserved areas of the multi-sensor configuration using both parametric and non-parametric algorithms. First, Kalman filtering is used to estimate the trajectories in the unobserved regions. Next, linear regression estimates the position of the target based upon the motion model generated from the measured positions in the field of view of each sensor. Finally, the relative orientation of the sensors is calculated using the observed and estimated target position from adjacent cameras. The performance of the algorithm was demonstrated on a set of real and synthetic data in networks of N = 3, N = 4 and N = 8 cameras. Their experiments showed that for a network of N = 4 non-overlapping sensors the average location estimation error is approximately 1% of the size of the scene and this error is further reduced to 0.75% for a N = 8 sensors network. Micusik et al. [71] solved a relative pose problem for non-overlapping surveillance cameras with known gravity vector. The method shows how to tackle the problem of missing point correspondences heavily required by SFM pipelines and how to go beyond this basic paradigm. The error of 0.38 m in center estimation and 5° in rotation for the method at the camera distance of 10m is obtained for the video surveillance. The above calibration methods based on structure from motion do not require a high-precision measuring device, so it is relatively inexpensive and flexible, and is often used for robot navigation, visual tracking, video surveillance, etc. These methods require scene information, which is difficult to obtain in industrial measurement, and accuracy still need to be improved. 2.5 Methods based on laser projection Laser projection method has a larger measurement range and is less affected by light, so often used in the global calibration method [74–80]. As the laser pointer is small, portable, distance measurement accuracy, methods based on the laser projection are suitable for non-overlapping field of view of the calibration parameters. Liu et al. [76] proposed a method for multi-vision system calibration on point laser projector. The field of view of a non-overlapping camera is realized by passing the laser beam through the field of view of different cameras, and the external parameters of the multi-camera are solved according to the fact that the spot of the same laser beam is collinear. The method shows that the point pair distance RMS error of the calibrated measurement system is about 1.2 mm with respect to 1.1 m measurement range. This method is simple, low cost for large-scale, off-site parameter calibration and it’s operable in narrow space environment. However, it is difficult to ensure that each camera captures high-quality planar targets and spot images. Zou et al. [77,78] installed a laser pointer on a calibration target, and proposed a method of calibrating a camera pointing toward and away from the camera. This method is suitable for factories and garages. As long as the laser can pass through, even a narrow space, this method can also be used. At the same time, this method is not sensitive to a variety of lighting conditions. However, it is difficult to ensure that the laser direct projection in the optical center. The method provides the standard deviation is about 1 cm, and the average reprojection error is 2.1 mm. Liu et al. [74] proposed a global calibration method using oblique light as the target. The proposed method utilizes pairs of skew laser lines, which are generated by a group of laser pointers, as the calibration objects. Each pair of skew laser lines provides a unique coordinate system in space which can be reconstructed in certain vision sensor’s coordinates. This method is more flexible, the camera with different perspectives can be calibrated, but it’s difficult in practice. Since it is necessary to project the laser line to the field of view of each camera, a large number of line lasers are required when the number of cameras is large. The method provides the angle difference is less than 0.02° and the baseline difference is less than 0.5 mm. Compared with the laser line, the laser plane provides more information, increases the accuracy of feature extraction, laser plane can cover more space, and it’s more flexible and suitable for field calibration. The method in reference [75] utilizes several light planes, which can be generated by a line laser projector or a rotary laser level, as the calibration objects. The fact that local light planes available in different cameras are identical in global coordinates is used to recover the geometries. It should be noted that this method assumes that the laser plane is absolutely flat, which is different from the actual situation. This method improves the former accuracy and provides angle difference is less than 0.01° and the baseline difference is less than 0.2 mm. 2.6 Methods based on visual measuring instruments If the spatial coordinates of multiple feature points and the internal parameters of the camera are known, the camera's external parameters can be solved by a single image captured by the camera. The spatial coordinates of the feature points can be obtained by using the technique of 3D reverse engineering. Thus, vision-based measurement devices such as close-range photogrammetry systems and hand-held scanners can be used for global calibration of non-overlapping cameras [87–90]. The close-range photogrammetry, one of the most important methods for modeling large-scale 3D objects and scenes, has served as a key solution to the extrinsic calibration of cameranet works. In the field of close-range photogrammetry, it is common to use easily identifiable encoded targets for multi-view matching of unordered image sets because there are seldom sufficient feature points on the surface of an object. Dong et al. [87] proposed a method for extrinsic calibration of a non-overlapping camera network based on close-range photogrammetry. As Fig. 3 shows, this method does not need to calibrate the target or camera. The method is carried out by reconstructing the three-dimensional coordinate points of the coded targets directly with a hand-held camera, and then calibrates the camera's internal parameters. Finally, each camera uses an image to calibrate the external parameters. The experimental results show that the method is simple and that the relative error for the 3D reconstruction is smaller than 0.003%, the relative errors of both rotation and translation are less than 0.066%, and the re-projection error is only 0.09 pixels. Bridal et al. [89] used a calibrator similar to the shape of the object to be measured, and then affixed enough reflective markings on it, and used the industrial close-range measurement method to obtain the 3D coordinates of these markers that are applied to the camera's global calibration. Results compared with the ATOS measurement show that the system can achieve 0.2 mm measurement accuracy, which indirectly proves that the global calibration accuracy of the system is high. Gong et al. [90] argued that it is important to find a suitable target for global calibration of non-overlapping multi-cameras. With the help of a hand-held scanner called REVscan that is a product of the Creaform company, the measured object can act directly as a calibrator without the need for additionally dedicated calibration targets. This method is very flexible and suitable for indoor or outdoor measurements. The experimental results show that the system achieves 0.1 mm measurement accuracy in the range of 1353 mm. Other works based on combined techniques are described in [91–106] to implement global calibration. 3 Discussion A comparison of calibration methods is presented in Table 1 in terms of accuracy, range, environmental influences, safety and economy. Some quantitative information is provided according to the referenced specific application. Methods based on large-range measuring device, large-scale calibration targets, and visual measuring instruments can provide acceptable accuracy under certain conditions for most applications. Many calibration methods need to be closer to the object as they have a short working distance except methods based on large-range measuring device and laser projection. Nowadays, many lightweight commercial instruments combined with these methods can also be used for global calibration. All methods are not dangerous for people, with the exception of some high power lasers that are not eye-safe. Table 2 compares advantages and disadvantages of the reviewed methods for global calibration. The calibration method based on a large-range of devices has a large operating range, enabling wide calibration of the cameras in wide-area distribution while maintaining high accuracy. However, due to the need for special devices such as laser trackers and theodolites, which are more expensive and relatively heavy, the cost of this method is particularly high and it is not convenient to move those devices. The method based on large-scale target is often used for global calibration because the method has the advantages of low cost and moderate precision. However, this method requires complex optimization algorithms and that multiple cameras can simultaneously capture multiple images of the target, and puts forward higher requirements for the design and placement of the target. The optical mirror-based calibration method requires only mirrors and calibration target, so the cost is not high. But the relatively small imaging area of calibration target in the mirror and the constrained placement of the target affect the accuracy of calibration. Calibration method based on structure from motion can work in long distance and does not require high-precision measurement device, so the cost is not high. But this method requires the support of the scene information, which is harsh for industrial measurements. In addition, the state of motion will influence the accuracy of calibration. Methods based on laser projection can provide moderate accuracy but are dangerous for people as some laser classes (high power) are not eye-safe. The method based on visual measuring instruments is a kind of great potential global calibration method because of its high precision and good flexibility. There are many commercial high-precision visual measuring instruments available, but the price of these instruments is not low. Table 3 summarizes the references of global calibration methods grouped by several kinds of applications. In the survey, main applications of global calibration are in the field of 3D reconstruction, visual track, parameter measurement and pose estimation. The global calibration method based on the large-range device is mainly used for the geometric parameter measurement of large objects because of the high precision and large measuring range. The global calibration method based on large-scale target has a good compromise in terms of cost and accuracy due to the need for simple auxiliary targets. Therefore, this method has a very wide range of applications, especially for geometric parameter measurement. The mirror-based global calibration method is also a less costly approach, more suitable for the visual systems where the distribution of the cameras is relatively sparse but the cameras changes greatly in orientation. The method based on structure from motion is rarely used for industrial measurement due to the lack of scene information support and low precision, but has a wide range of applications in visual tracking, pose estimation and robot navigation. The method based on laser projection can theoretically work in a large range, but it is difficult to obtain high calibration accuracy because the image quality of the spot or the light plane decays as the work distance increases. Therefore, this method is more often used for visual tracking tasks, or applied to some tasks of the parameters measurement where accuracy requirements are not considered first. The method based on the visual measuring instrument can reconstruct the three-dimensional model of arbitrary target according to the distribution of cameras. Thus, no matter how complicated the structure of the MVS is, it is theoretically possible to construct a stereoscopic target whose shape is close to the object to be measured. This method demonstrates very good adaptability and is a global calibration solution with great potential for application. In fact, many 3D vision techniques can be used for global calibration. Wilson [105] reviews 3D vision techniques and solutions in a literature with commercial purposes providing a list of applications and manufacturers. Sets of questions and advises are presented in [106] in order to help the reader to choose the right 3D vision technique for their project. Global calibration should be carried out with flexibility and accuracy in more complex and diverse tasks, such as reconstruction of complex objects and moving objects during navigation, collaborative work with humans, fine positioning, inspection, etc. In all the reviewed applications, each global calibration method has its single purpose. This is because requirements of each task are quite different and each technique has its scope and is more adequate than others. 4 Conclusion The calibration of the cameras is a fundamental task as well as a key part of MVS. The global calibration of cameras with non-overlapping FOV has a wide range of applications, but also is a tricky problem that has not yet been fully solved. This paper summarizes the different methods widely used in global calibration of non-overlapping FOV in the MVS. An excellent global calibration method should have the following characteristics, such as high precision, good adaptability, low cost, easy operation, and so on. However, it is very difficult to satisfy the above characteristics at the same time, especially for MVS with non-overlapping FOV. This article provides a detailed analysis of the accuracy, adaptability, and application of each method. Choosing which type of global calibration method depends entirely on the structure and task requirements of the vision system to be calibrated. With the advancement of optical technology and the reduction of the price of high-precision commercial equipment, the global calibration methods will become more and more diversified and convenient in the future. column2: Investigation of achromatic micro polarizer array for polarization imaging in visible-infrared band
column3: Abstract The design and fabrication of a micro polarizer array (MPA) for polarization imaging is described for visible-IR region. The MPA, composed of 1280 × 1024 elements, is designed to be integrated directly onto the CMOS chip. Each micro polarizer consists of a 200-nm-period Al wire grating with the dimension of 5.2 μm × 5.2 μm, and the performance of gratings with finite number of periods and gradient ridge-length has been thoroughly investigated. The grating ridge of each polarizer orients four different directions offset by 45°, which determines different polarization directions correspondingly. Initial test and experiment for the MPA are performed and the crosstalk caused by diffraction is discussed.
column5: Keywords Polarimetric imaging Micro polarizer array Subwavelength gratings 1 Introduction To compensate human eyes’ inability of identifying the polarization information, conventional imaging systems are designed to capture the intensity and wavelength information, when the polarization characteristic of the light is unfortunately ignored. Polarization is, however, an indispensable nature of light which indicates the vector information of the optical field. There are significant different polarization states of radiated and scattering light from different objects, or from the same object at different conditions. Analyzing the polarization images will bring us additional information, such as surface features, shape, shading, and roughness, which cannot be obtained from the conventional intensity image [1]. As a result, by taking into account of the polarization characteristics of light, it is possible to improve the ability of information acquisition and analysis. And capturing the polarization properties has proven to be beneficial in diverse applications, such as haze/foggy imaging [2], underwater imaging [3], material identification [4], non-contact fingerprint detection [5] and so on. Generally, existing polarization imaging systems include the following categories: division of time polarimeters [6], division of amplitude polarimeters [7], division of aperture polarimeters [8], and division of focal plane polarimeters [9,10]. The micro polarizer array polarimeter [11–14], a kind of division of focal plane polarimeters, is characterized with real time, high reliability and stability, but low power consumption. Each micro-polarizer of the MPA is essentially a sub-wavelength metal grating which obtains polarization variations of the light [15]. Compared with the traditional polarizers, subwavelength metal gratings have much broader spectral width and smaller volume. Due to their superiorities of small size, compact structure, and easy to be integrated, subwavelength metal gratings can replace the traditional optical polarimeters to reduce the optical components and increase system flexibility in the optical system [16]. The advantage of the polarizing imaging device based on micro polarizer array in terms of volume, weight, power consumption, has greatly promoted the application field of polarization imaging. The micro-polarizer array is designed to be integrated on the CMOS photosensitive chip. The size of the micro-polarizer array is exactly the same as that of the chip, and the micro-polarizer array is aligned strictly pixel to pixel with the chip. In a 2 × 2 unit of the MPA, as is shown in Fig. 1 , the polarization direction of the micro-polarizer is different from each other, which is decided by the orientation of the ridges: 0°, 45°, 90° and 135°. Therefore, in the image captured by the camera, each pixel in a 2 × 2 unit records the intensity of light passing through polarization analyzer of a certain polarization direction. The advantage of the micro-polarizer array is that it can acquire images of four different polarization directions by simply acquiring one single-frame image. 2 Design For subwavelength metal gratings [17], whose period is less than the wavelength of incident light, the traditional scalar diffraction theory is no longer suitable. Instead, the vector diffraction theory is used for detailed analysis of subwavelength structures. Some widely-used vector diffraction theories include Finite Element Method (FEM) [18], Rigorous Coupled Wave Analysis (RCWA) [19], Finite Difference Time Domain (FDTD) [20], and so on. Furthermore, some approximate analysis can be performed by the equivalent media theory [21], which can reflect the working principle of the grating polarization characteristic intuitively. Equivalent media theory is to replace the periodic structure with a layer of uniform medium. The periodic grating is regarded as a homogeneous medium, meanwhile, the entire electric field within the grating can be seen as uniform. According to the Maxwell equation boundary condition, the equivalent refractive index of equivalent dielectric layer for TM polarized light and TE polarized light is [22] (1) n T E = f n 2 2 + 1 - f n 1 2 1 2 (2) n T M = f n 2 - 2 + 1 - f n 1 - 2 - 1 2 in which n 1 , n 2 are the refractive index of air and the grating medium respectively, f is the duty cycle, and f = w / p, w is the width of the grating, p is the grating period. For metal gratings, n 2 = n + i *k, where n and k denote the refractive index and extinction coefficient of the metal, respectively. For different duty cycles f, the equivalent refractive index of TM polarized light and TE polarized light is different. Therefore, the grating exhibits polarization characteristic, that is, the incident TE polarized light (whose polarization direction is parallel to the grating ridge) is reflected, and the incident TM polarized light (whose polarization direction is perpendicular to the grating) is transmitted. The essence of this phenomenon is that the TE polarized light can excite the electrons of the nanowires to generate current, and is consequently reflected. While, due to the presence of the air gap between the nanowires, current cannot be excited by the TM polarized light, resulting in the transmission. The equivalent dielectric theory is utilized to understand the polarization characteristics of metal gratings and perform the preliminary parameter design. Transmittance is the most important parameter to evaluate the performance of gratings, which reflects the utilization of the grating for light energy. The rate depends on the parameters of the grating itself and the incident light. The incident light is decided by its wavelength, angle of incidence, and polarization state. Main parameters of gratings are grating period, grating groove parameters, surface roughness, grating materials. For polarized gratings, there is one more parameter to evaluate the polarization effect, that is the extinction ratio [23]. Extinction ratio is defined as the transmission rate of TE wave divided by the transmission rate of TM wave. To achieve high transmittance and high extinction ratio, it is necessary to optimize the parameters of the grating, in which the groove parameters are the most important factors affecting the transmittance and extinction ratio. The preliminary simulation and optimization of the structures are performed using the FDTD method. To calculate 3-dimensional models with a large simulation area, FDTD method is chosen because of its advantages of time-saving and accuracy. Aluminum is used for its characteristic of easy processing and the simulated Al wire gratings are positioned on top of an infinite silica slab. Spectral responses were calculated using normal incidence plane wave excitation at a wavelength of 630 nm and tabulated dielectric functions for both aluminum and silica [24]. Fig. 2 presents the simulation results of Al wire gratings illuminated by normally incident light at 630 nm for varying grating period (p), duty cycle (f) and groove depth (d). The groove depth is fixed to be 160 nm in Fig. 2(a) and (b), while in (c) and (d) the duty cycle is set to be 0.4. In Fig. 2(a) -Fig. 2(d), the transmittance and the extinction ratio decline with the raise of the grating period, which means the smaller period the better. However, considering the difficulty of the fabrication of structures with a too small period, the period is finally chosen to be around 200 nm. As can be seen from Fig. 2(a) and Fig. 2(b), with the increase of the duty cycle f, there is an obvious decrease of transmittance but a clear growth of the extinction ratio at the same time. Consequently, a centered value of duty factor, such as 0.4 or 0.5, is selected to get a transmittance larger than 0.8 and a high extinction ration larger than 100. In Fig. 2(c), there is no clear connection between transmittance and groove depth, while in Fig. 2(d), having a larger groove depth will get a better extinction ratio, and the depth should therefore be over 140 nm to feed the need. Thus, considering all above factors, the period, groove depth and duty cycle are finally determined as 200 nm, 160 nm and 0.4 respectively. Fig. 3 presents the calculated spectra for the designed grating at the wavelength from 500 nm to 1200 nm. The transmittance is larger than 0.8 and the extinction ratio is over 100, which achieve our requirement perfectly. The calculations above are for infinite periodic structures, but the target structure cannot be extended infinitely. The size of the micro-polarizer array is designed to be the same with that of the CMOS chip. A chip consists of 1280 × 1024 pixels, and the size of each pixel is 5.2 μm × 5.2 μm. Since the grating period designed is 200 nm, a basic unit consisting of horizontal or vertical (0° or 90°) ridges will have 26 periods. And for the unit consisting of oblique (45° or 135°) ridges, the periods number is 36. Thus, Al wire gratings with various finite periods are simulated at the wavelength of 630 nm. As is shown in Fig. 4 , the grating of smaller number of cycles does not exhibit good polarization characteristics with low maximum transmittance and low extinction ratio. While, it performs well when the period number reaches 20 or more, and the polarization performance of the grating with 26 periods can be comparable to that of the infinite periodic structure. Furthermore, the structure with oblique ridges is also calculated, with grading length of the ridge strips, unlike straight gratings with stable length. Fig. 5 presents the similar trend with Fig. 4. Gratings with oblique grating ridges achieve the requirements of polarization characteristics with the periods number over 20. Hence the 5.2 × 5.2 μm oblique grating with 36 periods can meet the requirements. But when the period number is the same, the performance of oblique gratings is not as good as that of straight gratings. 3 Experiment The micro polarizer array was fabricated on a fused silica substrate. First a 160 nm thick layer of aluminum was evaporated using DC sputtering. This was followed by an e-beam evaporation of SiO2 that acts as a hard mask for aluminum etching [25,26]. For the electron beam exposure, the sample was coated with ZEP7000 electron beam resist. The micro polarizer array with different line orientations was then exposed using Raith (former Vistec) EBPG 5000 + HR system. The exposed resist was then developed in ethyl 3-ethoxypropionate (EEP) and rinsed in Isopropanol and DI-water. The pattern in the resist was then transferred to SiO2 layer and finally to aluminum using reactive ion etching. Fig. 6 (a) presents the SEM photos of the 1080 × 1024 MPA. The overall structure matches the design perfectly, with each pixel of 5.2 μm × 5.2 μm. The width of the grating ridge is 10 nm wider than expected, because of the fabrication error. A reference polarizer with the dimension of 5 mm × 5 mm is also fabricated to do characterization, since there is no effective method to do transmittance measurement though a micro structure of 5.2 μm × 5.2 μm, as is shown in Fig. 6(b). The reference structure is Al wire grating with only one ridge orientation, and the structural parameters are the same with the designed grating. The optical parameters were measured by a ellipsometry (J. A. Woolam). A comparison between experimental data and calculated data is made in Fig. 7 . The maximum transmittance of the grating is about 0.6 during the wavelength from 500 nm to1200 nm, and the extinction ratio is about 100, which meets the usual commercial standards, though both data are lower than calculated results. Imaging experiments were performed using a black and white visible light CMOS camera. Object light reaches the CMOS window through the imaging lens and the MPA polarizer, and the protective case of the CMOS is removed in order to get a close contact between the polarizer and the CMOS chip. Fig. 8 presents polarized images taken by the reference polarizer. The object is a polarization testing pattern for polarized glasses, as is shown in Fig. 8(a), which is shot without the polarizer. There is a fish pattern with polarization selectivity in the red box, which is distinguished from the background. But the fish cannot be revealed in Fig. 8(a), because the fish and the background have the same light intensity in the natural light. The reference polarizer is rotated in front of the CMOS. With the polarizer rotating, the background intensity stays at the same level while the fish pattern will become bright and dark according to the rotation angle. The angle when the fish becomes brightest is defined as 0°, and it becomes darkest after the polarizer rotating by 90°. The contrast between the fish image and the background is not obvious when the polarizer is rotated by 45° or 135°, because they have similar intensity at this time. This phenomenon shows that, compared with the background, the fish pattern has an obvious polarizing effect depending on the incident light. And the polarizer presents good polarizability. To get the experiment photos photographed with the MPA polarizer, each micro-polarizer of the MPA needs to be strictly aligned with each pixel of the CMOS chip. Pixel images which are taken by the same kind of micro-polarizer are extracted to form four final pictures, and the processing is presented in Fig. 9 (a). Pixel images obtained with 0° polarizers are marked with “I”, and they are extracted from the original picture to form an image which can be regarded as photographed with a 0°-polarizer. Fig. 9(b) presents the processed four pictures, which, however, shows no obvious polarization effect. There should be no problem of the gratings, since experiments of the reference polarizer have shown the expected performance. Two reasons are responsible for the failure of the experiment. One possible reason is the inaccurately alignment of the system. To get a good experiment performance, each micro polarizer should be strictly aligned with a corresponding pixel of the CMOS chip as designed. And that means the adjustment precision of the system should be accurate to micron level, which is beyond the equipment condition of our laboratory. While another reason may be the strong crosstalk caused by diffraction [27,28]. A pixel of Al gratings can be seen as a rectangle polarizer. Diffraction occurs when light passes through a polarizer, and the further the transmission distance is, the more obvious the diffraction phenomenon will be. Considering the thickness of the SiO2 base of the MPA, the glass protective layer of the CMOS and the air gap between these elements, the spacing between the MPA and the photosensitive chip of the CMOS is estimated to be 2–3 mm. The diffraction of the adjacent polarization will affect each other to produce crosstalk. In order to study the diffraction effect, the diffraction calculation model of a square hole is built. The side length of the square is 5.2 μm. A beam of plane wave light at the wavelength of 630 nm is incident on the model. The field distribution is calculated at a distance of 2 mm off the square hole, as is shown in Fig. 10 . The field intensity along the straight line through the center is also specifically calculated. Fig. 10 (a) presents a nearly circular distribution of the diffraction field with a radius of about 100 μm, far beyond the 5.2 μm boundary limit of the square hole. And the full width at half maximum (FWHM) of the center optical filed is about 148 μm, calculated by the cross line at Fig. 10(b). The calculation result exhibits the strong influence of diffraction. The polarization of a micro polarizer has a significant effect on the surrounded polarizers within a radius of a dozen periods. As a result, there is no way to perform a good experiment for the MPA, since the performance of a polarizer if interfered and covered by others. It is known that there is a layer of micro lens at the surface of the CMOS, and the micro-polarizer array is designed to be integrated on the CMOS photosensitive chip, in the position between the photosensitive chip and the micro lens. Because of the focusing action of the micro lens, the crosstalk of the diffraction effect will be reduced. As a result, the following work is to explore the method of integrating the polarizer directly on the chip. 4 Conclusion In this paper, we have described the design and fabrication of a 1280 × 1024 MPA in visible-IR polarization imaging. The influence of the number of grating periods and grating shape on the polarization characteristics of the grating is discussed in detail. Each micro polarizer consists of a wire grating fabricated with Al on a SiO2 substrate. SEM evaluation indicates successful fabrication of the desired structures. The measurement result shows a maximum transmittance of 60% and an extinction ratio of about 100:1. The experiment of the reference group showed good polarization performance of the designed grating. The crosstalk caused by diffraction is analyzed. Future research will include integration of higher extinction-ratio wire grating structures into micro polarizer arrays, and efficient methods to integrate the MPA on a CMOS chip. Acknowledgments This work was funded by National Natural Science Foundation of China (Grant No. 61675020).

column2: Consistent neural network empirical physical formula constructions for nonlinear scattering intensities of dye-doped nematic liquid crystals with ultraviolet pump laser-driven Fredericksz threshold shifts
column3: Abstract Intrinsic high nonlinearity in experimentally measured laser scattering intensities poses significant difficulties in analyzing various molecular and optical properties of nematic liquid crystals (NLCs). In this respect, as we theoretically proved in a previous paper, universal nonlinear function approximator layered feedforward neural network (LFNN) can be applied to construct consistent empirical physical formulas (EPFs) for nonlinear physical phenomena. The novelty of this paper is that, by using our previous conference paper data (literature data or simply data for short) for He-Ne probe laser illumination nonlinear scattering intensities of dye-doped NLCs with ultraviolet pump laser-driven Fredericksz threshold (FT) shifts, we constructed definitive LFNN-EPFs for these illumination intensities of nonlinear scattering exhibiting FT shifts. The dyes used in the literature data were methyl red (MR) azo and disperse red (DR) anthraquinone. The LFNN-EPFs fitted the data very well. Moreover, magnificent LFNN test set forecastings over previously unseen data confirmed the consistent LFNN-EPFs inferences of the intensities of scattering. The LFNN-EPFs properly extracted the FT threshold shifts, as well as revealing the intensity dependencies on the kind of dye used. We, therefore, conclude the LFNN consistently infers nonlinear physical laws governing the NLC scattering data. Provided that sufficient scattering intensity data is available, these nonlinear physical laws embedded in LFNN-EPFs may potentially be useful for investigating various NLC molecular structure parameters in molecular nonlinear optics domain. This knowledge may be applicable in developing new optical materials.
column5: Keywords Neural network Empirical physical formula Nematic liquid crystal Fredericksz transition Azo and anthraquinone dyes Scattering intensity Ultraviolent laser 1 Introduction When subjected to optical, electrical, magnetic and thermal disturbances, liquid crystal (LC) materials show highly nonlinear optical responses [1,2]. In nematic LCs, although lacking positional order, they orient in the direction of director vector n → . As LCs are fluid, their physical properties, being proportional to orientation of molecules, change depending on the alignment of LCs. The alignment of LC molecules, which are sandwiched between parallel glass plates (LC cells), can be controlled by applying an external electric field. At a critical value, applied electric field causes reorientation of LC molecules which is called the Fredericksz transition (FT). Reorientation of LC molecules induced by external electric fields are very important both for theoretical and practical purposes, for instance displays, holographic recording and tunable LC lens [3–5]. The novelty of this paper is that, by nonlinear layered feedforward neural network (LFNN) [6], we produced definitive empirical physical formulas (EPFs) for He-Ne probe laser illumination intensities of nonlinear scattering from dye-doped NLCs which exhibited ultraviolet pump laser-driven Fredericksz threshold (FT) shifts. The data for the dye-doped NLC scattering intensities (experimental data, literature data or even simply data for short) was borrowed from our previous experiments published in an international conference proceedings [7]. Because a LFNN consistently approximate any function [8], as we previously theoretically proved [9] and experimentally [10,11] showed, LFNN can be suitably used to construct EPFs. The LFNN EPFs fitted the literature experimental data [7] very well. Moreover, magnificent LFNN test set forecastings over previously unseen data showed that the scattering intensities were consistently estimated by constructed LFNN-EPFs. The LFNN-EPFs properly extracted the FT threshold shifts, as well as revealing the intensity dependencies on the kind of dye used. We, therefore, conclude the nonlinear physical laws governing the NLC scattering data can be guessed consistently by LFNN. Provided that sufficient scattering intensity data is available, these nonlinear physical laws embedded in LFNN-EPFs may potentially be useful for investigating various NLC molecular structure parameters in molecular nonlinear optics domain. This knowledge may be applicable in developing new optical materials. 2 Theories 2.1 Fredericksz transition (FT) threshold in NLCs Under external electric field, energy density of undoped nematic LC layer of thickness of d can be expressed in terms of elastic, electric and anchoring energies [12], (1) F = 1 2 K 1 ( ∇ → . n → ) 2 + 1 2 K 2 ( n → . ∇ → × n → ) 2 + 1 2 K 3 ( n → × ∇ → × n → ) 2 − 1 2 ε 0 E 2 ( Δ ε sin 2 θ + ε ⊥ ) + 1 2 W sin 2 θ 0 z = 0 z = d K 1, K 2 and K 3 being elasticity constants, n → is director vector of NLC molecules, W is the anchoring energy coefficient, Δ ε is dielectric anisotropy and magnitude of electric field is E. The director makes θ 0 angle with the boundary surface at z = 0 and z = d In dye doped LC layer, the optical torque on the molecules can be given as (2) Γ o p t i c = ε 0 ς + n e 2 − n 0 2 n → . e → n → × e → E 2 where ς is dye concentration dependent dimensionless constant, e → is electric field vector direction and no and ne are respectively refractive indices of LC for ordinary and extraordinary rays [13]. By integrating the of Eq. (2) over angle, the interaction energy between electric field of light and dye molecules is found as (3) F o p t i c = − 1 2 ε 0 ς + n e 2 − n 0 2 E 0 2 sin 2 θ where E 0 , is the electric field component of light and θ is the angle between director and electric field vector. Total energy density of dye doped LC layer is obtained as (4) F t o t a l = F e l a s t i c + F e l e c t r i c + F a n c h o r i n g + F o p t i c In planar orientation of LC molecules in the cell ( n → = ( cos θ , 0 , sin θ ) ) and with electric field perpendicular to the director, and also setting K1 = K3 [12], and θ 0 = θ , Eq. (4) takes the simpler form (5) F t o t a l = 1 2 K θ ′ 2 − ε 0 E 2 ( Δ ε sin 2 θ + ε ⊥ ) − ε 0 ς + n e 2 − n 0 2 E 0 2 sin 2 θ + W sin 2 θ z = 0 z = d where θ ′ = d θ d z . After a lengthy derivation by applying Euler-Lagrange equation to (5), with small θ and properly imposed boundary conditions at the surface, Eq. (6) is found for critical electric field (6) E C = K π 2 Δ ε ε 0 d + K W 2 − ς + n e 2 − n 0 2 E 0 2 Δ ε ε 0 Without dye molecules and optical field and with strong anchoring energy ( W → ∞ ) Eq. (6) takes the form of classical formula for FT threshold [2] as in Eq. (7) (7) E C = π d K Δ ε ε 0 2.2 Short LFNN fundamentals and EPF formation by a LFNN Under absence of satisfactory theory, unknown molecular structure parameters in LCs have to be inferred from the limited set of measured data. One method is light-scattering. Still, theoretical formulas for dye-doped NLC scattering intensities are usually unknown as well as being extremely nonlinear. Briefly, it is a difficult pursuit to obtain suitable estimations for intensities. To overcome this difficulty, because a LFNN consistently approximate any function [8], in this paper, we built up definitive LFNN-EPFs to estimate the laser light intensities of scattering from dye-doped NLCs, Methyl red (MR) and Disperse Red (DR). As anticipated, the LFNN-EPFs found excellent matches both for the actually trained literature data values and also previously unseen untrained test data values. Because we developed a novel comprehensive theory about the applicability of LFNN to EPF formation [9], we will not go into details here. Still, we briefly point out some essential points when necessary. Also, we reproduce the brief details of a LFNN here. More can be found for instance in Refs. [6,8,11]. 2.2.1 LFNN in brief Mimicking functionality of the brain, an artificial neural network (ANN) [6] is built up from artificial neurons all of which connected by changeable synapses. The new information is learnt by ANN via weight adaptation. A LFNN has one input- multi hidden-one output layer ANN (Fig. 1 ). Because a proper one hidden layer LFNN can approximate any nonlinear function [8], in this paper, we trained solely one hidden layer LFNNs. In Fig. 1 (one hidden layer) the LFNN with multi-output vector f → is used t to estimate the target output vector y → by Eq. (8) (see Ref. [8]), (8) f → : R p → R r : f → k ( x → ) = ∑ j = 1 h 1 β j G ( A j ( x → ) ) , x → ∈ R p , β j ∈ R , A j ∈ A p , and k = 1 , ... , r where A p is functions (from R p to R ) which is defined as A ( x → ) = w → • x → + b . ‘ • ’ is for scalar product operation, in Fig.1 x → being the input and w → being vector of input layer to hidden layer weights, respectively. Bias component is b . w 1 (with column vector A ( x → ) ) and w 2 (with column vector β → ) w1 and w2 are the weight matrices (see Fig. 1 and Eq. (8)). Still, from Eq. (8) and Fig. 1, the matches w 1 → A ( x → ) and w 2 → β → are true solely for LFNNs with one hidden layer. To use multiple hidden layers, both Eq. (8) and the matches need to be altered correctly. With a suitable LFNN of Eq. (8), we present the sample data to simultaneously to input and output layers. Having done a finite number cycle of weight alteration, we obtain a set of final weights with reasonable level of error value between estimated and targets outputs. If, with the final weights LFNN, the test set predictions over untrained data set are also good, then the aim has been fulfilled. That is to say, the final LFNN successfully reveals the general relationship which connects input data to output data. 2.2.2 Applicability of LFNN to EPFs Physical functions (deterministic or random) generally have several independent variables with only one dependent variable. That is, the functions have the mathematical form of g → : R p → R r , where p ≻ 1 and r = 1 ). With enough sample data, we can use Eq. (8) of LFNN to finally obtain a suitable EPF for the physical function. For more details see for instance [9,11]. In both train and test periods, the independent ( p ≻ 1 ) variables are presented to the input while the dependent one ( r = 1 ) is presented to the output layer respectively. 3 Materials and Methods: the details of LFNN application to EPFs 3.1 The literature data to produce LFNN-EPFs The scattering intensities data of dye-doped NLCs (experimental data, literature data or even simply data for short) was borrowed from our previous experiments published in an international conference proceedings [7]. In the literature data, FT threshold voltages of pure LC, dye doped LCs azo (methyl red (MR)) and anthraquinone (disperse red (DR)) had been measured by plotting the applied voltage to LC cell versus light intensity. The LC cells had been exposed to both probe He-Ne and pump UV laser light. 3.2 The LFNN structure details Commercial NeuroSolutions V5.06 neural network software was used. The LFNN was 1-1-1 layer (input-hidden-ouput). The neuron numbers were one ( p = 1 ) for input layer, variable for hidden layer p = 1 ( h 1 = 4, 7, 10) and one ( r = 1 ) for output layer. The physical variables used were as follows. Applied voltage ( for input ) and pure and dye-doped LCs intensities of laser scattering (for output). Alterable weights were in number [ p x h 1 + h 1 x r = h 1 x ( p + r ) = h 1 ( 1 + 1 ) = 2 h 1 = 2 x ( 4 − 10 ) = ( 8 − 20 ) ] in this paper [see, Fig. 1]. No bias was applied. As we usually take in our previous papers [10,11], again in this paper, in Eq. (8) we used linear functions at the output layer, and at the hidden layer were the hyperbolic tangent G activation functions, that is tanh = ( e x − e − x ) / ( e x + e − x ) . The LFNN weight adaptation method was the Levenberg-Marquardt back-propagation. The whole of LFNN-EPFs were obtained by uniformly dividing the literature NLC data (consisting of 200–300 data points) into two separate parts 80% (train set to fit) and 20% (test set to predict). 3.3 The minimization of error function As in our previous papers [10,11], the error function minimization was the same apart from the identities of physical variables used. Again, the fitting error between the target and real output of the LFNN was the mean squared error (MSE) [Eq. (9)]. In Eq. (9), y → of Fig. 1 is the user defined target output vector, output vector f → of Eq. (8) is the LFNN predicted one and N is the number of train or test sample literature data. (9) M S E = ∑ k = 1 r ∑ i = 1 N y k i − f k i 2 N For both train and 10 - 3 test literature data, the final error levels were about 10 − 3 . 3.4 The definitive construction method for LFNN-EPFs of NLC laser scattering intensities Again, this part of the method is essentially the same as in our previous papers [10,11] apart from the fact that the identities of the physical variables used in this paper were naturally different from the previous ones. Therefore, we do not reproduce it here. For the definitive construction method for LFNN-EPFs, see Section 3 in Refs. [10,11]. In this paper, LFNN input vector x → was the applied voltage and target vector y → was the He-Ne probe laser scattering intensities from either pure (E7) or dye-doped (MR and DR1) NLC samples. 4 LFNN-EPFs construction results and discussion In this paper when appropriate we use the following abbreviations. exp : literature borrowed experimental data, nno : train and test set LFNN output results, au : arbitrary units. 4.1 Train set LFNN- EPFs results In Fig. 2 a–c, literature borrowed experimental data values (exp) of He-Ne probe laser light intensities which pass through the LC cells against voltage were shown together with LFNN-EPFs (nno) train set fittings of these exp values. Although already discussed in Ref. [7], still here we very briefly underline some useful points of exp values so that one can easily make comparisons with nno results. In the literature exp values by applying voltage to LC cell, FT threshold shifts had been measured with two types of measurements (with UV pump laser on/off). UV pump laser excites the LC sample and induces measurable changes by a probe He-Ne laser beam, which reaches the detector after passing through the LC cell. Detector only detects the intensity of probe laser beam. In Fig. 2a–c, literature data exp values and LFNN-EPFs (nno) train set fittings of exp values were given. With one hidden layer and h = 7 hidden neuron number, the LFNN-EPFs fitted very well the probe laser intensities for pure and dye-doped NLCs. In other words, the FT threshold shifts in NLCs were faithfully extracted by the LFNN-EPFs. Indeed, in order to gain more insight into what the LFNN-EPFs faithfully extracted, here we borrow the physical explanations from [7]. UV (exp (on)) light affects the LC-alignment layer surface energy, which causes a shift in FT threshold. As seen in Fig. 2a, UV off FT threshold voltages are higher than that of UV on voltages. Dye doped LC cells E7 + DR1, E7 + MR (Fig. 2b and c) show somewhat different behavior because under light illumination the interaction between dye molecules and LC molecules causes a change in FT threshold voltage. Marked FT threshold shifts in dye doped LC cells as compared to pure LC cell (E7) can be explained by UV light-dye and UV light-alignment surface interaction. The interactions between LC and dye molecules increases by UV light, making a significant shift in FT threshold to lower values. Note also that, from Eq. (6) we observe a decrease in FT in dye doped cells, depending on the dimensionless constant ς for dye concentration. As pointed out above, LFNN-EPFs faithfully extracted all these physical relationships (the FT threshold shifts) in NLCs. To gain an insight into how LFNN fitting ability with varying hidden neuron number is affected, in Fig. 3 a and b, with varying hidden neurons values (h = 4 to 10), nno fittings of exp values of E7 + DR1 were given for UV laser off and on conditions. As can be seen, it is very difficult to differentiate the nno fittings between h values. This may indicate that to fit our experimental results, increasing h values does not significantly contribute to better fits, indeed even LFNN with as low as h = 4 may be sufficient for acceptably well fits. 4.2 Consistent LFNN-EFPs predictions over test set If one does not investigate the performance of the train set FNN-EPFs (Figs. 2a–3b) over test sets (data not used in the train period), then one cannot consistently apply LFNNs to obtain acceptable scattering intensity EPFs. That is, if the train set LFNNs forecast well the test set data, one can consider the LFNN to have learnt the literature data in a consistent manner. We regard the consistent LFNNs as acceptable LFNN-EPFs. In Fig. 4 a-c, respectively for pure (E7) and dye-doped NLCs (DR1, MR), the estimations of the test set which correspond to train set results of Fig. 2a–c were plotted. In Fig. 4a-c, test set nno estimations of exp values were very good. Also, in Fig. 5 a-b, the test set estimations which correspond to train set results of Fig. 3a-b were remarkably good. These agreements show that the LFNNs consistently find the physical knowledge embedded in scattering intensities of FT threshold shifts in NLCs. In short, the constructed LFNNs can be used with safety as convenient LFNN-EPFs for scattering intensities accompanied with FT threshold shifts in NLCs. 5 Conclusion In this paper, for pure and dye-doped NLCs with ultraviolet pump laser-driven Fredericksz threshold shifts, we produced definitive LFNN-EPFs by using literature data of nonlinear scattering intensities. Marked conclusions and potential applications can be presented in the following. 1 Exceptional LFNN test set estimations over previously unseen data show that LFNN-EPFs predict the intensities consistently. Accordingly, the physical laws pertaining the FT shifts can be consistently revealed by the constructed LFNN. 2 The LFNN-EPFs estimate correctly the dependence of intensities on the identity of dye. 3 By using consistent NLC intensity predictions, the LFNN-EPFs may contribute to determine the undiscovered structure parameters of LC molecules.
