column2: Conversions and interactions of the nonlinear waves in a generalized higher-order nonlinear Schrödinger equation
column3: Abstract In this paper, we investigate a generalized higher-order nonlinear Schrödinger (NLS) equation with two free parameters, including the third-order and fourth-order dispersion with matching higher-order nonlinear effects. The results show that the breather solution can be converted into some types of localized and periodic waves under specified parameter conditions. Coupled with rich graphical examples, the coexistence and interaction of different nonlinear structures are displayed. Further, we demonstrate the explicit relation on the parallel propagation of the second-order breather solution.
column5: Keywords Breather-to-soliton dynamics Antidark soliton Multi-peak soliton Periodic wave 1 Introduction Several types of exact solutions have been investigated in many nonlinear evolution equations [1–16]. Solitons which arise due to the balance of the dispersive and nonlinear terms are a class of stable waves [1–4,17–19]. Under the continuous wave background the breather solution is often established. Breathers can be seen as the localized oscillating solitons in which the energy distribution is localized and periodic. According to the propagation characteristics, they are divided into the Kuznetsov–Ma breather (periodic in time but localized in space) and the Akhmediev breather (periodic in space but localized in time) [5,6]. There exists another kind of the localized solution, the Peregrine soliton (PS), which can well describe the rogue waves (RWs) [7,16]. As the limiting case of the breather solution, it is localized both in spatial and time. Recent studies have shown that the higher-order terms can lead to the conversion of nonlinear localized and periodic waves on the continuous wave background [20–23]. The dynamic breather-to-soliton and RWs-to-soliton conversions have been established in some nonlinear systems [24–26]. In this paper, we focus on a generalized higher-order nonlinear Schrödinger (NLS) equation in the operator form (1.1) i ψ x + S [ ψ ( x , t ) ] − i α H [ ψ ( x , t ) ] + γ P [ ψ ( x , t ) ] = 0 , where S [ ψ ( x , t ) ] = 1 2 ψ tt + ψ | ψ | 2 , H [ ψ ( x , t ) ] = ψ ttt + 6 ψ t | ψ | 2 , P [ ψ ( x , t ) ] = ψ tttt + 6 ψ | ψ | 4 + 4 ψ | ψ t * | 2 + 8 ψ tt | ψ | 2 + 6 ψ t 2 ψ * + 2 ψ 2 ψ tt * . S, H and P denote the nonlinear Schrödinger operator, the Hirota operator, and the Lakshmanan–Porsezian–Daniel (LPD) operator respectively. Eq. (1.1) has two independent coefficients: α and γ, in which the third-order and fourth-order linear dispersion and other nonlinear terms such as Kerr effects, cubic quintic nonlinearity, self-steepening and self-frequency shift are taken into consideration. When γ =0, without considering the LPD operator, Eq. (1.1) becomes the Hirota equation [22]. If α =0, Eq. (1.1) is known as the LPD equation modeling a general class of the one-dimensional continuum Heisenberg spin chain [23]. The integrability, Lax pair, and lower-orders soliton solutions of Eq. (1.1) have been demonstrated [27] and the existence of N-soliton by the bilinear method has been investigated in [28]. Furthermore, the Kuznetsov–Ma breather and Akhmediev breather on the continuous wave background has presented [29]. In this paper, we display a breather solution expression with two free parameters on the plane-wave background and derive some new types of nonlinear localized and periodic solutions, such as multi-peak soliton, antidark soliton, W-shaped soliton and periodic wave. Finally, we provide some examples of breathers into solitons and analyze the interaction behaviors of these nonlinear waves. 2 Different types of nonlinear waves For Eq. (1.1), we can use the Darboux transformation (DT) technique to generate the breather solution on the plane wave background. Substituting the seed solution ψ [0] = k exp[i(Gx + Ft)] by the Lax pair given in [27], we obtain the first order linear functions r 1 and s 1 in the form (2.1a) r 1 = 2 ie − ( i / 2 ) ( 1 + 6 γ ) x sin [ B ] , (2.1b) s 1 = 2 e ( i / 2 ) ( 1 + 6 γ ) x cos [ C ] . From the onefold DT, the first-order breather solution is (2.2) ψ [ 1 ] = 1 + 2 b N r + iN i D 1 e ix ( 1 + 6 γ ) , where κ = κ r + i κ i = 1 + λ 2 = 1 + ( a + ib ) 2 , A = A r + iA i , χ = χ r + i χ i = arccos [ κ ] , B = A − χ / 2 , C = A + χ / 2 , N r = cosh [ 2 A i ] sin [ χ r ] − sin [ 2 A r ] cosh [ χ i ] , N i = sinh [ 2 A i ] cos [ χ r ] − cos [ 2 A r ] sinh [ χ i ] , D = cosh [ 2 A i ] cosh [ χ i ] − sin [ 2 A r ] sin [ χ r ] . λ is a spectral parameter, and A r = t κ r + zV r , A i = t κ i + zV i , V r = d r κ r − d i κ i , V i = d r κ r + d i κ i , d r = a + α η 1 + γ η 2 , d i = b − α η 3 + γ η 4 , with η 1 =2(1−2a 2 +2b 2), η 2 =2a(η 1 +8b 2), η 3 =8ab and η 4 =2b(η 1 −8a 2). To simplify we fix the values of the amplitude k and the frequency F of the background in the above expression. Solution (2.2) depends on four independent parameters: the coefficients of the higher-orders effects α, γ, and the real parameters a, b. By adjusting their values to meet certain relations, we can present the breather-to-soliton conversions and derive different types of wave structures in solution (2.2). Since both N and D are composed of the trigonometric function and the hyperbolic function. Solution (2.2) characterizes an unified structure combined a soliton and a periodic wave with the propagation velocities V r /κ r and V i /κ i respectively. Based on the velocity difference, some new types of nonlinear wave structures can be clearly demonstrated in the following two cases: Case 1 – V r /κ r ≠ V i /κ i . Solution (2.2) shows an one-breather structure on the plane-wave background. Further taking a =− F/2, we have the time-periodic Kuznetsov–Ma breather with |k|<|b| and the space-periodic Akhmediev breather with |k|>|b|. When |k|→|b|, the period tends to infinity. Solution (2.2) describes the Peregrine soliton(PS) which is localized both in time and space. Case 2 – V r /κ r = V i /κ i . In this case, d j =0. The breather can be converted to other nonlinear waves in solution (2.2). The exact conversion relation can be obtained (2.3) 4 ( 1 − 6 a 2 + 2 b 2 ) γ = 8 a α − 1 . The higher-order coefficients α and γ cannot be zero simultaneously in this conversion. Based on parametric analysis, several types of localized and periodic structures are displayed in Figs. 1–7. If a ≠− F/2, then κ r ≠0, κ i ≠0. Solution (2.2) presents the multi-peak soliton, which is a localized one-soliton with some oscillation or main peaks [23,30]. This structure can describe the propagation of the few cycle pulses (FCP) in the Kerr media [31]. Figs. 1 and 2 depict the one-cycle pulses soliton and the two-cycle pulses soliton respectively. As shown in Figs. 1–3, when the parameter a increases, the oscillation becomes stronger. If a =− F/2, there are three solution structures displayed in Figs. 3–5 . When |k|<|b|, we have κ r =0, κ i ≠0, then V r =0, V i = κ i d r . Solution (2.2) keeps the soliton feature and a antidark soliton [32] is depicted in Fig. 4. When |k|>|b|, then V i =0, V i = κ r d r . Solution (2.2) shows the periodic structure. In Figs. 5 and 6 , we obtain two kinds of periodic waves with the period D t = π k 2 − b 2 . When |k|→|b|, D t →∞. Solution (2.2) generates a W-shaped solution [33] depicted in Fig. 7 . It is a limiting case of Fig. 6. 3 Conversion and interaction between the nonlinear waves In this section, we demonstrate the second-order breather-to-soliton conversion and mutual interaction of the different localized and periodic waves in Eq. (1.1). To give the second-order breather solution, we use (2.1) to have two sets of first order linear functions r 1,1 = r 1(λ 1), s 1,1 = s 1(λ 1) and r 1,2 = r 1(λ 2), s 1,2 = s 1(λ 2) with the eigenvalues λ 1 and λ 2 respectively, where r 1,j and s 1,j (j =1, 2) keep the same form as r 1 and s 1 in Section 1: λ j = a j + ib j , r 1 , j = 2 ie − ( i / 2 ) ( 1 + 6 γ ) x sin [ B j ] , s 1 , j = 2 e ( i / 2 ) ( 1 + 6 γ ) x cos [ C j ] , κ j = κ jr + i κ ji = 1 + λ j 2 = 1 + ( a j + ib j ) 2 , A j = A jr + iA ji , χ j = χ jr + i χ ji = arccos [ κ 1 ] , B j = A j − χ j / 2 , C j = A j + χ j / 2 , A jr = t κ jr + zV jr , A ji = t κ ji + zV ji , V jr = ( a j + α η j 1 + γ η j 2 ) κ jr − ( b j − α η j 3 + γ η j 4 ) κ ji , V ji = ( a j + α η j 1 + γ η j 2 ) κ jr + ( b j − α η j 3 + γ η j 4 ) κ ji . By DT technique [27], the second-order linear functions r 2,1 and s 2,1 can be written as (3.1a) r 2 , 1 = 2 ( − 4 ib 1 cosh [ iC 1 * ] cosh [ iC 2 ] sinh [ iB 1 ] − sinh [ iB 2 ] ( k 1 D 11 + k 2 D 12 ) ) D 11 + D 12 , (3.1b) s 2 , 1 = 2 ( 4 ib 1 cosh [ iC 1 ] sinh [ iB 1 * ] sinh [ iB 2 ] − cosh [ iC 2 ] ( − k 2 D 11 + k 1 D 12 ) ) D 11 + D 12 , where k 1 = a 1 − a 2 + i ( b 1 − b 2 ) , k 2 = a 1 − a 2 − i ( b 1 − ib 2 ) , D 11 = − cos [ 2 B r 1 ] + cosh [ 2 B i 1 ] , D 12 = cos [ 2 C r 1 ] + cosh [ 2 C i 1 ] . Further, the following second-order breather solution ψ [2] can be obtained (3.2) ψ [ 2 ] = ψ [ 1 ] − 2 i ( λ 2 − λ 2 * ) s 2 , 1 r 2 , 1 * r 2 , 1 2 + s 2 , 1 2 . Solution (3.2) describes the second-order breather structure on the plane-wave background, which contains two groups of the velocities: V 1r /κ 1r ,V 1i /κ 1i and V 2r /κ 2r ,V 2i /κ 2i . The velocities in each group correspond to each breather component and are determined by each eigenvalues in solution (3.2). Similarly, by the analysis of the velocities, the transition, coexistence, and interaction of different types of localized and periodic waves are exhibited for Eq.(1.1). Case 1 – V jr /κ jr = V ji /κ ji , j =1, 2. The second-order breather is converted into the soliton solution. We have (3.3) 4 ( 1 − 6 a j 2 + 2 b j 2 ) γ = 8 a j α − 1 , j = 1 , 2 . By adjusting parameters to meet the above relations, two breather components in solution (3.2) are all converted into other nonlinear waves. The coexistence and interaction of these localized and periodic structures are displayed in Fig. 8 . Case 2 – V 1r /κ 1r = V 1i /κ 1i , V 2r /κ 2r ≠ V 2i /κ 2i . We can choose one of the two breather components to convert it to a soliton, and the other component's structure remain unchanged. It is clear that the conclusion of the parameters condition met by these soliton and periodic solutions still holds. Then we can display many examples on the mutual interactions between breather and other types of nonlinear waves in Fig. 9 . Case 3 – V 1i /κ 1i = V 2i /κ 2i . This condition leads to the parallel propagation of the two breather component in solution (3.2). Taking λ 2 =1+0.2i and b 1 =0.8, we get a 1 =0.730,−0.0558, and 1.1584. A simple example is displayed in Fig. 10 (a) with a 1 =0.730. As shown in Fig. 10, two single component breather with different amplitudes and velocities keep the same propagation direction. 4 Conclusions In this paper, we have investigated a generalized higher-order dispersive nonlinear Schrödinger equation with two independent parameters. The breather solution has been converted into several types of solutions including multi-peak soliton, antidark soliton, W-shaped structure and periodic waves under different parameter conditions. Via some graphic illustrations, the coexistences and interactions of these nonlinear waves have been analyzed. Acknowledgements We express our sincere thanks to each member of our discussion group for their suggestions.

column2: Interferometric array configuration design for the expected UV-plane coverage
column3: Abstract UV-plane coverage (UVPC) represents the distribution of spatial frequency sampling of the interferometric array. This paper focuses on designing an interferometric array configuration for the expected UVPC. The method presented uses the array that can entirely sample the expected UVPC points as the initial array, and gradually deletes apertures to obtain a final array. The advantage of the method is that it can design an array configuration for any expected UVPC and the distribution of the generated UVPC can be quite similar to the expected one. Two examples are given to present the feasibility of the method.
column5: Keywords Interferometric array Array configuration design UV-plane coverage Removing apertures 1 Introduction In the past decades, optical telescopes have been built with increasingly large aperture for higher resolution observation in astronomy. With the aperture size growing, cost and weight grow too, which limits the construction of a large telescope. Several ways have been developed to solve this problem. One of them is the interferometric array, which can sample the spatial frequency information of the target and then obtain the intensity distribution by inverse Fourier transform. The resolution of an interferometric array depending on the longest baseline can reach up to hundreds of meters. UVPC comes from the locations of the array apertures and represents the distribution of spatial frequency sampling of the interferometric array. Excellent UVPC helps find important frequency information of the observed target and restore high quality target image. Therefore it is necessary to arrange the array configuration for the expected UVPC. There has been enormous research about the interferometric array configuration. For example, Golay [1] and Kopilovich [2] have discussed the construction of nonredundant array configurations; Boone [3] and Villiers [4] provided methods to achieve a desired natural tapering for the density distribution of the UVPC. Y. Su [5] introduced a “sieving” algorithm, removing element candidates in an array to fit the UVPC to a predefined shape. However, those approaches can only obtain uniform or Gaussian UVPC distributed symmetrically along the radius. In some practical cases, we need the UVPC to provide high resolution in several directions, where the densities of the UV-plane points are larger while uniform or Gaussian UVPC cannot meet the demand. Olivier Guyon [6] has proposed an optimization of UVPC for a rotating phased array of telescopes, telling us that when making use of the Earth's rotation for ground-based interferometers, nonuniform snapshot UVPC is needed. This paper will present a method that can design an array configuration for any expected UVPC. The method uses the array that can entirely sample the expected UVPC points as the initial array, and gradually deletes apertures to obtain a final array. This method is introduced in detail in Section 2. Two examples are given to present the feasibility of the method in Section 3. 2 Array configuration design method An array’s UVPC can be calculated accurately by the locations of its apertures, while the locations of array’s apertures cannot be calculated by UVPC. The relation between the UV-plane point and the location of apertures can be written as (1) ( u , v ) = ( x 2 − x 1 , y 2 − y 1 ) λ Where u and v are the coordinates of the UV-plane point, x 1 , x 2 , y 1 , y 2 are the coordinates of the apertures, λ is the wavelength. However, if put apertures on every point of half of the UVPC, these apertures plus the aperture on the center of the plane can form an array whose UVPC entirely contains all the points of the former UVPC. This case is shown in Fig. 1 . Of course, the number of the apertures is too large and the array will produce vast extra UV-plane points. Naturally, if we can reduce the number of the apertures while keeping the UV-plane points we want, the array configuration will be closer to an expected one. The question is how we could reduce the number of the apertures. In the array mentioned above, we actually only use the connections between the center aperture and “non-center” apertures to get the expected UV-plane points, and the connections between “non-center” apertures produce the extra UV-plane points. Considering a simple case shown in Fig. 2 , if the connection between one aperture A and the center aperture O is equal to the connection between some other two apertures B and C, which means the length and orientation of two connections are the same, then the aperture A is useless to produce the expected UV-plane points and it is necessary to delete it. Therefore, the number of apertures can be reduced by taking advantage of the connection between “non-center” apertures. However, the practical case is usually more complicated. Firstly, two entirely equal connections might not be existed. But if the length and orientation of two connections are close enough, we can treat them as the equal connection. Secondly, as shown in Fig. 3 , if one aperture’s connection with the center aperture can be replaced, but its connections with other “non-center” apertures replace more apertures’ connections with the center aperture, the operation of deleting this aperture will make more apertures that can be deleted survive. This situation leads to a question that which aperture should be really deleted. Here, we use two parameters to describe the contribution and substitutability of every aperture. Suppose A is the set of entire apertures, a 0 , a 1 , a 2 ,…, a N represent the apertures, where a 0 represent the center aperture. We have (2) A = a 0 , a 1 , a 2 , ⋯ , a N Define a x a y as the connection between a x and a y , a x a y = a m a n represents that two connections are the same (both length and orientation). The contribution C k of a k can be defined as the number of the set a m , a n , which satisfies (3) a k a m = a 0 a n ( 1 ≤ k , m , n ≤ N , k ≠ m , n ) The substitutability S k of a k can be defined as the number of the set a p , a q , which satisfies (4) a 0 a k = a p a q ( 1 ≤ k , p , q ≤ N , k ≠ p , q ) If an aperture has high contribution and low substitutability, it contributes to the expected UVPC a lot, and few other aperture pairs can replace it, which means it is supposed to be kept. If an aperture has low contribution and high substitutability, its impact on the expected UVPC is insignificant and can be replaced by other aperture pairs, which means it can be removed. To decide which aperture should be removed first, we define an objective function for each aperture. The objective function for each aperture can be defined as f k = S k / C k , ( 1 ≤ k ≤ N ). If C k = 0 , f k is treated as infinity. The aperture with maximum f k will be deleted first. Then calculate f k for every aperture again. Repeat the operation until the number of apertures or the UVPC meets the demand. The remaining apertures constitute the final array configuration. The parameters of every aperture except the center aperture in Fig. 3 are shown in Table 1 . Obviously, aperture E and G have maximum objective functions and should be deleted first. This result agrees with the demand for fewest aperture number. It is not appropriate to define the objective function as f k = S k − C k ,( 1 ≤ k ≤ N ). For example, aperture a 1 : C 1 = 0 , S 1 = 6 , f 1 = S 1 − C 1 = 6 ; aperture a 2 : C 2 = 5 , S 2 = 12 , f 2 = S 2 − C 2 = 7 . So that aperture a 2 should be deleted first. But aperture a 1 has no contribution to delete other apertures while 6 pairs of other apertures can replace it, so there is no reason to keep a 1 . When the objective function is f k = S k / C k , f 1 = inf , f 2 = 2.4 , aperture a 1 will be deleted first and aperture a 2 will be kept temporarily, which is more reasonable. The procedure of the presented array configuration construction can be concluded as follows: Step 1: Construct an initial array configuration according to the expected UVPC. The initial array contains apertures on points of half of the UVPC and a center aperture. Step 2: Set a maximum acceptable aperture number of the final array. Step 3: Calculate the objective function for every aperture and delete the aperture with maximum objective function. Step 4: Repeat the operation in step 3 until the aperture number equals the one set in step 2. The rest of the apertures constitute the final array. The impact of different aperture numbers on the final UVPC will be discussed in Section 3. 3 Examples We give two examples showing the results of array construction. The expected UVPC in Fig. 4 is distributed symmetrically along the radius, which is common in the traditional array configuration optimization research. The expected UVPC in Fig. 5 is distributed asymmetrically along the radius with the UV-plane points inside two circular areas. As mentioned in Section 2, if the length and orientation of the aperture connections are close enough, we treat them as the equal connection. However, too small tolerable errors of the length and orientation might lead to zero contribution and zero substitutability for most apertures, making the deleting operation quite random, while too large tolerable errors will make final result inaccurate. In practical cases, the tolerable errors should be determined by the accuracy requirement. Here, the tolerable error of length of the aperture connection is set as 0.5 m and the tolerable error of orientation of the aperture connection is set as 0.02 rad for good results. The picture (d) of Figs. 4 and 5 show the final array configuration with a certain number of apertures respectively. Their UVPC in the picture (e) of Figs. 4 and 5 are quite similar with the expected UVPC in the picture (a) respectively. To evaluate the result, we give the distribution of the expected UV-plane points that are missed (in the picture (f) of Figs. 4 and 5) and the distribution of extra UV-plane points (in the picture (g) of Figs. 4 and 5). And we give the parameters of results with different final aperture number, shown in Tables 2 and 3 . The number of the expected UV-plane point in Fig. 4(a) is 210, so that the number of initial array apertures is 106 (210/2 + 1=106). The theoretical least number of apertures to form this UVPC is 15 (15 × 14 = 210), although the array configuration with 15 apertures that forms this expected UVPC might not exist. Fig. 4 shows the final array configuration with 30 apertures and its UVPC. Although extra UV-plane points exist, the shape of the UVPC in Fig. 4(e) is similar to the expected one in Fig. 4(a). From the Table 2, we can find that when the aperture number is 30, the proportion of missing expected UV-plane points is only 2.9%, which means almost all the expected UV-plane points are obtained. The number of the expected UV-plane point in Fig. 5(a) is 420, so that the number of the initial array apertures is 211 (420/2 + 1=211). The theoretical least number of apertures to form this UVPC is 21 (21 × 20 = 420). From Table 3, we can find that when the aperture number is 50, the proportion of missing expected UV-plane points is 2.9%, which means most of the expected UV-plane points are obtained. But Fig. 5 shows that the UVPC produced by 30 apertures is already similar to the expected UVPC. According to the Tables 2 and 3, with the final aperture number increasing linearly, the number of expected UV-plane points missed does not decrease linearly while the number of extra UV-plane points increases fast. In practical cases, whether to obtain the entire expected UVPC points should be considered carefully, because sometimes missing a few UV-plane points will not influence the general distribution of expected UVPC but decrease the aperture number largely. The method proposed by Y. Su is a little similar to our method. We both remove apertures from candidate apertures. But there are two major differences between our methods. First, the candidate apertures in Y. Su’s method come from the practical terrain or random distribution, while the candidate apertures in our method come from the expected UVPC. Second, Y. Su’s method aims to form uniform or Gaussian tapered UVPC, while our method aims to form any expected UVPC. 4 Conclusion A method that can design an array configuration for the expected UVPC is provided in this paper. This method uses the array that can entirely sample the expected UVPC points as the initial array, and gradually deletes apertures to obtain a final array. The contribution, substitutability and an objective function for every aperture are defined as the indications to delete apertures. The advantage of this method is that it can design an array configuration for any expected UVPC and the distribution of the generated UVPC can be quite similar to the expected one. Two examples were given to present the feasibility of the method. It can be applied in the field of interferometer imaging.

Kopilovich Non-redundant hexagonal array configurations for optical interferometric systems conpactly covering central domains in the spatial-frequency plane J. Mod. Opt. 52 10 2005 1415 1420 [3] F. Boone Interferometric array design: optimizing the locations of the antenna pads Astron. Astrophys. 377 2001 368 376 [4] M. de Villiers Interferomrtric array layout design by tomographic projection Astron. Astrophys. 469 2007 793 797 [5] Y. Su Optimization of interferometric array configurations by “sieving” u-v points Astron. Astrophys. 414 2004 389 397 [6] Olivier Guyon Francois Roddier Aperture rotation synthesis: optimization of the (u,v)-plane coverage for a rotating phased array of telescopes Publ. Astron. Soc. Pac. 113 2001 98 104

column2: A novel unsupervised bands selection algorithm for hyperspectral image
column3: Abstract A novel bands selection method based on ABS (Adaptive Band Selection) and JSKF (Joint Skewness-Kurtosis Figure) is proposed in this paper. The hyperspectral data is separated into different sub-spaces by employing ABS and JSKF respectively. Subsequently a novel optimal bands selection method NIA (Normalization Index Algorithm) is proposed to select the optimal bands according to the value of ABS and JSKF. Both the high correlations of the adjacent bands and the richness of complementary information are considered in detail in this proposed method. Some numerical simulations are made to test the validity and capability of the proposed dimension reduction algorithm.
column5: Keywords Hyperspectral Dimension reduction Bands selection ABS JSKF 1 Introduction With the advanced development of the spectrometers, we are entering a new age of hyperspectral remote sensing. The high spectral resolution airborne and satellite spectrometers improve the capability for capture of targets in fields as diverse as geology, environment monitoring, agriculture or military [1]. However, the high dimensionality not only increases computational complexity but also may degrade classification accuracy [2]. Accordingly, dimensionality reduction is a necessary preprocessing step to obtain a smaller set of features that summarize the information in the hyperspectral image cube for most of the applications [3]. Some dimension reduction algorithms based on different transformations have been proposed to improve classifier efficiency on the hyperspectral image due to the high-dimensional nature of the data recently [4–7]. Moreover, some kinds of dimension reduction methods based on bands selection which can remove the bands that convey little or no discriminatory information have also been deeply researched [8–12]. There are primarily two kinds of approaches to reduce data dimensions can be identified in recent researches. The first approach is based on domain transform, such as PCA (Principal Component Analysis), OSP (Orthogonal Subspace Projection), CA (Canonical Analysis) and DWT (Discrete Wavelet Transform). Since the data are transformed, some critical information may be compromised and distorted [8].The other one is based on non-transform, like optimal bands selection and original data partition. In our research, the second approach is considered and utilized to reduce the dimensions of the hyperspectral image because the verified capability in keeping the characteristics of the original data [13]. It is anticipated that the redundancy resulting from inter-band correlation should be high and can be removed without loss the important information [7]. Therefore, the correlations of the adjacent bands in hyperspectral image should considered in detail. On the other word, the high correlations of the adjacent bands should be reduced and the selected bands should reserve the band range as wide as possible. However, the experimental result demonstrates that the optimal bands selected by ABS method will focus in a narrow spectral band. Furthermore, the JSKF classification can be used to divide the hyperspectral image into several subspaces. This subspaces ideas can be considered in bands selection algorithm to obtain a wide range selection result. Based on the selection algorithm ABS and JSKF, a novel bands selection method NIA is proposed in this paper. Firstly, the ABS and JSKF algorithms are introduced briefly and the band selection results are considered the intermediate variables of the proposed algorithm. A hyperspectral image is divided into diverse sub-spaces according to the threshold value of ABS and JSKF, respectively. The high level of redundancy from adjacent bands correlation can be reduce effectively after sifting by the ABS model. Meanwhile, the value of JSKF represents the degree of deviating from the normal distribution which equal to the degree of richness of complementary information [14]. Subsequently a new bands selection algorithm NIA is introduced to combine and take advantages of the two partitions sub-spaces from ABS and JSKF. Besides, the statistics evaluations of the selected bands are also considered in the paper. Numerical simulation is performed to validate the performance of the proposed bands selection algorithm for hyperspectral image. The rest of the paper is organized in the following sequence. In Section 2, the proposed bands selection algorithm is introduced in detail. In Section 3, numerical simulation results are made and given to demonstrate the validity of the algorithm. Concluding remarks are summarized in conclusion. 2 Bands selection algorithm Firstly, both the ABS and JSKF band partition algorithm are introduced in this section. Thereafter, the intact bands selection algorithm based on the ABS and JSKF is addressed in detail. 2.1 The authentic hyperspectral data The original data in this paper are acquired by a hyperspectral camera. The hyperspectral camera used in this research is Image-λ-V10E-PS, as shown in Fig. 1 , and its basic parameters are listed in Table 1 . In this experiment, the capture angle of the camera is controlled by the electric turntable as shown in Fig. 1, and the hyperspectral camera can be fixed on the turntable. In addition, to reduce the influence of ambient lighting changes, we chose a sunny afternoon in this experiment. The digital images are multiplexed and transmitted to computer in real-time. Here infrared cut filter or polarizer is not used in the present experiment. Some pre-processing, like grayscale correction and denoising, are necessary because of the systematic errors exist in this acquisition operations. One of the experiment data having 303 bands and 256 × 256 pixels for each band is regarded as the original data in this research. The false color composite of this hyperspectral image and its 3D sensitive schematic are shown in Fig. 2 . The black spot in the image is a tank model we set before. In the following sections, all the hyperspectral data are on behalf of this cube data by default. 2.2 OIF and ABS algorithm The concept of OIF (Optimal Index Factor) was first proposed by Chavez Berlin and Sowers in 1982 [15]. In their paper, OIF provides a new method to select an optimal group of the bands by estimating the value of OIF. High value of OIF indicates that the bands contain much information with little duplication [16]. In other words, the selected bands obtain more information and can reflect the different spectral features of the objects in the image more roundly. The OIF can be expressed as (1) O I F = ∑ i = 1 n σ i ∑ i = 1 n ∑ j = i + 1 n R i , j where σ i represents the standard deviation of the i - t h band of the hyperspectral image. The parameter R i , j denotes the correlation coefficients between the i - t h band and j - t h band of the image. In the literature [15], three bands are combined as a cluster and the total value of their OIF will be regarded as the only index of the subset. However, the drawbacks of this algorithm were soon appears in the practical application [17]. The “optimal” cluster of the hyperspectral image may not perform as wonderful as the description in the literature [15]. The fatal drawback of OIF is that the author neglected the high correlation between the adjacent bands. The correlation coefficients of each two bands are varying for different positions, the 3D schematic and the correlation coefficients curve of the adjacent bands are shown in Fig. 3 . Where the CCAB in Fig. 1(b) is short for Correlation-Coefficients-of-Adjacent-Bands and the hyperspectral data used in Fig. 3 contain 303 bands. The correlation coefficients of the adjacent bands used in this paper is defined as (2) C C A B = R i , i + 1 i = 1 , 2 ⋯ n - 1 , Following the OIF, some improved algorithms based on OIF are proposed to mitigate the influence of CCAB [13]. A new algorithm called ABS was proposed recently which the correlation of the adjacent bands is considered and utilized. The ABS index can be expressed as follow (3) I n d e x ( i ) = σ i ( R i − 1 , i + R i , i + 1 ) / 2 (4) σ i = 1 M × N ∑ x = 1 M ∑ y = 1 N f i x , y − μ i 2 1 2 (5) R i , j = E ( f i − μ i ) ( f j − μ j ) E ( f i − μ i ) 2 E ( f j − μ j ) 2 where I n d e x ( i ) denotes the ABS index value of the i - t h band. The parameters σ i and R i , j represent the standard deviation of the i - t h band and the correlation coefficients between the i - t h band and j - t h band of the image respectively. M a n d N gives the size of the specify band of the hyperspectral image. Besides, f i and μ i represent the i - t h band image and the average pixel value of the i - t h band image respectively. The symbol E is on behalf of mathematic expectation. The ABS curve of the experimental hyperspectral data is represented in Fig. 4 . It is obviously that all the maximum values of the ABS are concentrated in the exclusive “peak” of the curve as shown in Fig. 4. The result has demonstrated that the optimal bands selected by ABS method will focus in a narrow spectral band which disobeyed the original expectation of this algorithm. One of the main advantages of hyperspectral image is that it can provide the completed spectral information which is useful for analyzing the composition of the material. Thus, some improving schemes should be designed for ABS. 2.3 Joint-Skewness-Kurtosis-Figure algorithm The statistics parameters skewness and kurtosis are usually employed in multiple conflicting and competing portfolio objectives [18,19]. Skewness is a measure of the asymmetry of a distribution while kurtosis is a measure of the extent to which observations cluster around a central point. Both the skewness and kurtosis are sensitive to isolated peaks and valleys [20]. For a standard normal distribution, the value of skewness and kurtosis statistic are equal to zero. For hyperspectral image, the background information is approximate Gaussian distributed and the target features can be regarded as the anomaly information [14,21]. Therefore, to select the bands which target features are more clearly can be simplify as to select the bands which are obviously deviated from Gaussian distribution. Here the Joint-Skewness-Kurtosis-Figure (JSKF) is introduced to test the bands deviation from the Gaussian distribution. The definition of skewness, kurtosis and JSKF can be expressed as follow (6) S k e w n e s s = 1 n ∑ i = 1 n f i − μ 3 1 n ∑ i = 1 n f i − μ 2 3 2 (7) K u r t o s i s = 1 n ∑ i = 1 n ( f i − μ ) 4 1 n ∑ i = 1 n f i − μ 2 2 − 3 (8) J S K F = S k e w n e s s ⋅ K u r t o s i s where f i and μ represent the i - t h band image and the average pixel value of the hyperspectral image respectively. The symbol n is the largest band number of the hyperspectral data. In fact, Eq. (6) and Eq. (7) are the definition of the third central moment and fourth central moment of the data. The JSKF curve of the experimental hyperspectral data is illustrated in Fig. 5 . The result of the JSKF can be divided into three sub-spaces adaptively according to the distribution of the value. The grayscale distribution and anomaly information are similar in the same sub-space while the similarity between different sub-spaces is much lower [14]. For this reason, the classification based on the value JSKF is suitable for bands selection of the hyperspectral image. 2.4 Novel bands selection algorithm The flowchart of the bands selection scheme is displayed in Fig. 6 . To design this bands selection algorithm both the ABS and JSKF method are considered and utilized. Firstly, the hyperspectral data is divided into single band as shown in Fig. 6. Subsequently, the hyperspectral data is converted by suing JSKF algorithm and the data is divided into certain sub-spaces by estimating the JSKF value. In the meantime, the hyperspectral data is also converted by ABS algorithm and the result of ABS is classified into certain sub-spaces by the rule of JSKF algorithm. In the following step, a bands selection method called NIA (Normalization Index Algorithm) is proposed in order to perform the full algorithm shown in Fig. 6. Finally, the NIA is performed for the results of the ABS and JSKF and the selected bands in NIA are regarded as the final selection of this novel algorithm. Two weight factors p and q representing background information and anomaly targets information are introduced in NIA. Some simulations will be given to show the capability of this algorithm in Section 3. In order to perform the full algorithm, NIA is necessary to be introduced in this section. The Normalization Index Algorithm is performed as follow: the hyperspectral data in each subset are encoded afresh respectively. Assume that the three partitions of the data are encoded as (9) a 1 , a 2 ... , a l ; j 1 , j 2 ... , j l , 1 s t s u b s e t a l + 1 , a l + 2 ... , a m ; j l , j l + 1 ... , j m , 2 n d s u b s e t a m + 1 , a l + 2 ... , a n ; j m + 1 , j m + 1 ... , j n . 3 r d s u b s e t where a and j represent the value of ABS and JSKF respectively. n is the total number of the hyperspectral data where n = 303 in this research. Moreover, the quantities of each subsets in this experiment are l , m - l and n - m as we can obtain in Eq. (9). Subsequently the values of NIA can be obtained according to the classification in Eq. (9). The normalized NIA results are regarded as the final valuation factors in this research. Besides, the parameter k in Eq. (10) is correlated to the parameter i mentioned before. The k - t h band will be considered to select while the value of NIA is more close to 1 than others. Moreover the quantity of the selected bands can be controlled by a threshold value. The k - t h value of NIA is defined as (10) N I A ( k ) = p a k | max ( a 1 , a 2 ... , a l ) | + q j k | max ( j 1 , j 2 ... , j l ) | , ( 0 ≤ k ≤ l ) p a k | max ( a l , a l + 1 ... , a m ) | + q j k | max ( j l + 1 , j l + 2 ... , j m ) | , ( l < k ≤ m ) p a k | max ( a m + 1 , a m + 2 ... , a n ) | + q j k | max ( j m + 1 , j m + 2 ... , j n ) | . ( m < k ≤ n ) (11) p + q = 1 where the parameters p and q denote two weight factors of NIA. Note that p and q are equal to 0.5 respectively in this paper. Actually, other values can be introduced for replacing the value we set. It depends on what kinds of information we search for. The parameter p represents the weight of information and independence of the bands while q represents the weight of anomaly targets information. 3 Numerical simulation Numerical simulation in this section is considered for demonstrating of the bands selection algorithm. A hyperspectral image obtained from the experiment mentioned above who having 256 × 256 pixels is regarded as the original images and is shown in Fig. 2. Of the data, there are several classes: tree, grass, road, trail, tank models and shadow. Furthermore, some objective performance evaluation criteria are used to assess the proposed algorithm in this paper, such as the standard deviation, average gradient and Entropy. The hyperspectral image obtained from the experiment owns 520 bands from 400 nm to 1000 nm is merit-based selected. To simplify the calculation, the original data is equidistant sampled into 303 bands in the visible wave range. As the partition shown in Fig. 6, the hyperspectral data is divided into three sub-spaces: { 1 , 2... , 125 } , { 125 , 126... , 213 } and { 214 , 215... , 303 } . In other words, the parameter l and m in Eq. (9) are confirmed as 125 and 213 respectively. Part of the bands selection results and the stem curve of NIA are displayed in Figs. 7 and 8 respectively. It is obviously that the curve of NIA is smoother than those ABS and JSKF, especially when the weight factor q is larger than p . Of course the selecting operation will be taken place among all the subsets as shown in Fig. 8. The smooth values and decentralized selected bands are benefit to bands selection since we can reserve the visible wave range spectral information approximately which is significant to the following processing for the hyperspectral data (e.g. anomaly target detection and recognition). Besides, some statistics evaluations like standard deviation, space frequency, entropy and average gradient are applied to evaluate the selected bands. The statistics evaluation in detail is shown in Table 2 . Note that the “Average” in the last list of Table 2 is the average value of the entire bands. Larger standard deviation and entropy indicate that more information is contained in the selected bands while the larger average gradient indicates richer detailed information. As shown in Table 2, the selected bands perform better than the average one in all of the statistics evaluations. To demonstrate the validity and capability of the proposed algorithm, the ABS and JSKF are considered to the following comparison experiment. The experiment results of ABS, JSKF and proposed algorithm are listed in Table 3 . It is obviously that the selected bands of ABS and JSKF algorithm are centralized in the relatively narrow area which matches the curves in Figs. 4 and 5. Also, the corresponding spectral positions of the selected bands by different algorithms are illustrated in Fig. 9 . From the curves shown in Fig. 9, the curve of ABS algorithm is close to a horizon line which the positions are centralized in the narrow range [134, 149]. In addition, the performance of JSKF algorithm is better than the ABS one, however, the range of the selected bands is still much worse than the proposed algorithm. The selected bands of the algorithm we proposed covers most of the spectrum which benefit to the anomaly target detection and recognition as mentioned before. Mutual information is a typical measure for independence between random variables. In the following experiment, the mutual information is considered and utilized to test the independence between the selected bands in different methods and the result is displayed in Fig. 10 . The curves in Fig. 10 indicate that the mutual information between selected bands in proposed method is smaller than those in ABS and JSKF method. This result is expected because the selected bands in our algorithm are based on the NIA idea and the range of the selected bands is more widely than the other two methods. To weight the difference between the selected bands quantitatively, the relative mean square error (RMSE) function is introduced [22], defined as (12) R M S E = r m s e ( f i , f j ) = ∑ ∀ m , n f i ( x , y ) − f j ( x , y ) 2 m a x ∑ ∀ m , n f i ( x , y ) 2 , ∑ ∀ m , n f j ( x , y ) 2 where f i and f f represent the i - t h and j - t h selected bands respectively. The values of RMSE denote the difference of the two images. Now we test the RMSE values between the selected bands in different methods, respectively. The RMSE curves are calculated and displayed in Fig. 11 . The result has demonstrated that the bands selection algorithm in this paper performs better than the other two algorithms. RMSE of the proposed algorithm is larger than the other two algorithms, in other words, the errors between the selected bands in proposed method is more dissimilar than the other two sets of data. As we can know from Fig. 11, the result meets the expectation of bands selection for hyperspectral image. As mentioned above, the second sub-space range from 125th band to 213th band. In this space, the selected results of these three selection algorithms are list in Table 4 . As we can see from Table 4, the selected result of ABS and JSKF are almost the same with the result shown in Table 3 because the selected bands are focus in the center area of the spectrum curve. The result of the proposed has the widest range. To verify the ability of the proposed band selection algorithm, another hyperspectral image is considered and utilized in the following experiment. A hyperspectral image from AVIRIS having 126 bands is utilized to test the proposed algorithm. The size of single band of the hyperspectral image is 256 × 256 and the scene of the image is a military airport, which shown in Fig. 12 . By using the ABS and JSKF band selection algorithms, the results of this hyperspectral image are depicted in Figs. 13 and 14 , respectively. Also, the spectrum information can be divided into four sub-spaces adaptively according to the distribution of the value as shown in Fig. 14. The three sub-spaces are { 1 , 2... , 19 } , { 20 , 21... , 63 } , { 64 , 65... , 126 } and { 96 , 97... , 126 } , respectively. According to the bands selection results of ABS and JSKF, the band selection result of NIA is illustrated in Fig. 15 . In calculation we use a computer with Core2, CPU 2.5 GHz and 2048 Mbytes memory under Windows 7 system. Except the calculation of the correlation coefficients of each two bands, the band selection processes for this hyperspectral image take 4.7281 s. The selection results of ABS, JSKF and NIA are list in Table. 5 , respectively. As we can learn from Table 5, the selection results of ABS concentrate on the range of [21, 31], while the JSKF results concentrate on [2,18]. Furthermore, the selection results of the proposed algorithm have the widest range. As mentioned above, the wide range selection results reserve the visible wave range spectral information approximately. At the aspect of quantitative analysis, the mutual information and relative mean square error are employed to weight the independence and the difference between the selected bands. As shown in Fig. 16 , the mutual information of the between the selected bands by using the proposed algorithm are smaller than those by using ABS and JSKF, which indicates that selected results by NIA are more independent than the other two algorithm. Besides, the RMSE curves displayed in Fig. 17 demonstrates the errors between the selected bands in proposed method is more dissimilar than the other two sets of data. The statistics evaluations and the curves of the experiments above demonstrate that the proposed algorithm is optimal one, especially for the case that abundant anomaly features are contained in the original hyperspectral image. 4 Conclusion We have presented a bands selection algorithm for hyperspectral image by using ABS and JSKF model in this paper. The hyperspectral data is separated into several sub-spaces automatically by employing ABS and JSKF respectively. Subsequently a novel optimal bands selection method NIA (Normalization Index Algorithm) is proposed to select optimal bands. Two weight factors p and q representing background information and anomaly targets information in NIA serve as the valve of the whole algorithm to interpose the ultimate results. Some numerical simulations have demonstrated the validity and superior performance of the proposed bands selection scheme for hyperspectral image. Acknowledgments This work was supported by the National Natural Science Foundation of China (Grant 11104049) and Specialized Research Fund for the Doctoral Program of Higher education (Grant 20102302120009) and the Program for New Century Excellent Talents in University (NCET-12-0148). The authors are indebted to the two anonymous reviewers for their helpful comments.

column2: Mathematical modelling of optical properties of CdSe/ZnS core shell quantum dot
column3: Abstract In this paper, the electron and hole energies are computed for core/shell quantum dots (CSQDs) using two ways. First, we have resolved the three dimensional Schrödinger equation in the spherical coordinate system. The second approach is based on a combination of coordinate transformation and the finite difference method. The carrier energy levels of CdSe/ZnS CSQD are investigated, then the transition energies and the oscillator strength are deduced.
column5: Keywords CdSe/ZnS Core-shell quantum dot Coordinate transformation Transition energy Oscillator strengths 1 Introduction The last decade has been marked by great progress on the synthetic chemistry of semiconductor nanocrystals (NCs). Among these, the core-shell NCs [1], obtained with II-VI semiconductors, such as CdS/CdSe [2,3], CdSe/ZnS [4,5] and CdTe/ZnS [6]. These hetero-structures present a large mismatch and the band gap of the shell material encloses the band gap of the core and the electrons and holes are confined within the width of semiconductor quantum dot. The CSQDs have been used in many applications, in the optical domain such as QD lasers [7], solar cells [8,9], optical communication [10] and recently for several biological purposes [11]. The different existing shapes for the nanostructures are a consequence of different techniques of growth. For III–V compound semiconductors, we can find pyramidal and lens shapes profile quantum dot [12,13] and due to their complex forms, the calculation of electronic and optical properties of these structures require an extensive theoretical and numerical effort [14,15]. For II–VI quantum dots, the transmission electron microscopy, have shown spherical shapes as shown in Fig. 1 [16] and we also can remark that the CSQDs are not perfectly sphere-shaped. Many theoretical investigations on these structures have been reported and the majority of these authors used the effective mass approximation and have resolved the Schrödinger equation with the spherical coordinates [17–19]. In the present work we have used for modelling CdSe/ZnS CSQDs, both, this method and a mathematical model based on coordinate transformation. The latest model, used in our previous works for modeling different geometrical forms of quantum wires and dots, has given results in agreement with experiment [20–22]. This paper is organized as follows. In Section 2, the details of different methods will be presented. The appropriate choice of coordinate transformation will be also discussed. In Section 3, the electron and hole energy levels, transition energies as well as oscillator strengths are investigated. Finally, conclusions will be presented in Section 4. 2 Theoretical methods 2.1 First mathematical method We consider a spherical quantum dot with a central semiconductor core coated with a larger bandgap semiconductor material acting as a shell. In this core-shell structure the inner radius is denoted by R1 and outer radius by R2 like is shown in Fig. 2 a). The first method consists to resolve the Schrödinger equation of the electron (hole) in the spherical coordinates [23]: (1) − ℏ 2 2 m i * r 2 ∂ ∂ r r 2 ∂ ∂ r + 1 sin θ ∂ ∂ θ sin θ ∂ ∂ θ + 1 sin 2 θ ∂ 2 ∂ ϕ 2 + U p ( r ) ψ n l m ( r , θ , ϕ ) = E ψ n l m ( r , θ , ϕ ) The expression of effective mass m i * and the confined potentials U p ( r ) (Fig. 2b)) of particles is: (2) m i * = m 1 * r ≤ R 1 m 2 * R 1 < r ≤ R 2 (3) U p i ( r ) = 0 r ≤ R 1 V c R 1 < r ≤ R 2 ∞ R 2 < r As the mass and the potential are symmetric spherically, the separation of radial and angular coordinates leads to: (4) ψ n l m ( r , θ , ϕ ) = R n l ( r ) Y l m ( θ , ϕ ) R n l ( r ) is the radial wave function, and Y l m ( θ , ϕ ) is the spherical harmonic, where n is the principal quantum number, l and m are the angular momentum quantum numbers. To achieve the wave function and their corresponding eigenenergy values, the radial function must satisfy the boundary conditions: (5) R n l , 1 ( R 1 ) = R n l , 2 ( R 1 ) and 1 m 1 * d R n l , 1 d r r = R 1 = 1 m 2 * d R n l , 2 d r r = R 1 and the normalization condition: (6) ∫ 0 R 1 r 2 R n l , 1 * R n l , 1 d r + ∫ R 1 R 2 r 2 R n l , 2 * R n l , 2 d r = 1 Two cases need to be considered for the solution of Rnl (r): In the region where E > Up , the solution is a linear combination of spherical Bessel function jl and Neumann function nl and can be written as follows [24]: (7) R n l ( r ) = R n l , 1 = A 1 j l ( k n l , 1 r ) + B 1 n l ( k n l , 1 r ) r ≤ R 1 R n l , 2 = C 1 j l ( k n l , 2 r ) + D 1 n l ( k n l , 2 r ) R 1 < r ≤ R 2 R n l , 3 = 0 r > R 2 Where A1, B1, C1 and D1 are normalized constants and: (8) k n l , 1 = 2 m 1 * E ℏ 2 and k n l , 2 = 2 m 2 * ( E − V c ) ℏ 2 In the region where E < Up , the solution is a linear combination of spherical Bessel function jl , Neumann function nl and Hankel function hl (+) and hl (−) and can be written as follows [24]: (9) R n l ( r ) = R n l , 1 = A 2 j l ( k n l , 1 r ) + B 2 n l ( k n l , 1 r ) r ≤ R 1 R n l , 2 = C 2 h l ( + ) ( i k n l , 2 r ) + D 2 h l ( − ) ( i k n l , 2 r ) R 1 < r ≤ R 2 R n l , 3 = 0 r > R 2 (10) k n l , 1 = 2 m 1 * E ℏ 2 and k n l , 2 = 2 m 2 * ( V c − E ) ℏ 2 2.2 Second mathematical method 2.2.1 The theoretical formulation Our proposed approach for modelling the shape of CSQD shown in Fig. 3 a) and c) in the (x,y) and (z,y) planes, is based on coordinate transformation. The effective mass Schrödinger equation for electrons (holes) in conduction (valence) band in space (x,y,z) is given by: (11) − ℏ 2 2 ∂ ∂ x 1 m * ∂ ψ ∂ x + ∂ ∂ y 1 m * ∂ ψ ∂ y + ∂ ∂ z 1 m * ∂ ψ ∂ z + U p ψ = E ψ where m* is the electron or hole effective mass, Up (x,y,z) is the 3D potential profile determined by the conduction or valence band offset, E and ψ ( x , y , z ) are the quantized energy levels and their corresponding wave function, respectively. We begin by a selection of the coordinate transformation. If ε = ε ( x , y , z ) designates the old coordinate space and β = β ( u , v , w ) the new space with x = x(u,v,w), y = y(u,v,w), z = z(u,v,w). Our purpose is to pass from the old to the new space, an example is shown in Fig. 3. This transformation makes simpler the geometry of the nanostructure leading to flat interfaces in the computational domain. The Schrödinger Eq. (11) can be mapped into β space as: (12) − ℏ 2 2 u x ∂ ψ x 1 ( u , v , w ) ∂ u + v x ∂ ψ x 1 ( u , v , w ) ∂ v + w x ∂ ψ x 1 ( u , v , w ) ∂ w + u y ∂ ψ y 1 ( u , v , w ) ∂ u + v y ∂ ψ y 1 ( u , v , w ) ∂ v + w y ∂ ψ y 1 ( u , v , w ) ∂ w + u z ∂ ψ z 1 ( u , v , w ) ∂ u + v z ∂ ψ z 1 ( u , v , w ) ∂ v + w z ∂ ψ z 1 ( u , v , w ) ∂ w + U p ψ = E ψ with: (13a) ψ x 1 ( u , v , w ) = u x m * ∂ ψ ∂ u + v x m * ∂ ψ ∂ v + w x m * ∂ ψ ∂ w (13b) ψ y 1 ( u , v , w ) = u y m * ∂ ψ ∂ u + v y m * ∂ ψ ∂ v + w y m * ∂ ψ ∂ w (13c) ψ z 1 ( u , v , w ) = u z m * ∂ ψ ∂ u + v z m * ∂ ψ ∂ v + w z m * ∂ ψ ∂ w In Eqs. (12) and (13a)–(13c): ψ[x(u,v,w), y(u,v,w), z(u,v,w)] = ψ(u,v,w), U  p [x(u,v,w), y(u,v,w), z(u,v,w)] = U  p (u,v,w) while u x , u y , u z , v x , v y , v z , w x , w y and w z are the elements of the Jacobian matrix Jx,y,z representing partial derivatives of the inverse functions u = u(x,y,z), v = v(x,y,z) and w = w(x,y,z) with respect to x, y and z, as example, u x = ∂ u ∂ x The Jacobian matrix Juvw corresponding to the transformation x = x(u,v,w), y = y(u,v,w), z = z(u,v,w) is explicit function on u, v and w: (14) J u v w = x u x v x w y u y v y w z u z v z w where subscripts denote the partial derivatives with respect to u, v and w. Thus, the Jacobian matrix Jxyz for the inverse mapping u = u(x,y,z), v = v(x,y,z) and w = w(x,y,z) given by J x y z = J u v w − 1 , an explicit function on u, v and w: (15) J x y z = u x u y u z v x v y v z w x w y w z = x u x v x w y u y v y w z u z v z w − 1 We can remark that, the elements of matrix J x y z depend on the selected coordinate transformation. For the first step and for the shapes that we have to study, we consider the following form of the transformation: (16a) x = Cu (16b) y = Cf(u,v,w) (16c) z = Cw C is a scaling factor, expressed in nanometers. Thus, we obtain: (17a) J u v w = x u x v x w y u y v y w z u z v z w = C 0 0 C f u C f v C f w 0 0 C (17b) J x y z = u x u y u z v x v y v z w x w y w z = 1 / C 0 0 − f u / ( C f v ) 1 / ( C f v ) − f w / ( C f v ) 0 0 1 / C = 1 C 1 0 0 μ ρ λ 0 0 1 where fu , fv and fw are derivatives of f(u,v,w) with respect to u, v and w. μ = C . v x = − f u / f v , ρ = C . v y = 1 / f v and λ = C . v z = − f w / f v . We note that the determinant of the Jacobian matrix is not zero and we obtain J x y z = J u v w − 1 = C 3 f v ≠ 0 . The second step consists on the mapping of the Hamiltonian into the new coordinate space using the Jacobian matrix for the selected coordinate transformation. In our problem, the Eq. (12) is simplified, using the transformation (17b), and becomes: (18) − ℏ 2 2 C 2 ∂ ∂ u 1 m * ∂ ψ ∂ u + μ m * ∂ ψ ∂ v + μ ∂ ∂ v 1 m * ∂ ψ ∂ u + μ m * ∂ ψ ∂ v + ρ ∂ ∂ v ρ m * ∂ ψ ∂ v + λ ∂ ∂ v λ m * ∂ ψ ∂ v + 1 m * ∂ ψ ∂ w + ∂ ∂ w λ m * ∂ ψ ∂ v + 1 m * ∂ ψ ∂ w + U p ψ = E ψ Thus and in the third step, the above equation is discretized using 3D finite difference method. We consider Nu , Nv and Nw the number of points in each direction u, v and w, the discretization equation is given in considering the following in boundary conditions: (19) ψ 0 , j , k = ψ N u + 1 , j , k = 0 ψ i , 0 , k = ψ i , N v + 1 , k = 0 ψ i , j , 0 = ψ i , j , N w + 1 = 0 (20) − ℏ 2 2 C 2 A u u 1 1 m * i + 1 / 2 , j , k − A u u 2 1 m * i − 1 / 2 , j , k + A u v 1 μ m * i + 1 / 2 , j , k − A u v 2 μ m * i − 1 / 2 , j , k + μ i , j , k A v u 1 1 m * i , j + 1 / 2 , k − A v u 2 1 m * i , j − 1 / 2 , k + A v v 1 μ m * i , j + 1 / 2 , k − A v v 2 μ m * i , j − 1 / 2 , k + ρ i , j , k A v v 1 ρ m * i , j + 1 / 2 , k − A v v 2 ρ m * i , j − 1 / 2 , k + λ i , j , k A v v 1 λ m * i , j + 1 / 2 , k − A v v 2 λ m * i , j − 1 / 2 , k + A v w 1 1 m * i , j + 1 / 2 , k − A v w 2 1 m * i , j − 1 / 2 , k + A w v 1 λ m * i , j , k + 1 / 2 − A w v 2 λ m * i , j , k − 1 / 2 + A w w 1 1 m * i , j , k + 1 / 2 − A w w 2 1 m * i , j , k − 1 / 2 + U p i , j , k ψ i , j , k = E i , j , k ψ i , j , k where: (21) A u u 1 = ψ i + 1 , j , k − ψ i , j , k h u 2 , A u v 1 = ψ i + 1 / 2 , j + 1 / 2 , k − ψ i + 1 / 2 , j − 1 / 2 , k h u h v , A v u 1 = ψ i + 1 / 2 , j + 1 / 2 , k − ψ i − 1 / 2 , j + 1 / 2 , k h v h u A u u 2 = ψ i , j , k − ψ i − 1 , j , k h u 2 , A u v 2 = ψ i − 1 / 2 , j + 1 / 2 , k − ψ i − 1 / 2 , j − 1 / 2 , k h u h v , A v u 2 = ψ i + 1 / 2 , j − 1 / 2 , k − ψ i − 1 / 2 , j − 1 / 2 , k h v h u A v v 1 = ψ i , j + 1 , k − ψ i , j , k h v 2 , A v w 1 = ψ i , j + 1 / 2 , k + 1 / 2 − ψ i , j + 1 / 2 , k − 1 / 2 h v h w , A w v 1 = ψ i , j + 1 / 2 , k + 1 / 2 − ψ i , j − 1 / 2 , k + 1 / 2 h w h v A v v 2 = ψ i , j , k − ψ i , j − 1 , k h v 2 , A v w 2 = ψ i , j − 1 / 2 , k + 1 / 2 − ψ i , j − 1 / 2 , k − 1 / 2 h v h w , A w v 2 = ψ i , j + 1 / 2 , k − 1 / 2 − ψ i , j − 1 / 2 , k − 1 / 2 h w h v A w w 1 = ψ i , j , k + 1 − ψ i , j , k h w h w , A w w 2 = ψ i , j , k − ψ i , j , k − 1 h w h w In the above expression, i, j and k are indices of the discretization points, while hu, hv and hw are the discretization steps, along u, v and w coordinate, respectively. We obtain a generalized eigenvalue problem, B X = λ X , where X is an eigenvector corresponding to the eigenvalue λ , B is a sparse and band matrix. Once the general forms of the matrices involved is established, there are several computer packages available which can be used to solve this system of equations. In our work we have used the package LAPACK. In the next step, we propose to study the coordinate transformation which can fit the shape of core-shell quantum dot 2.2.2 Choice of the coordinate transformation In this part, we will be interested to adjust the different parameters to find a realistic approach for CSQD shapes, and we propose to use the following coordinate transformation: (22a) x = C u (22b) y = C sinh ( A . v ) K cosh ( B u ) cosh ( D . w ) , is the detailed expression of 16b (22c) z = C w Let us study the effect of parameters A, B, D and K on the shape of the quantum dot for fixed value of v = 1.5 and C = 1 nm. From Fig. 4 a) and b), we can note that the peak of the function increases with A, however, an increase in K, leads to a decrease in the hauteur of the function. When we increase the couple B, D, the width of quantum dot decreases, like is shown in Fig. 4c). The variable v plays an important role on form of quantum dot. For fixed values of A, K, B and D, the peak and the width of the function increases with positive values of v. The function is also decreases and is negative with negative values, as shown in Fig. 5 . Also, we can notice that the function is symmetric with respect to the axes u and w and finally we can conclude that the parameters A, K, B, D and the variable v, playing a very important role on the fitting of the shape of core shell quantum dot. It is therefore relatively easy to plot a geometrical form of CSQD. The CSQD profile in ε -space shown in Fig. 3a) and c) in the (x,y) and (z,y) planes respectively, are mapped in the β -space, the corresponding computational domains are in (u,v) and (w,v) planes (Fig. 3b) and d)) and it is therefore a parallelepiped. For fixed values of parameters A, K, B, D and C, the real dimensions of core and shell depend of the variation of computational domain in u, the variation domain in v and the variation domain in w and therefore we have: D C o r e u = [ u 1 , u 2 ] , D C o r e v = [ v 1 , v 2 ] , D C o r e w = [ w 1 , w 2 ] , D S h e l l u = [ u 3 , u 4 ] , D S h e l l v = [ v 3 , v 4 ] and D S h e l l w = [ w 3 , w 4 ] , which corresponds in ε -space to D C o r e x = [ x 1 , x 2 ] , D C o r e y = [ y 1 , y 2 ] , D C o r e z = [ z 1 , z 2 ] , D S h e l l x = [ x 3 , x 4 ] , D S h e l l y = [ y 3 , y 4 ] , D S h e l l z = [ z 3 , z 4 ] with: x 2 − x 1 2 = a S x 4 − x 3 2 = a C z 2 − z 1 2 = c S z 4 − z 3 2 = c C y 2 − y 1 2 = b S y 4 − y 3 2 = b C Due to complex form of CSQDs, the resolution of Schrödinger equation in ε -space is very difficult and this transformation makes it easier in β -space using the finite difference method. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Energy levels We start our work with numerical simulation of the electron and hole energy levels for the spherical quantum dot using the first method. The effects of the core and shell sizes on the energy levels have been studied. The parameters used in our calculations are listed in Table 1 [25]. We note that the conduction band minimum and the valence band maximum of the different cores are taken as references for electron and hole energy levels respectively. Fig. 6 a) illustrates the effect of core thickness for fixed value of shell width in CdSe/ZnS CSQD. We can remark that the electron and hole energies decrease when increasing the core radius. It is straightforward to mention from Fig. 6b) that the electron energy shows the same behaviour with the shell thickness at fixed value of core width. The hole energy is insensitive to core thickness change. These same behaviours of charge carriers have been underlined in the works of Zgaren et al for CdSe/ZnS CSQD and for different II-VI nanocrystals [26]. In the target to compare the two proposed methods for the same widths of the two shapes of CSQD illustrated in Fig. 7 , our calculated values of energy levels for electrons and holes are listed in Table 2 . We have considered three dimensions of the CSQD, with R1  = aC  = bC  = cC and R2  = aS  = bS  = cS . E1e (E1h ) and E2e (E2h ) are the electron (hole) energy levels using the first and the second approaches. As can be seen, the energies are very similar for 2 nm and 4 nm core and shell thicknesses respectively. However, the discrepancy increases with the core and shell sizes, the ratios E 2 e − E 1 e E 1 e and E 2 h − E 1 h E 1 h reach 80% for electrons and 100% for holes with 4nm and 6nm core and shell thicknesses. This behaviour can be explained by the difference between the geometric shapes and the volume of the two CSQD forms used in this work. In the aim to achieve the same electron energies E1e , obtained with the first method (Table 2), we have examined the new dimensions of modelled shape and we have calculated the new energies using the second theoretical approach. The corrected values of the thickness listed in Table 3 are a’C  = b’C  = c’C  = 2.15, 3.85 and 5.15 nm for the core and a’S  = b’S  = c’S  = 4.3, 6.41 and 7.72nm for the shell. We can note that, the ratio between the new and the old dimensions is of 1.075, 1.283 1.287 for the first, the second and the third structure respectively. The new hole energy values E 2 h * calculated with the second method (Table 4 ), for the different corrected structures, are in agreement with those (E1h ) obtained with spherical CSQDs (Table 2), the ratio E 2 h * − E 1 h E 1 h does not exceed 5.9%. 3.2 Optical properties: transition energy, wavelength and oscillator strength The new dimensions of CSQD listed in Table 3 are used to study and carry out the quantum efficiency of a transition. We have calculated the corresponding transition energies, wavelengths and the oscillator strengths given by the expression [22,27]: (23) f m → k = 2 m 0 ℏ 2 ( E m − E k ) 〈 ψ m l ψ k 〉 2 where (Em – Ek) is the energy difference between the initial ψm and final ψk states and 〈 ψ m l ψ k 〉 is the dipole matrix element of the transition between the initial and the final states. In our case we are interesting on the interband transition, m0 is the free electron effective mass. The results are listed in Table 4. The transition energy decreases with core thickness and varies in the range 1.912–2.245 eV, which corresponds to emission wavelength range 0.648–0.552 μ m . Many experimental data with photoluminescence spectra confirmed these results [28–31]. In the Ref. [28] for example, the authors mentioned that the emission wavelength found for quantum dot sizes 2.4 ± 0.2 n m , 2.9 ± 0.4 n m and 4.4 ± 0.9 n m , are 0.504 ± 0.006 μ m , 0.537 ± 0.006 μ m and 0.590 ± 0.030 μ m respectively. For better comparison with the experience, we must take into account the effect of the coulomb interaction. The corresponding oscillator strength values decrease when the transition energies augment. This behavior can be explained by a decrease in overlap wave functions. In contrast to the first mathematical method presented in this manuscript, the second has the advantage of being able to be applied for non-concentric core shell and can be developed for others CSQDs and auto-organized quantum dots. 4 Conclusions We have presented in this paper two mathematical methods to model the core-shell quantum dots. The first is based in the spherical coordinate, the second on a coordinate transformation. The energy levels for corrected structures are in agreement with experimental data and can be generalized for others CSQD. The obtained wavelength range 0.552–0.648 μ m achieved with the spherical CSQD and the adjusted structure modeled with second method is very important for solar cells conception. Our proposed method has the advantage of being able to be developed for auto-organized quantum dots. It offers a fast and inexpensive way to check device designs and processes and can provide good guidance for the selection of CSQD parameters to experimental studies.

column2: Detection of magnesium ion concentration using fiber coupler based displacement sensor with concave mirror target
column3: Abstract Detection of magnesium ion concentration was successfully demonstrated using a fiber coupler based displacement sensor probe in conjunction with a concave mirror target. Analysis of peak voltage result, which was obtained by moving a sensing port displacement from a fixed concave mirror (CM) was found to be useful to detect a magnesium ion concentration, which is filled in between the probe and target. The proposed sensor is capable for measuring magnesium ion with variation of concentration 0–5%. The resolution of the sensor can be achieved at 0.2%. It was also observed that the use of CM with a longer focal length improves the sensitivity of the sensor. The high sensitivity, the small size, the ease fabrication process, and the bio-compatibility of the proposed device are appealing characteristics that makes it ideal for practical bio-sensing applications.
column5: Keywords Fiber coupler Displacement sensor Concave mirror Refraction 1 Introduction Detections of refractive index and concentration of liquid solution have widely been reported using various fiber-optic sensors [1–5]. Owing to the intrinsic characteristics of the optical fiber, these sensors are in general simple to fabricate, compact, robust, immune to electromagnetic radiation, chemical and biological inert, and can be integrated in complex networks for real-time multiple parameter sensing. In recent years, many important advances were achieved in the fiber optic sensor technology; in terms of sensitivity, resolution, dynamic range, response time, signal to noise ratio and fabrication techniques. These advances have also promoted the development of optical fiber chemical sensors and biosensors [1,2]. For instance, the side-emitting technique was conducted using fiber optic micro-bend [3] and tapered fiber [4] to detect refractive index of chlorinated water and concentration of uric acid, respectively. Optical fibers coated with silver thin layer [5] and nanocomposite of ZnO-polypyrrol [6] were also used to detect concentration of uric acid and manganese ion based on surface plasmon resonance (SPR). Coreless fiber [7] and thin core fiber [8] connected to single mode fiber were used to detect concentration of sucrose and refractive index of solution, respectively. A method based on displacement sensor can also be used to measure the concentration or refractive index of solution. For instance, a displacement sensor with a bundled fiber probe was capable of measuring refractive of solution [9], glucose concentration [10], calcium [11] and salinity [12]. This type of sensor works based on detection the output voltage as the displacement between sensor probe and mirror immersed in liquid of the solution sample is varied. Fiber coupler is an optical device that can be used to split a beam of light. It was used as a displacement sensor using a mirror as a target [13]. Based on the displacement sensor, fiber coupler was also employed as a level sensor [14] and a Rhodamine B concentration sensor [15] using a concave mirror (CM) as a target in conjunction with a green light source. In this paper, we propose a new displacement sensor for measuring magnesium ion concentration using a fiber coupler as a probe and a concave mirror as a target. The magnesium ions detection is explored in this study since the ion is very important for the human in energy metabolism process, protein synthesis, muscle contraction, fat breakdown, DNA stability, and cell growth. Lack of magnesium ions in the body will affect health even can cause disease and cancer [16]. Therefore, the magnesium ions sensing device is becoming important especially for the food and beverage industry in order to meet the needs of magnesium ions that are perceived by the body. 2 Working principle of the sensor Mechanism of magnesium ion detection using fiber coupler and concave mirror (CM) is shown in Fig. 1 . Light source of the laser is coupled to input port of the coupler, part of the output light beam from the sensing port (Pe ) enter to concave mirror. Medium between sensor port and CM is the testing sample. Partial of the reflected light beam from CM passed through a sensing port (Pb ) and then transmitted to the detection port (Pd ). The distance between sensing port and CM is attributed by d. If position of sensing port is changed in relation to CM, then the detected optical power as function of d is given by [15]; (1) P d = P 0 1 − exp − 2 d − f 2 / f 2 d 2 − 2 d f d − f a tan sin − 1 N A n + 1 2 where a, NA, f and n is core of radius, numerical aperture, focal length of CM and refractive index of medium between sensing port and CM, respectively. P0 can be written by equation as follows; (2) P 0 = 1.15 c r 1 − c r 10 − 0.1 L e − 2 × 10 − 0.1 D 2 P i n , where cr, Le , and D are coupling ratio, excess loss, and directivity of fiber coupler respectively. While Pin optical power of the laser which is coupled to input port [13]. Optical power of laser is measured by an optical detector using digital voltmeter in term of output voltage (Pd ). Output power is proportional to output voltage. When Eq. (1) is simulated, we can obtain the curve showing the relationship between output voltage (V) and d. The curve also indicates a peak voltage at a certain location. The value of Vp increase with refractive index of medium. If we assumed that refractive index is a linear function to magnesium ion concentration in solution as a medium, then the test sample of magnesium ion concentration can be read from the peak voltage. Variation of position scanning between sensing port and concave mirror is used to obtained peak voltage. 3 Experimental Setup The schematic experimental setup for the proposed magnesium ion concentration sensor is shown in Fig. 2 . It consists of a He-Ne laser (with wavelength of 632.8nm and maximum power of 10mW), fiber coupler and silicon detector. The fiber coupler probe was constructed from a multimode plastic fiber with structure 2×2, diameter of 1mm, 50/50 splitting ratio, 4dB insertion loss and 1.6dB excess loss. A CM with two different focal length 4.5 and 6mm was used as reflector. CM was placed on the bottom sample tube with diameter of 4cm and 3cm height. The positioning of the fiber coupler sensing port was accomplished by mounting it on a micro-displacement meter, which was rigidly attached to a vibration free table. Light from the fiber coupler input port was coupled into the sensing port. The signal from sensing port was measured by moving the probe away from the zero point, where the reflective surface of concave mirror and the probe were in close contact. The signal from the optical detector was converted into voltage and was measured by a digital voltmeter. The output intensity was measured by changing the position of the fiber coupler sensing port, which functions as probe from 0 to 15mm in step of 100μm. The measurements were carried out for magnesium ion with concentrations of 1, 2, 3, 4 and 5%. During the experiment, temperature was kept constant to that error due to temperature fluctuation is negligible. 4 Result and Discussion Detection of magnesium ion concentration was obtained by monitoring the output voltage while the displacement between the sensing port and CM is varied. The initial position of the sensing port is about 2mm above the center of the CM. The curves related to the output voltage as function of displacement sensing port was measured for two different CMs for comparison purpose. The results are analyzed and plotted as shown in Fig. 3 . Figs. 3(a) and (b) shows the displacement curves with CM1 and CM2, which has a focal length 6 and 12mm, respectively. The measurement error for both curves is obtained at around 0.6mV. It is shown that the peak voltage position was obtained at around 7.0mm and 9.5mm for the displacement curves with CM1 and CM2, respectively. It is worthy to note that CM 1 and CM 2 has a diameter of 9.0mm and 12.0mm, respectively. In the experiment, the starting position of sensing port was at 2.0m from surface of concave mirror. Compare to reference of 12, the main novelty of the proposed setup is applying fiber coupler probe as element sensing. In this probe, we have a first peak voltage at very close distance, therefore the sensor is suitable for a shorter distance measurement. Figs. 4 (a) and (b) show the peak voltage position at various magnesium ion concentrations for CM1 and CM2 target respectively. It is shown from both figures that peak voltage position changes irregularly with the variation of magnesium ion concentration. Therefore, it is difficult to predict magnesium ion concentration using the peak voltage position. Correlation between peak voltage value and magnesium ion concentration is shown in Fig. 5 . It indicates a linear trend relation between the peak voltage and magnesium ion concentration. The linearity is more than 99%. Therefore, we can determine value of concentration based on value of peak voltage. Slope of the curve in Fig. 5 defines sensitivity of the sensor, which indicates CM2 produces a better sensitivity than that of CM1. This is attributed to the longer focal length that allows the sensing fiber port to collect more light and increases the sensitivity. The refractive index of various magnesium ion concentrations was also measured using Abbe refractometer and the result is summarized in Fig. 6 . The result shows that the refractive index is linearly correlated with the concentration. Therefore, this approach can be used for detection of magnesium ion concentration. The stability of the sensor was then tested for 720s for each interval 30s and the result is presented in Fig. 7 . Fig. 7 shows the sensor has a high stability with standard of deviation is 0.4mV (0.1%) and 0.5mV (0.11%) for CM 1 and CM 2, respectively. Resolution of the sensor is defined by ratio of standard deviation over sensitivity (slope of the linear curve). Overall, performance of the proposed magnesium ion concentration sensor using fiber coupler probe for CM 1 and CM 2 is summarized in Table 1 . Table 1 shows that sensitivity of the sensor with CM 1 is higher than sensor with CM 2, therefore the sensor resolution with CM 2 is lower than CM 1 (1/1.5 times). The results indicate that fiber coupler based displacement sensor can be used for detection of magnesium ion concentration. During the experiment, the error due to this temperature variation is negligible as the temperature is kept constant at 25°C. Based on a simple calculation, a response time or bandwidth of optical detector is used in this experiment can be found at 0.175kHz. 5 Conclusion Fiber optic coupler based displacement sensor configured with CM was proposed and demonstrated for detection of magnesium ion concentration. The results shows that a peak voltage of the sensor is linear to the concentration with the best resolution is obtained at 0.2% and range of 0–5%. The use of CM with a longer focal length improves the sensitivity of the sensor. The simplicity and low cost of the sensor make it suitable for various industrial applications. Acknowledgement This work was supported by the Airlangga University through “Mandat Grant” No: 569/UN3/2017.
