column2: Electromagnetic radiation analysis of planar, segmented and circular array antenna in THz applications
column3: Abstract The electromagnetic radiation of three types of antenna arrays, such as planar, three-segmented and circular are designed, analyzed and compared in view of their applications in communication systems for THz applications. Each array consists of a number of sub-arrays which consists of vertical linear arrays of patch antennas, with certain values of intensities and phase distributions that determine the shape of beam in vertical direction. In this paper, the ranges of angles for beam scanning of planar array, segmented array and circular array are simulated with MATLAB in Terahertz frequency range. The beam steering capabilities of each array are analyzed and a comparative analysis at 1THz frequency is reported.
column5: Keywords Microstrip antennas Adaptive arrays Beam steering Scanning angle range Electromagnetic radiation 1 Introduction The antennas with beamsteering facility make them intelligent by improving range and channel capacity while reducing the interference. These types of antennas have significantly huge application in military and space systems. With advanced techniques of antenna fabrication, beamsteering can be achieved with less complex and compact patch antennas. Several applications of continuous millimetre (mm) and sub-millimetre (smm) wave signals with photonics technology attract great attention in recent research [1–3]. The factors like high-speed measurements, spectroscopy techniques, with wireless communications, also the supply of local signals for radio telescopes are discussed. A uni-travelling carrier photodiode (UTC-PD) with log-periodic toothed wide band antenna generates mm and smm waves at terahertz frequencies were investigated by Hiroshi Ito et al. [4]. A thorough research of the operational characteristics of the UTC-PD reveals the use of electron-velocity overshoot on the depletion layer is important for increasing the output power in the THz frequency range. Photomixers which produce high-frequency signals with photoconductive switch using low-temperature-grown GaAs (LT-GaAs) are most widely used [5,6]. Also, sub-millimetre wave generation at up to 5 THz has been reported, though with quick response the device can also work for long-wavelength (λ ≈ 0.8 μm) light signal [7]. A dual band dipole antenna in THz frequency range, with a novel small flat quartz-copper reflector has been reported [8]. Such an antenna supports maximum gain of 12.4 dB at 5.2 THz frequency with two main resonant frequencies at 2.58 THz and 5.33 THz, and can be used as an array element in linear and planar sets of elements, which were evaluated by using array techniques. This enables high conversion efficiency from dc to radiated power in THz range. The design evolution of the distributed active radiator (DAR) follows from an inverse design approach. On the other hand, a two dimensional 4 × 4 radiating antenna without high-resistivity substrate array has been implemented in 45 nm SOI CMOS and it radiates with a maximum gain of 9.4 dB at 0.28 THz. Also beam steering capabilities in 2-dimension over 80° in both azimuth and elevation has been reported in this work [9]. This chip dissipates 820 mW of DC power and reported integrated beam-scanning array at THz frequencies in silicon. In the past few years, research activities in the terahertz frequency range (0.3–3 THz) led to the development of several applications ranging from ultrafast wireless communication, imaging, low-cost diagnostics to remote sensing, spectroscopy and quality control [10,11]. A polymide based optical MPA at THz frequency has been presented and discussed [12]. This proposed antenna with 5.22 dB gain has impedance bandwidth 40.16 GHz and applicable for video rate imaging system and homeland defence applications which has frequency range 0.6 THz–0.8 THz. Another THz patch antenna based on Graphene nano ribbon on polymide substrate has been presented by S. Anand et al. and its radiation characteristics are analyzed in 0.725 THz–0.775 THz band, a bandwidth of 50 GHz [13]. Such terahertz antenna system can generate and transmit at high data rates, low transmitted power with secured wireless communication. Yagi antenna with a graphene loop added to dipole radiator in 1 THz frequency range can achieve high gain [14]. There is a demand for antennas that can transmit signals at higher data rates as wireless communications are shifting attention towards frequencies above 100 GHz. Higher Q- factor, higher bandwidth with high gain pattern are the benefits of the novel structure that are important in THz systems. Kallnichev studied the beam-steering and directive characteristics of adaptive antenna arrays in microwave region [15]. By proper consideration of antenna array parameters this work can be extended in THz region, as this region of EM spectrum is attracting more and more attention due to its capability of carrying high data rate. In this paper, electromagnetic radiation-patterns of two dimensional planar, three-segmented and circular antenna arrays have been analysed and simulated. Their radiation patterns are compared in the THz frequency band for photonics applications. 2 Theoretical analysis Three simple configurations of antenna array systems are planar array, three segment array and circular array [16]. The analysis of electromagnetic radiation patterns of these three configurations has been presented with comparison. In this paper, by considering N × M two dimensional antenna arrays which is consisting of N number vertical linear subarrays of M number of antennas. In planar array, antennas are arranged along a plane with vertical separation dh as shown in Fig. 1 . In Fig. 2 , a three-segment array in a quasi-planar structure has been shown, in which two edge segments are bent. For circular array, equally spaced N vertical subarrays along with arc of radius ‘r’ are formed as shown in Fig.3 . The length and width sizes are determined for each radiating patch are L = 39.5 μm and W = 56.8 μm, with the impedance matching at central frequency at 1 THz, which is applicable for beam steering antenna. In this section theoretical analysis of each configuration with electromagnetic radiation pattern has been presented. 2.1 Planar array antenna A planar array of N × M elements can produce a large aperture, and can be used for generating directional beam. The directional beam thus produced can be controlled by varying the relative phase of each radiator. Planar arrays provide more number of symmetrical patterns with lower side lobes. It has high directivity with narrow main directional beam. As shown in Fig. 1 the elemental antennas are arranged along a plane and formed an N × M planar array. The vertical spacing between two elements is dv and the horizontal spacing is dh. The radiation pattern of this array is given by Eq. (1). (1) F p l θ , ∅ = ∑ m = 1 M ∑ n = 1 N e j ( m - 1 ) ( k d v . c o s θ . s i n ∅ + δ m ) F n m θ , ∅ . e j ( n - 1 ) ( k d h s i n θ . c o s ∅ + δ n ) where δm and δn are the phase difference in adjacent element or progressive phase shift in vertical and horizontal direction respectively. Fnm (θ, ∅ ) is the radiation pattern of a patch radiator, located in nth column and mth row and given by Eq. (2). (2) F n , m θ , ∅ = sin ∅ . sin ( 0.5 k w cos ∅ ) cos ∅ . cos 0.5 k L e sin ∅ cos θ In Eq. (2), ‘k’ represents the wave number vector directed towards the observation point P in far field zone. The rectangular patch radiator has width ‘w’ and effective length ‘Le’. The Radiation pattern of planar array with main beam steer in the direction (θ0, ∅ 0) is given by Eq. (3). (3) F p l θ , ∅ = ∑ m = 1 M ∑ n = 1 N F n m θ , ∅ . e j k d v ( m - 1 ) ( c o s θ . s i n ∅ - c o s θ ° ) . e j k d h ( n - 1 ) ( s i n θ . c o s ∅ - s i n θ ° c o s ∅ ° ) 2.2 Three segmented array antenna To increase the scanning range of planar array in a three segment array antenna, two edges of planar array are bent and oriented them at same angle ∅ b with respect to the central planar array. Front and top view of three segment array is shown in Figs. 2 and 3 respectively. In this case two edge subarrays of planar array bent at an angle ∅ b. The central segment contains several sub-arrays and act as a planar array. The analysis of electromagnetic radiation of a three segment array antenna is quite similar to that of circular structure. The reference point is selected at the intersection of two perpendiculars through the midpoints of two side segments as shown in Fig. 3. The distance of each radiating element from midpoint is r1, r2, r3, r4 and r5 respectively and ∅ 1 , ∅ 2 , ∅ 3 , ∅ 4 and ∅ 5 are respective angles in between the adjacent radiator.The electromagnetic radiation pattern of three segmented array antenna is given by Eq. F 1 , n m θ , ∅ 1 , n m . e j ( k r n s i n θ . c o s ∅ + δ n ) where δm and δn are the phase differences in adjacent element or progressive phase shift in vertical and horizontal direction respectively. Three segment array antenna considered in our study contains five columns and five rows as shown in Figs. 3 and 4 , with r1, r2, r3, r4 and r5 respectively representing the distances of sub-arrays from the centre, which are given by Eqs. (14) is the radiation pattern equation for five columns & five rows of segmented array. 2.3 Circular array antenna Circular array consists of a set of identical rectangular patches which are uniformly spaced around a circle with radius ‘r’. Schematic diagram of circular array has been presented in Fig. 4. In the present analysis, equally spaced N vertical subarrays are arranged along an arc of radius ‘r’. Radiation pattern of this type of circular array is given by Eq. (4). (15) F c i r c u l a r θ , ∅ = ∑ m = 1 M ∑ n = 1 N e j m - 1 k d v c o s θ s i n ∅ + δ m . F 1 , n m e j n - 1 k r s i n θ c o s ∅ + δ n Where δm and δn are the phase difference in adjacent element or progressive phase shift in vertical and horizontal direction respectively. Here ‘k’ represents the wave vector directed towards the observation point P in far field zone and dv represents the vertical spacing between the radiating patch. F1,nm is the radiation pattern of an element located in the nth column and mth row and is given by Eq. (16). (16) F 1 , n m θ , ∅ 1 , n m = s i n ∅ 1 , n m s i n 0.5 k w c o s ∅ 1 , n m c o s ∅ 1 , n m c o s 0.5 k L e s i n ∅ 1 , n m c o s θ with 0 < ∅ 1,nm<π and ∅ 1,nm =90 +  ∅ - ∅ n The radiation pattern of circular array is given by Eq. (17). (17) F c i r c u l a r θ , ∅ = ∑ n = 1 N ∑ m = 1 M e j k d v m - 1 c o s θ s i n ∅ - c o s θ ° . F 1 , n m e j k r s i n θ c o s ∅ - ∅ n - s i n θ ° c o s ∅ ° - ∅ n 3 Result and analysis The electromagnetic radiation patterns of the planar, three-segment and circular array antennas have been analyzed using Eqs. (3), (14) and (17) respectively. 3.1 Analysis of planar array The elevation angle is fixed at θ = θ° = 90° in the one dimensional azimuth beam tracking characteristics. The presented results are obtained by considering N = 5 of vertical subarrays for three types of array configurations. In this case, the subarrays are placed side by side and separation of midline by spacing of dh = 0.5 λ. Each column subarray contains M = 5 patches with uniform magnitude and phase distribution. The vertical spacing between patches are dv = 0.8 λ, in order to obtain a 3 dB beam width about 16° in the elevation. The length and width are determined for each radiating patch which are L = 39.5 μm and W = 56.8 μm, with the impedance matching at central frequency (1 THz), which is applicable for beam steering antenna. The radiation pattern of beam steering antenna in planar array configuration with N linear subarrays of M patch radiators is the product of the space factor and element pattern of planar configuration array antenna. The directive beams of planar array consisting N × M i.e. 5 × 5 and at 1 THz frequency, with varying ∅ in different angles(π/2,π/3 and π/6) is shown in Fig. 5 . Planar array with 5 subarrays has achieved the scanning angles π/2, π/3 and π/6 with high gain and directivity. 3.2 Analysis of three-segment array The three segment array consists of planar array with two edges are bent and oriented at same angle ∅ b with respect to the central planar array. The central segment only acts as planar array. The normalized patterns for the 3-segment array antenna with bend angle of ∅ b = 45◦has shown in Fig. 6 . The electromagnetic radiation pattern of five subarrays segmented array antenna analysis has been carried for ∅ =π/2, ∅ = π /3 and ∅ = π /8 as shown in Fig. 6. The 3 segmented array structure has capability to steer the radiation pattern up to π /8 which is better than planar array as shown in Fig. 5. The column subarrays had the radii, a1 = a5 = 1.31 λ, a2 = a4 = 1.21 λ, a3 = 1.1 λ and angle coordinates are ∅ 1 = 45◦, ∅ 2 = 65.6◦, ∅ 3 = 90◦, ∅ 4 = 114.4◦ and ∅ 5 = 135◦. 3.3 Analysis of circular array For the circular array antenna,the radius of the circular arc, r = 0.95 λ has been selected to for 30° angular separation between the adjacent columns, with their angular coordinates were ∅ 1 = π/6, ∅ 2 = π/3, ∅ 3 = π/2, ∅ 4 = −π/3 and ∅ 5 = −π/6. The directive beam is steered from ∅  = π/2 to ∅  = 0 plane but the beamwidth and sidelobe levels both are increased, consequently both, gain and directivity decreased.The azimuth plane normalized radiation patterns of circular array are calculated for the values of ∅ 0 = π/2, π/3 and π/12 as shown in Fig. 7 . The circular array can steer the beam up to π/12, which is much better than planar and segmented array. Yet both gain and directivity are reduced. Scanning range is improved. But fabrication of circular array is more difficult than planar and segmented array. Similar simulations can be carried out for larger values of M and N like for larger array N ≥ 9 sub-arrays, the planar configurations are to be more preferred as the aperture size of it is enough to provide the required scan of 120°, also it has highest directivity as compared to circular and segmented curved structures. 4 Conclusion In this paper the electromagnetic radiation patterns of three different configurations of adaptive array antennas have been analyzed and compared with respect to their beam scanning capabilities in terahertz range. All three systems of planar, 3-segmented and circular array antennas are formed using same vertical linear sub-arrays of microstrip patch radiators. The planar array is providing scanning angles of π/2, π/3 and π/6. In case of 3-segmented array, scanning range capabilities increased and it can scan up to π/8. In case of circular array, it is found that beam scanning capability increased drastically and it can scan from π/2 to 0, which is better than planar array and segmented array. The three segment array has a narrower beam than that of circular array, which gives better directivity. The analysis has carried out for 1 THz frequency. Similar analysis can be carried out for 0.3–3 THz frequency range with more number of radiating patches. Acknowledgments Authors would like to thank Dr. Kh. S. Singh, Reader, D. J. (PG) College, Baraut, Baghpat, UP, India for the valuable input and support.

column2: Numerical modelling of auto-organized InAs/ InP quantum wires with different shapes
column3: Abstract In this paper, energy levels of electrons and holes for different shapes of isolated and self-organized InAs/InP quantum wire are calculated. We have used a theoretical method based on the coordinate transformation employing a newly analytical function to resolve the Schrödinger equation. The purpose of this work is to show how the shape of the quantum wire depend on the parameters introduced in the function and to discuss the effect of the wire height on the energy levels. The optical transitions energies are also investigated.
column5: Keywords InAs/InP Coordinate transformation FDM Transition energy 1 Introduction In the past few years, the low-dimensional semiconductor structures like quantum dots, quantum wires, and quantum wells have aroused much attention due to their fundamental properties and their wide range application such as light emitting diodes [1–3], solar cells [4,5], medicine [6,7] and quantum computing [8]. Among them, the quantum wires, the charge carriers (electrons and holes) are confined in two dimensions. The quantum confinement of carriers in QWs leads to spectrally sharp energy levels depending on the shape and the size of quantum wires. Using the growth techniques of semiconductor nanostructures like molecular-beam epitaxy [9], it was possible to obtain a certain type of cross-sections such as dome, lens-shaped, T-shaped [10], elliptical [11] and V-groove quantum wires [12–15]. These quantum wires have been obtained in a variety of materials such as GaAs/AlGaAs [16–19], InAs/InP [20] and InGaAs/GaAs [21]. Many theoretical and numerical methods are used for modelling and simulating such different shapes and forms of isolated and self-organized quantum wires [22]. In this paper, focus will be on the modelling of different shapes of InAs quantum wire embedded in InP matrix. We will also study its electronic properties, suggesting a numerical method based on the combination of coordinate transformation and the FDM. In the second section, we will present the description of this method, exposing the choice of coordinate transformation which can model the structures of dome and lens-shaped quantum wire. In the third section, we will investigate the influence of the quantum wire shape and height on the electron and hole energy levels, and transition energies. In Section 4, we will finalise by drawing the conclusions of this paper. 2 Theoretical method 2.1 Theoretical formulation In the following, we present a general and theoretical method for modelling a semiconductor quantum wire with different geometrical shapes in order to investigate their properties. We start from the envelope function approximation (EFA) 2D Schrödinger equation for electrons (holes) in conduction (valence) band: (1) − ℏ 2 2 ∇ 1 m * x , y ∇ ψ x , y + V x , y ψ x , y = E ψ x , y We can obtain the electron (hole) energy levels E and their corresponding wave function ψ ( x , y ) by solving this equation. where ψ x , y is the varying part of the total wave function, m* is the electron or hole effective mass, E is the confinement energy and V x , y is the total potential which is given by: V x , y = ℏ 2 k z 2 2 m * + V p x , y V p x , y is the 2D potential profile determined by the conduction or valence band offset, we can write Eq. (1) as: (2) − ℏ 2 2 ∂ ∂ x 1 m x , y * ∂ ψ ( x , y ) ∂ x + ∂ ∂ y 1 m x , y * ∂ ψ ( x , y ) ∂ y + ℏ 2 k z 2 2 m * + V p ( x , y ) ψ ( x , y ) = E ψ ( x , y ) The first step of the method consists of a selection of the coordinate transformation that can provide a good fit of the shape and size of the computational domain. Once the coordinate transformation x = x u , v and y = y u , v is chosen. Consequently, Eq. (2) becomes: (3) − ℏ 2 2 u x ∂ ∂ u u x m * ∂ ψ ∂ u + v x m * ∂ ψ ∂ v + v x ∂ ∂ v u x m * ∂ ψ ∂ u + v x m * ∂ ψ ∂ v + u y ∂ ∂ u u y m * ∂ ψ ∂ u + v y m * ∂ ψ ∂ v + v y ∂ ∂ v u y m * ∂ ψ ∂ u + v y m * ∂ ψ ∂ v + U ψ = E ψ where (4) ∂ ∂ x = ∂ ∂ u ∂ u ∂ x + ∂ ∂ v ∂ v ∂ x = ∂ ∂ u u x + ∂ ∂ v v x (5) ∂ ∂ y = ∂ ∂ u ∂ u ∂ y + ∂ ∂ v ∂ v ∂ y = ∂ ∂ u u y + ∂ ∂ v v y In Eq. (3), ψ x ( u , v ) , y ( u , v ) = ψ ( u , v ) , U p x ( u , v ) , y ( u , v ) = U p ( u , v ) while ux, uy, vx and vy are the elements of the Jacobian matrix Jx,y representing partial derivatives of the inverse functions u = u x , y and v = v x , y with respect to x and y. The Jacobian matrix Juv corresponding to the transformation x = x u , v , y = y u , v is an explicit function on u and v: (6) J u v = x u x v y u y v Here x u / y u and x v / y v denote the partial derivatives to u and v respectively. Jxy is the Jacobian matrix for the inverse mapping u = u(x,y) and v = v(x,y), which is an explicit function on u and v. It is given by J x y = J u v − 1 , we finally derive Jxy as: (7) J x y = u x u y v x v y = x u x v y u y v − 1 Therefore, the coordinate transformation which can fit lens and dome shapes and determine the computational domain can be written in this general form: (8a) x = K u (8b) y = K f u , v We note that K is a factor related to the scale and expressed in nanometers. Thus, we obtain: (9a) J u v = x u x v y u y v = K 0 K f u K f v (9b) J x y = u x u y v x v y = 1 / K 0 − f u / ( K f v ) 1 / ( K f v ) = 1 K 1 0 μ ρ Where fu and fv are derivatives of f(u,v) with respect to u and v. μ = K . v x = − f u / f v a n d ρ = K . v y = 1 / f v By using the expressions of μ and ρ , the Eq. (3) can be expressed as follows : (10) − ℏ 2 2 K 2 ∂ ∂ u 1 m * ∂ ψ ∂ u + μ m * ∂ ψ ∂ v + μ ∂ ∂ v 1 m * ∂ ψ ∂ u + μ m * ∂ ψ ∂ v + ρ ∂ ∂ v ρ m * ∂ ψ ∂ v + U ψ = E ψ In the second step, the above equation is solved using 2D finite difference method and the Eq. (10) becomes: (11) − ℏ 2 2 K 2 1 h u 1 m * i + 1 / 2 , j ψ i + 1 , j − ψ i , j h u − 1 m * i − 1 / 2 , j ψ i , j − ψ i − 1 , j h u + μ m * i + 1 / 2 , j ψ i + 1 / 2 , j + 1 / 2 − ψ i + 1 / 2 , j − 1 / 2 h v − μ m * i − 1 / 2 ψ i − 1 / 2 , j + 1 / 2 − ψ i − 1 / 2 , j − 1 / 2 h v + μ i , j h v 1 m * i , j + 1 / 2 ψ i + 1 / 2 , j + 1 / 2 − ψ i − 1 / 2 , j + 1 / 2 h u − 1 m * i , j − 1 / 2 ψ i + 1 / 2 , j − 1 / 2 − ψ i − 1 / 2 , j − 1 / 2 h u + μ m * i , j + 1 / 2 ψ i , j + 1 − ψ i , j h v − μ m * i , j − 1 / 2 ψ i , j − ψ i , j − 1 h v + ρ i , j h v ρ m * i , j + 1 / 2 ψ i , j + 1 − ψ i , j h v − ρ m * i , j − 1 / 2 ψ i , j − ψ i , j − 1 h v + U i , j ψ i , j = E ψ i , j Where i and j are indices of the discretization points, while hu is the discretization step along u coordinate and hv along v coordinate. 2.2 Coordinate transformation In this section, we propose to study the coordinate transformation which is given as follows: (12) x = K u y = K f u , v = sinh ( A v ) D + arctan h ( K sin 2 ( π u L ) ) ( 1 + B v 2 ) Fig. 1 shows the manner each parameters in coordinate transformation (Eq. (12)) influences the shape of the function f u , v , for a fixed value of v = 2 . In Fig. 1a) and b), we can see that A affects the peak of the function, which increases with A but decreases when the D parameter augments. The B parameter controls the shape width of quantum wire. An increase in B leads to a decrease in the curve width as shown in Fig. 1c). As can be seen in Fig. 1d), for fixed values of A, D and B, the maximum of the curve increases with v . The function given by relation (Eq. (12)) has the advantage of modelling one or more quantum wires, the part sin 2 π u L is related to the periodicity, which gives us more than one quantum wire. We have taken, for example, three and five quantum wires and we suggest two models of this structure. Where ε = ε x , y represents the old coordinate space, the Schrödinger equation can be mapped into new β = β u , v space. In Fig. 2 a) and b), we have presented the two models of the quantum wire. The first model, shown in Fig. 2a), has a dome-like shape. In addition, the second model in Fig. 2a) has the form of lens cross-section. We observe from the figures that the two models are obtained when the parameter v varies between the 0 , 2 and − 1 , 1 , respectively. As shown in Fig. 2c) and d), a three quantum wires self-organized have the first and the second forms respectively. A five quantum wires which have a dome-like shape and a lens cross-section shape are shown in Fig. 2e) and f) respectively. The InAs/InP QW profiles in ε-space illustrated in Fig. 2 in the x , y plane are mapped in the β-space, the corresponding computational domain is u , v plan. D u and D v are the selected domain size in the mapped space [4]. The proposed method based on the coordinate transformation, which can fit the hetero interface of QW shown in Fig. 2 and simplify the computational domain as well as the resolution of Schrodinger equation in β-space, becomes possible compared to the case when the problem is solved in the original ε-space. It should be noted that the function given by relation (12) makes simpler the modelling of two shapes of quantum wires. In the next part, we use the general theoretical method proposed above to calculate the eigenvalues for the different shapes of quantum wire. In both directions, the discretisation steps are equal, i.e. Δ = h u = h v . Therefore, the total number of grid points that corresponds to the size of the discretization matrix is ( N u v = N u × N v ) . 3 Results and discussion In this part, We depict the numerical study of eigenvalues for InAs/InP quantum wires with different forms. The parameters used in our calculations are presented in Table 1 and taken from Refs. [5,6]. In fact, to characterize and explore our method, we analyze the influence of geometrical parameters of the quantum wire with different shape on the calculated eigenenergies. The analysis is based on the variation of the quantum wire height H. The effect of this parameter on the transition energies is also mentioned in the discussion. First, we have modelled an isolated quantum wire and calculated the ground state energies of electrons and heavy holes as a function of the height H for different models and for a fixed width of 14 nm. According to Fig. 3 we find that, for an isolated QW and all models, the energies decrease with the height H. As can be seen in Fig. 3a) the ground state energies for electron for model 1 is lower compared to model 2. For heavy holes, for H ˂ 3.3 nm, the energies for model 1 is higher than that for model 2, but for H ˃ 3.3 nm, the two models change the trend as illustrated in Fig. 3b). We have deduced the transition e-hh (electron-heavy hole) behaviour with the wire height H. The results are shown in Fig. 3c). The difference between the two models is of 2.22 meV with H = 2.73 nm, 5.07 meV with H = 3.22 nm and 8.28 meV with H = 3.71 nm. To better explain the behaviour of the transition e-hh, we have plotted in Fig. 4 the transitions of energies as a function of the height for one, three and five QWs in the same figure. For model 1 and 2, the energy of 1 QW is a little bit higher compared to 3 QWs but the difference between this energy and that obtained for 5 QWs is more remarkable. This difference remains nearly constant at about 7 meV and 8 meV for model 1 and 2, respectively. From these figures, we can note that the values for the transition energy of the isolated QW are always higher than the other two cases. By virtue of the importance of the energy levels, we have also studied the ground state energies of electrons and heavy holes and the transition energies e-hh as a function of the number of quantum wires and for a fixed height of 4 nm. The results of this study are illustrated in Fig. 5 . As for electrons, it is observed that the energy decreases as the number of QWs increases. This means that the energy is divided with the increase of QWs number. In Fig. 5b), the energy of heavy holes remains constant with the increase of the QWs number. It is maximum and minimum at about 77.42 meV and 75.67 meV for models 1 and 2, respectively. As shown in Fig. 5c), for the two models, the transition energies decrease when the number of the wire increases (Fig. 5). 4 Conclusion In the present work, we presented first an efficient method, which consists on a coordinate transformation in order to model a quantum wire with different forms. The proposed method has been used to calculate the electron and hole energy levels of isolated and self-organized quantum wires. Thus, the Schrödinger equation is solved by the FDM in the new computational space. Then, we studied the influence of geometrical parameters on the shape of the quantum wire and we investigated the optical transition energies. According to the obtained results for the ground state energies for electrons and heavy holes as well as the deduce transition energies e-hh, the geometrical parameters, the shape and the number of quantum wires have an important role in the optical properties.

column2: Study a scanning beam current in focusing ion beam device of overcome mirror effect
column3: Abstract The present work adopted mathematical model used to study the effect the electron beam current on the electron-mirror images. This mathematical model employed to study the characteristics polymer PMMA a through ion mirror effect phenomenon. The results show it is possible to use this model to study an ion mirror effect phenomenon and an electron mirror effect phenomenon alike. Results demonstrated that best understand and interpret for the physical behaviors of a scanning ion may be extracted. Hence can be finding energy safer, which can be used without damage to the sample under study and also can be calculating the required current to reach the surface of the sample for each scanning potential. Furthermore, the mathematical model shows an ability to produce a method for calculating the trapped charge and the maximum stopping potential to disappear the ion mirror effect and accurately excellent.
column5: Keywords Ion optics Focusing ion beam device Ion beam current Ion mirror effect Insulator charging 1 Introduction The term "Electron optics" or "Ion optics" are defined as the branch of physics that deals with matters related to the motion of particles charged by magnetic fields and electric fields, and the generation of images using electron beams or ion beams [1,2]. Today's optical electronic devices have become analytical devices that are indispensable in many technology fields. Although the age is short for scientific development, these devices have undergone great development and mutations in a short period of time [3]. That the first and simplest application of electronic optics is the construction of the Scanning Electron Microscope (SEM). The advanced applications of the charged particles are the instrument Focus Ion Beam (FIB) [4,5]. The understanding of the mechanism of accumulation of charges in insulation materials is very important in science and modern technology because it leads to best applications of insulation materials, especially in the fields of electronics and space technology [6,7]. The scanning electron microscope (SEM) and the instrument Focus Ion Beam (FIB) are among the most important devices used in the accumulation of charges because it provides the possibility of controlling the number of the charge orient towards the insulation and the area in which it is distributed, in addition to controlling the charges conditions different. The Focus Ion Beam instrument (FIB) is one of the most important devices currently used in nanometer scale applications [8,9]. The Focus Ion Beam instrument (FIB) is similar to Scanning Electron Microscope (SEM), and the fundamental difference to both is the nature of the beam used in scan. In the Focus Ion Beam instrument (FIB) from ions and often Gallium ion Ga + , the beam ion (FIB) can be emitted to a diameter equivalent to the fraction of nanometer. As a result, the accuracy obtained by FIB is better than SEM and the interaction of the Gallium ion Ga + to the target material varies on interaction of electrons with the same material and Table 1 shows a comparison between (FIB) and (SEM) [10]. The electron mirroring effect (EME) occurs in scanning electron microscope (SEM) has been notified since the 1970s [11,12]. In 2008, a similar effect observed in focusing ion beam (FIB) by Croccolo and Riccardi, it is called Ion mirror effect [13]. Since then, great effort has been to make sure the electron mirror effect and ion mirror effect does not occur. Recently, it turns out that the electron mirror effect and ion mirror effect is quite useful and use it as a tool to obtain information about the model dielectric materials properties or use it as an analytical tool in the SEM and FIB systems [14]. 2 Theoretical aspects 2.1 Mirror effect phenomenon mirror effect phenomenon is occurring inside the chamber of the scanning electron microscope (SEM) or inside the chamber of the focus ion beam instrument (FIB) in a non-conductive sample when the irradiated by electrons or ions, an excess charge is spatially trapped within the sample generating distortions in the electrons or ions beam path, leads to image the insider chamber space instead of imaging the sample surface[13]. The imaging ion mirror effect (IME) is the result of a two-step process (see Fig. 1 ). 2.1.0.1 First step The first step is the charging the insulating surface until it acts as an ion mirror of sufficient strength to deflect the ions of the primary beam towards the secondary electron detector (i.e., forming a layer of ions on the sample surface (charge trapping)) (see Fig. 1a). When the focusing ion beam is used as a source energetic ion, the disc charge area is produced. A disc of radius Rs with amount positive charge trapping Qt on the surface sample (see Fig. 2 a). The electric field as a function of the optical axis-z due to a group of point charge dq can be written as [16]: (1) d E Z = 1 2 π ε ° d q y 3 z Eq. (1) can be written as; (2) E Z = ∫ d E = 1 2 π ε ° ∫ d q z 2 + r 2 3 z Where ε ° is the permittivity of free space ( ε ° = 8.85 × 10 - 12 F / M ), dq is a differential element of charge trapping, z is the optical axis-z (i.e., distance between the insulator surface and the ion gun aperture), y = z 2 + r 2 and r is the distance from the center of the disc charge to dq. Since the differential element of charge trapping (dq) is assumed to be uniform, thus (3) ∴ d q = σ d A = 2 π r σ d r Where s is a surface charge density. We substitute Eq. (3) in to Eq. (2) we get (4) ∴ E Z = z 2 π ε ° ∫ 0 R s 2 π r σ z 2 + r 2 3 d r By solving Eq. (4) we get (5) ∴ E Z = z π σ 2 π ε ° [ 1 z - 1 z 2 + R s 2 ] (6) ∴ E Z = Q t 2 π R s 2 ε ° [ 1 - z z 2 + R s 2 ] Where Q t = π R s 2 σ . The electric potential at the sample surface due to the trapping charge can be found by ϕ s Z = - ∫ E d z (7) ∴ ϕ s Z = = Q t 2 π R s 2 ε ° [ z 2 + R s 2 - z ] 2.1.0.2 Second step The second step is the building up of an image of the ion mirror effect as the insulator sample is irradiated with lower energy ions, which are reflected back from the charged sample in the form of an ion beam directed to the chamber walls. The subsequent interaction of ions with the chamber materials generates secondary electrons. Eventually, the some of which are detected by the detector causing the ion mirror effect image (see Fig. 2b). A similarly to the first step, assume that these ions may be distributed uniformly within a disc of radius Rb with a total charge Qb=It. Where it is time providing an injected charge (Qb) within the beam space. Thus, Eq. (7) can be using to finding ions beam potential along the ions beam axis (see Fig. 2b). Eq. (7) can be written as; (8) ϕ b W D - Z = I b t 2 π R b 2 ε ° [ W D - z 2 + R b 2 - W D - z ] Where WD is the working distance. Eq. (8) provides a shortcut to understanding the behavior of the ions beam potential ϕ b W D - Z , which depends on the beam's current and diameter. So the numbers of accelerated ions that construct the ions beam. It is clear that Eq. (7) represents an opposed potential which tries to pause the scanning ions from reaches the sample surface. (i.e., represents a surface potential ( ϕ s Z ) to weaken the incoming ions and hence resist them to progress towards the sample surface). On the other hand, Eq. (8) shows a potential ions beam ( ϕ b W D - Z ) that test to weaken the first one and so push the incoming ions away from the FIB column diaphragm. When the sum of the accelerating scanning (Vsc) and ions beam potentials ( ϕ b W D - Z ) being equal to the sample potential ( ϕ s Z ), the incoming ions stop moves at a specific axial point (z) and hence reflected back towards the chamber inner walls of the focuing ion beam instrument (FIB). Accordingly, an equation to describe the conservation of energy law can be written as follows: (9) ϕ s Z = ϕ b W D - Z + V s c . Substitute Eq. (7) and Eq. (8) in Eq. (9) and rearrange can be obtain (10) Q t R b 2 I b t R s 2 z 2 + R s 2 - z - W D - z 2 + R b 2 - W D - z - 2 π ε ° R b V s c I b t = 0 Can be using Eq. (7) to determine the position for ion reﬂection for speciﬁc experimental parameters (i.e., depends on the trapped charge Q t , working distance W D , and radius of the charged disc R b a n d R s .) 3 Results and discussions This section dedicated to discuss influence of ion beam current parameters on the main incident ion beam. Furthermore, trapped charges determination will be discussed and so some results of certain published literatures will be definition for implementation and comparison purposes. In fact, the all results are obtained for the values of Qt = 508 pC, Rb = Rs = 0.457 mm and work distance = 30 mm. These values are chosen according to conditions of usual operation in focusing ion beam (FIB) experiments with the ion mirror effect phenomenon for Poly Methyl Methacrylate (PMMA) sample and according to Ref. [2]. 3.1 Ion beam current characteristics parameters Fig. 3 shows the variation of the ion reflection point versus the ion beam current (Ib) for different values of the scanning potential (Vsc). It is seen that the increasing of the number of ions (ion beam current) in the beam gives increasing of Qb over its counterpart trapped charge (Qt) (i.e. resist the sample potential) although it’s scanning potential (Vsc) is fixed. In other word, this increase the number of ions more and more (beam potential) gives ions the ability to penetrate more and more within the area of influence for the surface potential and hence the ion beam approaching much from the surface. On the other hand, Fig. 1 shows the reflection point decreases when higher scanning potential (Vsc). Strictly speaking, the reflection point of an incident ion becomes closer from the Poly Methyl Methacrylate (PMMA) surface pointedly when the scanning potential (Vsc) goes to higher values. It’s clear that can overcome the ion mirror effect phenomenon either through higher scanning potential (Vsc), or through a low scanning potential (Vsc) by using the ion beam current (Ib) parameters. In other words, the ion beam current (Ib) can only be used to adjustment ion mirror effect at low values of the scanning potential (Vsc). So the ion beam current (Ib) can be considered as important parameter to control the ion mirror effect phenomenon. Obviously, Fig. 3 shows that the ions can’t reach to the sample under study when the scanning potential equals to 6 Kv whatever the values of the beam current (ion current). This result is very important to imaging the sample surface without any damage to the sample under study. Fig. 3 also shows that the current (Imax) required for a beam of ions so as to hit a sample surface for different values of scanning potential (Vsc) (see Table 2 ). It is seen that the increases in the values of Vsc, a beam current that allow the ions to hit the sample surface have a low quantity (the ion beam current decreases when the values of scanning potential (Vsc) increased). 3.2 Disappearance mirror effect Figs. 4–8 show Variation of ion beam current versus the quotient Qb / Qt (remembering that Q b = Ibt) for different values of scanning potential (Vsc = 6–10 Kv respectively). Reverting to Figs. 4–8, it is worth to mention that there is a similar behavior between the curves of ion beam current) for different values of scanning potential (Vsc = 6–10 Kv respectively). Consequently, one may readily realize that the increase in beam potential leads to big increase in the values of Qb /Qt for different values of scanning potential. This a result may directly afford in mind that, the increases of the ion beam current give the ion beam additional ability to fight the sample potential. Therefore this ability increase more and more as the ion beam current increases further and further. Thus, chance of the incident ion to reach the sample surface increases with increasing of the ion beam current. So the ion beam current can be deeming as an important parameter to control the images of ion mirror effect. When Qb /Qt become equal to unity. This result led to disappeared mirror effect. For such setup, actually, the incident ion reflects at the midpoint of the working distance, and so ions can never reach the sample surface for this case, as long as the ion beam current supplies a number of ions equal to that trapped at the sample surface. From the Figs. 3–8, it provides an important tool for the theoretical calculation to the ion beam current accurately higher (see Table 2). 4 Conclusions The presented work proved can be used the same procedure mathematically to study ion mirror effect phenomenon in focusing ion beam(FIB) microscope and electron mirror effect phenomenon in scanning electron microscope (SEM). Results show the prospect using the ion beam current to set and controlling the ion mirror effect accurately. In the other hand, the results have clearly shown that the ion beam current an influence similar to that of the scanning potential parameter. But the ion beam current has an important effect on the deduced mirror images in comparison with the other beam parameters. The reason for this that impact the ion beam current can be control of the mirror effect phenomenon for low values of the scanning potential. Furthermore, the “adjust” of mirror images can substantially be made up with the variation of ion beam current rather than the variation of scanning potential. Results show fact, which is that sample PMMA needs a beam current one is (0.12 nA) for all variation of scanning potential to disappear ion mirror effect. As well the maximum stopping potential to disappear the ion mirror effect is (16 Kv) and safe scanning potential is (≤6 Kv). Hence, the procedure mathematically to study ion mirror effect phenomenon in focusing ion beam (FIB) microscope provides an important tool for the calculation of the trapped charges that may accumulate on the PMMA sample surface inside the FIB chamber. Furthermore the reflection coordinates of the head-incident on can be well defined without need to solve the ion equation of motion. Thus, a good interpretation can be extracted for the ion mirror effect images.

column2: Circular-path polarization point-diffraction interferometer and analysis of the fringe parameters
column3: Abstract A circular-path polarization point-diffraction interferometer (PDI) is developed, in which the reference and test waves travel in a nearly same optical path and in opposite directions. Furthermore, a linear tilting modulation can be introduced into two interfering waves by rotating the polarization beam splitter (PBS). As a result, the fringe pattern with carrier frequency is captured and the Fourier transform method is employed to extract the tested wavefront. Furthermore, by analyzing the fringe parameters, i.e., fringe contrast and carrier frequency, it can be concluded that the proposed PDI can adjust easily these two fringe parameters. Therefore, the fringe pattern with the highest contrast and suitable carrier frequency can be captured, and so as this PDI with compact configuration can also obtain high accuracy of phase meausrement.
column5: Keywords Point-diffraction interferometer (PDI) Common path interferometer Phase measurement Fringe contrast Carrier frequency 1 Introduction The point-diffraction interferometer (PDI) is a self-referencing interferometer developed in many years. This interferometric method can realize the absolute measurement of wavefront and directly obtain the wavefront information [1,2] without the difficult reconstruction algorithm similar to that using in the shearing interfermoter [3,4]. Also, PDIs has been applied to the adaptive optics or detect the waveftont phase in strong scintillation [5,6]. The PDI’s primary advantages is its common-path design and no requirement of other reference wave to be introduced. An interferogram can be formed with only a single laser path rather than with the two paths required for Mach–Zehnder or Michelson interferometers. This is especially important in the measurement of large objects such as wind tunnel flows, in which the optical paths are very long and air turbulence must be minimized along the paths. A single path is also advantageous when the size of the instrument must be kept small. The common-path design requires relatively few optical elements, thereby reducing the cost, size, and weight of the instrument and simplifying alignment. Like any interferometer, the interferograms produced by the PDI must be interpreted to extract information about the object wave front. The effective way to measure wave-front aberration is to use phase-shifting interferometry [7] or Fourier transform method [8]. The PDI has traditionally been unable to use this advanced technique, however, because its common-path design makes it difficult to shift the phase of one beam relative to the other. Many modifications have been proposed to add phase shifting or introduce phase modulation to the PDI. For example, the Liquid-crystal PDI proposed by Mercer [9–11] embedded a microsphere within the liquid-crystal layer, and employed a liquid-crystal layer to introduce phase shifts. The PDI developed by Kwon [12] used a specially fabricated diffraction grating to produce three phase-shifted interferograms simultaneously. Since Murty [13] proposed the basic form of circular-path or cyclic interferometer, it was studied widely and applied in PDI [14] or radial shearing interferometer [15–17] to implement common path structure. Some new PDI configurations have been developed to apply in lens testing, fluid flow diagnostics, opaque surfaces, and so on. However, some drawbacks are still not overcome, which include poor real-time measurement in phase shifting technique [16,17], poor craft of making the PDI mask in Kwon and Mercer technique [9,12], and the contrast of interferograms is limited for great majority techniques such as the literature [14,15]. In the paper, the combination of a circular-path polarization structure and a polarizer with pinhole as the PDI mask carry out a common-path PDI. After a linear modulation is introduced conveniently, one can use the Fourier transform method to extract real-time the wavefront phase. In addition, this system allows the fringe contrast and spatial frequency to be adjusted easily, and hence the fringe pattern with the highest contrast and suitable carrier frequency can be obtained. Therefore, the circular-path polarization PDI can measure different aberration wavefront with high accuracy of phase measurement. 2 Experimental setup We propose and demonstrate a new PDI with a polarization circular-path configuration. The schematic of its experimental setup is shown in Fig. 1 . The circular-path optical system is composed of a polarization beam splitter (PBS), two mirrors, M1, M2, and two lenses (i.e., L1 and L2) with the equivalent focal lengths. An expanded and collimated beam linearly polarized incidence into the circular-path system, and then it is split into the transmitted and reflected waves by the PBS, which orthogonal linearly polarized state. Two waves travel in a nearly same optical path and in opposite directions. Namely, the transmitted wave traverses along anticlockwise direction and the reflected wave traverses along clockwise direction, which are represented respectively as solid line and dotted line in Fig. 1. A polarizer P1(90°) placed in the common focal plane of lenses L1 and L2, contains a reference pinhole centered on the foci of the reference wave. The transmission axis of P1 orients along the Y-axis, which is perpendicular to the polarized direction of the transmitted wave but parallel to that of the reflected wave. Therefore, the transmitted wave will be focused by lens L1 on the pinhole and so be filtered with pinhole diffraction. Furthermore, an ideal plane wave is obtained after traveling through the lens L2 and works as a reference wave. As for the reflected wave, it will focus on the outside of the reference pinhole while tilting the PBS slightly, and thus it will pass through P1 wholly with no any attenuation and work as a test wave. The reference and test waves are transmitted and reflected by the PBS again. Finally, the interference pattern is formed by the superposition of two interfering waves in the CCD plane after passing through a quarter-wave plate (QWP) and another polarizer P2(0°) with their transmission axis oriented at 45° and 0° respectively. The spatial filtering with pinhole diffraction will give rise to the attenuation of intensity of reference wave. To improve the contrast of fringe, a half-wave plate (HWP) is inserted in front of PBS. As shown in the next section, while rotating its transmission axis direction of α with the reference Z-axis, the amplitude proportion of two interfering waves will also vary. The He-Ne laser wavelength (λ) is equal to 632.8 nm, and the aperture diameter (D) of input beam is equal to 4.61 mm. The focal lengths (f) of lens L1 and L2 are equals to 250 mm. The diameter of reference pinhole in the P1 is equal to 60 μm, which equals about 60% of the Airy-disk for unaberrated wave, namely 1.46 λ f / D . 3 Mathematical analysis of principle According to the conventional Jones matrix formalism [18], Each wave is represented in a Jones matrix for mathematical interpretation. The incident linearly polarized light expressed as E = exp i φ is divided into two orthogonal waves, i.e., the transmitted wave and reflected wave. They are presented respectively as (1) E a = cos α 1 0 exp i φ and (2) E b = sin α 0 1 exp i φ , where i = − 1 , φ is the wavefront phase to be tested, α is the transmission axis direction of the HWP to the reference Z-axis, which varies from 0 to 90°. The Jones matrix of the P1(90°) with its transmission axis oriented at 90° is given by P 90 ° = 0 0 0 1 . It is assumed that the spatial filtering after pinhole diffraction is perfect, so the transmitted wave will become a reference plane wave which is expressed as (3) E r = κ cos α 1 0 , namely the phase information included in the factor exp i φ in the above expression will be eliminated. By spatial filtering the optical intensity passing through the pinhole will reduced, and the parameter κ in Eq. (3) denotes the intensity transmission rate of the pinhole under a given wavefront aberration φ . The test wave from the reflected wave holds same amplitude and polarization direction with the reflected wave and its Jones matrix is given by (4) E m = 0 0 0 1 ⋅ E b = 0 0 0 1 ⋅ sin α 0 1 exp i φ = sin α 0 1 exp i φ . Jones matrix of QWP(45°) with transmission axis at 45° is expressed as 1 2 1 − i − i 1 . After transmitting the QWP the reference and the test waves become right-circularly and left-circularly polarized light which are expressed respectively as (5) E ′ r = Q W P 45 ° ⋅ E r = 1 2 1 − i − i 1 ⋅ κ cos α 1 0 = κ cos α 2 exp i 0 exp -i π / 2 , (6) E ′ m = Q W P 45 ° ⋅ E m = 1 2 1 − i − i 1 ⋅ sin α 0 1 exp i φ = sin α 2 exp -i π / 2 exp i 0 exp i φ . The result after recombining two waves is expressed as (7) E x E y = E ′ r + E ′ m = 1 2 κ cos α + sin α exp i φ − π / 2 κ cos α exp -i π / 2 + sin α exp i φ . After passing through the polarizer P2(0°) with transmission axis oriented at 0° whose Jones matrix expressed as P 0 ° = 1 0 0 0 , only the component in x direction of the recombined wave will pass. The result is given by (8) E x = κ cos α 2 + sin α 2 exp i φ − π / 2 . The intensity of the Eq. (6) is expressed as (9) I = E x E x * = κ cos 2 α 2 + sin 2 α 2 + κ cos α sin α sin φ . Assume that I r = κ cos 2 α 2 and I m = sin 2 α 2 , Eq. (9) is rewritten as (10) I = I r + I m + 2 I r I m sin φ . When the PBS is rotated slightly around the Z-axis, the linear tilting modulation can be introduced between two interfering waves. In this case, the intensity distribution of the interference pattern is generally written as (11) I = I r + I m + 2 I r I m sin φ + 2 π f 0 x , where f 0 is the introduced spatial carrier frequency. With the Fourier transform method the wavefront phase can be extracted from the Eq. (11). 4 Analysis of fringe contrast The contrast of interference fringe is one of the important factors affecting the accuracy of phase measurement in the interferometer [19]. According to the intensity formula of interference pattern shown as Eq. (11), the contrast formula is given by (12) K = 2 I r I m I r + I m = 2 κ cos α sin α κ cos 2 α + sin 2 α = 2 κ tan α κ + tan 2 α . If we let K in above expression be equal to one, then the relationship between α and κ is described as (13) α = arctan κ . From Eq. (12) we can find that the angle α of the HWP will affect the contrast K , namely, the contrast in this PDI system can be adjusted by rotating the HWP. At the same time, Eq. (13) indicates that in the case of a given intensity transmission κ one can obtain a value of α that makes the contrast of interference fringe reach to the highest value (i.e. one). It is a fact that the intensity transmission ratio of reference wave is influenced by two factors, namely, the size of pinhole making point diffraction and the incident wavefront to be tested. Derivation of reference wave and influence of pinhole size have been analyzed in the literature [20]. Here, we use an atmospheric phase screen consistent with Kolmogorov theory to simulate numerically. The phase screen with D / r 0 = 1 and D / r 0 = 5 consists of 3–25 Zernike modes, where D is the diameter of input aperture and r 0 is the Fried parameter, and a wrapped phase is shown in Fig. 2 (a) and (b). A pinhole with 60% of the Airy-disk diameter for the unaberrated wave is used to generate the reference wave and moderately improve intensity transmission. The fringe contrast K as a function of the rotation angle α of the HWP is illustrated in Fig. 2(c), and in either case, K is ascensive at first and degressive afterwards along with increase of θ . Therefore, one can obtain an important conclusion that K is variable and can reach a maximum value (K = 1) in varying range of θ . Their difference of two curves in Fig. 2(c) represents that the varying trends are different for each aberration modes. However, the value of θ corresponding to the highest contrast is not identical. In the case of any incident wavefront aberration, through varying α the intensity ratio of two interfering wave can be appropriately adjusted in order to maximize the contrast. 5 Analysis of carrier frequency size The Fourier transform method was originally introduced and demonstrated by Takeda et al [8], and only one frame of fringe is required to extract wavefront phase. So it is the easiest method capable of dealing with dynamic situations. To descript briefly principle of Fourier transform method, generally, the intensity distribution of the carrier frequency interferogram shown as Eq. (11) can be rewritten as (14) g x , y = a x , y + b x , y cos φ x , y + 2 π f 0 x , where a x , y and b x , y are background and modulation intensity. With the definition (15) c x , y = 1 2 b x , y e i φ x , y , Eq. (14) is rewritten as (16) g x , y = a x , y + c x , y e i 2 π f 0 x + c * x , y e -i 2 π f 0 x , where superscript * denotes the complex conjugate. The Fourier transform of Eq. (14) is given by (17) G u , v = A u , v + C u − f 0 , v + C * u + f 0 , v , where the capital letters denote the transforms of the corresponding functions, and u and v are the variables in the frequency domain. Assumed that the quantities a x , y , b x , y and φ x , y are slowly varying functions compared to the carrier frequency f 0 , that is (18) f > ∂ a x , y ∂ x , ∂ b x , y ∂ x , and ∂ φ x , y ∂ x , the terms A, C, and C * will be separable in the frequency domain. Thus the term C may be isolated with a suitable frequency filter. With the inverse Fourier transform of C, c x , y is obtained, and the wrapped phase is calculated from (19) φ w x , y = tan − 1 Im c x , y Re c x , y . Furthermore, one can obtain the unwrapped phase φ x , y with the phase-unwrapping algorithm [21]. Generally, the intensity distribution of reference wave from the PDI no longer is uniform, and the greatest nonuniformity will appear when the pinhole size is equal to the Airy-disk diameter [22]. We use respectively Gaussian function and uniform function I r = 60 e − 2 x 2 + y 2 and I m = 65 to descript the intensities of reference and test waves, and then use the wavefront shown in Fig. 2(b) and the intensity formula shown in Eq. (13) to simulate the interferograms. In the used expression, − 1 ≤ x 2 ≤ 1 and − 1 ≤ y 2 ≤ 1 . In the above given condition, background and modulation intensity of interferogram are also of spatial variation. The simulated interferograms are sampled with a resolution of 256 × 256 pixels, and each pixel is quantized to 256 possible gray levels. A series of interference fringe are created as the frequency f 0 varies. Fig. 3 (a) shows a frame of simulated fringe with f 0 = 25 , and its Fourier transform and corresponding central-section curves are plotted respectively in Fig. 3(b) and (c). With the Fourier transform method the wavefront phases are extracted from the simulated fringe pattern. The difference between extracted and given phases is obtained and defined as residual phase. Also, the root mean square (RMS) values of residual phases are calculated. The behavior of the RMS value versus the carrier frequency size under the given aberration as shown in Fig. 2(b) is plotted in Fig. 4 . It can be concluded from Fig. 4 that the larger error occurs at the carrier frequency of less than 30 and greater than 95, and the RMS values are typically less than 0.08λ within the frequency values ranging from 40 to 75. Although only one aberration phase is analyzed, the simulated result from Fig. 4 still may reflect the affecting law of carrier frequency. Namely, a suitable carrier frequency is great important to the Fourier transform method especially while the wavefront to be tested are unknown, which holds wide-range alterability such as different aberration mode or varying magnitude. In fact, in the case of totally separation of zero-frequency and fundamental frequency compositions the lower carrier frequency size may increase the spatial sampling resolution to the period of one fringe. As a result, the higher accuracy of phase extraction will be obtained. For example, in the above simulation the optimal carrier frequency should be equal to 45. However, the determination of the appropriate carrier frequency depends mainly on the varying speed of a x , y , b x , y and φ x , y . Therefore, an adjustable carrier frequency is very helpful to improve the accuracy of the Fourier transform method used in an interferometer. 6 Experimental results In the experiment, a phase-only liquid crystal (LC) spatial light modulator (SLM) is used to introduce the tested wavefront. This SLM has an array of 256 × 256 pixels across a 4.61 mm square aperture, and the relationship between the phase retardance and the gray levels has been calibrated accurately in our previous work [22]. The collimated plane laser output passes through the SLM and then incidences into the circular- path polarization PDI system. At first, a wavefront phases is introduced by the SLM, and the generated fringe pattern is captured by the CCD camera. Through rotating gradually the HWP a series of fringe pattern with different fringe contrast are captured and the values of contrast are calculated. According to the fitting results of calculated data, the rotation angle of the HWP associated to the highest contrast is determined. Then by rotating the HWP and tilting the PBS, the interferogram with the highest contrast and a suitable carrier frequency is captured, and two frames of fringe patterns under different wavefront are shown in Fig. 5 . For the first tested phase, with the rotation of HWP the calculated contrast values and the fitting result from calculated data are wholly shown in Fig. 6 . From the fitting result we can know that the rotation angle corresponding to the highest contrast equals about 8°. With the Fourier transform method the phases are respectively extracted from the fringe patterns. Also, the residual phase, i.e., the difference of extracted and given phases, is calculated. Fig. 7 (a) and (b) describes the introduced original phase and residual phase corresponding to Fig. 5(a). Another results shown in Fig. 7(c) and (d) correspond to Fig. 5(b). For the residual phase shown in Fig. 7(b), the RMS value and the peak-to-valley (PV) value are equal to 0.05λ and 0.43λ, respectively. For the residual phase shown in Fig. 7(d), the RMS value and the PV value are equal to 0.03λ and 0.44λ, respectively. The maximal errors appear in the area near to the borders of the analyzed interferogram, which is mainly due to the well-known border effect [23] from the Fourier transform method. 7 Conclusion The paper has presented a new circular-path polarization PDI with many advantages such as convenient to set up and use, compact in structure, easy fabrication of PDI mask, and low cost to system. More importantly, the fringe contrast and carrier frequency in this system can be adjusted easily. Therefore, the high measuring accuracy can be obtained for different tested aberration wavefront no matter mode style or magnitude size. This characteristic is of great practicality as a wavefront sensor especially using in the closed-loop adaptive optics. As a result, it is very beneficial to improve the speed of closed loop. Acknowledgements This research was supported by the National Natural Science Foundation of China under grant No. 51765054, the Natural Science Foundation of Inner Mongolia of China under grant Nos. 2015MS0616 and 2016MS0620.

column2: Investigation of near-infrared luminescence in Er3+ and Er3+/Yb3+ co-doped ZnMgAl10O17 phosphors
column3: Abstract ZnMgAl10O17-phosphor samples doped with Er3+ ions and codoped with both Er3+ and Yb3+ ions were prepared using a combustion method. The formation of combustion products was confirmed by the XRD analysis. Upon the excitation at 980 nm, the IR-emission spectra of ∼1.53 μm were measured for the Er3+-doped and Er3+/Yb3+-codoped ZnMgAl10O17-phosphor samples. The deconvolvement of the emission spectra and the fitting analysis suggest that the Er3+ ions occupied the same sites in both phosphor samples. Further, the wavelength of the sublevel-split components and the effective linewidths were determined. The significant enhancement of the IR-emission intensity and the broadening of the Er3+ ions (4I13/2 → 4I15/2) in the prepared phosphors were explored.
column5: Keywords Combustion Infrared emission Phosphors Energy transfer Er3+Yb3+ 1 Introduction Trivalent erbium (Er3+)-doped materials have attracted great attention due to their potential applications in the design of optical devices such as light converters, sensors, optical-fiber amplifiers, displays, high-density memories, solid-state lasers, waveguide lasers, and infrared (IR) photodetectors [1–5]. Among the various rare-earth ions, the Er3+-doped fiber amplifiers at 1.5 μm have received much attention in terms of the capability regarding long-distance optical transmissions [6–9]. Dedicated efforts have been made to achieve excellent IR luminescence properties with respect to the Er3+-doped varieties of inorganic compounds [10–16]. Although Er3+-doped systems are well known for IR-region emissions, a dearth exists regarding the reports on Er3+-doped aluminate-based phosphors. Singh et al. [17] reported the effect on the IR-luminescence intensity of a codoping with Yb3+ and Mg2+ ions in terms of the CaAl12O19:Er3+ matrix. The IR emissions of the MgSrAl10O17:Er3+ phosphor that had been codoped with Yb3+/Ba2+/Ca2+ ions that were obtained using the solution-combustion route were reported by the same group [18]. The literature survey of the present-study authors revealed a scarcity of papers that deal with Er3+-doped aluminates compared with the other trivalent rare earths and the transition-metal-ion-doped aluminate phosphors, and a recent extensive spectroscopic study of this ion that also presents a particular investigation of the ZnMgAl10O17 host does not exist. It is noticeable that the exact crystal structure of ZnMgAl10O17 has not been discussed in detail. Further, the optical properties of the rare-earth-doped ZnMgAl10O17 have not been reported in detail. In view of these circumstances, and due to the great demand for IR-emitting phosphors, preparations of the phosphors of the Er3+-doped ZnMgAl10O17 and the Er3+/Yb3+-codoped ZnMgAl10O17 are contained in the present work. Recently, the successful employment of a self-propagating and gas-producing combustion method for the synthesis of the rare-earth-doped varieties of complex oxide phosphors was achieved [17–20]. For the present work, the same synthesis method has been employed for the preparations of the Er3+-doped ZnMgAl10O17 and Er3+/Yb3+-codoped ZnMgAl10O17 phosphors. The enhancement of the IR-luminescence intensity of the Er3+ ions that is due to the sensitizer role of the Yb3+ ions is also discussed. In addition, the formations of the combustion-synthesized products were confirmed using the X-ray powder diffraction (XRPD) technique. 2 Experimental The phosphors were prepared using combustion synthesis. The used precursors are zinc nitrate hexahydrate (Zn[NO3]2·6H2O), magnesium nitrate hexahydrate (Mg[NO3]2·6H2O), aluminum nitrate nonahydrate (Al[NO3]3·9H2O), erbium(III) nitrate pentahydrate (Er[NO3]3·5H2O), ytterbium nitrate hydrate (Yb[NO3]3·xH2O), and urea (NH2CONH2). The precursors were mixed according to the chemical formulae ZnMgAl10O17:Er0.05 and ZnMgAl10O17:Er0.05,Yb0.06. The metal nitrates acted as oxidizers, while the NH2CONH2 served as the organic fuel for the combustion process. The oxidizer and fuel ratio was calculated based on the oxidizing (O) and fuel (F) valencies of the reactants, keeping the O/F = 1, as reported earlier [21]. The desired amounts of the starting materials were dissolved with a small amount of deionized water in a Pyrex dish with an approximate capacity of 300 ml, and the resultant solution was introduced into a furnace that had been preheated to 550 °C. Within a few minutes, the combustion reaction occurred with the evolution of the gases. The entire combustion process was completed within approximately 5–8 min, at which point the Pyrex dish was immediately removed from the furnace. The resultant fluffy mass was then crushed into a fine powder, and this was followed by an in-air annealing of the combustion-reaction product at 800 °C for 5 h. The resultant fine powder was then further used for the purpose of characterization. The XRPD patterns of the samples were recorded using the Rigaku Miniflex-II diffractometer (Rigaku, Japan), with CuKα radiation providing the X-ray source. The XRPD patterns were taken at a scan rate of 5°/min in the 2θ range of 10–80°. The IR-luminescence spectra of both of the combustion-derived materials were measured using an excitation for which the continuous wave laser diode (CWLD) was operated at 980 nm. With the aid of a convergent lens, these emissions were focused onto the 0.18-m Jobin Yvon TRIAX 180 single-grating monochromator (HORIBA, Japan) with a grating of 150 grooves/mm that was coupled with the multichannel InGaAs charge-coupled device (CCD) detector (BaySpec, U.S.A.). All of the measurements were performed at room temperature. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 XRPD analysis Fig. 1 shows the XRPD patterns of the ZnMgAl10O17:Er3+ and ZnMgAl10O17:Er3+/Yb3+ phosphors. All of the diffraction peaks that were observed for both of the samples are compatible with those of the ref. [22] that was reported earlier, confirming the formation of a cubic ZnMgAl10O17 phase. The diffraction peaks can be indexed as (111), (220), (311), (400), (422), (511), (440), (620), and (533), as reported in the ref. [22]. Also, the dopants did not participate in the overall crystal formation, with the exception of the replacing/sitting that occurred between a few atoms. For the phosphor crystallite sizes, the full width at half maximum (FWHM) value of the main XRPD peak was used in the application of the well-known Scherrer equation, as follows: D = 0.9λ/βcosθ, where λ is the wavelength of the incident X-ray, θ is the corresponding Bragg-diffraction angle, and β is the FWHM of the (311) peak. The calculated crystallite sizes of the phosphors of the ZnMgAl10O17:Er3+ and the ZnMgAl10O17:Er3+/Yb3+ are 24.65 nm and 24.55 nm, respectively. In the literature, the exact crystal structure of ZnMgAl10O17 has not been well investigated. 3.2 IR-emission spectral analysis upon a 980-nm excitation The well-known IR emission of Er3+ ions at 1.5 μm has attracted considerable interest due to the practical use of these ions in the broadband amplification of fiber amplifiers. However, its low-absorption cross-section at nearly 980 nm limits the pumping efficiency, while the emissions of the commercially available laser diodes are in the wavelength region of 0.8–1.5 μm [23]. To enhance the absorption efficiency at 980 nm, Yb3+ ions are used as the sensitizer because the Yb3+ exhibits a large absorption cross-section and a broad absorption band from 850–1080 nm compared with the weak absorption of the Er3+ ions. Moreover, the large overlap between the Yb3+ emissions and the Er3+ absorption bands at 980 nm allows for the following resonant energy transfer (ET) from the Yb3+ ions to the Er3+ ions: 2F5/2(Yb3+) + 4I15/2(Er3+) → 2F7/2(Yb3+) + 4I11/2(Er3+). The population of the Er3+ ions reaches the 4I13/2 level as a result, thereby strengthening the luminescence intensity after the relaxation to the ground state [24]. The energy-level schematic diagram for the Yb3+:Er3+ ions of Fig. 2 shows the possible occurrence of the IR-emission band and the mechanisms that are involved. In the present work, the room-temperature IR-emission spectra of the phosphor samples of the Er3+-doped and Er3+/Yb3+-codoped ZnMgAl10O17 that are around 1.53 μm were recorded with the use of an excitation at 980 nm, and this is shown in Fig. 3 . The observed broadband- and intense-emission bands that are evident around 1.53 μm correspond to the Er3+: 4I13/2 → 4I15/2 transition in both of the phosphor samples. In Fig. 3(a), it is evident that the appearance of two stark split peaks suggests that the Er3+ ions incorporated into the ZnMgAl10O17 phosphor. Whereas the spectra of the Er3+/Yb3+-codoped ZnMgAl10O17 phosphor, which are shown in Fig. 3(b), show a similar emission line with two stark split peaks that occur at the same wavelength. Therefore, both the Er3+-doped and Er3+/Yb3+-codoped ZnMgAl10O17 phosphors share the same local ligand-ion symmetry that surrounds the Er3+ ions. In addition, the deconvolved emission spectra that fit the analysis show eight sublevel-split components in the phosphor samples of both the Er3+-doped and Er3+/Yb3+-codoped ZnMgAl10O17, which can be seen in Figs. 4 (a) and 4 (b), respectively, and this strongly affirms that the Er3+ ions occupied the same sites in both of the phosphor samples. The spectral-fitting analysis shows an important feature, where both the short- and long-wavelength peaks are much broader than the central-wavelength peaks that are incompatible with the other reported host matrices [25]. The fitting analysis of the sublevel-splitting component wavelength and the linewidth of each sublevel are given in Table 1 . The only difference between both of the emission spectral analyses is the significant enhancement of the emission intensity, with the addition of the Yb3+ ions to the Er3+ ions in terms of the ZnMgAl10O17 phosphor, thereby indicating that an efficient energy transfer takes place between the Yb3+ and Er3+ ions. It is possible to estimate the requisite number of photons for the population of the excited level through a measurement of the pump-power-dependent IR-emission intensities. In the present work, an attempt was made to measure the pump-power-dependent IR-emission intensities upon the excitation at 980 nm for the Er3+-doped and Er3+/Yb3+-codoped ZnMgAl10O17 phosphors (Fig. 3). Fig. 5 shows a plot of the logarithmic emission intensities as a function of the logarithmic pump power of a laser yielding a straight line with the slope m = 1.00/0.89 regarding the observed 4I13/2  → 4I15/2 emission band. Thus, one near-IR (NIR) laser photon is responsible for the peaking of the IR emission at 1.53 μm. The gain bandwidth for the amplifiers is an important parameter that is characterized by the FWHM, and the corresponding values are 53 nm and 52 nm for the 4I13/2  → 4I15/2 emission band in the Er3+-doped and Er3+/Yb3+-codoped ZnMgAl10O17 phosphors, respectively. The evaluative precision of the effective linewidth of the observed emission band, however, is more accurate than the FWHM because of the asymmetric emission-line profile. The effective linewidth (Δλeff) was determined as follows [26]: (1) Δ λ e f f = ∫ I λ d λ I m a x where Imax is the emission-peak intensity. The effective linewidths, which were determined from the measured emission spectra, are 73.89 nm and 70.81 nm for the Er3+-doped and Er3+/Yb3+-codoped ZnMgAl10O17 phosphors, respectively. Table 2 shows the effective linewidths (Δλeff) of the emission transition of Er3+:4I13/2  → 4I15/2 in various phosphor matrices. It is evident that the effective linewidth of the 4I13/2  → 4I15/2 transitions of the Er3+-doped and Er3+/Yb3+-codoped ZnMgAl10O17 phosphors is higher than those of the other hosts [27,28], and this is due to the higher local field environment of the dopant ion. Thus, the observed intense emission with the broadening line shape of the Er3+:4I13/2  → 4I15/2 transition in the phosphor samples of the Er3+-doped and the Er3+/Yb3+-codoped ZnMgAl10O17 could be suitable for the optical telecommunication window and wavelength-division-multiplexing (WDM) applications [18]. 4 Conclusion Er3+-doped and Er3+/Yb3+-codoped ZnMgAl10O17 phosphors were successfully prepared via a solution-based combustion-synthesis technique using organic urea fuel. The XRPD data indicate that the influence on the phases from either the doping or the codoping is not evident, while the codoping of the Yb3+ in the ZnMgAl10O17:Er3+ phosphor increased the IR-luminescence intensity. It is clear from the deconvolved Gaussian-fit emission spectra that the Er3+ ions occupied the same sites in both of the phosphor samples. The effective linewidth was determined from the measured emission spectra and then compared with those of the other host matrices. The observed spectral analysis indicates that the intense emission with the broadening line shape of the Er3+:4I13/2 → 4I15/2 transition in terms of the Er3+-doped and the Er3+/Yb3+-codoped ZnMgAl10O17 phosphors can be used for amplifiers that operate at levels of around 1.53 μm.
