column2: Circuit modeling of tunable terahertz graphene absorber
column3: Abstract In this work an efficient circuit model of functional thin-film graphene assisted metamaterial (GM) devices with exploiting transmission line theory (TLT) is presented. In our proposed model, graphene sheet layer considered as parallel R-L-C circuits and the other parts of the devices modeled as circuit elements. Here we develop the structure and design multi-layer unpattern GM absorber. To evaluate robustness, performance and accuracy of our developed TLT method, the results obtained from an easy to implement MATLAB code for a GM absorber have been compared with those obtained from full-wave simulations and analytical approach. Our proposed method in addition to reducing the calculation time and the need for less memory compared to full-wave simulations, is in good agreement with the full-wave and analytical simulations (with an error less than 3%). By changing chemical potential and/or dielectric thickness of the GM absorber, the absorption peek’s frequency could be tuned in terahertz band as desired, indicating the potential applications of the absorber in sensors and filters.
column5: Keywords Circuit model Terahertz Graphene Absorber Transmission line theory 1 Introduction In recent years, Nano technology has provided novel solutions for engineering society, to the extent that fabrication of electronic devices for specific application are realized and appropriately discussed. In any effort to increase sustainability and energy efficiency, neither productivity nor quality should suffer–quite the opposite should be the case. Increased sustainability and efficiency can only be achieved through the use of reliable and modern technology. Nowadays, Terahertz (THz) technology has attracted the attention of many researchers by utilizing new materials. Graphene based devices outperform silicon products, regarding higher operational frequency, design efficiency and even fewer losses. So researchers hope, graphene will paved the way to new era of high frequency-high efficiency electronics and optical devices. As a two dimensional substance, Graphene shows transparent structure with hexagonal shape, has attracted a lot of attention due to its excellent physical, electrical and optical properties [1]. Extensive research and investigations have begun and continue to design, description and implementation of graphene-based Nano devices. Long and highlighted list of these researches is exist. In application point of view for instance, modulators [2–4], tunable reflectors, filters, absorbers and polarizers [5–8] are among most known fields. Due to the high potential of terahertz absorbers in sensing, imaging and detecting [9–11] THz metamaterial absorbers are in major interest and play an important role in many devices like biosensing, imaging and communications [12]. Graphene’s ability to supporting surface Plasmon Polariton-based absorbers at terahertz frequency has made it one of the best materials for designing THz-wave absorbers [5,13–19]. The absorbers based on graphene in THz band can be tunable and broadband [20–21] which is the need of some applications. In the other hand, the necessity of the other applications is tunable narrow band absorbers that research on this issue continues [22]. Narrow band or single-band metamaterial perfect absorbers (MPAs) have important applications in thermal imaging, detection of materials, and biological sensing, in many cases, such as in the simultaneous monitoring and detection of some explosive materials or hazardous substances, multiple-band and even broadband MPAs are necessary [23]. As the demand for the process of designing applications in terahertz frequency band increases, the provision of a circuit model for these structures is very important, since all parts of the terahertz device can be easily analyzed with the circuit model. Here we develop and extend a transmission line theory to model and design a tunable narrow band terahertz graphene absorber. We suggest a simple but powerful circuit model for GM description and tunable narrow band GM design. The remainder of this paper is organized as follows. In Section 2, the structure is explained and the proposed circuit model is presented. In Section 3, design of GM absorber based on circuit model will be discussed and results are drawn in Section 4. Finally the paper has been concluded in Section 5. 2 Structure and circuit model A schematic of the unit cell of the studied GM absorber illustrated in Fig. 1 and graphene is embedded into polyethylene cyclic olefin copolymer (Topas polymer with np = 1.53) which has low losses in THz band [24]. The thickness of graphene layer and the square length of unit cell are considered Δ = 2 nm and 15 μm respectively. The surface conductivity of graphene is derived using the well-known Kubo formula [25]. At sufficiently low frequencies, when ℏω << 2 μc (which includes THz regime) interband term of conductivity is negligible and intraband transition is considered solely, so graphene surface conductivity can be written as (with exp (jωt) time harmonic dependency) [25,26]: (1) σ g ω , μ c , τ , T = σ int r a = − j e 2 k B T π ℏ 2 ( ω − j τ − 1 ) × μ c K B T + 2 ln exp ( − μ c K B T ) + 1 where e is the electron charge, KB is the Boltzman constant, ℏ is the reduced Planck’s constant, τ is the relaxation time of electrones, T is the temperature and μ c is the chemical potential. In this work, we use T = 300 K (ambient temperature) and τ = 1 ps. In Fig. 1, the structure located upon a metallic ground plane (reflection = −1) and a Fabry-Perot resonator like is formed. It should be noted that this configuration is polarization insensitive (under normal incidence). In a symmetrical environment for embedded graphene (n1 = n2, see Fig. 2 ) the maximal absorbance cannot exceed 50% but we can gain larger absorbance if we use more conductive layers of graphene separated with a dielectric spacer [14]. In the terahertz frequency band, the thickness of the graphene layer is much smaller than the wavelength. In such situations, thickness can be ignored and the conductive layer is considered as a point load [14], as shown in Fig. 2. In pursuit of model whole structure as circuit elements by exploiting transmission line theory, dielectric layer can be modeled as either capacitance or inductive depending on its thickness in order to satisfy the absorption goal and the metallic ground plane represent a short circuit. So, if we can model unpatterned graphene layer as circuit elements, we can provide a circuit model for entire structure as depicted in Fig. 3 . In practical applications the most important case is normal incidence, therefor we drive the formula for specification of circuit elements under normal incident. In this model ε0 is the dielectric constant of vacuum and indicating of Z0 = 120π, where Z0 is the impedance of free space. For the equivalent impedance of different parts, the following equations are extracted: (2) Z 1 = j Z p . tan ( β p d n ) (3) Z 2 = Z 1 . Z g n Z 1 + Z g n (4) Z 3 = Z p Z 2 + j Z p . tan ( β p d n − 1 ) Z p + j Z 2 . tan ( β p d n − 1 ) where Zp  = Z0 /nd is the impedance of dielectric intermediate layers and βp is the propagation constant of propagating THz wave in the dielectric material. Based on [20,27], a periodic array graphene ribbons (PAGR) could be modeled with an infinite number of parallel R-L-C circuits, each representing a mode of the structure. As a result, by considering W = D for the studied PAGR in [27] (where D and W are the period and the width of the graphene ribbons), we can characterized a continuous graphene sheet as illustrated in Fig. 4 . The resistance, inductance and capacitance of the n’th mode are calculated as follows [27]: (5) R n = D S n 2 π ℏ 2 e 2 E F τ , L n = R n τ , C n = D S n 2 2 ε e f f Q n where εeff  = ε0(ε1  + ε2)/2 (Subtitles 1 and 2 refer to the permittivity of dielectric materials which surround the continuous graphene sheet on both sides), Sn is the integral of the eigenfunctions of equation governing the surface current given in Table 1 of [27] and Qn  = qn(π /W) is the eigenvalue of that equation which is given in Table 2 of [27] and in our case (W/D = 1) q1 = 0.28 is selected. In this paper for simplicity, we consider only the first mode and it was be noted that the final results will be obtained without this consideration. So, the impedance of each continuous layer of graphene will be: (6) Z g = R 1 + j ω L 1 + 1 j ω C 1 Which in our proposed structure, the values of R1, L1 and C1 for all the graphene layer except the first one are the same. By continuing the calculations in the same way as described above, the input impedance of the structure can be obtained as follows: (9) Z 2 n − 1 = Z p Z 2 n − 2 + j Z p t a n ( β p d 1 ) Z p + j Z 2 n − 2 t a n ( β p d 1 ) (8) Z i n = Z g 1 . Z 2 n − 1 Z g 1 + Z 2 n − 1 Now we can analyze the absorption of GM absorber using circuit analysis which is presented in next section. 3 Design based on circuit model Here by exploiting circuit analysis we intend to analyze and design the GM absorber. From the point of view of the fields and the waves, impedances between two transmission lines must be adapted for perfect absorption (A = 1). It means that the conditions are: Real(Zin) = Z0 and Im(Zin) = 0. But if we consider the goal of design A ≥ 0.9 and use these relations: A = 1-|Г|2 and Г = (Zin-Z0)/(Zin + Z0),its lead to |Г|≤0.32 and 194.2 ≤ Zin ≤ 731.8. So, by satisfying this relation for Zin in the desired frequency band, the design goal can be achieved without the need for full-wave simulations that take a lot of time. In equation (2), dn can be chosen such a way βpdn = π/2, So The effect of the last dielectric layer which has the most thickness between the dielectric layers disappears and the thickness of the remaining layers is very low due to the nature of the GM absorber and in this work the thickness of dielectric spacer is 4 nm. The continuation of the design process depends on the graphene parameters and the values of the R-L-C that the graphene layers produce, which should be in such a way to satisfy the equation obtained for Zin in the desired frequency band. This can be easily done using optimization algorithms such as genetic algorithms (GA) or PSO (particle swarm optimization) algorithms. For instance, we used a simple genetic algorithm to design a dual band absorber with graphene double-layer at frequencies 0.4 and 1.136 THz which the input impedance for this implementation is shown in Fig. 5 . The obtained parameters to meet the design goal for these two frequencies are presented in Table 1 . 4 Results Now let us verify the accuracy of our proposed circuit model by comparing its results with the results of full-wave simulations in ref [14]. The studied structure is a graphene double-layer absorber with a = 15 μm, h = 35.9 μm and τ = 1ps, where a is the square length of unit cell and h is the dielectric thickness. As shown in Fig. 6 (a), the results of our proposed circuit model are in a very good agreement with the full-wave numerical modeling. Moreover, in pursuit of evaluating performance of our method, we use the analytical approach besides full-wave simulations and the structure has been simulated up to 20 THz and compared with the results of our developed TLT model, as depicted in Fig. 6(b). In the analytic method, we use impedance transformation by exploiting this expression [28]: (9) Z i n ( z ) = η 2 η 3 + j η 2 tan ( β 2 d 2 ) η 2 + j η 3 tan ( β 2 d 2 ) where η2 is the characteristic impedances of medium 2, η3 is the wave impedance of total field of Previous layers, β2 is the propagation constant of propagating wave in medium 2, d2 is the thickness of medium 2 and we are looking the structure at the interface between medium 1 and 2. To analyze the design tunability of the presented method and its ability to move the absorption peaks in THz regime, we design four graphene double-layer absorber in different frequencies which details of these Structures are given in Table 1 and the absorption diagram of two structures are illustrated in Fig. 7 . As shown in this figure, the designed absorbers are multi-band and show a fluctuating behavior (Immediately after high absorption, its absorption reaches zero), which is very functional matter in sensing applications point of view. In order to analyze robustness of the presented method, the absorber with four and six continuous graphene sheet for frequencies 4.99 and 5.12 THz have been designed (which details are in Table 1) and its results are compared with results of full-wave simulations and analytical approach, as shown in Fig. 8 . Our results show that by adding more continuous graphene layers to the graphene double-layer structure (making it difficult to fabricate) the absorption peak’s frequency shifts a bite to the higher frequencies. Figs. 9 and 10 show how the first and second resonant frequencies of the graphene double-layer configuration gradually varies with the graphene Fermi level and dielectric thickness (dn which illustrated in Fig. 1). As shown in these figures, the results obtained by our developed TLT are in excellent agreement with those obtained from full-wave simulations. The first and second peaks of the structure is plotted in these figures, where red dashes and blue dots representing full-wave approach and the circle and square markers representing results of the developed TLT method. Eventually, it is worth discussing about our proposed method compared with full-wave simulations in terms of reducing the computational time and the need for less memory. For the studied structure, it takes more than 10 min to complete analysis using the frequency-domain electromagnetic solver with a computer possessing the following characteristics: processor, Intel(R) Core (TM) i7-3770 CPU @ 3.40 GHz; installed memory (RAM), 8.0 GB. While, for the same computer the computation time with our proposed method is less than 0.5 s. So, we can analyze these structures at a noticeable less time exploiting a simple and easy to implement MATLAB code. 5 Conclusion We have proposed a method to model graphene metamaterial with circuit elements using Transmission line theory and investigate GM absorbers. Since the graphene sheet is relatively ultra-thin compared to the wavelength (in THz regime), it was considered as a point load in circuit model. Analytical and full-wave simulations confirm the validity, accuracy and robustness of our circuit approach to model GM absorbers while making benefits in terms of simulation time and memory sources. By modeling the GM structure as circuit elements, we proposed a circuit approach to design a multi-layer GM absorber at desired frequency band by exploiting optimization algorithms. This research did not receive any specific grant from funding agencies in the public, commercial, or not-for-profit sectors. Declarations of interest None.

column2: Optical soliton perturbation for complex Ginzburg–Landau equation with modified simple equation method
column3: Abstract The modified simple equation method applied to perturbed complex Ginzburg–Landau equation gives dark and singular solutions to the model. The perturbation terms appear with full nonlinearity. There are eight nonlinear forms studied in this paper. These solitons appear with constraint conditions that gurantee its existence and these are also presented.
column5: OCIS Codes 060.2310 060.4510 060.5530 190.3270 190.4370 Keywords Solitons Perturbation Full nonlinearity Modified simple equation equation method 1 Introduction The complex Ginzburg–Landau equation (CGLE) is one of the many models that studies the dynamics of optical soliton propagation through a wide range of waveguides such as crystals, optical fibers, optical couplers, optical metamaterials and metasurfaces as well as PCF. This model is an extended version of the usual nonlinear Schrödinger's equation that is visible all across. These models and other nonlinear evolution equations, that arise in mathematical photonics as well as other areas of mathematical physics, are all successfully addressed by the modified simple equation method [1–10]. When perturbation terms are turned on, the perturbed CGLE will be addressed in this paper by the modified simple equation method. There are eight forms of nonlinear media that will be studied. All of these nonlinear forms will lead to the retrieval of dark and singular soliton solutions to the governing model. The existence of these solitons will be guaranteed with the constraint conditions in the parameters. The perturbation terms are all of Hamiltonian type. After a quick recapitulation of this integration scheme, soliton solutions will be derived in the subsequent subsections. 1.1 The model The dimensions form of CGLE is [2–4,6–8]: (1) iq t + aq xx + bF | q | 2 q = 1 | q | 2 q * α | q | 2 | q | 2 xx − β | q | 2 x 2 + γ q where x is the spatial variable that represents the non-dimensional distance along the fiber, while t is the temporal variable. Then, a, b, α, β and γ are valued constants. The coefficients a and b come from the group velocity dispersion and nonlinearity, respectively. The terms with α and β are additional nonlinear terms and γ comes from detuning effect. In (1), F is real-valued algebraic function and it is necessary to possess the smoothness of the complex function F | q | 2 q is k times continuously differentiable, so that F | q | 2 q ∈ ∪ ∞ m , n = 1 C k ( ( − n , n ) × ( − m , m ) ; R 2 ) . In presence of perturbation terms, CGLE gets extended to [4]: (2) iq t + aq xx + bF | q | 2 q = 1 | q | 2 q * α | q | 2 | q | 2 xx − β | q | 2 x 2 + γ q + i δ q x + λ | q | 2 m q x + μ | q | 2 m x q where δ is the inter-modal dispersion that arises in addition to chromatic dispersion, λ represents the self-steepening effect for short pulses and μ is the higher–order dispersion coefficient. The parameter m accounts for full nonlinearity. 2 Revisitation of the integration algorithm Suppose we have a nonlinear evolution equation in the form [1,5,9,10]: (3) P u , u t , u x , u tt , u xt , u xx , . . . = 0 where P is a polynomial in u(x, t) and its partial derivatives in which the highest order derivatives and nonlinear terms are involved. In the following, we give the main steps of this method. Step-1: We use the transformation (4) u ( x , t ) = U ( ξ ) , ξ = x − ct , where c is a constant to be determined, to reduce Eq. (3) to the following ODE: (5) Q U , U ′ , U ′ ′ , U ′ ′ ′ , … = 0 where Q is a polynomial in U(ξ) and its total derivatives, while ′ = d/dξ. Step-2: We suppose that Eq. (5) has the formal solution (6) U ( ξ ) = ∑ l = 0 N a l ψ ′ ξ ψ ξ l , where a l are constants to be determined, such that a N  ≠ 0, and ψ ξ is an unknown function to be determined later. Step-3: We determine the positive integer N in Eq. (6) by considering the homogeneous balance between the highest order derivatives and the nonlinear terms in Eq. (5). Step-4: We substitute (6) into (5), then we calculate all the necessary derivatives U′, U ′ ′ , … of the unknown function U(ξ) and we account the function U(ξ). As a result of this substitution, we get a polynomial of ψ ′ ξ / ψ ξ and its derivatives. In this polynomial, we gather all the terms of the same power of ψ − j ξ , j = 0, 1, 2, … and its derivatives, and we equate with zero all the coefficients of this polynomial. This operation yields a system of equations which can be solved to find a k and ψ ξ . Consequently, once can retrieve the exact solutions of Eq. (3). 3 Soliton solutions In order to solve Eq. (2) by the trial equation method, we start with the following wave transformation (7) q ( x , t ) = U ( ξ ) e i ϕ ( x , t ) , q * ( x , t ) = U ( ξ ) e − i ϕ ( x , t ) where U(ξ) represents the shape of the pulse, ξ = x − vt and ϕ =− κx + ωt + θ. The function ϕ(x, t) is the phase component of the soliton, κ is the soliton frequency, while ω is the wave number, θ is the phase constant and v is the velocity of the soliton. Substituting Eq. (7) into Eq. (2) and then decomposing into real and imaginary parts yields a pair of relations. The imaginary part gives (8) v + δ + 2 a κ + 2 m + 1 λ + 2 m μ U 2 m = 0 while the real part gives (9) a − 2 α U ′ ′ − ω + a κ 2 + γ + δ κ U − κ λ U 2 m + 1 + bF U 2 U − 2 α − 2 β U ′ 2 U = 0 . By choosing α = 2 β the last term of Eq. (9) vanishes. Therefore Eq. (2) changes to (10) iq t + aq xx + bF | q | 2 q = β | q | 2 q * 2 | q | 2 | q | 2 xx − | q | 2 x 2 + γ q + i δ q x + λ | q | 2 m q x + μ | q | 2 m x q and Eq. (9) condenses to (11) a − 4 β U ′ ′ − ω + a κ 2 + γ + δ κ U − κ λ U 2 m + 1 + bF U 2 U = 0 . The imaginary part equation implies (12) v = − 2 a κ − δ and (13) ( 2 m + 1 ) λ + 2 m μ = 0 . Eq. (12) gives the velocity of the soliton and Eq. (13) gives the constraint relation between the two perturbation terms, while Eq. (11) can be integrated to determine the soliton profile. This form for the velocity remains the same for all types of nonlinearity, F(s). 3.1 Kerr law In this case, F ( s ) = s so that Eq. (10) reduces to (14) iq t + aq xx + b | q | 2 q = β | q | 2 q * 2 | q | 2 | q | 2 xx − | q | 2 x 2 + γ q + i δ q x + λ | q | 2 m q x + μ | q | 2 m x q and Eq. (11) simplifies to (15) a − 4 β U ′ ′ − ω + a κ 2 + γ + δ κ U − κ λ U 2 m + 1 + bU 3 = 0 . Balancing U ′ ′ with U 3 in Eq. (15), then we get N = 1. Consequently, we reach (16) U ξ = a 0 + a 1 ψ ′ ξ ψ ξ . Substituting Eq. (16) into Eq. (15) along with m = 1 and setting the coefficients of ψ −j , j = 0,1,2,3 to zero, then we obtain a set of algebraic equations. Solving this system, we obtain (17) a 0 = ± − ω + a κ 2 + γ + δ κ κ λ − b , a 1 = ± 2 a − 4 β κ λ − b , and (18) ψ ′ ′ = ± − 2 ω + a κ 2 + γ + δ κ a − 4 β ψ ′ , (19) ψ ′ ′ ′ = − 2 ω + a κ 2 + γ + δ κ a − 4 β ψ ′ . From Eqs. (18) and (19), we can deduce that (20) ψ ′ = ± − a − 4 β 2 ω + a κ 2 + γ + δ κ k 1 e ± − 2 ω + a κ 2 + γ + δ κ a − 4 β ξ , and (21) ψ = − a − 4 β 2 ω + a κ 2 + γ + δ κ k 1 e ± − 2 ω + a κ 2 + γ + δ κ a − 4 β ξ + k 2 , where k 1 and k 2 are constants of integration. Substituting Eqs. (20) and (21) into Eq. (16), we obtain following exact solution to Eq. (14) q x , t = ± − ω + a κ 2 + γ + δ κ κ λ − b ± 2 a − 4 β κ λ − b ± − a − 4 β 2 ω + a κ 2 + γ + δ κ k 1 e ± − 2 ω + a κ 2 + γ + δ κ a − 4 β ( x − vt ) − a − 4 β 2 ω + a κ 2 + γ + δ κ k 1 e ± − 2 ω + a κ 2 + γ + δ κ a − 4 β ( x − vt ) + k 2 e i − κ x + ω t + θ If we set k 1 = − 2 ω + a κ 2 + γ + δ κ a − 4 β e ± − 2 ω + a κ 2 + γ + δ κ a − 4 β ξ 0 , k 2 = ± 1 we obtain: (22) q x , t = ± − ω + a κ 2 + γ + δ κ κ λ − b tanh − ω + a κ 2 + γ + δ κ 2 a − 4 β x − vt + ξ 0 e i − κ x + ω t + θ , (23) q x , t = ± − ω + a κ 2 + γ + δ κ κ λ − b coth − ω + a κ 2 + γ + δ κ 2 a − 4 β x − vt + ξ 0 e i − κ x + ω t + θ , where (22) and (23) represent dark soliton and singular soliton solutions respectively. These solitons are valid for ω + a κ 2 + γ + δ κ a − 4 β < 0 . (24) q x , t = ± ω + a κ 2 + γ + δ κ κ λ − b tan ω + a κ 2 + γ + δ κ 2 a − 4 β x − vt + ξ 0 e i − κ x + ω t + θ , (25) q x , t = ± ω + a κ 2 + γ + δ κ κ λ − b cot ω + a κ 2 + γ + δ κ 2 a − 4 β x − vt + ξ 0 e i − κ x + ω t + θ , where (24) and (25) represent singular periodic solutions. These solutions are valid for ω + a κ 2 + γ + δ κ a − 4 β > 0 . 3.2 Power law In this case, F ( s ) = s n so that Eq. (10) reduces to (26) iq t + aq xx + b | q | 2 n q = β | q | 2 q * 2 | q | 2 | q | 2 xx − | q | 2 x 2 + γ q + i δ q x + λ | q | 2 m q x + μ | q | 2 m x q aand Eq. (11) simplifies to (27) a − 4 β U ′ ′ − ω + a κ 2 + γ + δ κ U − κ λ U 2 m + 1 + bU 2 n + 1 = 0 . By using transformation U = V 1 2 n , Eq. (27) becomes (28) a − 4 β 1 − 2 n V ′ 2 + 2 nVV ′ ′ − 4 n 2 V 2 ω + a κ 2 + γ + δ κ − 4 n 2 κ λ V m n + 2 + 4 n 2 bV 3 = 0 . Balancing VV ′ ′ or V ′ 2 with V m n + 2 in Eq. (28), then we get N = 2 n m . Setting m = 2n, we reach (29) V ξ = a 0 + a 1 ψ ′ ξ ψ ξ . Substituting Eq. (29) into Eq. (28) and setting the coefficients of ψ −j , j = 0,1,2,3,4 to zero, then we obtain a set of algebraic equations. Solving this system, we obtain (30) a 0 = 2 n + 1 b 2 n + 1 κ λ , a 1 = ± 1 2 n 2 n + 1 a − 4 β κ λ , (31) ω = − 1 4 κ λ n + 1 2 4 κ 3 a λ n 2 + 8 κ 3 a λ n + 4 κ 2 δ λ n 2 + 4 κ 3 a λ + 8 κ 2 δ λ n + 4 κ γ λ n 2 + 4 κ 2 δ λ + 8 κ γ λ n + 4 κ γ λ − 2 b 2 n − b 2 , and (32) ψ ′ ′ = ± nb n + 1 2 n + 1 a − 4 β κ λ ψ ′ , (33) ψ ′ ′ ′ = n 2 b 2 2 n + 1 n + 1 2 a − 4 β κ λ ψ ′ . From Eqs. (32) and (33), we can deduce that (34) ψ ′ = ± n + 1 nb a − 4 β κ λ 2 n + 1 k 1 e ± nb n + 1 2 n + 1 a − 4 β κ λ ξ , and (35) ψ = n + 1 2 a − 4 β κ λ n 2 b 2 2 n + 1 k 1 e ± nb n + 1 2 n + 1 a − 4 β κ λ ξ + k 2 , where k 1 and k 2 are constants of integration. Substituting Eqs. (34) and (35) into Eq. (29), we obtain following exact solution to Eq. (26) q x , t = 2 n + 1 b 2 n + 1 κ λ ± 1 2 n 2 n + 1 a − 4 β κ λ ± n + 1 nb a − 4 β κ λ 2 n + 1 k 1 e ± nb n + 1 2 n + 1 a − 4 β κ λ ( x − vt ) n + 1 2 a − 4 β κ λ n 2 b 2 2 n + 1 k 1 e ± nb n + 1 2 n + 1 a − 4 β κ λ ( x − vt ) + k 2 1 2 n e i − κ x + ω t + θ where ω is given by Eq. (97). If we set k 1 = n 2 b 2 2 n + 1 n + 1 2 a − 4 β κ λ e ± nb n + 1 2 n + 1 a − 4 β κ λ ξ 0 , k 2 = ± 1 we obtain: (36) q x , t = 2 n + 1 b 4 n + 1 κ λ 1 ± tanh nb 2 n + 1 2 n + 1 a − 4 β κ λ x − vt + ξ 0 1 2 n e i − κ x + ω t + θ , (37) q x , t = 2 n + 1 b 4 n + 1 κ λ 1 ± coth nb 2 n + 1 2 n + 1 a − 4 β κ λ x − vt + ξ 0 1 2 n e i − κ x + ω t + θ , where Eqs. (36) and (37) represent dark soliton and singular soliton solutions respectively. These solitons are valid for a − 4 β κ λ > 0 . 3.3 Parabolic law In this case, F ( s ) = b 1 s + b 2 s 2 where b 1 and b 2 are constants. Therefore, Eq. (10) reduces to (38) iq t + aq xx + b 1 | q | 2 + b 2 | q | 4 q = β | q | 2 q * 2 | q | 2 | q | 2 xx − | q | 2 x 2 + γ q + i δ q x + λ | q | 2 m q x + μ | q | 2 m x q and Eq. (11) simplifies to (39) a − 4 β U ′ ′ − ω + a κ 2 + γ + δ κ U − κ λ U 2 m + 1 + b 1 U 3 + b 2 U 5 = 0 . By using transformation U = V 1 2 , Eq. (39) becomes (40) a − 4 β − V ′ 2 + 2 VV ′ ′ − 4 V 2 ω + a κ 2 + γ + δ κ − 4 κ λ V m + 2 + 4 b 1 V 3 + b 2 V 4 = 0 . Balancing VV ′ ′ or V ′ 2 with V 4 in Eq. (40), then we get N = 1. Consequently, we reach (41) V ξ = a 0 + a 1 ψ ′ ξ ψ ξ . Case 1 Substituting Eq. (41) into Eq. (40) along with m = 1 and setting the coefficients of ψ −j , j = 0,1,2,3,4 to zero, then we obtain a set of algebraic equations. Solving this system, we obtain (42) a 0 = 3 κ λ − b 1 4 b 2 , a 1 = ± 1 2 − 3 a − 4 β b 2 , (43) ω = − 16 κ 2 ab 2 + 3 κ 2 λ 2 + 16 κ δ b 2 − 6 κ λ b 1 + 16 γ b 2 + 3 b 1 2 16 b 2 , and (44) ψ ′ ′ = ± 3 κ λ − b 1 2 − 3 a − 4 β b 2 ψ ′ , (45) ψ ′ ′ ′ = − 3 κ λ − b 1 2 4 b 2 a − 4 β ψ ′ . From Eqs. (44) and (45), we can deduce that (46) ψ ′ = ± 2 − 3 a − 4 β b 2 3 κ λ − b 1 k 1 e ± 3 κ λ − b 1 2 − 3 a − 4 β b 2 ξ , and (47) ψ = − 4 b 2 a − 4 β 3 κ λ − b 1 2 k 1 e ± 3 κ λ − b 1 2 − 3 a − 4 β b 2 ξ + k 2 , where k 1 and k 2 are constants of integration. Substituting Eqs. (46) and (47) into Eq. (41), we obtain following exact solution to Eq. (38) q x , t = 3 κ λ − b 1 4 b 2 ± 1 2 − 3 a − 4 β b 2 ± 2 − 3 a − 4 β b 2 3 κ λ − b 1 k 1 e ± 3 κ λ − b 1 2 − 3 a − 4 β b 2 ( x − vt ) − 4 b 2 a − 4 β 3 κ λ − b 1 2 k 1 e ± 3 κ λ − b 1 2 − 3 a − 4 β b 2 ( x − vt ) + k 2 1 2 e i − κ x + ω t + θ where ω is given by Eq. (43). If we set k 1 = − 3 κ λ − b 1 2 4 b 2 a − 4 β e ± 3 κ λ − b 1 2 − 3 a − 4 β b 2 ξ 0 , k 2 = ± 1 we obtain: (48) q x , t = 3 κ λ − b 1 8 b 2 1 ± tanh 3 κ λ − b 1 4 − 3 a − 4 β b 2 x − vt + ξ 0 1 2 e i − κ x + ω t + θ , (49) q x , t = 3 κ λ − b 1 8 b 2 1 ± coth 3 κ λ − b 1 4 − 3 a − 4 β b 2 x − vt + ξ 0 1 2 e i − κ x + ω t + θ , where Eqs. (48) and (49) represent dark soliton and singular soliton solutions respectively. These solitons are valid for a − 4 β b 2 < 0 . Case 2 Substituting Eq. (41) into Eq. (40) along with m = 2 and setting the coefficients of ψ −j , j = 0,1,2,3,4 to zero, then we obtain a set of algebraic equations. Solving this system, we obtain (50) a 0 = 3 b 1 4 κ λ − b 2 , a 1 = ± 3 2 a − 4 β κ λ − b 2 , (51) ω = − 16 κ 3 a λ − 16 κ 2 ab 2 + 16 κ 2 δ λ − 16 κ δ b 2 + 16 κ γ λ − 16 γ b 2 − 3 b 1 2 16 κ λ − b 2 , and (52) ψ ′ ′ = ± 3 b 1 2 a − 4 β κ λ − b 2 ψ ′ , (53) ψ ′ ′ ′ = 3 b 1 2 4 a − 4 β κ λ − b 2 ψ ′ . From Eqs. (52) and (53), we can deduce that (54) ψ ′ = ± 2 a − 4 β κ λ − b 2 3 b 1 k 1 e ± 3 b 1 2 a − 4 β κ λ − b 2 ξ , and (55) ψ = 4 a − 4 β κ λ − b 2 3 b 1 2 k 1 e ± 3 b 1 2 a − 4 β κ λ − b 2 ξ + k 2 , where k 1 and k 2 are constants of integration. Substituting Eqs. (54) and (55) into Eq. (41), we obtain following exact solution to Eq. (38) q x , t = 3 b 1 4 κ λ − b 2 ± 3 2 a − 4 β κ λ − b 2 ± 2 a − 4 β κ λ − b 2 3 b 1 k 1 e ± 3 b 1 2 a − 4 β κ λ − b 2 ( x − vt ) 4 a − 4 β κ λ − b 2 3 b 1 2 k 1 e ± 3 b 1 2 a − 4 β κ λ − b 2 ( x − vt ) + k 2 1 2 e i − κ x + ω t + θ where ω is given by Eq. (51). (56) and (57) represent dark soliton and singular soliton solutions respectively. These solitons are valid for a − 4 β κ λ − b 2 > 0 . 3.4 Dual-power law In this case, F ( s ) = b 1 s n + b 2 s 2 n where b 1 and b 2 are constants. Therefore, Eq. (10) reduces to (58) iq t + aq xx + b 1 | q | 2 n + b 2 | q | 4 n q = β | q | 2 q * 2 | q | 2 | q | 2 xx − | q | 2 x 2 + γ q + i δ q x + λ | q | 2 m q x + μ | q | 2 m x q and Eq. (11) simplifies to (59) a − 4 β U ′ ′ − ω + a κ 2 + γ + δ κ U − κ λ U 2 m + 1 + b 1 U 2 n + 1 + b 2 U 4 n + 1 = 0 . By using transformation U = V 1 2 n , Eq. (59) becomes (60) a − 4 β 1 − 2 n V ′ 2 + 2 nVV ′ ′ − 4 n 2 V 2 ω + a κ 2 + γ + δ κ − 4 n 2 κ λ V m n + 2 + 4 n 2 b 1 V 3 + b 2 V 4 = 0 . Balancing VV ′ ′ or V ′ 2 with V 4 in Eq. (60), then we get N = 1. Consequently, we reach (61) V ξ = a 0 + a 1 ψ ′ ξ ψ ξ . Case 1 Substituting Eq. (61) into Eq. (60) along with m = n and setting the coefficients of ψ −j , j = 0,1,2,3,4 to zero, then we obtain a set of algebraic equations. Solving this system, we obtain (62) a 0 = 2 n + 1 κ λ − b 1 2 n + 1 b 2 , a 1 = ± 1 2 n − 2 n + 1 a − 4 β b 2 , (63) ω = − 1 4 b 2 n + 1 2 4 κ 2 an 2 b 2 + 8 κ 2 anb 2 + 2 κ 2 λ 2 n + 4 κ δ n 2 b 2 + 4 κ 2 ab 2 + κ 2 λ 2 + 8 κ δ nb 2 − 4 κ λ nb 1 + 4 γ n 2 b 2 + 4 κ δ b 2 − 2 κ λ b 1 + 8 γ nb 2 + 2 nb 1 2 + 4 γ b 2 + b 1 2 , and (64) ψ ′ ′ = ± n κ λ − b 1 n + 1 − 2 n + 1 a − 4 β b 2 ψ ′ , (65) ψ ′ ′ ′ = − n 2 κ λ − b 1 2 2 n + 1 n + 1 2 a − 4 β b 2 ψ ′ . (64) and (65), we can deduce that (66) ψ ′ = ± n + 1 n κ λ − b 1 − a − 4 β b 2 2 n + 1 k 1 e ± n κ λ − b 1 n + 1 − 2 n + 1 a − 4 β b 2 ξ , and (67) ψ = − n + 1 2 a − 4 β b 2 n 2 κ λ − b 1 2 2 n + 1 k 1 e ± n κ λ − b 1 n + 1 − 2 n + 1 a − 4 β b 2 ξ + k 2 , where k 1 and k 2 are constants of integration. (63). If we set k 1 = − n 2 κ λ − b 1 2 2 n + 1 n + 1 2 a − 4 β b 2 e ± n κ λ − b 1 n + 1 − 2 n + 1 a − 4 β b 2 ξ 0 , k 2 = ± 1 we obtain: (68) q x , t = 2 n + 1 κ λ − b 1 4 n + 1 b 2 1 ± tanh n κ λ − b 1 2 n + 1 − 2 n + 1 a − 4 β b 2 x − vt + ξ 0 1 2 n e i − κ x + ω t + θ , (69) q x , t = 2 n + 1 κ λ − b 1 4 n + 1 b 2 1 ± coth n κ λ − b 1 2 n + 1 − 2 n + 1 a − 4 β b 2 x − vt + ξ 0 1 2 n e i − κ x + ω t + θ , where Eqs. (68) and (69) represent dark soliton and singular soliton solutions respectively. These solitons are valid for a − 4 β b 2 < 0 . Case 2 Substituting Eq. (61) into Eq. (60) along with m = 2n and setting the coefficients of ψ −j , j = 0,1,2,3,4 to zero, then we obtain a set of algebraic equations. Solving this system, we obtain (70) a 0 = 2 n + 1 b 1 2 n + 1 κ λ − b 2 , a 1 = ± 1 2 n 2 n + 1 a − 4 β κ λ − b 2 , (71) ω = − 1 4 n + 1 2 κ λ − b 2 4 κ 3 a λ n 2 + 8 κ 3 a λ n − 4 κ 2 an 2 b 2 + 4 κ 2 δ λ n 2 + 4 κ 3 a λ − 8 κ 2 anb 2 + 8 κ 2 δ λ n − 4 κ δ n 2 b 2 + 4 κ γ λ n 2 − 4 κ 2 ab 2 + 4 κ 2 δ λ − 8 κ δ nb 2 + 8 κ γ λ n − 4 γ n 2 b 2 − 4 κ δ b 2 + 4 κ γ λ − 8 γ nb 2 − 2 nb 1 2 − 4 γ b 2 − b 1 2 , and (72) ψ ′ ′ = ± b 1 n 2 n + 1 n + 1 a − 4 β κ λ − b 2 ψ ′ , (73) ψ ′ ′ ′ = b 1 2 n 2 2 n + 1 n + 1 2 a − 4 β κ λ − b 2 ψ ′ . From Eqs. (72) and (73), we can deduce that (74) ψ ′ = ± n + 1 a − 4 β κ λ − b 2 b 1 n 2 n + 1 k 1 e ± b 1 n 2 n + 1 n + 1 a − 4 β κ λ − b 2 ξ , and (75) ψ = n + 1 2 a − 4 β κ λ − b 2 b 1 2 n 2 2 n + 1 k 1 e ± b 1 n 2 n + 1 n + 1 a − 4 β κ λ − b 2 ξ + k 2 , where k 1 and k 2 are constants of integration. Substituting Eqs. (74) and (75) into Eq. (61), we obtain following exact solution to Eq. (58) q x , t = 2 n + 1 b 1 2 n + 1 κ λ − b 2 ± 1 2 n 2 n + 1 a − 4 β κ λ − b 2 ± n + 1 a − 4 β κ λ − b 2 b 1 n 2 n + 1 k 1 e ± b 1 n 2 n + 1 n + 1 a − 4 β κ λ − b 2 ( x − vt ) n + 1 2 a − 4 β κ λ − b 2 b 1 2 n 2 2 n + 1 k 1 e ± b 1 n 2 n + 1 n + 1 a − 4 β κ λ − b 2 ( x − vt ) + k 2 1 2 n × e i − κ x + ω t + θ where ω is given by Eq. (71). If we set k 1 = b 1 2 n 2 2 n + 1 n + 1 2 a − 4 β κ λ − b 2 e ± b 1 n 2 n + 1 n + 1 a − 4 β κ λ − b 2 ξ 0 , k 2 = ± 1 we obtain: (76) q x , t = 2 n + 1 b 1 4 n + 1 κ λ − b 2 1 ± tanh b 1 n 2 n + 1 2 n + 1 a − 4 β κ λ − b 2 x − vt + ξ 0 1 2 n e i − κ x + ω t + θ , (77) q x , t = 2 n + 1 b 1 4 n + 1 κ λ − b 2 1 ± coth b 1 n 2 n + 1 2 n + 1 a − 4 β κ λ − b 2 x − vt + ξ 0 1 2 n e i − κ x + ω t + θ , where Eqs. These solitons are valid for a − 4 β κ λ − b 2 > 0 . 3.5 Quadratic-cubic law In this case, F ( s ) = b 1 s + b 2 s where b 1 and b 2 are constants. Therefore, Eq. The modified simple equation method was the integration scheme applied here and it has its limitations. It can only retrieve dark and singular solitons. This method fails to obtain bright soliton solution to the model. Nevertheless
column13: this method has advantages in studying soliton dynamics. Later
column14: this scheme will be applied to several other models to obtain soliton solutions in optics and other areas of mathematical physics. Those results are awaited currently and will be reported with time. Acknowledgements The work of the seventh author (QZ) was sponsored by the Chutian Scholar Program of Hubei Government in China. column2: Design, fabrication and testing of fiber bragg grating based fixed guided beam pressure sensor
column3: Abstract A stainless steel pressure sensor using rigid center diaphragm and a fixed guided beam with FBG sensor is proposed in this paper. Two bare FBGs are bonded on to the tensile and compressive regions of the fixed guided beam. The deflection of the diaphragm due to the applied pressure induces strain on to the fixed guided beam which in-turn shifts Bragg wavelength of the FBG. The sensor is fabricated and tested for its performance in the range of 0–20 bar. The test results are in close agreement with the results obtained from analytical and experimental models. The sensitivity, nonlinearity and resolution of the sensor are found to be 0.103 nm/bar, 0.0008% full scale deflection (FSD) and 0.05 bar. The use of rigid center diaphragm improves the linearity of the sensor for a wider pressure range, and the fixed guided beam provides equal magnitudes of tensile and compressive stresses on the surface of the beam. The differential output in wavelength shifts of the two FBGs nullifies the temperature effect and hence offers temperature compensation.
column5: Keywords Pressure sensor Rigid center diaphragm Fixed guided beam Fiber Bragg grating (FBG) Linearity Temperature compensation 1 Introduction Pressure is an important physical parameter to be measured in almost all fields of engineering and industrial applications. Over the years many potential improvements were realized by using structures like flat diaphragm [1], boss diaphragm [2,3] and embossed diaphragm structures [4] in the fabrication of pressure sensors as they have played a key role in stress transferring mechanism to the sensing element. Structures using stainless steel as fabrication material have an added advantage of usage in, corrosive and harsh environmental applications as they isolate the sensing element from the media. A media compatible stainless steel diaphragm based capacitive pressure sensor developed by Shih-Shian Ho et al. [5] showed a nonlinearity, hysteresis of 3.4% and 2.2% FS, A piezoelectric resonant based pressure sensor with stainless steel diaphragm developed by Y. Sujan et al. [6] for a pressure range of 0–25 bar, showed a nonlinearity, hysteresis of 1.1% and 1.35%. Various types of secondary sensing element like optical, piezoresistive, piezoelectric, capacitance etc have been used along with the diaphragm as the primary sensing element, has been reported in the literature. But optical based Fiber Bragg grating (FBG) for sensing the strain caused by induced displacement has received considerable attention in various fiber-optic sensor applications and is a preferred choice in our experimentation owing to its advantages of compact size, high sensitivity, absolute measurement, low cost, multipoint sensing, immunity to electromagnetic interference and easy integration into electronic circuits as highlighted by Marcelo M, Regina C.S.B. Allil et al. [7]. It works on the principal of shift in Bragg wavelength caused by change in strain due to applied pressure. Diverse methods of aligning the FBGs to the primary sensing element to improve the output characteristics have been adopted.A pressure sensor with FBG bonded along the perpendicular axis of a stainless steel circular diaphragm has been designed and tested by Vengal Rao et al. [8] showed a sensitivity, linearity of 0.0205/MPa and 0.998, the other developed by Yanling Xiong et al. [9] displayed a sensitivity, linearity of 0.023/MPa and 0.9720. A FBG pressure sensor based on diaphragm-cantilever structure with FBGs bonded on to the cantilever developed by Min-Fu Liang et al. [10] displayed a sensitivity, linearity of 0.339 nm/MPa and 0.9997 and a double shell cylinder consisting of two steel shells with two FBGs mounted in axial and tangential direction developed and tested by Wentao Zhang et al. [11] displayed a sensitivity of 0.0937nm/MPa, indicating that the alignment of the FBGs affects the sensitivity and linearity of the sensor. In order to achieve higher sensitivity with good linearity novel ways of aligning the FBGs and the primary sensing element design are crucial. However FBG and the structure material are also sensitive to temperature and hence isolating the temperature induced wavelength shift in the FBG based pressure sensors is of great practical importance. To address this issue a number of techniques have been developed, such as a double shell cylinder consisting of two steel shells with two FBGs mounted in axial and tangential direction by Wentao Zhang et al. [11], using a independent reference FBG to sense only temperature by Yong Zhao et al. [12], fabricating two FBG of different diameter fibers as in D. Sengupta et al. [13], a structural element made of three kinds of material with different temperature coefficient of expansion, which can induce negative strain by Y.S. Hsu et al. [14], A FBG based pressure sensor with two FBGs bonded along the radial axis of a large stainless steel circular diaphragm by Jun Huang and Zude Zhou [15], and combining FBG with Fabry-Perot interference devices as suggested by Yuchi Lin and Wei Wang [16]. This paper presents a compact stainless steel integrated structure comprising of a rigid circular diaphragm and a fixed guided beam landing at its centre, with two FBGs mounted in the tensile and compression regions of the fixed guided beam has been designed and tested. The advantage of the proposed sensor is that it is fabricated from a monolithic single metal die, and the stress transfer mechanism proposed provides maximum stress to the FBGs, in addition it provides a simpler mechanism to compensate for temperature, as the structure offers equal magnitudes of tensile and compressive stresses on the surface of the fixed guided beam, compared to the mechanisms already reported in literature. The proposed sensor also exhibits improved linearity, hysteresis, repeatability and offers temperature compensation for a pressure range of 0–20 bar, the pressure sensitivity increases substantially compared to the single FBG based sensing. 2 Sensor design and principle The schematic diagram of the proposed sensor is shown in Fig. 1 . It comprises of a rigid centre diaphragm with a fixed guided beam made of stainless steel (SS) as the primary sensing element and Fiber Bragg Grating strain sensor as the secondary sensing element. As the primary sensing structure consists of multiple individual elements like the diaphragm, rigid mass and the beam it is analyzed separately as section I, section II and evaluated together finally. The section I of the primary sensing element as shown in Fig. 2 a consists of a circular diaphragm with a rigid mass at the centre (rigid centre diaphragm) with radius a, thickness h, rigid mass height c and b the distance of rigid mass from the centre of the diaphragm. The section II as shown in Fig. 2b, consists of a fixed guided beam with length l, width w and thickness t, resting on the rigid centre of the diaphragm, with its guided end free to move vertically along with the rigid centre. This integrated mechanical structure is laser welded on to a stainless steel pressure port (M14 × 1.5) shown in Fig. 1a, for applying input pressure P. The complete sensor with the FBG sensing element after assembly is shown in Fig. 1c. When an input pressure P is applied to the rigid centre diaphragm via the pressure port, the deflection of the diaphragm with its outer edge clamped is governed by the differential equation given by [17] (1) d d r 1 r   d d r r   d y d r =   Q D where y is the deflection at radius r, d y d r is the slope at radius r, Q is the shearing force per unit length and D is the rigidity given by, (2) D =   E h 3 12   ( 1 − μ 2 ) For uniformly distributed load of pressure the equation reduces to, Q   ×   2 π r =   P   ×   π   r 2 (3) d d r 1 r   d d r r   d y d r =   P   r 2 D Integrating (4) 1 r   d d r r   d y d r =   P   r 2 4 D + C 1   (5) r   d y d r =   P   r 4 16 D   +   C 1   r 2 2 +   C 2 The slope and deflection equations of the rigid centre diaphragm are given by (6)   d y d r =   P   r 3 16 D   + C 1 r 2 +   C 2 r (7)   y =   P   r 4 64 D   +   C 1   r 2 4 +   C 2   ln ( r ) +   C 3 The constants C1,C2 and C3 are obtained by applying appropriate boundary conditions. At the clamped end of the diaphragm the slope and deflection are d y d r   ( r = a ) =   0     a n d     y ( r = a ) =   0         (8)   P   a 3 16 D   + C 1   a 2 +   C 2 a   = 0 (9)   P   a 4 64 D   + C 1   a 2 4 +   C 2 ln ( a ) + C 3   = 0 At the rigid mass end of the diaphragm the slope is d y d r ( r = b ) =   0   (10)   P   b 3 16 D   + C 1   b 2 +   C 2 b = 0 Solving for constants C1, C2 and C3 from the above Eqs. (8)–(10) (11) C 1   = − P 8 D   ( b 2 +   a 2 )   C 2   = P   b 2   a 2 16   D   C 3   = P a 2 16 D   a 2 4   +   b 2 2   −   b 2 ln ( a ) The deflection of the rigid centre diaphragm at b is given by, (12)   y d =   P   b 4 64 D   +   C 1   b 2 4 +   C 2   ln ( b ) +   C 3 Substituting for C1, C2 and C3 in Eq. (12) (13) y d = P   16   D a 4 4 − b 4 4   +   a 2 b 2 ln ( b ) − a 2 b 2 ln ( a ) (14) y d = P   16   D A p Where Ap is a constant related to the geometry of the structure. The stiffness of the rigid centre diaphragm is given by (15) k d = F o r c e D e f l e c t i o n = Pr e s s u r e   * A r e a D e f l e c t i o n = P   π a 2   y d The displacement of the fixed guided beam yb as shown in Fig. 2b is determined using a third order polynomial equation as there are four boundary conditions.[18] (16) y b = a 0 + a 1 x + a 2 x 2 + a 3 x 3 Differentiating Eq. (16) d y b d x = a 1 + 2 x a 2 + 3 x 2 a 3 d 2 y b d x 2 = 2 a 2 + 6 x a 3 d 3 y b d x 3 = 6 a 3 The constants a0, a1, a2 and a3 are determined by satisfying appropriate boundary conditions, at the fixed end y b ( x = 0 ) = 0 d y b d x ( x = 0 ) = 0 at the guided end d y b d x ( x = l ) = 0   d 3 y b d x 3 E I ( x = l ) = −   F Where E and I are the Young's modulus of the material and Moment of inertia of the fixed guided beam. Solving for constants a0, a1, a2 and a3 from the above boundary conditions a 0     = 0           a 1 = 0           a 2 = F l 4 E I         a 3 = − F l 6 E I Substituting the constants in the Eq. (16) the displacement of the fixed guided beam yb along its length for a specified distance x from the fixed end is (17) y b = F 12 E I ( 3 l x 2 − 2 x 3 ) The maximum displacement ybmax of the fixed guided beam at the guided end, when x = l will be (18) y b max = F l 3 12 E I The stiffness of the fixed guided beam is given by (19) k b = F o r c e D e f l e c t i o n = 12 E I l 3 = E w t 3   l 3 Where w and t are the width and thickness of the fixed guided beam. As the integrated structure is monolithic and the stiffness of the rigid centre diaphragm is substantially higher than the stiffness of the fixed guided beam, the deflection of the diaphragm y d is transferred as an input to the fixed guided beam. The force F generated on the fixed guided beam at its guided end due to its deflection y b , imposed by the deflection y d of the rigid centre diaphragm under pressure is derived to be y d = y b max = F l 3 12 E I (20) F = 12   E I l 3 y d The stress (σ) generated on the fixed guided beam along its length for a specified distance x from the fixed end is given by [19] (21) σ = F t 2 I l 2 − x Substituting for the generated force F in Eq. (21), the axial stress (σ) and strain (ε) on the fixed guided beam along its length for a specified distance x from the fixed end is derived to be (22) σ = 6   E   t   ( y d )   l 3 l 2 − x (23) ε = 6   t   ( y d )   l 3 l 2 − x Where x is the distance from the fixed end where the secondary sensing element is mounted. The maximum stress generated on the fixed guided beam is tensile at the free end and compressive towards the fixed end of equal magnitudes, as shown by the schematic representation in Fig. 3 (a and b), when the values of x is l or ‘0’, thereby the maximum tensile and compressive strain on the fixed guided beam is given by (24) ε t   max = 3   t   ( y d )   l 2 (25) ε c   max =   − 3   t   ( y d )   l 2 Two FBGs of length lf and diameter df which forms the secondary sensing element is bonded on the maximum tensile and compressive regions of the fixed guided beam as shown in Fig. 1c. The sensing property of FBG is based on the shift in the Bragg wavelength of the FBG (Δλ) which is simultaneously modulated by strain (Δε) and temperature (ΔT) [7,15,16,20] (26) Δ λ =   λ b   1 − p e Δ ε   + α + ζ Δ T Where pe is the effective photoelastic coefficient constant, α is the thermal expansion coefficient and ζ the thermal optic coefficient. The reflected Bragg wavelength   ( λ b ) is given by (27) λ b =   2   η   Λ Where η and Λ are the refractive index of the fiber and the pitch of the grating in the fiber respectively. The shift in Bragg wavelength (λ) is captured by the FBG interrogator and logged using data acquisition system. By interrogating the shift in Bragg wavelength, pressure and temperature can be quantified. The wavelength shift ( Δ λ t and Δ λ c ), experienced by the FBG1 and FBG2 mounted in the tensile and compressive region is given by (28) Δ λ     t λ   t =   1 − p e 3   t   ( y d )   l 2 + α + ζ Δ T (29) Δ λ     c λ   c =   1 − p e − 3   t   ( y d )   l 2 + α + ζ Δ T As the two FGBs are fabricated with identical initial wavelengths of 1525 nm and the initial wavelength is much larger than the wavelength shifts ( Δ λ t , Δ λ c ), λ t and λ c is replaced by an equivalent value ( λ ). Additionally, as the distance between them is small the two FBGs are assumed to undergo the same temperature variation. Hence the difference in wavelength shifts of the two FBGs is a linear function of pressure and independent of temperature, as the temperature effect is nullified as shown in Eq. (31) and k is the pressure sensitivity constant for the structure. In addition, when the wavelength shift difference of the two FBGs is considered as the sensing signal, the pressure sensitivity is increased considerably, compared to using the wavelength shift of a single FBG. (30) Δ λ   t − Δ λ c =   3   λ     t   ( A p )   ( 1 − p e )   8   l 2 D P (31) Δ λ   t − Δ λ c =   k P 3 Sensor fabrication and testing The fabrication of the sensor involves two major steps the first being the fabrication of the integrated structure which makes up the primary sensing element and laser welding it to the pressure port. The second step is the mounting of the FBG on to the primary sensing element. The dimensions and properties of the sensor are given in Table 1 .The material 17-4 pH stainless steel is considered for fabrication of the structural element, due to its high chromium content and high strength coupled with good corrosion resistance and excellent toughness, which are very much desirable properties for a pressure sensor as they find usage in corrosive environments. The dimensions of the structure such as the b/a ratio are chosen to ensure linear relation between the applied pressure and deflection of the diaphragm for the entire range of operating pressure. The thickness of the diaphragm and the beam are fixed considering the EDM manufacturing process limitations. The material of diameter 30mm and length 50mm was machined to the designed dimension, the diaphragm and the fixed guided beam were realized by wire cut EDM process and laser welded to the pressure port (M14 × 1.5). Two bare FBG sensors were bonded using adhesive axially in the tensile and compression region of the fixed guided beam, the photograph of the sensor is shown in Fig. 4 (c and d). The sensor was calibrated for a pressure range of 0–20 bar in increment of 4 bar using a dead weight primary standard hydraulic calibrator (Make: FLUKE, Model: P3125-BAR). The FBG interrogator (Make: Micron optics, Model SM130) was used to acquire data, which has the capability to acquire the reflected Bragg wavelength dynamically. The block diagram and the photograph of the calibration setup areas shown in the Fig. 4(a and b). 4 Results and discussion To show the advantages of the rigid centre diaphragm used in the design of the proposed pressure sensor, a comparative study of the pressure-deflection characteristics of the integrated structure with the rigid centre diaphragm and a flat circular diaphragm is carried out using COMSOL Multiphysics. The dimensions and properties of the diaphragm used in the simulation are the same as given in Table 1, designed for a pressure range of 0–20 bar. It is seen that the stiffness brought about by the rigid centre reduces the deflection of the centre diaphragm under load. This makes the response of the rigid centre diaphragm to applied pressure more linear compared to that of the flat diaphragm, but on the other hand decreases the sensitivity. It is observed that a maximum improvement of up to 2.5% in linearity can be achieved, with a 36% reduction in sensitivity. The comparison of the displacement characteristics of the flat and rigid centre diaphragm indicates, smaller the h/a ratio higher is the displacement as indicated in Fig. 5 a.The b/a ratio of the rigid center diaphragm which is another important dimensional ratio affecting the performance characteristics of the primary sensing element shows that a higher b/a ratio decreases the displacement of the diaphragm, as depicted in Fig. 5b. Simulation studies are also carried out on the integrated structure to determine the optimal landing position of the guided end of the fixed guided beam and the stress distribution with respect to the beam position. It is noticed that landing the fixed guided beam eccentric to the centre of the rigid centre diaphragm increases or decreases the tensile/compressive strain accordingly, however by landing the beam at the centre of the diaphragm, higher and equal magnitudes of tensile and compressive strain of∼900 με at 20 bar can be generated as shown in Fig. 6 a. The stiffness for rigid centre diaphragm and fixed guided beam calculated using Eqs. (15) and (19) are 13,338 N/mm and 135 N/mm, which shows that the value of stiffness of the rigid centre diaphragm is substantially higher than that of the fixed guided beam, thereby completely transferring the displacement of the rigid centre diaphragm, induced due to the applied pressure, on to the fixed guided beam. The comparison of analytical and numerical simulation done using COMSOL Multiphysics software also show a close match as seen in the Fig. 6b. The maximum tensile and compressive strain of ∼900 με at 20 bar pressure was observed. The input-output characteristics namely sensitivity, non-linearity, hysteresis and resolution of the pressure sensor are obtained experimentally for a pressure range of 0–20 bar in increments of 4 bar. The results are as shown in Fig. 7 (a–c), conducted using an experimental setup as in Fig. 4(a and b). The sensitivity, non-linearity, hysteresis and resolution were found to be 0.103 nm/bar, 0.0008% full scale deflection (FSD),0.0006% FSD and 0.05 bar as in Fig. 7(a and b).The calculated linearity was found to be 99.94%.The sensor was also tested for repeatability by applying three cycles of ascending and descending pressure and found to have good repeatability as shown in Fig. 7c. The calculated experimental maximum tensile and compressive strain values was 870 με, at 20 bar pressure shows a close match to the obtained simulation and analytical results. In order to evaluate the sensor’s temperature compensation performance, the wavelength shift difference versus the temperature raise at constant pressure has been tested. The fluctuation of wavelength shift is mainly caused by the difference of thermal stress distribution on the surface of the fixed guided beam. A hot and cold chamber (Make: Votch, Model: VCL 7003) is used in our experimentation to vary the temperature of the sensor between 0 °C to 60 °C with a sampling interval of 10 °C. The effect of change in wavelength with respect to temperature change of the two FBG’s are plotted in Fig. 8 a. The differential output of the two FBGs results in nullifying the effect of temperature, as shown in Fig. 8b. The maximum differential value of 0.0067 nm occurring at 50 °C and the sensor’s temperature compensation effect is quite noticeable. It is also observed that sensors sensitivity increases considerably by taking the differential output of both the FBGs as noticed in Eq. (30). The 'k' pressure sensitivity constant of the structure calculated using Eq. (30) is found to be 1.16. The comparison of cumulative analytical and experimental differential output of the sensor shows a close match as in the Fig. 9 . 5 Conclusion A stainless steel FBG based pressure sensor with a rigid centre circular diaphragm and a fixed guided beam landing at its centre,(for a pressure range of 0–20 bar) is designed, fabricated and tested for its performance. In this sensor design, the fixed guided beam is favorably landed on to the rigid centre circular diaphragm so that it produces equal magnitudes of tensile and compressive strain at its free and fixed end, which is captured by the two FBGs to determine the applied pressure. The differential output of the two FBGs nullifies the effect of temperature and also increases the sensitivity of the sensor, in addition the sensor is found to have improvement in linearity as compared to the sensor designed with flat diaphragm. The sensor possess good repeatability and low hysteresis, further the resolution is found to be 0.05 bar. The experimental test results are in close agreement with the results obtained from the analytical model. Acknowledgements The authors thank departments of CeNSE, IAP IISc, Prof. Asokan S, Dr. Sharath U and Ms. Shweta Pant for providing systems and facilities to carry out the present work.

column2: Recognition of 25 natural geological samples using a modified correlation analysis method and laser-induced breakdown spectroscopic data
column3: Abstract The recognition of natural geological samples is of great significance for mineral exploration and geological research. Because of the powerful element analysis ability, the laser-induced breakdown spectroscopy data was widely used in the classification and recognition of samples in recent two decades. Correlation coefficient, as a classical statistic parameter, reflects the degree of a close correlation between variables, and can be used to compare the LIBS data of test samples with the existing data. But it is difficult to get high accuracy in dealing with the identification problems of natural geological samples, which are usually composed of similar elements and mixed with minor impurity constituents. So, some typical spectral data segments and quantitative features, such as the intensity ratios of elements of LIBS data, are extracted and combined with the correlation coefficient by a specially designed analytical model to identify the geological samples. The modified correlation coefficient method shows a positive improvement in the recognition accuracy, while less complexity than the widely used pattern recognition methods.
column5: Keywords Mineral recognition LIBS The modified correlation analysis Intensity ratios 1 Introduction The recognition of natural geological samples is of great scientific significance for mineral exploration, and geological evolution research on the planets. Laser-induced Breakdown Spectroscopy (LIBS) can detect element composition of samples, and have great advantages in in-situ component analysis application. Some researches on geological samples analysis have been carried out based on LIBS [1–3]. On the other side, the natural geological samples are usually composed of complex elements. Some multivariate analysis methods, such as Principal Components Analysis (PCA), Partial Least Squares-Discriminate Analysis (PLS-DA), Soft Independent Modeling Class Analog (SIMCA), and so on, were naturally used to resolve the multivariate analysis problems in these intricate system [4–8]. The combined using of LIBS data and diverse multivariate methods(pattern recognition methods) have showed a good ability in field of component analysis. But unfortunately, the multivariate analysis methods are often too complex to use in for some in-situ application of portable LIBS instrument. This research prefers to find an analysis method with less complexity and small calculation load. As a classical statistic parameter, correlation coefficient reflects the degree of a close correlation between variables. It can be used to compare the detected laser-induced breakdown spectroscopic data of test samples with the existing element LIBS data, and then to identify samples with obvious elemental difference [9–11]. Correlation coefficient is also widely used as one parameter to assess the validity of some processing method, so does in field of LIBS data analysis [12,13]. But the correlation coefficient is difficult to deal with the classification and identification problems directly because of its deficiency in quantitative data. The natural mineral samples are usually composed of similar elements, such as some main diagenetic elements: Na, Mg, Al, Si, K, Ca, or mixed with some minor impurity constituents. So, the elements composition and relative contents are vital for the mineral and rock identification. In this paper, some quantitative features of the LIBS data, such as the intensity ratios of spectral lines from different elements, are extracted as an indicator of relative contents and combined with correlation coefficients by an analytical model to identify the minerals. Some preliminary results are presented. 2 Samples and experimental setup A detection system (Fig. 1 ) was set up and used to obtain the LIBS spectra of the samples, detailed description of which has been given before [14]. Only some key information about this system were presented here: a 10ns pulse width and 10 Hz repetition 1064 nm laser (Quantel, Brilliant B) was used as the excitation source. The LIBS signal was collected by a lateral double lens system, went through a Mechelle 5000 spectrograph, and acquired by an iStar DH734i-18F-03 intensified CCD camera (with internal Digital Delay Generator). Using this system, wide spectral range (212 nm–1032 nm) and high resolution (5000@500 nm) LIBS spectrum can be obtained at only one acquisition. Twenty five kinds of natural geological samples were used in this study, which were listed in Table 1 . All samples were broken into little pieces and the sampling points are in the new fracture plane to avoid the environment contamination. In view of the roughness of the samples’ fragmentized surface, careful laser focusing is done for every sampling point, but the fluctuation of the pulsed laser energy and the excited plasma is inevitable. To improve the stability of the LIBS data, the signal Integration On CCD chip (IOC) from 3 pulses excitation and accumulation of 2 spectra in memory were done. That is to say, a single LIBS spectrum was obtained from 6 laser pulses. 3 Methods 3.1 Spectra preprocessing Because of the instabilities of laser pulse energy, the laser focus precision, the heterogeneous component distribution of natural mineral samples, and so on, the spectra of the same mineral are still inconsistent, even though the IOC and accumulation operation during the LIBS data acquisition. To further improve the homogeneity of the spectra, each LIBS data was firstly normalized with its maximum intensity, then the numeric average of the normalized data were made for each kind of geological sample. The LIBS data of natural geological samples were usually redundant for recognition application: First, only part of the LIBS data include effective spectral lines; secondly, only part of the spectral lines are necessary. So, In order to reduce the unnecessary computation and avoid the possible blocking in the program processing from the full LIBS data, the LIBS data were usually condensed by feature extraction operation, for instance, Principal Components Analysis (PCA). But, the extracted PCS are often absence of clear physical meaning. According to the NIST database [15] and the mineral LIBS data obtained from the experiment, some spectral data segments containing typical spectral lines of some usual ore-forming elements like Si, Ca, K, Na, Mg, Al, Ba, Fe, Li, et al. were extracted as the classification features. Fig. 2 shows the main spectral lines of 5 samples: Tektite, Biotite, Albite, Reniform hematite and Anhydrite. The relevant information was listed in Table 2 . By this operation, the dimensions of LIBS data were reduced from 28,243 to 1578. 3.2 Correlation coefficient and the modified method Correlation coefficient reflects the degree of a close correlation between variables, which was based on the product of deviations between two variables and their averaged values. The linear correlation coefficient is calculated using the following formula [9]: (1) r = ∑ ( x i − x ¯ ) ( y i − y ¯ ) ∑ ( x i − x ¯ ) 2 ∑ ( y i − y ¯ ) 2 Here, x and y are two data sets, which may be the full LIBS data or corresponding spectral segments of unknown mineral and foregone mineral. x ¯ and y ¯ are their mean value. Then the value of r can be used to compare the detected LIBS data of test samples with the existing data, and it is a good statistic parameter to indicate whether they have the same components or they are the same kind of mineral, only if x and y containing corresponding spectral features. Most natural geological samples are mixture of complex compositions, usually the main compositions and some kinds of impurities. As for the elements, which are the detection target of LIBS technique, similar elements such as some ore-forming elements like Ca, K, Na, Mg, Al, et al. may exist in different natural geological samples, and even, their distinction could lie in their structure or different content. Another possibilities, the same kind of minerals may contain different elements, for instance, different impurity elements. In a word, the existence and quantity of every elements are vital for identification of natural geological samples. Correlation coefficient method is easy to judge the existence of different elements, but it is difficult to display the elements content information. So, a new parameter m was introduced as a supplement to correlation coefficient. m n can be defined like this, (2) m = M a x [ x i ] M a x [ y i ] In this formula, x i and y i are spectrum segments of 2 LIBS data. Just as mentioned before, the 2 LIBS data were firstly normalized with their own maximum intensity. M a x means get its maximum intensity value in the spectrum segments. Then if x i and y i are from the same kind of mineral, m means the ratio of peak intensity of the same spectral line. And they should have roughly the same elements, nearly the same intensity in corresponding spectrum segment, then m should tend to be 1. If n spectrum segments are featured and extracted from the full LIBS data to recognize an element, a parameter f can be designated to identify this element, and “f” will obtain its minimum value only when x and y are from the same mineral. (3) f = 1 n ∑ i = 1 n ( r i - 1 ) 2 + 1 n ∑ i = 1 n ( m i - 1 ) 2 A database including k elements and their corresponding spectrum segments’ information was needed to set up, and the analytical model as formula (4) can be used to identify the different kinds of minerals: (4) P = ∑ i = 1 K f i 4 Result and analysis One hundred spectra were used for each sample. In view of the fact that the standard spectral data of the natural geography samples play an key role in the analysis models, 20 spectra were averaged as the standard spectral data to get robust standard spectral data, and the last were averaged every 8 spectra and used as a testing set. So, there are 10 test data for each kind of mineral sample. Table 3 gives the comparison of the identification results of modified methods and traditional correlation coefficient (data are shown in the sequence of ‘correlation coefficient /modified methods’) of 25 kinds of minerals (shown in the same sequence number as in Table 1) respectively by the correlation coefficient and modified method presented in this study. Some difference in the classification accuracy can be noticed in Table 3, and the correlation coefficient method has an average accuracy of 94.4% for the 250 validation spectra, while the modified method has a higher accuracy of 96.80%. The classification errors were concentrated in nearly the same kinds of mineral, such as Idocrase (NO. 6), Carbuncle (NO. 8), Magnesite (NO.14), Albite (NO.15), Diopside (NO. 19) and Moonstone (NO. 22) for both the traditional correlation coefficient method and the modified method. So, the similar element components cause the failure of classification, and the introduction of quantitative spectra information in the modified method improves the recognition accuracy. To validate the improvement in accuracy of the modified method, we directly applied the two methods to a group of new samples: white mica, olivine, scoria, desert rose stone, quartzite, fibrous gypsum, which were not used in course of the algorithm research in this paper, and we got a lower classification accuracy of 86.6% and 91.6% respectively for the correlation coefficient method and the modified method. The decreased classification accuracy probably results from the featured spectral segments, which were not so good for these samples. That is to say, more works on feature extraction needed before applying this method to more unknown minerals. But, we have reasons to believe that the modified method has a better classification accuracy than the correlation coefficient method. The SVM (Support Vector Machine) method have shown good performance in terms of classification and recognition application. Here we apply SVM to the same LIBS data from the 25 mineral samples: for every sample, the 20 spectra data were averaged every 2 data and used as the training set, and the rest 80 spectra were averaged every 8 data and used as a testing set. Firstly, the 1578 data extracted as in Table 2 were used to train and test, with the radial basis function as the kernel function, and an averaged classification accuracy of 85.2% was obtained. So, comparing with the modified correlation coefficient method elaborated above, the SVM has a lower accuracy under the similar training set (standard data for the modified method) and testing set. We think it is due to the limited number of training set data. Although it is difficult to judge the performance of the modified correlation coefficient method at present, it shows some accuracy advantages in condition of the limited training data. When the full 28,243 spectra data were used to train and test, the accuracy was only 77.6%, and the computing time was tremendous long because of the huge number of data dimensions. So, the featured data have a higher classification accuracy and less calculation load than the full spectra when using the SVM method, and this result also proves the effectiveness and feasibility of the feature extraction operation presented in this paper. 5 Conclusions This research prefers to find a processing method with less complexity to recognize the mineral samples by their LIBS data. An analytical model, combining the ratios of LIBS spectrum lines intensity of some typical elements with the correlation coefficients of extracted spectral segments, is presented in this research, and some positive improvement in accuracy of mineral classification was obtained comparing to the traditional correlation coefficient method. The contrastive analysis with the SVM method shows that the modified correlation coefficient method may have the advantage of high accuracy in the condition of limited training set, and the advantage of less complexity is promising in the in-situ mineral classification and identify application. As a vital operation in the modified method, feature extraction of LIBS data is preliminarily verified by SVM method, but it also shows some deficiencies in the test to new samples. Improving the adaptability of the LIBS characteristics database is the next step to strengthen the practicality of the modified correlation coefficient method. Acknowledgement This research is supported by Natural Science Foundation of China (Grant No. 41503063) and the National Key Research and Development Program of China (Grant No. 2016YFC0302101). The authors show deep thankfulness to Tian Ye for his valuable suggestions.

column2: A passively Q-switched 1087.2 nm c-cut Nd:YVO4 laser with WS2-based saturable absorber
column3: Abstract A compact and simple pulsed 1087.2 nm c-cut Nd:YVO4 laser with WS2-based saturable absorber (SA) is reported for the first time. A chosen output-coupled mirror with high-transmission coating at 1066 nm and part-reflection coating at 1087 nm to achieve a high gain at 1087.2 nm and suppress the line at 1066 nm. The highest CW and pulse 1087.2 nm powers are 2314 mW and 608 mW, respectively. The shortest pulse width is only 135 ns.
column5: Keywords WS2 1087.2 nm laser Q-switched Diode-pumped lasers 1 Introduction Pulse near-infrared Nd:YVO4 lasers at 914, 1064, 1066, 1085, 1110 and 1342 nm, which are passively Q-switched by some various SAs, have been paid great attention due to their admirable applications in self-Raman lasers, medical treatments, laser ranging, and producing visible light by frequency doubling technique [1. 2]. Various conventional SAs such as Co2+, V3+ and Cr4+-doped materials, PbS glass and SESAM have been used widely for a very long time, but they are restricted due to narrow absorption-band [1]. Recently, some two-dimensional nano-materials, such as graphene-oxide, graphene, MoS2, WS2, Bi2Se3, WSe2, and black phosphorus, become very novel SAs due to their outstanding broadband operation [2–4]. Among them, WS2 exhibits greater SA performance in higher damage threshold and larger modulation depth [4,5]. Here, we demonstrate a pulsed 1087.2 nm laser with WS2-based SA for the first time. 2 Experimental setup The setup of a 1087.2 nm Nd:YVO4 laser is displayed in Fig. 1 . An 808 LDA is the pump light, which is focused into a c-cut Nd:YVO4 crystal with focusing lens. The length and Nd3+-doped concentration of the crystal are 20 mm and 0.27%, respectively. The 4 cm plane-plane cavity is formed by an input-mirror (Min) with high-transmission (HT) coating at 808 nm and high-reflection (HR) coating at 1087 nm, and an output-coupled mirror (Moc) with HT coating at 1066 nm and part-reflection (PR) coating at 1087 nm. The transmittances of Moc at 1066 and 1087 nm are 89.8% and 11.5%, which can be used to suppress oscillation at 1066 nm and improve gain at 1087 nm, respectively. The 1087 nm laser is passively Q-switched by a WS2− based SA with a transmittance of 88.4% (Fig. 2 ), which is manufactured via a liquid-phase-exfoliated method [2]. 3 Result and discussion 3.1 CW 1087 nm Nd:YVO4 laser The spectrum is detected firstly, when the pump power is changed from 4.15 W to 11.15 W. Only single-wavelength line at 1087.2 nm is found, and other line at 914, 1066, 1085, 1110 or 1342 nm does not emit. According to the spectrum monitored, we can see that the transmittance of Moc at 1066 nm is too large to suppress the oscillation at 1.06 μm. Fig. 3 presents the spectrum at the pump powers of 4.15 and 11.15 W, and the central wavelengths are 1087.15 and 1087.24 nm, respectively. Compare with the traditional oscillation at 1066 nm, the line at 1087.2 nm has a lower emission cross-section, corresponding to the transition of 4F3/2 (R2, 11,391 cm−1) → 4I11/2 (Y6, 2186 cm−1). However, the lower transmittance at 1087 nm of Moc can obtain an admirable gain-coefficient and obtain a single-wavelength line at 1087.2 nm. The threshold of the 1087.2 nm laser is about 4.05 W in Fig.4 . The CW 1087.2 nm power becomes larger and larger with the increase of the 808 nm pump power, and reaches to the largest rate of 2314 mW at the pump power of 11.15 W, corresponding to a conversion-efficient of 20.8%. This CW 1087.2 nm laser is very compact and efficient. 3.2 Pulsed 1087 nm Nd:YVO4 laser In order to achieve a pulsed 1087 nm laser, the WS2-based SA is integrated into the cavity. We obtain a pulsed 1087 nm laser with WS2-based SA for the first time. The pulse train of the pulsed 1087 nm laser at the pump of 11.15 W is shown in Fig. 5 . The threshold and the largest 1087 nm power are 6.95 W and 608 mW in Fig. 4, respectively. The higher threshold and the lower 1087 nm power can be chalked up to the inserting loss of the WS2-based SA. The repetition rate and pulse width of the 1087.2 nm laser are observed in Fig. 6 . When the pump power is changed from 6.96 W to 11.15 W, the repetition rate increases from 60 kHz to 255 kHz and the pulse width decreases from 383 ns to 135 ns. 4 Conclusion We obtain a pulsed 1087.2 nm laser with WS2-based SA for the first time. We employ an output-coupled mirror with HT coating at 1066 nm and PR coating at 1087 nm to achieve a high gain at 1087.2 nm and suppress the line at 1066 nm. The narrowest pulse width and the largest 1087 nm power are 135 ns and 608 mW, respectively. This 1087.2 nm laser can produce visible green light at 543.6 nm by frequency doubling technique. Acknowledgement This paper is partly sponsored by the Open Fund Project of Key Laboratory of Modern Precision Measurement and Laser Nondestructive Detection of China (2016XKA003), the Scientific Research Fund of Fujian Provincial Education Department of China (JAT170408), and the Fujian Natural Science Foundation of China (2016J01683).
