column2: Luminescent properties of green emitting Tb3+ doped Sr2ZnSi2O7 phosphors
column3: Abstract This article deals with green-emitting Tb-doped Sr2ZnSi2O7 phosphors. The Sr2ZnSi2O7:Tb3+ phosphor is prepared using the sol-gel method. The structural characterizations of the Sr2ZnSi2O7:Tb3+ phosphors were conducted using the XRPD and SEM analyses. The excitation and emission spectra signified that the phosphor could be effectively excited by a 239-nm ultraviolet excitation, and a green emission that is centered at 543 nm and that corresponds to the 5D4 → 7F5 transition was exhibited. Sound green emissions with the CIE chromaticity coordinates (0.2661, 0.43204) could be achieved. The Sr1.95ZnSi2O7:Tb0.05 powder showed the highest emission intensity for the 239-nm excitation, indicating its potential applicability in the fields of lighting and displays.
column5: Keywords Sol-gel XRPD Tb3+ ions Sr2ZnSi2O7 Photoluminescence 1 Introduction The photoluminescence (PL) that is related to the terbium (Tb) content in different host matrices has attracted significant attention in terms of the green-light emission, which is important in the field of long persistent phosphors, displays, sensors, and solid-state lighting [1–4]. Normally, the Tb3+ ions are preferred as a potential green-emitting dopant for the display of the sharp lines at approximately 543 nm that are attributed to the 5D4–7FJ (J = 6, 5, 4) transitions. The intensity of the Tb3+ absorption peaks, however, is weak, and the excitation band is very narrow due to the forbidden 4f–4f transition [3]. The Tb3+-doped luminescent materials such as La5Si3O12N [3], La0.6Y0.4PO4 [5], Ba3LaK(PO4)3F [6], NaLi2PO4 [7], and Ca2PO4Cl [8] have been studied by researchers because of their great optical performances. In general, the crystal structure of the host matrix is responsible for the luminescent performance of phosphors. The crucial part is the selection of the best possible host matrix. Recently, alkaline earth silicates have been reported as suitable materials for the lamp industry, and especially Sr2ZnSi2O7 [9–12]. This silicate possesses a tetragonal akermanite-type structure with the space group P 4 - 21m (no. 113) [13], and it contains discrete (Si2O7)6− units that are formed by two corner-sharing silicate (SiO4) tetrahedrals. The zinc (Zn) atoms lie in the tetrahedral that is formed by oxygen (O) atoms, while the tetrahedral of the Sr2+ cations is capable of an eight-fold O coordination [14]. In this article, Sr2ZnSi2O7 was selected as the host matrix because of its excellent luminescent performance. Earlier, it was prepared using the conventional solid-state method, but it is difficult to reduce the synthesis cost and time when this method is employed. Here, an attempt is made to prepare Tb-doped, high-quality Sr2ZnSi2O7 phosphors using a simple method (i.e., the sol-gel method). The effects of the Tb3+ ions on the photoluminescent properties of the Sr2ZnSi2O7:Tb3+ phosphors have been reported. This silicate phosphor could be an alternative green-emitting phosphor for the lighting and displays fields. 2 Experimental A series of Sr 2-x ZnSi2O7:Tb x (x = 0.01 ≤ x ≤ 0.11) samples were prepared via a citrate sol-gel method. High-purity-grade Sr(NO3)2, Zn(NO3)2∙6H2O, SiO2, citric acid, and Tb(NO3)3∙5H2O were used for the synthesis. The details of the sample composition and the starting materials are given in Table 1 . The stoichiometric amounts of the starting materials were dissolved in 10 ml of distilled water, and the citric acid (citric acid/metal ion = 2:1; molar ratio) was added with stirring to obtain a transparent solution. The citric acid served as a complexing/chelating agent while the stirring lasted for approximately 1 h to make a completely homogeneous solution of all of the reactants. The obtained transparent aqueous solution was kept in an oven at 110 °C for 12 h to produce a dried gel, and then the obtained dried gel was preheated in a furnace at 400 °C for 2 h. Lastly, the samples were grinded and sintered at 1000 °C for 6 h to obtain the final samples. A number of complementary methods were used to characterize the prepared phosphors. The X-ray powder diffraction (XRPD) patterns of the samples were recorded using the Rigaku Miniflex-II diffractometer (Rigaku, Japan), with CuKα radiation (λ = 1.5406 Å) playing the role of the X-ray source. The XRPD patterns were taken at a scan rate of 5°/minute in the 2θ range of 10–80°. The morphology details were obtained using the Hitachi S-3400 scanning electron microscope (SEM) from Hitachi, Japan. The photoluminescent measurements were carried out at room temperature on the Shimadzu RF-5301PC spectrofluorophotometer (Shimadzu Corporation, Japan) that had been equipped with a xenon-flash lamp. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Crystal structure and crystallite -size analysis Fig. 1 shows the XRPD patterns of the series of the Sr 2-x ZnSi2O7:Tb x (x = 0.01 ≤  x ≤ 0.11) samples. All of the notable peaks are in sound agreement with the pattern of the Joint Committee on Powder Diffraction Standards for Sr2ZnSi2O7 (International Centre for Diffraction Data [JCPDS] Card No-39-0235), thereby confirming a tetragonal structure [14]. From the XRPD pattern, it can be confirmed that the incorporation of the Tb ion into the Sr2ZnSi2O7 host lattice does not significantly alter the host structure (i.e., when the Sr2+ is replaced by the Tb3+, the crystal structure of the Sr2ZnSi2O7:Tb3+ phosphors remains unchanged). Although, a number of extra weak peaks (♦), which may belong to Sr2SiO4 and were formed during the synthesis, are present. Also, at the higher Tb3+ concentrations, the quantity of the additional peak intensities was increased. The Scherrer formula was then applied to calculate the crystallite size, as follows: (1) D = 0.9 λ/β cos θ, where λ is the wavelength of the incident X-ray, θ is the corresponding Bragg-diffraction angle, and β is the full width at half maximum (FWHM) of the (211) peak. The calculated crystallite size is in the region of 34–44 nm. The crystallite sizes and the FWHM values for all of the samples are given in Table 2 . 3.2 SEM analysis Fig. 2 shows the SEM morphologies of the Sr1.95ZnSi2O7:Tb0.05 phosphor, wherein it is evident that the powder was aggregated; this aggregation is owing to the high-temperature (1000 °C) annealing that increased the sizes of the phosphor particles, thereby making them highly vulnerable to agglomeration. The SEM images exhibit sponge-like agglomerated microcrystalline powders. The particle shapes are not regular, while the larger particles were formed from the agglomeration and the adhesion of the smaller particles, as shown in Fig. 2(a) and (b). It is difficult to control the aggregation of particles at higher temperatures because it is possible to observe highly aggregated particles in SEM images, and the highly agglomerated nature of particles makes it impossible to determine the exact particles sizes from SEM images. The formation of the smaller particles, however, can be seen in higher-magnification SEM images, and this is demonstrated in Fig. 2(c) and (d). The present study reveals that the excellent luminescent properties of the microcrystalline powder enhance the ability to find more corresponding applications [15–17]. 3.3 PL analysis The PL spectra of the Sr2- x ZnSi2O7:Tb x (x = 0.01 ≤ x  ≤  0.11) phosphors are presented in Fig. 3 . The PL-excitation spectra that are shown in Fig. 3(a) and were monitored at 543 nm reveal the maximum excitation peak at ∼239 nm. The spectra can be distinguished into different excitation bands, which are composed of two major bands, both of which are in the ultraviolet (UV) range, as follows: a band centered at ∼239 nm and a band centered at ∼ 280 nm. These observed bands at ∼239 nm and ∼280 nm are due to the spin-allowed and spin-forbidden 4f8–4f75d1 transitions of the Tb3+, respectively [18], and the latter peaks could be attributed to the forbidden Tb3+ 4f–4f transitions; that is, at ∼ 317 nm (7F6 → 5H7), at ∼ 351 nm (7F6 → 5D2), and at 377 nm (7F6 → 5G6) [19]. The former-band excitation intensity of ∼239 nm is much higher than that of the latter band; therefore, it has been chosen for further investigation. Fig. 3(b) shows the PL-emission spectra for the series of the Sr2- x ZnSi2O7:Tb x (x = 0.01 ≤  x ≤ 0.11) phosphor. The most pronounced emission band at ∼543 nm is due to the 5D4 → 7F5 transition that shows a bright-green emission, and it comprises the strongest intensity and the highest probability of the electric-dipole transition [20]. All of the prepared samples with the different Tb3+ concentrations exhibited similar emission peaks with the exception of the intensity values. The transitions of 5D3 or 5D4 to 7FJ produce a wide coverage emission between 360 nm and 620 nm. The peaks that are centered at ∼384, ∼415, ∼435, and ∼469 nm are from the 5D3–7FJ (J = 6, 5, 4, 3) transitions [7], while the peaks that are centered at ∼492, ∼543, ∼582, and ∼622 nm are due to the 4f–4f transitions from 5D 4 to 7F J (J  = 6, 5, 4, 3) [7]. Fig. 4 (a) and (b) show photographs of the Sr1.95ZnSi2O7:Tb0.05-phosphor powders that were prepared using the sol-gel method under room light and UV radiation (254 nm), respectively. The Sr1.95 ZnSi2O7:Tb0.05-phosphor emits green light under a UV source. The relative emission intensities show a trend that is similar to the increasing of the Tb3+-doping concentration (i.e., with the increasing of the Tb3+ concentration, the emission intensity of the Sr2- x ZnSi2O7:Tb x [x = 0.01 ≤ x ≤ 0.11] phosphors initially increased and reached a maximum at x = 0.05, but then it decreased due to the concentration quenching), as shown in Fig. 5 . The concentration quenching is mainly caused by the energy transfer from one activator to another that is in consideration of the Sr2ZnSi2O7:Tb3+ multipolar interaction [21]. Fig. 6 shows the Commission Internationale de l´ Eclairage (CIE) chromaticity diagram for the Sr2- x ZnSi2O7:Tb x (x = 0.01 ≤ x ≤ 0.11) phosphor that has been excited at 239 nm. All of the results that were calculated from the spectra and that are shown in Fig. 3 are plotted in the CIE 1931 chromaticity diagram, as can be seen in Fig. 6. The CIE color coordinates for the Sr2- x ZnSi2O7:Tb x (x = 0.01 ≤ x ≤ 0.11) phosphor are given in Table 3 . It has been reported that an adjustment of the Tb3+-doping concentration in the phosphors can significantly tune a variety of the emission colors from blue to green. In the present case, a warm white emission was achieved since the emission lines of the Tb3+ in the Sr2ZnSi2O7 phosphor cover the almost-whole visible region. The increased Tb3+ concentration induced the emission colors to shift from the blue to the green region. This fundamental work might be important in the ongoing development of new luminescent devices, making it applicable for the green phosphors of the lamp industry; furthermore, it could be helpful in the development of a phosphor-based generator that produces white light with a particular ratio. 4 Conclusions A series of the Sr2- x ZnSi2O7:Tb x (x = 0.0 ≤ x ≤ 0.11) phosphor was successfully prepared via the sol-gel method. The XRPD study revealed that crystals of a tetragonal structure were formed. The SEM results revealed that the powdered-phosphor shapes are irregular. Most of the bigger particles were formed by the adhesion of the smaller particles. The phosphor, with a single excitation band at 239 nm, could be efficiently excited by UV light-emitting diodes (LEDs), and it is believed that it could be a promising green-emitting phosphor for the lamp industry. The strong emission peak that is centered at 543 nm is the most favorable for the attainment of a phosphor with a high color purity. The excitation and emission intensities increased with the addition of Tb3+ content, and the maximum intensity was obtained for the Sr1.95ZnSi2O7:Tb0.05 sample. Acknowledgements This paper was supported by the KU Research Professor Program of Konkuk University.

column2: Two color laser self focusing and terahertz generation in multi-ion species plasma
column3: Abstract An analytical formalism of self focusing of two co-propagating laser beams, fundamental ω 1 and close to second harmonic ω 2 ≈ 2 ω 1 , in a multi-ion species plasma and resonant terahertz radiation generation has been developed. The nonlinearity arises due to ponderomotive force on electrons by both the beams and subsequent ambipolar redistribution of the plasma. The ions of higher charged state are strongly depleted from the axial region due to space charge field effects and electron charge is largely compensated by the ions of lower charge. When the power of the strong beam equals the critical power for its self-guiding, the plasma provides an oscillatory waveguide for the weak beam; the weak beam shrinks and rebounds when its frequency is lower than that of the strong beam, and it swallows and rebounds when the frequency is higher. When both beams are strong the nonlinearities have cumulative effect on both the beams. The cross coupling of the beams gives rise to nonlinear current giving rise to terahertz radiation at ω = ω 2 − 2 ω 1 frequency. An axial density ripple aids phase matching and gives rise to higher power conversion efficiency. Self focusing leads to enhancement in conversion efficiency.
column5: Keywords Laser plasma interaction Cross focusing Terahertz generation 1 Introduction Self focusing is an important issue in high power laser plasma interaction. It plays significant role in inertial confinement fusion [1–3], laser driven charged particle acceleration [4,5] and other applications [6–8]. In long pulse experiments nonlinearity for self-focusing arises through the ponderomotive force induced ambipolar diffusion of plasma and subsequent density depression in regions of higher intensity [9,10]. In the steady state in a single ion species plasma to which most theories of self focusing are restricted, the modified electron density goes as n e = n 0 exp − β 0 I / ω 2 where n 0 is the equilibrium electron density, I and ω are the intensity and frequency of the laser, and β 0 is a constant dependent on electron and ion temperature. For a Gaussian beam, this translates into axial part of the wavefront propagating with smaller phase velocity than the marginal rays and wavefront acquiring curvature, leading to self focusing. In collisional plasma, nonlinearity arises through Ohmic heating of electrons and subsequent ambipolar redistribution of plasma density [11,12]. This occurs on the time scale of temperature relaxation time which is orders of magnitude longer than a collision time. For short pulses, shorter than the ion response time, the nonlinearity arises through the combined effects of relativistic mass variation and ponderomotive force induced electron density modification [10,13]. Andreev et al. [14] have studied ponderomotive self focusing of a laser pulse of duration comparable to ambipolar diffusion time and studied its coupling to stimulated Brillouin backscattering. They observe periodic bursts of scattered radiation. The treatment, however, is limited to fractional change in electron density δ n / n 0 < < 1 . In experiments on self modulated laser wakefield acceleration, a plasma wave perturbation causes periodic focusing of the laser which in turn exerts a periodic ponderomotive force on electrons, driving the plasma wave [15,16]. Ions are practically immobile in these situations. The analytical studies are limited to density modifications being small; however, numerical studies are valid for arbitrary density modifications. In laser wakefield acceleration one encounters quasistatic relativistic and ponderomotive self focusing [17–19]. In laser beat wave accelerator, one encounters simultaneous propagation of two high power laser beams. The nonlinearity is a cumulative effect of the two beams and both the beams influence self focusing of each other. When the beat frequency is close to plasma frequency, ω = ω 1 − ω 2 ∼ ω p , the beat frequency ponderomotive force F → p ω gives rise to large amplitude plasma wave and the latter has significant influence on cross focusing of the beams. Kalmykov et al. [20] have shown that the beam focusing is enhanced for Ω < ω p and suppressed for Ω > ω p . Sprangle et al. [21,22] have analyzed that in partially stripped plasmas, bound electrons significantly enhances the forward Raman instability and filamentation instability. However, our treatment is limited to pre-existing plasmas with fully electron stripped ions, e.g. CH plasma. In multi ion species plasmas, the process of ambipolar diffusion poses complications as the stochiometry of composition (the ratio of densities of different ion species) is not conserved. The space charge field, produced due to the displacement of electrons under ponderomotive force, pushes ions of higher charge with stronger force, hence disturbs the relative composition. Shikha et al. [23] have developed a theoretical formalism of self focusing of a Gaussian electromagnetic beam in a multi-ion species plasma. They invoke a technique to evaluate the density redistribution on different ion species under the approximation of quasi neutrality. However, the electron density is governed by a transcendental equation that at high intensity is to be solved numerically. Xie et al. [24] have experimentally observed THz radiation in air by nonlinear mixing of two color laser, choosing two coaxial laser beams of frequencies ω 1 and ω 2 such that ω 2 − 2 ω 1 falls in the terahertz range. Kumar [25] has developed an analytical theory for this experiment, ignoring the effect of self focusing and considering a plasma of single ion species. Recently, Vvedenskii et al. [26] have investigated low frequency THz emission in the experiment with the ambient air ionized by a two color femtosecond laser pulse. Liu et al. [27] have studied cross phase modulation of two short pulse lasers including the effect of self focusing in a plasma, however, ion dynamics is taken to be frozen. Kumar et al. [28] have investigated the self focusing/defocusing of a relativistic laser pulse in a multiple-ionizing gas but ignored the redistribution of ions. In this paper we address the issue of self focusing and THz radiation generation of two color laser in two ion species plasma, e.g. CH plasma, or hydrogen embedded helium plasma or helium plasma with singly and doubly ionized ions. Two coaxial laser beams of frequencies ω 1 and ω 2 , propagating through a pre-existing plasma, exert cumulative ponderomotive force on electrons and cause ambipolar diffusion of plasma. We bring out specific cases where modified electron density is expressible in terms of cumulative ponderomotive potential. At high intensity, we note that the ion species of higher charge flushes out almost completely from the paraxial region and quasi neutrality is maintained by the balance of densities of lower charge ions with electrons. In this case nonlinear plasma permittivity turns out to have exponential dependence on the intensities of lasers. 2 Nonlinear permittivity Consider a plasma comprising two ion species of densities n 10 (of charge Z 1 e ) and n 20 (of charge Z 2 e ) and temperature T i and electrons of density n 0 0 and temperature T e . Quasi-neutrality demands, (1) n 0 0 = Z 1 n 10 + Z 2 n 20 Two Gaussian laser beams propagate through the plasma, (2) E → j = x ˆ A j ( r , z ) exp [ − i ( ω j t − k j z ) ] , A j | z = 0 2 = A j00 2 exp ( − r 2 / r 0 2 ) , j = 1 , 2 where k j = ( ω j / c ) ( ε j 0 0 ) 1 / 2 , ε j 0 0 = 1 − ω p 2 / ω j 2 , ω p = n 0 0 e 2 / m ε 0 1 / 2 is the unmodified plasma frequency, and − e and m are the electronic charge and mass of the electrons and ε 0 is the free space permittivity. For z > 0 , assuming paraxial ray approximation, the energy conserving Gaussian intensity profiles are, (3) A j 2 = A j 00 2 f j 2 exp − r 2 / r 0 2 f j 2 , j = 1 , 2 where f 1 , f 2 are the beam width parameters. This approximation would fail had the two laser frequencies differed by plasma frequency ( ω 1 − ω 2 = ω p ) as in that case an electron plasma wave is excited that leads to energy transfer from one beam to the other. The lasers impart oscillatory velocities to electrons v → j = e E → j / m i ω j , and exert a time average ponderomotive force on them F → p = e ∇ φ p (4) φ p = − e 4 m A 1 2 ω 1 2 + A 2 2 ω 2 2 The ponderomotive force also has a beat frequency component, however for ω 2 − ω 1 > > ω p its influence on ion density redistribution is small. The static ponderomotive force displaces the electrons radially outward, creating a space charge field E → s = − ∇ φ s , that pulls the ions along. In the steady state, the equation of motion for electrons and two ion species give 0 = − e E → s + F → p − T e / n e ∇ n e 0 = Z 1 e E → s − T i / n 1 i ∇ n 1 i (5) 0 = Z 2 e E → s − T i / n 2 i ∇ n 2 i where n e = Z 1 n 1 i + Z 2 n 2 i . In writing Eqs. (5), the contribution from ponderomotive force on ion has been ignored due to their large masses. Eliminating e E → s from Eqs. (5) and integrating the resulting equation under the condition that at r → ∞ , φ p → 0 , n 1 i = n 10 , n 2 i = n 20 and n e = n 0 0 , one obtains (6) n 1 i n 10 = n e n 0 0 − Z 1 T e / T i P Z 1 (7) n 2 i n 20 = n e n 0 0 − Z 2 T e / T i P Z 2 where P = exp − e φ p / T i , One may note that (8) n 2 i n 20 = n 1 i n 10 Z 2 / Z 1 The relative density reduction of the higher charged state is greater than that of the smaller charged state. The reason is that the space charge force on ions of higher charge is stronger. Using Eqs. (6) and (7), and employing the condition for charge quasi neutrality, one obtains, (9) n e n 0 0 = Z 1 n 10 n 0 0 n e n 0 0 − Z 1 T e / T i exp − Z 1 e φ p T i + Z 2 n 20 n 0 0 n e n 0 0 − Z 2 T e / T i exp − Z 2 e φ p T i We solve it in different cases. a) Weak Nonlinearity Approximation In the weak nonlinearity approximations, one may solve Eq. (9) by expanding n e as n e = n 0 0 + Δ n e , Δ n e < < n 0 0 , Then Eq. (9) yields (10) Δ n e n 0 0 = β e φ p / T i 1 + β T e / T i where β = n 10 Z 1 2 + n 20 Z 2 2 / n 0 0 . b) Isothermal Plasma ( T e = T i ) with Z 1 = 1 , Z 2 = 2 (e.g., helium plasma embedded with deuterium or hydrogen) In this case, Eq. (9) takes the form of a cubic (11) n e n 0 0 3 − n 10 n 0 0 n e n 0 0 P − 2 n 20 n 0 0 P 2 = 0 with roots n e n 0 0 = n 20 n 0 0 P 2 + n 20 2 n 0 0 2 P 4 − 1 27 n 10 n 0 0 P 3 1 / 3 + n 20 n 0 0 P 2 − n 20 2 n 0 0 2 P 4 − 1 27 n 10 n 0 0 P 3 1 / 3 c) Isothermal Plasma with Z 1 = 1 and Z 2 = 3 In this case, Eq. (9) becomes bi-quadratic giving (12) n e n 0 0 = P 2 n 10 n 0 0 + n 10 2 n 0 0 2 + 12 n 20 n 0 0 P 1 / 2 d) High Intensity Limit ( P ≤ .5 ) For T e / T i > 1 and Z 2 > Z 1 , when P ≅ exp − e φ p / T i ≤ 0.5 , one may ignore the last term in Eq. (9), giving (13) n e n 0 0 ≈ n 10 n 0 0 T i / Z 1 T e + T i exp e φ p / Z 1 T e + T i For T e / T i ≥ 4 , the first factor on the right is of the order of 1, hence one may write (14) n e = n 0 0 exp − e 2 4 m Z 1 T e + T i A 100 2 ω 1 2 f 1 2 + A 200 2 ω 2 2 f 2 2 In all these cases, n e has implicit dependence on r through P or A 1 2 and A 2 2 . One may express n e in the paraxial region as n e = n e 0 + n 2 ( r 2 / r 0 2 ) where n e 0 = n e ( r = 0 ) and (15) n 2 = ∂ n e ∂ P ∂ P ∂ r 2 r = 0 r 0 2 For cases (a) and (d), one may explicitly write n e 0 = n 0 0 + β e φ p ( 0 ) / T i 1 + β T e / T i = n 0 0 − β e 2 4 m β T e + T i A 100 2 ω 1 2 f 1 2 + A 200 2 ω 2 2 f 2 2 (16) n 2 = β e 2 4 m β T e + T i A 100 2 ω 1 2 f 1 4 + A 200 2 ω 2 2 f 2 4 n e 0 = n 0 0 exp − e 2 4 m Z 1 T e + T i A 100 2 ω 1 2 f 1 2 + A 200 2 ω 2 2 f 2 2 (17) n 2 = n e 0 e 2 4 m Z 1 T e + T i A 100 2 ω 1 2 f 1 4 + A 200 2 ω 2 2 f 2 4 For other cases n e 0 and n 2 can be obtained from Eq. (11) to (12) when the need arises. In the presence of the laser beams, the plasma permittivity at ω 1 and ω 2 can be written as (18) ε j ω j = ε j 0 + φ j A 1 , A 2 where φ j = − ω p 2 ω j 2 n e − n 0 0 n 0 0 , represents the contribution due to nonlinear effects. In the case of weak nonlinearity (19) φ j = β e 2 4 m T i + β T e ω p 2 ω j 2 A 1 2 ω 1 2 + A 2 2 ω 2 2 At high intensity, (20) ε j ω j = 1 − ω p 2 ω j 2 − ω p 2 ω j 2 n e n 0 0 = ε j s − ε j 2 r 2 / r 0 2 , j = 1 , 2 ε j s = 1 − ω p 2 / ω j 2 n e 0 / n 0 0 , ε j 2 = ω p 2 / ω j 2 n 2 / n 0 0 3 Cross focusing under weak nonlinearity The wave equation governing the propagation of the laser beam is (21) ∇ 2 E → + ω 2 c 2 ε E → = 0 Substituting for E → from Eq. (2) and using WKB approximation (neglecting the term ∂ 2 A / ∂ z 2 assuming A ( r , z ) to be a slowly varying function of z), Eq. (21) takes the form (22) 2 i k j ∂ A j ∂ z + ∇ ⊥ 2 A j − ω 2 c 2 φ j A j = 0 We write A j = A j 0 ( r , z ) exp ( i k j S j ) , where A j 0 and S j are real functions of r and z , and separate out the real and imaginary parts of Eq. (22), (23) ∂ A j 2 ∂ z + ∇ ⊥ 2 S j A j 2 + ∂ S j ∂ r ∂ A j 2 ∂ r = 0 (24) 2 ∂ S j ∂ z + ∂ S j ∂ r 2 − φ j ε j 0 = 1 k j 2 A j ∇ ⊥ 2 A j We expand the eikonal S in the paraxial ray approximation as (25) S j = S j 0 ( z ) + S j 2 ( z ) r 2 2 ; j = 1 , 2 and introduce function f j ( z ) such that (26) S j 2 = 1 f j d f j d z where S j 0 z is arbitrary and f j is the beam width parameter for slowly converging/diverging fields. Using these in Eq. (23), one obtains the solution for A j 2 given by Eq. (3) exactly. Using Eqs. (3), (25) and (26) in Eq. (24) and collecting the coefficients of r 2 on both sides, we obtain the equations governing with the beam width parameters d 2 f 1 d ξ 2 = 1 f 1 3 − r 0 2 ω p 2 c 2 e 2 4 m T i β 1 + β T e / T i A 100 2 ω 1 2 f 1 4 + A 200 2 ω 2 2 f 2 4 f 1 (27) d 2 f 2 d ξ 2 = k 1 k 2 2 1 f 2 3 − ω 1 2 ω 2 2 r 0 2 ω p 2 c 2 e 2 4 m T i β 1 + β T e / T i A 100 2 ω 1 2 f 1 4 + A 200 2 ω 2 2 f 2 4 f 2 where ξ = z / R d 1 , R d 1 = k 1 r 0 2 , ( r 0 ω p / c ) = ( r 0 ω 1 / c ) Z 1 n 01 / n c r + Z 2 n 02 / n c r 1 / 2 and n c r = m ε 0 ω 1 2 / e 2 . The first terms on the right-hand-side of these equations represent diffraction due to divergence. The second terms represent focusing due to ponderomotive nonlinearity. In the case when power of the second beam is lower than that of the first beam, the nonlinearity in permittivity arises only due to the first beam. In this case, A 200 2 terms in Eqs. (27) can be dropped, Under a special case when r 0 2 ω p 2 c 2 e 2 A 1 2 4 m ω 1 2 β β T e + T i = 1 i.e., when the diffraction term for the first beam is exactly balanced by the self focusing term, the first beam (with plane wavefront) propagates without convergence or divergence, the beam width parameter of the second beam (having d f 2 / d z = 0 at z = 0 ) turns out to be (28) f 2 2 = 1 + α 1 sin 2 ω 1 ω 2 k 1 k 2 ξ where α 1 = ω 2 2 ω 1 2 − 1 . For ω 2 > ω 1 , α 1 is positive and f 2 varies in a space periodic manner between 1 and 1 + α 1 1 / 2 . It undergoes divergence (due to predominance of diffraction) acquiring a maximum f 2 = ω 2 / ω 1 and then falls of due to predominance of self focusing. For ω 2 < ω 1 , the trend is opposite, f 2 varies between 1 and 1 − α 1 1 / 2 . For the general case, when both beams are strong, we have solved Eqs. (27) numerically with appropriate initial boundary conditions, at z = 0 , f 1 , f 2 = 1 and d f 1 / d z , d f 2 / d z = 0 . Fig. 1 shows the variation of the beam width parameter f 1 , 2 as a function of normalized distance of propagation ξ for the following set of parameters r 0 ω 1 / c = 65 , n 01 / n c r = 0.02 , n 02 / n c r = 0.01 , n 01/n 02 = 2, T e / T i = 2.9 , ω 1 / ω 2 = 0.5 , k 1 / k 2 = 0.5 , A 200 / A 100 = 2 , e 2 A 2 100/4mTiω2 1 = 0.3 (corresponds to laser intensity of 5 × 10 14 W/cm2 for T i = 100 e V ). Solid curve represents Z 1 = 1 , Z 2 = 2 (i.e. hydrogen embedded helium plasma) and dashed curves represents Z 1 = 1 , Z 2 = 6 (i.e. CH plasma). The self focusing of the first beam is stronger than the second beam when ω2 >ω1 . For higher charged state, both the beams gets self focused earlier than the lower charged state. However, this is valid up to a distance of ξ = 0.2 beyond which the weak nonlinearity approximation fails. 4 Cross focusing under strong nonlinearity In this case the nonlinear permittivity can be expanded in powers of r 2 (in the paraxial region) as (29) φ j = ω p 2 ω j 2 n e 0 − n 0 0 n 0 0 + ω p 2 ω j 2 n 2 r 2 r 0 2 n 2 = ∂ n e ∂ P ∂ P ∂ r 2 r = 0 r 0 2 (30) n 2 = n e 0 e 2 4 m Z 1 T e + T i A 100 2 ω 1 2 f 1 4 + A 200 2 ω 2 2 f 2 4 With this expression for φ j , Eq. (19) can be solved in the same way as in section III. The resulting equations for the beam width parameters f 1 , f 2 are d 2 f 1 d ξ 2 = 1 f 1 3 − r 0 2 ω p 2 c 2 I 10 1 f 1 4 + ω 1 2 A 200 2 / ω 2 2 A 100 2 f 2 4 exp − I 10 1 f 1 2 + ω 1 2 A 200 2 / ω 2 2 A 100 2 f 2 2 f 1 (31) d 2 f 2 d ξ 2 = k 1 2 k 2 2 f 2 3 − k 1 2 k 2 2 r 0 2 ω p 2 c 2 I 10 1 f 1 4 + ω 1 2 A 200 2 / ω 2 2 A 100 2 f 2 4 exp − I 10 1 f 1 2 + ω 1 2 A 200 2 / ω 2 2 A 100 2 f 2 2 f 2 where ξ = z / R d 1 , I 10 = e 2 A 100 2 / 4 m ω 1 2 ( Z 1 T e + T i ) , and the value of r 0 ω p / c is expressible in terms of r 0 ω 1 / c as given after Eq. (27). We have solved Eq. (31) numerically for initially plane wavefronts. Fig. 2 shows the variation of beam width parameters f 1 , 2 as a function of normalized distance of propagation ξ for r 0 ω 1 / c = 65 , n 01 / n c r = 0.02 , n 02 / n c r = 0.01 , ω 1 / ω 2 = 0.5 , k 1 / k 2 = 0.5 , A 200 / A 100 = 2 , e 2 A 100 2 / 4 m ω 1 2 ( Z 1 T e + T i ) = 0.3 . Solid curves represent Z 1 = 1 , Z 2 = 2 (hydrogen embedded helium plasma) and dashed curves represent Z 1 = 1 , Z 2 = 6 (CH plasma). One notices that both the beams get self focused when ω 2 > ω 1 . The self focusing for the first beam takes place earlier and is stronger than the second beam. For higher charged state i.e. Z 2 = 6 , both the beams gets self focused earlier than the lower charged state i.e. Z 2 = 2 . It means self focusing in a CH plasma will take place earlier in comparison to hydrogen embedded helium plasma. The reason is that the ions of higher charged state are strongly pushed out from the axial region. 5 Terahertz generation The two Gaussian laser beams also exert time varying ponderomotive force on electrons that drives density oscillations, which when beat with electron oscillatory velocities, give rise to nonlinear current producing THz radiation. We allow a density ripple in the plasma (32) n 0 0 = n 0 ∗ + n q 0 e i q z The relevant components of ponderomotive force that contribute to THz generation at ω = ω 2 − 2 ω 1 are F → p 2 ω 1 = − i m v → 1 . v → 1 2 k → 1 (33) F → p ω 2 − ω 1 = − i m v → 2 . v → 1 ∗ 2 k → 2 − k → 1 These components of ponderomotive force impart oscillatory velocities to electrons (34) v → ω 2 − ω 1 = − F → p ( ω 2 − ω 1 ) i m ( ω 2 − ω 1 ) and produce density perturbations n 2 ω 1 , n ω 2 − ω 1 at wave vectors 2 k 1 − q and k 2 − k − q (35) n 2 ω 1 = − n q ∗ v → 1 . v → 1 8 ω 1 2 ε ( 2 ω 1 ) k 1 2 (36) n ω 2 − ω 1 = − n q ∗ v → 2 . v → 1 ∗ ( k 2 − k 1 ) 2 4 ( ω 2 − ω 1 ) 2 ε ( ω 2 − ω 1 ) where ε ( 2 ω 1 ) = 1 − ω p 2 / 4 ω 1 2 and ε ( ω 2 − ω 1 ) = 1 − ω p 2 / ( ω 2 − ω 1 ) 2 appear due to the self consistent space charge field produced by the density perturbations n 2 ω 1 , n ω 2 − ω 1 . For ω 1 > > ω p , ε ( 2 ω 1 ) ≈ 1 , ε ( ω 2 − ω 1 ) ≈ 1 . The density perturbations beat with the oscillatory velocities and yield a nonlinear current density at ω = ω 2 − 2 ω 1 , J → ω N L = − 1 2 n 2 ω 1 ∗ e v → ω 2 − 1 2 n ω 2 − ω 1 e v → ω 1 ∗ (37) = n q ∗ e k 1 2 16 ω 1 2 v → 1 ∗ . v → 1 ∗ v → 2 + n q ∗ e k 2 − k 1 2 8 ω 2 − ω 1 2 v → 2 . v → 1 ∗ v → 1 ∗ Since ω 2 − ω 1 ≈ ω 1 , k 2 − k 1 ≈ k 1 , and v → 2 v → 1 x ˆ , Eq. (37) can be written as (38) J → ω N L = − 3 n q ∗ e 4 k 1 2 E → 1 ∗ . E → 1 ∗ 16 i m 3 ω 1 4 ω 2 E → 2 This current density is perpendicular to the direction of laser propagation, hence ∇ × J → ω N L ≠ 0 . It gives rise to the generation of electromagnetic THz radiation. The terahertz field E → ω , in turn produces self consistent (linear) current density (39) J → ω L = − n 0 0 e 2 m i ω E → ω The wave equation governing E → ω is (40) − ∇ ( ∇ . E → ω ) + ∇ 2 E → ω + ( ω 2 − ω p 2 c 2 ) E → ω = − i ω ε 0 c 2 J → ω N L We presume q = k 2 − 2 k 1 − k where k = ω / c ( 1 − ω p 2 / ω 2 ) 1 / 2 . Writing E → ω = x ˆ A e − i ω t − k z and assuming ∂ / ∂ z E ω > ∂ / ∂ r E ω , we obtain (41) 2 i k ∂ A ∂ z ≈ ω ε 0 c 2 3 n q ∗ e 4 k 1 2 A 1 2 A 2 16 n 0 0 m 3 ω 1 4 ω 2 In the paraxial region, in compliance with Eq. (3) one may write A = A 0 exp − r 2 r 0 2 2 f 1 2 + 1 f 2 2 Using above in Eq. (41), one obtains (42) ∂ A 0 ∂ z = − i 3 n q 0 32 n 0 0 ω p 2 ω 2 c ( 1 − ω p 2 / ω 2 ) 1 / 2 ( e A 100 m ω 1 c ) 2 A 200 f 1 2 f 2 We solved Eq. (42) numerically in conjunction with the equations governing f 1 , f 2 for the following parameters: e 2 A 100 2 / 4 m ω 1 2 T e = 0.3 , v t h / c = 0.1 , r 0 ω 1 / c = 65 , n q 0 / n 0 0 = 0.2 , ω p / ω = 0.5 , ω 2 / ω 1 = 2 , k 2 / k 1 = 2 . We have plotted in Figs. 3 and 4 , normalized amplitude A 0 / A 200 as a function of normalized distance ξ = z / R d 1 in the case of strong and weak nonlinearities for hydrogen embedded helium plasma and CH plasma. The amplitude rises steadily. As the beams get self focused, terahertz amplitude rises sharply. 6 Conclusions The self focusing of two color laser in multi ion species plasma is sensitive to the composition of charge states of ions. The beam of higher frequency undergoes slower self focusing as the nonlinear plasma susceptibility decreases with wave frequency. The ion species of higher charge moves out of the paraxial region more rapidly leaving behind depressed density electrons and smaller charge ions. Thus the self focusing of beams takes place earlier for higher charged state than the lower charged state. In the case of laser produced plasma with T e ≥ 4 T i , e φ p ≥ T e , the higher charge species are almost completely pushed out of the axial region offering an analytical expression for nonlinear plasma permittivity. The saturation effect of nonlinearity manifests itself in periodic focusing of the beams. Self focusing has a strong effect on two color laser THz excitation. The presence of a density ripple helps achieve phase matching, making THz generation as a resonant third order nonlinear process. The terahertz amplitude rises with distance. As the beams undergo self focusing and their axial intensities rise, the THz amplitude rises rapidly. It slows down around the minima in beam width parameters. Here we have neglected the contributions of bound electrons to plasma permittivity which is justified when the laser frequency is much lower than the frequency of revolution of bound electrons. We have also neglected the dynamical change of states of ionization, hence the treatment is limited to pre-existing plasmas with fully electron stripped ions, e.g., CH plasma. The laser pulse considered here are longer than the ion response time r 0 / c s where c s is the sound speed. For r 0 ∼ 2 μ m , c s ∼ 10 7 c m / s , it corresponds to 20 ps. The assumption of Gaussian ansatz may not be applicable beyond a few Rayleigh lengths. The neglect of collisions implies that the absorption coefficient k i < R d 1 − 1 , where k i ≈ ν / 2 c ω p 2 / ω 1 2 , R d 1 ≅ ω 1 / c r 0 2 . This condition demands r 0 ω p / c 2 ν / 2 ω 1 < 1 . It is satisfied when electron density is substantially subcritical. A major limitation to present treatment comes from the neglect of Forward Raman whose growth rate goes as Andreev et al. [29] Γ ∼ 1 / 2 2 a 0 n e / n c r . It should be less than R d 1 / c . At n e / n c r ∼ 0.01 , one may avoid it for beams of low spot size. Tripathi, IIT Delhi for the helpful discussions. The authors are also grateful to UAE University Program for Advanced Research under Fund No. 31S164, United Arab Emirates for financial support.

column2: Polarization switching mechanism in surface-emitting semiconductor lasers
column3: Abstract Within the scope of the earlier proposed approach to the description of polarization dependences in VCSEL based on analysis of the experimental and theoretical data, an explicit expression for the function describing the relationship between the amplification anisotropy and the current density is suggested. The conducted numerical calculations support the peculiarities of the polarization switching (PS) process and enable one to explain the effect of the PS point anomalous shift when the current variation rate is high. A special attention is given to a fairly clear physical interpretation of the formation of polarization radiation in VCSEL.
column5: OCIS codes (250.7260) Vertical cavity surface emitting lasers (260.5430) Polarization (140.3430) Laser theory 1 Introduction The effect of quick switching of one linear polarization to the orthogonal polarization in the output radiation of injection semiconductor lasers has been known for a fairly long time [1,2], still being exotic to some extent due to its rather hard realization conditions. However, even at such conditions polarization switching (PS), owing to its hysteresis character, has found wide applications in various devices developed for optoelectronic systems [3]. Interest to this phenomenon has increased greatly since revealing of «spontaneous» PS in vertical cavity surface-emitting lasers (VCSEL) [4,5], when PS occurs due to variations in the injection current. Many works associated with this problem have been published during a period of about twenty years and, nevertheless, it remains of a particular importance [6–9] as VCSEL, and PS in particular, have numerous applications [7–9]. But the PS effect is very unwanted for the majority of optoelectronic systems because of their polarization sensitivity. Different methods to suppress PS have been developed (e.g., [7,10]). However, they are associated with sophistication of the VCSEL production technology and, to some or other extent, affect the output parameters diminishing the source advantages inherent in VCSEL. The PS effect is important because it illustrates instabilities occurring in nonlinear systems − many attempts were undertaken to interpret this effect as some phase transition (e.g., see [11]), though these attempts little contributed to better understanding of its mechanism. At the present time, the most commonly used approach to interpretation of the PS effect is based on the polarizations modes approach (PMA) assuming that, due to anisotropy of gain and/or loss, two independent polarization modes are formed in a semiconductor laser. When this anisotropy is relatively high, as is usual in end-pumped semiconductor lasers, one of the modes becomes dominant and the output radiation is linearly polarized [12]. In VCSEL such anisotropy is low, being induced by the electrooptic, elastooptic, and thermal processes [6] during their production or operation, and at the particular conditions the concurrence of these modes is liable to lead to polarization instability and to the PS effects. The approach has attracted much attention since publication of the works [13,14], where the authors had developed the so-called Spin Flip Model (SFM) for the case of VCSEL with a QW active layer. SFM is a microscopic model, according to which the generation process is realized by a system of two spin subsystems whose interaction is described by the phenomenological parameter of the spin relaxation rate. As a result of concurrent radiations from the subsystems, two orthogonal linearly-polarized modes are stable, and their concurrence leads to dominance of the only one of them. Still there are some instability regions, where SP can occur. SFM is very popular because it offers explanation [14] for numerous effects accompanying PS (both types of PS, bistability, hysteresis, etc.). Nevertheless, many effects of PS may be explained from the viewpoint of the phenomenological theory that is based on rate equations, if we distinguish self- and cross-saturation of orthogonal modes [15]. But the introduction of saturation effects into SFM [16], in principle, gives similar results [15]. Despite wide applications of the above-mentioned models, they are not free from some intrinsic contradictions and both fail to describe fully all the phenomena associated with SP. The main disadvantage of SFM, and of PMA as a whole, is the introduction of the polarization mode phases as net, i.e. rigorously defined, parameters [13,14]. SFM was formed as a direct analog of a theory of gas lasers [13] characterized by slow phase relaxation. For semiconductor lasers, fast phase relaxation (dealt with in greater detail further in the text) is the case, and the rigorously defined mode phases may be considered as an asymptotic approximation, i.e. as a limit for the quasi-stationary state. Properly speaking, the introduction of two orthogonal linearly polarized modes in SFM is just associated with the limiting transition to the stable state. However, the admitted assumption of the phase definiteness results in the fact that in the region of SP the dynamic states of elliptic polarization should be formed [17,18], though they are hardly detected as the obtained data afford no unambiguous interpretation [18,19]. SFM has been extended and refined due to the introduction of a complex medium susceptibility [20]. Unfortunately, this leads to a considerable complication of the equations [21,22] containing numerous parameters the definition of which is problematic. Because of this, much favor holds a microscopic model of PMA using an asymmetric scheme of nonlinear effects [15], with the self- and cross-saturation factors considered as system’s parameters. But it should be noted that the calculation results are differing considerably [23]. Moreover, as demonstrated by the detailed studies, the results have different spectral dependences [24] and are also dependent on the pump pulse energy [25], i.e. they are the function of the process as well. These intrinsic contradictions affect the effectiveness of the approaches developed with the use of PMA. Nonlinear coupling of polarization modes has been introduced in terms of the induced nonlinear anisotropy [26]. Besides, some other corrections and supplements to the initial models have been suggested, though in several cases (e.g., see [27]) the experimental results were described inadequately. The fundamentally different approach to the description of PS – the polarization components approach (PCA) – has been based on the idea of the incoherent nonpolarized spontaneous radiation sequentially amplified in an active medium with anisotropic gain and/or loss factors. Within the scope of this approach, the PS process is considered as a sequential deterministic transition from one linearly polarized state to the orthogonal state by means of a chain of partially polarized states rather than a process resultant from concurrence of two orthogonally polarized modes. In the works [28,29], with the use of this approach, the possibility to describe the principal effects accompanying PS has been demonstrated and their fairly simple physical interpretation has been presented. In more recent works [30] it has been shown that PCA may be used to study the spectral and statistical characteristics in the region of PS. In other words, the applicability of PCA is proven. Now the applicability limits of this approach for the description of the formation of polarized radiation in VCSEL should be examined. The article is organized as follow. Section 1 presents the development of a theoretical model based on PCA; based on analysis of the literature data, we introduce the function that, in the explicit form, describes gain anisotropy depending on the injection current density. Section 2 is devoted to the numerical results obtained for the stationary approximation as well as for the case when the current increases at the constant rate. For the last case it was shown that besides the natural shift of PS point in the greater current range (that leads to hysterics phenomena) there is an effect of a reverse PS point shift for high rate of the current increases. 2 Theoretical model PCA has been considered in detail as applied to dye lasers in [31–33]. Here we deal with the main points and the requirements enabling one to describe PCA as a basic method for the description of lasing in semiconductor injection lasers, as a whole, and surface-emitting lasers, in particular. Using PCA, we first represent a plane monochromatic wave propagating along the axis z of a laboratory system with the coordinates as (1) E ( z , t ) = ∫ 0 π e ψ E ( ψ , z , t ) exp [ i ϕ ( ψ , z , t ) ] d ψ where e ψ , E(ψ, z, t), and ϕ(ψ, z, t) are the unit polarization vector, amplitude, and phase of a particular component; the angle ψ determines the polarization vector orientation e ψ relative to some axis within the wavefront plane [31]. Expression (1) represents superposition of the linearly polarized plane waves having different orientations of the polarization vector and may be considered as a generalization of the definition for a polarized plane wave with an arbitrary polarization. Indeed, to obtain the net polarization state, the functions and must be specified rigorously. To illustrate, for a linearly polarized wave, we have E(ψ, z, t)= E(z, t)δ(ψ − ψ 0). Most important, however, is the fact that Expression (1) describes partially polarized radiation as well. In this case epresents a continuous function of whereas are completely uncorrelated, i.e. 〈 ϕ ( ψ , z , t ) ϕ ′ ( ψ ′ , z ′ , t ′ ) 〉 = ϕ δ ( ψ − ψ ′ ) δ ( z − z ′ ) δ ( t − t ′ ) . With the use of the slowly varying amplitude approximation, we can derive a reduced wave equation [31], where a vector of the medium polarizability may be given in the form of (1). On condition of fast phase relaxation, that for dye molecules is below several tens of femtoseconds [31,33], we can obtain a reduced wave equation for the intensity of a particular polarization component [31], introduced in terms of the relation for the total intensity, in the following form: (2) I ( z , t ) = ∫ 0 π I ψ ( ψ , z , t ) d ψ where I ψ (ψ, z, t) − intensity of a particular polarization component. As demonstrated by the results in [32], a point model works well for the description of the PS effects, provided the pump energy distribution in the volume of the active layer is sufficiently homogeneous. In this approximation a dynamic equation for the intensity of a particular polarization component may be given in the form [31] (3) d I ( ψ ) d t = v ( k a m p − k l o s ) I ( ψ ) + L ( ψ ) where k amp (ψ) and k los (ψ) – gain and loss factors for a particular polarization component, respectively; v – velocity of light in the active medium, and the parameterL(ψ) represents an orientation component of the spontaneous radiation power density, when using the representation of (1) for its integral value. Note that the starting idea of PCA has been developed for the near-threshold region of dye lasers and was defined as a sequential amplification of the initially uncorrelated polarization components of spontaneous radiation in the case of orientation (dependent on the angle ψ) anisotropy of the gain. As shown in [33,34], an assumption of the weakly-correlated polarization components is true even for the significantly exceeded threshold. Applicability of PCA to the description of semiconductor injection lasers has been discussed in [35] but in the main the possibility to use the single-frequency approximation has been considered. As regards the base approximation of fast phase relaxation, in the case of semiconductor injection lasers, specifically VCSEL [36], it is estimated in the region of about 50fs and it seems unlikely that this relaxation is markedly varying with the pump power. The mode spectral interval for semiconductor lasers, and especially VCSEL, is much greater than that for dye lasers. Because of this, it is hard to expect that stable correlations between the polarization components are more probable. It is believed that PCA is well applicable to describe the formation of polarized radiation in semiconductor injection lasers and especially VCSEL. It is worth to underline that Eq. (3) are derived for the partial component intensity but not amplitude. In such a case it is more convenient to use photon densities rather than intensities (4) I ( ψ ) = h v 2 2 λ S ( ψ ) as is common in a semiconductor laser theory. Moreover, the use of the photon densities S(ψ) makes it possible to avoid problems with the polarization mode spectral shift and we can apply the single-frequency approximation. Now it is necessary to redefine the main parameters involved in Eq. (3). The simplest decision relates to L(ψ) because this term is determined by a contribution of spontaneous emission into the polarization component. Under assumption that spontaneous emission is isotropic (that is quite real for VCSEL), L(ψ) can be given as (5) L ( ψ ) = β N π τ N where N τ N carrier density and lifetime, β − spontaneous emission factor, and the factor π is due to the equal contributions of spontaneous emission for each of the polarization components. As a rule, the heterostructure growing process for VCSEL is organized so that the gain and loss must be isotropic [6] but, due to the technological procedures and due to the properties of semiconductor structures themselves, weak anisotropy is a result of electrooptic, elastooptic, and thermal processes. Now we suppose that this additional anisotropy provides a contribution only to the gain though it may appear in the loss [37], taking this assumption as our first approximation. Direct calculations of matrix elements for the transitions [38,39] demonstrate that the orientation dependence for an additional term of the gain caused by this anisotropy may be represented as follows: (6) k s ( ψ ) = k x cos 2 ( ψ ) + k y sin 2 ( ψ ) where the parameters k m (m = x, y) determine orientation anisotropy of an additional term of the gain with respect to the crystallographic axes of an active layer and should be weak functions of the injection current densityj. Unfortunately, no theoretical calculations of a similar function have been found in literature − as a rule, the phenomenologically introduced functions are used. For example, the authors of [15,40] have examined a weak linear dependence of k x , whereas k y was considered to be independent of At the same time, the calculations for the gain factor anisotropy as a function of internal stresses [41] point to a certain (and in some cases [42] to a complete) antisymmetry, i.e. an increase in must be accompanied by a decrease of and vice versa. But linearity of the system’s response may be considered as our second approximation because it is supported by the results [43] of direct measurements of the effects exerted by mechanical and thermal stresses on anisotropy of the gain. Because of this, it is assumed that, for the factors the precise antisymmetry is fulfilled and the gain factor k amp may be written as (7) k a m p = g 0 ( N − N t r ) ( 1 + k 0 ( 1 − j j p s ) cos 2 ψ ) where g 0 ( N − N ) t r – standard expression for the gain factor of semiconductor injection lasers [44,45], N tr – concentration of transparency, j ps – injection current corresponding to PS, k 0 – relative gain dichroism – dimensionless parameter determining the variation rate of a degree of anisotropy for the gain η found from the relation (8) η ( J ) = ( k a m p ) x − ( k a m p ) y ( k a m p ) x + ( k a m p ) y = k 0 ( 1 − j j p s ) In principle, the value of k 0 is selected from the experimental data and in fact it is an adjustable parameter. By the present moment, the only significant constraint is the requirement for k 0 <<1. Estimating the value of we can take into consideration that it should determine the PS region width, i.e. the current range Δj, where a degree of polarization is varying from −1 to +1 or vice versa. Actually, a width of the PS region is also determined by other factors [15]. We start our reasoning from the estimate given by the authors in [46]: separation of polarization modes begins in the regionη ∼5·10−5. Assuming that suppression of one of the modes takes place for that is greater by an order of magnitude, and at a relative width of the PS region Δ j / j p s ≈ 0.1 , we can obtain k > 0 5 ⋅ 10 − 4 . A more specific estimate of k 0can be obtained with the data of the gain for two orthogonal polarization modes from [47]. Supposing j ps =1.5j th , we have k 0 ≅0.04. Moreover, from the data of [48] it follows that k 0 ≅0.003. So we can suppose that 10−1 < k 0 <10−3. As follows from our further calculations, this estimate is quite correct. Introducing the gain induced anisotropy as a function of the injection current density, the authors of [15,40] have emphasized that the form of this function is of no particular importance. Besides, linearity of such a function is strongly justified only close to the point of PS. Indeed, release of the thermal energy is growing with the injection current density j, especially in the stationary mode of excitation. As the heat power is proportional to j 2, additional influence of the thermal processes should result in the nonlinear function η(j). In principle, nothing can exclude a decrease in a degree of the induced anisotropy, when we can obtain the second point of PS for higher j ′ p s but this time – for inverse PS. Such an effect of two PS points is fairly often observed experimentally (e.g., see [49]), though the reasons underlying this phenomenon may be considerably more complex due to spectral effects disregarded in a single-frequency model. An interesting feature in representation of the gain in the form given by (7) is that the average value of the gain factor over the angles ψ is independent of j − in line with a linear dependence of the total output intensity I ( j ) o u t . Just this dependence is observed in the majority of cases, without any manifestations of the PS point. Still such a behavior of I ( j ) o u t is not general, one can also observe [49] nonlinearities of the function Iout (j) and intensity jumps at the point of PS. Consequently, the representation given by (7) is not universal and it should be generalized with due regard for the spectral effects. It should be noted that, at special conditions, the loss can also have the anisotropic component [37] that may be represented by (7). In this case the difference in the induced gain and loss should be described by a linear function of j. Considering the above-mentioned assumptions, we assume (9) k a m p − k l o s = g 0 ( N − N t r ) ( 1 + k 0 ( 1 − j j p s ) cos 2 ψ ) − k l o s ' where k l a s ' = ρ + 1 2 L ln 1 R 1 R 2 , ρ − isotropic intrinsic loss, L − cavity length, R 1, R 2 − reflectivity of up and down Bragg’s reflectors. The parameter k 0 determines a degree of anisotropy for the difference in the induced gain and loss that may be referred to as the amplification dichroism . But in order to simplify our further calculations, we suppose that additional anisotropy relates only to the gain and consider the loss to be fully isotropic. Then we can write the final form of a dynamic equation for the photon density component S(ψ) as follows: (10) d S ( ψ ) d t = Γ β N π τ N − v ( Γ g 0 ( N − N t r ) ( 1 + k 0 ( 1 − j j p s ) cos 2 ψ ) − ρ + 1 2 L ln 1 R 1 R 2 ) S ( ψ ) where τ N − carrier lifetime in an active layer, Γ − optical confinement factor (for QW active layer). Now it is necessary to add the equation for the carrier densityN. As, in essence, equations (10) are rate equations, the evolution of N is adequately described by the classical rate equation [44,45], where the effect of a field of laser radiation must be integral for a set of polarization components (11) d N d t = j e d − v ∫ g 0 ( N − N t r ) ( 1 + k 0 ( 1 − j j p s ) cos 2 ψ ) S ( ψ ) d ψ − N τ N where e − electron charge, d- active layer thickness, τ N − carrier lifetime in the active layer. To find a solution for system (10) and (11), we use the numerical methods. The values of the main parameters are listed in Table 1 . 3 Analysis of numerical calculations Note that quite natural the main results we have obtained are in agreement with the results of [28]. But, due to the definition of the function that describes a weak gain anisotropy, some peculiarities of polarization switching are revealed explicitly. 3.1 Steady state approximation First of all, it should be noted that MPM gives a new interpretation of PS and we exert every effort to verify that. Let us consider that the injection current is switched on at t =0and it reaches the steady state value in 1ns. The finite speed of the current growth is of no special importance and is needed to decrease the influence of transient processes. Our calculations show that the time required to attain the steady state values of the output intensity is in the region of 10ns and is weakly dependent on j and k 0. A very different pattern is observed for a polarization degree that is defined in the classical way as (12) P = I x − I y I x + I y = ∫ I ( ψ ) ( cos 2 ψ − sin 2 ψ ) d ψ ∫ I ( ψ ) ( cos 2 ψ + sin 2 ψ ) d ψ = ∫ I ( ψ ) cos 2 ψ d ψ I where I x and I y are components of the total intensity I passing through the polarizer orientated along the axes x and y, respectively. Both the steady state value P and the time needed to attain such a value is greatly dependent not only on but also on the relation between the injection current density and its value at the point of PS. As seen from the functions given in Fig. 1 , at the same value of the values of are decreasing as the difference j − j ps decreases, while the time required to attain the stationary values is growing. At the same time, an increase in k 0 leads to the contrary situation. This is absolutely understandable: increase of k 0 and decrease of the difference j − j ps are both determined by the growth of the gain anisotropy and vice versa. All the foregoing data support the assumption made in [28] that the limiting values of a polarization degree are determined by the finite photon lifetime in a laser cavity – the laser intensity and also anisotropy of the orientation distribution for the polarization component E(ψ) governing the polarization degree are increased simultaneously. The intensity quickly reaches its steady state value at a relatively low polarization, and then the orientation distribution collapse takes place at the practically invariable total intensity that, in fact, is determined by the carrier density N. Actually, the latter is practically constant and the intensity is redistributed between the polarization components due to anisotropy of the gain. Anisotropy in the region of the PS point becomes very low. Because of this, the components with high gain fail to suppress those with lower gain due to the finite photon lifetime in a laser cavity and radiation becomes partially polarized. The effect exerted by the photon lifetime in a cavity on the formation of polarized radiation should be most marked in dynamics. Let us consider not the steady state limit but a pure time dynamics of the output-radiation polarization components (Fig. 2 ). It is seen that, after the threshold, both polarized components of the intensity are varying in a similar way, their separation occurs with the lapse of time. The period of time when the components reveal a synchronous behavior is greatly dependent on dichroism of the induced anisotropy k 0 and also on the relation j / j p s , being in the region from 0.2 to 4ns and in line with the experimental results [50]. The functions derived completely support the assumption that initially the formed radiation is nonpolarized or weakly polarized and then its polarization degree is changing due to the intensity redistribution of some polarization components, while the total intensity remains practically invariable. 3.2 Approximation of a constantly growing current Now let us consider the radiation formation dynamics when the current is growing sequentially at a constant rate. This approach to PS is used when there is a need to exclude the effect of heating of the active region [51]. We assume that the injection current density is linearly increased from zero up to the value considerably exceeding j ps , see Fig. 3 . For the selected reference value k 0 =0.01 (Fig. 4 а), we can observe both the increased threshold value j th and the increased j ps at the point of PS. In fact, both phenomena have been described in [50], though the effect was lower considerably. This is explainable as in [50] such a growth was not from zero but from the value j 0 ≈0.5j th . In any case, these effects are identically associated with finiteness of the photon lifetime in a cavity – when the current is relatively fast growing, radiation fails to attain the values corresponding to the stationary process. Besides, at a high rate of the current increase, the point of PS begins to shift to lower values. This effect has been observed experimentally by М. Sondermann as stated in his thesis [52] but the author presented no explanations for the effect and never returned to it in his further publications. To explain the effect of the backward shifted PS point, let us consider the form of the corresponding functions: after the threshold, a degree of polarization never approaches the limiting values − the polarization switching process begins for radiation with a low degree of orientation anisotropy that is more easily compensated by anisotropic amplification. This may be confirmed by the data in Fig. 3b obtained at a much higher degree of the amplification dichroism (k 0 =0.1). In this case a minimal polarization degree is very close to −1 and there is no backward shift of the PS point. Next, let us consider a shift in the threshold current with the increased pumping rate. When for the curves given in Fig. 3 we define the scale of relative values of the current density j / j t h (Fig. 4), the situation is somewhat changed. We have the backward shifted PS point for k 0=0.1 as well, but only for a single curve with a minimal value far from −1. The obtained results demonstrate the applicability of the polarization components approach to describe the polarization effects in surface-emitting lasers and the possibility of a unified interpretation for the observed effects due to the deterministic formation process of laser radiation. 4 Conclusion In this way, the phenomenological introduction of the function describing a weak gain anisotropy enables us to verify a mechanism of polarization switching in VCSEL as a process of sequential transformation of the initial linear polarization into orthogonal polarization by means of a sequence of the partially polarized states upon variation of the injection current. Besides, within the scope of the developed approach, we can describe the effect of anomalous SP shift when the current is varying at a high rate. It should be noted that the proposed approach is based on a clear physical concept: the process of lasing is activated by the spontaneous radiation that is initially incoherent. In the process of amplification, both the intensity and the polarization degree is growing. As the intensity growing rate determines the difference in gain and loss and the polarization growing rate is determined by their anisotropy, at a relatively low value of such anisotropy, the polarization growing rate is considerably lower than the intensity growing rate. Because of this, in the case of stationary excitation the intensity rapidly runs to its stationary value, whereas polarization arrives at its stationary value much slower. Here the second factor is important – finiteness of the photon lifetime in a cavity. This means that every photon initiating the process of sequential (avalanche) amplification can form a confined flux of such photons, their number being proportional to the amplification value for this orientation of the polarization vector by this group of the photons, i.e. it is dependent on the angle ψ. Since attainment of a stationary value of the lasing intensity means that the carrier density also arrives at its stationary value, further growth of the polarization degree is possible only due to redistribution of the polarization components: an increase in the intensity of “stronger” components is realized by suppression of the “weaker” ones. Representing the orientation distribution function I(ψ) in the form of a particular oval, we can see that evolution of laser radiation is associated with elongation of this oval on the retention of its area. However, note that, for a relatively low amplification anisotropy, the saturation effects are important: amplification of the “stronger” components diminishes with respect to the “weaker” components, and a particular equilibrium is achieved when the “distribution oval” is invariable. This means that a stationary value (that is below 1) of the polarization degree is attained. In the limit when amplification is isotropic (PS point) such equilibrium occurs from the beginning, whereas the polarization degree is zero. Considering that spontaneous radiation is weakly polarized, with a weak orientation polarization of its components, such anisotropy may be compensated by the amplification anisotropy, leading to some shifting of the PS point without changes in a mechanism of the polarized radiation formation. In principle, when the injection current is varying in time, the pattern of the polarization radiation formation is not changed. But when the current is varying at a high rate, the effects of delay will be revealed both for the intensity (by the shifted threshold values) and polarization (lowering of the polarization growth rate), see Figs. 3 and 4. Note that the proposed approach (PCA) from the start includes the formation dynamics of polarized radiation while PCA seems to divide the process into two stages: first, the two modes are independently enforced, and then they are concurrent. This is the reason why a contribution of spontaneous radiation into PCA is so important, unlike the initial SFM model [13,14], where such contribution is not involved. column2: Characterization of the sandblasted glass degradation by light scattering
column3: Abstract In Sahara region, the sandstorms cause a serious damage of windshield vehicle. The windscreen wear for driver visibility in vehicle lighting is very important and it is related to the stay light by transmission or reflection. This paper presents a study of the light scattering transmittance and reflectance on a sandblasted soda–lime–silica glass. A stay light measurement which characterizes the level sandblasting degradation was assessed using the stay light index ‘SLI’. The results show that the SLI values were found to be linearly to the surface damage and a relationship was established between the SLI and the surface roughness’ Ra’. An SLI critical value which seems to be adopted as the cut-off for the use limit of wear windshield was determined.
column5: Keywords Glass Sandblasting Scattering Reflection Transmission Roughness 1 Introduction The visibility of objects through a car glass windshield can be affected by its surface state. The exterior windshield surface is differently exposed to damaging effect caused by dust, hail or sand according to the geographical region [1,2]. In Saharan regions for instance, sandblasting during sandstorms can affect tremendously the vehicles windshields surfaces. This inevitable and undesirable glass erosion phenomenon induces stray light that is harmful to drivers’ vision particularly at night and during sunset or dawn. In this context, during the daylight, the eye is adapted to stronger light with many different wavelengths, therefore the impact of stray light is not very severe at this time. However, in the case of on-coming headlights of another vehicle at night, the light that hits the windscreen suddenly can be deflected into the driver’s eye by means of wide angle light scattering, causing the genesis of ghost image in the field of conductor view [3,4]. The conductor loss visibility is a consequence of reducing objects contrast which is caused by stray light. The stray light by transmission or reflection caused by the soiling and/or windshields vehicles damage. Light that has been disturbed and deviated more than 2.5 degrees on the average is referred to as “stray light”. It depends on various factors such as the inclination angle, the intensity of the light source and the surface state of the windshields [5,6]. The ratio of the intensity of the stray light to the intensity of useful light defines the degree of windscreen degradation and it is critical for driver [7]. This ratio is called the reduced luminance coefficient and is also referred to as the Scattered Light Index (SLI). According to the German Standard DIN 52298-1 [8], the SLI is equivalent to the scattering distribution function on the transmitting side of the scattering surface at 1.8 scattering angle, multiplied by the transmission of the windows. Timmerman [2] restricts the measurement of the stray light to a limited range of angles, from 1.5 to 2 degrees. In this work, we carry out a study of the light scattering by reflection and transmission induced by surface heterogeneities caused by sandblasting on soda–lime–silica glass samples. The aim of this study is to optically characterize the sandblasted glass degradation, to establish a relationship between Scattered Light Index ‘SLI’ and roughness ‘Ra’ and to determine the good windshield visibility limit, in terms of SLI critical value. This latter is calculated from the SLI expression defined by Timmermann and Gehring [9]. 2 Materials and test conditions The samples were prepared from a soda-lime glass manufactured by AFRICAVER (an Algerian company located at Jijel region). The dimensions used were 50 × 50 × 3 mm3. In order to simulate the effects of the sandstorm on the surface state of a glass, a sand blower apparatus was used (Fig. 1 ). The eroded glass samples were submitted to different projected sand masses varying between 10 and 100 g at a normal impact angle (the samples are oriented perpendicularly to the sand flux). The Size range of the sand grains is about (250÷350) μm and the sand flow speed was fixed at 16 m/s which is about the average speed encountered in the Sahara sandstorms. In real conditions, sand wind velocities vary usually between 12 and 25 m/s. We took as a reference sample without any damaging effect, a glass sample in its received state. Fig. 2 shows typical example photos of the glass samples damaged by different projected sand masses. For low projected sand mass, there are individual impacts, but for higher projected sand mass, the damages extend and cover the entire exposed surface which reaches a saturated state. 3 Optical experimental apparatus Fig. 3 shows the schematic principle of the optical apparatus prepared for the purpose of this study. It consists in illuminating a sample fixed on the vertical goniometric plane at variable illuminating angle (α = 30° and 60°) from a 300 W white light xenon source. The emitted light beam is collimated by a Koehler system composed of a condenser” C”, a lens” L” and two diaphragms (a field diaphragm” FD” and an aperture diaphragm” AD”) before being diffused by the eroded analyzed surface area whose diameter is 3 mm. The transmitted and reflected beams are captured by a phototransistor (T) which is mounted on a mobile arm. This latter is solidly attached to goniometric rotating table. The phototransistor (T) is placed at a distance of 50 mm from the analyzed surface where the measuring elementary solid angle corresponds to d Ω  = 1.97.10−3 sr. It allows converting the luminous energy into electrical energy expressed in EVA type nano-ammeter (10 nA-1 mA). The position of the phototransistor (T) in relation to the specular direction at the surface determines the diffusion angle θ. The goniometer is composed of a fixed table graded from 0° to 360° and a moving table equipped with a graded jack between 0°à 30°. The optical system resolution is of 1’ (1/60°). In this study, we determined the variations of the scattered light normalized intensity with variations of angle θ at a pace of 10’. 4 Results and discussion Fig. 4 shows the angular scattering distribution transmission and reflection versus the scattering angle for the different projected sand mass (Mp = 0, 10, 20, 50 and 100) g at the illuminating angle (α = 30° and 60°). One can notice clearly that for the representing low projected sand mass curves (Mp ≤ 20 g), the best fitting function of the transmittance and reflectance curves is that of the Gaussian function while for the other curves that the projected sand mass is higher (Mp ≥ 50 g), the best fitting function is that of the Lorentz function. Consequently, we can conclude that, in the case of low surface damage, the most of the incident light is concentrated in the specular direction and in the case where the surface state is more damaged, the transmitted and reflected light diffused in large scattering angle. Fig. 5 illustrates clearly this result. As the projected sand mass increases, the specular transmittance and reflectance decreases and reaches the minimum values of 13% and 1% respectively while the scattered transmittance and reflectance increases and reaches the maximum values of 81% and 8% respectively at the illuminating angle (α = 60°). We concluded that the degradation of surface state induces the losses in specular transmittance and reflectance, the increase in scattering transmittance and reflectance which is caused by the increasing damage surface. The surface degradation is characterized by the increasing roughness of the eroded samples. The opposite evolution of both specular transmittance and reflectance, the scattering transmittance and reflectance curves, reveal that the loss of optical transmission is essentially attributed to the light reflected and the scattering transmittance. Furthermore, the majority of scattered transmission is enormously dominated in comparison with scattered reflection. Mefford et al. [10] reported that during daytime driving, of the total veiling luminance that the driver sees, about 60% was attributable to reflection dash board and about 40% to scatter. 5 Characterization of the sandblasted glass degradation It is well known that the most modern techniques use the Scattered Light Index “SLI” as a measure of windscreen degradation. In this study, we have calculated the light scattering index “SLI” from the expression defined by Timmermann [9] as following: S L I = 1 / Ω Q 1 R / Q 1 L – Q 0 R / Q 0 L 1 Where, Ω : Solid angle. Q o L : Specular light transmits without specimen. Q 1 L : Specular light transmits with specimen. Q o R : Scattered light transmits without specimen. Q 1 R : Scattered light transmits without specimen. Fig. 6 illustrates the SLI variation versus the projected sand mass. This curve shows a regular increase of the Scattered Light Index from 0.43 up to 4.5 sr−1 and then tends toward a constant level. It is the saturating state which occurs from mass larger than 50 g. For the low projected sand masses (low surface damage), the diffuse light is very small, from which it has a low SLI value, whereas for the important projected sand masses (higher surface damage), the totality of the light is diffused in a wide diffusion angle, hence the value of SLI is important. Helmers et al. [11] reported that the very worn windshield present an SLI value of 3.04 cd m−2 lux−1 and a relative detection distance was found to be linearly related to the mean SLI values of the windshields. In the same veiw, Timmermann [9] concluded that, the SLI value found is about 4.31 cd m−2 lux−1 corresponding to wiper damage. As to Derkum [12], the SLI value attains 6.3 cd m−2 lux−1 relative to the damage in windshield caused by the wiper. The variation of the surface roughness ‘Ra’ versus the projected sand mass is presented in Fig. 7 . It is clear that this curve represents a similar tendency like the Scattered Light Index curve. Thus, we have represented the variation of the Scattered Light Index ‘SLI’ versus the surface roughness ‘Ra’ Fig. 8 . We show that, a linear relationship was obtained between SLI and Ra and the best fitting function is that of a single degree polynomial. The flowing expression defines this relation: (2) S L I = 1.78 R a + 0.3 Where, SLI = 0.3 (SLI of the measuring system) From this expression and knowing the Ra limit value, we have determined the SLI critical value limit. Note that, the Ra limit value was graphically obtained, based on the transmission value limit “Tlim” given by B. Savaëte [13] Fig. 9 .We remind that, the tolerated visibility limit which corresponds to a minimal value of the valid transmission in Europe is 75% while it is 70% in Japan and in the United States of America. As to Derkum [14], the exact transmission value, from which drivers’ vision becomes significantly worse, lies between 60% and 70%. In this work, we opted to the medium value of the transmission limit Tlim = 70%. Thus, the SLI value limit obtained is 1.46 sr−1 which corresponds to the roughness critical value Ra = 0.66 μm. Therefore, values below 1.46 sr−1 define a good visibility domain corresponding to low windscreen damage and low light scattering. Timmermann [2] has reported that, when driving with a degraded windscreen, the minimum stray light index values which cause an important reduction on driver perception are 1.1 (re-adaptation times) and 1.7 (detection distances). Therefore we can conclude that, the SLI value limit obtained in our study is included in the interval [1.1–1.7] which is reported by Timmermann. 6 Conclusion In this work, we simulated the effect of sand blasting on the surface of a soda-lime glass. The results lead to the conclusions that the projected sand mass parameter affects enormously the transmittance and the reflectance with a different behaviour. This influence is very important especially when the projected sand mass became greater than 50 g at the illuminating angle (α = 60°). By varying the projected sand mass, the surface damage increases and brings about a decrease of the specular transmittance and reflectance which reach the minimum values of 13% and 1% respectively, as for the scattered transmittance and reflectance increase and reach the maximum values of 81% and 8% respectively. Therefore, the loss of the optical transmission is essentially attributed to the light reflected and the scattering transmittance. Characterization of the sandblasting degradation by the calculation of the SLI provides us with the possibility to distinguish between acceptable and non-acceptable windscreen damage or good and impaired visibility. The established relationship between Ra and SLI largely helps the authorities to simply assess the limit of good visibility.
