column2: Zn doping in the In0.53Ga0.47As(100)β2(2 × 4) surface for negative electron affinity photocathode: A first-principles research
column3: Abstract InGaAs is an important ternary III-V semiconductor material with good spectral response in the near infrared region of 1–3 μm. The negative electron affinity is generated from the proper sensitization of In0.53Ga0.47As(100)β2(2 × 4) surface. Doping and sensitization are indispensable in the preparation of InGaAs photocathode. However, the surface doping mechanism of InGaAs is not clear. This article focuses on the suitable doping sites of substitutional Zn atoms for sensitization on In0.53Ga0.47As(100)β2(2 × 4) surface. Considering the symmetry, there are eight doping sites and the eight doping surface models are formed. The surface atomic structures and surface formation energies of these models are discussed. The lower the formation energy is, the more stable the surface is. Zn4 and Zn5 are the more stable doping models based on the analysis of formation energy. Therefore the band structure, surface charge distribution, work function and optical properties are further discussed for these two doping models. The Zn4 doping surface has a lower work function and reflectivity and better absorption in the range of 1–3 μm than Zn5. In a word, the InGaAs surface with Zn4 doped is more conducive to the photoelectrons transport and photoemission. Then Zn4 is the most favorable doping site for the InGaAs photocathode.
column5: Keywords Zn doping In0.53Ga0.47As(100)β2(2 × 4) surface Formation energy Electronic structure 1 Introduction In0.53Ga0.47As is a good sensing material in the field of military night vision. The image of the negative electron affinity (NEA) photocathode In0.53Ga0.47As is clear and it’s hard to be detected by electronic reconnaissance and interference. It is suitable to use in extremely weak night as the high response speed and the good sensitivity and resolution [1,2]. According to W. E. Spicer's three-step model of photoemission [3], the photoemission capability is related to the doping and surface morphology besides of the internal structure of the photocathode. It has been shown that the Zn doping in the GaAs bulk and surface is favorable for the transport of photoelectrons to the surface and improve the photoemission [4,5]. It’s indicated that the interaction between the Zn doping and the As vacancy defects is benefit for the photoelectrons transport in bulk In0.53Ga0.47As [6]. However, the doping of Zn atoms in In0.53Ga0.47As surface has not been studied due to many kinds of reconstructions on the In0.53Ga0.47As (100) surface. The β2(2 × 4) reconstruction can provide stages and holes for later Cs-O adsorption to form NEA surface [7]. The doping sites and depth of Zn atoms in In0.53Ga0.47As (100)β2(2 × 4) surface are investigated to make preparation for NEA surface in this article. The atomic structure, band structure, electron distribution and work function of the Zn doped In0.53Ga0.47As (100)β2(2 × 4) surfaces are calculated and analyzed. The contribution of Zn doping to the formation of the NEA In0.53Ga0.47As surface is explained theoretically and the most favorable Zn doping sites are found out. 2 Models and methods Zn-doped surface models were built when a Ga atom or In atom was substituted by a Zn atom in the intrinsic In0.53Ga0.47As (100) β2 (2 × 4) surface model (six layers), shown in Fig. 1 (a) and (b). The difference of the band structure, electron distribution and optical properties was not significant whether Zn substituted Ga or In atom in bulk In0.53Ga0.47As [12]. As a result only doping sites were considered when Zn was doped in the surface models. Zn atom was doped to replace the Group III atoms in the fourth or sixth layer, regardless of whether Ga or In was replaced. Considering the symmetry, Zn substituted one of the four atoms of Group III in sixth layer, generating four models named Zn1, Zn2, Zn3 and Zn4, shown in Fig.1(a). The other four Zn doping models named Zn5, Zn6, Zn7 and Zn8 were generated when Zn atom substituted one of the Group III atoms in the fourth layer, shown in Fig.1(b). These substitution sites in fourth layer were chosen mainly considering the stages and holes on the β2(2 × 4) reconstruction surface as the dipole was generated between doped Zn and the Cs and O atoms adsorbed, which helped to form NEA surface. The ab initio quantum mechanics program of Cambrige Serial Total Energy Package (CASTEP) [8] based on density function theory (DFT) combined with the generalized gradient approximation (GGA) [9,10] was used to perform the calculations. The bulk and surface models were optimized by the Broyden Flecher Goldfarb Shanno (BFGS) algorithm. The energy cutoff of the final sets of energies was computed as 400eV. The integral in the Brillouin zone was sampled with the Monkhorst-Pack [11] scheme and special k points of high symmetry. The number of k points is 4 × 2 × 1 in calculation of the surface model. Valence electrons in orbit of Ga (3d, 4s, 4p), In (4d, 5s, 5p), As (4s, 4p) and Zn (3d, 4s) were only considered during the calculations and the analysis. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Surface relaxation and formation energy For the surface of InAs and GaAs, the stability of the reconstructed surface is not only related to the atomic structure but also to the formation energy of surface [13–17]. The lower the formation energy is, the more stable the surface is. In0.53Ga0.47As is also III-IV compound and its atomic and surface structures are similar to those in InAs and GaAs. The undoped reconstruction surface In0.53Ga0.47As(100)β2(2 × 4) contained four kinds of atoms, In, Ga, As and H saturated on the bottom and its formation energy is shown in Ref. [7]. For the doped models, a Ga or In atom is replaced by a Zn atom. Then the formation energy is deduced as Eq. (1). (1) σ = E d o p e − s u r f − E s u r f − ( μ Z n − μ i ) A where σ is the formation energy, A is the area of the surface model, E d o p e − s u r f is the surface energy of doped model, E s u r f is that of undoped model, μ Z n is the chemical potential of Zn, μ i is the chemical potential of Ga or In atom when it is replaced by Zn atom in the surface model. The surface energy and the formation energy of the undoped and the doped models after geometrical optimization are shown in Table 1 . The formation energy of the Zn6 and Zn8 surface models is positive. It is shown that about 3 eV/ Å2 will be absorbed from outside when the Ga or In atom is replaced to form doped surface, which indicates that the models Zn6 and Zn8 are not so stable because they are at the high energy point. As a result the Zn atom will be separated out in the real In0.53Ga0.47As surface due to the surface effect. The formation energies of the other six surface models are all negative, which means the energies are released during the doping. These six models are more stable than Zn6 and Zn8. The Zn4 and Zn5 models are the most stable surface because of the most energy they released and the doped Zn atoms are just under the As-As dimers, which are benefit for the surface doping. In In0.53Ga0.47As photocathode Zn doping is prepared for the following alternative adsorption of the Cs and O atoms to form NEA surface and the Zn atoms doped in the Zn4 and Zn5 sites under the As-As dimers are suitable for the adsorption according to the traditional theory. Based on the above analysis, the other properties of Zn4 and Zn5 surface models are focused on and discussed as followed. The atomic radius and the outer electrons decrease due to the divalent Zn ions. The surface atomic relaxation of the doped In0.53Ga0.47As is shown in Table 2 . In Table 2, L1-1 and L1-2 are the length of the two As-As dimers on the first layer and L3 is that on the third layer. D1 and D2 are the distances between the As atoms in the two As-As dimers. It is shown in Table 2 that the positions of atoms which form stages are changed little when the Ga atom is substituted by the Zn atom in the models of Zn4 and Zn5. Then the Changes caused by Zn doping should be more reflected in the work function and electronic structure. 3.2 Energy bands and electronic structure The periodic potential which affects the moving of electrons becomes aperiodic when the Zn doping happens. The electrons movements are changed and the new energy levels, especially the localized levels confined around the doping atoms which are different from those in the ideal crystal, are generated in the band gap. According to the localized energy levels away from the edge of the band, shallow and deep levels are differentiated. The characters of the doped Zn in group II are similar to the substituted Ga and In atoms in group III except the number of outer electrons. An electron is obtained to form a covalent bond and a hole is created in the valence band as the doped Zn atom has one less outer electron than the substituted Ga or In atom. Shallow acceptor levels are generated and appear near the top of valence band. Therefore, the energy levels around Fermi level in the band gap are analyzed after doping. The energy bands of Zn4 and Zn5 models are shown in Fig. 2 . New energy levels arise in the band gap in both Zn4 and Zn5 models, shown in Fig. 2. The wave functions are expanded within a bigger volume than the primitive cell although the electrons in the impurity state are bound around the doped Zn atom. Compared to the impurity potential, which can be considered as perturbation, crystalline potential plays a leading role. Acceptor levels of Zn4 model are closer to the top of valence band than Zn5 model. The doped Zn in sixth layer of Zn4 model is right under the As-As dimer in third layer, which is slightly farer from the surface than that in Zn5. Then the wave functions expansion of Zn4 is less affected by the surface than Zn5. The new shallow impurity energy levels generated by Zn doping narrow the energy gap further. For Zn5 model, there are some differences. The doped Zn in fourth layer of Zn5 model is under the two As-As dimers in the first layer. The conduction band moves to the high energy region and the band gap increases. Two impurity levels in the band gap are a little far from the top of the valence band. Based on the analysis above, Zn doped at Zn4 site is more benefit for the narrowing of the band gap and the transition of the photoelectrons. For further analysis, the electron density difference of Zn4 and Zn5 models is shown in Fig. 3 . In Fig. 3, blue indicates the loss of electrons and red means the increase while black represents no change in this area. It is dark red at the position of the Zn and In atoms in the fourth layer of Zn5 model, which means massive charge enrichment, shown as Fig. 3(b) and (d). On the contrary, the doped Zn is blue in Zn4 model which means the charge loss, shown in Fig. 3(a) and (c). For the other atoms, As atoms in the first layer and Ga atoms in the fourth layer have some charge enrichment and the other charges mostly distribute in bonds in Fig. 3(a) and (c). Covalent bonds are generated between the doped Zn and the atoms around in Zn4 model. However, the doped Zn in Zn5 model obtains electrons from the other atoms around and formed covalent bonds with strong ionic character. The charge distribution and the bonds are also analyzed from population. The population around the doped Zn atom is shown in Table 3 In Table 3, the Zn atom loses 0.1 electrons in Zn4 model which is more than 0.01 electrons in Zn5 model. The As1, As2, As3 and As4 atoms in Zn4 model obtain 0.10, 0.10, 0.20 and 0.20 electrons separately and it is clear for the electrons enrichment. The charges of the As atoms around the doped Zn atom in Zn5 model are -0.11, 0.00, -0.16 and 0.16 electrons. Electrons of the As atoms happen to be got, lost or kept the same. There is still enrichment of electrons around the bond between the doped Zn and As atoms as the bond population shown in Table 3. It is indicated that the charge distribution of Zn5 model is affect by the surface than by the doped Zn as the Zn atom is closer to the surface than that in Zn4 model. The closer to the surface is, the more the charge distribution and the bonds of the models are changed. 3.3 The work function of the Zn-doped surfaces Electron affinity is generally positive. It is an electronic barrier to prevent electrons escape from the bulk. It comes from the first ionization energy of the discrete atoms that make up the solid. When a large number of atoms get close to each other to form a solid, the atom energy levels split into energy bands. The electron affinity of most solid elements is lower than the first ionization energy of the corresponding discrete atoms because of the energy levels’ upwards bend. Most of the photoelectrons are from the valence band and the photoemission is affected as the electron affinity is changed effectively by upwards bend of the defect levels in the NEA photocathode [18]. The Fermi level in the bulk is close to the bottom of conduction band while that in the surface is on the top half of the band gap. Fig. 4 shows the band structure of the n-type GaAs surface measured by a UV photoelectron spectrometer (UPS). E0 is the vacuum level. The core level of 3d state of Ga in the bulk is about 18.81 eV far from the valence band maximum (VBM) for the n-type GaAs [18–21]. The band bends up and a barrier is formed to restrain electrons escape due to the surface potential. The surface barrier model of n-type In0.53Ga0.47As is similar to GaAs. Then the In0.53Ga0.47As with Zn doped is p-type and the impurity band is near the VBM, shown in Fig. 5 . The Fermi level is in the lower half of the band gap due to the As dangling bonds. At equilibrium, the surface Fermi level must be equal to the bulk, which causes the energy band a downward bending near the surface, as shown in Fig. 5. On the other hand, Zn doping on the surface produces many holes and accelerates the movement of electrons to the surface, which is favorable for the photoelectron emission. The work function is further reduced after doping. The work functions of Zn4 and Zn5 models are 3.962 eV and 4.011 eV respectively, which are decreased by 0.312 eV and 0.263 eV compared with 4.274 eV of intrinsic In0.53Ga0.47As. For the work function, Zn doped in Zn4 and Zn5 sites both causes the surface work function to decline. The band bending region (BBR) is formed on the surface, which is benefit for the transport and the emission of photoelectrons. H owever, it is more obvious in Zn4 model in the decline of the work function, reaching 7.3%. 3.4 Optical properties of the Zn-doped surfaces After Zn doping, new impurity levels appear on the surface. The photoelectron transitions among impurity and continuous levels also play an important role in the absorption and emission of light and the capture and release of carriers. It has a significant impact on the optical properties of photocathode. It is the first step that the electrons get energy from the incident photons. The absorption coefficient α, which is related to the incident photon energy and the material character, indicates absorption capacity. It is found that the absorption edge moves to the long wavelength.as the doping concentration increases in GaAs photocathode. As a result, the GaAs photocathode still has a spectral response at 930 nm. Then the absorption coefficient curves of Zn4 and Zn5 doping surface models are shown in Fig. 6 . In Fig. 6, the absorption coefficient peaks of Zn4 and Zn5 surface models both appears at 302.56 nm in the short wave UV region. However, the short wave limit depends on the window layer and In0.53Ga0.47As photocathode mainly works in the infrared area. Therefore, the infrared work region from 1000 to 3000 nm is focused on. The absorption coefficient of Zn4 model is significantly greater than the Zn5, which also corresponds to the structure of energy band. The energy gap of the Zn4 model is obviously smaller than that of the Zn5. The light can be absorbed as much as possible in Zn4 model. The photon energy is converted to the kinetic energy for the electrons transition and emission. In conclusion, Zn doped in Zn4 site is more suitable than Zn5 from the analysis of the absorption coefficient. Another optical property is reflectivity, as shown in Fig. 7 . The reflection peaks are both at 230.3 nm in UV region, which makes no sense for infrared photocathode in Fig. 7. The reflectivity of Zn4 model is less than that of Zn5. The Zn atom doped in Zn4 site reduces the light reflection on the surface. The surface with Zn4 doped allows more light to enter the photocathode than Zn5. For the reflectivity, the Zn4 model is more advantageous than Zn5, which is consistent with the analysis of absorption coefficient. 4 Conclusions This article focuses on the surface doped with Zn atom for In0.53Ga0.47As photocathodes. The atomic structure and the formation energy are analyzed firstly. The Zn4 and Zn5 are considered as the suitable doping sites according to the stability. The energy bands, electronic structures, work functions and optical properties of these two doping surfaces are analyzed concretely. It is concluded that the surface with Zn4 doped can not only narrow the band gap and improve the electronic structure, but also have advantages in optical absorption coefficient and reflectivity. Therefore, Zn4 site is more appropriate for doping in In0.53Ga0.47As surfaces for infrared photocathodes. column2: Research on traffic decision making method based on image analysis case based reasoning
column3: Abstract As the deteriorating urban traffic incurs multiple traffic safety problems, this article designed a system framework for the traffic monitoring and management system according to its characteristics and provided a traffic emergency aid decision making method by integrating the case-based reasoning specific to the traffic emergencies. Meanwhile, the article built a traffic aid decision making case base, designed overall-local characteristic attribute similarity calculating measures and provided a case retrieval strategy. Finally the traffic aid decision making method was verified by examples.
column5: Keywords Image analysis Case-based reasoning Traffic congestion Similarity 1 Introduction In recent years, the number of vehicles increases rapidly with economic development, but road construction speed cannot keep pace with the rapid increase of vehicles due to its long construction period, which leads to deteriorating traffic condition. This is almost a common problem among all the cities. Therefore, it's an effective solution for improving the traffic situation to build a traffic monitoring system with perfect functions in the city traffic management departments. The traffic monitoring system can strengthen traffic management, improve traffic capacity of the existing roads, coordinate treatment of sudden traffic incidents, ease the traffic jams and improve traffic conditions accordingly. In order to achieve effective traffic management, the monitoring system must be utilized to acquire, clear up and analyze the city traffic information and provide a traffic control strategy aiming at such data. Under the premise that the monitoring system acquires complete traffic information, how to provide the complete traffic control strategy to solve the traffic emergencies quickly and reasonably is of great importance. Ref. [2] put forward a kind of typical congestion management method under congested network condition to judging and responding with different congestion situations. Ref. [3] proposed a technique to put traffic congestion dispersion decision system into database to get congestion knowledge by using rough set theory. Ref. [4] gave a CBR distribution model for transportation network by Markus Shade. Ref. [5] proposed a traffic control system based on CBR technology which can monitor and manage traffic accidents by John L. McLin and some other people. But these researches mainly focus on emergency events with less attention on daily traffic dispersion. This paper makes the congestion management experience to form expertise knowledge library by using case reasoning to propose a management method to deal with daily traffic dispersion. 2 System framework of traffic monitoring and management platform and case based reasoning process 2.1 System framework of traffic monitoring and management platform In order to make traffic management more reasonable, the designed traffic monitoring system consists of the following modules: (1) Traffic information acquisition module, which is mainly used for acquiring road traffic information by the monitoring cameras arranged on the road, including vehicle license plate, vehicle type, traffic flow and weather situation. It is generally the acquisition process of daily information. (2) Emergency scene information capture module, which is mainly used for further acquiring road emergency information quickly under the premise that the normal traffic information is acquired, including weather condition, traffic flow, road information, emergency property and scope of influence. (3) Human-computer interface module, which is used for completing representation and result display of human-computer interaction and emergencies and inspecting matching of the input parameters to determine their weights. It will remind users timely if necessary parameters are unavailable. It further includes: ① a preprocessing module which analyzes the issues submitted by the users and converts them into the information source of CBR processing unit for accident handling; ② a vocabulary and syntax database which contains relevant vocabularies and basic grammars in this field for calling by the preprocessing module; ③ a vocabulary and grammar expansion interface which is used for updating the vocabulary and syntax database. (4) Emergency modeling module, which is used for building a scene module specific to parameter information matching of the human-computer interface module. (5) Aid decision making module, which is used for forming a case rapidly according to the built model to perform case retrieval, find the matched case, modify the matched case according to the scene conditions and find the optimum time solution. (6) Database module, which contains three sub-databases of a law base, a model base and a case base, providing corresponding support respectively specific to the above different modules. See Fig. 1 for the specific system framework. 2.2 Reasoning process of aid decision making method based on case-based reasoning From Table 1 , the aid decision making module is comparatively important in the system framework of the whole management platform and is the key process to resolve traffic emergencies reasonably. The article introduces the case based reasoning into the aid decision making module to acquire a solution and analyzes the current problem by utilizing the existing case to find out the best way to solve the problem. Case based reasoning (CBR) [1] is a novel reasoning mode emerging in the field of artificial intelligence in recent years, also an important knowledge learning and solution deducing method. CBR refers to the process that the similar case in the existing knowledge base is searched when there is a new case, and applied into the environment of the new case to acquire parameters matched with the new case and modify the parameters according to the new case to form parameter types consistent with the new case finally and deduce the new case result. Generally, the typical CBR case analysis solving process includes four steps [6]: Retrieve [7]: retrieve the case or case set most similar to the case set from the cases; Reuse: reuse the centralized case information and knowledge in the target case set in the new case; Revise [8]: in case of large difference between the previous case in the case base and the question to be solved of the target case, revise the previous case to adapt to the current target case question and obtain the new solution of the question to be solved; Retain [9]: retain the new solution of the current question to be solved into the case base for future use. See Fig. 1 for its working process: The CBR working process is shown as Fig. 1: a new question to be solved appears, the target case appears. The description of the target case question is utilized to retrieve a similar case in the case base to further obtain a source case similar to the target case and find a solution for solving the new question in the source case [10]; if the solution cannot solve the new case, the case should be revised to obtain a new source case capable of solving the target case, and the new source case is saved in the case base after the target case is solved successfully. In this article, the current question or condition is called the target case while the previous question or condition is called the source case. According to the “4R” model [11] proposed by foreign scholars Aamodt, Plaza, et al. [12], Fig. 2 shows the reasoning process of the aid decision making method based on case based reasoning by combining the actual condition of secondary recognition and testing (Fig. 3 ). 3 Case structure and representation of aid decision making Case base construction must follow a certain rule to form a relatively standardized structure. Generally case base construction should be favorable for case retrieval, knowledge organization, case base maintenance and management and knowledge expansion. According to relevant technical features of traffic monitoring and monitoring capture image information processing requirement, cases having a certain effect on solving of the traffic emergencies are selected from the existing traffic emergencies to form the case base. The case base structure can be shown as C = ( c 1 , c 2 , c 3 , c 4 , c 5 , c 6 , c 7 , c 8 , c 9 ) , wherein c1 is the Traffic peak, including early peak, latte peak and peak peace;c2 is the emergency type, mainly including traffic accident, traffic jam, natural disaster, mass disturbance, emergency secret service event and other relevant emergencies; c3 is the event location, mainly including four levels of expressway, trunk road, secondary main road and branch; c4 is the weather condition, generally including several typical weathers of sunny, foggy, thundery, sandstorm and snowy days; c5 is the traffic area affected by the event, mainly the road condition affected by the emergencies, including three effects of dot, line and plane according to the road area affected by the event; c6 is the casualty of the emergencies, which refers to the interval range of the casualty; c7 is the number of vehicles destroyed in the emergencies, which mainly refers to the interval range of the number of vehicles destroyed in the emergencies; c8 is the emergency aid decision making solution; c9 is the handling effect. The typical attribute characteristics of the cases in the case base are represented, as shown in Fig. 4 ; the values and attribute types of the characteristic attributes in the case base are shown as follows in Table 1. Construction of the aid decision making case base of the emergency is the key point of the whole reasoning system. The characteristic attributes contained in the case base are the necessary conditions for solving the traffic emergencies. The final effect evaluation of traffic emergency handling is performed in accordance with the handling efficiency and handling cost after implementation of the decision solution. 4 Case retrieval strategy Case retrieval is a key core problem to achieve case based reasoning. The case retrieval means to find the similar case in the case base according to the question description of the target case by utilizing the index and organization structure of the case base. Some popular retrieval methods in the CBR include the nearest neighbor method, the inductive retrieval method and the knowledge guiding method. This article adopts the nearest neighbor method to retrieve the case. This article adopts an overall and local similarity calculation integrating method. The calculation between the target case and the source case is utilized as the overall calculation while the attribute similarity calculation inside the case serves as the local calculation. There are multiple attribute types inside the case. Here the similarities of the attributes of various types are calculated separately. 4.1 Local similarity 4.1.1 Enumerated attribute similarity It's simple to calculate the enumerated attribute similarity, mainly by comparing attribute values of two cases. The similarity is 1 if the values are identical, otherwise it is 0. Assume the kth attributes of two cases C i and C j are enumerated attributes, the equation is shown as follows: (1) s i m ( C i k , C j k ) = 1 , C i k = C j k 0 , C i k ≠ C j k 4.1.2 Numerical attribute similarity The difference between the same numerical attribute of different cases reflects the distance between the two cases, with the similarity calculated as follows: (2) s i m ( C i k , C j k ) = C i k − C j k max k − min k Wherein max k and min k are the maximum and the minimum of the kth attributes in the cases. 4.1.3 Fuzzy attribute similarity The interval-type attribute can be represented by the fuzzy interval numbers. Assume the kth attribute G i k of the case C i is in the numerical interval type, G i k means the fuzzy interval number is G i k − , G i k + , wherein G i k − and G i k + are respectively the lower limiting value and the upper limiting value of the interval; similarly, the fuzzy interval number of the kth attribute G j k of the case C j is G j k − , G j k + , the similarity between the kth attributes of the cases C i and C j is calculated as follows: (3) s i m ( C i h , C j k ) = 1 - D ( C i h − C j k ) = 1 − 1 2 ( G i k − − G i k + ) 2 + ( G j k − − G j k + ) 2 Wherein: D ( C i h , C j k ) is the average Euclidean distance on the kth attributes of the cases C i and C j , and D ( C i h , C j k ) ∈ 0 , 1 4.2 Overall similarity After calculation of the similarity of the case attributes, the similarity between the cases and the overall similarity can be calculated. Suppose the case has h characteristic attributes, because the attributes contribute to the overall similarity of the case in different degrees, the similarity between the two cases is: (4) s i m ( C i , C j ) = ∑ k = 1 h q i ( C i k , C j k ) Wherein: q i is the weight of the ith attribute of the case, and ∑ k = 1 h q i  = 1. 5 Example analysis Take one city as an example, take a captured traffic accident of the traffic monitoring system as an example, suppose the traffic accident to be the target case K, its case index attribute values are as follows: K= {Latte peak, Traffic accident, expressway, foggy, plane, [1–3], [2,3]}, The appropriate emergency solution is obtained by CBR. First select 10 past emergencies happening on the road section with the given threshold of 0.9, the case base structure can be represented as C = ( c 1 , c 2 , c 3 , c 4 , c 5 , c 6 , c 7 , c 8 , c 9 ) , and the generated case base is shown as Table 2 . The case similarity is calculated in the following steps: A Determine the weights of the characteristic attributes. Due to the fact that the emergency cases have diversified attributes with different importance, and the attributes should be provided with the weight coefficients according to the importance. The article adopts the analytic hierarchy process (APH) [15] to determine the weights of the attributes [13,14]: ① Build a 3-hierarchy analytic hierarchy model of a target hierarchy, a criterion hierarchy and a project hierarchy. The target hierarchy describes the emergency describing demand; the criterion hierarchy tests the emergency case selection standard and requirements correspondingly, mainly including the testing demand index attribute content in the case frame; the project hierarchy corresponds to the emergency case set provided by the case base. ② Determine the weight of the criterion relative to the target by comparing the index attributes in the criterion hierarchy [16], i.e. to build the case attribute judgment matrix; then calculate the judgment matrix maximum characteristic value and its corresponding characteristic vector, and utilize the consistency index to perform consistency test on the judgment matrix. If the test is passed, the characteristic vector subject to normalization processing is the weight set of the corresponding attributes. See Table 3 for the weights: B Calculate the local similarity [17,18], i.e. the similarity of the index attributes between the cases, and calculate the similarity of the attributes respectively according to the Eqs. (1)–(Fig. 3). C After acquiring the local similarity, calculate the similarity between the target case K and the source cases according to the Eq. (4). The calculation results are shown as Table 4 : From Table 4, the case 9 in the case base has the highest similarity with the target case among all the calculation results, with the similarity exceeding the given threshold 0.8, indicating that the target case K is most similar to the source case 9. Therefore, the emergency handling scheme 10 in the source case 9 can be used to handle the current emergency (traffic accident). In case the handling scheme is unsatisfactory, the case 9 can be revised according to the actual condition till reaching a satisfactory handling effect. 6 Conclusion Based on the traffic information captured by the urban traffic monitoring system, the road traffic emergencies were analyzed and handled. First, the article built the system framework of the traffic monitoring system and proposed the traffic aid decision making method based on CBR. Second, the article built the traffic emergency case base to analyze the target case and source cases in the case base and adopted the overall-local characteristic attribute similarity calculating method to calculate the similarity between the cases reasonably. Finally, the cases indicate that by using CBR to calculate similarity between cases with similarity comparison for traffic congestion management, a solution to the problem of traffic congestion could be found. Meanwhile, by adjusting and correcting the successful cases, it improves the speed of reasoning solution and satisfies the real-time requirements of traffic congestion management to solve the traffic dispersion problem with certain guiding significance. Acknowledgements This work was supported by funds from Universities Key Fund of Natural Science Research. Universites Key Project of Anhui Province of China under Grant KJ2017A466. Anhui Province for Young Talentts of Chiina under Grant GXYQ2017079. Tongling science and technology plan project under Grant 2017NS76.

column2: Focusing light through scattering media using the harmony search algorithm for phase optimization of wavefront shaping
column3: Abstract Utilizing the wavefront shaping technique to focus light through a scattering medium is a newly emerging field and has shown great potential for various applications. A critical task in this field is identifying a fast, robust algorithm for wavefront shaping. In this work, we introduce a simple-structure algorithm, the harmony search (HS) algorithm, for use in the phase optimization of wavefront shaping. We experimentally demonstrate that HS converges faster than the continuous sequential algorithm (CSA) and reaches a higher overall enhancement. In addition, we establish a simulation model based on random matrix theory. The numerical simulation results agree well with the experimental results and show that the HS algorithm is more resistant than the CSA to noise and sample decoherence.
column5: Keywords Scattering material Wavefront shaping Harmony search algorithm 1 Introduction When light propagates through scattering materials, such as paper and biological tissue, it is scattered by sub-wavelength particles in all directions and forms a random speckle pattern. Multiple scattering events make these materials opaque; as a result, focusing or imaging through a scattering medium was once thought to be impossible. However, in 2007, Vellekoop and Mosk [1] experimentally demonstrated that instead of scattering into a random speckle pattern, coherent light can be focused into a sharp, intense point through scattering materials by using a spatial light modulator (SLM) to compensate the phase distortion of the incident wavefront. Since then, this method, which is called the wavefront shaping technique, has drawn a tremendous amount of interest, and numerous potential applications have been demonstrated in various areas, including light polarization control [2,3], optical trapping [4], super-resolution imaging [5,6], fluorescence imaging [7], and deep tissue microscopy [8,9]. For the wavefront shaping technique, finding a fast, robust optimization algorithm that can compensate for the phase distortion of the incident wavefront is critical. Two basic approaches are currently being adopted in the research of optimizing the phase of the incident wavefront: the transmission matrix (TM) approach and the iterative optimization (IA) approach. The TM approach directly measures the transmission matrix of the scattering medium through an interference method and calculates the phase pattern applied to the modulator using the obtained TM [10]. The IA approach achieves focusing by adjusting the input wavefront according to the feedback signal from the intended point in the output plane [11,12]. The TM approach updates the phase pattern only when all measurements are completed, while the IA approach adjusts the phase pattern during each measurement. Therefore, one of the greatest strengths of IA is its good performance under noisy and decoherence environments, which is important to realizing real-time dynamic focusing and imaging. Thus, several reports have been published that identify a fast, robust phase optimization algorithm for IA, including the continuous sequential algorithm (CSA) [11], the stepwise sequential algorithm [11], the partitioning algorithm [11], and the genetic algorithm (GA) [12]. Among these algorithms, CSA and GA are two best-performing and widely used algorithms. As the CSA independently optimizes each input mode, it has a simple structure; however, the enhancement approaches the theoretical maximum more slowly than that of GA and is more sensitive to environmental noise and sample vibrations. In contrast, GA converges faster and performs better, especially in noisy and vibrating environments; however, it suffers from a complex structure. To obtain a faster, more robust algorithm with a simple computation and structure, we propose a harmony search (HS) algorithm to optimize the phase of the wavefront because HS is easy to implement and has been demonstrated to handle optimization problems with a small number of candidates [13]. In this paper, we first describe the operation of the HS algorithm for phase optimization in detail. Then, phase optimization experiments are employed to compare the overall enhancement and convergence speed of HS and CSA. Finally, we build a simulation model to quantitatively study the resistance of the two algorithms to noise and decoherence. 2 Harmony search algorithms applied to phase mask optimization Inspired by harmony improvisation, the HS algorithm was first proposed by Geem [14,15] to solve the optimization problem of water distribution networks. Since then, HS has been widely applied to various optimization problems, including transportation, manufacturing, robotics, and medical science. Fig. 1 depicts the flow chart of the HS algorithm for phase optimization of wavefront shaping. First, we generate an n-dimensional HS memory (HM), which is represented as follows: (1) H M = φ 1 1 , φ 2 1 , ... , φ n 1 φ 1 2 , φ 2 2 , ... , φ n 2 ... φ 1 H M S , φ 2 H M S , ... , φ n H M S where φ 1 i , φ 2 i , ... , φ n i ( i = 1 , 2 , ... , H M S ) is a phase mask applied to the SLM, n is the number of the controlled segments of the SLM, and HMS is the size of the HM. The algorithm updates the HM using the signal-to-background ratio (SBR) of the intended area in a camera as feedback. In each generation, the HS generates a new phase mask in three ways: harmony memory usage, random search and pitch adjustment. Harmony memory usage involves randomly selecting a solution in the HM with a probability equal to the harmony memory considering rate (HMCR) and with a probability equal to 1-HMCR, the random search creates a new random solution. After selecting the solution, the HS algorithm adjusts the pitch according to Eq. (2), adjusting the variable with a probability equal to pitch adjusting rate (PAR). (2) φ n e w = φ o l d + B W * ( 2 r a n d − 1 ) where rand is a number from the uniform pseudorandom distribution from 0 to 1, and BW is the bandwidth of the adjustment. We use the variables HMCR, BW and PAR, which change dynamically with generation numbers: (3) H M C R ( g e n e r a t i o n ) = H M C R min + H M C R max − H M C R min N I * g e n e r a t i o n (4) P A R ( g e n e r a t i o n ) = P A R max exp ln P A R min / P A R max N I * g e n e r a t i o n (5) B W ( g e n e r a t i o n ) = B W max exp ln ( b w min / b w max ) N I * g e n e r a t i o n where NI is the total number of iterative procedures, and generation is the generation number. HMCR takes a linear form, and PAR and BW change into exponential forms [16]. In the early generations, BW and PAR are large, and HMCR is small to force the HS algorithm to increase the diversity of the solutions, whereas in the final generations, smaller BW and PAR and a larger HMCR enable the algorithm to converge to the optimal solution. 3 Scattering model As light transport through scattering media is a linear system, it can be described using a transmission matrix model: (6) E m = ∑ n t m n E n where n is the mode of the incident field E n , m is the index of the transmitted field E m , and t m n is the transmission matrix element of the scattering media and follows the circular Gaussian random distribution. To acquire the transmission properties of the TM, we apply the singular value decomposition (SVD) to the TM: (7) T = U Σ V ∗ where * denotes the transpose conjugate, and U and V are unitary matrices. U links the transmission channel output modes with the output free modes, and V links the input free modes with the transmission channel input modes. Σ is a diagonal matrix with positive values, the squares of which are called the transmission eigenvalues. The density of the transmission eigenvalues determines the possibility waves transmitting through multiple scattering media for each input mode. In theory, the TM follows a bimodal distribution; however, in experiments, because of the incomplete channel control, it follows a Marchenko-Pastur distribution [17]. (8) ρ λ ˜ = γ 2 π λ ˜ λ ˜ 2 − λ ˜ min 2 λ ˜ max 2 − λ ˜ 2 ∀ λ ˜ ∈ λ ˜ min , λ ˜ max where γ is the input/output asymmetric ratio M / N , λ ˜ min = 1 − 1 / γ is the smallest singular value, and λ ˜ max = 1 + 1 / γ is the maximum singular value. 4 Experimental results The HS algorithm was tested using the experimental setup depicted in Fig. 2 . A linearly polarized light (5 mW, 632.8 nm He-Ne laser), whose polarization direction was in accordance with the phase-only modulation orientation of the SLM (Holoeye PLUTO VIS), was expanded by a 10× beam expander (L1 and L2) and then spatially modulated by the SLM with phase-only modulation. Next, the shaped beam was focused onto the scattering sample (a ground glass diffuser) using lens L3 with a focal length of 45 mm. A 40× objective with a numerical aperture (NA) of 0.65 collected the transmitted light through the ground glass diffuser and imaged the scattering pattern onto an 8-bit charge-coupled device (CCD) camera (ImageSource DMK-21BU04) with a 200 mm focal length lens (L4). The SBR of the intensity of the centre of the CCD was used to provide a feedback signal to the optimization algorithm. By grouping sets of pixels together, the SLM was divided into a variable number of square segments, N. Fig. 3 (a)–(c) show pictures captured with the CCD camera before HS optimization, after HS optimization with N = 256, and after HS optimization with N = 1024, respectively. Before HS optimization, the transmitted intensity pattern on the CCD camera shows a random speckle pattern. After HS optimizations, the transmitted intensity patterns are dominated by a bright spot at the target point, and optimization with 1024 segments shows a brighter focus than optimization with 256 segments. These results demonstrate that HS can effectively focus light through the scattering sample. The modulation pictures projected onto the SLM for Fig. 3(b) and (c) are depicted in (d) and (e), respectively. Unlike the CSA algorithm, which has discrete phase choices for only one mode (in this case, we chose 8 phase steps), HS expands the phase search scope because the SLM can display grey levels ranging from 0 to 255. To test the performance of the proposed HS algorithm, experiments for focusing through scattering media were performed with control segments on the SLMs with 256 and 1024 segments. Fig. 4 compares the performance of the HS algorithm with that of the CSA algorithm. Each curve is averaged over five runs. To better compare the two algorithms, the number of iterations for HS was set to be 8 × N, which is equivalent to the number of phase mask measurements for the CSA. The enhancement is defined as the ratio between the SBRs before and after phase optimization. As shown in Fig. 4, the HS algorithm converged faster than the CSA and reached a higher overall enhancement when the incident wavefront was divided into 256 (Fig. 4(a)) and 1024 (Fig. 4(b)) controlling modes. To reach the same enhancement as CSA, HS required 600 generations, which was 23% of that for CSA under N = 256 circumstances. For N = 1024, HS converges even faster, requiring only 14% of the measurements required by CSA to reach the same enhancement as that of CSA. Furthermore, HS reached a 1.75 times (N = 256) and 3 times (N = 1024) higher overall enhancement than CSA. Thus, the HS algorithm converged faster and obtained a higher overall enhancement than the CSA algorithm for this experimental configuration, especially when the segments became larger. 5 Simulations To quantitatively analyse the effects of noise and decoherence on the performance and effectiveness of the HS and CSA algorithms, we develop a simulation model based on transmission matrix theory. We first generate a random matrix following a circular Gaussian distribution and then reconstruct the eigenvalues to obey the Marchenko-Pastur law. Next, measurement noise is simulated by adding a Gaussian random value to the simulated detector signal. Finally, sample decoherence is included by repeatedly adding a small perturbation, which follows a complex Gaussian distribution with a mean of 0 and a standard deviation δ to each of the matrix elements. The results of the simulations for the HS algorithm are shown in Fig. 5 . Similar to the experimental results, before HS optimization, the output field (Fig. 5(a)) shows a random pattern. After HS optimization, the intended point of the output field (Fig. 5(b–c)) shows a clear spot, and the enhancement increases with the increasing number of segments. To validate the effectiveness of the simulation model, the simulation results of HS and CSA under a given experimental noise level are compared in Fig. 6 . We set the signal-to-noise ratio (SNR) of the measurement noise to 10 dB, which approximates the SNR during the optical experimental measurements. The figure reveals that the simulation results agree well with the experimental results. The HS optimization converges faster and reaches a larger overall enhancement than the CSA optimization. Because the simulations capture the overall behaviour of the algorithms very well, we can use them to estimate cases with considerable noise and strong decoherence. Fig. 7 shows the simulated enhancements versus measurement noise levels for both algorithms. According to the figure, except for the low-noise condition (SNR > 22 dB), HS clearly performs better than the CSA; even when the CSA loses effectiveness, HS still has an enhancement of 77.3 (HMS = 30) and 31.5 (HMS = 5) when the SNR is 0 dB. In addition, we computed the searching ability for different values of HMS. HMS with values of 5 and 30 are presented with a black dashed line and circle markers and a blue dashed line and square markers, respectively. Fig. 7 shows that a larger HMS performs better under high-noise conditions, whereas a smaller HMS exhibits a higher enhancement under low-noise conditions. The parameter values used in various simulations and experiments are presented in Table 1 . Fig. 8 shows the simulated enhancements of the algorithms under different decoherence conditions on a logarithmic scale. The persistence time T p is defined as T p = T i / δ 2 , where T i is the iteration measurement time [11]. In Fig. 8, the enhancement clearly decreases for both algorithms with the decreasing persistence time T p . The CSA algorithm performs well when the persistence time is long, but as the persistence time decreases, the enhancement quickly drops to zero. Although the HS algorithm leads to a relatively smaller enhancement than CSA when T p is large, it loses efficiency slowly and achieves an enhancement of 65.4, whereas CSA generates an enhancement of 4.2 and loses efficiency. 6 Conclusion In conclusion, we proposed the HS algorithm for the phase optimization of wavefront shaping, and we experimentally and numerically evaluated the performance and effectiveness of the algorithm. We experimentally demonstrated that the HS algorithm achieved focusing through scattering materials faster and generated a higher overall enhancement than the CSA algorithm at a SNR of 10. We also established a simulation model to evaluate the resistance of the algorithms to noise and decoherence. The simulation results indicated that HS achieves faster convergence speed and better enhancement than CSA, especially in high-noise environments and fluctuating circumstances. With its simple structure, the HS algorithm achieves a larger enhancement, faster convergence and stronger robustness than the CSA algorithm, indicating its promise for controlling light through scattering materials. Funding This research did not receive any specific grant from funding agencies in the public, commercial, or not-for-profit sectors.

column2: Design of intelligent LED lighting systems based on STC89C52 microcomputer
column3: Abstract In this paper, a kind of intelligent LED lighting system was designed, and intelligent processing and control technology were obtained based on STC89C52 MCU minimum system, which combining with the LED lighting technology, infrared sensing technology, photoelectric detection technology. The system can intelligently test the design of LED lighting system, realize the intensity of light control, infrared detection and the measurement of light intensity, reflecting the intelligence and humanity of LED lights, and further to achieve energy-saving green lighting.
column5: Keywords Single chip microcomputer LED Intelligent lighting Sensor Photoelectric detection 1 Introduction LED is the fourth generation of green lighting light source, has been widely used in all aspects of social life due to its low energy consumption, high photosynthetic efficiency, no pollution, long service life etc. [1–3]. With the development of science and technology, the people’s demand for lighting is continuously improved. The lighting not only could provide a comfortable environment brightness, but also build elegant and comfortable atmosphere. At present, as for indoor lighting, the application of LED intelligent lighting system is still in the exploratory stage and in the exploratory stage. The reason is that is the lighting technology and application cost. Therefore, it is very necessary to develop a set of feasible low-cost lighting management system solving the current urgent need of the defaults in lighting system, which s also a critical issue in the field of current lighting control [4–6]. The aim of this work is to design a kind of intelligent LED lighting system based on STC89C52 MCU minimum system, which combining with the LED lighting technology, infrared sensing technology [7], photoelectric detection technology [8] and intelligent control technology [9] et al. The system can realize intelligent control on the brightness of the lamp, not only for daily lighting needs, and but also have played an important role in saving energy. 2 The system hardware design The system design is based on single chip microcomputer minimum system, mainly including human pyroelectric infrared sensing, optical sensing, key presses, display module, so as to realize the adjusting the brightness of the light automatically, as shown in Fig. 1 . 2.1 Minimum MCU system The minimum MCU system includes crystal vibration circuit and reset circuit, its principle diagram is shown in Fig. 2 . The internal clock pulse signal was produced by a 12 MHZ crystal vibration and two 30 pf ceramics external clock oscillation circuit of capacitance picked up in XTAL1 (19 feet) and XTAL2 (20 feet) of MCU by STC89C52 chip. The typical values of 12 MHz or 11.0592 MHz were allowed in STC89C52 chip and 12MHz was used in this system. When the system falls into a dead loop in the execution of a program, the MCU may use the reset button at this time and let the internal procedure from the beginning. In this work, the manual reset and power on reset was combined. Usually a reset button was added between RST (9 feet) and power supply VCC, two ends of reset button was parallel connection with a 10 uf electrolytic capacitors, the parallel series after a 10 k resistor and connect to the ground, so as to form a reset circuit. 2.2 Pyroelectric infrared sensor module The HC - SR501 body heat release electric induction module was used to design infrared sensor module because of its high sensitivity and reliability. If someone appear in the sensing area, the signal output level, clockwise adjust potentiometer of delay time, the delay time, when people leave the induction area, intelligent lighting system will delay setting time, the intelligent lighting system will automatically shut down. 2.3 Light intensity sensor module BH1750FVI chip was adopted in light intensity sensor module, which can realize detection 1 l x - 65535 l x range of light intensity, according to different light environment to adjust the brightness of the lighting system and achieve the right lighting environment. BH1750FVI have two feet to received a single chip microcomputer, and through a 10 k resistor connected to the power supply, including SCL (4 feet) received the MCU clock end P1.6 port, used to pull up, pull down the clock line to the data SDA (3 feet) from MCU P1.7 port, used to send data, read data, the wiring diagram is shown in Fig. 3 . 2.4 LED lighting module 40 mA and 0.2 W LED light was adopted in the lighting module. In order to adjust the brightness of the light to achieve energy saving, PWM wave was used to change the current for so that the brightness of the LED lights change. Fig. 4 shows the LED control circuit diagram. From Fig. 4, the output of dimming signal could be realized by the connection between the end of light and P1.1 port of MCU. With the change of the duty cycle, the current also changed, and the different brightness display of light can be obtained, eventually achieve the result of dimming. 3 The system software design The master control module can be displayed on the LCD by measuring the light intensity operated by the metering module. If the button is pressed, LCD display the intelligent mode, on the contrary, for manual mode. The human induction module can induction someone, when someone, the light whether need turned on according to the light of the state. On the state of light, automatic adjusting light can be realized in automatic mode and manul adjusting light can be realized by key module in manual mode. The light turn off when in the condition of no one. Fig. 5 shows the main module flow chart. 3.1 Interrupt program Fig. 6 shows the flow chart of time 0. The PWM was produced by timer 0 and so as to light automatically adjusting according to the outside world based on smart mode. Fig. 7 shows the flow chart of time 1. Time 1 is used in a state of turning on the light. When people go and start counting and delay 10s automatically turn off the lights. 3.2 Liquid crystal display (LCD) module The LCD module can display four lines of numbers, The light intensity, whether to detect people, the lamp working mode and working condition were displayed from the first to fourth lines, respectively. The flow chart of LCD was shown in Fig. 8 . 3.3 Dimming module Intelligent lamp is divided into intelligent dimming and manual dimming lights under turning on the light and is divided into 4 stalls, representing different brightness. Fig. 9 shows the flow chart of intelligent mode. The automatic dimming can be realized according to the change of light intensity under the intelligent model. The brightness of the lamp will automatically change the corresponding gear brightness when the light intensity in the corresponding test set intensity range. Fig. 10 shows the flow chart of manual mode.When the key K2 was pressed, the mode is manual. And the dimming can be manually adjusted according to the needs. The key K3 is turn on or off the lights. The key K4 is increased brightness. The key K5 is brightness decreases. 4 Results and discussion The run results of intelligent lighting system can be displayed on LCD, and the first line of LCD shows the light intensity data collected, the second line of LCD shows whether the induction the people, the third line of LCD shows the current intelligent lamp working mode and lamp selection of gear, the fourth line of LCD shows intelligent lamp working condition. The debugging results are as follows: • The working mode is intelligent mode in someone state and the light intensity collected is 275 lx. The light is not bright whether induction area someone at this moment because the light intensity collected is more than 100 lx. The light would not work whether light intensity sensor data changes under no one condition. • At the time of strong light, the light would not work whether the human pyroelectric infrared sensor module in some people or no state. In weak light, the light would also not work when human pyroelectric infrared sensor could not induction the people, and only if someone is detected, the lamp will work and light dimmer automatically according to the outside world, thus realized the function of intelligent lamp, reduces the waste of electric power. 5 Conclusions For some public relations situation, a kind of intelligent lighting system was designed in this paper. The system can collect the light intensity through the human thermal release electron induction module and determine whether to turn on the light according to the need. The design of intelligent lighting system has advantage of easy installation, high sensitivity, strong anti-jamming capability, long service life, stable light evenly, and also automatically and manually adjustable light, which are help for achieving the best lighting effect, realizing the intelligent control of light and reducing the energy waste. Acknowledgments The authors would like to thank the funding support from the Natural Science Foundation of Jiangsu Province (Grants No. BK20150247), Six Talent Peaks Project in Jiangsu Province (No. 2017-XNY-015) and the Prospective Joint Program of Jiangsu Province (grant numbers BY2016030-07).

column2: Effect of q-parameter on relativistic self-focusing of q-Gaussian laser beam in plasma
column3: Abstract The exponential function in an expression of intensity profile of Gaussian laser beam has been replaced by algebraic function having q exponent in it. In preliminary theoretical investigations, it has been observed that q -Gaussian intensity distribution function plays vital role in the dynamics of laser beam propagating in relativistic plasma. In present theoretical investigation, the usual parabolic equation approach under paraxial and WKB approximations has been adopted, taking into account relativistic nonlinearity. We have established the nonlinear differential equation for the beam-width parameter f and solved it numerically by using fourth order Runge-Kutta method. The effect of q parameter on the variation of beam width parameter f with normalized distance of propagation ξ has been presented graphically and discussed.
column5: Keywords q-Gaussian Relativistic Self-focusing Plasma 1 Introduction In the interaction of ultra-high intensity laser beams with plasmas, the phenomenon of self-focusing of laser beams occupies a unique place due to its relevance to potential applications such as fast-ignition schemes for inertial confinement thermonuclear fusion [1], laser electron acceleration [2,3], x-ray sources [4], harmonic generation [5,6] etc. In all these applications, it is enviable that the high intensity laser beam should propagate in controlled manner while keeping its efficient interaction over a long distance with plasma. As such, propagation of laser beams through plasmas up to several Rayleigh lengths is an essential prerequisite for the feasibility of all these applications. Therefore, there have been ongoing efforts to explore the methods or processes that may support to increase the efficiency of laser-plasma coupling. Laser–plasma interaction is perennially burdened with copious nonlinear effects. This spans the gamut to many self-action effects such as self-focusing [7]. When an intense laser beam is shone into a plasma, it changes its dielectric properties. The subsequent variation of the light’s velocity across the beam’s wave front causes them to bend into medium, causing self-focusing of the laser beam [8]. The phenomenon of self-focusing is such a nonlinear optical self-action effect that averts the diffraction broadening of the laser beam. In the interaction of high power of the beams with plasmas, the quiver velocity of plasma electrons becomes comparable to that of light in the free space. This causes significant increase in the mass of plasma electrons that in turn alters the dielectric function of plasma. This is one of the typical mechanisms, which is generally known as relativistic-self-focusing of laser beams. Such type of nonlinearity sets in periods of the order of ω p − 1 , where ω p is the plasma frequency. In recent years, the field of laser-plasma interaction in the relativistic regime has been identified as a promising area of research. In this emerging era, phenomenon of self-focusing occupies a unique position due to its relevance to all other phenomena in the field of laser-plasma interaction. Hora [9] described the detailed mechanism of self-focusing of laser beam that occurs in a homogeneous plasma. It is based solely on the relativistic dependence of the optical constants on laser irradiance. Hauser et al. [10] have presented the analytical calculation of relativistic self-focusing length of intense laser beam propagating into a plasma under WKB approximation. Relativistic self-focusing of laser beams of arbitrary intensity in plasmas has been employed by Asthana et al. [11]. Feit et al. [12] have presented the description of relativistic self-focusing of laser beam in underdense plasma. They have emphasized the importance of electron cavitation in suppression of the possibility of channel power well above the critical power of self-focusing for a distance of many Rayleigh lengths. Gupta et al. [13] have presented the relativistic effect on stimulated Raman scattering of a laser in plasma. Plasma density ramp for relativistic self-focusing of laser has been elaborated by Gupta et al. [14]. Dynamics of Gaussian spikes on Gaussian laser beam in relativistic plasma has been described by Singh et al. [15]. Patil et al. [16] have explored the ponderomotive and weakly relativistic self-focusing in the interaction of Gaussian laser beam in plasma. Gupta et al. [17] have explored the laser pulse distortion in a plasma of the weakly relativistic regime. Patil et al. [18] studied the effect of light absorption on relativistic self-focusing of Gaussian laser beam in plasma. In current studies [19–24], it has been observed that quantum effects in plasmas can significantly enhance relativistic self-focusing in comparison to the classical relativistic case of reference. A review of literature highlights the fact that most of above-mentioned studies have been carried out by considering fundamental Gaussian irradiance distribution along the wavefront of the beam. Nevertheless, few studies have been done on relativistic self-focusing of super-Gaussian beams [25], hollow-Gaussian beams [26], cosh-Gaussian beams [27], Hermite-Gaussian beams [28], Hermite-cosh-Gaussian beams [29], quadruple Gaussian beams [30] etc. Apart from these, a great interest has recently been evinced on optical beams suggesting a long-tailed beam profile, usually known as q - Gaussian beam. It is interesting to note that the intensity profile of the Vulcan petawatt laser has been found to be deviating from Gaussian intensity distribution [31]. The suggested intensity profile of such distribution that gives justice to the experimental data observed in laboratory has q Gaussian distribution. One must note that for a given power of laser beam, the average square of electric vector in the wavefront is much higher in case of q Gaussian irradiance profile as compared to Gaussian irradiance. Sharma and Kourakis [32] pointed out the narrowing nature of beam for higher q values. Singh and Gupta highlighted the significance of the interaction of q Gaussian laser beams with plasmas for second harmonic generation [33]. In present paper we have studied relativistic self-focusing effect of q-Gaussian laser beam in plasma by adopting usual parabolic equation approach under the paraxial and WKB approximations. In Section 2, intensity distribution of input q Gaussian laser beam and relativistic dielectric function of plasma is presented. The second order nonlinear differential equation governing the propagation dynamics of the laser beam in plasma is obtained in Section 3. The discussion of results is presented in Section 4 and finally a brief conclusion is added in Section 5. 2 Theoretical considerations The intensity distribution of the q Gaussian laser beam along its wavefront at the plane of incidence ( z = 0 ) is given by [29] (1) E E ∗ = E 0 2 1 + r 2 q r 0 2 − q where E 0 is the axial amplitude of the laser beam at z = 0 , r 0 is the initial spot size of the laser beam, and q is a parameter associated with deviation of intensity profile of laser beam from Gaussian distribution. Fig. 1 illustrates the normalized intensity profile of the laser beam for different values of q . Note that small values of q are characterized by a long tail, while as q increases towards higher values, the distribution becomes Gaussian for q → ∞ , i.e., (2) lim q → ∞ E E ∗ = E 0 2 exp − r 2 r 0 2 When such high intensity q Gaussian laser beams propagate through plasmas, the effect of transverse quiver motion of plasma electrons changes and the electron mass is modified by the relativistic effects, which eventually affects the expression for plasma dielectric function which can be written as (3) ε = 1 − Ω 2 γ where Ω = ω p / ω , γ = 1 + α E E ∗ 1 / 2 is the Lorentz relativistic factor with α = e 2 / m 0 2 ω 2 c 2 as coefficient of relativistic nonlinearity. Here, e and m 0 are the charge and rest mass of electron; respectively, ω is the frequency of laser beam and c is the speed of light in free space. One can formally express the dielectric function of plasma as [8] (4) ε = ε 0 + φ E E ∗ where ε 0 and φ are linear and nonlinear parts of dielectric function respectively. 3 Propagation dynamics of laser beam The wave equation governing the electric field E of the beam in plasmas with the dielectric function given by Eq. (4) can be written as (5) ∇ 2 E − ∇ ∇ ⋅ E + ω 2 c 2 ε E = 0 Even if E has longitudinal components, the polarization terms ∇ ∇ ⋅ E of Eq. (5) can be neglected; provided ( c 2 / ω 2 ) | ( 1 / ε ) ∇ 2 ln ε | < < 1 . Introducing E = A ( r , z ) exp ( − i k 0 z ) in Eq. (5), the behavior of complex amplitude A ( r , z ) A r , z is can be described by the parabolic equation in the WKB approximation as (6) 2 i k 0 ∂ A ∂ z + ∇ ⊥ 2 A + ω 2 c 2 φ E E ∗ A = 0 In the absence of any spikes, one can express (7) A = A 0 ( r , z ) exp ( − i k 0 S ) A = A 0 r , z e x p - i k S , ( 10 ) where A 0 and S are real functions of r and z ( S being the eikonal of the beam). Substituting for A in Eq. (6) and separating real and imaginary parts, we obtain (8) 2 ∂ S ∂ z + ∂ S ∂ r 2 = 1 k 0 2 A 0 ∇ ⊥ 2 A 0 + ω p 2 ω 2 ε 0 1 − 1 + α E E ∗ − 1 / 2 (9) ∂ A 0 2 ∂ z + ∂ A 0 2 ∂ r ∂ S ∂ r + A 0 2 ∂ 2 S ∂ r 2 + 1 r ∂ S ∂ r = 0 Following the paraxial approach given by Akhmanov et al. [7], and extended by Sodha et al. [8], solutions of Eqs. (8) and (9) for q Gaussian laser beam propagating along z axis is given by (10) S = r 2 2 f d f d z + ψ z (11) A 0 2 = E 0 2 f 2 1 + r 2 q r 0 2 f 2 − q where ψ z is the axial phase and the function f = f z is known as dimensionless beam-width parameter governed by following differential equation (12) d 2 f d ξ 2 = 4 + q q f 3 − ρ 0 2 Ω 2 P 0 2 f 3 1 + P 0 f 2 − 3 2 where ρ 0 = r 0 ω / c is the normalized equilibrium beam radius, ξ = z / R d η = z / k r 0 2 is the dimensionless distance of propagation with R d = k 0 r 0 2 as the Rayleigh length, P 0 = α E 0 2 is the initial intensity parameter. Eq. (12) can be solved numerically with appropriate boundary conditions. For an initially plane wavefront at ξ = 0 , f = 1 and d f / d ξ = 0. 4 Results and discussion Eq. (12) is the second-order, nonlinear, ordinary differential equation governing the behaviour of beam-width parameter f as a function of dimensionless distance of propagation ξ . It is to be noted that at q → ∞ , Eq. (12) reduces to f parameter differential equation for relativistic self-focusing of Gaussian laser beam in plasma as obtained earlier [15,18]. Since the analytical solution of Eq. (12) is not possible, we have solved this equation numerically by using Runge-Kutta fourth order method for following laser-plasma parameters; n 0 = 10 18 c m − 3 , λ = 1.06 μ m , r 0 = 20 μ m , Ω = 0.03 − 0.06 , P 0 = 1.00 − 1.30 , q = 1 , 2 , 3 , 4 , ∞ . The first term on the right-hand side of Eq. (12) is the diffraction term that appears due to the Laplacian ∇ ⊥ 2 in Eq. (6), while second term is the nonlinear term arises due to the relativistic nonlinearity. The diffraction term leads to the divergence (defocusing), while nonlinear term is responsible for convergence (focusing) of the laser beam propagating through plasma. If the magnitude of first term on right-hand side of Eq. (12) is such that d 2 f / d ξ 2 > 0 , then the beam undergoes divergence due to predominance of diffraction effect. In contrast, if the two terms are such that d 2 f / d ξ 2 < 0 , the beam undergo self-focusing. For d 2 f / d ξ 2 = 0 , the first term on right-hand side is cancelled by second term and the beam propagates with uniform waveguide / self-trapped mode. This condition is known as critical condition obtained from Eq. (12) as (13) ρ 0 2 = 2 1 + 4 / q 1 + P 0 Ω 2 P 0 3 / 2 It is to be noted that at infinite q values, one can recover the expression for critical curve derived earlier [29] for Gaussian beam under relativistic self-focusing. Fig. 2 is known as critical curve. It highlights the dependence of normalized equilibrium beam radius ρ 0 as a function of intensity parameter P 0 according to Eq. (13). It is observed that for a particular value of q parameter, ρ 0 decreases rapidly with increase in P 0 . With a further increase in P 0 , the change in ρ 0 is slightly insignificant. It is further noticed that minimum value of ρ 0 is lowest in case of Gaussian beam and with increase in q parameter, curves recovers the critical curve of Gaussian beam for q → ∞ . Thus larger spot-sized beams with lower q values can be relativistically propagated through plasma in comparison with smaller spot-sized Gaussian beam. Fig. 3 describes the variation of dimensionless beam-width parameter f with normalized distance of propagation ξ for Ω = 0.03 , P 0 = 1.00 and different q values q = 1 , 2 , 3 , 4 , ∞ . It is observed from this figure that for above mentioned parameters, steady and oscillatory defocusing is respectively observed for q = 1 and q = 2 , while oscillatory self-focusing of f is observed for q > 2 . From this figure it is also observed that as q value increases, minimum of oscillations decreases, whereas maximum remains same and is equal to unity. As obvious, with increase in value of q , reduction in focusing length has been observed and finally for q tending towards infinity, beam recovers the stationary oscillatory self-focusing trend of f for Gaussian beam propagation in plasma. This is due to faster self-focusing of axial rays as compared to that of off-axial rays. Fig. 4 depicts the dependence of f on ξ with q = 3 for four values of normalized plasma density parameter Ω Ω = 0.03 , 0.04 , 0.05 , 0.06 and above mentioned set of parameters. From this figure it is evident that with increase in plasma density parameter, enhanced self-focusing is observed with subsequent reduction is self-focusing length as reported [15] earlier for Gaussian beam propagation in plasma. Fig. 5 describes the variation of f against ξ with q = 3 for four values of initial intensity parameter P 0 P 0 = 1.00 , 1.10 , 1.20 , 1.30 . Rest of the laser-plasma parameters are kept same as mentioned earlier. It is obvious that with increase in intensity of the laser beam, stronger self-focusing has been observed. In this case also, slight reduction in self-focusing length with distance of propagation is observed with increase in P 0 values. Similar results were also reported [15] earlier for Gaussian laser beam. 5 Conclusion In conclusion, we have explored the evolution of q -Gaussian laser beams propagating through a relativistic plasma. The equation for beam-width parameter is derived by using parabolic equation approach under paraxial and WKB approximations. Following important conclusions are drawn from present analysis: • q -Gaussian beams can be analyzed like Gaussian beam in plasma and influence of q parameter on the laser beam propagation is obvious. • Self-focusing power of q -Gaussian laser beam is lower than Gaussian beam. • Self-focusing of q -Gaussian laser beam increases with increase in plasma density parameter as well as with increase in laser intensity parameter. These results are related to various situations of laser-plasma physics. Besides its apparent relevance to inertial confinement fusion, these results can also be obliged in other applications involving laser beams with localized energy. It would be interesting to study the present analysis in extra-paraxial region of the beam which, however, to the best of our knowledge has not been presented in the literature at present.
