column2: Two-axis gimbal platform controller design in finite time application occasions: LMI approach
column3: Abstract In this paper, a controller design approach based on LMI optimization method is proposed for the two-axis gimbal platform in finite time application. This method is based on the linear parameter varying (LPV) model of the two-axis gimbal platform, considering the cross-coupling problem between the pitch and yaw channel. Firstly, the dynamic equation of the two-axis gimbal platform is analyzed and its LPV model is obtained. Then, the sufficient conditions which can ensure the LPV system is finite time bounded(FTB) are introduced, and the controller is designed accordingly. Finally, the performance of the platform with finite time controller and PI controller is analyzed qualitatively. The results show that the proposed controller can guarantee the tracking accuracy in finite time and effectively suppress the coupling interference between the pitch and yaw channel.
column5: Keywords Two-axis gimbal platform Linear parameter varying state equation Finite-time boundedness LMI 1 Introduction The payload (such as IR, laser and television) has found a wide use in many important fields, for example guided missiles, tracking systems and image processing. Two-axis gimbal platform controller is used to isolate payload from disturbances. The controller is usually implemented via two loops, the outer loop called track loop and the inner loop called line of sight (LOS) stabilization loop. The typical control architecture of the two-axis gimbal platform is shown in Fig. 1 . The track loop consists of specific sensor such as image processer and image tracker. However, in most cases, the LOS stabilization loop employs a two-axis gyro in the inner frame to sense rate disturbance. The LOS stabilization loop determines the performance of the system and is the focus of the design. However, structural defects and cross-coupling between pitch and yaw channels can deteriorate the performance of platform in the condition of the base disturbance [1,2]. Controller design is based on the kinetic model of two-axis gimbal platform, which can be obtained through the Euler rigid body dynamics [3] or Lagrange equation [4]. The configuration of the sensor, which can be divided into direct method and indirect method [5], is another problem of controller design. For most two-axis gimbal platform, direct method is a common approach. After determining the configuration of the sensor, the controller can be designed based on a variety of control methods. So far, several control schemes were introduced to the two-axis gimbal platform design. PID controller and its improved form have been widely used in the controller design [6–8]. H∞ optimization approach has been regarded as an effective and efficient multivariable robust design method. Compared with the PID controller design procedure, the design procedure of H∞ can take unmodeled dynamics into consideration and effectively handle the multi-input multi-output(MIMO) systems. H∞ control is also widely used in the two-axis gimbal platform [9–11]. Sliding mode control, which is one of the nonlinear robust control methods, has been used in the LOS stabilization loop [12,13]. This method can drive the systems states from any initial state to a user-specified surface. However, the high switching gain and switching action between the different sliding mode surfaces may lead to serious chattering problem [14]. During recent years, some intelligent control strategies, such as adaptive fractional-order sliding-mode [15], fuzzy logical [16,17] and Self-Organizing Recurrent Wavelet-Neural-Network [18] were also applied in LOS stabilization loop. Sometimes, the two-axis gimbal platform only works for a limited period of time, in which case we only examine its performance during that time period. For example, missile seeker only works in the terminal guidance stage, which begins from the seeker catching a target and ends after the missile hitting the target. This example can be described with finite time stability (FTS) theory. A system is said to be FTS if, given a bound on the initial condition, its state does not exceed a certain threshold during a specified time interval [19]. On this basis, many scholars have studied the finite time stability of various conditions, such as the FTS of continuous systems with additive time-varying delays [20] and FTS for linear discrete-time system with time-varying delay [21]. Amato [22] extended the definition of FTS to the definition of finite-time boundedness (FTB) and provided a sufficient condition guaranteeing FTB via state feedback. For finite-time control problems of linear systems subject to time-varying parametric uncertainties and exogenous disturbance, a synthesis method based on minimizing a linear objective with LMI constraints was presented in [23]. Most of these researches put forward controller based on the model of azimuth axis while the elevation angle was kept fixed, cross moments of inertia were taken to zero and the disturbance from the roll axis of the basement were neglected. When the roll angular velocity of the basement is not zero, the system dynamics and operational conditions will change. So the performance of two-axis gimbal platform with a controller based on single axis model will deteriorate under high dynamic circumstances. To improve control performance, we adopt the LPV model to design the LOS stabilization loop controller in the finite time application. Based on the sufficient condition of FTB, we can get the controller by solving the LMI feasibility problem. When an application environment is determined, we can get more targeted controllers. The outline of the paper is organized as follows. In Section 2, we establish the dynamic model of the two-axis gimbaled platform and obtained its LPV form. In Section 3, a controller design method based on FTB theory is proposed, and the corresponding parameter setting principle is established. A series of simulations validate the effectiveness of the controller in Section 4. Finally, the conclusions are highlighted in Section 5. 2 Dynamic model of a two-axis gimbal platform 2.1 Equation of motion of a two-axis gimbal platform A conventional configuration for the gimbal motion of a two-axis gimbaled platform is depicted as in Fig. 2 . Three coordinate frames are used to define the rotation about a dynamic platform, that is a body-fixed frame (B), a frame (A) fixed to the outer yaw (azimuth) gimbal and a frame (E) fixed to the inner pitch (elevation) gimbal. x a z y a z z a z and x e l y e l z e l represent the yaw and pitch gimbal frame axis, respectively. x b y b z b represent the body frame axis. LOS elevation control is exercised via the inner gimbal y-axis, while azimuth control is applied via the outer gimbal z-axis. The angular rate sensors are mounted on the LOS axes. The center of rotation is in the frame origin, which is assumed to be the same point for the three frames. ψ θ and ϕ are defined as the Euler angles which uses yaw-pitch-roll transformation order. ψ represents the relative azimuth angle between the outer and base coordinate frames. θ represents the relative elevation angle between the inner and outer coordinate frames. ϕ represents the relative angle between the inertial and base coordinate frames. The transformation matrixes can be expressed as below. (1) R z , ψ = cos ψ sin ψ 0 − sin ψ cos ψ 0 0 0 1 , R y , θ = cos θ 0 − sin θ 0 1 0 sin θ 0 cos θ , R x , ϕ = 1 0 0 0 cos ϕ sin ϕ 0 − sin ϕ cos ϕ We introduce (2) ω B = p q r , ω A = ω a x ω a y ω a z , ω E = ω e x ω e y ω e z as the angular velocity vectors of frames B, A and E, respectively. Therefore the angular velocities of the outer and inner gimbal are given by the Euler angular relationship. (3) ω A = R z , ψ ω B + 0 0 ψ ˙ T (4) ω E = R y , θ ω A + 0 θ ˙ 0 where ψ ˙ = ω a z − r and θ ˙ = ω e y − ω a y . The relationship between the angular acceleration of the inner and outer gimbal coordinate frames is obtained by differentiating (4). (5) ω ˙ E = R y , θ ω ˙ A + R ˙ y , θ ω A 0 θ ˙ 0 T + 0 θ ¨ 0 T where R ˙ y , θ = − sin θ 0 − cos θ 0 0 0 cos θ 0 − sin θ . Then ω ˙ A is given by (6) ω ˙ A = R y , θ T ω ˙ E − R y , θ T R ˙ y , θ ω A 0 θ ˙ 0 T − R y , θ T 0 θ ¨ 0 T Based on rigid body dynamics, the dynamic equation of motion for a two-axis gimbaled sensor system can be formulated as (7) J E ω ˙ E + ω E × J E ω E = T E where the sum of the kinematic torques about the elevation gimbal is (8) T E = T e x T e l M o t o r T e z − 0 T e f 0 T e x and T e z are reaction torques exerted by elevation on azimuth gimbal. T e l M o t o r is elevation stabilization control torque. T e f is friction torques. The friction torque consist of both linear and nonlinear parts, so it can be expressed as T e f = K e f θ ˙ + T e f r i c , where K e f is viscous friction coefficient, T e f r i c is nonlinear friction torques. To simplify the analysis, it is assumed that the gimbal rotation axes are aligned with the principal axes of inertia so that the inertia sub-matrices of elevation are diagonal J E = d i a g J e x x J e y y J e z z . The elevation control axis is the inner gimbal y-axis, so the inner gimbal dynamics equation can be expanded as (9) J e y y ω ˙ e y = − ω e z ω e x J e x x − J e z z + T e l M o t o r − K e f θ ˙ − T e f r i c As the disturbance stems from base rates ω B and the controlled variables are ω e y and ω e z , so substituting (3) into (4) and then into (9). Then the elevation axis dynamics can be expressed as below (10) J e y y ω ˙ e y + K e f ω e y + ω e z ω a x − sin θ ω e z cos θ J e x x − J e z z = T e l M o t o r − T e f r i c + K e f q cos θ − p sin θ In a similar manner, the torque dynamics for the azimuth gimbal body are derived from (11) J A ω ˙ A + ω A × J A ω A + R y , θ T T E = T A where T A = T a x T a y T a z M o t o r − 0 0 T a f . T a x and T a y are azimuth gimbal reaction torques on base. T a z M o t o r is azimuth stabilization control torque. T a f is the friction torque between base and azimuth gimbal. As with the inner gimbal friction torque. T a f = K a f θ ˙ + T a f r i c , where K a f is viscous friction coefficient, T a f r i c is nonlinear friction torques. Assuming the outer inertia matrix is also diagonal, J A can be expressed as J A = d i a g J a x x J a y y J a z z . Substitute the T E as (7) into (11) and the ω ˙ A as (6) into (10) to obtain (12) J A R y , θ T + R y , θ T J E ω ˙ E + ω A × J A ω A + R y , θ T ω E × J E ω E − J A R y , θ T R ˙ y , θ ω A 0 θ ˙ 0 T − J A R y , θ T 0 θ ¨ 0 T = T A The azimuth axis dynamics are generated by the third element of vector (12). Expanding the equation for this component results in (13) J ¯ a z ω ˙ e z = sin θ J a z + J e x ω ˙ a x + J a z ω e z − sin θ J e x ω a z θ ˙ − cos θ ω a x ω a y J a y − J a x − sin θ ω e y ω e z J e z + ω e y ω a x J e y − cos θ ω e x ω e y J e x + cos θ T a z M o t o r − T a f − K a f θ ˙ where J ¯ a z = J a z + cos 2 θ J e z + sin 2 θ J e x As with the elevation axis, this equation needs to be expressed in terms of the controlled variables ω e z ω e y , the elevation and azimuth angles θ and ψ , and base disturbances. Based on (3) and (4), we can get (14) ω e x = 1 cos θ ω a x − sin θ ω e z (15) ω a z = 1 cos θ ω e z − sin θ ω a x Substitute (14) and (15) into (13), the modified expression is derived as (16) J ¯ a z ω ˙ e z = g z ω e z + g y ω a x ω e y + g y z ω e y ω e z + T o b a s e + c o s θ T a z M o t o r − T a f where T o b a s e is the disturbance from base motion. (17) T o b a s e = cos ψ p ˙ + sin ψ q ˙ − ω a y r J a z z + J e x x sin θ − 1 cos θ J a z z ω a x ω a y 1 + sin 2 θ − 2 J e x x ω a x ω a y sin 2 θ cos θ − J a y y − J a x x ω a x ω a y cos θ + K a f cos θ sin θ ω a x + r (18) g y = 1 cos θ J a z z + sin 2 θ J e x x ω a x + cos θ J e x x − J e y y ω a x (19) g z = 2 tan θ J e x x + J a z z ω a y − K a f (20) g y z = − J a z z + J e x x tan θ + J e z z − J e x x sin θ cos θ 2.2 LPV form of the stabilization loop The elevation and azimuth axis dynamics can be expressed in a state differential equation form as (21) x ˙ = A t x + D x , t + J − 1 T m o t o r + T o b a s e + T n o n l i n e a r where (22) x 1 = ∫ 0 t ω e y τ d τ ; x 2 = ω e y t ; x 3 = ∫ 0 t ω e z τ d τ ; x 4 = ω e z t (23) A t = 0 1 0 0 0 − K e f J e y y 0 − J e x x − J e z z J e y y cos θ ω a x 0 0 0 1 0 g y J ¯ a z 0 g z J ¯ a z (24) D x , t = 0 J e x x − J e z z sin θ J e y y cos θ x 4 2 0 g y z x 2 x 4 J ¯ a z (25) J − 1 = d i a g 0 , 1 / J e y y , 0 , 1 / J ¯ a z (26) T m o t o r = 0 T e l M o t o r 0 T a z M o t o r T (27) T o b a s e = 0 K e f q cos θ − p sin θ 0 T o b a s e T (28) T n o n l i n e a r = 0 − T e f r i c 0 − cos θ T e f r i c D x , t is omitted after linearizing the system at the equilibrium point. System matrix A t changes according to ω a x t and ω a y t , what’s more, azimuth and elevation axis dynamics are coupling. Assuming ω a x t and ω a y t are bounded and in the polytope of vertices: (29) ω a x t ∈ − ω a x 0 , ω a x 0 (30) ω a y t ∈ − ω a y 0 , ω a y 0 The linearized LOS stabilization loop is a polytopic LPV system with exogenous disturbance: (31) x ˙ t = A p t x t + B u t + G w t where B = G = J − 1 , u t = T m o t o r , w t = T o b a s e + T n o n l i n e a r , A p t is constrained to the polytope P given by (32) P = A p t : A p ( t = ∑ j = 1 4 p j t A j , ∑ j = 1 4 p j t = 1 , p j t ≥ 0 , j = 1 , ⋯ , 4 and (33) A 1 = 0 1 0 0 0 − K e f J e y y 0 − J e x x − J e z z J e y y cos θ − ω a x 0 0 0 0 1 0 g y 1 J ¯ a z 0 g z 1 J ¯ a z , A 2 = 0 1 0 0 0 − K e f J e y y 0 − J e x x − J e z z J e y y cos θ ω a x 0 0 0 0 1 0 g y 2 J ¯ a z 0 g z 2 J ¯ a z A 3 = 0 1 0 0 0 − K e f J e y y 0 − J e x x − J e z z J e y y cos θ − ω a x 0 0 0 0 1 0 g y 3 J ¯ a z 0 g z 3 J ¯ a z , A 4 = 0 1 0 0 0 − K e f J e y y 0 − J e x x − J e z z J e y y cos θ ω a x 0 0 0 0 1 0 g y 4 J ¯ a z 0 g z 4 J ¯ a z (34) g y 1 = g y 3 = 1 cos θ J a z z + sin 2 θ J e x x − ω a x 0 + cos θ J e x x − J e y y − ω a x 0 g z 1 = g z 2 = 2 tan θ J e x x + J a z z − ω a y 0 − K a f g y 2 = g y 4 = 1 cos θ J a z z + sin 2 θ J e x x ω a x 0 + cos θ J e x x − J e y y ω a x 0 g z 2 = g z 4 = 2 tan θ J e x x + J a z z ω a y 0 − K a f The exogenous disturbance w is time varying and satisfies the constraint in a fixed finite time interval (35) ∫ 0 T w T t w t d t ≤ d 2 , d ≥ 0 3 Controller design in finite time application occasions We need the following FTB concept for LPV system. Given a positive scalar T and a class of exogenous disturbance signals w defined as (35), the closed-loop system (36) x ˙ t = A p t x t + B p t u t + G p t w t is said to be finite-time bounded with respect to c 1 , c 2 , T , R , d ( c 1 < c 2 and R > 0 ),if (37) x T 0 R x 0 ≤ c 1 2 ⇒ x T t R x t ≤ c 2 2 , ∀ t ∈ 0 , T , ∀ w : ∫ 0 T w T t w t d t ≤ d 2 , d ≥ 0 Given system(36), there exists a state feedback in form of u t = K p t x t such that the system (38) x ˙ t = A p t + K p t x t + G p t w t is FTB if, fix a scalar α ≥ 0 and find two symmetric positive definite matrices Q 1 ∈ R n × n and Q 2 ∈ R l × l and matrices L j ∈ R m × n , j = 1 , ⋯ , N , and positive scalars λ 1 , λ 2 , λ 3 such that the following LMIs hold (39) λ 1 I < Q 1 < I (40) λ 2 I < Q 2 < λ 3 I (41) c 2 2 e − α T c 1 d c 1 λ 1 0 d 0 λ 2 > 0 (42) Θ i j + Θ j i < 0 , 1 ≤ i < j ≤ N (43) Θ i i < 0 , i = 1 , ⋯ , N where (44) Θ i j = M G i Q 2 Q 2 G i T − Q 2 , 1 ≤ i , j ≤ N (45) M = A i R − 1 2 Q 1 R − 1 2 + B i L j + A i R − 1 2 Q 1 R − 1 2 + B i L j T − α R − 1 2 Q 1 R − 1 2 then the state feedback gain is given by (46) K p = ∑ j = 1 N p j t K j , ∑ j = 1 N p j t = 1 , p j t ≥ 0 , j = 1 , ⋯ , N with (47) K j = L j R − 1 2 Q 1 R − 1 2 − 1 Remark: In order to solve the controller design problem with the sufficient conditions above, we need to use the LMI toolbox to solve LMI feasibility problem, which is described by conditions (39)–(45), then evaluate the state feedback matrix K j . The detailed proof of the sufficient condition is shown in reference [23]. However, we solve LMI feasibility problem to get a controller, instead of minimize linear objective under LMI constraints in [23]. The principle of parameter setting should be determined before designing the controller. Design specifications of the controller depends on the stability requirement, the intensity of the movement of the base and the sensor specifications. When the lead-proportional-integral controller is adopted in the single-channel decoupling model, P. Garnell [24] illustrated how to determine the design specifications and how to compromise in a given condition. However, with the controller design method presented in this paper, the controller parameters depend on c 1 , c 2 , T , d . The desired finite time T , scalar α and the ratio of c 1 and d is determined by the typical working mode. The value of c 2 will have an effect on the specifications of the two-axis gimbal platform, such as bandwidth and settling time. A smaller c 2 will result in a bigger gain and a higher bandwidth. When an application environment is determined ( c 1 , α , T , d is determined), the design process can be simplified as adjusting c 2 . The controller is designed with the following gimbal parameters, which were listed in Table 1 . Considering a typical application environment, c 1 , c 2 , and d is set as c 1 = 1 , c 2 = 165 , T = 13 and d = 1 . At the same time, limited working time is set to 13 s. The LMI feasibility problem yields the state feedback matrix with (48) K 1 = − 0.0396 − 68.3903 − 0.001 0.0290 − 0.003 0.0118 − 0.0967 − 132.5956 K 2 = − 0.0396 − 68.3903 0.001 − 0.0290 0.003 − 0.0118 − 0.0967 − 132.5956 K 3 = − 0.0396 − 28.8318 − 0.001 0.0290 − 0.003 0.0118 − 0.0967 − 35.2223 K 4 = − 0.0396 − 28.8318 0.001 − 0.0290 0.003 − 0.0118 − 0.0967 − 35.2223 The state feedback gain is given by(46), with (49) p 1 = 0.5 − ω a x + 0.5 − ω a y 4 (50) p 2 = 0.5 − ω a x + 0.5 + ω a y 4 (51) p 3 = 0.5 + ω a x + 0.5 − ω a y 4 (52) p 4 = 0.5 + ω a x + 0.5 + ω a y 4 According to (3), we can get ω a x and ω a y by the angular velocity of the base, which is measured by the gyroscopic mounted on the base. (53) ω a x = p cos ψ + q sin ψ (54) ω a y = − p sin ψ + q cos ψ 4 Simulation and results The two-axis gimbal platform was simulated in order to provide a comparison of the controller designed in this paper and a PI compensator. Two rate gyros are chosen to provide angular velocity information of the gimbal in the control process, whose constant drift is 15°/h. A PI compensator was given by (55) G c s = 18 s + 25 s In order to test the designed FTB controller performance in a limited time, especially the pitch and yaw channel coupling interference suppression performance, a simulation experiment is designed. The sinusoidal disturbance rates are p = q = r = 3 sin ( 6 π ) . The simulation represents a typical disturbance environment with aircraft. System input angular velocity is section of trapezoidal wave, the maximum angular velocity is 6°/s. Angular velocity input and the corresponding framework angle input is shown in Fig. 3 . When the pitch channel tracking the input signals, pitch output error and yaw coupling error are shown in Fig. 4 (a) and (b).Even if the input is a single frequency sine signals, yaw channel also can produce error due to the coupling. It can be seen from the diagram that, the max tracking error of pitch channel were 0.2°/s with both PI and FTB controller. The max coupling error of yaw channel with PI controller is 0.8°/s, however, the max coupling error of yaw channel with FTB controller is down to 0.2°/s. When the yaw channel tracking the input signals, pitch coupling error and yaw output error are shown in Fig. 5 (a) and (b). It can be seen that the max tracking error in yaw channel with PI controller is 0.3°/s and that with FTB controller is down to 0.14°/s. As for the max coupling error, FTB controller reduced that from 0.14°/s to 0.06°/s. In order to support the performance analysis, a quantitative study of error analysis has been achieved utilizing two frequently used error integral criteria; integral square error(ISE) and integral absolute error(IAE): (56) I S E = ∫ 0 T e t 2 d t I A E = ∫ 0 T e t d t where e t is the measured error, and T = 13 . The values of error integral criteria obtained for elevation and azimuth channels are provided in Table 2 , which indicates that the error in FTB controller is minimum as compared to PI controller which shows the superiority of the proposed FTB controller. To quantitative coupling error between pitch and yaw channel, we statistic the coupling output in 13 s. That is to say, we cumulative the pitch angular velocity coupling when yaw channel tracking orders and the yaw angular velocity coupling when pitch channel tracking orders. We also use the ISE and IAE to measure coupling. The quantitative results are provided in Table 3 . It can be seen from the table that, compared to PI controller, FTB controller have a stronger coupling inhibition ability. 5 Conclusions In this paper, we developed the dynamic model of a pitch-yaw gimbal platform and presented its LPV form. A FTB controller is proposed to improve the performance under disturbance in finite time. A simulation test was designed to compare the controller presented in the paper and the PI controller. The results show that the FTB controller has a stronger disturbance rejection and coupling inhibition capability. The design and analysis method can be applied in the controller design of seeker or some other pitch-yaw gimbaled sensor system. Conflicts of interest The authors declare that there is no conflict of interests regarding the publication of this article. Author contributions Yang Chen conceived the methodology and wrote the paper. Hairong Chu and Lihong Guo designed and performed the experiment. Tingting Sun and Feng Zhang developed the program used in the experiment. Acknowledgments None.

column2: Investigation of optical bandgap variation and photoluminescence behavior in nanocrystalline CuO thin films
column3: Abstract Since the absorption spectrum of CuO is well matched with the spectrum of the sunlight, it is considered to have potential applications in some optoelectronic devices such as solar cells etc. In order to obtain better performance of CuO-based devices, it is necessary to deeply understand the effect of structural parameters of thin films such as thickness on the physical properties of CuO thin films. In this study, the CuO thin films with different thicknesses were prepared by a facile sol-gel method. The structural, morphological, compositional and optical properties of the samples were analyzed by X-ray diffraction (XRD), scanning electron microscopy (SEM), X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS), UV–vis absorption spectra and photoluminescence, respectively. The results show that all samples have a cubic structure regardless of film thickness. However, the photoluminescence behavior that strongly depends on the film thickness is found. When the film thickness is thin, CuO films show a strong violet, green and red co-emission. However, as the thickness increases, the fluorescence of the CuO films is rapidly quenched. It is proposed that the photoluminescence behavior of CuO thin films is closely related to the change of optical bandgap caused by the variation of crystallite size and we gave a tentative explanation for the luminescence changes.
column5: Keywords CuO thin films Sol-gel method Film thickness Optical bandgap Photoluminescence behavior 1 Introduction Wide bandgap metal-oxide semiconductors such as ZnO, TiO2, SnO2 and so on have been extensively and deeply studied due to a wide range of applications including optoelectronic devices [1–10]. In recent years, the medium bandgap CuO materials have also attracted wide attention because they have potential applications in optoelectronic devices such as solar cells and photodetectors. However, compared with the above-mentioned several wide bandgap metal-oxide semiconductors, the studies on CuO are still far few. CuO is a thermally and chemically stable medium bandgap semiconductor with a bandgap energy in the range of 1.2–2.6 eV varying with the preparation conditions [11–13] and is usually shown as p-type conductivity due to the presence of copper vacancy defects [14]. So far, CuO thin films have been prepared by many methods, such as electrodeposition [13], chemical vapor deposition [15], magnetron sputtering [16], pulsed laser deposition [17], successive ionic layer adsorption and reaction [18], sol-gel method [12,19] and so on. Among these thin film deposition techniques, sol-gel method is a wet chemical method, which has been widely used in many fields due to some advantages like low cost, simple equipment, no need of vacuum environment, high film-forming efficiency and easy realization of molecular level doping. It is well known that the photoelectric properties of thin films depend on the preparation techniques, the deposition conditions and the structural parameters of the film itself. So far, there have some reports on the influence of the preparation techniques and deposition conditions on the CuO thin films [11–15], but the effects of the film structure parameters such as film thickness on the optical properties of CuO thin films are reported to be very few [18,20], especially for the CuO thin film with a thickness in the range of 0–200 nm. For example, Akaltun et al. [18] deposited the CuO thin films with thickness in the range of 125–310 nm on the glass substrates by successive ionic layer adsorption and reaction and studied the effect of film thickness on the structure, optical bandgap and refractive index of the samples. Shrividhya et al. [20] prepared CuO films on glass substrates by double dip technique; the effect of the growth solution concentration on the CuO films was studied. The thickness of the deposited CuO films was in the range of 1.3–2.1 μm. Al-Ghamdi et al. [21] studied the effect of growth time on the structure and optical properties of CuO thin films deposited by magnetron sputtering on glass substrates. They found that as the growth time increased, the film thickness rose from 160 to 490 nm. The change of the film thickness also led to the obvious variation of bandgap and luminescence behavior of CuO thin films. In addition, Ravichandran et al. [22] synthesized CuO thin films on glass substrates using successive ionic layer adsorption and reaction, and investigated the effect of immersion time on the physical properties of CuO thin films. Because the different immersion time led to different film thicknesses, they were equivalent to indirectly investigating the effect of film thickness on the physical properties of CuO films. As an important parameter affecting the physical properties of CuO thin films, it is very important to understand the effect of film thickness on the properties of CuO films. As far as we know, the effect of the thickness of the CuO thin film prepared by the sol-gel method on its optical properties is reported to be very few. In view of this, we prepared CuO thin films with different thicknesses using sol-gel method in this study, and investigated the effect of thickness on the optical properties of CuO thin films. The experimental results showed that the optical bandgap and luminescence behavior of CuO thin films exhibited a strong dependence on the thickness of the films. The detailed results are described below. 2 Experiments The CuO thin films were prepared on glass substrates by sol-gel method. The specific preparation procedure is described below. First, a CuO sol is prepared by using monohydrate copper acetate, anhydrous ethanol and monoethanolamine as solute, solvent and stabilizer, respectively. The concentration of copper acetate in the sol is 0.2 mol/L; the molar ratio of copper acetate to monoethanolamine is 1:1. The sealed CuO sol is allowed to stand at room temperature for 24 h, and then the CuO sol is coated on the substrates by spin-coating. The spin-speed of the substrate is 2800 rpm, and the spin-coating time is 40 s. After the completion of one coating, the sample is put into a furnace at 280 °C for 3 min to remove the solvent and the organic residue, and then the next coating is carried out. In order to obtain CuO thin films with different thicknesses, the spin-coating process is repeated 1, 2, 4, 6 and 8 times, respectively, and the corresponding CuO thin films are named Sample A, B, C, D and E. Finally, the CuO thin films were annealed at 450 °C for 60 min in air atmosphere. The surface and cross-section morphologies of the samples were analyzed by a field emission scanning electron microscope (S4800). The crystalline phase of the samples was determined by an X-ray diffractometer (SmartLab). The surface composition and the chemical bonding states of the constituent elements of the films were analyzed by an X-ray photoelectron spectrometer (Thermo escalab 250Xi). The optical absorbance and reflectivity of the samples were measured by a double beam spectrophotometer (Cary5000). The photoluminescence behavior was analyzed by a spectrometer (LabRAM HR800) using a He-Cd laser as the excitation source with a wavelength of 325 nm. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 The morphology, crystalline phase and chemical composition of the films Fig.1 displays the surface and cross-section morphology images of the samples. As for the sample which is coated only one time, it can be seen from Fig. 1(b) that the film thickness is about 20 nm. The surface of the film shows a lot of nanocrystals, indicating a polycrystalline nature of the sample. These nanocrystals are not tightly packed together, but basically stand alone. The appearance of this result is due to the growth mode of the film. That is to say, the “island-growth-mode” dominates the growth of CuO thin films at this stage. However, with the increase in the number of coated layer, not only the thickness of CuO thin film increases, and the film density is also significantly improved. The grains are gradually growing up. For sample A, B, C, D and E, their in-plane average grain sizes are 4.1, 10.3, 13.4, 37.1 and 39.2 nm, respectively. It can be seen from the variation of the grain size that when the number of coated layer exceeds 4, the growth rate of the grains in the CuO films appears to be faster, but when the number of coated layer is higher than 6, the growth rate of the grains decreases again. Fig.2 shows the XRD patterns of CuO thin films with different thicknesses. When the film is relatively thin, its diffraction peak is very weak, indicating that the crystallites are very small and the crystallinity of the film is poor. As the film thickness increases, two distinct diffraction peaks (002) and (111) are clearly observed. A (−202) diffraction peak is also observed when the number of coated layer exceeds 4. All of these diffraction peaks correspond to the diffraction peaks of CuO in a monoclinic phase (JCPDS card No. 45-0937), and no diffraction peaks associated with cuprous oxide or cuprous hydroxide are observed, indicating that the deposited CuO films have a pure monoclinic phase regardless of film thickness. With the increase of the thickness, the intensity of the diffraction peaks is gradually enhanced, suggesting that the crystallinity of CuO thin films is gradually improved. The average crystallite size of the CuO thin films was calculated using the data from the (002) peaks by the following formula: (1) d = 0.9 λ β cos θ where d is the average crystallite size, λ is the wavelength of the X-ray, β is the angular line width at the half-maximum intensity in radians, and θ is the diffraction angle. For sample B, C, D and E, their crystallite sizes are 8.1, 13.3, 20.5 and 22.1 nm, respectively. Since the diffraction peak of sample A is very weak, accurate data cannot be extracted to calculate its crystallite size. However, it can be qualitatively known from the results given by the SEM images that the crystallite size of sample A should be less than 4 nm. We can see that the trend in the change of the crystallite size calculated from the Sherrer’s formula is consistent with the results observed from the SEM images, i.e., as the film thickness increases, the crystals gradually grow up. When the number of the coating is less than 6 layers, the crystal sizes obtained from SEM and XRD is almost same. However, when the film is thicker, the crystal sizes observed from SEM are significantly larger than those calculated from the XRD data. It is generally accepted that the grains observed by the SEM are actually formed by the aggregation of some small crystallites [23,24] and are therefore larger than the crystallites obtained from the XRD data. However, some researchers have reported that the grain size observed by SEM is substantially same as the crystallite size calculated by XRD data [25]. The difference may be related to thin film growth mode caused by different deposition techniques. Here it can be seen from Fig. 1(a) that when the film is very thin, most of the CuO grains are basically not combined together, but exist independently. In this situation, a grain maybe is composed of one crystallite. Therefore, the crystal size calculated from XRD data is almost same as that observed from the SEM image. However, when the film is relatively thick, the adjacent small crystallites gradually merge and grow up during the annealing process, resulting in the crystal size calculated from the XRD data is not consistent with that observed from the SEM image. In order to analyze the surface composition and the chemical state of the constituent elements, the XPS spectra have been taken for sample B, as shown in Fig.3 . The binding energy in the XPS spectra has been calibrated by using that of C 1s (284. 8 eV). It can be seen from the survey spectrum of Fig. 3(a) that only the signals of Cu and O are shown in this spectrum, which means that the sample is composed only of Cu and O and does not contain other impurities. Fig.3(b) illustrates the high-resolution spectrum of Cu 2p. The two signal peaks at 933.7 and 953.7 eV are from Cu 2p3/2 and Cu 2p1/2, respectively, along with two satellite peaks at 942.5 and 962.4 eV. The above information indicates that Cu ions are in +2 valence state in the films [14,20]. Therefore, the samples are pure CuO thin films, which is consistent with the results of XRD. Fig.3 (c) gives the high-resolution XPS spectrum of O 1s. A signal peak at 530.0 eV is observed, and it is clear that the peak is geometrically symmetric; this signal is thought to result from the lattice oxygen bound to Cu2+ [14,20]. 3.2 The optical properties of CuO thin films Fig.4 (a) shows the optical absorption spectra of the samples. All samples show strong absorption in the visible and near infrared regions. With the increase of the film thickness, the absorbance of the CuO thin films gradually increases, and similar results were reported in other studies [21]. The optical bandgaps of the CuO thin films can be obtained by using Tauc's relation [24] to make plots of (αhν)2 vs. hv, and extrapolate their linear parts to the energy axis, as shown in Fig. 4(b). For sample A, B, C, D and E, their direct bandgap are 2.51, 2.40, 2.10, 1.65 and 1.56 eV, respectively. These values are close to those of the CuO films prepared by the sol-gel method reported by Baturay et al. and Akgul et al. [12,24]. As the thickness of the film increases, the optical bandgap decreases gradually, and similar results have been also reported by other researchers [18,21], which is mainly attributed to the grown-up of CuO grains and the improvement of crystal quality [24]. The larger bandgap is expected when the CuO crystallite is smaller according to the following formula given by Marotti et al. [26]: (2) E ( R ) = E g ( ∞ ) + E b π a B R 2 where R is the radius of the crystallite, E ( R ) is the lowest transition energy, E g ( ∞ ) is the “bulk” band gap energy, E b is the exciton binding energy and a B is the exciton Bohr radius. For the bandgaps of CuO films, the results reported show a large difference. For example, Jundale et al. [11] deposited CuO thin films by sol-gel method. They found that as the annealing temperature increased from 300 to 700 °C, the bandgap of the CuO films was reduced from 1.64 to 1.46 eV. Kawwam et al. [14] used pulsed laser deposition to grow a highly (111) oriented CuO thin film on MgO (100) substrates with a band gap of 1.32 eV; Chen et al. [17] also prepared CuO thin film by pulsed laser deposition and found that the direct bandgap of the film was 2.12 eV. For another sample, Wang et al. [13] fabricated nano-structured CuO films by electrodeposition on glass substrates to find their bandgap up to 3.3 eV. From these results it can be seen that even if the CuO films deposited by the same method [14,17], their bandgaps may also be very different. This indicates that the bandgaps of CuO films are closely related to the deposition method and deposition parameters. The bandgap of CuO thin film has a wide range of adjustment, which is different from most other metal-oxide semiconductors. For example, the bandgap of ZnO thin films can be only changed greatly in the case of doping. Such a feature of the CuO bandgap is an important advantage for its application in some optoelectronic devices. As we all know, photoluminescence is a non-destructive, highly sensitive analytical method that can study the electronic structure and defects of materials. Therefore, more information can be gotten from the photoluminescence study of CuO films, but the reported results on photoluminescence of the CuO thin films are few to date. Even if there have some reports on photoluminescence of CuO thin films, most did not give a reasonable explanation about the luminescence behavior due to the complex band structure of CuO. Here, some strange phenomena of emissions in CuO thin films are also observed. Fig. 5 (a) shows the photoluminescence spectra of CuO thin films with different thicknesses. Sample A shows a strong luminescence, while the luminescence intensity of sample B is weakened compared with sample A. As the thickness further increases, the luminescence of the CuO film is almost completely quenched. For direct bandgap metal-oxide semiconductor materials, in general, there are two main types of emissions. One is caused by the electron transition from the conduction band bottom to the valence band top (near band edge emission, NBE emission), belonging to the intrinsic emission (for example, the UV emission of ZnO in the range of 370–390 nm belongs to this type of emission [3,7]); and the other is caused by the transitions between the defective energy levels or between the defect levels and the conduction band/valence band, which is called defect-related emission. In general, the photon energy of the NBE emission is close to or less than the bandgap energy, and the photon energy of defect-related emissions is far less than the bandgap energy. In order to clarify the emission wavelength (photon energy) of the CuO thin films, we have performed a Gaussian fitting for the emission spectrum of sample A, as shown in Fig. 5(b). This wide luminous band is actually superimposed by three emission peaks: the violet emission peak located at 429 nm (2.89 eV), the green emission peak located at 519 nm (2.39 eV), and the red emission peak located at 681 nm (1.82 eV). For sample A, its bandgap is 2.51 eV, so the green and red emissions here may be caused by the electron transitions between the defect levels in the forbidden band or between the defect levels and the conduction band/valence band, but the origin of the violet emission seem not to be attributed to the direct transition of the electrons between the conduction band bottom and the valence band top since the photon energy of the violet emission is significantly higher than the value of the bandgap. The similar phenomena have also occurred in other studies. For example, Al-Ghamdi et al. [21] prepared three CuO thin films by magnetron sputtering, all of which showed a UV emission of 387 nm (3.20 eV), whereas the bandgap of the three films was 1.73, 1.88 and 2.2 eV, respectively. They did not specify the origin of the UV emission. Chand et al. [27] deposited Li-doped CuO thin films by pulsed laser deposition. Those CuO thin films exhibited similar emission spectra shape at 325 nm UV excitation. They all included three luminescent centers, namely, ultraviolet emissions at 359 and 383 nm and blue emission at 441 nm. The bandgap of the Li-doped CuO thin films was reduced from 2.99 to 2.76 eV with increasing Li doping concentration. Chand et al. deemed that the UV emissions centered at 359 and 383 nm were the band edge emissions of CuO, while the blue emission centered at 441 nm was related to defects such as oxygen vacancies etc. Although this special luminescence behavior is rarely reported in other metal-oxide semiconductors, it has been found several times in CuO nanomaterials, indicating that the band structure of CuO has some particularity. It can be clearly seen from Fig. 5(a) that the luminescence intensity of the CuO thin film decreases rapidly with increasing thickness, and a similar phenomenon occurred in the study of Al-Ghamdi et al. [21]. The phenomenon is very different from that in other metal-oxide semiconductor thin films. For example, in the ZnO thin films, the crystal quality is usually improved with the increase of the film thickness, and therefore its intrinsic luminescence tends to increase [28]. Furthermore, the emission attenuation of the CuO thin film seems to be related to the decrease of the bandgap, since that the luminescence intensity decreases with the reduction of the bandgap of CuO films has been observed in several studies [21,27,29], and all the emissions regardless of wavelength are weakened. However, because the band structure calculations of CuO nanostructures are limited even in its bulk form due to large variations in the electron and hole effective mass, prediction and photoluminescence band assignments are complex [29]. It is known that whether the crystallite size of the CuO thin films calculated using the XRD data or the optical bandgap of the thin films derived from the absorption spectra is an integral parameter or an average value that is used to describe the overall properties of the film. However, the actual situation is that there may be many nanocrystals less than the average crystallite size in the CuO thin films, especially in the thinner CuO films. From the above formula (2), it can be known that the actual bandgap is much larger than that of the films for these small nanocrystals [30]. In this case, it is entirely possible that ultraviolet emission or violet emission is produced by electron transitions from the conduction band bottom to the valence band top. Since the quantum dots/nanodots often contain many point defects, the defect-level related transitions may cause blue, green, red and other visible emissions. Then, why will the emissions be significantly reduced or even completely quenched when the bandgap of the CuO thin film decreases? One possibility is that the bandgap type of CuO has been changed from direct bandgap to indirect bandgap (some researchers also tend to think that CuO has an indirect bandgap [14,20,31]), which maybe lead the electronic direct transition efficiency to be greatly reduced or makes the excited electrons release energy in a non-radiative manner. However, it should be noted that this is only a speculation. In order to completely reveal the true origin of emissions above the bandgap energy in CuO, a large number of theoretical calculations and experimental studies are needed. In addition, it is necessary to calculate the energy levels for the common point defects such as oxygen vacancy, copper vacancy, etc. in CuO forbidden band, which makes it possible to determine the origin of visible emissions. Fig. 6 shows the reflection spectra of the CuO thin films with different thicknesses. These CuO films show a relatively high reflectivity, especially for the two samples A and B which has a thinner thickness. It can be seen that the reflectivity of the CuO thin film with the same thickness changes little in the visible region while the reflectivity in the infrared region changes greatly. As the thickness increases, the reflectivity of the CuO thin film is gradually reduced, except that of sample B which is slightly increased. Chen et al. [17] prepared a CuO thin film with a thickness of 140 nm using pulsed laser deposition. The reflection spectrum showed that the average reflectivity of the sample in the visible region was about 15%. Shrividhya et al. [20] prepared CuO films with thicknesses more than 1 μm by two double dip method, whose reflectivity exceeded 80% in the visible region. Akgul et al. [24] deposited CuO thin films with a thickness of 520 nm by spin coating, which exhibited a reflectivity of about 10% in the visible region. These results show that the appropriate thickness can reduce the reflectivity of the CuO films. When the CuO film is used in solar cells, its reflectivity is an important parameter, so it is necessary to optimize the thickness to reduce the reflectivity and improve the absorption efficiency as much as possible. 4 Conclusion In this study, we investigated the effect of thickness on the optical properties of CuO thin films. When the CuO film is very thin, it shows a strong photoluminescence. The fitted emission spectrum shows three emission peaks, namely, violet, green and red emission peaks. The violet emission may be due to the transition between the conduction band bottom and the valence band top in those nanocrystals with larger bandgap energy than that of the films, while the green and red emissions may be related to the transition between the defect levels or between the defect levels and conduction band/valence band. It is found that the optical bandgap and photoluminescence intensity of CuO thin films decreased gradually with the increase of film thickness. The bandgap reduction of CuO thin films is mainly due to the grown-up of CuO grains and the improvement of crystal quality. The luminescence decay of the CuO thin film may be associated with its reduced bandgap. However, due to the lack of support from the theoretical results of CuO, here we give some tentative suggestions for the luminescence behavior of CuO thin films. In order to realize the application of CuO films in optoelectronic devices as early as possible, it is necessary to carry out more and deeper research on CuO materials. Acknowledgements This work is supported by the Natural Science Foundation of the Jiangsu Higher Education Institutions (Grant no. 16KJB430021), the Open Foundation of Labs in Nanjing University of Information Science and Technology in 2017 (17KF015) and partially supported by the National Natural Science Foundation of China (Grant no. 41675154).

column2: Exponential density transition based self-focusing of Gaussian laser beam in collisional plasma
column3: Abstract In this work, nonlinear aspects of a high intensity Gaussian laser beam propagating in plasma having upward density ramp of tangent and exponential profiles are studied. We have employed the nonlinearity in dielectric function of plasma due to nonuniform heating of carriers along the wavefront of the laser beam which is important in collisional plasmas. The differential equation governing the dimensionless beam width parameter is achieved by using Wentzel–Kramers–Brillouin (WKB) and paraxial approximations and solved it numerically by using Runge-Kutta fourth order method. Effect of exponential density ramp profile on self-focusing is systematically carried out and compared with tangent density ramp profile. It is found that exponential plasma density ramp causes the laser beam to become more focused than tangent density ramp over several Rayleigh length and gives reasonably interesting results.
column5: Keywords Self-focusing Gaussian laser beam Density ramp Collisional plasma 1 Introduction Advances in the laser technology opened the way to experiments involving laser pulses focused to extremely high intensities. High energy laser beam and plasma interaction give variety of phenomena which are important in many applications, such as generation of new radiation sources [1], high harmonic generation [2], laser-driven inertial confinemet fusion [3], laser-based plasma accelerators [4], self-phase modulation [5], soft X-ray generation [6], etc. Self-focusing describes in general focusing of the laser beam by itself as a result of the nonlinear refractive index induced by the beam itself. It describes the trapping of light in a plasma channel created by the instantaneous response of the nonlinear refractive index to the light beam [7]. Self-focusing is often responsible for the optical damage created in a solid by a high-power laser beam [8]. When a laser beam, having non-uniform intensity distribution along its wavefront, propagating through the plasma, electrons get heated and temperature gradient occurs. Temperature gradient results out electron diffusion and generation of space charge field. The collisional non-linearity occurs because of electrons acquiring temperature higher than other species, i.e. ions on account of net effect of ohmic heating and energy lost by electrons due to collisions with heavy particles (atoms/molecules and ions) and by thermal conduction. This analysis accounted only one type of energy loss viz. collisional or thermal conduction. Thus the effective dielectric function get modified significantly, this self-induced inhomogeneity in the dielectric constant of the plasma gives rise to self-focusing and defocusing effect of the beam [9]. In recent years, a considerable interest has been evinced for slowly increasing plasma density ramp to overcome the diffraction and guiding the laser beam over long distance. There are lot of work had been carried with different density ramp profiles [10–20], in which tangent density ramp profile has been studied extensively due to its upward increasing nature but profile such as n = n 0 + n 0 tan(ξ/d) shoot to infinity at particular value of ξ = ξ d , which signifies that medium will have infinite density at ξ d , so that study of self-focusing by using such profiles are limited to the value of ξ < ξ d . This limit is systematically overcame by replacing new exponential density ramp profile of n = n 0 exp(ξ/d), such type of ramp profile has been suggested by Sen et al. [21] but not explored extensively. The aim of this paper for the first time is to investigate the effect of exponential density ramp on self-focusing of Gaussian laser beam in collisional plasma. As usual, present analysis employs parabolic wave equation approach under WKB and paraxial approximations. We have shown noteworthy comparison of n = n 0 exp(ξ/d) with n = n 0 + n 0 tan(ξ/d), as both profiles shows n = n 0 at ξ = 0. The systematic organization of this paper is as fallows: Section 1 describes the evolution of beam width parameter of Gaussian laser beam propagating through collisional plasma with upward density ramp profiles. In Section 2, detailed discussion of the results has been presented. Finally a brief conclusion is added in Section 3. Here we are considering propagation of laser beam into the plasma along z direction, starting from z = 0: (1) E = A ( r , z ) exp [ i ( ω t − k 0 z ) ] , where k 0 = ω c ε 0 is wave number in the absence of plasma density transition and ω is frequency of laser used. The wave equation governing the electric field vector of a laser beam in plasma medium with effective dielectric function ε can be written as (2) ∇ 2 E → + ω 2 c 2 ε E → = 0 . In cylindrical coordinate system, Eq. (2) can be written as (3) ∂ 2 E → ∂ z 2 + ∂ 2 E → ∂ r 2 + 1 r ∂ E → ∂ r + ω 2 c 2 ε E → = 0 . The effective dielectric function of plasma can also be written as [9] (4) ε = ε 0 + ϕ ( EE * ) , where ε 0 = 1 − ( ω p 2 / ω 2 ) is the linear part of dielectric constant with ω p = ( 4 π ne 2 / m ) 1 / 2 as the plasma frequency. Here e and m are the electronic charge and its rest mass respectively. The perturbed electron density n is given by (5) n = n 0 exp z dR d and (6) n = n 0 + n 0 tan z dR d , where n 0 is the equilibrium electron density, R d = kr o 2 is diffraction length with k = ω c ε is the wave number in presence of plasma density transition and d is adjustable dimensionless parameter. Second term in Eq. (4), the intensity dependent part of dielectric constant for collisional plasma is given by, (7) ϕ ( EE * ) = ω p 2 ω 2 α EE * 2 + α EE * , with α = e 2 M 6 k B T 0 ω 2 m 2 where M, k 0 and T 0 are mass of ion, Boltzmann constant and equilibrium temperature of plasma respectively. We now introduce eikonal S as, (8) A = A 0 ( r , z ) exp [ ikS ( r , z ) ] , where A 0(r, z) and S(r, z) are real function of r and z with, (9) S = r 2 2 β ( z ) + ϕ ( z ) , where β(z) can be expressed as (1/f)(∂f/∂z) and it represent the reciprocal of curvature of the wave front and ϕ(z) is phase shift. For incident Gaussian laser beam we write, (10) A 0 2 = E 0 2 f 2 exp − r 2 r 0 2 f 2 , where f is beam width parameter which is measure of both axial intensity and width of the beam and r 0 is initial radius of laser beam. Following the approach given by Akhomonov et al. [22] and devoloped by Sodha et al. [23], we have obtained nonlinear differential equation in presence of exponential density ramp profile as, (11) 1 − ξ ω p 0 2 exp ξ / d 2 d ω 2 1 − ( ω p 0 2 / ω 2 ) exp ξ / d d 2 f d ξ 2 = 1 f 3 − 2 exp ξ / d α E 0 2 ω p 0 2 fr 0 2 ( α E 0 2 + 2 f 2 ) 2 c 2 − ξ ω p 0 2 exp ξ / d 2 d ω 2 1 − ( ω p 0 2 / ω 2 ) exp ξ / d df d ξ 2 + ω p 0 2 exp ξ / d 2 d ω 2 1 − ( ω p 0 2 / ω 2 ) exp ξ / d 1 − ξ ω p 0 2 exp ξ / d 2 d ω 2 1 − ( ω p 0 2 / ω 2 ) exp ξ / d df d ξ . Similarly we have obtained nonlinear differential equation in presence of density ramp of tangent profile as (12) 1 − ξ ω p 0 2 sec 2 ξ / d 2 d ω 2 1 − ( ω p 0 2 / ω 2 ) 1 + tan ξ / d d 2 f d ξ 2 = 1 f 3 − 2 1 + tan ξ / d α E 0 2 ω p 0 2 fr 0 2 ( α E 0 2 + 2 f 2 ) 2 c 2 − ξ ω p 0 2 sec 2 ξ / d 2 df ω 2 1 − ( ω p 0 2 / ω 2 ) 1 + tan ξ / d df d ξ 2 + ω p 0 2 sec 2 ξ / d 2 d ω 2 1 − ( ω p 0 2 / ω 2 ) 1 + tan ξ / d 1 − ξ ω p 0 2 sec 2 ξ / d 2 d ω 2 1 − ( ω p 0 2 / ω 2 ) 1 + tan ξ / d df d ξ . 2 Results and discussion Eqs. (11) and (12) represents variation of beam width parameter f with normalized distance of propagation ξ for exponential and tangent density ramp profiles respectively. These are the second order nonlinear differential equations and can be numerically solved by choosing following laser-plasma parameters: r 0 = 20 × 10−4 cm, ω = 1.7760 × 1015 rad/s, n 0 = 3.9645 × 1017 cm−3. α E 0 2 = 5 , d = 20 . The first term on the right-hand side of Eqs. (11) and (12) corresponds to the diffraction divergence of the beam and the second term corresponds to the convergence resulting from the nonlinearity and remaining terms appears due to plasma density ramp. It is important to note that in absence of density transition, Eqs. (11) and (12) reduces to (13) d 2 f d ξ 2 = 1 f 3 − 2 α E 0 2 ω p 0 2 fr 0 2 ( α E 0 2 + 2 f 2 ) 2 c 2 . Eq. (13) is identical to a similar equation obtained earlier by Sodha et al. [23] for collisional plasma of uniform density. In Fig. 1 , both tangent and exponential density ramp profiles are plotted for d = 10 and n 0 = 3.9645 × 1017 cm−3. From this figure it is clear that tangent function increases rapidly with increase in value of ξ and diverges to infinity at particular value of ξ = ξ d . In this case ξ d  = 15.8. On other hand, exponential profile shows smooth variation of density with respect to normalized distance of propagation ξ. Fig. 2 a shows variation of beam width parameter f with normalized propagation distance ξ. This gives comparison of f with ξ for exponential density ramp plasma, tangent density ramp plasma and plasma having no ramp. Oscillatory self-focusing is observed when density of plasma is uniform. In presence of density ramp, oscillatory self-focusing with decrease of spot size with ξ is observed. Fig. 2a shows that there is initial agreement of f values for both profiles. It is to be noted that enhanced self-focusing is observed for exponential ramp profile than tangent profile. Fig. 2b explain reason of such behavior. In this figure the intensity dependent dielectric constant ϕ is plotted as function of normalized propagation distance ξ. In presence of ramp, the value of ϕ increases rapidly as compared to value of ϕ in absence of ramp. Since the strength of self-focusing depends upon the value of ϕ, laser spot size decreases rapidly and become more focused as laser beam goes more deeper into the plasma. From Fig. 2, it is clear that, minimum value of f matches with the peak value of ϕ and vice versa, along the beam axis. It is to be noted that divergence of tangent profile at particular value of ξ put limitation on the study of self-focusing. Such limitation is overcame by introducing exponential ramp profile. Thus for large value of normalized propagation distance ξ, the exponential ramp profile is more preferable than tangent ramp profile. Such exponential upward density ramp profile slowly increases the self-focusing by slowly increasing the density. As the laser propagates through the exponential density ramp region, it sees a slowly narrowing channel. In this plasma environment, the oscillation amplitude of the laser spot size reduces significantly, while its frequency increases. Thus exponential plasma density ramp causes the laser beam to become more focused over several Rayleigh length. Normalized intensity I/I 0 versus beam normalized beam width r/r 0 and normalized propagation distance ξ in plasma are plotted in Fig. 3 . It shows that by propagating the laser beam through the plasma its intensity is increased which shows self-focusing. To support this result the density plot for spot size profile is shown in Fig. 4 . It is observed from this figure that with increase in distance of propagation ξ spot size decreases which leads to increase in laser intensity. Moreover, the peaks of beam intensity correspond to valleys of f parameter. 3 Conclusion In conclusion, we comparatively studied the effect of tangent and exponential density ramp profiles on self-focusing of Gaussian laser beam in collisional plasma by using usual parabolic equation approach. Following important conclusions are drawn from present analysis: • As obvious, exponential and tangent density profiles causes the laser beam to become more focused in collisional plasma. • Enhanced self-focusing is observed for exponential density ramp profile than tangent density ramp profile. • For the propagation of laser beam over several Rayleigh length, exponential ramp profile is more preferable than tangent ramp profile. The present results are of relevance in various laser plasma-applications, where propagation of laser beam with localized energy over several Rayleigh length are required.
