column2: Designing a 2-to-4 decoder on nanoscale based on quantum-dot cellular automata for energy dissipation improving
column3: Abstract Quantum dot Cellular Automata (QCA) as a new architecture at the nanoscale is developed as a feasible alternative for the existing Complementary Metal–Oxide–Semiconductor (CMOS) designs. The decoder in the QCA is a very important circuit to address the QCA-based random access memory arrays. It plays a key role in many circuit designs, such as Controlled Logic Block (CLB), Field Programmable Gate Array (FPGA), and memory circuits’ designs. In this paper, a five-input majority gate is used in a modular design methodology to design a 2-to-4 decoder in QCA. The proposed 2-to-4 QCA-based decoder can be utilized to synthesize n-to-2n decoders as well. The functional correctness of the proposed circuit is evaluated using QCADesigner tool. Also, QCAPro simulator as a popular power estimator tool in QCA evaluates the power dissipation. The obtained results have shown the significant success in terms of clock speed (%57), wire-crossing (%33), cell number (%27), area (%26) and power dissipation than the existing designs.
column5: Keywords Quantum dot cellular automata Power consumption Decoder Nanoscale QCA 1 Introduction Quantum-dot Cellular Automata (QCA) was proposed by Lent in 1993 [1]. Low power, high density, and regularity are considered for its performance. Also, it presents a new device architecture for nanotechnology [2,3]. Cells are made up of four quantum dots along corners of a square with two electrons. The two possible arrangements signify logic 0 or logic 1 [4,5]. The Columbic interactions with neighboring cell states define the position of the cell [5,6]. Circuits occupy smaller area using QCA technology compared to Complementary Metal-Oxide-Semiconductor (CMOS). Thus, they stand as a good substitute to the CMOS technology [7]. The power consumption is significantly less than conventional CMOS circuits because of electrical current absence in QCA computations. The power consumption issue of the circuits has been ignored in many QCA logical and arithmetic designs [8]. On the other hands, the decoder is a circuit that modifies a code into a set of signals. The line decoder is considered as a type of decoder, which receipts an n-digit binary number and decodes it into 2n data lines. The 1-to-2 decoder is considered as the simplest. There is a procedure to design larger line decoders. Smaller decoders just like other digital circuits should combine together for making larger decoders. An alternative circuit for the 2-to-4 line decoder which is changing the 1-to-2 decoders with their circuits will show that both circuits are alike. In a similar fashion, a 3-to-8 decoder can be designed based on 1-to-2 and 2-to-4 decoders, and a 4-to-16 decoder can be designed based on two 2-to-4 decoders. The selection among multiple devices is done through a line decoder circuit [9]. Decoders play an important role in circuit designs, such as carrying out of a Field Programmable Gate Array (FPGA), Controlled Logic Block (CLB) and memory circuits designs [10]. The optimization of a power consumption in the modular decoder is not mentioned properly in the literature although the decoder has an important role in QCA-based designs. A modular design method for the QCA-based decoder is proposed in this paper to improve the power consumption. Briefly, the important features of this work are as follows: • A modular QCA-based decoder is designed and its efficiency in realizing n to 2n decoders (n > = 2) is explored. • A one-level architecture with tree clocks for reducing the energy consumption of the QCA-based decoder is proposed. • The analysis of the offered design in terms of wire-crossings, delay, number cell, and area are reported. This paper is organized as follows: Section 2 reviews the related work and basic terminologies. Section 3 provides the design of the proposed decoder. The proposed decoder is simulated and evaluated in Section 4. Conclusions and future studies are discussed in the last section. 2 Background and related work This section reviews some background materials and related work in order to understand the structure of QCA and state–of–the–art designs. 2.1 QCA technology The QCA technology is based on new design concept [2]. Four charged containers are placed at the corners of a square in QCA [11]. Two extra mobile electrons move in the cell by tunneling between dots. Columbic repulsion makes the cell a bi-state device, as shown in Fig. 1 [12]. The assignment of the QCA cells in a particular pattern relates the ground state of the system with a logic function [13]. Binary wires and inverter chains are employed as interconnections for QCA circuits [14–18]. For having a better stability in QCA structures, it is necessary to have an efficient interconnection between components. For this reason, wire crossing is a significant issue in QCA circuit design [19,20]. Both 45-degree and 90-degree QCA cells are required for performing single –layer crossing [21,22]. Each one is dedicated to one side of a crossing, as shown in Fig. 2 . These different cells can pass over the crossing without any significant effect on each other [19,20]. Multi-layer crossing uses only 45-degree cells or 90-degree ones [19]. The majority voter and inverter circuits are considered as the basic logic devices for QCA [14–18]. Inverter types are shown in Fig. 3 . A 3-input majority gate is the most important gate in QCA [4,23]. It has three inputs and one output as shown in Fig. 4 (a). Three inputs labeled A, B, and E, an output cell, and one middle cell are included in this design. Also, a schematic of the 3-input majority gate is depicted in Fig. 4(b). A 5-input majority gate as a most important gate in QCA must have five inputs and one output as shown in Fig. 5 (c). Five inputs labeled A, B, C, D and E, an output cell and four middle cells labeled 1, 2, 3 and 4 are included in this design. The input cells have stable polarization. The middle cells and output cell are changeable. Also, a schematic of the 5-input majority gate is depicted in Fig. 5(d). A 3-input AND gate and a 3-input OR gate can be realized by means of this majority gate [18]. Four clock phases such as a switch, hold, release and relax are included in QCA cell which is shown in Fig. 6 . QCA cells are unpolarized during the switch phase and they have low inter-dot potential barriers. The position of their drivers (their input cells) makes the QCA cells to be polarized. This clock phase makes the actual computation. The high barriers stop electron tunneling at the end of the clock phase which causes to have fixed cell states [24,26]. 2.2 Power dissipation model Timber and Lent [16] have developed the first power formalism for QCA. [27]. The total energy and a power of QCA cell are measured by the Hamiltonian matrix. The Hamiltonian for an array of QCA cells is presented using Hartree–Fock approximation [28] and the Columbic interaction between cells by a mean-field approach is exposed as [27,29]: (1) H = - E K 2 ∑ i C i f i , j - γ - γ E K 2 ∑ i C i f i , j = - E K 2 ∑ i ( C j - 1 + C j + 1 ) - γ - γ E K 2 ∑ i ( C j - 1 + C j + 1 ) Where Ci is the polarization of the ith juxtaposed cell and fi,j is the geometrical factor specifying the electrostatic interaction between cells (i and j). In the case of similarly neighboring cells, fi,j is absorbed into the Kink energy definition (Ek ). This energy is related to the energy cost of two QCA cells (i and j) having opposite polarizations and can be calculated as [30]: (2) E i , j = 1 4 Π ε 0 ε r ∑ n = 1 4 ∑ m = 1 4 q i , n q j , m r i , n - r j , m Furthermore, the expectation value for QCA cell energy at each clock cycle is calculated as [29]: (3) E = H = ℏ 2 . Γ → . λ → Where Γ → is the energy environment vector of the cell including its neighbor’s effects, ℏ is reduced Planck constant, and λ → represents the coherence vector. Also, the Hamiltonian vector is obtained via Eq. (4): (4) Γ → = 1 ℏ - 2 γ , 0 , E k C j - 1 + C j + 1 Where C j - 1 + C j + 1 is the sum of neighboring polarizations. As illustrated in Fig. 7 , the QCA cell power located in a binary wire is divided into the four main signal flows. As demonstrated in [27,31], the horizontal signal powers are equal, where P i n is the attained signal power from the left neighboring cell and P o u t is the released signal power to the right side cell. As mentioned earlier, in the switch phase, inter-dot barriers are slowly raised causing to transfer of a large amount of energy to the cell ( P c l o c k ) and in the release phase, these barriers are fallen, consequently, the energy is returned to the clocking circuit. Therefore, there is a negligible power dissipation in a clocking circuit called P d i s s [16,29]. Furthermore, instantaneous total power equation for a single QCA cell is obtained as: (5) P i = d E d t = ℏ 2 d Γ → d t . λ → + ℏ 2 Γ → . d λ → d t = P 1 + P 2 Where P 1 includes two main components: first, the power is attained from the difference of the input and output signal powers ( P i n - P o u t ), second, the transferred clocking power to the cell ( P c l o c k ). Also, P2 represents P d i s s [31]. Based on [27], the energy dissipation in one clock cycle, T c c = - T , T , can be represented as Hamiltonian and Coherence vectors [27]: (6) E d i s s = ℏ 2 ∫ - T T Γ → . d λ → d t d t = ℏ 2 Γ → . λ → - T T - ∫ - T T λ → . d Γ → d t d t It is notable that extreme energy dissipation will occur when the changing rate of Γ → is maximum. So, by representing Γ → - and Γ → + as Γ → ( + T ) and Γ → ( - T ) , the upper bound power dissipation model is given as [31]: (7) P d i s s = E d i s s T C C < ℏ 2 T C C Γ → + × - Γ → + Γ → + t a n h ℏ Γ → + K B T + Γ → - Γ → _ t a n h ℏ Γ → _ K B T Where kB represents the Boltzmann constant and T represents the temperature. In an array of similar QCA cells, the total dissipated power can be calculated by adding the dissipated power of all cells when each QCA cell have the same presented model [29,32]. 2.3 QCA–based decoder designs Researchers have made several attempts to design efficient QCA-based decoders. The construction of 4-to-16 decoder relies on a modular design methodology which is proposed in [32]. The latency of this decoder is only five clock cycles. A solution is suggested to the problem by symmetrical fan out where there is no wire crossing. Five 2-to-4 decoders in a tree structure are required to build a 4-to-16 decoder using AND, and delay (modular) blocks. Eight 2-input AND gates are used in each decoder. Enabling or disabling output is possible via four of eight AND gates. Three-input majority gates perform a 2-to-4 decoder. Three additional A, B, and EN rails and four additional 2-input AND gates have made the circuit structure and a decoder to be the same. The logical functionality is as follows: If the enable rail is high (logic ‘1’), it activates the 2-to-4 decoder as normal operation; otherwise, it deactivates the decoder and forces all outputs to logic ‘0’. The top rail carries the signal EN, middle rail carries the signal B, and lower rail carries the signal A. Inversion chains are used to invert A and B. A single clock zone can use three or more rails with coplanar interconnections. 318 cells are used for each 2-to-4 decoder. The 2-to-4 decoder that is used in design has a high cell number and AND gates. The operation of the 2-to-4 decoder of this design takes one clock cycle. In [33], a new modular-based design methodology is presented for QCA. The basic block of QCA cells for logic computation is considered as a tile. In general, a tile can have many different topologies in the QCA layout. For generating stable and synthesis-amenable logic functions, a tile must have the following features: (1) logic functions must have flexible tile at high polarization level. The interactions from unwanted external cells are limited by strong tile. (2) Signals should be routed easily between and among tiles such as Manhattan strategy. (3) A tile should have stable signals, in which an output should not suffer from the lack of polarization or the presence of a glitch. The non-fully populated tile is defined as a tile in which one or more QCA cells are undeposited. By adding input and output cells to the 3 × 3 grid, five different tiles can be constructed. The 3 × 3 grid occupies the same area in the layout as an inverter voter or majority voter (with no input/output cells). Three majority voter gates present the QCA-based decoder. Three baseline tiles, seven double fan-out tiles, six orthogonal tiles are also used in this design. The interconnection tiles as wires are used to connect these tiles. The 2-to-4 decoder using the 3 × 3 grid as part of the tile achieves a reduction in an area and in the number of clocking zones. This design has 588 cells. A 4-to-16 decoder in [7] has five-layered structure. The inputs are placed in the middle layer (layer 3) moving up and down. A 7-input majority gate is used as 4-input AND gate in the decoder design. For each different input, the decoder gives 16 different outputs (0–15), which address the memory cells. There is the same clock vertically in all layers due to layer clocking. The decoder of one clock cycle has low latency in comparison with other decoders. The cell count and latency are reduced by high input majority gates in different layers compared to other designs. Furthermore, developing XOR gate in order to design a 2-to-4 decoder has been proposed in [34]. The synchronization of the entire circuit requires 4 clock zones or 1 clock cycle. In this design, the outputs of any majority voter act as the input to the next majority voter at the same clock zone. Thus, the entire circuit has low latency. The performance of 3 to 8 decoder requires the extension of decoder module. The AND operation is derived from 2 to 4 decoder modules to achieve the outputs of the proposed 3 to 8 decoder. The third input in the form of non-inverted and inverted perform AND operations through QCA wires with each of the previously arrived components to derive corresponding outputs. Here, the inputs and outputs of the circuit need wire crossings to be extended. The synchronization of operations needs total 8 clock zones (2 clock cycles). The 4-to-16 counterpart requires similar operations to be carried. This designing decoder results in reducing cell count, wire-crossing, and delay. Finally, in [18], the 3-input majority gate in QCA is used to design the circuit of the 2-to-4 decoder which has eight majority gates. A 5-input majority gate is needed for performing a logical 2-to-4 decoder [14] in QCA. The delay and complexity in the circuit are increased by eight majority gates using traditional methods. Four 5-input majority gates are included in the implemented decoder arrayed as AND. This circuit reaches the output in 7 clock phases (1.75 clock cycles) and includes two inputs and an enabled input. When the EN input is inactive (EN = 0), all output will be passive. When the EN is active (EN = 1), the outputs will appear with respect to inputs A and B. High consistency in the output is provided by the decoder and it becomes a controllable module by EN input 268 cells are included in the 2-to-5 decoder to cover an area of 0.3 lm2. Table 1 shows the performance of the reviewed QCA-based decoder design in terms of area, clock zones, and cell complexity. 3 Proposed design Decoders play a significant role in digital constructions. The look-up table of the 2-to-4 decoder is shown in Table 2 . The logical functionality is as follows: The 2-to-4 decoder is activated as the normal operation when there is high enable rail (logic 1); otherwise, the decoder is deactivated and forces all outputs to logic ‘0’. The top rail carries signal EN, the middle rail carries signal B, and lower rail carry signal A. An initial attempt to design an efficient 2-to-4 decoder is reported in [18]. Five-input majority gates are required for its performance presented in [14]. It assumes seven clock zones. A design with three clock zones is proposed to make it more efficient with less delay. It requires four 5-majority gates and two inverters as shown in Fig. 8 . According to Fig. 8, the proposed decoder is composed of two separate blocks. The first block includes inputs and inverter gate, and the other block includes a five-input majority generates the o u t p u t signal. All of these blocks are implemented in a single layer design. This QCA-based design uses 200 quantum cells. It uses both types of 90° and 45° cell and also reverse Chinese is done. Fig. 9 shows an inversion chain. Each cell in an inversion chain gets its logical value from the previous cell due to coulomb interaction. Inversion chains are suitable for developing bus rails with perpendicularly tapped normal wires as shown in Fig. 9. The placement of the tap defines whether the output X is simply buffered (Fig. 9a) or inverted (Fig. 9b) based on the input A. Also, Fig. 10 shows a majority voter which is used in the proposed structure. This method considers five inputs labeled A, B, C, D, and E, and the output cell which is shown by out. Furthermore, four middle cells labeled 1, 2, 3 and 4 are considered. The input cells have fixed polarization and middle cells and output cell are changeable. In this design, the input cell A only has an effect on middle cell 1. Also, the input cells B and C have only effect on 1, 2, 3 and on 1, 3, 4 middle cells, respectively. In a similar manner, the input cells D and E have an effect on middle cells 2 and 4. The production of five-input majority gate is due to the movement of the majority decision of inputs to the output. This design has coplanar wire crossing. All the inputs (A, B, and EN) are placed in one clock zone, the inputs of majority gates are placed in other clock and the majority gate and output of majority gate are placed in another clock zone. 4 Results The proposed QCA full adder is simulated by means of QCADesigner version 2.0.3 tool and QCAPro. The QCADesigner and QCApro are given in the rest of this section. The simulated parameters are presented in Section 4.2, and 4.3 describes the simulation of the proposed design. The results of the simulation are shown in section 4.4. The comparative results and analysis of energy are described in Sections 4.5 and 4.6, respectively. 4.1 Simulation tools The benefits of different simulation engines are discussed in [36]. QCADesigner is considered as one of these engines to create a rapid and accurate simulation and layout tool for QCA [36]. It is capable of simulating complex QCA circuits on most standard platforms [37,38]. The QCADesigner has been developed at the ATIPS Laboratory of the University of Calgary. This developed project has the ability to be collected and used on a wide range of systems. This project aims to create an easy to use simulation and layout tool accessible freely to the research community via the Internet. The developers are able to join their own utilities into QCADesigner using this design. A standardized method of representing information within the software is provided to complete the project. A standardized calling scheme and data types are needed to combine the simulation engines into QCADesigner [36]. Three simulation engines are included in the present version of QCADesigner. A digital logic simulator as the first simulator considers cells to be either null or fully polarized. The second is a nonlinear approximation engine, which employs the nonlinear cell-to-cell response function to iteratively control the stable state of the cells within a design. A two-state Hamiltonian is used by the third to form an approximation of the full quantum mechanical model of a system [36]. The error and power dissipation in QCA circuit design are estimated by QCAPro [31]. A fast approximation based technique is used to estimate false cells in QCA circuit design [16]. An average, maximum and minimum power loss in a QCA circuit are evaluated by QCAPro during an input switching operation. In this regard, a good platform is offered for researchers who wish to study polarization error and power dissipation related issues in QCA circuits [36]. The tool checks a design and also estimates polarization error at each of the QCA cell for a particular input vector [27]. The output in textual and graphical formats is provided via QCAPro. The correctness of the proposed designs and the estimation of their power consumptions are evaluated by QCADesigner and QCAPro. 4.2 Simulation parameters The simulation engine in QCADesigner must be set to coherence vector type using simulation parameters. Most of these parameters are default values in QCADesigner. A brief description of each parameter used for a simulation engine is shown in Table 3 . 4.3 Design simulation The simulation of the 2-to-4 decoder based QCA with five majority gates is discussed in this section. Fig. 11. shows the layout of the 2-to-4 decoder in QCADesigner. The colored logic elements indicate the different clock zones in Fig. 11. Each of the A, B, and EN inputs are placed in different clock zones. This QCA-based design has 193 quantum cells. It uses both types of 90° and 45° cell and also reverses Chinese is done. This design has coplanar wire crossing to build a 3-to-8 decoder using two 2-to-4 decoders. 4.4 Accuracy analyses The simulation result for the proposed decoder is shown in Fig. 12. The QCA Designer version 2.0.3 with stated default parameters is used to simulate and verify the 2-to-4 decoder in bistable approximation. In this design, A, B, and EN are labeled out1, out2, out3, and out4, respectively. When input cells A, B, and EN have logic 1 values, out4 will have logic 1 values and other outs have logic 0 values. The proposed QCAdecoder works well and has an appropriate performance based on simulation results. 4.5 Comparative results Table 4 describes a comparison between the proposed 2-to-4 decoder gate and the state-of-the-art designs. A great progress happens in cell count (complexity) and the area in comparison to the previous single/multilayer designs. 200 QCA cells are used in the proposed design whereas two good designs use 268 QCA cells as shown in [3]. It shows 75% improvements. The proposed circuit has a low area of the layout. The needed delay for moving the input signals to the output is three which is the minimum clock phase. Therefore, three factors, including area, complexity, and delay are considered to increase the proposed decoder. The QCA cells should be formed and arranged in a way to achieve an efficient and high-performance implementation. Also, the output places are surrounded by other cells, so there is no need of wire crossover to feed into the other circuits. 4.6 Power analyses The highly pipelined architectures with extremely high speed are proposed by QCA computational paradigm. The molecular QCA can be faster than 2.5 THz and theoretically, processing speed may reach to 25 THz [39]. The kink energy plays a major function in power estimation due to its direct and inverse relation with power dissipation and steady-state polarization error. Three different tunneling energy levels, including 0.5 E k , 1 E k , a n d 1.5 E k are used to evaluate the proposed design as well as the previous structures at 2 K temperature. The QCAPro environment is used to perform the power dissipation process. Fig. 13 shows the power dissipation of presented decoder in [18] and the map of the proposed decoder with 0.5 E k is shown in Fig. 14 . A temperature factor is stable in this context. The dimension of the QCA cell, as well as the spacing between the adjacent cells, are changed via the kink energy. The sharp clock transitions are required to compute the power loss in a QCA circuit in [30]. It results in non-adiabatic operations and yields the upper bound of power consumption [31,40]. The thermal layout for average power dissipation at each cell in the 2-to-4 decoder is illustrated in Fig. 14. The worst thermal hot spots in the design are shown by a black mark. The weak spots are considered as the logic cell of the majority voters in the decoder. The dissipation of maximum power (averaged over all input combinations) by hot spots is required to form a thermally stable/tolerant design. Table 5 shows the effect of varying kink energy on the power dissipation through a switching event from one clock zone to other in a decoder circuit. The leakage and switching energies for the proposed decoder and the presented decoder in [18] are shown in Table 5. The kink energy in a circuit and the overall average power dissipation have close relationships. The kink energy improves the output node polarization error but reduces the power dissipation. The average leakage energies of the presented decoder in [18] and the proposed decoder are shown in Fig. 15 . The proposed decoder is better than the presented design in [18] based on the obtained result where it has less leakage energy. Fig. 16 illustrates that the proposed decoder has less switching energy than the presented decoder in [18] by modifying the level of the tunneling energy. 5 Conclusion and future work A new methodology has been proposed to design a modular decoder using QCA technology, which is better than the existing modular decoder in terms of a number of cells, clock zones, and wire-crossings. This study explores a modular approach in designing the higher order decoder by cascading lower order decoders. The rate of power dissipation and output node polarization error should be reduced to ensure a low power modular design. Therefore, designing circuits with less number of cells and complexity are considered as one of the problems. Providing methods such as multi-level designing are helpful to reduce the complexity. At the same time, the fault tolerance of the proposed circuit can be improved in terms of different aspects. Finally, it is possible to offer some solutions to reduce delay. Conflicts of interest None

column2: Conditions required to make gauge-invariant the electromagnetic spin and orbital angular momenta and helicity densities in isotropic and anisotropic media
column3: Abstract The spin and orbital angular momenta densities ( s n and l n ) and helicity density (hn ) of the electro- magnetic (EM) fields are defined using an electric vector potential C in analogy with the magnetic vector potential A , where C is introduced to observe the duality invariance and electric-magnetic democracy. However, their definitions for s n , l n and hn have an essential drawback (lacking for the gauge invariance) that they vary widely depending on the choice of two kinds of A and C . To solve this problem, it is necessary to make s n , l n and hn gauge-invariant. The gauge invariance for s n , l n and hn in isotropic and anisotropic media can be established by an appropriate combination of gauge functions and scalar potentials. As a result, it is proved in a distinct way from the second quantization procedure that the gauge invariance for s n and l n depending on the phase difference between A and C leads to the quantization of electromagnetic spin. Moreover, the gauge-invariant hn gives a reasonable explanation for the Faraday rotation caused in an anisotropic medium.
column5: PACS 03.50.De 41.20.Jb 42.25.Bs Keywords Electromagnetic wave Spin angular momentum Orbital angular momentum Gauge invariance Helicity 1 Introduction The angular momentum (AM) carried by light can be characterized by the spin angular momentum (SAM) associated with the circular polarization (CP) and orbital angular momentum (OAM) associated with the spatial distribution of the electromagnetic (EM) wave. In practice, both SAM and OAM of a light beam have been measured [1–3]. Theoretically, the old SAM and OAM densities have been defined as s o  = ( D ×  A ) and l o  = Σ i = x , y Di ( r × ∇)Ai for the transverse plane EM waves propagating along the z axis, where the symbol ∇ is the gradient operator, D is the electric induction field and A is the magnetic vector potential defined as B  = ∇ ×  A , where B is the magnetic induction field [4–7].The SAM arises in the transverse plane EM waves, while the OAM never appears there. When the phase gradient satisfies certain conditions providing the transverse energy circulation within the beam, however, the OAM arises sometimes [8,9].On the other hand, the old helicity density ho has been defined as ho  =  H ∙ A for the transverse plane EM waves traveling along the z axis, where H is the magnetic field [10]. The old SAM density s o  = ( D  ×  A ) defined above for the transverse plane EM waves traveling along the z axis does not contain the D and B fields equivalently, resulting in the breakdown of the electric-magnetic democracy [5]. The same applies to the helicity density ho  =  H ∙ A , because E and H fields are not included equivalently in ho . For this reason, the SAM ( s n ), OAM ( l n ) and helicity (hn ) densities are defined here as s n  = [( D  ×  A ) + ( C  ×  B )]/2, l n  = Σ j  =  x, y, z [Dj ( r  × ∇)Aj  − Bj ( r  × ∇)Cj ]/2 and hn  = ( A ∙ H  +  C ∙ E )/2 for the optical fields, to leave invariant under the duality transformations of ( E , H ) ↔ ( H ,−), ( D , B ) ↔ ( B ,−) and ( A , C ) ↔ (− C , A ) which result from the interchange of the electricity and magnetism [11], where E is the electric field and D is defined as D  = ∇ ×  C using an electric vector potential C . There are also similar definitions for the spin density s d and helicity density hd in the dual electromagnetism [12–14]. However, s d and hd are inapplicable to anisotropic media, because they originate basically from the free-field Maxwell’s equations. It will be shown here that hn defined here gives a reasonable explanation for the Faraday rotation caused in an optically active medium [15]. As is clear from the total angular momentum density j defined as j =  r  × ( D  ×  B ) for the optical fields [13], j is invariant under the gauge transformation, but both s o and l o generated [5,6,14] by the partial integration of j due to the introduction of the vector potential A lack generally a gauge invariance. Even if s o and l o are improved to have both duality invariance and electric-magnetic democracy, their gauge invariances are not recovered at all. This is because the physical quantities of s n , l n and hn which are defined above vary significantly depending on the choice of two kinds of A and C . In general, the observable physical quantity must be invariant under the gauge transformation. For this reason, it is investigated here whether the gauge invariances for s n , l n and hn can be established by an appropriate combination of gauge functions and scalar potentials contributing to A and C and what conditions are required to acquire the gauge invariance in isotropic and anisotropic media. The first purpose of this study is to find the conditions required to make s n , l n and hn gauge-invariant, and the second one is to show that hn gives a reasonable explanation for the Faraday rotation occurring in an anisotropic (opticall active) medium. 2 Analysis 2.1 Maxwell’s equations The Maxwell equations for the EM fields in the absence of free charges or electric currents are given in SI units by [16] (1) ∇ × E = − ∂ B ∂ t , (2) ∇ × H = − ∂ D ∂ t , (3) ∇ ⋅ B = 0 (4) ∇ ⋅ D = 0 where the electric D and magnetic B inductions are related to the field strengths E and H through D  = ε E and B  = μ H , where ε and μ represent the permittivity and permeability tensors, respectively. Maxwell’s equations in the absence of free charges or electric currents are invariant by putting ( E , H ) → ( H , – E ) and ( D , B ) → ( B , – D ) in the optical fields. This duality transformation leaves quadratic forms such as ( E  ×  H ), ( E · D  +  H · B ) and the components of the Maxwell stress tensor Tij invariant, where i, j = x, y and z [16]. The Maxwell’s equations have an important feature that they are invariant under the duality and gauge transformations. 2.2 Old spin and orbital angular momenta in an isotropic medium The total angular momentum J of the EM fields has been defined as [16] (5) J = ∫ τ r × D × B dv = ∫ τ j d v in analogy to the interpretation of the linear momentum density ( D  ×  B ), where j is the angular momentum density and is gauge-invariant. Here a medium is assumed to be loss-free and homogeneous. This definition is invariant under the duality transformation and is valid at least when the medium is linear but not necessarily isotropic in its response. The magnetic induction field B is expressed by the magnetic vector potential A as [16] (6) B = ∇ × A . By substituting Eq. (6) into Eq. (5), the old SAM ( S o ) and OAM ( L o ) for EM waves traveling along the z direction in an isotropic medium have been described as [4–7] (7) S o = ∫ τ d v s o = ∫ τ d v D × A and (8) L o = ∫ τ dv l o = ∫ τ dv Σ j = x , y , z D j ( r × ∇ ) A j , where τ is a volume integrated over the wave packet along the trajectory. As is clear from Eqs.(7) and (8), the old SAM and OAM densities ( s o and l o ) do not contain equivalently D and B fields, resulting in the breakdown of the electric-magnetic democracy. This is because D and B fields are not treated on equivalent footing in defining s o and l o . The electric field E is expressed by substituting Eq. (6) into Eq. (1) as [16] (9) E = − ∂ A ∂ t − ∇ φ , where φ is the electric scalar potential dependent on position and time. It is possible to transform the vector and scalar potentials ( A 0 and φ 0) into another pair ( A and φ) by means of the simultaneous gauge transformations, leaving the EM fields invariant; (10) A = A 0 + ∇ u , (11) φ = φ 0 − ∂ u ∂ t , where u is an arbitrary scalar function which is called a gauge function [16]. The physical quantities independent of the gauge function are said to be gauge-invariant. Basically, all physical observables are required to be gauge-invariant. If A 0 and φ 0 are respectively the vector and scalar potentials intrinsic to describe the EM fields, the vector and scalar potentials ( A and φ) generated newly by means of the simultaneous gauge transformations also produce the same fields as the original ones. Two pairs of ( A , φ) and ( A 0, φ 0) are then called gauge-equivalent, so that E can be expressed using A 0 and φ 0 as (12) E = − ∂ A 0 ∂ t − ∇ φ . When the transverse plane EM waves are traveling linearly in an isotropic medium, S o and L o are effectively decoupled, because the intrinsic L o vanishes completely for transverse plane waves. In general, the old s o and l o vary significantly depending on the choice of A and φ, so that they are gauge-variant. This cause for lacking the gauge invariance is that only one kind of vector potential is included in the old definitions of the SAM and OAM densities, leading to a lack of the electric-magnetic democracy. 2.3 New spin and orbital angular momenta in an isotropic medium In order to define newly the SAM and OAM densities for the transverse plane EM waves traveling in an isotropic medium, we have introduced an electric vector potential C defined as [11,17] (13) D = ∇ × C . This replacement of the electric flux density D with the electric vector potential C is permitted in the optical fields. Substituting Eqs. (6) and (13) into Eq. (5) separately and dividing their summation by two, the total angular momentum J n is expressed as (14) J n = S n + L n , where (15) S n = ∫ τ d v s n = 1 2 ∫ τ d v [ ( D × A ) + ( C × B ) ] and (16) L n = ∫ τ d v l n = 1 2 ∫ τ d v Σ j = x , y , z [ D j ( r × ∇ ) A j – B j ( r × ∇ ) C j ] , where S n and L n are integrated over the wave packet along the trajectory and s n and l n are new SAM and OAM densities, respectively [11]. Substituting Eq. (13) into Eq. (2), the magnetic field H is expressed as (17) H = ∂ C ∂ t − ∇ ψ . in a similar expression to Eq. (9), where ψ is the magnetic scalar potential. It is possible to transform the vectors and scalar potentials ( C 0 and ψ 0) into another pair ( C and ψ) so as not to change the EM fields by means of the following gauge transformations (18) C = C 0 – ∇ υ , (19) ψ = ψ 0 ∂ υ ∂ t where υ is an arbitrary gauge function analogous to u. If C 0 and ψ 0 bring forth an optical field, the vector and scalar potentials ( C and ψ) generated by means of the gauge transformations also produce the same optical field for any function of υ, leaving s n and l n invariant. The gauge equivalence is also established for ( C , ψ) and ( C 0, ψ 0), so that H can be expressed using C 0 and ψ 0 as (20) H = ∂ C 0 ∂ t – ∇ ψ 0 . When Eqs. (14) and (15) contain D and B equivalently, both s n and l n can be invariant under the duality transformation such as ( D , B ) → ( B , – D ) and ( A , C ) → (– C , A ) [11]. The requirement of the duality invariance results from the observance of the electric-magnetic democracy. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 The gauge transformations of s n and l n in an isotropic medium 3.1.1 s n It is investigated in this section what conditions are necessary to make s n and l n gauge-invariant for the transverse plane EM waves traveling in an isotropic medium. The SAM density s n defined for the optical fields is expressed as [11,17] (21) s n = 1 2 [ ( D × A ) + ( C × B ) ] , where D =ε 0 E and B =μ 0 H . Using these relations, s n is expressed as functions of electric and magnetic vector potentials and their vector fields as (22) s n = 1 2 [ ε 0 ( E × A ) + μ 0 ( C × H ) ] . Further substitutions of Eqs. (10), (12), (18) and (20) into Eq. (22) yield the following expression (23) s n = 1 2 { [ ε 0 ( A 0 × ∂ A 0 ∂ t ) + μ 0 ( C 0 × ∂ C 0 ∂ t ) ] + [ ε 0 ( ∇ u × ∂ A 0 ∂ t ) + μ 0 ( ∂ C 0 ∂ t × ∇ υ ) ] + [ ε 0 ( A 0 × ∇ φ 0 ) + μ 0 ( ∇ ψ 0 × C 0 ) ] } = s e + s g , where (24) s g = 1 2 [ ε 0 ( A 0 × ∂ A 0 ∂ t ) + μ 0 ( C 0 × ∂ C 0 ∂ t ) ] and (25) s g = 1 2 { [ ε 0 ( ∇ u × ∂ A 0 ∂ t ) + μ 0 ( ∂ C 0 ∂ t × ∇ υ ) ] + [ ε 0 ( A 0 × ∇ φ 0 ) + μ 0 ( ∇ ψ 0 × C 0 ) ] } , where s e is the effective SAM density and s g is the apparent SAM density associated with the gauge and scalar functions. It should be noted here that A 0 and C 0 are intrinsic vector potentials indispensable to reproduce the optical fields exactly. Here, two cross products (∇ φ 0 × ∇ u) and (∇ υ × ∇ ψ 0) appeared on the right hand side of Eq. (25) are dropped because the vector products between the same gradient operators vanish. The two terms in the former bracket on the right hand side of Eq. (25) are associated directly with gauge functions u and υ, and two terms in the latter one are related with indefinite scalar potentials φ 0 and ψ 0. Now the condition necessary to make s n gauge-invariant is that s g disappears but s e survives for any combination of A 0 and C 0. In other words, s g disappears necessarily when the inner products of ( s g · A 0) and ( s g · C 0) become equal to zero simultaneously. Using a simple vector algebra, their conditions are expressed as (26) ( s g · A 0 ) = μ 0 ( C 0 × A 0 ) ∇ ψ 0 + μ 0 ( A 0 × ∂ C 0 ∂ t × C 0 ) ∇ υ + ε 0 ( ∂ A 0 ∂ t × A 0 ) ∇ u = 0 and (27) ( s g · C 0 ) = ε 0 ( C 0 × A 0 ) ∇ φ 0 + ε 0 ( ∂ A 0 ∂ t × C 0 ) ∇ u + μ 0 ( C 0 × ∂ C 0 ∂ t ∇ υ = 0. Dividing Eq. (26) by E 0 and Eq. (27) by H 0, both expressions have the same physical unit. In order to take a phase difference between Eqs. (26) and (27) into account, after multiplying Eq. (26) by a phase factor ei α and adding it to Eq. (27), the following expression is obtained as (28) ( μ 0 E 0 e i a ∇ ψ 0 + ε 0 H 0 ∇ φ 0 ) ⋅ ( C 0 × A 0 ) – ( A 0 E 0 e i a + C 0 H 0 ) × ( μ 0 ∇ υ × ∂ C 0 ∂ t – ε 0 ∇ u × ∂ A 0 ∂ t ) = 0 , where α is a phase difference between A 0 and C 0. In order for this equation to establish under any condition, therefore, it is necessary to disappear four parentheses in Eq. (28). For this reason, to begin with, two parentheses which are associated with a set of φ 0 and ψ 0 and that of u and υ in Eq. (28) need to satisfy simultaneously the following two equations (29) ( μ 0 E 0 e i a ∇ ψ 0 + ε 0 H 0 ∇ φ 0 ) = 0 and (30) ( μ 0 ∇ υ × ∂ C 0 ∂ t – ε 0 ∇ u × ∂ A 0 ∂ t ) = 0. When these two equations are not satisfied at the same time, however, it is further necessary to satisfy simultaneously the following two equations including only a set of A 0 and C 0 in Eq. (28), (31) ( C 0 × A 0 ) = 0 and (32) ( A 0 E 0 e i a + C 0 H 0 ) = 0. By multiplying Eq. (32) by A 0 and by C 0, respectively, and summing up them after some manipulations, the following equation is derived as (33) ( A 0 · C 0 ) ( e i α E 0 + e − i α H 0 ) + [ ( A 0 · A 0 ) E 0 + ( C 0 · C 0 ) H 0 ] = 0. In general, the complex vectors and real vectors have completely different properties. For example, in real vector algebra, ( A 0· A 0) = 0 implies A 0 = 0, while in complex vector algebra, A 0 represents the circular polarization (CP). If the complex vectors A 0 and C 0 satisfy simultaneously ( C 0 ×  A 0) = 0 and ( A 0· C 0) = ( A 0· A 0) = ( C 0· C 0) = 0 in Eqs. (31) and (33), they are CP and multiplies of each other [18]. It means that A 0 and C 0 form a circular polarization with a phase difference α. Substituting C 0 derived from Eq. (32) into Eq. (30), ∇ u and ∇ υ are linked to each other as (34) ( μ 0 E 0 e i α ∇ υ + ε 0 H 0 ∇ u ) = 0. The combination of Eq. (29) and Eq. (34) yields (35) ∇ u · ∇ ψ 0 = ∇ υ · ∇ φ 0 . This is just a condition that s g disappears, i.e., a condition that makes s n and hn gauge-invariant for the transverse plane EM waves propagating linearly in an isotropic medium. It also leads to the demonstration of the gauge invariance for the helicity density hn , as shown in Appendix A. These results are listed in Table 1 . For example, the condition of ∇ u = ∇ υ = ∇ ψ 0 = ∇ φ 0 = 0 meeting to Eq. (35) is indeed referred to as the radiation gauge [16]. While Eq. (35) is fulfilled, therefore, the gauge invariance holds for s n in an isotropic medium, despite the phase difference (α) between A 0 and C 0 is indefinite. The acquirement of this gauge invariance for s n is attributed to the presence of two kinds of vector potentials ( A 0 and C 0), because s g survives without disappearing in the presence of the sole magnetic vector potential A 0. When s g  = 0, however, s n can be described exactly by only two kinds of vector potentials ( A 0 and C 0) without u, υ, φ 0 and ψ 0. 3.1.2 l n As mentioned above, the OAM density l n defined here is expressed as (36) l n = 1 2 Σ j = x , y , z [ D j ( r × ∇ ) A j – B j ( r × ∇ ) C j ] . If the EM fields are composed of the transverse plane EM waves propagating along the z axis, all of E , H , A and C fields are rotating around the optical axis in the x-y plane and have no component along the z axis. However, some of the electric and magnetic field components of their fields based on scalar potentials should have z component at least when the gauge invariance of l n is established. In such EM fields, therefore, Eq. (36) can be decomposed into two components of effective OAM density l e and apparent OAM density l g which are respectively perpendicular and parallel to the z axis, regardless of whether a medium is isotropic or anisotropic. Under such conditions, D and B fields can be derived from Eqs.(12) and (20) as (37) D j = x , y = – ε 0 ∂ A 0 j / ∂ t , B j = x , y = μ 0 ∂ A 0 j / ∂ t , D z = – ε 0 ∇ φ 0 , B z = – μ 0 ∇ ψ 0 , where the symbol ∇ is a scalar operator which denotes a derivative of ∂/∂z. Substituting Eq. (37) into Eq. (36), l n is decomposed into two parts of l e (associated with a set of A 0 and C 0) and l g (associated with a series of φ 0, ψ 0, u and υ) as (38) l n = – 1 2 { Σ j = x , y [ ε 0 ∂ A 0 j ∂ t ( r × ∇ ) A 0 j + μ 0 ∂ C 0 j ∂ t ( r × ∇ ) C 0 j ] + [ ε 0 ∇ φ 0 ( r × ∇ ) ∇ u + μ 0 ∇ ψ 0 ( r × ∇ ) ∇ υ ] } (39) = l e + l g . When l g  = 0, therefore, l n becomes gauge-invariant only when it can be described by only two kinds of vector potentials ( A 0 and C 0). Next, we investigate here what conditions are necessary to disappear l g in an isotropic medium. For the transverse plane EM waves propagating along the z axis, l g is derived from Eq. (38) as (40) l g = 1 2 ( y e 1 – x e 2 ) ( ε 0 ∇ φ 0 Δ u + μ 0 ∇ ψ 0 Δ υ ) , where the symbol Δ denotes a second derivative of ∂2/∂z 2. The substitution of Eq. (34) into Eq. (40) yields (41) l g = 1 2 ( y e 1 – x e 2 ) μ 0 Δ υ ( ∇ ψ 0 – H 0 E 0 e i α ∇ φ 0 ) . Further substitutions of ∇φ 0 and ∇ψ 0 derived from Eq. (29) into Eq. (41) produce (42) l g = 1 2 ( y e 1 – x e 2 ) μ 0 Δ υ ∇ ψ 0 ( 1 + e i 2 α ) = 1 2 ( y e 1 – x e 2 ) ε 0 Δ u ∇ φ 0 ( 1 + e − i 2 α ) . When any one of ∇ψ 0 = ∇φ 0 = 0, ∇u = ∇υ = 0 and ei 2 α  = –1 holds, Eq. (42) gets to zero. When any one of the former two conditions holds, l g disappears regardless of the value of α. The last condition (ei 2 α  = –1) among them leads to the quantization (α = ±π/2) of the phase difference between A 0 and C 0 in an isotropic medium. This is quite the same as the condition required for the gauge invariance of s n in an anisotropic medium, as will be shown later. In a homogeneous isotropic medium, when l g  = 0, l n (= l e ) can then be expressed by either a set of ∂ A 0/∂t and ∂ C 0/∂t or a set of E and H as (43) l g = ε 0 μ 0 ( ∂ C 0 ∂ t × ∂ A 0 ∂ t ) z ( y e 1 – x e 2 ) = ε 0 μ 0 E × H z ( y e 1 – x e 2 ) . It is thus found that when l g  = 0, l n also becomes invariant under the simultaneous gauge transformations in a homogeneous isotropic medium, like s n . 3.2 The gauge transformations of s n and l n in an anisotropic (optically active) medium 3.2.1 s n It is examined in this subsection what conditions are necessary to make s n and l n gauge-invariant in an anisotropic (optically active) medium. Here we consider the incident plane wave to be a superposition of the right circularly polarized (RCP) and left circularly polarized (LCP) waves with equal amplitude. The complex ε and μ tensors of a uniaxial medium with threefold or higher rotational symmetry about the z axis are represented by Hermite matrices as (44) ε = ε 0 – i ε 1 0 + i ε 1 ε 0 0 0 0 ε z and μ = μ 0 – i κ 0 + i κ μ 0 0 0 0 μ z , where the symbols ε 0, ε 1, μ 0 and κ are adopted to conform to accepted conventions and εz and μz are z component of their tensors [19]. When the linearly polarized incident wave traveling along the z axis entered such a medium, it splits to the RCP and LCP waves in a medium [20]. The circulating vectors (such as Er and Eℓ ) with the subscripts “r” and “ℓ” represent clockwise and counterclockwise rotations in the x-y plane, respectively, when the plane is viewed from –z to +z direction. The D and B induction fields in such a medium are expressed as (45) D = Σ i , j = x , y ε i j E j e i And (46) B = Σ i , j = x , y μ i j H j e i . where εij and μij are the complex ε and μ tensors described in Eq. (44). The substitutions of Eqs. (45) and (46) into Eq. (21) yield (47) s n = 1 2 { [ ε 0 ( E × A ) + μ 0 ( C × H ) + i κ C · H – ε 1 E · A ] e 3 } . where e 3 is a unit vector pointing in the z direction. Further substitutions of Eqs. (10), (12), (18) and (20) into Eq. (47) give (48) s n = s e + s g + s a , where s e and s g are respectively expressed by Eqs. (24) and (25) and s a is the anisotropic spin density associated with non-diagonal elements (ε 1 and κ) which is expressed as (49) s a = 1 2 [ κ ( ∂ C 0 ∂ t · C 0 + ∇ ψ 0 · ∇ υ ) + ε 1 ( ∂ A 0 ∂ t · A 0 + ∇ φ 0 · ∇ u ) ] e 3 , where all terms of ∇ φ 0· C 0, ∇ υ·∂ C 0/∂t, ∇ ψ 0· A 0 and ∇ u·∂ A 0/∂t are dropped because of inner products between orthogonal vectors. Substituting Eqs. (29), (32) and (34) into Eq. (49), it is rewritten using either a set of A 0, ∇ φ 0 and ∇ u or a set of C 0, ∇ ψ 0 and ∇ υ as (50) s a = i 2 μ 0 ( κ · ε 0 e i 2 α + ε 1 · μ 0 ) ( ∂ A 0 ∂ t · A 0 + ∇ φ 0 · ∇ u ) e 3 and (51) s a = i 2 ε 0 e − i 2 α ( κ · ε 0 e i 2 α + ε 1 · μ 0 ) ( ∂ C 0 ∂ t · C 0 + ∇ ψ 0 · ∇ υ ) e 3 . In order to make s n gauge-invariant in an optically active medium, it is necessary to vanish s a . When α satisfies (κ·ε 0 ei 2 α +ε 1·μ 0) = 0 in Eqs. (50) and (51), s a disappears regardless of the vector and scalar potentials and gauge functions, so that the gauge invariance of s n is established in an anisotropic medium. When (κ·ε 0 ei 2 α +ε 1·μ 0) ≠0, however, the following two conditions need to be fulfilled simultaneously to make s n gauge-invaraint (52) ∂ C 0 ∂ t · C 0 + ∇ ψ 0 · ∇ υ = 0 and (53) ∂ A 0 ∂ t · A 0 + ∇ φ 0 · ∇ u = 0. The substitution of C 0 derived from Eq. (32) into Eq. (52) yields (54) ε 0 μ 0 ∂ A 0 ∂ t A 0 e i 2 α + ∇ ψ 0 · ∇ υ = 0 , where we made use of the relation (H 0 /E 0) = (ε 0 /μ 0)1/2 [11]. Further substitution of (∂ A 0/∂t)· A 0 derived from Eq. (53) into Eq. (54) produces (55) ε 0 μ 0 e i 2 α – ∇ ψ 0 ∇ φ 0 ∇ υ ∇ u = 0. The combination of Eq. (55) with Eq. (35) yields (56) ε 0 μ 0 e i 2 α – ( ∇ υ ) 2 ( ∇ u ) 2 = ε 0 μ 0 ( e i 2 α – e − i 2 α ) = 0 , where we made use of the relation [∇ υ/∇ u = –(ε 0 /μ 0)1/2 e − iα ] derived from Eq. (34) [11]. There are two kinds of solutions for Eq. (56): ei 2 α  = +1 or –1, where the former has a phase difference (between A 0 and C 0) of α = 0, while the latter gives α = ±π/2. When α = 0, both Eqs. (52) and (53) must hold in order to vanish s a , because of κ·ε 0+ε 1·μ 0≠0. In the case of α = ±π/2, however, s a gets to zero only when the relation κ·ε 0 = ε 1·μ 0 holds or Eqs. (52) and (53) are established. In either case of α = 0 or α = ±π/2, therefore, both s g  = 0 and s a  = 0 are satisfied, because Eq. (35) holds regardless of the value of α. The condition required to make s n gauge-invariant in an anisotropic (optically active) medium (see Table 1) is the observance of the relationship ∇ u·∇ ψ 0 = ∇ υ·∇ φ 0, as listed in Table 1. The presence of non-diagonal elements in ε and μ tensors is thus found to make possible the quantization of the phase difference. Subsequently, in order to find out which of eiα  = –i and eiα  = +  corresponds to RCP or LCP wave, two kinds of vector potentials A 0 and C 0 are employed as follows (57) A 0 = E 0 2 ω e − i ω t [ − i ( e i k r z + e i k ℓ z ) e 1 + ( e i k r z − e i k ℓ z ) e 2 ] and (58) C 0 = H 0 2 ω e − i ω t [ ( e i k r z − e i k ℓ z ) e 1 + i ( e i k r z + e i k ℓ z ) e 2 ] , where A 0 and C 0 are composed of both RCP and LCP waves and kr and kℓ are the wave vectors of RCP and LCP waves, respectively [11]. By substituting Eqs. (57) and (58) into Eq. (32), the phase factor ei α is linked with both RCP and LCP waves as (59) ( A 0 E 0 e i α + C 0 H 0 ) = – i e − i ω t √ 2 ω [ e i k r z ( e i α + i ) e r + e i k ℓ z ( e i α – i ) e ℓ ] = 0 , where e r = ( e 1+ i e 2)/√2 and e ℓ = ( e 1– i e 2)/√2 [21]. In order for Eq. (59) to hold usually, the relations eiα  = –i and eiα  = +  correspond respectively to LCP (α = –π/2) and RCP (α = +π/2) waves, because there is no solution of α which satisfies both relations at the same time. Substituting Eqs. (57) and (58) into Eq. (24) and taking their complex conjugates, the gauge-invariant se is obtained as se  = (ε 0 E 2 + μ 0 H 2)/2ω for α = +π/2. On the other hand, sn is derived as sn  = ℏ/V using the second quantization method, where V is an arbitrary volume [4]. It is found from se  = sn that the gauge invariance of s n leads to the quantization of electromagnetic spin, resulting in a photon spin S = ℏ. Then, the anisotropy in ε and μ tensors contributes to the generation of quantization axis (z axis) of spin. When A 0 and C 0 are respectively described by Eqs. (57) and (58), C 0 lags behind A 0 by π/2 in each rotation direction for RCP and LCP waves, as shown in Fig. 1 . The gauge invariance of s n in an anisotropic medium result from the quantization (α = ±π/2) of phase difference between A 0 and C 0. From a macroscopic point of view, therefore, an appearance of LP (linear polarization) or EP (elliptical polarization) wave is only possible for a light beam, because LP and EP waves can be constructed as a composite wave by an appropriate linear combination of CP waves with opposite helicities. The conditions necessary for the gauge invariance are as follows: one condition for generating s g  = 0 is ∇ u·∇ ψ 0 = ∇ υ·∇ φ 0 in an isotropic medium, while in an anisotropic (optically active) medium, another condition for establishing s a  = 0 is α = ±π/2, as listed in Table 1. While the gauge symmetry is established, however, the spin direction of a massless particle is limited to either parallel or antiparallel to the traveling direction, because the gauge field must be massless [22]. 3.2.2 l n When the transverse plane EM waves are propagating along the z axis in an anisotropic medium, most of E , H , A and C fields are in the x-y plane but some of their field components derived from the gauge functions should have somewhat z component in the gauge-invariant state. Under such conditions, x and y components of D and B fields are expressed by Eqs.(45) and (46) and their z components are derived from Eqs. (12) and (20) as (60) D z = – ε z ∇ φ 0 , B z = – μ z ∇ ψ 0 . Substituting Eqs. (45),(46) and (60) into Eq. (36), l n is decomposed into two parts of l e (associated with E and H ) and l g (associated with the gauge functions) as (61) l n = l e + l g , where (62) l e = ( y e 1 – x e 2 ) [ ( ε 0 μ 0 – ε 1 κ ) E × H z + i ( ε 0 κ – ε 1 μ 0 ) ( E ⋅ H ) ] and (63) l g = – 1 2 ( y e 1 – x e 2 ) ( ε z ∇ φ 0 Δ u + μ z ∇ ψ 0 Δ υ ) , where the symbols ∇ and Δ denote the first and second derivatives of ∂/∂z and ∂2/∂z 2, respectively. Of course, Eq. (62) is reduced to Eq. (43), at least when both ε 1 = 0 and κ = 0 are realized. Here Δu is derived from the differentiation of Eq. (34) with respect to z as (64) Δ u = – ( μ 0 / ε 0 ) 1 / 2 e i α Δ υ . Substitutions of ∇ψ 0 (or ∇φ 0) derived from Eq. (29) and of Δu (or Δυ) from Eq. (64) into Eq. (63) yield l g for the transverse plane EM waves traveling in an anisotropic medium (65) l g = ( y e 1 – x e 2 ) ( μ 0 / ε 0 ) 1 / 2 ε z e − i α [ e i 2 α + ( ε 0 μ z / μ 0 ε z ) ] ∇ φ 0 Δ υ . and (66) l g = 1 2 y e 1 − x e 2 ε 0 / μ 0 1 / 2 μ z e i a e − i 2 a + μ 0 / ε 0 μ z ∇ ψ 0 Δ u . These two equations are reduced to Eq. (42) for εz  = ε 0 and μz  = μ 0. When Eq. (42) is combined with Eqs. (65) and (66) and any one of ∇ψ 0 = ∇φ 0 = 0 or ∇u = ∇υ = 0 holds, l g disappears in either isotropic or anisotropic medum. Furthermore, when α satisfies ei 2 α  = –(ε 0 μz /μ 0 εz ), l g vanishes, leading to the gauge invariance of l n in an anisotropic medium. This means that α is quantized at a phase difference shifted somewhat from π/2. It indicates that when l n is described using only two kinds of vector potentials ( A 0 and C 0), it can be gauge-invariant even in an anisotropic medium. It is thus found that two kinds of vector potentials of A 0 and C 0 are indispensable to make s n and l n gauge-invariant, whether the medium is isotropic or not. In addition, it was found in a different way from the traditional procedure that the phase difference α between A 0 and C 0 can be quantized successfully by imposing the gauge invariance on s n and l n which are respectively generated in isotropic and anisotropic media, as listed in Table 1. The success of phase quantization due to the gauge invariance seems to suggest indirectly the existence of an electric vector potential. The existence of the magnetic vector potential A has indeed been confirmed through the A-B effect of electrons moving in the vector potential A produced by the solenoid [23]. By analogy with the magnetic vector potential A , the existence of electric vector potential C would probably be confirmed someday by a similar experiment due to a magnetic fluxon [24]. 3.3 The continuity and torque equations for hn 3.3.1 Continuity equation The helicity density hn defined here for the optical fields is duality-invariant and given by [11] (67) h n = 1 2 [ A · H + ( C · E ) ] , where the first and second terms in the bracket are referred to as the magnetic helicity [10] and the electric helicity [17], respectively. The helicity density hn in various media originates from the anisotropy and inhomogeneity of the EM fields and is related to the difference between the number densities (nr and nℓ ) of right and left circularly polarized photons [25]. In fact, the second quantization of Eq. (67) yields (68) h n = ℏ c V ( n r – n ℓ ) , where V is an arbitrary volume. In general, the helicity of the optical fields is referred to as the “screw action” [26]. The substitutions of Eqs. (10),(12),(18) and (20) into Eq. (67) yield (69) h n = 1 2 { [ ( A 0 · ∂ C 0 ∂ t ) − ( C 0 · ∂ A 0 ∂ t ) ] + ( ∇ υ · ∇ φ 0 – ∇ u · ∇ ψ 0 ) } (70) = h e + h g , where he [=( A 0·∂ C 0/∂t –  C 0·∂ A 0/∂t)/2] is the effective helicity density and hg (=∇ υ·∇ φ 0 – ∇ u·∇ ψ 0) is the apparent helicity density associated with gauge functions (u and υ) and scalar potentials (φ 0 and ψ 0). All terms of ∇ φ 0· C 0, ∇ υ·∂ A 0/∂t, ∇ ψ 0· A 0 and ∇ u·∂ C 0/∂t which are generated in deriving Eq. (69) are dropped because of inner products between orthogonal vectors. When hg  = 0, of course, hn becomes gauge-invariant. The condition that hg of the second term on the right hand of Eq. (69) is eliminated is given by Eq. (35), which is quite the same as the condition of the gauge invariance obtained from s n arisen in an isotropic medium, as listed in Table 1. The same is also obtained by imposing the gauge invariance on s n of the optical fields in an isotropic medium (see Appendix A). Next, let us consider the time derivative of gauge-invariant hn (for hg  = 0) when the transverse plane EM waves are traveling along the z axis. It is investigated here whether hn can form the continuity equation in a homogeneous and isotropic medium without source of the screwness. The time-derivative of gauge-invariant hn is as follows (71) ∂ h n ∂ t = 1 2 ∂ ∂ t [ ( A 0 · ∂ C 0 ∂ t ) − ( C 0 · ∂ A 0 ∂ t ) ] . By substituting Eqs. (12) and (20) into Eq. (71), ∂hn /∂t is expressed as (72) ∂ h n ∂ t = 1 2 ( A 0 · ∂ 2 C 0 ∂ t 2 − C 0 · ∂ 2 A 0 ∂ t 2 ) = 1 2 ( A 0 · ∂ H ∂ t + C 0 · ∂ E ∂ t ) , where A 0·∂∇ ψ 0/∂t and C 0·∂∇ φ 0/∂t which are generated in deriving Eq. (72) are dropped because of inner products between orthogonal vectors. In a homogeneous isotropic medium, Eq. (72) is rewritten using Eqs. (1)

column2: Energy transfer studies for the liquid and solid state materials of Rhodamine B and Styryl 7 Dye
column3: Abstract Samples of dye doped Rhodamine B and Styryl 7 with MMA in solid state and the dye mixture in liquid state were prepared. Frequencydoubled Nd-YAG laser was used to evaluate solid and liquid dye samples laser emission. Using dye cell and dye-coated prism setup, distributed feedback dye laser(DFDL) activity was initiated. The dependence of pulse widths, and output power on acceptor – donor concentrations and pump power were analyzed in theoretical form. The resulting output energy of DFDL for liquid and solid sampling were checked at high emission levels of donor and acceptor dyes for various pump powers and acceptor-donor concentrations and were compared with theroretical results. To identify the thermal stability of solid pattern, the differential thermal analysis(DTA) and Thermogravimetric analysis(TGA) were performed. By adjusting the prism arrangement, for liquid and solid samples continuous tunability was observed from 570 to 727nm.
column5: Keywords Rhodamine B Styryl 7 Distributed feedback dye laser Methyl methacrylate 1 Introduction In physics, biology, photochemistry and radiation, the concept of transfer of energy has a vital aspect. The transmission of radiationless energy might take place in solid, liquid and gas states [1]. In order to increase the performance of dye lasers and spectral range, the energy trnasfer in laser dye mixture was examined [2–6]. The two main collaborating molecules in the process of energy transfer are the donor and the acceptor molecules. In the first phase the donor molecules absorb the electromagnetic radiations gets excited to higher energy state. At this point no energy radiations was traced around the acceptor molecules. Through radiators or the process of non radiative deactivity, the highly excited donor molecules restores to the ground state. Since the molecules of acceptor dye absorbs energy and hence become excited, is tracked by acceptor molecule along with photon emission. In this process of energy transmission, the lifetime of excited donor molecules and its light emissions gets decreased whereas there is an increase in the acceptor molecules emission of light [7,8]. The FRET is abbreviate in as Fluorescence energy transfer, which is otherwise called as the radiationless energy transfer The interaction happens between the donor and acceptor molecules through the excitation lifetime of donor before the radiance of photon. This state of radiationless energy transfer happens because any of the following reasons. a) diffusion-controlled collision and transfer occurs due to intermolecular distance, and it depends on the solvent viscosity and temperature. b) Resonance transfer due to long range dipole interactions. In other words, the distance between the acceptor and donor molecules are closer with a distance of 10–100Å [9–12]. There are many disadvantages of using liquid dye lasers that relevant for engaging huge amount of organic dye solutions that are relatively expensive and toxic in nature. By combining the molecules of dye into solid matrices, various experiements were performed to handle the dye solution issues. Various solid state host materials like porous glasses, modified organic silicates, polymers [4,7], glass of polycom and nano composites of silicates have been recommended. The host materials of solid state tend to have high efficicent nature and Photostability [13–22]. In comparision with similar host materials of solid state, polymeric matrices can help to produce active elements that can efficiently restrict the emission of radiation attributes [23]. Methyl Methacrylate has the best optical transparent nature and can highly resist the damage of laser and hence it is the most widely recommended polymeric material [24–26]. One of the widely used resonators is the distributed-feedback (DFB) type because these lasers are relatively easy to fabricate and they provide better laser performance. DFDL provides narrow band output, widely tunable, low amplification of spontaneous emission (ASE) of radiation,and eliminate the need for lossy dispersive elements. In this particular laser class, DFB lasers consisting of prisms or gratings, present extra advantages of grating which can be utilized to restrict the light output path. This helps to evaluate the emission wavelength represented as λDFDL =n λP/np sin θ. The refractive index of prism and dye are represented as n and np, λP represents pump laser wavelrngth. This equation permits estimation of emission wavelength at the time of fabrication of sample or during transient gratings or prisms in laser operation. The spectrum of tuning range is increased by the polymer fluorescent utilized or the gain of fluorophore spectrum which can be increased to 100nm. When a nano second or sub nanosecond pulse is pumped into the DFB structure (grating or prism), a shorter pulse of 20–100 times could be generated than the normal pump pulse. The reduction of pulse is caused by self Q switch that occurs in the gain medium due to spatial gain modulation of the feedback [27,28]. The present study consist of two phases,which includes the energy transfer of mixture of dye lasers in solid and liquid media, which are compared and implemented.The enery transfer between Rhodamine B and Styryl 7, DFB laser activity of are estimated both in solid and liquid states under the excitation of 532nm Nd- YAG laser which is a source of laser pump. The resultant output energy of DFDL is estimated during the peak radiation emission in acceptor and donor dyes with various acceptor and donor concentrations and different pump variations. Prism arrangement is utilized to analyze tuning range of wavelength. 2 Theoretical studies In solid polymeric matrix and solution form, the DFDL attributes were analyzed with donor as Rhodamine B and acceptor as Styryl 7 mixture in reference to rate equation [29]. The Runge − Kutta process was used to solve the rate equation. Rhodamine B and Styryl 7 spectral range parameters are estimated from the spectra of absorption and fluorescent data. Tables 1 and 2 show the estimated spectral parameters utilized in the rate equation model. From the observed spectral parameters it was found that in the solid matrix, R0 value is higher than the liquid dye mixture. Hence the energy transfer rate was found to be maximum for solid matrix [30] The results of simulation is estimated by substituting observed spectral parameters. The result of DFDL is analyzed for both donor and acceptor molecules at peak wavelengths. While the concentration of donor/pump power is increased, the DFDL’s single pulse resulting power is maximized, and the pulse width decreases. Simultaneously DFDL pulse comes out early as in comparision to the pulse of DFDL that radiated with low pump power and low donor concentration. This happens due to the accelerated increase in inversion of population to increment pump rate. The second pulse of DFDL is emitted over a specific concentration of donor/pump power. It has been noticed that over a greater concentration of donor/pump power, the emission of DFDL second pulse emerges. Yet, the DFDL radiation of donor wavelength depends on the acceptor concentration. When the acceptor concentration increases, the number of DFDL pulses decreases at the donor region. Also, the output power of the single pulse is found to decrease with increase in pulse width and the DFDL pulse is found to be delayed. But in the case of DFDL emission at acceptor wavelength build on the increase in the concentration of acceptor, and the pulse count of DFDL gets maximized with decrease in pulse width. The overall total energy for the series of pulses is obtained in calculation of distinct energy of pulse, through the datas obtained in simulation. The results of experiment correspond to the theoretical results. 3 Experimental studies 3.1 Materials MMA and laser grade type dyes of Rhodamine B and Styryl 7 were acquired at Sigma Aldrich and spectroscopicgrade of ethanol was utilized. Fig. 1 shows the general structures of MMA, Styryl 7 (C.I), RhodamineB (C.I)and the chemical formula. To pump DFDL, a repeated rate of 10Hz Nd-YAG laser(Spectra Physics, USA) with Q switch of 6ns pulse width is used. A spectrophotometer (PERKINELMER LS25) was used to measure the absorption of 0.01mm dye concentration along with spectrofluorometer (PERKIN ELMER LS45) was used to evaluate the emission range at the same dye concentration. 3.2 Spectrum of florescence and absorption Fig. 2 a and b shows the absorption and the emission of fluorescence spectrum with RB and S7 dyes in ethanol and the fluorescence spectrum of RB and S7 solid matrix. The fluorescence spectrum of RB overlap with the absorption of S7 spectrum, permitting the energy of electron to transmit from one dye to another. The overlap of spectrum shows the exisitance of radiative and nonradiative energy transmission. Fig. 2 indicate no additional fluorescent peak was present, which shows there is no complex arrangement of dye blend both in liquid and solid state. Hence any composite kind of energy transmission and collision kind of energy transmission were ignored both in liquid and solid state. 3.3 Preparation of dye-doped polymer Synthesis of polymer matrix with dye doped was performed using thermal bulk free radical polymerization method. The solvent used was ethanol. The monomer utilized was Methyl methacrylate. Polymer initialization was performed by Benzoyl peroxide. 10% of NaOH was used to wash MMA three times to remove any impurities. A ratio of 4:1 (v/v) for MMA and ethanol was used. A concentrate of 1mM Styryl 7 and a concentrate of 3mM Rhodamine B dye were mixed with the combination of 3gms per liter of initiator and MMA for polymeriastion. The mixed solution was placed inside a test tube and kept in a temperature controlled water bath in a nitrogen atmosphere. The water bath temperature was slowly increased till 80°C. Dye doped organic polymeric matrix gel was received and was used to coat over the prism and permitted to get dry. 3.4 Thermo gravimetric and differential thermal analysis Differential thermal analysis(DTA) and Thermogravimetric analysis(TGA) were conducted in order to find the dye doped polymer film’s temperature stability by the use of NETZSCH STA409C analyzer in a state of nitrogen when heated at 10°C/minute to a heating range of 800°C (Fig. 3 ) There were no loss of weight found in TGA curve till 335°C while dominant loss of weight begins at 400°C. The loss of weight denotes material point of decomposition. No loss of weight is noticed after 400°C. This shows that the material texture is maintained till 400 °C. DTA shows dominant endothermic peaks identified at 431.2°C show the crystallization in the phases of material decomposition. 3.5 Experimental set-up Fig. 4 (a) shows the experiment setting with a film of thin dye coating prism and frequency doubled Nd:YAG laser. A right angled isosceles quartz prism which is used to obtain a distributed feedback dye laser. Polymer matrices dye mixture was coated on one part of prism for example BC in solid condition as in Fig. 4(b) and in liquid condition dye mixture was filled in the dye cell of the BC of the prism as in Fig. 4(a). In order to target the emerging beam to the prism’s AB hypotenuse, the cylindrical quartz lens with a focal length of 5cm was used.The light coming out from the prism side AB is total internally reflected on the prism side AC,that reflected light interfere with the BC of the prism and forming fringes(Fig. 4(c)). Fig. 4(c) shows the light emerging from AB side of the prism, reflects internally to the AC prism side that intrude to the light reflection of prism BC side, that forms fringes. As a result,there is a variation of refractive index and gain in the medium. The output beam will be obtained by Bragg scattering reflection from the periodic structure implied all over the active medium.In this setup, the crosswisely excited pump of 0.02cm is provoked in the dye doped polymeric matrices coated prism and dyecell attached prism. While an incident pump laser light ray of wavelength λ p with an angle θ on the active medium, a DFDL may be obtained whose wavelength is given by [31]. λDFDL = nλp /np sin θ Here n and np are the refractive indices of the dye solution and prism material, respectively 3.6 Output measurements 3.6.1 Energy characteristics With the help of dual channel power meter(EPM 2000), the resulting energy radiation of liquid state and solid state dye samples for various input powers,concentrations of acceptor and donor were estimated. As shown in Figs. 5–10 . Wherever the concentration of donor/pump power is elevated, the output energies for donor and acceptor dye were found increased(Figs. 5–8). When there is an increase in acceptor concentration, the resulting energy of acceptor increases and there is a decrease in donor energy (Figs. 9 and 10). When the acceptor concentration increases, the energy transfer rate decreases because of donor quenching. During the donor quenching, internal quenching increases and donor energy decreases which leads to reduce the energy transfer rate constant [30]. Output energy for the solid matrix is high compared with the liquid solution. The reason for that is the concentration quenching in liquid solutions, originating from molecule collisions, is effectively reduced when organic molecules are embedded in a rigid matrix [32,33]. Experimental results were correlated with theoretical results. 3.6.2 Wavelength tuning In an individual experiment, sample of solid state was glazed over the prism and a dye sample of liquid state was obtained in the dye cell of a prism. A ratio of RB 3mM and S7 1mM was considered. The pump beam interference angle (θ) was adjusted. The emission peaks of both donor RB and acceptor S7 were calculated. Spectrometer (OSM2) was used to measure the wavelength output. The prism was tuned to the acceptor region by adjusting the angle of interference between 43° and 51° whose peak is obtained at 45° and for the donor region angle between 51° and 57° with its peak at 54° The angle of interference was adjusted inbetween 43° and 51° in order to tune the prism to acceptor region, and the peak was received at 45°, Whereas in the case of donor region angle was between 51° and 57°, with 54° as its peak. The wavelength tunability range was between 570 and 598nm and was continued till 698nm in the liquid state of acceptor DFDL, where as in the solid state it was angle extend of 41° for acceptor region.The donor DFDL tuning range was between 570 and 612nm and was continued till 727nm in the acceptor DFDL. From Figs. 11 and 12 compares the values of experiment to the theory value, it is clear that tuning angle of acceptor and donor is close to linear. 4 Conclusion The attributes of DFDL energy transfer in the solid and liquid dye mixture were analyzed. Solid-state dye samples based on MMA co-doped with RB and S7 dye mixture shows increase in lasing performance when compared with the liquid solution. This is due to concentration quenching in liquid solutions, originating from moleculear collisions, that is effectively reduced when organic molecules are embedded in a rigid matrix. The decomposition of solid polymeric matrix starts at 431.2°C while the themal stability is at 400°C. With the process of RB and S7 polymer matrix, resulting wavelength was increased from 698 to 727nm. This type of long range tunanble coherent lasers finds vital role in underwater communications and in biomedical applications.
