column2: Investigations on Ho-TiO2 nanoparticles synthesized by precipitation method for optical applications
column3: Abstract The holmium doped titania nanoparticles are synthesized by precipitation method using titanium tetrachloride as a raw material. XRD for phase structure, DRS-UV absorption spectrum, FTIR presence of functional group, HRSEM with EDX morphological structure and presence of the elements in the synthesis material are assessed and the results evaluated. The study investigates the photocatalytic activity degradation of methylene blue dye under the visible light irradiation at different calcination temperatures enhancing the photocatalytic activity relatively with rise in temperature to 700°C parallelly records the inverse proportionality of photocatalytic activity with electron hole recombination through Photoluminescence spectra.
column5: Keywords Titania Nanoparticles Phase transformation Photocatalytic activity 1 Introduction Titania are well known for their numerous application in technological areas such as: electrolysis of water to generate hydrogen [1], powerful photocatalyst [2,3], solar cells [4], air purification [5] and water sanitization [6]. Titania have three obviously occurring crystalline phases at various annealing temperature [7]. The tetragonal structures of anatase and rutile phase are generally considered for photocatalytic reactions. On comparing the phases, the anatase phase is reported to exhibit efficient photocatalytic activity [8]. The high impact of anatase and rutile phase in titania has attracted an extensive interest over the past decades. The photocatalytic activity of titania have some limitation like the fast recombination of electrons and holes [9] that depends on the crystalline phase of the synthesis materials [10]. Recent modifications in titania have been implemented to tune the characterization using several approaches. One of the approaches is doping, rare earth metal ions into the titania medium to enhance the concentration of organic pollutants on the surface of the material which increases the photocatalytic activity [11]. Among the rare earth elements, holmium trivalent ions when doped with inorganic element improved absorption properties and acts as an effective activator [12]. For example, rare earth elements doped with Fluorapatite: Yb3+/Ho3+ crystal get activated by Ho3+ ions at 980nm NIR light, as a result the crystal emits bright green and red light [13]. The holmium oxide has cubic crystalline structure, which exhibits Lewis acid sites and is well reactive in base sites (OH−). The interaction of OH− radicals at the holes results in the formation of surface hydroxyl radicals which enhances the photocatalytic activity of titania [14]. Hence, holmium ion modified the titania to give an efficient photocatalytic activity is chosen for study. Subject to various physical and chemical methods, viz., sol-gel [15], micro emulsion [16], electro-spinning [17], Magnetron sputtering [18], micro wave-hydrothermal [19], precipitation [20], the titanium dioxide is synthesized. Among these methods, the precipitation method is simple and cost efficient, gives fine crystalline structure. The present study, synthesis holmium doped titania implementing precipitation method at different annealing temperatures and relative crystalline phase, size, absorption, microstructure, luminescence properties to investigate the photocatalytic activity. 2 Experimental All substances of analytical grade are purchased from Loba and used without any further purification. Deionized water is used in experiments. The precipitation method is used to synthesise the holmium doped titania using ammonia solution as the precipitating agent. TiOCl2 solution is formed on adding 10ml of TiCl4 gradually to 100ml of cold deionized water. On stirring the turbid solution for 24h using a magnetic stirrer a clear solution is formed. The sulfuric acid is used to dissolve holmium oxide (Ho2O3) which is added to 20ml of the TiOCl2 to blend well. The blend is injected into 100ml of 7.3M ammonia solutions allowing it to form a precipitate on the surface. The precipitate filtered and rinsed with deionized water fed into the muffle furnace at 65°C for 24h. The amorphous titanium powder formed is ground using agate mortar. The prepared amorphous nanoparticles are annealed at 600°C and 700°C for 1h in an alumina crucible in muffle furnace. X-ray diffraction evaluates the phase transformation of the material. 3 Characterization The phase transformation of the holmium doped titania is recorded by Bruker D8 advanced X-ray diffractometer with wide-angle range of 2θ from 10 to 60 using CuKα radiation. Shimadzu model 2600 is used to measure the absorption spectrum of the sample. The Spectroflurometer with 450W xenon lamps is the excitation source to characterize the photoluminescence properties. Bruker instrument is used to study the functional group of the material. The morphological structure and present element studied using FEI Qunta FEG 200 high resolution scanning electron microscopy. 4 Results and discussion 4.1 Phase structure The X-ray diffraction pattern (XRD) provides an exact idea of crystallinity and phase transformation of the synthesized material. The XRD pattern of holmium doped titania at different annealing temperature is shown in Fig. 1 . The holmium doped titania have tetragonal structure with lattice parameters of a=3.783Å, c=9.497Å having characteristic diffraction peaks are perfectly indexed to the (101), (112), (200), (105) and (211) planes. These peaks represent the anatase phase of titania at 600 and 700°C respectively (JCPDS No.082084 anatase). In undoped titania, the rutile phase take place between 500 and 700°C [7]. Above 600°C the transformation from anatase to rutile is prevented the substitution Ti4+ ions gets by Ho3+ ions this special feature qualifies itself to be taken for study. The anatase phase gets stabilized at 700°C because of the Ti-O rare earth bonding. This investigation explains the formation of TiOHo bond and its interaction with the synthesized material. The crystalline size (D) of the sample is calculated from the XRD data using Scherrer’s formula [21]. Based on the Scherrer’s formula, the crystalline size measured on the (101) plane of the anatase phases are 7.18nm and 8.06nm for two respective temperatures. The grain size of the sample exhibits expansion at higher annealing temperature. From the X-ray diffraction technique, it is confirmed that the holmium ions enhance the thermal stability of the anatase phase. 4.2 Absorption spectra The UV–vis-diffuse reflectance spectroscopy (DRS-UV) is used to determine the absorption spectrum of the material in the scan range of 200–1200nm (Fig. 2 ). The observed absorption spectrum of the material displays peaks near 391 and 418nm and these peaks in the spectrum shift towards the longer wavelength region giving better red shift absorption. The red shift reveals that the band gap energy of the material gets reduced due to intermediate energy level produced at higher calcination temperature. The band gap energy of the material can be determined using following equation [22], αhϑ = A(hϑ − Eo ) n Where α is absorption coefficient, h- Planck’s constant, ϑ- the frequency of light, A- the characteristic parameter for transition and Eo represents the energy related parameter and n transition parameter. Indirect transition parameter as n =½ and that, of direct transition n=2. Fig. 3 . Shows indirect band gap energy 3.1eV and 2.9eV at two temperatures respectively. It is revealed that the band gap energy of the holmium doped titania shift from 3.2eV to 2.9eV due to the annealing of temperature. 4.3 FTIR analysis Infrared spectroscopy determines the presence of functional groups of the nanoparticles during the precipitation process. The infrared absorption spectrum of the holmium doped titania annealed at different temperatures is plotted in Fig. 4 . The bands around 689–691cm−1 attribute to the vibration mode of TiOTi bond. The peak attributed around 805cm−1 confirms TiO vibration in anatase phase and the presence of metal oxygen bond γ(MO). The peak around the 1130cm−1 represents the vibration mode of Ti-OH. This peak reveals the presence of holmium metal ions in the synthesized material. The peaks ascertains 1619cm−1, 1635cm−1 for annealing temperature at 600°C and 700°C the ensures of oxygen belonging to groups i.e., CO, COO and CO. The bending vibration of OCO is around 2345–2349cm−1 and the stretching vibration of intermolecular hydrogen (OH) bond is assigned to the broad band around 2800–3600cm−1. 4.4 Photoluminescence spectra Photoluminescence (PL) spectroscopy is a very useful technique to determine the luminescence properties of the material. The emission property of the material is related to its electron-hole pair recombination [23]. The Fig. 5 shows, the suppression of electron hole recombination at elevated annealing temperature. It is inferred that when the sample is annealed at 700°C the emission intensity of the spectrum decreases as the holmium ions trap the excited electrons which in turn reduces the electrons and holes recombination. The adsorbed O2 molecules by holmium ions produces OH radicals on the surface of the titania which facilitate the photocatalytic activity of the titania. 4.5 HRSEM with EDX The morphology of anatase holmium doped titania samples is investigated by High Resolution Scanning Electron Microscope (HRSEM). The spherical nanoparticles of the holmium doped titania calcined at 700°C is res in Fig. 6 (a–c). The aggregate spherical nanoparticles with different sizes have irregular voids dispersed among the particles. The Energy dispersive X-ray Spectrometer (EDX) pattern of holmium doped titania annealed at 700°C is shown in Fig. 6d, which indicates the presence of Titanium, Oxygen and Holmium in the synthesized material. 4.6 Photocatalytic activity The photocatalytic activity depends upon the light absorption properties of the semiconductor material which in turn is related to band gap energy of the material. This energy must be equal to or greater than the photon energy in order to accelerate the photocatalytic activity of the synthesis material [24]. The titania nanoparticles exhibiting amorphous phase have lower photocatalytic activity than anatase [25]. So, the study undertakes the photocatalytic activity of anatase phase at annealing temperatures 600 and 700°C. 300W tungsten Xenon lamp is used as the visible light source for the degradation of the methylene blue as the model organic pollutant. Fig. 7 depicts the residual concentration ratio (C0/Ct) of methylene blue versus irradiation time under visible light irradiation. Where C0 represents the concentration of methylene blue and Ct is the concentration varying with respect to the irradiation time. From the result, it is observed that the photocatalytic activity of the synthesized material depends on the annealing temperature. While annealing temperature increases the photocatalytic activity and decreases the electron hole recombination. The rare earth doped with titania shifts the light absorption edge position to visible region increasing the calcination temperature. Therefore, 700°C calcined sample shows enhanced photocatalytic activity due to the suppression of the electron hole recombination, which facilitates the redox reaction for photodecomposition of pollutants. The efficient degradation is obtained due to the adsorption of the pollutants on the surface of the synthesized materials. Hence, the holmium plays an important role in sustaining the anatase phase, which supports the photocatalytic activity. Comparing the samples calcined at 600 and 700°C, the sample at 700°C shows enhanced photocatalytic activity than 600°C. 5 Conclusion The holmium doped titania nanoparticles are synthesized by precipitation method. The DRS-UV spectra analysis shows better red shift which indicates the reduced the band gap energy of the synthesis material at higher calcination temperature. The luminescence intensity of the holmium doped titania shows the suppression of the electron hole recombination at higher calcination temperature. The holmium doping with titania stabilizes the anatase phase of the host material and produced hydroxyl radicals to increase the photocatalytic activity. It is concluded that, holmium rare earth element and temperature play significant role in enhancing photocatalytic activity. Acknowledgment The authors gratefully acknowledge DST-SERB, India for granting financial support for the project ref-SR/S2/CMP/117/2012, PDF/2015/001072 and SSN management for giving junior research fellowship.

column2: Elimination of quenching defects by facile anion doping in CdSiO3 synthesized by green fuel assisted combustion method
column3: Abstract Despite being simple, and economical method, solution combustion synthesis (SCS) method’s applicability in preparation of silicate based phosphors is seriously limited. This is due to the fact that SCS method results in samples with quenching defects.We present a simple one pot synthesis technique for eliminating the defects in CdSiO3 by simple anion doping. We show that just by mere addition of SO4 2− anion, defects related to different kinds of oxygen vacanices disappear and PL spectra shows pure blue emission. Powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) and scanning electron microscopy (SEM) reveals that the SO4 2−doped CdSiO3 exhibits monoclinic phase and rod-like microstructure morphology respectively. Photoluminescence (PL) results reveal that the SO4 2− doped CdSiO3 shows a single emission at 406nm under the excitation wavelength of 259nm. Where as undoped CdSiO3 phosphor presented a series of emission peaks ranging from UV to green (349, 404, 423, 444, 472, 508 and 529nm) under the same excitation wavelength.
column5: Keywords Solution combustion CdSiO3 Nanophosphor Photoluminescence 1 Introduction The phosphors are a type of energy storage materials, which can absorb ultraviolet/visible light and gradually release the energy at a certain wavelength [1]. Most of long-lasting phosphors are based on sulphide, aluminate, or silicate hosts. However, sulphide and aluminium based phosphors applicability is limited due to their thermal degradation at high temperatures [2]. Among the host lattices for luminescent material, silicate based compounds have been extensively investigated owing to their excellent stability towards acid, alkali, oxygen, their visible light transparency and relatively easy preparation methods [3–5]. In this context, CdSiO3 gained significant attention due to its one dimensional (1D) chain structure with edge-sharing SiO4 tetrahedron. With this kind of low dimensional structure it is easy to implant other ions into the host lattice to create traps at suitable depths, which can store excitation energy and emit light at room temperature [6]. During the past decade, a significant amount of work has been carried out to understand the emission properties of various rare earth ions and transition metal ions doped CdSiO3 [7–12]. Nevertheless, the doping of this material with anions has not been reported up to the moment. Therefore, studies of the luminescence behaviour of anion doped CdSiO3 can create new opportunities for researchers and for the applications of luminescence materials. In the present work, a new kind of CdSiO3:SO4 2− phosphor has been synthesized, where SO4 2− ion has been doped into the CdSiO3 lattice and its effect on PL behaviour is investigated. The prepared new material has been thoroughly investigated for its structural and optical properties. 2 Materials, methods, and characterization 2.1 Materials Cadmium nitrate, silicic acid and sulphuric acid were used as starting materials. The fresh Solanumlycopersicum extract (tomato) extract, which was prepared by squeezing Solanumlycopersicum fruit purchased from local market, Bangalore, India, and is used as a fuel. 2.2 Method In a typical synthesis of CdSiO3, stoichiometric quantities of cadmium nitrate, silicic acid and Solanum lycopersicum extract were taken in a beaker. The mixture was stirred for 15min and then placed on a hot plate till all the water evaporated. The resulting gel like residue was kept in the preheated furnace maintained at 500°C. Spontaneous smoldering type combustion takes place with the liberation of large volume of gases resulting in the formation of a brownish powder. The as-formed powder was subjected to heat treatment at various temperatures to obtain crystalline monoclinic CdSiO3. The same procedure was carried out for SO4 2− doping in CdSiO3 using 0.25, 0.5, 1, 2 and 4ml of sulphuric acid (H2SO4). 2.3 Characterization PXRD data were recorded using Philips Xpert PRO PAnalytical X-ray diffractometer with graphite monochromatized Cu-Kα radiation source (λ=1.5418A°). The FTIR spectrum of the sample was recorded at room temperature using Fourier transform infrared Nicolet spectrometer in the range 400–4000cm−1. The microstrucure of the silicate powders was captured using JEOL-JSM–6490 LV SEM. UV–vis absorption spectra were measured with Perkin Elmer Model Lambda 750 spectrometer. PL spectra was examined by Perkins Elmer spectrometer using He–Cd laser with an excitation wavelength of 255nm. 3 Results and discussion Fig. 1 (a–d) shows the PXRD patterns of the as -prepared and calcined CdSiO3 products. The CdSiO3 powder obtained after combustion reaction at 500°C is amorphous as shown in Fig. 1a. The product obtained after calcination at 750°C/2h (Fig. 1b) indicates the formation of monoclinic phase besides some impurity peaks (marked by*). Further calcination of the as-formed product at 850°C and 950°C are respectively shown in Fig. 1(c and d) indicate the pure monoclinic CdSiO3 [JCPDS35-0810]. The absence of impurity peaks in the spectrum indicates that the natural fuel used in the present synthesis is not affecting the phase of the material. Intense and well defined X-ray diffraction peaks indicate a high degree of crystallinity. The crystallite size of the CdSiO3 obtained at 950°C is estimated using Debye-Scherrer formula and it is found to be ∼43nm. Fig. 2 (a–e) shows the PXRD pattern of the SO4 2− doped CdSiO3 products calcined at 950°C using different volume of H2SO4. –It clearly indicates that no significant changes observed as compared to monoclinic CdSiO3 (JCPDS 35-0810). The crystallite size of the SO4 2− doped CdSiO3 prepared at 950°C has been calculated using Debye-Scherrer formula and it is found to be ∼49nm. FTIR spectra have been recorded for undoped and SO4 2− doped CdSiO3 to confirm the presence of SO4 2− and other impurities present in the samples. Fig. 3 (a) and (b) shows the FTIR spectra of undoped and SO4 2− doped CdSiO3 respectively. The absorption bands corresponding to sulphate group are seen at 1191 and 617cm−1 in anion doped sample (Fig. 3b) [11]. However, these peaks are absent in FTIR spectrum of the undoped CdSiO3 (Fig. 3a). This result confirms the presence of SO4 2− in CdSiO3. Further, the asymmetric stretching vibrations of Si-O-Si bonds and stretching vibrations of terminal Si-O bonds are seen at ∼870 and 1227cm−1 respectively in both the samples. The bands at 485 and 555cm−1 are attributed to symmetric stretching vibrations of Si-O-Si bridges [12]. These FTIR results are in consistent with PXRD results confirming the foramtaion of CdSiO3 and SO42− doped CdSiO3. The UV–vis absorption spectra of different concentrations of SO4 2− doped CdSiO3 is measured in the range 200–700nm and it is shown in Fig. 4 A. A sharp peak is observed at ca. 235nm in UV absorption spectra of CdSiO3, this can be attributed to the absorption edge, (edge is the excitation from the top of the valence band(VB) to the bottom of the conduction band) [13]. Further, broad absoption bands observed between 250 and 480nm are due to various kinds of defects in the sample. These are typical of combustion derived samples due to various defects formed in carbon rich ambient synthesis [14,15]. It should be noted that when the volume of H2SO4 added was 1ml the nature of UV spectra changes. The broadness of the UV spectrum has considerably decresed and there is significant increase in absorbance intensity at a particular wavelength ca ∼300nm. This might be due to variation in the concentration and nature of defects at this particular anion concentration. The optical bandgap energy (Eg) is estimated using the Tauc relation as shown in (see Fig. 4B). It has been previously reported that the undoped CdSiO3 exhibits an optical energy band gap of 5.45eV [16]. Additionally, the Dy3+ (1–9 mol%) doped CdSiO3 exhibits a band gap of 5.49–5.65eV [16], which is higher than the undoped CdSiO3 band gap. It is interesting to note that the SO4 2− doped CdSiO3 samples exhibit a band gap in the range 4.90–4.78eV. This study indicates that the SO4 2−doped CdSiO3 shows lower band gap compared to the undoped CdSiO3. The result indicates that the SO4 2− modifies the defects which acts as intermediate energy levels within the band gap. Similar kind of results were also reported by Kouser et al. [17] where the substitution of anions like P and Cl into the lattice of CdS as well as in ZnS decreases the band gap. Fig. 5 a shows the typical surface morphology of the combustion derived CdSiO3 calcined at 950°C.The micrographs of undoped CdSiO3 powder is composed of particles with diameters in the range 8–10μm. The particles are nearly spherical shape and majority of them are also formed as semi-micro rods. These particles of varying size/shape are agglomerated and consist of voids. These morphological feautures are very typical of combustion derived products [18]. The SEM image of the SO4 2− doped CdSiO3 shows well ordered rod-like morphology and a few irregular particles (Fig. 5b). The length of the SO4 2− doped CdSiO3 rods are found to be in the range of 20μm. This rod like morphology observed in SO4 2− doped CdSiO3 is very unusual in products synthesized by combustion technique. In our previous reports we have shown that CdSiO3 prepared using oxylyldihydrizide as a fuel via solution combustion exhibits irregular particle aggregates, porous morphology with high degree of porosity [12]. The formation of nearly uniform rods is due to the fact that the tomato extract serves as a sacrificial biotemplate in the formation of CdSiO3 particles. Since, tomato extract consists of several multifunctional organic compounds such as carbohydrates, sugars, fibers, proteins and vitamins. The precursors distribute uniformly in tomato extract and form athree-dimensional polymeric network. The resulted polymeric network undergoes slow decomposition via smoldering type combustion, as observed for similar work by Maliyekkal et al. where, cellulose extract were used as templates for the preparation of MgO [19]. Photoluminescene emission spectra of CdSiO3 prepared without and with anion doping are shown in Fig. 6 (A) and (B) respectively. Upon 259nm excitation a series of emissions peaks ranging from UV to green are observed. The bands observed are centered at 349, 404, 423, 444, 472, 508 and 529nm. It is well known that neither Cd2+ nor Si4+ has its own characteristic emissions, therefore the series of luminous peaks seen are result of non-stoichiometry in prepared sample. This is typical of most of the combustion derived products, due to the fact that the products in SCS are formed in carbon rich environment (since carbon based compounds are used as fuels). The observed emissions in the region (347–472nm), may be attributed to (i) the radiative recombination of holes with an electron occupying the oxygen vacancy and (ii) recombination of a delocalized electron close to the conduction band with a single charged state of surface oxygen vacancy [20]. Further, the emissions in green region are (509 and 530nm), are due to the self-activated shallow luminescence centers of nanocrystalline CdSiO3 [21,22]. The emission spectra of anion doped CdSiO3 shows single broad band centred at 404nm. It is interesting to note that the defect related emission vanish with the addition of SO4 2− anion. The observed elimination of defect related emission is due to the substitution of SO4 2− for the anion vacancies. SO4 2− is substituted in place of defects (different kinds of oxygen vacancies) causing non-radiative transition and thereby reduces the non-radiative defect density. This is true because from PL spectra it is evident that with varying concentration of anion doping the nature of emission spectra changes. When the concentration of sulphate source is 0.25ml PL spectra shows broad emission with well defined shoulder at ∼340nm and a band centred at 404nm. With increase in SO4 2− concentration the sholder peak decreses in intensity and for 1ml of sulphate source a single well resolved emission centred at 404nm is observed. This result is consistent with our previous work [23], where PL spectra of CdSO4 exhibit a strong broad emission around 400nm. However, with further increase in sulphate source a shoulder peak appears at ∼420nm. To highlight these observation deconvolution of PL spectra was done for samples prepared with 0.25ml, 4ml of sulphate source and are presented in Fig. 7 (a), (b) respectively. This variation in PL spectra with varying SO4 2− concentration can be explained as follows. When the concentration of SO4 2− added was less (0.25ml) all the defects are not eliminated due to insufficient anion concentration. This results in shoulder peaks related to defect emission. On the other hand when the concentration of anion is beyond certain concentration (in this case 3ml) sholder peaks appear at different position (∼460nm). This is due to excess anion doping leads to the formation of new kinds of defects. This result is particularly interesting in phosphor designing, just by mere doping of optimized anion concentration the quenching defects can be eliminated. Elimination of quenching defects in rare earth doped phosphors will aid in enhanced PL emission with higher quantum efficiency. 4 Conclusions We have proposed a facile route for eliminating the quenching defects by simple aninon doping in CdSiO3. The doping of optimized concentration of SO4 2− into the lattice compensates for the various vacancies/defects and thus there is no emission due to defects. Photoluminescence studies on CdSiO3 doped with different SO4 2− ion concentration convincingly supports the proposed analysis.Photoluminescence results shows that undoped CdSiO3 shows number of defect related peaks ranging from blue to green. While the optimized anion doped CdSiO3 show single peak centered at 404nm. We believe that these findings would certainly facilitate in decreasing the quenching related to various defects in rare earth ion doped phosphors and help in design of efficient phosphors with better color purity. Acknowledgements R. Hari Krishna is grateful to the Management and Principal of M.S. Ramaiah Institute of Technology, Bangalore, for their constant support and encouragement.

column2: An adaptive RGB colour enhancement formulation for logarithmic image processing-based algorithms
column3: Abstract This paper presents an effective colour enhancement framework for statistical and logarithmic image processing (LIP)-based enhancement algorithms. The proposed approach utilizes the fusion of partial, multiple computed luminance channels with colour image channel statistics obtained from the input colour image for adaptive colour enhancement. The proposed scheme does not modify the image intensity channel, avoiding colour fading typically observed in colour images processed with conventional algorithms. The colour enhancement scheme compensates for the weaknesses of greyscale-based contrast enhancement and illumination normalization algorithms by focusing on preserving/restoring or enhancing colour. The proposed system avoids the conversion to complex, non-linear colour spaces such as HSI and HSV while producing similar results without manual adjustment of parameters. Additionally, an adaptive scheme for detection of images with unbalanced colour and uneven illumination is combined with the proposed system. Results show that the proposed scheme augments colour results of greyscale-based contrast enhancement algorithms and is relatively less complex compared to most algorithms in the literature.
column5: Keywords Logarithmic image processing Illumination normalization Colour enhancement Adaptive colour correction Nonlinear colour space models Generalized un-sharp masking 1 Introduction The continued growth of high definition digital colour media and devices for their acquisition, transmission, processing and storage has precipitated the necessity for novel, effective and efficient colour image enhancement algorithms. These algorithms must utilize relatively low hardware resources to fit within the real-time digital hardware implementation constraints of embedded systems for such devices, which process great amounts of image and video data at high resolutions. Moreover, unwanted and unavoidable processes that manifest during the acquisition and transmission stages are still ever present in electronic devices. These include; blurring, noise, non-ideal illumination conditions, distortions, limitations of the dynamic range and display capabilities of electronic devices [1,2]. Several algorithms have been proposed to address these problems, however, the majority are suited to greyscale images. Greyscale, histogram-based algorithms perform poorly when processing images with uneven illumination [1–4]. Conversely, standard logarithmic image processing approaches also yield subpar results and at best produce faded images when processing faded or bright, low contrast images [4,3]. In addition, these algorithms developed for greyscale image enhancement do not work well for RGB colour images due to non-linearity and vector nature of the RGB colour channels that comprise the image [1,2]. Thus, processing individual RGB image channels usually leads to colour distortion or fading and numerous schemes have been devised in the literature to rectify this deficiency. These include colour restoration functions in the Multi Scale Retinex with Colour Restoration (MSRCR) [5], Ratio Rule-based neural network guided Homomorphic filtering (HF) [6,7] and luma-based approaches utilizing non-linear colour spaces such as the HSI and HSV colour spaces [8,3,9]. The effectiveness of the non-linear colour spaces lie in their ability to decouple the Intensity or Value channel from the Hue and Saturation channels, which are all components embedded within the individual Red, Green and Blue image signals [1,2]. Currently, most recent work on colour image enhancement has focused on the non-linear colour space alternatives, which are consistent and proven in their performance. These include combining HSI combined with Homomorphic filters [8] and HSV colour spaces with Contrast Limited Adaptive Histogram Equalization (CLAHE) [10,11] and Genetic Algorithm or Particle Swarm Optimization (PSO) techniques [12], Dynamic Stochastic Resonance (DSR)-based image enhancement [13,14] and Tone mapping algorithms [15–19], Generalized Unsharp Masking (GUM) [11] and Probability-based illumination normalization [20] algorithms. However, algorithms such as Generalized Histogram Equalization (GHE) and Adaptive Histogram Equalization (AHE) [2] yield worse results in HSI or HSV space, leading to the gamut problem described by Naik and Murthy in their work [21]. They also proposed a technique for avoiding gamut problem after enhancement without resorting to colour coordinate transforms. The recent work on fast hue and range preserving histogram specification (HS) functions by Nikolova and Steidl [22,23], utilize these foundations for their proposed improved algorithm. Additionally, the proposed LIP algorithm by Patrascu and Buzuloiu [24], is also hue preserving, though its adaptive nature requires the solution of a set of relatively complex equations to obtain particular image parameters for enhancement. Alternative colour enhancement and preserving techniques include tensor-based methods using a Quaternion Discrete Fourier Transform [25], histogram modification equalization-based methods in 1D [26] and 3D spaces [27], development of a colour LIP colour correction framework [28] and multi-exposure homomorphic filtering [17]. Recently, works utilizing alternative LIP models [29] combining the Generalized Un-sharp Masking (GUM) [11,29] and probabilistic models for simultaneous illumination and reflectance estimation have been reported [20]. All the aforementioned alternatives still require colour conversion to HSV/HSI colour space to avoid/minimize the distortion or colour fading resulting from illumination correction operations in RGB space. This also adds increased hardware resource usage in digital hardware system implementations [3,30]. Furthermore, even when some of the algorithms are implemented in the HSI and HSV colour space, there is usually not much colour improvement in addition to faded colours observed after processing. Furthermore, any unregulated modification of the hue and saturation affects the final colour aesthetics of the colour image when converted back to RGB space. Thus, it is vital that the proposed system avoids the distortion of colours. The primary motivation of the proposed algorithm in this work was to address the issues of colour distortion, automation and consistency of results in implementation. This is because most of the conventional approaches yield inconsistent colour results, are highly complex and not usually adaptive or automated, requiring manual adjustments of several parameters and selection of various functions. Even with canonical values, some of the earlier schemes do not yield best results for all images, lacking generality in application. In contrast, the proposed system yields consistent results as expected due to its theoretical foundations supported by extensive experimentation. The rest of the paper is outlined as follows; the second section highlights the key contributions, features and objectives of the proposed scheme. The third section discusses relevant related works in detail and their limitations. The fourth section discusses the details of the proposed colour enhancement function and the justification for its implementation with presentation of theoretical formulation. The fifth section presents experimental results of the proposed scheme and its colour augmentation ability in addition to comparisons with other algorithms from the literature. Additional presentations include the modification of a previously computational complex algorithm by replacing a non-linear colour space converter with the proposed colour enhancement algorithm. Additional replacement of the edge preserving component of the contrast enhancement algorithm with a less complex but more effective alternative, reduced the run-time and complexity of the algorithm. The sixth section presents a brief discussion and possible applications and hardware realization possibilities of the proposed system. The final section presents the conclusions and a comprehensive summary of the work. 2 Key contributions, features and objectives The key and novel contributions of this work include: • Adaptive, combined fusion of intensity and value components to enhance colour rendition of processed colour images using weighted combination computed from colour channel statistics. • Colour restoration of processed colour images with distorted or degraded colours using computed modal ratios from all three colour channels. • Use of probability mass function (PMF) to compute standard deviation from mode (SDFM) and mean of modal ratio (MOM) parameters as inputs in the implemented system, ensuring adaptive and automated colour enhancement/restoration. • Additional scheme for detecting dark images or images with dominant colour cast based on statistical contrast measure and entropy values used as inputs to a classifier for decision-based colour enhancement processing. The key objectives and features include: • The design and realization of a generalized and practical colour enhancement algorithm that can be a companion function to almost any grayscale-based image enhancement algorithm, improving its colour enhancement performance. • Improving colour enhancement and colourfulness by regulated dilation without upsetting colour balance. • Algorithm yields improved colour images, matching and/or surpassing results of HSI and HSV-based approaches while avoiding their complex and extensive colour coordinate forward and reverse transformation functions. • The developed algorithm is fast, feasible and practical for hardware implementation due to its point-wise nature of operation. • The proposed algorithm can also be modified to mimic results of any colour space conversion technique without performing the actual full colour space conversion. 3 Prior related works The illumination correction algorithms treated in this paper are limited to the LIP and SLIP models with some discussions about the log-ratio (LR) based models. However as noted, these algorithms generally have a number of limitations, which include; minimal edge and contrast enhancement, inability to perform consistent colour correction, loss of details in bright image regions and inability to enhance faded, low contrast images. The colour fading and distortion aspect is addressed in this work and solutions to the colour fading problem from the literature are included for comparison. Furthermore, the drawbacks of these approaches are also briefly discussed with added references for further details. 3.1 Logarithmic image processing (LIP) and symmetric LIP (SLIP) models The illumination correction term discussed here is based on a variant of the log-ratio (LR), log image processing (LIP) [11] and symmetric LIP (SLIP) model [29]. The Retinex-based algorithms are derived from the LR method while the Homomorphic filter is a variation of the model. The LR and the LIP values are defined in the range: (0, L-1), where L is the number of defined grey levels. The operations for the LIP model [11,29] are; (1) ψ ( a ) = − R ln ( 1 − a R ) ; a ⊕ b = a + b − a b R ; λ ⊗ a = R − R ( 1 − I i ( x , y ) R ) λ (2) ⊖ b = − 1 ⊗ b = − R ( b R − b ) ; a ⊖ b = a ⊕ ( ⊖ b ) = R ( a − b R − b ) In (1) and (2), ⊕, ⊖ and ⊗ are vector addition, vector subtraction and scalar multiplication operations in the LIP domain, respectively. The terms a and b are vectors while λ is a scalar value. R is the range of the image vector, defined in the domain, (0, R) and ψ ( a ) is a LIP-based transformation function for vector a. Conversely, the operations for the SLIP model [29] are; (3) ψ ( a ) = − R * s g n ( a ) ln ( 1 − | a | R ) ; a ⊞ b = R * s g n ( a + b ) [ 1 − ( 1 − | a | R ) γ 1 ( 1 − | b | R ) γ 2 ] Where in (3), the exponents, γ 1 = s g n ( a ) s g n ( a + b ) and γ 2 = s g n ( b ) s g n ( a + b ) . Also; (4) λ ⊠ a = R * s g n ( λ a ) [ 1 − ( 1 − | a | R ) | λ | ] ; ⊟ b = − 1 ⊠ b = R * s g n ( − b ) [ 1 − ( 1 − | b | R ) | − 1 | ] (5) a ⊟ b = a ⊞ ( ⊟ b ) = R * s g n ( a + ( ⊟ b ) ) [ 1 − ( 1 − | a | R ) γ 1 ( 1 − | ( ⊟ b ) | R ) γ 2 ] (6) ψ − 1 ( a ) = R * s g n ( a ) ( 1 − e − | a | R ) In (3)–(6), ⊞, ⊟ and ⊠ are vector addition, vector subtraction and scalar multiplication operations in the SLIP domain [29], respectively. The signum function, sgn is defined as; s g n ( x ) = { − 1 , x < 0 0 , x = 0 1 , x > 0 . The terms a and b are vectors while λ is a scalar value. R is the range of the vector, defined in the domain, (0, R) and ψ ( a ) is a SLIP-based forward transformation function for vector a while ψ − 1 ( a ) is a SLIP-based inverse transformation function for vector a. 3.2 Generalized Un-sharp Masking (GUM) algorithm The GUM algorithm proposed by Deng [11] is composed of three essential components namely an Edge Preserving Filter (EPF), Contrast Enhancement (CE) function and the Adaptive Gain Control function (AGC). The algorithm utilized for the EPF is the Adaptive Median Filter (AMF) [31] and the selected CEF was the Contrast Limited Adaptive Histogram Equalization (CLAHE) [10] algorithm. The LIP- and SLIP-GUM algorithms are defined by the expressions; v L I P = z ⊕ [ γ ⊗ ( x ⊖ y ) ] and v S L I P = z ⊞ [ γ ⊠ ( x ⊟ y ) ] where x, y, z and γ are the input image, EPF output, CEF output and AGC output respectively. Based on the work from the current literature, the LIP-GUM [11] and the SLIP-GUM [29] algorithms show some promising results. However, this is to be expected due to the fact that these algorithms are a combination of several algorithms such EPF, CE and AGC components. The outputs of these components are evaluated in the LIP and SLIP domains respectively. However, as pointed out in [20], the traditional log-based approaches lead to detail loss in the extracted reflectance component. Additionally, the traditional LIP GUM leads to out of range errors for some images and have to be corrected with the SLIP approach [29]. Furthermore, there is still loss of detail in the GUM outputs in addition to little colour improvement despite the fact that the operations are performed usually on the intensity component of the HSI or HSV transformed image. This is in addition to the AMF and CLAHE, which are highly computationally complex as well. Thus the exploration of comparable, less complex algorithms to replace the AMF in the GUM forms part of the improvements of the work. Consequently, we utilize relatively less complex but highly effective algorithms for the EPF component of the GUM. 3.3 Colour enhancement approaches The key, relevant, related works on colour enhancement include the Colour restoration routine [5], ratio rule [6,7], non-linear colour spaces [2], discrete cosine transform (DCT)-based method [32] and hue preserving algorithms [21,23]. Each scheme has its own unique features resulting in advantages and disadvantages. 3.3.1 Colour restoration function (MSRCR) The colour restoration function for the popular MSRCR [5] is given as; (7) C i ( x , y ) = β log 10 [ α I i ( x , y ) ∑ i = 1 s I i ( x , y ) ] (8) I M S R C R i ( x , y ) = G [ C i ( x , y ) . I M S R i ( x , y ) + b ] (9) I M S R i ( x , y ) = ∑ s = 1 S w s [ log 10 ( I i ( x , y ) ) − log 10 ( I i ( x , y ) * h s ( x , y ) ) ] (10) h s ( x , y ) = K e − x 2 + y 2 c s 2 In Eqs. (7)–(10), i = 1,...N where N is the number of bands or channels in the input image, s = 1,..S, where S is the number of scales, w s is the weight of the scale, I i ( x , y ) is the ith band of the input RGB colour image, h s ( x , y ) is the Gaussian surround function or spatial filter kernel, I M S R i ( x , y ) is the ith band of the output image of the MSR algorithm while I M S R C R i ( x , y ) is the ith band of the final output image of the MSRCR algorithm after applying the colour restoration function. Lastly, α, β, G and b are constants which are termed canonical gain-offset parameters to obtain the best results for the MSRCR [5] which is highly computationally complex. The colour restoration function in (7) utilizes decoupled, normalized R, G and B channels of the original image (the value being converted to the logarithm domain) to reduce effects of inter-channel dependency [5]. 3.3.2 Ratio rule The ratio rule was developed by Seow, et al. [7,6] and is a state-space associative memory-based neural network. The network employs a line-of-attraction-based representation to describe the RGB inter-channel colour relationships within the image [6,7]. After training the network with the initial colour arrangement prior to processing, the system recalls the initial colour structure of the processed image by iteration [6,7]. This information is used to recalibrate the colours of the processed faded RGB colour image, effectively performing restoration. The homomorphic filter [1,2] was the image enhancement algorithm used for the processing of the RGB colour image, leading to the faded result that required restoration. The Ratio Rule scheme is evidently computationally complex [33], and it is not clear what the implications would be if the size of the images increases considerably in addition to increase in iterative operations. Furthermore, the algorithm and its results were not extensively compared to existing colour enhancement alternatives. A similar colour retrieval and enhancement scheme is proposed by Iqbal, et al. for surveillance images [34]. 3.3.3 Non-linear colour spaces Luma-based approaches have become the norm in colour enhancement-based image processing, due to the established colour coordinate transforms and successes in colour segmentation applications utilizing non-linear colour spaces. Studies carried out using this solution have shown that the system is feasible and hardware architectures utilizing the schemes have been reported in the literature [8,9]. These include the HSI and HSV colour spaces and in the latter, the hue is defined as the rotation angle between the Red plane and the origin [1–3]. The saturation is the distance from any point in the colour space system to the colour surface [1–3], while the value (V) represents the intensity (or luminosity) channel attributes of the image. The equations for the RGB to HSV transformation [1,2] are given as; (11) V = max ( R , G , B ) ; S = V − min ( R , G , B ) (12) H = { G − B S ; R = V 2 + B − R S ; G = V 4 + R − G S ; B = V } The HSI colour space was based on the human visual system and colour perception and is modelled with a colour hexagon, triangle or circle representation [1,2]. The hue, saturation and intensity attributes are similar in definition to that of the HSV system; however, their mathematical expressions are different. The primary and secondary colours of light are vertices in the hexagon model and line segments in the colour triangle model [1–3]. The primary and secondary colours are separated by a value of 120° in the colour circle representation [1–3]. The equations for the RGB to HSI conversion [1,2] are given as; (13) I = R + G + B 3 ; S = 1 − min ( R , G , B ) I (14) H = { θ ; i f B ≤ G 360 ° − θ B > G } ; θ = c o s − 1 ( ( R − G ) + ( R − B ) 2 ( ( R − G ) 2 + ( R − B ) ( G − B ) ) ) The HSI colour conversion yields superior results compared to the HSV colour space [30,3,8]. Large LUTs are normally used for the hue computation in HSI space, though this becomes impractical for images with larger bit depths greater than eight bits per pixel (bpp) on digital hardware systems with limited memory. There are numerous alternative equations for calculating the hue component [3,30], which is the most crucial aspect. The search for alternatives is partly due to the challenges encountered in accurately computing the hue channel in digital hardware devices such as FPGAs using fixed point [3,30]. However, a hardware architecture solution utilizing a proven alternative formula, resulting in the full HSI converter FPGA hardware architecture has been reported in recent literature [3,30]. To date, this is still the only publicly known or available implementation. Based on work in the literature, the HSV variant is the most common digital hardware implementation of nonlinear colour space converters [9,3,35,18]. This is due to its relative ease of implementation compared to the HSI colour space conversion in fixed-point digital hardware [30]. Since the Hue is the most important aspect of the human visual system, on which the HSI and HSV colour spaces are based, any distortions in computation would affect the final result, even without further processing [3,30]. In the HSV case, hue computation is much more straightforward, using multiplexer and basic rational operations. However, utilizing the non-linear colour space converters result in a speed performance bottleneck in hardware if only the intensity channel is processed (though this is an advantage in terms of reduced computational load and complexity, if the image processing algorithm itself is relatively highly involved). This is because latency increases since the Hue and Saturation channels must be synchronized with appropriate delays to ensure that they are correctly combined with the corresponding processed intensity channel for accurate conversion to RGB space after processing. This thwarts parallelization efforts due to the dependency of all three channels on each other for the reverse conversion. Even pipelining techniques reach a peak performance ceiling beyond which there is no further improvement in speed of the design. Latency is increased further along with throughput as a result but this delay adds to the speed of the reverse conversion. Thus, no matter how fast the image processing algorithm or the colour space conversions are, they all depend on the amount of delay required to ensure accurate synchronization and conversion to RGB space. 3.3.4 DCT-based colour enhancement This scheme was proposed by Mukherjee and Mitra for colour enhancement in DCT domain [32]. The approach converts the RGB image to the YCbCr or YUV colour space and computes the DCT of each component [32]. Three main processes are then performed on these transformed components, namely; local background illumination adjustment, local contrast preservation and colour preservation [32]. In spite of its apparent simplicity, there is DCT computation, block splitting and merging steps and several parameters to consider in addition to a blocking artefact removal (BAR) algorithm [32]. Also, the number of parameters to tune increases, depending on the function chosen for illumination adjustment. Thus, the algorithm is not automated, requires user specified parameters, a selected function and option of using BAR algorithm if blocky effects appear in the processed images. 3.3.5 Hue and range preserving colour enhancement Initially, the work by Naik and Murphy proposed a colour image enhancement algorithm that avoided the gamut problem [21]. Recently, Nikolova and Steidl proposed a fast hue and range preserving histogram specification algorithm to mitigate the gamut problem that occurs after RGB colour image enhancement [23]. Rather than processing each individual channel, they convert the image to the HSI colour space and map the intensity channel to an ideally chosen histogram using strict ordering algorithm developed by [36]. However, the algorithm is not automated and performs best with user specified parameters and and may yield inconsistent results. 4 Proposed colour enhancement approach Based on analysis of related works, there is need for a scheme that combines the effectiveness and advantages of the HSI and HSV colour space while avoiding their weaknesses. Such a scheme should be able to handle most images presented and yield good colour enhancement/rendition regardless of the damaging effects of the prior applied image contrast enhancement algorithm. This is in addition to avoidance of distortion or degradation of the image pixel intensity values in the process of colour rendition. The requirements of this system include; • Perform on par or (if possible) better than the HSI and HSV colour converters • Inherit their strengths (decoupling intensity, thus becoming contrast agnostic) and eliminating their weaknesses. • Should not distort colour balance of the R, G and B channels. • Suitable, practical and amenable to hardware implementation. • Should be adaptive and avoid manual parameter adjustments. • Should be generic and work with most algorithms it is combined with. The general form of the proposed algorithm consists of a contrast enhancement transfer function, T ( f ( x , y ) ) and colour enhancement function, C ( f ( x , y ) ) of an input RGB colour image f ( x , y ) = { I i ( x , y ) ; i = 1 t o N } with the number of channels, N =3 expressed in the following form for each channel; (15) I i f i n a l ( x , y ) = C ( I i ( x , y ) ) . T ( I i ( x , y ) ) Assume the RGB colour cube as a container, within which all possible colour image configurations will fit. Thus, we show a colour plot of the relationship between the R, G and B channels in a colour image. If we consider the image pixels as particles, and that the cohesion of these particles taken as a function of their distances apart from their mean, then we can measure the correlation of the pixels to each other. Ideally, highly correlated particles are closer (greater cohesion) while those that are further apart have less correlation (lower cohesion) with each other. However, since the distribution of image colour pixels do not follow a normal distribution and will have highly skewed mean vales, the usage of the mode in the probability mass function (PMF) gives a better estimate. Thus, we initially assume that the colourfulness or colour aesthetics that is visualized by the human visual system and interpreted by the brain could be perceived as a measure of the cohesion or correlation of these particles defined by their closeness to their modal ratio values. If the R, G and B particles are slightly apart, the colour balance is slightly modified. However, if the distance increases between the particles and the centre of the probability mass distribution, the colour fades or distorts and colour balance is lost (destabilization). This balance is the inherent colour relationship between the R, G and B channels of colour images. We proceed to test these assumptions with actual experiments to verify, modify, discard or re-evaluate them. The figures shown in Fig. 1 illustrate this idea of a colourful (Notre Dame) [5] image and its distortion in relation to its RGB colour plot. In Fig. 1(b), the image is highly distorted since the R, G, B particles are scattered and some are almost at the edge of the cube. This distortion can arise from a grey-scale algorithm with extremely high gain incorrectly applied to a RGB colour image. Furthermore, the degradation is drastic in the high frequency regions or areas with more “energetic” pixels. Note that the smooth, slowly varying regions (blue sky) are relatively unaffected by the distortion. The proposed system re-establishes correlation between the various colour channels by forcing these scattered particles closer or re-arranging the structure of the particles without upsetting the colour balance. This reduces the distance between particles, indicating a visual plot of colourfulness. The proposed method enhances colour images, avoids saturation of bright/dark regions of images, thus suitable for both contrast enhancement and illumination normalization/correction algorithms. We will show that considerable improvements are obtained with the proposed colour enhancement scheme. 4.1 Colour channel dominancy and distortion prediction Initial experiments were performed to determine any discernible consistent pattern between the R, G and B channels using normalized decoupled versions of the channels based on formulations from the literature. The sample results for the initial experiment are as shown in Fig. 2 (a) with the histogram of the inverse normalized RGB channels or intensity ratios of the girl image [37] processed with the intensity ratio controlled HF. Observing the modal ratios show that the Red channel has a less common occurring value. Any attempt at using the actual modal ratio values for the red component in this case will yield erratic results as shown in Fig. 2(b) as the most occurring pixel ratio is not up to a third of the RGB colour image. Thus, when using the adaptive the red channel is overcompensated, leading to oversaturation, causing the observed colour bleeding effect in Fig. 2(b). The red flower in the image is completely indistinguishable from the red scarf in Fig. 2(c) and other red regions are also overcompensated. Sample results in Table 1 show the modal ratios of the normalized colour channels of several tested images and indicate that most of the pixel values are close to the assumed model of intensity, with a factor of 3. The pie charts generated in Fig. 3 shows the modal ratio profile (i.e. most common ratio) values obtained for the decoupled, normalized R, G and B channels of the Girl image. The values generated in the plots indicate the percentage of values that match the modal ratio of each channel. Rounding up of values as shown on the left hand side of Table 1 will increase the respective percentages for each of the channels in the modal profiles, which would lead to colour distortions after processing. Based on quick observation, 3 is the most commonly encountered ratio value, validating the naive intensity model from the HSI by experimentation. The pie chart representation was chosen since it provides quick visual cues regarding the balancing of R, G and B channels of a colour image, which may not be easily observed using conventional visual representations such as histograms and image diagrams. The dominance of a channel can be easily deduced due to the pie chart plots of the modal ratio values in each channel (Fig. 4 ). The reason for the distortion of colours in the background component of the image in Fig. 2(c) is due to the naïve adaptive scheme applying the computed modal ratio of each channel as a factor. This favours the less dominant channels (in this case, R and B) and will result in some colour regions of the image being over enhanced (where modal ratio values are less than or equal to 3) and punishes the more dominant channels (in this case, G) while other colour regions are slightly or moderately enhanced (where ratio values are greater than 3). This is confirmed by the saturated blue background and red hue of the face and scarf foreground and the RGB image modal ratio profile in Fig. 3. Thus, the modal ratio profile is a reliable indicator of the results of the blind, adaptive scheme, which are clearly undesirable. This observation may possibly explain the gamut problem for certain images after processing in a different colour space and reverse-mapped to RGB. 4.2 RGB colour enhancement Initially, the system was developed using the intensity component computation of the HSI colour space as a starting point since it provides the best colour rendition when combined with enhancement algorithms [30]. Additionally, the proposed system is less computationally complex than the colour restoration function and the ratio rule method (which is iterative). Based on approximations of the experimental results, we define the enhanced output colour image as; (16) I i f i n a l ( x , y ) = [ I i ( x , y ) I ] . I i ' ( x , y ) ; I = ∑ i = 1 N w i I i Where i =1…, N; N being the number of channels (N =3 for RGB image) and the intensity channel, I while w i is the weighting factor of the ith channel such that ∑ i = 1 N w i = 1 . The weights do not have to be equal but their sum must be unity. For the HSI colour space, the intensity is calculated and setting R = I 1, G = I 2, and B = I 3 and recognising that w 1 = w 2 = w 3 = 1 3 , the well-known form is as shown in (17) (17) I = I 1 + I 2 + I 3 3 = R + G + B 3 Thus, based on extensive experimentation, a large majority of colour images are properly enhanced using the scheme, while a few outlier images need some modification by using unequal weights for the improved colour output. The well balanced images will yield ratios of 3 for each channel, but other images will yield ratios greater than or less than 3 for either the R, G or B channels. Investigation of the degree of dispersion of pixel ratios from the modal value necessitated a measure to evaluate the standard deviation from mode (SDFM) and is defined as; (18) S D F M = ρ = ∑ i = 0 N ( I i − m ) 2 N Where m is the modal value obtained from I i , the image intensity ratio (or inverse normalized image) distribution of the ith channel of the colour image. The values obtained from the R, G and B channels of the girl image are 0.6711, 13.9831 and 6.7491 respectively. The figures imply that the R channel has the lowest variance from the modal value. However, this does not give a clear explanation, thus the usefulness of the modal profile, which indicates that the R channel intensity ratios are quite low. Evaluation of the maximum value in the R channel yields a value of 9 and a minimum value of 1.0233. For the G channel, maximum value is 168 and minimum value is 1.2857. For the B channel, maximum value is 225 and minimum value is 1.6667. Thus, the modal values actually give the maximum value of the probability mass function, which cannot be deduced from the maximum and minimum pixel intensity values across colour channels. The standard formula for computing a greyscale image from RGB space based on the luminous efficacy curve [1] is given as; (19) I = 0.299 * R + 0.587 * G + 0.114 * B In (19), w 1 =0.299, w 2 =0.587, w 3 =0.114 and in all cases w 1 + w 2 + w 3

column87: 42]. 5 Experiments and comparisons The results in this section are presented to verify the claims made concerning the proposed colour enhancement/restoration algorithm (PA). The first part introduces the relevant metrics used in assessing image quality and how they are interpreted in results. The second part deals with the augmentation of the colour enhancement abilities of existing greyscale image-based contrast enhancement algorithms with PA. The third and fourth section compare PA with other relevant colour spaces and colour enhancement algorithms from the literature respectively. The fifth section discusses the justification for the substitution of the AMF within the EPF component of the SLIP-GUM algorithm for reduced computational time. The sixth section deals with attempts to adaptively determine the type and degree of degradation (unbalanced colour or uneven illumination) of the input image prior to processing. 5.1 Image quality metrics The visual and quantitative results are presented to verify the claims made about the proposed algorithm. The quantitative measures for evaluation include the Colourfulness (C) [40]

The ratio of the HDI is not computed since the metric utilizes the original and processed images in computation of the deviation parameter. The flowchart for the entire experimental system setup is shown in Fig. 7 . The details of determination of colour balance of the input colour image and checking for adequate colour correction is explained in subsequent sections. 5.2 Colour enhancement of images processed with greyscale-based algorithms This section presents results visually observed in images processed with the proposed colour enhancement scheme combined with existing illumination correction and contrast enhancement algorithms. We compare results using the swan image [5] processed with HSI

The results in Table 2 show that for colour enhancement metrics such as relative colour enhancement (RC)
column165: the proposed colour enhancement algorithm gives consistently higher values than the standard RGB-based approaches. The colourfulness and EMEC values have increased while the HDI value has dropped considerably
column166: indicating that the colour enhancement algorithm has reduced the hue deviation and avoided colour distortion effect of the various algorithms
column167: thus the lower HDI can be seen as better cohesion of colour components. In general
column168: the proposed scheme yields improved colour rendition when combined with grey-scale based enhancement algorithms for processing RGB colour images. 5.3 Comparisons with relevant colour spaces from the literature The proposed approach is also compared with the relevant colour spaces in this section and results indicate improved colourfulness compared to nonlinear colour spaces such as HSI and HSV systems. Due to space constraints
column169: we only present a sample of the results for the HF algorithm instance. The image results and corresponding RGB plots are shown in Fig. 9

column172: it yields clearly richer colours and saturation without bleeding (light-house and surfers images [5]). The colour fading is clearly observed in the standard RGB result of the HF in Fig. 9 and which has the lowest RC/CEF and REMEC values in the plots in Fig. 10. Also
column173: observing the RGB colour plots in Fig. 9

column175: HDI and EMEC in Fig. 10 for the processed images. The HDI can be used as a measure of the degree of spread since too much dilation leads to colour distortion
column176: while excessive contraction results in fading corresponding to very high HDI (RGB result)
column177: while a moderate HDI indicates adequate dilation (RGB-IV result) and minimal HDI yields the ideal balance
column178: as observed in results using HSI and HSV colour spaces. 5.4 Comparisons with other algorithms from the literature We also compare the proposed scheme with other colour enhancement algorithms from the literature such as MSRCR

column182: HSI variants of the HF for the surfer

column185: based on CEF/RC values. It should be noted that several of these other approaches still require processing in the HSV/HSI/YUV/YCbCr colour space to improve colour rendition results. Conversely
column186: PA can replicate and improve on these results since it can mimic any of the colour spaces without performing the full forward or reverse transformations. The expression for estimating computational complexity given by [32] as; a A + m M + E e is employed
column187: where a is the number of additions
column188: m is the number of multiplications and e is the number of exponential operations per pixel. However
column189: the estimates from [32] do not include divisions and logarithms or incorporate the iterative nature of the DCT-based CES algorithm. We include divisions and logarithmic operations per pixel as d and l in the amended expression given as; a A + m M + e E + d D + l L omitting max/min
column192: trigonometric and compare operations. We compare structural complexity of algorithms in Table 5 . Based on results
column193: the proposed scheme contributes minimal multiplication operations
column194: though it has a relatively large number of division operations per pixel. Only the HSI and HSV forward conversion operations are taken into account in the calculation of their computational complexity. It is also not clear whether the algorithms proposed by [32] included the calculations of the operations for the colour space conversions utilised in their approach. It is also observed that the MSRCR has the highest computational complexity as noted in [32]. In summary
column195: PA attempts to address colour distortion and improve consistency of results
column196: while introducing automation with moderate complexity. Having made the case for the PA
column197: we proceed with reducing the run-time of the earlier mentioned GUM algorithm. 5.5 Edge preserving filter (EPF) replacement in GUM The AMF
column198: which functions as the EPF component in the GUM algorithm is of considerable computational complexity and this adds to the increased run-time of the GUM algorithm. Thus
column200: we explore three contemporary filters that surpass the edge preserving properties of the AMF based on PSNR
column202: MAE and MSE measurements [45] (see also [46]). These three filters include; • The Noise Adaptive Fuzzy Switching Median Filter (NAFSMF) [47] • Entropy guided Switching Trimmed Mean Deviation-boosted Anisotropic Diffusion filter (STMDF-AD) [45] • The Efficient Weighted Average (EWA) Filter [48] The results are shown in Fig. 12 and the mesa image from [11] was processed using the modified GUM algorithm with the aforementioned filters as EPF replacements. For the NAFSMF
column203: the processing of the canyon image is about 0.037363s
column204: while the processing time for AMF is about 6.561111s and for the STMDF-AD
column205: the processing time is about 4.194520s for one iteration. Lastly
column207: the processing time is about 0.336881seconds. Thus based on results
column208: the NAFSMF is the least computationally complex filter and also the fastest while yielding visually similar results to the AMF and EWA filter (which is the second fastest edge preserving filter). The STMDF-AD filter is the second slowest and most complex of the chosen EPFs. Also
column209: its results do not work well in some regions of the processed image since it performs a thresholding effect though there is evidence of increased colour enhancement (Fig. 13 (a)). Either the EWA filter or the NAFSMF can be selected as a EPF replacement
column210: drastically reducing the run-time of the LIP-GUM and SLIP GUM algorithms as a result. We also replace the HSV component with the PA in the GUM algorithm and compare performance. A summary of results is presented in Table 6 for processing the RGB colour swan image with dimensions 385×513. Results show that the STMDF-AD yields the highest values for F and RSD while the NAFSMF yields the best EMEC
column212: RAG values and lowest runtimes. The RGB-IV-based GUM yields the highest RC values and lower runtimes than the HSV-based GUM algorithm. However
column213: the HDI is higher than for the HSV
column214: since hue is not considerably modified in the HSV colour space. Nevertheless
column215: the HDI varies depending on the image being processed
column216: while the RGB-IV scheme yields better results than the standard RGB version and is much faster than the HSI and HSV versions of the SLIP-GUM algorithm (due to parallelization). Moreover
column217: the image results from both HSV and RGB-IV versions of the SLIP-GUM in Fig. 13 are quite similar and bolded values in Table 6 indicate better results. With the RGB-IV and the EPF substitutions
column218: the run-time of the SLIP-GUM algorithm is drastically reduced
column219: while colour and contrast enhancement results are more or less maintained. Thus
column220: the proposed colour enhancement algorithm allows the option of processing in the RGB space
column222: colourful results of the HSI/HSV colour spaces and considerably reducing execution time of the algorithms it augments. 5.6 Classification of image colour quality attributes and limitations of PA It is important to note that although the proposed colour enhancement works well for balanced colour images
column223: it is not suitable for images with haze or dominant colour casts such as underwater images. These images are predominantly blue or green since the blue light has the shortest wavelength and penetrates at greater depths than the other colours [49]. Based on this fact
column224: we attempt to classify images based on the perceptual metrics and also on the modal ratio values of the various images obtained in Table 1. The aim is to understand the limitations of the proposed approach and to predict which images suffer from colour imbalance in order to automatically correct them prior to processing especially those suffering from uneven illumination. It should be noted that though several illumination correction algorithms can perform colour correction on some images
column225: their results are usually not consistent. Also
column226: some images which do not visually exhibit this colour imbalance may still be affected by colour correction algorithms
column227: especially if their dynamic range is not fully utilized. Thus a colour correction stage should be applied only when necessary and we perform some experiments to enable us obtain more information about these types of images. We utilize the mean and the standard deviation of the hue
column228: saturation and value components to help quantify the amount of clustering and dispersion around the mean value for each of the components. It may be deduced that such high variation is an indication of greatly increased contrast as observed in previous works [4
column229: 32]. Based on the preliminary experiments we were able to infer three classes of colour images namely; • Dark colour images with uneven illumination (and dominant colour cast) • Colour images with shadows/uneven illumination • Faded colour images with dominant colour cast Further extensive experiments were performed involving 195 natural images of various types of illumination used by various authors in the literature (see image references). Based on some prior simplistic assumptions; images with the histograms skewed to the right of the distribution are likely to be faded or bright images while those skewed to the left are likely to be the dark images. For the clustered dataset in Fig. 14
column230: lower mean and standard deviation values imply dark images while higher mean and standard deviation values imply brighter images. However
column231: this scheme appears too ambiguous and may make it difficult to properly classify some images. Thus
column232: the images are converted to greyscale from which a binary mask is generated
column233: then the area of light vs black pixels is computed to determine if the image is dark or light. Based on the plot in 14(c)
column234: it is visually clear that the proportion of black pixels is always greater than the proportion of white pixels
column235: thus confirming that all the tested images can be visually perceived as predominantly dark. However
column236: there are varying degrees of proportions based on the different peaks of both white and dark pixel counts
column237: thus the second class of images where the area of black and white pixels is roughly equal. This makes it difficult to accurately predict since some images may have more dark pixels than bright ones but will have them spread out evenly
column238: thus having the appearance of a reasonably bright image with shadow regions. This could lead to the image being misclassified as a dark image and processed accordingly. Other factors include the thresholding function used and accuracy of the selected threshold value
column239: which may move additional pixels below or above the selected threshold. The particular scheme utilized for this experiment is Otsu’s algorithm [50]
column240: which computes an adaptive threshold. Experiments were repeated for images with dominant colour cast to determine these features numerically. and the results are presented in Fig. 15 . For the plot in Fig. 15(a)
column241: the 195 images have their hue components measured for mean and standard deviation and show high values for both quantities with some correlation. However
column242: in the case of 35 underwater images with dominant blue colour cast
column243: the mean and standard deviations of the hue components are quite low and appear to be uncorrelated in 15(b). The images are then colour corrected and have their respective hues measured once more using the mean and standard deviations in 15(c). There is an observed general increase in standard deviation
column244: and variance (contrast) while the mean generally has decreased. The proposed colour enhancement scheme is applied to dark images with dominant colour casts by comparing the mean and standard deviation values of the hue components. An increase or decrease in standard deviation will indicate the effectiveness of the colour enhancement for such images. However
column245: the scheme mostly yields over-saturation of colour corrected images since these do not have faded colours. Thus
column246: it is generally ineffective for underwater images
column247: which are better served by previously developed algorithms in the literature. The findings indicate that a mainly colour correction or white balancing algorithm does not have considerable contrast enhancement or illumination correction effect on images
column248: which are not suffering from dominant colour cast. However
column249: utilizing a strong contrast enhancement algorithm (which depends on the input image statistics such as standard deviation or mean) will drastically alter the results
column250: considerably modifying the image histogram and consequently
column251: the pixel intensity values in each of the R
column254: 52]. The HSI and HSV-based algorithms cannot perform proper colour correction since their inherent strengths of hue preservation and decoupling
column256: which must be performed in RGB space for images with colour cast. However
column257: for contrast enhancement and illumination correction
column258: only the intensity component (for images without colour cast problems) is usually processed. In summary
column259: an ideal colour correction algorithm should only affect the hue and (or) saturation component and not distort the RGB colour relationships of the three channels. Conversely
column260: an ideal contrast enhancement and illumination correction algorithm should modify only the pixel intensities and eliminate uneven illumination without distortion of the hue/saturation components. However
column261: this is rarely achievable in practice due to the non-linear nature of most contemporary algorithms
column262: thus the need for processing in the HSI and HSV colour spaces. It has been shown that the proposed scheme helps to somewhat mitigate this imperfection of contrast enhancement and illumination correction algorithms enabling improved colour processing in RGB space. However
column263: for images with dominant colour cast
column264: the proposed algorithm is unsuitable due to initial incorrect colour composition of such images. Thus
column265: by extracting features that help describe this dominancy in such images
column266: a colour dominance degree detection scheme can be used to determine suitability for such images. 6 Discussions and possible application areas Based on experiments and observable results
column267: the proposed approach eliminates colour fading and distortions usually associated with application of greyscale image enhancement algorithms to RGB colour images. The proposed approach is fast and naturally parallelizable while being relatively easier to implement in FPGA hardware using either fixed or floating point scheme
column268: yielding visually comparable results similar to HSI and HSV-based approaches. The colour bleeding effect observed with processing certain images in the HSI colour space has been mitigated by the combined I–V and adaptive approach. Future possibilities include optimized implementation of the colour enhancement system in hardware for comparison with previous work utilizing HSI and HSV colour spaces in terms of both speed
column269: hardware resource usage and performance. Ultimately
column270: the proposed colour enhancement algorithm due to its generality
column271: can be applied in digital colour photography
column272: tone mapping techniques and remote sensing. Future work will explore the application of the algorithm to other areas in more detail. 7 Conclusion A fast and generalized colour enhancement model has been proposed in this work and shows performance gains in image colour fidelity and reduced complexity. The proposed approach can be modified to mimic the results of any colour space without performing the full transformation in that colour space. This results in cost savings in hardware and faster operation on devices with limited memory and real-time constraints. The colour enhancement algorithm is non-iterative and based on the colourfulness and HDI measure yields excellent and consistent colour enhancement compared to naïve RGB implementations. An adaptive pre-colour correction stage is performed for (dark) images suffering from dominant colour cast prior to colour enhancement and illumination correction as determined from the modal ratio values and statistical parameters of the hue component. Furthermore
column273: we have also improved the effectiveness of the SLIP-GUM algorithm by substitution of the colour and EPF component drastically reducing execution time while maintaining similar results obtained in HSV/HSI domain using the proposed colour enhancement scheme. "
