column2: Band-Gap tuning of graphene by dual AuCl3-Acceptor and N-Donor doping: A first principle study
column3: Abstract Graphenes dual-doped by AuCl3-acceptor and N-donor have been investigated using the first principle calculations. The band gaps of the dual-doped graphenes are opened. Three supercell models of dual-doped graphenes were calculated for comparison. With the increasing of N-AuCl3 distance, the band-gap width of graphene decreases, but the work function and the formation energy (E form) of graphene increases. We suggest the changes of band-gap width and Fermi level are attributed to the charge redistribution between N, AuCl3 and graphene. The change of E form is originated from the variations of L CN(Å) and L CC(Å) caused by the interaction between AuCl3 and graphene layer.
column5: Keywords Graphene Band-Gap tuning N-AuCl3 dual doping First-principles 1 Introduction Graphene, a two-dimensional (2D) monolayer structure of carbon, has attracted intense attention since its first successful preparation in 2004 [1]. Graphene has been widely used in many applications such as solar cells [2], composites [3–5], field emission sources and vacuum electronic devices [6,7]. In these areas, graphene shows interesting optical and electrical properties such as high transmittance，high surface area, strong electrical conductivity, easy to modify and mass production [8–11]. Through exploring the band structure of graphene, it is possible to get a deeper understanding and more rational use of the special optical and electrical properties of graphene. Thus, the band gap opening of graphene becomes an interesting work. Researchers have studied the methods to open the band gap of graphene, such as single-doping [12] or dual-doping with donors and acceptors [13,14], molecule absorbing [15,16], and B-N embedding [17–19]. Dual-doping with donors and acceptors is a good way to open the band gap of graphene. Especially, B-N dual doping has been investigated by many researchers, because the radii of B and N atom are similar with that of C atom. However, B acceptors and N donors are both substitutional defects. Dual doping with high concentration may strongly degrade the lattice integrity of graphene and decrease the electrical properties such as carrier mobility [13,14]. AuCl3 is an acceptor-like molecule for graphene and does not substitute the C atoms, because the Au3+ ions can be reduced to Au clusters through a charge transfer from the graphene surface [20–22]. Thus, the N-AuCl3 dual doping may provide a way to open the band gap of graphene with less substitutional defects. However, to our best knowledge, so far there has few calculation studies on the band-gap tuning of graphene by N-AuCl3 dual doping. In this paper, the band-gap tuning of graphene by AuCl3-acceptor and N-donor dual doping were studied using the first-principle calculations. Results show that the band-gaps of graphenes are successfully opened. Three supercell models of dual-doped graphenes were calculated for comparison. The band structures, the density of states (DOS), the partial density of states (PDOS), the formation energies (E form) and the charge densities difference of the three supercell models were comprehensively investigated. 2 Models and methods All the calculations were performed by CASTEP package based on density functional theory and all the models have been optimized successfully. We chose the projector augmented wave method (PAW) [23] to signify electron-ionic core interaction. Using Perdew Burke Ernzerhof (PBE) [24] of the generalized gradient approximation (GGA) to treat the electron exchange and correlation. We build 7×7×1 supercells of pristine and dual-doped graphenes. Each supercell has 98 carbon atoms. In the dual-doped graphene system, a carbon atom was substituted by a nitrogen atom and then an AuCl3 molecule was adsorbed on the surface of graphene. A vacuum layer with a thickness of 20Å was set to keep the adjacent graphene layers without interaction. In Fig. 1 , in order to study the effect of Au-N distances on the graphene electronic properties, we constructed three supercell models with different Au-N distances for comparison. The Au-N distances for model A, B and C were 3.757, 5.561 and 6.731Å, respectively. The cutoff energy of the plane wave was set to be 350eV, and k-point meshes with a reciprocal space resolution of 2π×0.03Å−1 were used for Brillouin zone sampling to ensure the error bars of the total energies were less than 1 meV/atom. 3 Results and discussion Fig. 2 shows the calculated band structures of doped graphenes. The band-gap width of pristine graphene is zero [25,26]. As for the doped graphenes, the conduction band minimums are higher in energy than the corresponding valence band maximums, which indicates the band-gaps successfully opened by the N-AuCl3 dual doping. The Fermi level of model A is in the band-gap, which is similar with previous study for graphene by B and N doping [27]. However, the Fermi levels of model B and C are in the valence band, which suggests the effective charge transfer for AuCl3 is larger than that for N atoms. The calculated band-gap values for model A, B and C are listed in Table 1 . The d Au-N values are the distances between N and Au atoms. Clearly, the band-gap width of graphene decreases with the increasing of N-AuCl3 distance. Model A has the largest band-gap width (0.398eV) with the smallest N-AuCl3 distance of 3.757Å. Fig. 3 shows the density of states (DOS) of graphenes. DOS for pristine graphene at the Fermi level is very small [25,26,28]. Compared with the band structure of pristine graphene, the band-gap opening is observed in the DOS map. It is obvious that band-gap of graphene decreases with the increasing of N-AuCl3 distance. In order to further understand the electronic properties of dual-doped graphenes, the partial density of states (PDOS) were calculated. And the calculated results show that the three models have similar PDOS spectra. In Fig. 4 , we give a representative PDOS of model A. Hybridizations between Au-d and Cl-p states, which located at −5eV, −1.85eV and −0.6eV, were observed [29]. Similarly, hybridizations also appear between p orbitals of C atoms and the p orbitals of N atom. Fig. 4 also indicates the DOS peaks near the Fermi level are mainly dominated by the AuCl3 molecule. Thus, the interaction between AuCl3 molecule and graphene layer enhances with the increasing of N-AuCl3 distance. The formation energy (E form) is important for doping efficiency and stability. We have calculated the E form of the dual-doped graphenes, which is defined as: (1) E form = E doped − E pure − E N- E AuCl3 + E C where E doped, E pure, E N, E AuCl3 and E C are total energies of the doped graphene, the pristine graphene, the isolated N atom, the AuCl3 molecule and the isolated C atom, respectively. The calculated E form, L CN and L CC of the doped graphenes are shown in Table 2 . It is obvious that the E form increases with the increasing of d Au-N. Model A with the smallest d Au-N of 3.757Å has the lowest E form of 0.4547eV, due to the average L CN and L CC increase with the increasing of d Au-N. The change of E form is mainly originated from the variations of the average L CN and L CC caused by the interaction between AuCl3 and graphene layer. In order to further understand the Fermi level shift caused by d Au-N, the charge densities difference of the model A and C are calculated, shown in Fig. 5 . Here in, the electronic charge density difference as a two-dimensional (2D) plane was studied. The (110) plane crossing two C atoms and one N atom is selected to estimate the charge variation of graphene plane. It can be seen from the figure that there is no transfer of charge between graphene and AuCl3 molecules, therefore the interaction of them is Van der Waals force, and belongs to physical adsorption.It is known that the information of charge redistribution is mainly based on the shift of Fermi level [30] and the charge redistribution usually shifts the Fermi level [31]. Comparing model C with model A, we find that the change in charge around gold atoms indicates that the interaction between gold atoms and chlorine atoms is weakened and that the effect of AuCl3 molecules on graphene layers is enhanced, thus making the graphene layers charge redistribution, leading to Fermi level into the valence band. 4 Conclusions In summary, three supercell models (dual-doped graphenes with different d Au-N) were calculated based on the density functional theory method. The band structures, DOS, PDOS, E form and electronic charge densities difference were studied. Our results show that the band-gaps of the graphenes were successfully opened by AuCl3 N dual-doping. With the increasing of d Au-N, the band-gap width of graphene decreases, however, the work function and E form of graphene increase. The dual-doped graphene with the smallest d Au-N of 3.757Å shows a largest band-gap width of 0.398eV and a lowest E form of 0.4547eV. The changes of band-gap width and Fermi level are attributed to the charge change between N, AuCl3 and graphene. The change of the E form is originated from the variations of LCN and LCC caused by the interaction between AuCl3 and graphene. Acknowledgments This work was supported by the National Natural Science Foundation of China (51501017 and 61604016), the China Postdoctoral Science Foundation funded project (2016M590913), the Shannxi Postdoctoral Science Foundation funded project (2016BSHEDZZ01), and the Fundamental Research Funds for the Central Universities (CHD2017ZD142).

column2: A simplified modal expansion formalism adapted to the optical design of resonant cavity enhanced photodetectors using metallic gratings
column3: Abstract In this communication, we present a method to model the light absorption in a resonant photoconductor based on a photoconductive layer sandwiched between a metallic grating in front side and a metallic backside mirror. We started from a modal expansion formalism previously developed in order to model the transmission and the reflection of an infinite array of holes and we added the effect of a stack of homogeneous layers ended by a metallic mirror. It is finally shown that the electromagnetic response of the structure calculated with this numerical method is in good agreement with a more rigorous method such as the rigorous coupled wave analysis, whereas it requires a much lower computing power.
column5: MSC 00-01 99-00 Keywords Ultrafast photodetector Modal expansion analysis Diffraction gratings 1 Introduction Ultrafast photodetectors are key devices for the generation and the detection of THz waves based on the laser and optoelectronics technologies [1,2]. As far as now, the devices which present suitable properties for these applications, i.e. a THz frequency bandwidth and a high saturation photocurrent, are uni-travelling carrier photodiodes [3] (UTC-PD) pumped by 1550 nm lasers and ultrafast photoconductors based on photoconductive materials presenting sub-picosecond carrier life time. This second class of devices is dominated by THz photoconductors using GaAs epitaxial layers grown at low temperature (200°C) [4] and pumped by 780-nm-lasers [5]. Last years, it has been shown that their properties could be greatly improved by using resonant optical cavities in which metallic layers serve in the same time as bias electrodes and mirrors of the cavity [6,7]. Concerning the THz photoconductors, the optical cavity allows for reducing the thickness of the absorption layer while keeping constant the quantum efficiency (defined here as the ratio of the number of charge carrier generated in the device to the number of incident photons by unit of time) resulting in an increase of the photoresponse. This concept can also be adapted to the UTC-PD in order to reduce the thickness of the p-doped absorbing layer, and then improve the frequency bandwidth without loss in quantum efficiency. The front mirror of the optical cavity is semi-transparent and consisted of a thin (20nm) gold layer in the first attempts [6], however this solution suffers from some drawbacks such as high optical losses and high sheet electrical resistivities. In a second step, front mirrors consisting of a one dimensional array of slits has been considered, allowing for a better transmission and a lower effective sheet electrical resistivity [8]. In this work, we present a simplified modal expansion formalism (SMEF) based on the work of De Leon-Perez and co-workers [9,10], in order to design such an optical cavity which needs a very low computing power as compared with more standard methods such as the rigorous coupled wave method. The SMEF is similar to a coupled mode analysis [11], but with some simplification coming from the use of waveguide modes in the slits patterned in the metallic sheet. Here, in a first part, we will remind the method as presented by De Leon-Perez and coworkers with the addition of some missing steps. In a second part we will present the additional steps allowing for modeling model not only a metallic grating, but a also Fabry-Prot cavity based on such a grating. 2 Scattering of light by an array of metallic holes In this first part, we are going to remind the main steps of the SMEF method as presented in Ref. [9] allowing for the calculation of the electromagnetic response of an infinite two-dimensional array to an incident plane wave. The array is assumed to be in the x–y plane and has a finite thickness h, as we can see in Fig. 1 . The lattice parameters are L x and L y . The analysis is performed by using the CGS system and only the transverse components of the electric field E and magnetic field H , which are used in the boundary conditions at the interface between different media, are taking into account. The dirac notation is used, such that 〈 r ∥| E 〉= E ( r ∥)=(E x ( r ∥), E y ( r ∥)) t where t stand for transposition and r ∥ =(x, y). Regions I and III are dielectric semi-spaces characterized by the real dielectric constant ϵ 1 and ϵ 3, respectively. Region II represents the corrugated metal film with a wavelength-dependent dielectric function ϵ m . We assume that the system is illuminated by an incident wave coming from region I. We expand the EM fields on the eigenmodes of each region, and match them at the boundaries. In region I, the fields are expanded into an infinite set of plane waves with parallel wavevector k ∥ =(k x , k y ) and polarization σ. The incident radiation is labeled by the superscript 0. The fields can be written in terms of reflection amplitude ρ k ∥σ as (1) | E I ⟩ = e i k z 0 z | k ∥ 0 σ 0 ⟩ + Σ k σ ρ k ∥ σ e - i k z z | k ∥ σ ⟩ (2) | - u z × H I ⟩ = Y k ∥ 0 σ 0 e i k z 0 z | k ∥ 0 σ 0 ⟩ - Σ k ∥ σ Y k ∥ σ ρ k ∥ σ e - i k z z | k ∥ σ ⟩ where u z is the unitary vector along the z-direction and the summation runs over parallel wavevectors such as k ∥ = k ∥ 0 + K R , K R being a vector of the reciprocal lattice. The real space representation of the plane waves is given by 〈 r ∥ | k ∥ σ 〉 = exp ( i k ∥ · r ) k ∥ L x L y ( k x , k y ) t , p − polarization ( − k y , k x ) t , s − polarization where we assume a ∥ k ∥ σ ⟩ independent normalization 〈 k ∥ σ| k ∥ σ〉=1. The electric and magnetic field are related through the admittance Y k ∥p = k ω ϵ 1/k z and Y k ∥s = k z /k ω where k ω =2π/λ 0 (λ 0 is the free space wavelength of the incident radiation, and k ∥ 2 + k z 2 = ϵ 1 k ω 2 (see Appendix A for further details). 2.1 Expansion of the fields in the 3 regions We have already seen in Eq. (1) the expansion on a basis of plane waves in the region I. In this first part, we assume that the Region III (z ≥ h) is semi-infinite, so the EM fields can also be expanded in plane waves and expressed in terms of transmission amplitudes t k ∥σ : (3) | E III ⟩ = Σ k σ t k ∥ σ e i k z ′ ( z - h ) | k ∥ σ ⟩ (4) | - u z × H III ⟩ = Σ k ∥ σ Y k ∥ σ ′ t k ∥ σ e i k z ′ ( z - h ) | k ∥ σ ⟩ Now, we are going to expand the EM fields in Region II on a waveguide modes basis corresponding to the geometry of the holes. Noting |α〉 a certain waveguide mode, and C α and D α the expansion coefficient, we can write: (5) | E II ⟩ = Σ α ( C α e i k α z z + D α e - i k α z z ) | α ⟩ (6) | - u z × H II ⟩ = Σ α Y α ( C α e i k α z z - D α e - i k α z z ) | α ⟩ where Y α = k ω ϵ 2/k αz and Y α = k αz /k ω for TE and TM modes respectively. 2.2 Application of the boundary conditions at each region interface Following Ref. [9], we use a crude approximation in order to take into account the real properties of the metal sheet forming the grating. It establishes the following relation between the tangential components of the EM fields at the horizontal interface: E = z s H × u n , where u n is the vector normal to the surface and pointing to the interior of the metal and z s = 1 / ϵ M . This continuity equation must be satisfied at each interface. In Region I u n = u z and the continuity equation gives: (7) z s H × u z = z s H x z s H y z s H z × 0 0 1 = z s H y - z s H x 0 = z s Y k ∥ σ · E x E y 0 2.2.1 Continuity of the electric field in z =0 In z =0 and with the dirac notations, it gives: (8) | E I 〉 = z s Y k ∥ σ | E I 〉 ⇔ (9) | k ∥ 0 σ 0 ⟩ + Σ k σ ρ k ∥ σ | k ∥ σ ⟩ = z s Y k ∥ 0 σ 0 | k ∥ 0 σ 0 ⟩ - Σ k ∥ σ z s Y k ∥ σ ρ k ∥ σ | k ∥ σ ⟩ Now, if we project on the plane waves basis 〈 k ∥ σ|, we obtain: (10) δ k ∥ , k ∥ 0 δ σ , σ 0 + ρ k ∥ σ = z s Y k ∥ 0 σ 0 δ k ∥ , k ∥ 0 δ σ , σ 0 − z s Y k ∥ σ ρ k ∥ σ In Region II, in z =0+, with also u n = u z , it gives (11) Σ α ( C α + D α ) | α ⟩ = Σ α z s Y α ( C α - D α ) | α ⟩ And once projected on the 〈 k ∥ σ| basis: (12) Σ α ( C α + D α ) 〈 k ∥ σ | α 〉 = Σ α z s Y α ( C α − D α ) 〈 k ∥ σ | α 〉 If we have the continuity of the Electric Field in z =0, we must equalize both terms of Eqs. (10) and (12). Then it gives: (13) Σ α ( C α + D α 〈 k ∥ σ | α 〉 = δ k ∥ , k ∥ 0 δ σ , σ 0 + ρ k ∥ σ (14) Σ α z s Y α ( C α − D α ) 〈 k ∥ σ | α 〉 = z s Y k ∥ 0 σ 0 δ k ∥ , k 0 δ σ , σ 0 − z s Y k ∥ σ ρ k ∥ σ (13) and (14) gives: (15) Σ α 〈 k ∥ σ | α 〉 E α = δ k ∥ , k ∥ 0 δ σ , σ 0 ( 1 − z s Y k ∥ σ ) + ρ k ∥ σ ( 1 + z s Y k ∥ σ ) ⇔ (16) ρ k ∥ σ = 1 f k ∥ σ + Σ α 〈 k ∥ σ | α 〉 E α − f k ∥ σ − f k ∥ σ + δ k ∥ , k ∥ 0 δ σ , σ 0 where E α = C α f α − + D α f α + and f α ± = 1 ± z s Y α . 2.2.2 Continuity of the electric field in z = h In z = h −, u n =− u z and we have: (17) Σ α ( C α e i k α z h + D α e - i k α z h ) | α ⟩ = - Σ α z s Y α ( C α e i k α z h - D α e - i k α z h ) | α ⟩ In z = h +, (18) Σ k ∥ σ t k ∥ σ | k ∥ σ ⟩ = - Σ k ∥ σ z s Y k ∥ σ ′ t k ∥ σ | k ∥ σ ⟩ Once projected on the 〈 k ∥ σ|, (18) and (17) gives: (19) t k ∥ σ − Σ α ( C α e i k α z h + D α e − i k α z h ) 〈 k ∥ σ | α 〉 = − z s Y k ∥ σ ′ t k ∥ σ + Σ α z s Y α ( C α e i k α z h − D α e − i k α z h ) 〈 k ∥ σ | α 〉 ⇔ (20) t k ∥ σ = − 1 f k ∥ σ ′ + Σ α 〈 k ∥ σ | α 〉 E α ′ where E α ′ = − C α f α + e i k α z h − D α f α − e − i k α z h . 2.2.3 Continuity of the magnetic field Let us now impose the continuity of the tangential component of the magnetic field which has to be fulfill only in the slits. This is done by projecting the fields on the |α〉 basis. In z =0, we obtain: (21) Y k ∥ 0 σ 0 | k ∥ 0 σ 0 ⟩ - Σ k ∥ σ Y k ∥ σ ρ k ∥ σ | k ∥ σ ⟩ = Σ α Y α ( C α - D α ) | α ⟩ and once projected in the |α〉, it becomes: (22) Y k ∥ 0 σ 0 ⟨ α | k ∥ 0 σ 0 ⟩ - Σ k ∥ σ Y k ∥ σ ρ k ∥ σ ⟨ α | k ∥ σ ⟩ = Y α ( C α - D α ) In z = h, once projected on |α〉 we obtain: (23) Σ k ∥ σ Y k ∥ σ ' t k ∥ σ ⟨ α | k ∥ σ ⟩ = Y α ( C α e i k α z h - D α e - i k α z h ) If we put the expressions of ρ k∥σ and t k∥σ given in Eqs. (16) and (20) in theses expressions, we obtain for Eq. the set of coupled equations for E α and E α ′ which are essentially the modal amplitudes of the electric field at the input and output interfaces of the holes, respectively: (33) ( G α α − Σ α ) E α + ∑ β ≠ α G α β E β − G α V E α ′ = I α (34) ( G γ γ ′ − Σ γ ) E γ ′ + ∑ ν ≠ γ G γ ν ′ E ν ′ − G γ V E γ = 0 Once E α and E α ′ are known, all the other quantities can be calculated. 3 Scattering on a 1D periodic array of infinite slits 3.1 With only the TM 0 mode of the slit taken into account The problem is greatly simplified in the case of an array of infinite slits with a period p = L x and a width a perpendicular to the incidence plane ( x z plane, i.e. k∥ = k x x as seen in 2 ) of a p-polarized plane wave, if we consider only the TM 0 in the slit, we obtain: | α = 0 ⟩ = 1 a ( 1 0 ) t if | x | ≤ a / 2 0 if | x | > a / 2 The normalization factor ensures that 〈 0 | 0 〉 = ∫ x = − L x / 2 x = L x / 2 1 a dx = 1 . Furthermore, by considering that the metal is perfect along the slit, we can assume that k 0z = k ω . So, it is now possible to evaluate easily the overlap integral G 00 in the case of p-polarized incident wave because: 〈 0 | k ∥ σ 〉 = ( 1 0 ) ( k x 0 ) t 1 k x a p ∫ x = − p / 2 x = p / 2 exp ( i k x x ) dx = 1 a p exp ( i k x a / 2 ) − exp ( − i k x a / 2 ) i k x = a p sin k x a 2 k x a 2 And then G 00 = ∑ k ∥ σ Y k ∥ σ f k ∥ σ + | 〈 0 | k ∥ σ 〉 | 2 = ∑ k ∥ σ Y k ∥ σ f k ∥ σ + a p sin 2 k x a 2 k x a 2 2 Here the metallic sheet is assumed to be a perfect electric conductor allowing for an analytical expression of the overlap integration. Nevertheless it is possible to use a first order correction to improve the accuracy of the model [12] According the Bloch theorem, the sum runs over k ∥ = k x x where k x = k x 0 + n 2 π p , n being an integer. The system of equations to be solved becomes: (35) ( G 00 − Σ 0 ) E 0 − G 0 V E 0 ′ = I 0 (36) ( G 00 ′ − Σ 0 ) E 0 ′ − G 0 V E 0 = 0 where G 00 = ∑ k ∥ σ Y k ∥ σ f k ∥ σ + a p sin 2 k x a 2 ( k x a 2 ) 2 I 0 = 2 a p Y k ∥ 0 σ 0 f k ∥ 0 σ + sin k x 0 a 2 k x 0 a 2 Σ 0 = Y 0 f 0 + e i k 0 z h + f 0 − e − i k 0 z h f 0 + 2 e i k 0 z h − f 0 − 2 e − i k 0 z h G 0 V = 2 Y 0 f 0 + 2 e i k 0 z h − f 0 − 2 e − i k 0 z h The solution of this set of equation is: E 0 ′ = I 0 G 0 V / D and E 0 = ( G 00 ′ − Σ 0 ) / D , where D = ( G 00 − Σ 0 ) ( G 00 ′ − Σ 0 ) − ( G 0 V ) 2 . Once E 0 ′ and E 0 are obtained, we can calculate the transmission t k ∥ p and reflection coefficients ρ k ∥p f or each diffracted order and then the transmitted and reflected power are given by: T = ∑ k ∥ p propag Y k ∥ p ′ | t k ∥ p | 2 R = ∑ k ∥ p propag Y k ∥ p | ρ k ∥ p | 2 propag indicates that only the propagative plane waves solutions should be taken into account. 3.2 With the TM 0 and the TM 1 modes of the slit taken into account When the width of the slit becomes close to λ/2, the second TM 1 mode in the slit has to be also taken into account. This mode is noted here |α =1〉 and is defined as follows, if we consider perfect metal walls: | α = 1 ⟩ = 2 a sin ( π a x ) ( 1 0 ) t if | x | ≤ a / 2 0 if | x | > a / 2 The normalization factor ensures that 〈 1 | 1 〉 = ∫ x = − L x / 2 x = L x / 2 2 a sin 2 π a x dx = 1 . Furthermore, k 1 z = k ω 2 − ( π / a ) 2 . So, it is now possible to evaluate G 11 in the case of p-polarized incident wave because: 〈 1 | k ∥ σ 〉 = ( 1 0 ) ( k x 0 ) t 2 k x a p ∫ x = − p / 2 x = p / 2 sin π a x exp ( i k x x ) dx = i cos ak x 2 ( 2 a ) 3 / 2 ( π 2 − k x 2 a 2 ) p if | k x | ≠ π a i 2 π p | k x | 3 / 2 if | k x | = π a And then we can evaluate G 11, G 01, G 10, G 1 V , Σ1 and resolve the system of equations given below in order to obtain E 0, E 1, E 0 ′ and E 1 ′ and then T and R. ( G 00 − Σ 0 ) E 0 + G 01 E 1 − G 0 V E 0 ′ = I 0 ( G 11 − Σ 1 ) E 1 + G 10 E 0 − G 1 V E 1 ′ = I 1 ( G 00 ′ − Σ 0 ) E 0 ′ + G 01 E 1 ′ − G 0 V E 0 = 0 ( G 11 ′ − Σ 1 ) E 1 ′ + G 10 E 0 ′ − G 1 V E 1 = 0 4 Scattering on a 1D periodic array of slits forming the top mirror of a Fabry-Perot cavity photodetector Now, we are interesting in the reflection and absorption of the system shown in Fig. 3 , where the periodic array of slits is backed by a stack of dielectric layers finished by a semi-infinite metallic layer serving as back-mirror of the cavity. We have to consider the waves reflected by the stacked of the layers and then the expression of the field in the region III (here we insure that ϵ 3 defined in the case of a grid without cavity is equal to ϵ n defined here). The field in the region III becomes (see Eq. (3)) expressed in terms of transmission amplitudes t k ∥σ : (37) | E III ⟩ = ∑ k σ ( t k ∥ σ e i k z ' ( z - h ) + Π k ∥ σ e - i k z ' ( z - h ) ) | k ∥ σ ⟩ (38) | - u z × H III ⟩ = ∑ k ∥ σ Y k ∥ σ ' ( t k ∥ σ e i k z ' ( z - h ) - Π k ∥ σ e - i k z ' ( z - h ) ) | k ∥ σ ⟩ 4.1 Continuity of the electric field in z = h The continuity equation of the Electric Field in z = h (same method as in Eqs. (17) and (18)) gives once projected on the 〈 k ∥ σ|: In z = h −, u n =− u z and we have: (39) ∑ α ( C α e i k α z h + D α e - i k α z h ) | α ⟩ = - ∑ α z s Y α ( C α e i k α z h - D α e - i k α z h ) | α ⟩ In z = h +, (40) ∑ k ∥ σ ( t k ∥ σ + Π k ∥ σ ) | k ∥ σ ⟩ = ∑ k ∥ σ - z s Y k ∥ σ ' ( t k ∥ σ - Π k ∥ σ ) | k ∥ σ ⟩ Once projected on the 〈 k ∥ σ|, (40) and (39) gives: ( t k ∥ σ + Π k ∥ σ ) - ∑ α ( C α e i k α z h + D α e - i k α z h ) ⟨ k ∥ σ | α ⟩ = - z s Y k ∥ σ ' ( t k ∥ σ - Π k ∥ σ ) + ∑ α z s Y α ( C α e i k α z h - D α e - i k α z h ) ⟨ k ∥ σ | α ⟩ ⇔ (41) f k ∥ σ ′ + t k ∥ σ + f k ∥ σ ′ − Π k ∥ σ = − ∑ α 〈 k ∥ σ | α 〉 E α ′ The dielectrics layers below the scattering grid are assumed to be uniform and then the set of | k ∥ σ〉 is a subset of the orthogonal eigenmode basis (plane waves) which is independent of the layer. Therefore, as in a basic 1D uniform multilayer problem, no scattering occurs and we can calculate for each | k ∥ σ〉 the reflection coefficient R k ∥ σ brought by the cavity which is defined by: (42) R k ∥ σ = Π k ∥ σ t k ∥ σ The reflection coefficient of a stack of uniform dielectric layers ended by a semi infinite layer (the metallic mirror here) is easily obtained by a transfer matrix method or a scattering matrix method (which is more robust, in terms of numerical stability, see [11] for example). We define the total S matrix as just below: t k ∥ σ metal Π k ∥ σ = S 11 S 12 S 21 S 22 · Π k ∥ σ metal t k ∥ σ Once the total scattering matrix obtained (see Fig. 4 for the definition of forward and backward waves) which gives the linear dependency between the waves right after the metallic grid and at the beginning of the semi-infinite gold layer R k ∥ σ is easily calculated. Indeed, the backward wave in the metallic layer, Π k ∥ σ is null and then: (43) R k ∥ σ = S 11 Now if we come back to Eq. (41), we can obtain an equation similar to Eq. (20) found in the case of a grid without cavity but with a slight different factor. (44) − ∑ α 〈 k ∥ σ | α 〉 E α ′ = f k ∥ σ ′ + t k ∥ σ + f k ∥ σ ′ − t k ∥ σ R k ∥ σ = t k ∥ σ ( f k ∥ σ ′ + + f k ∥ σ ′ − R k ∥ σ ) which gives: (45) t k ∥ σ = − 1 F k ∥ σ ∑ α 〈 k ∥ σ | α 〉 E α ′ where F k ∥ σ = f k ∥ σ ′ + + f k ∥ σ ′ − R k ∥ σ 4.2 Continuity of the magnetic field in z = h Now, it remains to use the second continuity equation at the backside interface where the problem is different from the grid without cavity. The continuity of the magnetic field gives after projection on |α〉: (46) ∑ k ∥ σ Y k ∥ σ ′ ( t k ∥ σ − Π k ∥ σ ) 〈 α | k ∥ σ 〉 = Y α ( C α e i k α z h − D α e − i k α z h ) ⇔ (47) ∑ k ∥ σ Y k ∥ σ ′ t k ∥ σ ( 1 − R k ∥ σ ) 〈 α | k ∥ σ 〉 = Y α ( C α e i k α z h − D α e − i k α z h ) If we put the expressions of t k∥σ given in Eq. (45) in theses expressions, we obtain: ∑ k ∥ σ Y k ∥ σ ′ 1 F k ∥ σ ∑ β 〈 k ∥ σ | β 〉 E β ′ ( 1 − R k ∥ σ ) 〈 α | k ∥ σ 〉 = − Y α ( C α e i k α z h − D α e − i k α z h ) ⇔ ∑ β G α β ′ c E β ′ = − Y α ( C α e i k α z h − D α e − i k α z h ) where: (48) G α β ′ c = ∑ k ∥ σ Y k ∥ ′ ( 1 − R k ∥ σ ) F k ∥ σ 〈 α | k ∥ σ 〉 〈 k ∥ σ | β 〉 E β ′ Eventually, we have a similar set of equations to the one obtained in the case of the grid without cavity (Eqs. (33) and (34)). We have only to use G ′ c instead of G′. Once the E α and E α ′ are calculated by resolving the two-equation (if only one waveguide mode is taken into account) linear system, the electromagnetic fields can be derived in the structure and then for a given incident optical power, the power reflected by the whole structure and the amount of power absorbed in each layer can be easily calculated. 4.3 Comparison with results obtained by Rigorous Coupled Wave Analysis The SMEF has been implemented to study the electromagnetic response to a normally incident plane wave (wavelength λ = 800 nm) of a resonant photoconductor as shown in Fig. 5 . In Fig. 6 are compared the absorbance of the GaAs layer as calculated by the SMEF and by a rigorous coupled wave analysis (RCWA) [13] as a function of the layer thickness and the period (the width of the slit a = 0.5p). The 400 simulation points required to plot the figures have needed a 13 times longer duration by using the RCWA method (despite the use of a small number of harmonics n = 20), than by using the SMEF (number of waveguide mode n s = 1, number of diffracted mode n D = 1) implemented on the same platform (SCILAB). It is easily explained by the fact that each simulation point requires the inversion of a 2×2 matrix for the SMEF instead of a 20×20 matrix for the RCWA. It can be seen in Fig. 6 that the numerical results obtained by both analysis are similar, nevertheless it can be noticed that the absorbance is overestimated by the SMEF. This is consistent with the fact that in we have considered here that the metal was a perfect metallic conductor (PEC) inside the slit in order to keep the very simple analytic form of the waveguide mode. Then the losses induced by the metal and the effective width of the slit are underestimated. As already mentioned before [12], the accuracy of this method could be improved by taking into account of the effect of the non perfect metal on the waveguide modes in the slits. Acknowledgements We gratefully acknowledge Mathias Vanwolleghem for fruitful discussions. This work is supported by the French Defense Agency DGA (Direction générale de l’armement), RENATECH (French Network of Major Technology Centers), Lille University, and the Rgion Nord Pas de Calais Picardie. Appendix A Calcul of the admittance Y k∥σ Here, we demonstrate the relation between E t and H t in the s and p-polarization. In both case, it is based on the Maxwell-Faraday equation in CGS: rot → E = − 1 c ∂ B ∂ t where c is the speed of light in free space. Furthermore, if we assume that the materials have no magnetization,then H = B . A.1 s-Polarization For a s-polarized incident plane wave, (i.e. E z =0, ϕ( r , t)= k · r − ωt) of pulsation ω and of wave vector k =(k x , k y , k z ) t rot → E = − 1 c ∂ B ∂ t becomes: (49) jk x jk y jk z × E x E y 0 = 1 c · j ω H x j ω H y j ω H z ⇔ (50) − k z E y k z E x k x E y − jk y E x = k ω H x k ω H y k ω H z Now, if we are only interested by the transverse parts of E and H , we have indeed: (51) | - u z × H ⟩ = 0 0 - 1 × H x H y H z = H y - H x 0 = Y k ∥ s · E x E y 0 with Y k ∥ s = k z k ω . A.2 p-Polarization For a p-polarized incident plane wave, (i.e. H z =0, ϕ( r , t)= k · r − ωt) of pulsation ω and of wave vector k =(k x , k y , k z ) t rot → E = − 1 c ∂ B ∂ t becomes: (52) jk x jk y jk z × E x E y E z = 1 c · j ω H x j ω H y 0 ⇔ (53) k y E z − k z E y k z E x − k x E z k x E y − k y E x = k ω H x k ω H y 0 So, it gives that k x E y = k y E x and we know that without electric charge:k x E x + k y E y + k z E z =0. It gives for the x term: (54) k y E z − k z E y = − k y k x k z E x − k y 2 k z E y − k z E y = − k y 2 k z E y − k y 2 k z E y − k z E y = − 1 k z ( k ∥ 2 + k z 2 ) E y = − 1 k z ϵ 1 k ω 2 E y So for the x-term: k y E z − k z E y = k ω H x ⇔ 1 k z ϵ 1 k ω E y = − H x Now, if we are interested by the y term: (55) k z E x − k x E z = k x k y k z E y + k x 2 k z E x + k z E x = k y 2 k z E x + k x 2 k z E x + k z E x = 1 k z ( k ∥ 2 + k z 2 ) E x = − 1 k z ϵ 1 k ω 2 E x Eventually, for the y-term: k z E x − k x E z = k ω H y ⇔ ϵ 1 k ω k z E x = H y Now, if we are only interested by the transverse parts of E and H , we have indeed: (56) | - u z × H ⟩ = 0 0 - 1 × H x H y H z = H y - H x 0 = Y k ∥ p · E x E y 0 with Y k ∥ p = k ω ϵ 1 k z .

column2: Properties of boehmite (γ-AlOOH) and Eu3+-doped boehmite synthesized by hydrothermal method
column3: Abstract Boehmite nanoplates and Eu3+-doped boehmite nanoplates were synthesized by a facile hydrothermal reaction. And the boehmite nanoparticles behave as plate-like in morphology and have a small size about 59nm. Those nanoplates could be effectively excited by near-UV light in the range of 360nm to 420nm. Because of existing of anionic oxygen vacancies (F-center) in those nanoplates, it has a broad emission peak at 483nm excited at 393nm. The emission peak at 615nm split into two peaks because of the way of asymmetric occupation about Eu3+ ions in the boehmite crystal lattice. Based on the experimental results, boehmite and Eu3+-doped boehmite nanoplates have great potential to serve as an attractive candidate in the application of luminescent devices.
column5: Keywords Boehmite Nanoplates Hydrothermal method 1 Introduction Boehmite has been studied in many fields, such as catalyst, catalyst carrier, adsorbent and so on [1–7]. In addition, boehmite as the precursor of γ-alumina has also caused great attention because of special features [8]. What's more, it has been reported that γ-alumina could be obtained by calcining boehmite nanoplates without changing its original shape and size [9]. Hydrothermal method has been developed rapidly because of its advantages such as simple and size-controlled compared with the solid phase method [11] and microwave method [12] since it is adopted by Bugosh [10] to synthesized boehmite nanofibers firstly. To date, boehmite has been synthesized in different morphologies (boehmite whisker, single-crystal boehmite nanobelts, nanorods, nanoflakes, nanofibers, boehmite flowerlike, etc.) [11,14–17] and studied in structure [18], photocatalysis and other properties. However, optical properties about rare earth doped boehmite, which synthesized by hydrothermal, has been rarely reported. Therefore, in this paper, in order to studying the optical properties, we synthesized boehmite nanoplates and Eu3+-doped boehmite nanoplates by hydrothermal method. And the samples can produce blue emission or blue and red mixture emission when excited by near-UV light. 2 Experimental section 2.1 Sample preparation Boehmite nanoplates: The boehmite nanoplates were synthesized by hydrothermal reaction with aluminium isopropoxide (A.R. ≥98%) and deionized water. All processes were carried out in air, 1.6339g of aluminium isopropoxide was added into 80ml deionized water in a glass beaker and vigorous stirring for 1h. The stirred solution was transferred into a 100ml Teflon-lined stainless-steel autoclave and heated at 220°C for 24h, then natural cool down to room temperature. Eu3+-doped boehmite nanoplates: Eu3+-doped boehmite nanoplates were prepared with the raw materials Aluminium isopropoxide (1.6339g), Europium nitrate pentahydrate (A.R. 99.9%) (0.1712g) and deionized water (80ml). Similarly, all solvents were dissolved in deionized water and the next steps were as same as the process of synthesizing boehmite nanoplates. Boehmite powder: The products were obtained after the reaction solutions were centrifuged and washed with anhydrous ethanol and deionized water for several times and dried at 90°C overnight. 2.2 Characterization The phase identification of the samples were carried out by powder X-ray diffraction (XRD) (Bruker Axs D2 PHASER diffractometer, Cu kα=0.15406nm) with 2θ ranging from 10° to 80°, operating at 30kV and 10mA. The morphology of the nanoplates were observed through a field-emission scanning electron microscope equipped with an energy-dispersive spectrometer (EDS) (FE-SEM, S-4800, Hitachi, Japan) and examined by a HitachiH-9500 transmission electron microscope (TEM). The excitation and emission spectra of nanoplates were measured by a PL3-211-P spectrometer (HORIBA JOBIN YVON, America). The diffuse reflectance spectra were investigate by a UV-3600 UV–vis spectrometer (Shimadzu, Japan) contrasting to the white powder BaSO4. Fourier transformed infrared (FTIR) (Brook Tensor 27) was used to detect the chemical identity of nanoplates. 3 Result and discussion 3.1 Phase identification and crystal structure Fig. 1 (a) depicts the XRD patterns of boehmite, Eu3+-doped boehmite and the standard date card of boehmite (PDF#21-1307). It’s obviously that the diffraction peak positions and the intensities of the samples were well matched with the standard date card of boehmite, indicating that the crystal structure of the sample which doped Eu3+ ions is not changed. Fig. 1(b) shows the XRD pattern of doped sample and related Rietveld refinement which obtained by the Material Studio program, and the refinement of parameters Rwp 9.29% and Rp 6.75%. The size and the morphology of the samples were characterized by scanning electron microscope (SEM) and transmission electron microscopy (TEM). It's distinct that those nanoparticles both look like plates and only have a few nanometers in thickness (Fig. 2 ). By observing the SEM images, obvious phenomenon of agglomeration can be seen in the samples because of the effect of surface functional groups and quantum size effect. And the thickness of nanoplates vary from 10nm to 21nm (Fig. 2a.inset.1). The thickness of nanoplates (along [010] direction, compliance with the boehmite lamellar structure), which can be measured from [020] and [080] lines broadening using the Scherrer formula, is well matched with the observed value [20,21]. The plate-like morphology can also be demonstrated by TEM and its size about 59nm (Fig. 2a. inset.2). A schematic diagram of boehmite's morphology is showed in Fig. 2 (b). Throughout all nanoplates, it seems to be exhibiting predominant (101) lateral faces in every cases, which can also be proved in Fig. 3 a.inset.1 [20]. The HRTEM image of Fig. 2a.inset.4 (obtained from Fig. 2a.inset.2) shows the interplanar crystal spacing of 0.608nm, which agree with the value has been reported before [6]. It was considered as orthogonal octahedral structure of crystal system and the symmetry was described by space group Cmcm. Until now, this is the best model reported for boehmite's crystalline [1,6,15,18,20]. The elemental composition of Eu3+-doped boehmite is tested by energy dispersive spectrum (EDS) and shown in Fig. 3(c). It demonstrates that Al, O and Eu exist in the product and it was proven to be pure after centrifugal washing because of almost no carbon content. What's more, the stoichiometric weight ratio of each element in boehmite (AlOOH:Eu3+) is Al 38.72%, O 48.30%, H 1.52% and Eu 11.47%, which was well matched with the contents detected by EDS (Al 43.05%, O 47.53% and Eu 9.42%) within the margin of error. In a word, the Eu3+ ion has successfully enter into the boehmite crystal lattice. Fig. 4 shows the FTIR absorption spectra of boehmite. It's clear to see that the sample exists all basically characteristic peak. The peaks at 3086cm−1 and ∼3290cm−1 could be ascribed to the symmetric and asymmetric stretching of AlOH group, respectively. The peaks at ∼1069cm−1 and ∼1159cm−1 indicate that symmetric and asymmetric bending vibrations of AlOH in the boehmite lattice. In the meantime, there are another three peaks can also be observed in the spectra: ∼737cm−1, ∼617cm−1 and ∼482cm−1, which corresponding to the torsional mode, the stretching and the bending vibration of AlO. Besides the obvious peaks in the spectra, there are several relatively weak peaks in the range of 1400cm−1 to 2500cm−1. Those peaks are caused by residual organic species. However, there was no redundant defect luminescence phenomena caused by residual organic species, which can be verified by excitation spectra and emission spectra. The peaks at ∼1968cm−1 and ∼2086cm−1 appear in the samples are associated with the CO stretching modes. The peak at ∼1635cm−1 belongs to the hydroxyl bands on the surface [17–22]. The absorption center at ∼1449cm−1 belongs to the CH stretching mode [19]. 3.2 Diffuse reflection spectra The diffuse reflection spectra of pure and Eu3+-doped boehmite are shown in Fig. 5 . The reflection intensity of pure boehmite is almost above 80% in the wavelength range of 200–800nm and shows a distinct drop in the range of full spectrum because of the transition between valence band and conduction band in the boehmite host lattice. There are several relatively weak absorption peak in around 320nm, 363nm, 399nm and 466nm, which can be ascribed to the characteristic transitions of Eu3+ from the ground state to the higher energy levels: 7F0 → 5H5 (322nm), 7F0 → 5D4 (362nm), 5D0 → 5L7 (385nm), 7F0 → 5L6 (393nm), 7F0 → 5D3 (404nm), and 7F0 → 5D2 (466nm). And it was well matched with the excitation spectra, which monitored at 615nm [23]. What's more, the other absorption peak appeares in 260nm, however, the emission intensity was not enhanced correspondingly, so it was speculated that the absorption band was ascribed to the transition toward the charge transfer state from the 2p orbital of O2− ions to the 4f orbital of Eu3+ ions [13]. Due to the absorption around 450nm, the intensity of blue emission decreased, which phenomenon has been mentioned above. 3.3 Photoluminescence properties Fig. 6 (a) illustrates the emission spectra of the boehmite (black solid line) and Eu3+-doped boehmite (red solid line). The emission spectra of boehmite and Eu3+-doped boehmite show a broad emission band in the wavelength range of 450–550nm, which is attributed to lattice anionic oxygen vacancies (F-center). And the lattice anionic oxygen vacancies (F-center) were introduced by capturing an electron during the hydrothermal reaction [11–15]. The emission intensity of boehmite is about three times the intensity of Eu3+ −doped boehmite at the peak position, and the phenomenon will be explained in the given below. In addition to the difference of the strength between the samples, there is a small blue shift from 483nm to 475nm may be caused by the lattice distortion. By studying the emission spectra of Eu3+-doped boehmite, there are five main peaks appear at 579nm (5D0 → 7F0), 588nm (5D0 → 7F1), 615nm (5D0 → 7F2), 654nm (5D0 → 7F3) and 698nm (5D0 → 7F4), which created by Eu3+ ions. Due to the Eu3+ ions’ asymmetric occupation in the crystal lattice, the emission peak at 615nm split into two peaks at 611nm and 618nm. In order to obtain as much as possible of red light, excitation spectra monitored at 615nm was tested for Eu3+-doped boehmite (Fig. 6(b)). A narrow sharp peak at 393nm (7F0 → 5L6) was noticed in the excitation spectra, thus, it’s the most suitable excitation wavelength. What's more, the peak positions at 360nm and 467nm are ascribe to 7F0 → 5G2 and 7F0 → 5D2, respectively. And the excitation spectra of boehmite and Eu3+-doped boehmite monitor at 483nm and 475nm, respectively, were also researched. It's obvious to found that they have the similar peak position and have an overlap. Thus, it was speculated that energy transfer exists between boehmite and Eu3+ ions and the residual organic species has limited effect in luminescence. Combined with Figs. 5 and 6, it was suspected that the intensity of main emission peak located at 475nm appears the phenomenon of sharp attenuation, which could be contributed to the absorption at 467nm and the diffuse reflection spectra entire lowing after doping Eu3+, for the above reasons, the fluorescence spectrum intensity weakened as a whole. In other words, the decrease of fluorescence intensity at ∼475nm was caused by the re-absorption between substrate and Eu3+. 4 Conclusions In short, boehmite and Eu3+-doped boehmite nanoplates were successfully synthesized by hydrothermal reaction method and their morphology and luminescence properties were also studied. The boehmite nanoplates present a blue emission band with a peak at 483nm under the excitation wavelength of 393nm. While the Eu3+-doped boehmite nanoplates present a blue emission band at 475nm under the excitation wavelength of 393nm and the red emission peak at 615nm occurs the phenomenon of splitting because of the asymmetric occupay in the crystal lattice by Eu3+ ions. All the spectrum features suggest that boehmite naoplates have great potential in white light emitting diode. column2: Simulation of LSPR based fiber optic sensor utilizing layer of platinum nanoparticles
column3: Abstract Analysis of localized surface plasmon resonance (LSPR) based fiber optic sensor using platinum (Pt) nanoparticles is carried out. For a fixed particle size of Pt nanoparticles, the sensitivity and figure of merit (FOM) increase with increase in thickness of Pt nanoparticles layer. Besides, sensitivity enlarges as the particle size increases from 5nm to 10nm and afterwards, it starts sinking with further increase in the particle size of Pt nanoparticles for all thicknesses of Pt nanoparticles layers. Optimized thickness and particle size of Pt nanoparticles layer are 50nm and 10nm respectively. 50nm thick Pt nanoparticles layer, particle size 10nm based sensor possesses sensitivity of 7450nm/RIU.
column5: Keywords LSPR Optical fiber Sensor Platinum nanoparticles 1 Introduction Surface plasmon resonance (SPR) is the main principle behind working of various biosensors and chemical sensors. SPR sensors are most commonly used for the investigations of surface interactions and sensing of liquids as well as gases. Physical, biological and chemical properties of materials can be sensed by using SPR. SPR based optical sensing is the most promising technique [1–3]. Surface plasmons are the charge density oscillations of free electrons in a metal leading in generation of surface plasmon waves. Surface plasmon waves propagate along the interface between a metal and a dielectric media under certain conditions. These waves are transverse in nature with their electric field decaying exponentially in both media. Surface plasmon waves can be excited by using prism coupling, grating coupling and optical fiber coupling. In prism coupling, Kretschmann configuration is generally utilized [4,5]. A high refractive index prism, coated with a thin metal layer is utilized in Kretschmann configuration. The metal layer touches the sample. Evanescent waves from prism at the total reflection condition excite the surface plasmon waves. However, there are some shortcomings in the prism coupler such as bulky size of sensor and incompatibility for remote sensing. In optical fiber coupling, the core of the optical fiber replaces the prism. Optical fiber based SPR devices offer numerous advantages over the prism and grating based SPR devices like simplified and flexible optical design, option of remote sensing, continuous analysis and in situ monitoring [6–8]. To exploit these advantages, a large number of experimental and theoretical research studies on optical fiber based SPR sensing have been reported [9–13]. The extraordinary nano-scale size dependent properties of metal nanoparticles make them unique in several research areas. The metal nanoparticles (having size much smaller than the wavelength of light) disclose outstanding optical properties and better sensing behavior than materials in the micro or larger scales [14]. The interface between metal nanoparticles and dielectric medium generates considerable changes in the optical properties, which make them size and shape dependent. Generally, localized surface plasmon resonance (LSPR) pertains to metallic nanoparticles and occurs when the wave vector and frequency of incident p-polarized light match with that of the collective oscillations of conduction electrons in metallic nanoparticles [15]. LSPR wavelength is dependent on nanoparticle’s size, shape, material and refractive index of surrounding medium [16,17]. Also, one of the most important features of LSPR is its sensing applications because the sensitivity of LSPR based sensor is controlled and optimized by changing the shape and size of nanoparticles [18–20]. Recently, platinum (Pt) has grabbed much attention of researchers because of its great performance and long lasting stability. Pt is an inert and chemically stable metal. It is highly reflecting and has high melting point. Pt has shown remarkable applications in optoelectronic devices, solar absorbers and jewellery industry [21]. Pt nanomaterials have been applied in various research fields including sensors, fuel cells, automotive industry, petroleum refining, hydrogen production and anticancer drugs [22–24]. In this paper, we theoretically report LSPR based fiber optic sensor utilizing Pt nanoparticles. It is to be mentioned here that the present research is quite novel as several research investigations using Pt nanoparticles have been carried out. However, the utilization of Pt nanoparticles in LSPR based fiber optic refractive index sensor has not been studied. The outcomes of thickness and particle size of Pt nanoparticles layer on the sensitivity and figure of merit (FOM) of sensor have been thoroughly studied. For a fixed particle size of Pt nanoparticles, the sensitivity and FOM increase with increase in thickness of Pt nanoparticles layer. In addition, the sensitivity is increased as the particle size increases from 5nm to 10nm and then, it starts decreasing with further increase in the particle size of Pt nanoparticles for all thicknesses of Pt nanoparticles layers. Optimized values of thickness and particle size of Pt nanoparticles layer are obtained to be 50nm and 10nm respectively. Sensor with 50nm thick Pt nanoparticles layer, particle size 10nm demonstrates largest sensitivity of 7450nm/RIU. 2 Theory LSPR sensing is based on the principle of ATR with Kretschmann configuration. In proposed LSPR based fiber optic sensor, the sensing probe is a three layer system consisting of fiber core-Pt nanoparticles layer-sensing medium as shown in Fig. 1 . The plastic cladding around the core from the middle portion of a step index multimode plastic clad silica (PCS) fiber (Numerical aperture=0.24 and fiber core diameter=600μm) is removed and the bare core is then coated with a thin layer of Pt nanoparticles, which is then finally enclosed by the sensing medium. Wavelength interrogation technique is utilized to analyze the LSPR sensor. In this technique, the light from a broadband source is launched into one of the ends of the optical fiber with suitable optics and the transmitted light is detected at the other end of the optical fiber. At resonance wavelength, a sharp dip in the transmitted power appears. The resonance wavelength is dependent on the refractive index of sensing medium. The core of optical fiber is presumed to be made of fused silica. The refractive index of fused silica depends on wavelength according to Sellmeier dispersion relation as, (1) n 1 ( λ ) = 1 + a 1 λ 2 λ 2 − b 1 2 + a 2 λ 2 λ 2 − b 2 2 + a 3 λ 2 λ 2 − b 3 2 Where, λ is the wavelength in μm and a1 , a2 , a3 , b1 , b2 and b3 are Sellmeier coefficients. The values of these coefficients are written as, a1 =0.6961663, a2 =0.4079426, a3 =0.8974794, b1 =0.0684043μm, b2 =0.1162414μm and b3 =9.896161μm [25]. Pt nanoparticles are considered to be spherical in shape with radius (R) 5nm, 10nm, 15nm, 20nm and 25nm. The mean free path of Drude electrons is reduced by the finite size of spherical nanoparticles and the size-dependent damping constant of Drude electrons of a metal is written as [26], (2) Γ = Γ B u l k + A v f R Where, Γ Bulk is the damping constant of the bulk material, A is constant equal to a value near unity, v f is the fermi velocity and R is the radius of the spherical nanoparticle. In addition, bulk collision wavelength (λ cBulk ) corresponds to the damping of electron density oscillations due to collisions among the electrons in the bulk metal. In terms of bulk collision wavelength, the above Eq. (2) takes the final form as follows to provide the size-dependence of the collision wavelength (λ c ), (3) c λ c = c λ c B u l k + A v f R Here, c is the speed of light in vacuum. The complex dielectric constant of a metal is written according to Drude model as, (4) ε m ( λ ) = ε m r + i ε m i = 1 − λ 2 λ c λ p 2 ( λ c + i λ ) Here, ε mr and ε mi are the real and imaginary parts of complex dielectric constant of metal respectively. In addition, λp and λc are plasma wavelength and collision wavelength of metal respectively. Values of λ p , λ cBulk and v f for Pt are mentioned in Table 1 [27,28]. The dielectric constant of sensing medium can be written as, ε s = n s 2 , where n s is the refractive index of the sensing medium. Resonance condition for the excitation of surface plasmon wave is written as, (5) 2 π λ n 1 sin θ = Re { K s p } Where, K s p = ω c ε m ε s ε m + ε s = 2 π λ ε m n s 2 ε m + n s 2 is the propagation constant of surface plasmon wave and c is the speed of light in vacuum. 2.1 Transmitted power The expression of reflection coefficient (reflectance) for p-polarized incident light is obtained by using matrix method of N-layer structure [29]. Considering that all the guided rays are launched in the fiber using a collimated source and a microscope objective, the angular power distribution of rays guided in the fiber is written as [30], (6) d P ∝ n 1 2 sin θ cos θ ( 1 − n 1 2 cos 2 θ ) 2 d θ Where, θ is the angle of the ray with the normal to the core-cladding interface. Also, n1 is the refractive index of the core of the fiber. To determine the effective transmitted power, the reflectance (Rp ) for a single reflection is raised to the power of the number of reflections the specific propagating angle undergoes with the sensor interface. Hence, for p-polarized light, the generalized expression for normalized transmitted power in an optical fiber based SPR sensor will be given as, (7) P t r a n s = ∫ θ c r π / 2 R p N r e f ( θ ) n 1 2 sin θ cos θ ( 1 − n 1 2 cos 2 θ ) 2 d θ ∫ θ c r π / 2 n 1 2 sin θ cos θ ( 1 − n 1 2 cos 2 θ ) 2 d θ Where, (8) N r e f ( θ ) = L D tan θ And, (9) θ c r = sin − 1 ( n c l n 1 ) Where, N ref (θ) is the total number of reflections performed by a ray making an angle θ with the normal to the core-metal layer interface in the sensing region. L and D represent the length of the exposed sensing region and the fiber core diameter respectively. In addition, θ cr is the critical angle of the fiber and ncl is the refractive index of the cladding of the fiber. 2.2 Sensitivity and figure of merit Sensitivity of SPR sensor utilizing wavelength interrogation method is expressed as the change in resonance wavelength per unit change in refractive index of the sensing medium [31]. Also, figure of merit of SPR sensor is defined as the ratio of sensitivity of sensor to FWHM of SPR spectrum [32]. 3 Results and discussion In the present research study, several solutions of glycerine in water with different concentrations, having refractive indices in the range from 1.33 to 1.37 are considered as the sensing mediums. For theoretical calculations, following values of parameters have been assumed: Numerical aperture of the fiber=0.24, fiber core diameter D=600μm, length of the exposed sensing region L=15mm. For optimizing the thickness of Pt nanoparticles layer, the transmitted output power of LSPR sensor is measured for various thicknesses i.e. 10nm, 20nm, 30nm, 40nm and 50nm of Pt nanoparticles layer. Fig. 2 depicts the variations of resonance wavelength of LSPR sensor with refractive index of sensing medium for 10nm, 20nm, 30nm and 40nm thick Pt nanoparticles layers with nanoparticle size of 5nm. It is obvious from this figure that resonance wavelengths for all thicknesses of Pt nanoparticles layers get raised linearly with increase in refractive index of sensing medium. Here, it becomes essential to mention that the calculations of transmitted power of LSPR based fiber optic sensor have also been done for 50nm thick Pt nanoparticles layer with nanoparticle size of 5nm. However, 50nm thick Pt nanoparticles layer with nanoparticle size of 5nm has not been discussed in the present study because the clear resonance minima has not been observed for 50nm thick Pt nanoparticles layer with nanoparticle size of 5nm. Similarly, Fig. 3 a describes the plots of resonance wavelength of LSPR sensor with refractive index of sensing medium for 10nm, 20nm, 30nm, 40nm and 50nm thick Pt nanoparticles layers with nanoparticle size of 10nm. It can be viewed that resonance wavelengths for all thicknesses of Pt nanoparticles layers increase linearly with increase in refractive index of sensing medium and follow the same pattern of Fig. 2. In the same way, Fig. 3b–d shows the variations of resonance wavelength with refractive index of sensing medium for 10nm, 20nm, 30nm, 40nm and 50nm thick Pt nanoparticles layers with nanoparticle sizes of 15nm, 20nm and 25nm respectively. It is again observed that the resonance wavelengths enlarge with increase in refractive index of sensing medium for all thicknesses of Pt nanoparticles layers. The rationale behind these expansions of resonance wavelengths with increase in refractive index of sensing medium for various thicknesses of Pt nanoparticles layers can be explained by Eq. (5). The real part of propagation constant (K sp ) of surface plasmon wave will be larger for large value of refractive index of sensing medium and so, its resonance condition is satisfied at higher wavelength [29]. In the same way, for small value of refractive index of sensing medium, the real part of K sp will be smaller and thus, the resonance condition is satisfied at shorter wavelength. However, for nanoparticles with particle size of 10nm, the variations in resonance wavelengths with refractive index of sensing medium are larger than that of nanoparticles with particle sizes of 5nm, 15nm, 20nm and 25nm. Fig. 4 a illustrates the plot of sensitivity of LSPR sensor with thickness of Pt nanoparticles layer for 5nm particle size of Pt nanoparticles. It can be seen from this figure that the sensitivity increases with increase in thickness of Pt nanoparticles layer. Likewise, Fig. 4b represents the plots of sensitivity with thickness of Pt nanoparticles layer for fixed 10nm, 15nm, 20nm and 25nm particle sizes of Pt nanoparticles. It is obvious that the sensitivity is enhanced as the thickness of Pt nanoparticles layer is raised from 10nm to 50nm for each particle size of Pt nanoparticles. It occurs because Pt possesses large value of real part of its dielectric function at all wavelengths. Thus, Pt enhances the shift between resonance wavelengths for a given change of refractive index of the sensing medium for each thickness of Pt nanoparticles layer and hence, the sensitivity of SPR sensor enlarges with the increase in the thickness of Pt nanoparticles layer. Also, Fig. 4c indicates the variations of sensitivity of LSPR sensor with particle size of Pt nanoparticles for fixed 10nm, 20nm, 30nm, 40nm and 50nm thick Pt nanoparticles layers. For a fixed particle size of Pt nanoparticles, the sensitivity is enhanced as the thickness of Pt nanoparticles layer is raised from 10nm to 50nm. Besides it, the sensitivity is found to be the highest for 10nm particle size for all thicknesses of Pt nanoparticles layers. Therefore, from Fig. 4a and c, it can be understood that the sensitivity increases as the particle size increases from 5nm to 10nm and then, it starts reducing with further increase in the particle size of Pt nanoparticles for all thicknesses of Pt nanoparticles layers. This fact can be understood in terms of the variation in absorption of light due to the change in particle size of the nanoparticles [33]. It is apparent from Eq. (3) that decrease in particle size causes decrease in collision wavelength (λc ). This increases the imaginary part of the dielectric function of Pt nanoparticles (according to Eq. (4)) and as a result, the imaginary part of Ksp . Since, the imaginary part of Ksp represents the optical absorption of incident light, it is palpable that more absorption of light intensity occurs for Pt nanoparticles of smaller particle size. It results in reduction of transmitted light intensity through the optical fiber and hence, sensitivity gets heightened. Therefore, the sensitivity is more for small particle sizes of Pt nanoparticles. Because of this reason, the sensitivity rises up to the particle size of 10nm and then, it starts falling with further enlargement in the particle sizes of Pt nanoparticles for all thicknesses of Pt nanoparticles layers. Moreover, for the estimation of maximum sensitivity of LSPR sensor, the particle size and thickness of Pt nanoparticles layer are optimized. The sensitivities of LSPR sensor for several particle sizes and thicknesses of Pt nanoparticles layers are matched in Table 2 . It is clarified form Table 2 that 10nm thick Pt nanoparticles layer based LSPR sensor with particle size 10nm displays sensitivity of 1000nm/RIU, while 50nm thick Pt nanoparticles layer based LSPR sensor with same particle size 10nm presents sensitivity of 7450nm/RIU. Hence, the optimized thickness of Pt nanoparticles layer and optimized particle size of Pt nanoparticles are concluded to be 50nm and 10nm respectively. Fig. 5 a displays the variation of figure of merit (FOM) of LSPR sensor with thickness of Pt nanoparticles layer for 5nm particle size of Pt nanoparticles. It is understandable from this figure that FOM increases with increase in thickness of Pt nanoparticles layer. In the same way, Fig. 5b exposes the variations of FOM with thickness of Pt nanoparticles layer for fixed 10nm, 15nm, 20nm and 25nm particle sizes of Pt nanoparticles. Once again, FOM is found to be enhanced with increase in thickness of Pt nanoparticles layer for all particle sizes of Pt nanoparticles. In addition, Fig. 5c interprets the variations of FOM with particle size of Pt nanoparticles for fixed 10nm, 20nm, 30nm, 40nm and 50nm thick Pt nanoparticles layers. For a fixed particle size of Pt nanoparticles, FOM is enlarged as the thickness of Pt nanoparticles layer is increased from 10nm to 50nm. However, FOM attains the maximum value for 50nm thick Pt nanoparticles layer with particle size of 10nm. Consequently, from above discussion, it is concluded that LSPR based fiber optic sensor with 50nm thick Pt nanoparticles layer of particle size 10nm reveals maximum sensitivity of 7450nm/RIU. Similar to the phenomenon of fiber optic sensing, some research studies on laser-plasma interaction have been reported in the past [34–37]. 4 Conclusions LSPR based fiber optic sensor with Pt nanoparticles layer is theoretically studied. For a fixed particle size of Pt nanoparticles, the sensitivity and FOM increase with increase in thickness of Pt nanoparticles layer. Also, the sensitivity is enhanced as the particle size increases from 5nm to 10nm and then, it starts falling with further increase in the particle size of Pt nanoparticles for all thicknesses of Pt nanoparticles layers. Optimized values of thickness and particle size of Pt nanoparticles layer are found to be 50nm and 10nm respectively. LSPR sensor with 50nm thick Pt nanoparticles layer, particle size 10nm exhibits highest sensitivity of 7450nm/RIU. Acknowledgement Authors are thankful to Jaypee Institute of Information Technology, Noida for providing facilities and support to carry out this work.

column2: Gray and black optical solitons with quintic nonlinearity
column3: Abstract A higher-order nonlinear Schrödinger equation with the third-order dispersion, the cubic–quintic nonlinearities, derivative non-Kerr nonlinear terms, Kerr dispersion, and stimulated inelastic scattering is considered. The model can be used to describe the subpicosecond or femtosecond optical pulse propagation in highly nonlinear optical fibers. We find the exact gray solitary wave solution (i.e., a dark localized structure with nonzero minimum in intensity) on a continuous-wave background for the equation by adopting an appropriate ansatz solution. The propagation characteristics of such solitary pulses are determined in the presence of all higher-order effects. We also find black solitary wave solutions for the higher-order evolution equation under specific conditions for its coefficients. The parametric conditions on fiber parameters for the existence of both types are given.
column5: Keywords Solitons Third-order dispersion Stimulated inelastic scattering 1 Introduction As it is well known, the cubic nonlinear Schrödinger (NLS) equation describes the dynamics of picoseconds optical soliton propagation in nonlinear optical fibers [1]. In the picosecond regime, this equation includes only the group velocity dispersion (GVD) and its counterpart self-phase modulation (SPM). It admits bright or dark soliton type pulse propagation in the anomalous or normal dispersion regimes, respectively [2]. Such solitons can propagate over a long distance without the amplitude attenuation and shape change in the uniform nonlinear fiber under the condition that the GVD balances the SPM [3]. However, several higher-order nonlinear effects like the Kerr dispersion (otherwise called the self-steepening) and the stimulated Raman scattering become important for femtosecond optical pulses [4,5]. Moreover, if short pulses whose duration are nearly 50fs have to be injected, the third-order dispersion (TOD) becomes important and must be included in the equation [6]. Furthermore, in many optical materials, such as semiconductors, semiconductor doped glasses, polydiacetylene toluene sulfonate (PTS), calcogenide glasses, and some transparent organic materials, the quintic non-Kerr nonlinearity arising due to fifth-order susceptibility can be obtained in addition to the SPM [7]. With all these important effects, wave propagation in optical fibers is governed by the higher-order nonlinear Schrödinger (HNLS) equation. In general, unlike the cubic NLS equation, HNLS models governing most practical cases are not completely integrable. In recent years, the femtosecond dark solitary waves or solitons became of increasing interest [8–14]. Physically, dark solitons are intensity dips on top of a continuous wave (cw) background with a phase jump across their intensity minimum [15]. Such objects possess many interesting characteristics and important among them are (i) these pulses are more resistant than bright solitons to perturbations during propagation, and (ii) they are less sensitive to background noise [14]. It is relevant to mention that these solitons are more suitable than bright solitons when used in optical communications [14]. In this paper, a class of dark (gray) solitary wave solutions of HNLS equation with derivative non-Kerr nonlinear terms is derived for the first time under some constraints on system parameters. We have used the ansatz method to solve the model and successfully obtained an exact gray solitary wave solution on a continuous-wave background. Black solitary wave solutions are also presented for some given specific parametric conditions. 2 Governing model We consider the HNLS equation with non-Kerr nonlinear terms describing the propagation of femtosecond pulses through a non-Kerr medium of the form [16,17]: (1) E z = i ( α 1 E tt + α 2 | E | 2 E ) + α 3 E ttt + α 4 ( | E | 2 E ) t + α 5 E ( | E | 2 ) t + i α 6 | E | 4 E + α 7 ( | E | 4 E ) t + α 8 E ( | E | 4 ) t , where E(z, t) is the slowly varying envelope of the electric field, z is the normalized distance along the fiber, and t is the normalized time with the frame of the reference moving along the fiber at the group velocity. The subscripts z and t denote the spatial and temporal partial derivatives, respectively. The coefficients α i (i =1, 2, …, 5) are the real parameters related to GVD, SPM, TOD, self-steepening and self-frequency shift due to stimulated Raman scattering (SRS), while α 6, α 7, and α 8 are the quintic non-Kerr terms. Eq. (1) has attracted a great deal of attention due to its applications in the study of pulse propagation in highly nonlinear optical fibers. For instance, Choudhuri and Porsezian [16] presented Dark-in-the-Bright solution also called dipole soliton of (1) under some parametric conditions. In Ref. [7], the impact of dispersion and non-Kerr nonlinearity on the modulational instability within the framework of Eq. (1) have been studied in the presence of an additional fourth-order dispersion term. Moreover, the existence of ultrashort double-kink and algebraic solitons of Eq. (1) with α i =1 (with i =1, 2, 3) has been demonstrated in [18]. Furthermore, bright and dark solitary wave solutions of (1) under the vanishing boundary conditions have been presented in [17]. We note that, for picosecond light pulses, the last six terms on the right-hand side of Eq. (1) can be omitted, and Eq. (1) reduces to the cubic NLS equation. Also note that by using the inverse scattering transform for the HNLS equation (1) with α 6 = α 7 = α 8 =0, the dark N-soliton solution has been constructed under Hirota parameter conditions in [19]. To our knowledge, studies of dark solitary waves of Eq. (1) under the nonvanishing boundary conditions have not been reported so far. In what follows, we investigate, for the first time, the propagation characteristics of gray optical solitary pulses on a continuous-wave background in a non-Kerr nonlinear medium that is describable in terms of the HNLS equation (1). It is worth mentioning that by appropriately scaling variables E, z and t, the governing Eq. (1) can be written in a dimensionless form with only five free parameters. In the following, however, we shall keep the original formulation with eight parameters in order to examine the individual role of each physical effect on the properties of femtosecond dark solitary waves. To obtain the exact solitary wave solutions of Eq. (1) we consider a solution of the form [20]: (2) E ( z , t ) = A ( z , t ) e i ϕ L ( z , t ) , where A(z, t) is the complex envelope function and ϕ L (z, t)= κz −Ωt is the linear phase shift function. The parameters κ and Ω represent the wave number and the frequency shift of the light pulse, respectively. Substituting (2) into (1) and removing the exponential term, one obtains: (3) iA z + ia 1 A t + a 2 A tt + a 3 | A | 2 A − ia 4 | A | 2 A t − ia 5 A 2 A t * − a 6 A + a 7 | A | 4 A − ia 8 | A | 4 A t − ia 9 A 2 | A | 2 A t * − i α 3 A ttt = 0 , where (4) a 1 = − 2 α 1 Ω + 3 α 3 Ω 2 , a 2 = α 1 − 3 α 3 Ω , a 3 = α 2 − α 4 Ω , a 4 = 2 α 4 + α 5 , a 5 = α 4 + α 5 , a 6 = κ + α 1 Ω 2 − α 3 Ω 3 , a 7 = α 6 − α 7 Ω , a 8 = 3 α 7 + 2 α 8 , a 9 = 2 α 7 + α 8 . In order to investigate localized dark solutions of Eq. (1), we adopt an ansatz soliton solution of the form [20]: (5) A ( z , t ) = i β + λ tanh η t − χ z , where η and χ are the pulse width and the inverse group velocity shift, respectively. It may be worth observing that we are seeking solitary wave solution with non-zero amplitude as t approaches infinity (i.e., |t|→∞). Since the envelope function A(z, t) is complex, the amplitude of A(z, t) is (6) | A ( z , t ) | = λ 2 + β 2 − λ 2 sech 2 η t − χ z 1 / 2 , and its corresponding nonlinear phase shift ϕ NL is (7) ϕ NL ( z , t ) = tan − 1 β λ tanh η t − χ z . For the special case of β =0, dark solitons have been called black; other dark solitons are called gray [21]. Both of these types of solitons play a vital role in understanding various physical phenomena in nonlinear systems. By substituting Eq. (5) into Eq. (3), expanding tanh terms to sech terms, and equating the coefficient terms that contain independent combinations of tanh and sech functions to zero, we obtain the following overdetermined system of equations: (8a) λ η 6 α 3 η 2 + a 4 + a 5 λ 2 + 2 a 8 + a 9 λ 4 + 2 a 8 β 2 λ 2 + a 7 β λ 4 = 0 , (8b) − λ 2 a 2 η 2 + a 3 λ 2 + 2 β η λ 2 a 5 + a 9 λ 2 + β 2 − 2 a 7 λ 3 λ 2 + β 2 = 0 , (8c) λ − χ η + a 1 η − 4 α 3 η 3 − a 4 η λ 2 + β 2 − a 5 η λ 2 − β 2 − 2 a 7 β λ λ 2 + β 2 − a 8 η λ 2 + β 2 2 − a 9 η λ 4 − β 4 − a 3 β λ 2 = 0 , (8d) λ a 3 λ 2 + β 2 − a 6 + a 7 λ 2 + β 2 2 = 0 , (8e) β a 3 λ 2 + β 2 − a 6 + a 7 λ 2 + β 2 2 = 0 , (8f) λ 4 a 7 λ − 2 a 9 β η = 0 , (8g) η λ 5 a 8 + a 9 = 0 . To reach the goal of finding the solitary wave parameters, we need to impose some restrictions on the model coefficients so that Eq. (8) become compatible. 3 Gray solitons In what follows below, we present the parametric conditions for which the dark solitary wave solution (5) exists for the HNLS equation given in Eq. (1). We will substitute for the parameters a i the expressions in terms of the physical coefficient α j given in (4). Firstly, from Eqs. (4) and (8g), we can get the parametric condition: (9) 5 α 7 + 4 α 8 = 0 , which implies that the derivative quintic non-Kerr terms in Eq. (1) are not independent and the corresponding solitary wave solution is obtained in the framework of this relationship. Now, using Eq. (8a) with Eqs. (8f) and (8g), we obtain (10) λ = η − 6 α 3 3 α 4 + 2 α 5 , which shows that it is necessary to have (11) α 3 3 α 4 + 2 α 5 < 0 . for solitary waves to exist. Then, we get β from Eq. (8b) using the relation: (12) β 1 − 2 α 7 + α 8 α 4 + α 5 β 2 + λ 2 = − 6 α 3 3 α 4 + 2 α 5 Ω − α 1 3 α 4 + 2 α 5 − 3 α 2 α 3 6 α 3 α 4 + α 5 , under the conditions α 3 3 α 4 + 2 α 5 < 0 and α 4 + α 5 ≠ 0 . Further, we find χ from Eq. (8c) as (13) χ = − 2 α 1 Ω + 3 α 3 Ω 2 + 2 α 3 η 2 + α 2 − α 4 Ω β λ / η − α 4 β 2 − 4 α 7 + α 8 β 2 λ 2 + β 2 , Finally, κ is obtained from Eqs. (8d) or (8e) as (14) κ = − α 1 Ω 2 + α 3 Ω 3 + α 2 − α 4 Ω λ 2 + β 2 + α 6 − α 7 Ω λ 2 + β 2 2 , Thus we can write the solitary wave solution of Eq. (1) in the form (15) E ( z , t ) = i β + λ tanh η t − χ z e i κ z − Ω t , where the parameters λ, β, χ and κ are given by the relations (10), and (12)–(14), while η and Ω are free parameters. The corresponding pulse intensity is given by (16) | E ( z , t ) | 2 = λ 2 + β 2 − λ 2 sech 2 η t − χ z . Eq. (15) determines a gray solitary pulse solution for the HNLS Eq. (1) with the minimum and maximum amplitudes equal to β and λ 2 + β 2 , respectively. This propagating envelope exist under the constraints (9) and (11) on the physical parameters. From the above results, we can notice that the optical solitary pulse parameters are uniquely determined from the characteristics of the nonlinear medium, i.e. the GVD, TOD, self-steepening, self-frequency shift, and the quintic non-Kerr terms. Compared with the corresponding solitary wave parameters in [19], quintic non-Kerr coefficients α 6, α 7 and α 8 are added in our parameters (12)–(14), which make our results more coincident with the real situation. The intensity profile of the solitary wave solution (Eq. (15)) is shown in Fig. 1 (a), using the following values for the model parameters [16]: α 2 =1, α 4 =−0.0247, α 6 =1, α 7 =−0.0247 and α 8 =0.030875. To satisfy the condition (11), we choose α 1 =1, α 3 =0, 2744, and α 5 =−0.03705. It is interesting to note that the wave profile remains unchanged during evolution, which we have shown in Fig. 1(b). 4 Black solitons Let us now identify the conditions on fiber parameters for the existence of black type solitary wave solutions of the HNLS equation (1). We notice that when the derivative non-Kerr nonlinear coefficients α 7 and α 8 in Eq. (12) satisfy the condition: (17) α 7 + α 8 = 0 , and if one forces the parameter of frequency shift Ω to take the value: (18) Ω = α 1 3 α 4 + 2 α 5 − 3 α 2 α 3 6 α 3 α 4 + α 5 , we obtain β =0 from Eq. (12), and then we can get the following solitary wave solution for Eq. (1): (19) E ( z , t ) = λ tanh η t − χ z e i κ z − Ω t . For this case, the pulse amplitude given in Eq. (6) reduces to the form (20) | A ( z , t ) | = λ 2 − λ 2 sech 2 η t − χ z 1 / 2 . The latter corresponds to a black solitary pulse solution, for which the minimum of the amplitude |A(z, t)| is zero. The intensity profile of a typical black solitary wave (Eq. (19)) is shown in Fig. 2 (a) for the same values of all parameters as for Fig. 1, except we choose α 7 =−0.0247 and α 8 =0.0247 for the parametric condition (17) to be fulfilled. We see that the solitary wave profile stays unaltered after propagating a distance of 20 normalized lengths, which we have shown in Fig. 2(b). The above results show that we must require 5α 7 +4α 8 =0 for the gray solution to exist, and α 7 + α 8 =0 for the existence of the black solitary wave, but the condition α 3 3 α 4 + 2 α 5 < 0 remains the same for the existence of both types of solitary waves. 5 Conclusion In this paper, the evolution of light pulses in nonlinear media exhibiting nonlinearities up to the fifth-order wherein the pulse propagation is governed by the higher-order nonlinear Schrödinger equation with derivative non-Kerr nonlinear terms is considered. This equation can be used to model femtosecond optical pulse propagation in highly nonlinear optical fibers. We have obtained an exact gray solitary wave solution (a dark structure with nonzero minimum intensity) on a continuous-wave background by using the ansatz method. We also demonstrated the existence of black solitary wave-type solutions for model under certain conditions on physical parameters. The obtained results are helpful in exploring more solitary waves in highly nonlinear optical fibers and providing a new reference for experimental verification. Acknowledgements The second author (QZ) was funded by the Young Foundation of Wuhan Donghu University under the grant number 2017dhzk001. The third author (SPM) would like to thank the research support provided by the Department of Mathematics and Statistics at Tshwane University of Technology and the support from the South African National Foundation under Grant Number 92052 IRF1202210126. The research work of sixth author (MB) was supported by Qatar National Research Fund (QNRF) under the grant number NPRP 8-028-1-001. The authors also declare that there is no conflict of interest.
