column2: The optical properties of GaN (001)surface modified by intrinsic defects from density functional theory calculation
column3: Abstract Based on the first principle density functional theory calculation, the effect of two kinds of intrinsic point defects on the optical properties of GaN polar surface was investigated in this paper. It was found that the band gap and the positions of the electronic states changed with the presence of defects, resulting in a change in the optical properties. The static dielectric function decreased slightly, the numbers and the positions of the peaks in the imaginary part of dielectric function change a lot, the intensity of the absorption spectrum decreased, significant of shrinking of the absorption spectrum was observed, and the electron energy loss spectra peak broadened along with the decrease in the peak height. In the case of the GaN polar surface with the N vacancy, the range of the absorption spectrum comprised the visible light, and the presence of the N vacancy resulted in a low energy plasma excitation peak.
column5: Keywords GaN polar surface Intrinsic defect Density of state Optical property 1 Introduction Gallium nitride (GaN) is a III–V compound semiconductor material, and a typical representative of third generation semiconductor materials. Owing to its wide direct band gap, large thermal conductivity, high breakdown voltage, high temperature resistance, and good physical and chemical stability [1–3], GaN has broad application prospects for the development of blue Light Emitting Diodes (LED), blue lasers, ultraviolet (UV) detectors, and so on [4,5]. In recent years, through the first principle density functional theory, considerable theoretical efforts have been made in order to gain insight into the physical processes on GaN [6–8]. Ji et al. has investigated the electronic structure and optical properties of GaN surface with Si doping,the results show that the absorption and reflection to ultraviolet are subdued, so Ga(Si)N material is more suitable for UV detection [9]. Cs adsorption on (100) surface of [001]-oriented GaN nanowires was studied by Sihao Xia et al.,the results show that Cs adsorption can greatly reduce the work function of GaN nanowire, Cs will lose electrons and electrons mostly transfer to surface Ga atoms [10]. Guerrero-Sánchez et al. has studied YN nanostructure formation on the GaN (0001) surface,the results show that the most stable configurations correspond to the Y adsorption at the T4 site, and the YN bilayers are in the wurtzite-like phase with the surface showing metallic characteristics [11]. Electronic structure of Al0.25Ga0.75N (0001) surfaces covered with different coverage of cesium were studied by Mingzhu Yang et al.,the results show that the density of states (DOS) at Fermi level increases by the joint effort of Cs 5s and 5p state electrons, which improves the conductivity of the surface and results in semi-metallic properties [12]. Defects, that are formed during the growth process of GaN, may interact with carriers and affect the optical properties of GaN, subsequently affecting the performances of photoelectric devices. Six kinds of intrinsic defects have been observed in GaN: N vacancy, Ga vacancy, N clearance, Ga clearance, substitution of N by Ga, and substitution of Ga by N. In the present study, the effects of point defects on the optical properties of GaN polar surfaces were studied by considering the case of substitution of Ga by N and N vacancy defects. Furthermore, the reasons for the changes in the optical properties were analyzed. 2 Theoretical model and calculation method 2.1 Theoretical model The ideal GaN crystal exhibits the hexagonal wurtzite structure, a 4×4 super-cell of the bulk GaN structure (four Ga-N layers) was constructed. To model the GaN (001) surface, the bulk GaN structure was cleaved along the (001) surface, the top two layers of this slab model were relaxed freely, the bottom two layers were fixed, at least a 1.3nm vacuum thickness was used to avoid the interaction between each other, and the dangling bonds at the bottom surface were saturated by pseudo-hydrogen atoms as shown in Fig. 1 (a). A 15Å wide vacuum region perpendicular to the GaN (001) surface was added, which was confirmed to be appropriate (based on the average electrostatic potential plot). Fig. 1(b) and (c) shows the GaN (001) surface structures with the substitution of Ga by N and N vacancy defects, a Ga atom was replaces by a N atom or a N atom was removed in the outermost layer, the defect concentration was 3.125%. The constructed structures were optimized to achieve the steady state. 2.2 Calculation method In this paper, the CASTEP (Cambridge Sequential Total Energy Package) module is adopted to calculate intrinsic point defects in GaN material using the first principles. Simulations are performed under generalized gradient approximation (GGA) with Perdew-Burke-Ernzerhof (PBE) exchange and correlation. The Brillouin-zone (BZ) integration is calculated by the highly symmetric K points in the form of a Monkhorst-Pack 7×7×1 grid. In the process of structure optimization, 500eV mesh cutoff energy is set for the expansion of plane wave basis sets and the convergence criteria was set to energy change below 2×10−6 eV/atom for all systems, force less than 0.02eV/nm, the convergence tolerance of a single atomic energy below 1×10−5 eV/atom, stress less than 0.05GPa, and change in displacement of atoms less than 1×10−3 Å. All calculations are carried in reciprocal space with Ga:3d104s24p1 and N:2s22p3. The optical properties of any system are in general evaluated with the help of frequency dependent complex dielectric function. ε(ω)=ε1(ω)+iε2(ω), where the real part ε1 =n2-k2, the imaginary part ε2 =2nk, n represents reflection coefficient and k represents extinction coefficient. The imaginary part ε2 is computed with the help of first order time dependent perturbation theory in the simple dipole approximation. In the long wavelength limit, the real part and imaginary part of the ε(ω) are given by: (1) ε 1 = 1 + c 2 ∑ V , C ∫ B Z d 3 K 2 2 p | e M C V ( K ) | 2 [ E C ( K ) - E V ( K ) ] h 3 [ E C ( K ) - E V ( K ) ] 2 - h 2 w 2 (2) ε 2 = c 1 2 w 2 ∑ V , C ∫ B Z d 3 K 2 ( 2 p ) 2 | e M C V ( K ) | 2 d [ E C ( K ) - E V ( K ) - h w ] where C and V represent conduction band and valence band respectively, BZ represents the first brillouin zone, ℏis planck's constant, K is electronic wave vector, eMCV(K)2 is defined as the matrix elements of momentum transition, ω is angular frequency, c1 and c2 are defined as constants, EC(K) and EV(K) represent intrinsic energy level on the conduction band and valence band respectively. The complex refractive index (Ñ) of a material is related to ε(ω) by the relation Ñ2 =ε(ω). On simplification one can obtain the real part as well as the imaginary part of the refractive index in the form of Ñ(ω)=n(ω)+ik(ω), where, (3) n ( w ) = ( e 1 2 + e 2 2 + e 1 2 ) 1 2 (4) k ( w ) = ( e 1 2 + e 2 2 - e 1 2 ) 1 2 With the magnitude of n(ω) and k(ω), one can further compute the reflectivity (5) R ( w ) = ( n - 1 ) 2 + k 2 ( n + 1 ) 2 + k 2 The absorption coefficient can also be evaluated using the formula, (6) a ( w ) = 2 k w c h Where c represents the speed of light in vacuum and ω is in energy unit.The electron energy loss spectra (EELS) is a direct measurement of the collective excitation of a system which is given by the relation L(ω)=Im(−1/ε(ω)). On simplification it becomes, (7) L ( w ) = ε 2 ε 1 2 + ε 2 2 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Density of states The total DOS and partial DOS have been depicted in Fig. 2 . By comparing the N vacancy defect structure with the pristine GaN polar surface, the Fermi level moves to the high-energy area and comes into the conduction band for the existence of N vacancy, which shows n-type semiconductor conductive properties as in the results of Refs. [13] and [14]. At the same time, the N 2s-and N 2p-state electrons move to low-energy area, so do the Ga 3d-, Ga4 s- and Ga 4p-state electrons. The reason for this change is that the vacancy causes partial changes of the electronic structures of the vacancy neighbor and next neighbor atoms. For the GaN polar surface with N substitute Ga defect, the conduction and valence bands have been linked together, which means that the band gap has disappeared. The electronic states of Ga and N atoms have a slight movement toward the low-energy direction. 3.2 Optical properties The optical properties of photoelectric materials are mainly characterized by the dielectric function, optical absorption spectra, conductivity, loss function, refractive index and reflection coefficient. The optical constants, relating the microscopic model of physical process with the microelectronic structure of the solid that can better characterize the physical properties of the material, are mainly determined by the electronic structures and the carrier concentration near the Fermi level. The changes in the electronic structures of GaN caused by the defects of substitution of Ga by N and N vacancy would influence its optical properties. The optical properties of the three different polar surface structures of GaN (pristine, Ga substituted by N, and N vacancy) are depicted in Fig. 3 . 3.2.1 Dielectric function and optical absorption Within the linear response range, the structure of the energy band of a solid and other kinds of spectral information can be obtained from the dielectric function, which associates the micro-physical process of inter-band transition with the electronic structure of the solid. The spectra of the GaN semiconductor material were produced by electronic transitions between bands. Each dielectric peak can be explained by band structures and density of states of GaN. In the dielectric function, the decline of the real part determines the peak value of the imaginary part, and the imaginary part represents the optical absorption intensity. Fig. 3(a) and (b) represents the frequency dependent real and imaginary parts of ε(ω) of the three different polar surface structures of GaN. For the pristine GaN polar surface, the static dielectric function ε1(0) was found to be 3.44, the maximum value of the real part was 4.17 at the optical frequency of 3.9eV, and the minimum value was found to be −0.57 at the optical frequency of 11.7eV. With an increase in the optical frequency, the real part decreased rapidly in the range of 3.9–11.7eV, which indicates that the imaginary part increased rapidly in this range. However, fluctuation in the trend of the imaginary part were also observed at certain points within this range. The main peaks of ε2(ω) corresponds to the specific inter-band transition. Five main peaks were observed in the graph of ε2(ω) at optical frequencies of 2.72, 6.84,8.56, 10.70, and 13.42eV. The peak at 2.72eV corresponds to the transition of N 2p state (upper valence band) to Ga 4s state, the peaks at 6.84 and 8.56eV indicate the transitions of N 2s state (lower valence band) to Ga 4s and Ga 4p states respectively, and the peaks at 10.70 and 13.42eV correspond to the transitions of Ga 4p state to N 2s and N 2p states respectively. Fig. 3(c) shows the absorption coefficients of the three different structures of GaN. As can be seen from the figure, the maximum value of the absorption coefficient is 213000cm−1 at the optical frequency of 11.34eV and the optical range of absorption spectra is 2.2–29.3eV. The absorption edge begins at the optical frequency of 1.66eV, which corresponds to the direct transition threshold and is in agreement with Refs [15]. This is caused by the electronic transition from the top of the valence band to the bottom of the conduction band. After the introduction of N substitution of Ga and N vacancy defects into the GaN polar surface, the static dielectric function ε1(0) decreased slightly, the numbers and the positions of the peaks of ε2(ω) that represent the transition change significantly, the intensity of the absorption spectrum decreased, and significant of shrinking of the absorption spectrum in the high energy region was observed. In the case of the GaN polar surface with Ga substituted by N, ε1(0) was found to be 1.97. The change in the peak of ε2(ω) indicates change in the interband transition, which is caused by the change in the electronic states. Only three peaks were observed in the graph of ε2(ω), which correspond to the transitions of N 2p state (upper valence band) to Ga 4s state, N 2s state (lower valence band) to Ga 4s state, and Ga 4p state to N 2p state. The maximum value of the absorption coefficient was 60,200cm−1 at the optical frequency of 6.58eV. The optical range of the absorption spectra was separated into two parts ranging from 1.9 to 11.46eV and 16.8 to 18.9eV and the absorption peak moved to the lower energy region. The absorption edge was observed at the optical frequency of 1.9eV, which indicates the red shift of the absorption edge. In the case of the GaN polar surface with the N vacancy defect, ε1(0) was determined to be 3.15. The shift in the absorption spectra towards the lower energy region is more evident in this case, and the range of the absorption spectrum comprised the visible light region (1.57–3.18eV). In addition, a new absorption peak appeared in the low energy region, this is because the N vacancy defect caused changes in the electronic structures of its neighboring atoms. 3.2.2 Reflectivity and refractive index The real part of the refractive index n(ω) was computed using Eq. (3), and the results are shown in Fig. 3(d). The static value of refractive index n(0) of the pristine GaN polar surface was 1.86, and the maximum value of its real part was 2.07 at the optical frequency of 4.02eV. The absorption of the high-frequency electromagnetic wave decreased with increase in the photon energy above 20eV, and the change in the refractive index was observed to be very small. In the case of the GaN polar surface with Ga substituted by N, the maximum value of n(ω) was found to be 1.56 at the optical energy of 2.01eV, which indicates a shift in the peak position to the low frequency region. The range of the optical frequency of n(ω) decreased in the high frequency region. In the case of the GaN polar surface with the N vacancy defect, the trend of the changes was the same as that of the GaN polar surface with Ga substituted by N; however, the magnitude of the changes was more pronounced. The optical parameter corresponding to the refractive index is reflectivity R(ω), which can be computed by Eq. (5). From Fig. 3(e), the maximum value of reflectivity of the pristine GaN polar surface was 0.36 at the optical frequency of 15.4eV. The reflectivity observed at optical energies above 28eV was very small. In the case of the GaN polar surface with the defects of Ga substituted by N and N vacancy, the maximum value of R(ω) became smaller and apparently shifted toward the low frequency region. In addition, the optical frequency range was reduced to values less than 15eV. 3.2.3 Electron energy loss function The electron energy loss function (EELS) describes the energy loss of electrons in a homogeneous medium. The peak value of the function represents plasma turbulence, and the corresponding oscillation frequency is known as the plasma frequency. The EELS was computed using Eq. (7), and the results are shown in Fig. 3(f). A single sharp peak of height 5.2 was observed at 15.9eV for the pristine GaN polar surface; this peak position corresponds to the edge energy of plasma and indicates the transition point of the material from metallic to dielectric properties. In the cases of the GaN polar surface with the defects of Ga substituted by N and N vacancy, the EELS peak broadened and the height of the peak decreased significantly, and the peak position shifted to the low energy region. Furthermore, a new peak was observed in the frequency region below 1.86eV for the GaN polar surface with the N vacancy defect. This indicates that the presence of N vacancy in the GaN polar surface gives rise to a low energy plasma excitation peak. 4 Summary In our work the optical properties of GaN polar surface with the two kinds of intrinsic point defects were calculated through the first principle density functional theory. The influence of Ga substituted by N and N vacancy defects on the optical properties of GaN (001) surface was mainly concentrated in the low-energy region and get weak in the high-energy region. The peak position of the dielectric function shifted to the low frequency region, which increases the electronic transitions in visible light region. Furthermore, the absorption to visible light and even infrared light is enhanced in the presence of N vacancy, which is suitable for the longer wave light detection instead of UV detection. Acknowledgment This research is supported by the National Natural Science Foundation of China (Grant Nos. 61376099 and 61434007).

column2: Active cancellation method of the chirp-subpulse stepped frequency (CSSF) based on repeater jamming
column3: Abstract This paper presents an active cancellation method based on repeater jamming to weaken the incident wave rather than to weaken the scattered wave in conventional method. The method works well on chirp-subpulse stepped frequency (CSSF) signal. The incident plane wave is interfered by a spherical wave which is generated by a horizontal electric dipole. The analysis and simulation show that the plane wave can be reduced obviously via this method. By incorporating frequency and phase modulation, the backscattering of the target is reduced significantly. Numerical experiments also show that with greater wavelength, the cancellation performance gets better.
column5: Keywords Cancellation Repeater jamming Spherical wave Chirp-subpulse stepped frequency (CSSF) Matched filter 1 Introduction The active cancellation's original concept came from Paul Leug, who proposed this method to control the noise as early as 1933. The method reduces the synthesized signal by using the transmitting signal and the incident signal's coherent interference. The concept was put forward in radar stealth technology in the 1960s. During the next 50 years, the research of the active cancellation involves the principle, the system and the performance [1,2]. The signal types include linear frequency modulation (LFM) and non-linear frequency modulation (NLFM) [3,4]. The traditional active cancellation uses the transmitting signal to weaken the scattered field. It relies on the targets’ scattering characteristics, which must be obtained and stored in a database to determine the cancellation signal's strength. Some numerical method have been developed to calculate radar cross section (RCS) of arbitrary shape, include finite-difference time-domain (FDTD) [5,6], shooting and bouncing ray (SBR) [7,8] and method of moments (MoM) [9]. However, it is very difficult to acquire precise RCS of complex targets such as the aircraft. Moreover, RCS of aircraft may fluctuate during the flight due to vibration of some moving parts. In this paper, a novel method is presented to weaken the incident field by repeating incident signal, which dexterously avoids establishing a scattering characteristics database. Theoretical analysis and numerical experiments show that the method is efficient in canceling chirp-subpulse stepped frequency (CSSF) signal. This method also has a less time delay and smaller error and is more convenient in practice. 2 The principle of active cancellation The CSSF signal has both the characteristics of chirp signal and step frequency signal. It has the high resolution and can reduce the instantaneous bandwidth of the digital signal processor. The active cancellation method proposed in this paper is based on repeater jamming after sampling to interfere with the CSSF signal. The delay time of this method is greatly reduced compared with traditional active cancellation technology. Moreover, if the modulation parameters are chosen properly, the two signals’ phases can be reversed mutually and their amplitudes are the same. Thus, the backscattering signal decreases significantly, which reduces the probability of target detection. The cancellation system is shown in Fig. 1 . The cancellation device consists of five components, which are receiving antenna, signal analysis device, frequency modulation-phase modulation device, power amplifier and transmitting antenna. The incident signal is received by the receiving antenna and distinguished by the signal analysis device. This signal's frequency and phase are modulated by the frequency modulation-phase modulation device to have the same direction, power, frequency and opposite phase with the incident signal. After augmented by the power amplifier, it is transmitted to the scattering target. 3 The coherent interference of the plane wave and the spherical wave 3.1 The scattering of the plane wave and the spherical wave In Fig. 1, the transmitting antenna's cancellation signal is a spherical wave. The incident wave is a plane wave, considering long distance from radar to target compared with wavelength. Thus, it is necessary to verify the effect of the plane wave and the spherical wave. The scattering source is an perfectly electric conductive sphere, whose radius is a. The incident plane wave is (1) E i = E 0 e jkz e ˆ x = E 0 e jkr cos θ e ˆ x where E i is incident electric field, e ˆ x is unit vector along with electric field, k is wave number, x and z are the Cartesian coordinate system's components, r and θ are the spherical coordinate system's components, j is imaginary unit, superscript “i” represents the incident wave, subscript “0” represents the electric field intensity amplitude. The plane wave's scattering far field can be approximated as (2a) E θ s 1 ≈ j E 0 cos ϕ e − jkr kr ∑ n = 1 ∞ b n P n 1 ′ ( cos θ ) − c n P n 1 ( cos θ ) sin θ (2b) E ϕ s 1 ≈ j E 0 sin ϕ e − jkr kr ∑ n = 1 ∞ b n P n 1 ( cos θ ) sin θ − c n P n 1 ′ ( cos θ ) where ϕ is the spherical coordinate's component. P n m ( x ) is associated Legendre polynomial, which is represented as (3) P n m ( x ) = ( − 1 ) m ( 1 − x 2 ) m / 2 d m P n ( x ) d x m where P n (x) is the Legendre function of the nth order. b n and c n are coefficients, which are (4a) b n = − j n ( 2 n + 1 ) J ˆ n ′ ( ka ) n ( n + 1 ) H ˆ n ( 2 ) ′ ( ka ) (4b) c n = − j n ( 2 n + 1 ) J ˆ n ( ka ) n ( n + 1 ) H ˆ n ( 2 ) ( ka ) where a is sphere's radius and (5) J ˆ n ( x ) = x j n ( x ) (6) H ˆ n ( 2 ) ( x ) = xh n ( 2 ) ( x ) where j n (x) is spherical Bessel function of the first kind, h n ( 2 ) ( x ) is spherical Hankel function of the second kind. Perfectly conductive sphere's backward RCS is (7) σ 0 = λ 2 4 π ∑ n = 1 ∞ ( − 1 ) n 2 n + 1 H ˆ n ( 2 ) ( ka ) H ˆ n ( 2 ) ′ ( ka ) 2 The horizontal electric dipole is used to simulate the spherical wave, which is shown in Fig. 2 . The electric dipole can be determined by a current element I d l a . The spherical wave's scattering field can be obtained by method of separate variable. Scattering electric field along with θ and ϕ direction can be expressed as (8a) E θ s 2 ( r ) = η I d l a e − jkr 4 π rd cos ϕ ∑ n = 1 ∞ X 1 P n 1 ′ ( cos θ ) − jX 2 P n 1 ( cos θ ) sin θ (8b) E ϕ s 2 ( r ) = η I d l a e − jkr 4 π rd sin ϕ ∑ n = 1 ∞ X 1 P n 1 ( cos θ ) sin θ − jX 2 P n 1 ′ ( cos θ ) where (9a) X 1 = j n ( 2 n + 1 ) n ( n + 1 ) J ˆ n ′ ( kd ) − J ˆ n ′ ( ka ) H ˆ n ( 2 ) ′ ( ka ) H ˆ n ( 2 ) ′ ( kd ) (9b) X 2 = j n ( 2 n + 1 ) n ( n + 1 ) J ˆ n ( kd ) − J ˆ n ( ka ) H ˆ n ( 2 ) ( ka ) H ˆ n ( 2 ) ( kd ) where d is the distance between the dipole and the center of the conducting sphere. In Cartesian coordinate system, the plane wave's and the spherical wave's back scattering field can be approximated as (10a) E s 1 ≈ E 0 e − jkz 2 kz ∑ n = 1 ∞ ( − 1 ) n r 1 e j θ 1 e ˆ x (10b) E s 2 ≈ − η I d l a e − jkz 4 π zd ∑ n = 1 ∞ j n r 2 e j θ 2 e ˆ x where r 1 and r 2 are amplitude of complex number, θ 1 and θ 2 are argument of complex number. r 1 e jθ 1 and r 2 e jθ 2 are represented as (11a) r 1 e j θ 1 = ∑ n = 1 ∞ j ( − 1 ) n 2 n + 1 H ˆ n ( 2 ) ( ka ) H ˆ n ( 2 ) ′ ( ka ) (11b) r 2 e j θ 2 = ∑ n = 1 ∞ j n 2 n + 1 X 3 + jX 4 where λ is wavelength, η is wave impedance in free space and (12a) X 3 = J ˆ n ′ ( ka ) H ˆ n ( 2 ) ′ ( kd ) H ˆ n ( 2 ) ′ ( ka ) (12b) X 4 = J ˆ n ( ka ) H ˆ n ( 2 ) ( kd ) H ˆ n ( 2 ) ( ka ) According to (10)–(12), the sum of back scattering field of the plane wave and the spherical wave can be expressed as (13) E s ≈ e − jkz e ˆ x 4 π z E 0 λ r 1 e j θ 1 − η I d l a 2 d r 2 e j θ 2 With the spherical wave incident on the sphere, RCS is (14) σ 1 ≈ λ 2 4 π r 1 e j θ 1 + p r 2 e j θ 2 2 where p = − η I d l a 2 λ E 0 d . In (14), σ 1 can be controlled by choosing the value of I d l a and d. 3.2 The effect of the coherent interference 3.2.1 The influence of the distance between source and target The distance between the spherical wave source and conducting sphere have great influence on the corresponding cancellation performance. From (14), when p = − r 1 r 2 cos ( θ 2 − θ 1 ) , σ 1 obtains the minimum value and the horizontal electric dipole is (15) I d l a = − 2 λ d r 1 cos θ 2 − θ 1 η r 2 E 0 When λ and d are assigned proper values, RCS of conductive sphere also gets the minimum value σ min, which is (16) σ min = λ 2 r 1 sin θ 1 − θ 2 4 π Fig. 3 show the variation of optimal cancellation RCS with d when different wavelengths are given. In Fig. 3, we can see that the optimal cancellation RCS is between 0 to πa 2 depending on d. The smaller the wavelength is, the more sensitive of d. In Fig. 3, σ min =0 and σ min = πa 2 when θ 2 − θ 1 = mπ, (m =−1, 0, 1) and θ 1 − θ 2 =0.5mπ, (m =−1, 1), respectively. 3.2.2 The influence of the wavelength on the optimal cancellation effect The variations of the optimal cancellation RCS with λ are shown in Fig. 4 , assuming that distance d between the source and the target is constant. In Fig. 4, we can see as λ varies, the normalized optimal cancellation RCS varies between 0 and 1. When d is constant, the spherical wave cannot always reduce the plane wave's scattering field to 0. 3.2.3 Evaluation of the cancellation's effect The cancellation degree is utilized to evaluate the cancellation's effect, which is defined as (17) S 0 = 20 lg 1 + Δ E E s where S 0 is the cancellation degree, ΔE is the cancellation remainder field, and E s is the target's scattering field. In order to assess the cancellation's effect more precisely, the modified cancellation degree is presented as (18) S = log 2 1 + Δ E E s = log 2 1 + σ σ 0 The cancellation device can make S less than 0.5 or 0.5–1, which mean complete cancellation or partial cancellation, respectively. If S >1, the backscattering is magnified rather than reduced. 3.3 Error analysis 3.3.1 The influence of distance's error The optimal cancellation RCS can be reduced to 0 by setting ideal values of d and I d l a . However, there may be some error to influence the canceling effect. By denoting error of d as Δd, RCS can be expressed as (19) σ 1 ′ ≈ λ 2 4 π r 1 e j θ 1 − η I d l a 2 λ E 0 d + Δ d ∑ n = 1 ∞ j n 2 n + 1 X 5 2 where (20) X 5 = J ˆ n ′ ( ka ) H ˆ n ( 2 ) ′ ( kd + k Δ d ) H ˆ n ( 2 ) ′ ( ka ) + j J ˆ n ( ka ) H ˆ n ( 2 ) ( kd + k Δ d ) H ˆ n ( 2 ) ( ka ) The distance between the spherical wave source and the conductive sphere center is d =2a. The influences of distance's error on the cancellation's effect are shown in Fig. 5 . In Fig. 5, we can see that distance error has a great influence on the cancellation effect. If the distance's error is too large, the result may be a negative effect on the cancellation. When the wavelength is longer, the requirement for the distance's error control is looser. The complete cancellation can be fulfilled in a larger error's range. On the contrary, when the wavelength is shorter, it is necessary to strictly control the distance's error to achieve the complete cancellation performance. 3.3.2 The influence of angle's error If the spherical wave's incident direction is not exactly toward −z, there are angle's errors denoted as Δθ and Δϕ. The back scattering field under Cartesian coordinate can be expressed as (21a) E x s 2 ( r ) = − η I d l a 4 π rd e − jkr cos Δ ϕ ∑ n = 1 ∞ j n ( 2 n + 1 ) n ( n + 1 ) X 6 (21b) E y s 2 ( r ) = − η I d l a 4 π rd e − jkr sin Δ ϕ ∑ n = 1 ∞ j n ( 2 n + 1 ) n ( n + 1 ) X 7 where (22a) X 6 = J ˆ n ′ ( ka ) H ˆ n ( 2 ) ′ ( kd ) H ˆ n ( 2 ) ′ ( ka ) P n 1 ′ cos Δ θ − j J ˆ n ( ka ) H ˆ n ( 2 ) ( kd ) H ˆ n ( 2 ) ( ka ) P n 1 cos Δ θ sin Δ θ (22b) X 7 = J ˆ n ′ ( ka ) H ˆ n ( 2 ) ′ ( kd ) H ˆ n ( 2 ) ′ ( ka ) P n 1 cos Δ θ sin Δ θ − j J ˆ n ( ka ) H ˆ n ( 2 ) ( kd ) H ˆ n ( 2 ) ( ka ) P n 1 ′ cos Δ θ The conductive sphere's total RCS is (23) σ ≈ λ 2 4 π r 1 e j θ 1 − η I d l a λ d E 0 cos Δ ϕ ∑ n = 1 ∞ j n 2 n + 1 n ( n + 1 ) X 6 2 + λ 2 4 π η I d l a λ d E 0 sin Δ ϕ ∑ n = 1 ∞ j n 2 n + 1 n ( n + 1 ) X 7 2 The distance between the spherical wave source and the conducting sphere center is d =2a. Angle ranges are 0⩽Δθ ⩽90°, −90°⩽Δϕ ⩽90° for θ and ϕ, respectively. The influence of the horizontal electric dipole angle's error on the cancellation degree is shown in Fig. 6 . From Fig. 6, we can see that near the point (Δθ =0, Δϕ =0), a slight increase of the angle error may result in a great change to the S. The change of S due to ϕ is smaller than the change due to θ. Generally, under the three different wavelengths, the change trend of S is primarily consistent with the smaller angle error. If angle errors are chosen as (Δθ ⩽15°, −30°⩽Δϕ ⩽30°), we have S <0.5, which means complete cancellation. Whiel if angle errors are chosen as (Δθ ⩽20°, −60°⩽Δϕ ⩽60°), we have S <1, which means partial cancellation. 4 The active cancellation's effect on chirp-subpulse 4.1 Analysis of the CSSF Assuming the CSSF's incident wave is (24) S ( t ) = 1 N τ ∑ i = 0 N − 1 u ( t − iT r ) e j 2 π f i t where N is the number of pulses in each burst, τ is pulse width, T r is pulse repetition time, f i is the ith chirp pulse's carrier frequency, which is (25) f i = f 0 + i Δ f where Δf is step frequency, u(t) is subpulse expressed as (26) u ( t ) = rect t τ e j π kt 2 where rect(x) is the rectangle function, which is (27) rect ( x ) = 1 , − 1 / 2 < t < 1 / 2 0 , others The repeater cancellation wave is (28) S J t = 1 N τ ∑ i = 0 N − 1 rect t − Δ τ − i T r τ e X 8 where the repeater time delay of cancellation device is Δτ(Δτ ≪ τ), the phase modulation is ϕ, the frequency modulation is f d and (29) X 8 = j π μ t − Δ τ − i T r 2 + j 2 π f 0 + f d + i Δ f t − Δ τ + j φ The receiver's matched filter response h(t) is conjugate of S *(−t), which is (30) h t = S * − t = 1 N τ ∑ i = 0 N − 1 rect t + i T r τ e − j π μ t + i T r 2 + j 2 π f 0 + i Δ f t After the target scattering, S(t) enters the receiver's matched filter with S J(t). Then the received signal is (31) S in ( t ) = S ( t ) + S J ( t ) The matched filter's output is (32) S out t = h t * S in t = ∫ − ∞ ∞ h ε S in t − ε d ε = ∫ − ∞ ∞ h ε S t − ε d ε + ∫ − ∞ ∞ h ε S J t − ε d ε = A + B where (33a) A = ∫ − ∞ ∞ h ε S t − ε d ε = 1 N τ ∫ − ∞ ∞ ∑ i = 0 N − 1 rect ε + i T r τ X 9 ∑ i = 0 N − 1 rect t − ε − i T r τ X 10 d ε (33b) B = ∫ − ∞ ∞ h ε S J t − ε d ε = 1 N τ ∫ − ∞ ∞ ∑ i = 0 N − 1 rect ε + i T r τ X 9 ∑ i = 0 N − 1 rect t − ε − Δ τ − i T r τ X 11 d ε where (34a) X 9 = e − j π μ ε + i T r 2 + j 2 π f 0 + i Δ f ε (34b) X 10 = e j π μ t − ε − i T r 2 + j 2 π f 0 + i Δ f t − ε (34c) X 11 = e j π μ t − ε − Δ τ − i T r 2 + j 2 π f 0 + f d + i Δ f t − ε − Δ τ + j φ According to the definition of the rectangular function and piecewise integral to the (33), we have (35a) A = τ − t − k T r N τ e X 12 sinc ( X 13 ) X 14 (35b) B = τ − t − Δ τ − k T r N τ e X 15 sinc ( X 16 ) X 17 where sinc x = sin x x and (36a) X 12 = j π 2 f 0 t + Δ fkt + Δ f k 2 T r (36b) X 13 = π μ − t + k T r − k Δ f τ − t − k T r (36c) X 14 = ∑ i = max − k , 0 min N − 1 − k , N − 1 e j 2 π Δ fi ( t + k T r ) (36d) X 15 = j π 2 f 0 + f d t − Δ τ + Δ fk t − Δ τ + Δ f k 2 T r + j φ (36e) X 16 = π μ − t + Δ τ + k T r − f d − k Δ f τ − t − Δ τ − k T r (36f) X 17 = ∑ i = max − k , 0 min N − 1 − k , N − 1 e j 2 π Δ fi ( t − Δ τ + k T r ) The receiver's matched filter output S out is available when −N +1⩽ k ⩽ N −1. It can be represented in piecewise function, which is (37) S out ( t ) = h t * S t − τ + k T r < t ⩽ − τ + k T r + Δ τ h t * S t + S J fd t − τ + k T r + Δ τ < t ⩽ τ + k T r h t * S J fd t τ + k T r < t ⩽ τ + k T r + Δ τ The convolution terms are (38a) h ( t ) * S ( t ) = τ − t − k T r N τ e X 18 sinc X 19 X 20 (38b) h ( t ) * S J fd ( t ) = τ − t − Δ τ − k T r N τ e X 21 sinc X 22 X 23 where (39a) X 18 = j π 2 f 0 t + Δ fkt + Δ f k 2 T r (39b) X 19 = π μ − t + k T r − k Δ f τ − t − k T r (39c) X 20 = ∑ i = max − k , 0 min N − 1 − k , N − 1 e j 2 π Δ fi t + k T r (39d) X 21 = j π 2 f 0 + f d t − Δ τ + Δ fk t − Δ τ + Δ f k 2 T r + j φ (39e) X 22 = π μ − t + Δ τ + k T r − f d − k Δ f τ − t − Δ τ − k T r (39f) X 23 = ∑ i = max − k , 0 min N − 1 − k , N − 1 e j 2 π Δ fi t − Δ τ + k T r From (37)–(39), we can see that in every pulse recurrence period, the matched filter's output consists of three components. The three components’ domains are (−τ + kT r , − τ + kT r +Δτ), (−τ + kT r +Δτ, τ + kT r ), and (τ + kT r , τ + kT r +Δτ). The corresponding single frequency oscillation outputs are generated by S(t), S(t)+ S J(t), and S J(t), respectively. In the first component, τ −|t − kT r | is close to 0. While in the third component, τ −|t −Δτ − kT r | is close to 0. Thus, the two parts’ peak values can be infinitesimal. The question is how to reduce the peak value of the second component, which is a function of Δτ, f d and ϕ. In order to make the S(t) and S J(t) have better cancellation effect, the repeater time delay should be close to 0. The f d and ϕ should satisfy the following condition (40a) π μ − t + k T r − k Δ f τ − t − k T r = π μ − t + Δ τ + k T r − f d − k Δ f τ − t − Δ τ − k T r (40b) π 2 f 0 t + Δ fkt + Δ f k 2 T r + π = π 2 f 0 + f d t − Δ τ + Δ fk t − Δ τ + Δ f k 2 T r + φ When Δτ is close to 0, the (40) can be written as (41a) μ − t + k T r − k Δ f = μ − t + Δ τ + k T r − f d − k Δ f (41b) π ( 2 f 0 t + Δ fkt + Δ f k 2 T r ) + π = π 2 f 0 + f d t − Δ τ + Δ fk t − Δ τ + Δ f k 2 T r + φ By simplifying (41), we get (42a) f d = μ Δ τ (42b) φ = π 2 f 0 Δ τ − 2 f d t − Δ τ + Δ fk Δ τ + 1 Frequency modulation is the product of μ and Δτ and phase modulation depends on f 0, Δτ, f d, t, Δf and k. 4.2 The simulation of the CSSF's repeater jamming cancellation 4.2.1 The influence of time delay on the cancellation Numerical experiment is conducted to validate the method in this paper. In the numerical experiment, the number of subpulse is N =8, the carrier frequency is 10GHz, which is median of X band whose frequency range is 8–12GHz, the step weight is Δf =1MHz, the pulse recurrence period is T r =100μs, the subpulse's pulse width is τ =10μs, the subpulse's bandwidth is B =5MHz, the subpulse's frequency modulation slope is μ = B/τ =0.5MHz/μs. The cancellation effect under different time delay is shown in Fig. 7 . From Fig. 7, we conclude that the time delay has a significant influence on the cancellation effect. When the time delay is less than 10ns and 50ns, the peak value can be reduced to approximately 20% and 95%, respectively. However, when the time delay increases to 100ns, the peak value exceeds that of no cancellation. Thus, the cancellation device has a very high requirement for the components’ time delay. A short time delay is required to obtain a good cancellation effect. If the time delay is not controlled well, the method may not work or even strengthen the backscattering. 4.2.2 The influence of frequency modulation and phase modulation In (40), Δτ is approximate to infinitesimal. But when τ −|t − kT r | is close to Δτ, the time delay's effect cannot be ignored. It may cause the frequency modulation and phase modulation in (42) ineffective. So the effect of frequency modulation and phase modulation on cancellation should be analyzed. The delay time Δτ is set to 10ns and other simulation parameters are the same as above. The simulation result is shown in Fig. 8 . From Fig. 8, we conclude that appropriate frequency modulation or phase modulation can make the cancellation effect better. The frequency modulation can reduce the side peak value. The phase modulation plays a more important role in the cancellation effect, which makes the peak value reduce to 0.25. 4.2.3 The influence of incident wave's parameters The radar incident wave parameters may have an impact on the cancellation. We studied the influence of bandwidth and step weight on the cancellation effect, which is shown in Figs. 9 and 10 . From Figs. 9 and 10, we conclude that the radar incident wave parameters have a great impact on the cancellation performance. The bandwidth mainly influences the side peak value. The greater the bandwidth, the larger the side peak value. In particular, the step weight mainly influences the main peak value. When the step weight is 0.1MHz and 1MHz, the peak value is lower than 0.025 and higher than 0.2, respectively. However, when the step weight is greater than 10MHz, the peak value exceeds 1. 5 Conclusions This paper proposed a novel active cancellation method to reduce the electromagnetic backscattering of target via interfering incident wave by spherical wave. The active cancellation based on repeater jamming works well on CSSF. The simulation and analysis show that the spherical wave is very efficient in reducing the incident wave in a certain error range. A greater incident wavelength can result in a better cancellation effect. The appropriate frequency modulation and especial phase modulation can make the cancellation wave and original echo get the lower total output amplitude after the matched filter's processing. This method is suitable for the incident signal with a small bandwidth and a small step weight.

column2: Investigation of exact solutions for the Tzitzéica type equations in nonlinear optics
column3: Abstract In this paper, we consider the Tzitzéica type equations and establish the travelling wave transformation which turns the nonlinear evolution equations into the ordinary differential equations, then we obtain exact solutions of the Tzitzéica-Dodd-Bullough equation, the Tzitzéica equation and the Dodd-Bullough-Mikhailov equation by using the exponential rational function method.
column5: MSC 33F10 83C15 Keywords Exact solutions Travelling wave transformation Exponential rational function method Tzitzéica type equations 1 Introduction Nonlinearity is a magnificent feature of natural phenomena whose importance has attracted the attention of researchers for several decades. Exact solutions are of practical importance for nonlinear evolution equations (NLEEs). For instance, exact solutions can provide criteria to check the convergence and precision of numerical algorithms and the references for setting up parameters for experimental investigation [1]. Therefore, a considerable attention has been paid for finding exact solutions of NLEEs and various methods have been proposed e.g., inverse scattering transformation [2], Hirota method [3], modified ( w / g ) -expansion method [4], exp-function method [5], extended auxiliary equation method [6], trial equation method [7], tanh method [8], (G′/G, 1/G)-expansion method [9], improved tan ϕ ( ξ ) 2 -expansion method [10], transformed rational function method [11], exp(−ϕ(ξ)) method [12], ansatz method [13] and so on. In this paper, we skillfully apply the travelling wave transformation that converts the NLEEs into the ordinary differential equations. Then, we derive exact solutions of Tzitzéica type equations. 2 The exponential rational function method We consider the following NLEE of the type [14]: (1) P ( u , u t , u x , u tt , u xt , u xx , … ) = 0 , where u is an unknown function and P is a polynomial of u and its partial derivatives. For solving Eq. (1), we follow the steps below. Step 1. By applying the travelling wave transformation (2) u ( x , t ) = U ( ξ ) , ξ = kx + lt , where k and l are non-zero arbitrary constants, we reduce Eq. (1) to the following ordinary differential equation (3) Q ( U , U ′ , U ′ ′ , U ′ ′ ′ , … ) = 0 . Here, prime denotes derivative with respect to ξ. Eq. (3) should integrated term by term one or more times. Step 2. Assume the solution of Eq. (3) can be expressed as follows: (4) U ( ξ ) = ∑ n = 0 m a n ( 1 + e ξ ) n , where a n (a m ≠0) are constants to be determined later. Determine the integer m by balancing the highest order linear term with the highest order nonlinear term in Eq. (3). Step 3. By substituting Eq. (4) into the left-hand side of Eq. (3) and collecting all terms, we arrive at a polynomial in eξ. We equate each coefficient of this polynomial to zero, for deriving the set of algebraic equations. Finally, we solve the system to construct a variety of exact solutions for Eq. (1). 2.1 The Tzitzéica-Dodd-Bullough equation The Tzitzéica-Dodd-Bullough equation is written as (5) u xt − e − u − e − 2 u = 0 . Under the Painlevé transformation v = e − u or u = − ln v , this equation can be reduced as follows (6) − vv xt + v x v t − v 3 − v 4 = 0 . By introducing a transformation as (2), Eq. (6) can be turned into an ordinary differential equation: (7) kl ( ( V ′ ) 2 − V V ′ ′ ) − V 3 − V 4 = 0 . Balancing V V ′ ′ with V 4 gives m =1. The method of exponential rational function assumes that the solution be written in the following form (8) V ( ξ ) = a 0 + a 1 1 + e ξ , where a 0 and a 1 are constants to be determined. Substituting Eq. (8) into Eq. (7), and setting the coefficients to zero, we obtain a system of algebraic equations (9) − a 0 4 − a 0 3 = 0 , − 4 a 0 3 a 1 − 4 a 0 4 − 3 a 0 2 a 1 − l k a 0 a 1 − 4 a 0 3 = 0 , − 6 a 0 4 − 12 a 0 3 a 1 − 6 a 0 3 − 9 a 0 2 a 1 − 6 a 0 2 a 1 2 − 3 a 0 a 1 2 = 0 , l k a 1 2 − 12 a 0 3 a 1 + l k a 0 a 1 − 4 a 0 3 − 4 a 0 4 − 4 a 0 a 1 3 − a 1 3 − 9 a 0 2 a 1 − 6 a 0 a 1 2 − 12 a 0 2 a 1 2 = 0 , − 3 a 0 2 a 1 − 3 a 0 a 1 2 − 4 a 0 3 a 1 − 6 a 0 2 a 1 2 − 4 a 0 a 1 3 − a 0 3 − a 0 4 − a 1 4 − a 1 3 = 0 Then, we solve this system by using Maple and we find two different cases:Case 1.1: (10) a 0 = 0 , a 1 = − 1 , l = − 1 k , and (11) v 1 ( x , t ) = − 1 1 + cos kx − t k + sinh kx − t k . Therefore, the travelling wave solution of the Tzitzéica-Dodd-Bullough equation is (12) u 1 ( x , t ) = − ln 1 − 1 − cos kx − t k − sinh kx − t k . Case 1.2: (13) a 0 = − 1 , a 1 = 1 , l = − 1 k , and (14) v 2 ( x , t ) = − 1 + 1 1 + cos kx − t k + sinh kx − t k . Therefore, the travelling wave solution of the Tzitzéica-Dodd-Bullough equation is (15) u 2 ( x , t ) = − ln − 1 + 1 1 + cos ( kx − t k ) + sinh ( kx − t k ) . 2.2 The Tzitzéica equation The Tzitzéica equation is given as (16) u tt − u xx − e u + e − 2 u = 0 . Under the Painlevé transformation v = e u or u = ln v , this equation can be reduced as follows (17) vv tt − vv xx − v t 2 + v x 2 − v 3 + 1 = 0 . By using a transformation as Eq. (2), Eq. (17) is converted to the following ordinary differential equation (18) ( l 2 − k 2 ) ( V V ″ − ( V ′ ) 2 ) − V 3 + 1 = 0. Balancing VV″ with V 3 gives m =2. We seek the exact solution of Eq. (18) as: (19) V ( ξ ) = a 0 + a 1 1 + e ξ + a 2 ( 1 + e ξ ) 2 . Substituting Eq. (19) into Eq. (18) and equating the coefficients to zero, we find: (20) − a 0 3 + 1 = 0 , − 3 a 0 2 a 1 + 6 + l 2 a 0 a 1 − k 2 a 0 a 1 − 6 a 0 3 a 1 = 0 , − 3 a 0 a 1 l 2 + 15 + 2 l 2 a 0 a 1 − 15 a 0 2 a 1 − 15 a 0 3 − 4 k 2 a 0 a 2 − 3 a 0 2 a 2 + 4 l 2 a 0 a 2 − 2 k 2 a 0 a 1 = 0 , l 2 a 1 a 2 − 12 a 0 a 1 2 + l 2 a 1 2 + 20 − a 1 3 − 12 a 0 2 a 2 − 6 a 0 a 1 a 2 − 30 a 0 2 a 1 − 20 a 0 3 − 6 k 2 a 0 a 2 − k 2 a 1 a 2 + 6 l 2 a 0 a 2 + k 2 a 1 2 = 0 , − 18 a 0 a 1 a 2 + 2 k 2 a 1 a 2 − 3 a 1 2 a 2 − 3 a 1 3 + 2 k 2 a 0 a 1 − 18 a 0 a 1 2 + 2 k 2 a 1 2 − 18 a 0 2 a 2 − 30 a 0 2 a 1 + 15 − 2 l 2 a 1 a 2 − 3 a 0 a 2 2 − 2 l 2 a 0 a 1 − 2 l 2 a 1 2 − 15 a 0 3 = 0 , 2 k 2 a 2 2 − 3 a 1 a 2 2 − 12 a 0 2 a 2 − 18 a 0 a 1 a 2 + 2 k 2 a 0 a 2 − 6 a 0 a 2 2 + k 2 a 0 a 1 + k 2 a 1 2 − l 2 a 1 2 − 2 l 2 a 2 2 − 15 a 0 2 a 1 − 3 l 2 a 1 a 2 − 6 a 1 2 a 2 − l 2 a 0 a 1 − 2 l 2 a 0 a 2 + 3 k 2 a 1 a 2 − 3 a 1 3 + 6 − 6 a 0 3 − 12 a 0 a 1 2 = 0 , 1 − 3 a 1 a 2 2 − 3 a 0 2 a 1 − 3 a 0 2 a 2 − 3 a 0 a 1 2 − 3 a 0 a 2 2 − 3 a 1 2 a 2 − a 1 3 − a 0 3 − 6 a 0 a 1 a 2 − a 2 3 = 0. From the solution of the system above, we obtain different cases: (21) a 0 = 1 , a 1 = − 6 , a 2 = 6 and l = ± 3 + k 2 Case 2.1–2.2:We substitute Eq. (21) into Eq. (19) to find: (22) v 1 , 2 ( x , t ) = 1 − 6 1 + cosh ( kx ± 3 + k 2 t ) + sinh ( kx ± 3 + k 2 t ) (23) + 6 ( 1 + cosh ( kx ± 3 + k 2 t ) + sinh ( kx ± 3 + k 2 t ) ) 2 . Therefore, the travelling wave solutions of the Tzitzéica equation are obtained as (24) u 1 , 2 ( x , t ) = ln ( 1 − 6 1 + cosh ( kx ± 3 + k 2 t ) + sinh ( kx ± 3 + k 2 t ) + 6 ( 1 + cosh ( kx ± 3 + k 2 t ) + sinh ( kx ± 3 + k 2 t ) ) 2 ) . 2.3 The Dodd-Bullough-Mikhailov equation Finally, we consider the Dodd-Bullough-Mikhailov equation (25) u xt + e u + e − 2 u = 0 . Under the Painlevé transformation v = e u or u = ln v , this equation can be reduced as follows (26) vv xt − v x v t + + v 3 + 1 = 0 . Now we use a transformation as Eq. (2) to convert Eq. (26) to the following ordinary differential equation: (27) kl ( V V ″ − ( V ′ ) 2 ) + V 3 + 1 = 0. Balancing VV″ with V 3 gives m =2. So, the homogeneous balance method admits the use of a finite expansion in the form Eq. (19). We substitute Eq. (19) into Eq. (27) and after that set the coefficients equal to zero. This results in: (28) a 0 3 + 1 = 0 , 6 a 0 3 + k l a 0 a 1 + 3 a 0 2 a 1 + 6 = 0 , 2 k l a 0 a 1 + 3 a 0 2 a 2 + 15 a 0 2 a 1 + 3 a 0 a 1 2 + 4 k l a 0 a 2 + 15 + 15 a 0 3 = 0 , k l a 1 a 2 + 20 a 0 3 + 12 a 0 2 a 2 − k l a 1 2 + 12 a 0 a 1 2 + 20 + 30 a 0 2 a 1 + 6 k l a 0 a 2 + 6 a 0 a 1 a 2 + a 1 3 = 0 , − 2 k l a 1 a 2 + 15 a 0 3 + 3 a 1 2 a 2 − 2 k l a 1 2 + 18 a 0 2 a 2 + 18 a 0 a 1 a 2 + 18 a 0 a 1 2 + 30 a 0 2 a 1 + 3 a 0 a 2 2 − 2 k l a 0 a 1 + 15 + 3 a 1 3 = 0 , 18 a 0 a 1 a 2 − k l a 0 a 1 − 2 k l a 0 a 2 + 3 a 1 3 − 3 k l a 1 a 2 + 15 a 0 2 a 1 − k l a 1 2 − 2 k l a 2 2 + 3 a 1 a 2 2 + 12 a 0 a 1 2 + 6 a 0 3 + 6 a 1 2 a 2 + 6 + 12 a 0 2 a 2 + 6 a 0 a 2 2 = 0 , 1 + 3 a 0 2 a 1 + 3 a 0 2 a 2 + 3 a 0 a 1 2 + 3 a 0 a 2 2 + a 1 3 + 3 a 1 2 a 2 + 3 a 1 a 2 2 + a 2 3 + 6 a 0 a 1 a 2 + a 0 3 = 0. Then, we solve this system with Maple and find (29) a 0 = − 1 , a 1 = 6 , a 2 = − 6 , l = 3 k , and (30) v ( x , t ) = − 1 + 6 1 + cosh ( kx + 3 t k ) + sinh ( kx + 3 t k ) (31) − 6 ( 1 + cosh ( kx + 3 t k ) + sinh ( kx + 3 t k ) ) 2 . Therefore, the travelling wave solution of the Dodd-Bullough-Mikhailov equation is obtained as (32) u ( x , t ) = ln ( − 1 + 6 1 + cosh ( kx + 3 t k ) + sinh ( kx + 3 t k ) − 6 ( 1 + cosh ( kx + 3 t k ) + sinh ( kx + 3 t k ) ) 2 ) . 3 Conclusions With the help of symbolic computation (Maple), we have solved the Tzitzéica-Dodd-Bullough equation, the Tzitzéica equation and the Dodd-Bullough-Mikhailov equation by using the exponential rational function method. Several exact solutions have been derived which are in agreement with the results reported in [15]. It is worthwhile to mention that the exponential rational function method is an effective technique for solving other nonlinear evolution equations in mathematical physics.

column2: A novel optimized double junction CZTS/CIGS solar cell with improved performance: A numerical simulation
column3: Abstract In this paper, the performance of a double junction solar cell with a novel structure, i.e., made up of two layers of copper zinc tin sulfide (CZTS) & copper indium gallium diselenide (CIGS) and two layers of anti-reflector coatings namely zinc telluride (ZnTe) and cadmium sulfide (CdS) on the top layer of the cell are studied and optimized. To obtain an optimized performance, the effect of CIGS band gap changes on the efficiency is studied. For establishing the current matching in two sub-cells, the effect of thickness of ZnTe and CdS anti-reflectors layers is investigated for optimum short circuit current. The optimized proposed double junction CZTS/CIGS solar cell has an efficiency and fill factor of 45.37% and 86.37%, respectively.
column5: Keywords Double junction Anti-reflector Current matching Efficiency Fill factor 1 Introduction Today, the increase of global energy consumption and the environmental pollution caused by fossil fuel consumptions are the greatest problems that endanger the survival of the environment. To decrease the consumption of non-renewable natural resources and malicious fuels for environment, many scientific attempts has been made to reduce the costs of the renewable energy resources production. With the increasing development of technology, the production of electrical energy have been done, using solar spectrum energy; and this energy conversion has been made through the use of the essential property of semiconductors. Among the renewable energy resources, the solar spectrum energy has got a particular importance: because it is easily available, unlimited, and does not pollute the environment. The thin-film solar cells are appropriate and authentic options for production of electrical power and photovoltaic (PV) applications [1–4]. In [1], a double junction (DJ) InGaN/CIGS solar cell with a CdS anti-reflector coating (ARC) was simulated, and the obtained efficiency and fill factor were 40.42 % and 78.6 % respectively. While CIGS has been made of scarce elements, CZTS is made of abundant elements on earth; thus CZTS can be an appropriate replacement for CIGS. In [2], a method of simple solid-phase synthesis was utilized to prepare pure CZTS nano-crystalline. CZTS absorber films were fabricated by developing a novel route based on integration of non-vacuum and vacuum technique. In [3], DJ InGaP/GaAs solar cell with InAlGaP back surface field (BSF) layers was modeled numerically. However, a maximum conversion efficiency of 32.19 % was achieved, which is a low efficiency. Review of previous researches about CIGS solar cells development indicates the maximum value of 20 % for efficiency [4] which is not yet satisfactory. ARC less DJ InGaP/GaAs solar cell that a InGaP/InGaP tunnel junction has been used in its structure, and its top BSF dual layer has been optimized, has a better absorption of solar spectrum due to invention of a new tunnel junction and optimization of the top BSF layer; and therefore improves parameters of short-circuit current density (Jsc) ،open-circuit voltage (Voc) and efficiency [5]. However, the efficiency value of 40.87 % is achieved for 1000 suns illuminated under standard AM1.5G spectrum. The simulated structure of the InGaP/GaAs based DJ solar cell, by using a layer of 0.11μm thick carbon nanotubes, shows that adding a layer of carbon nanotubes on the surface of the cell, although leading to an increased efficiency of 41.95 %, but leads to a decreased fill factor of 72.2% [6]. CZTS as one of the most applicable semiconducting compounds, which functions as an absorber layer in the solar cells are in demand. The applicability of CZTS is as the result of the high absorption constant of 104–105 cm−1 in the visible light wavelengths range, direct band gap energy in the range of 1.4–1.5 ev, and also being formed by abundant and non-toxic elements [7]. A solution, with the focus on the results of sulfurization technique study, has been proposed to improve the conversion efficiency of the thin-film solar cell based on CZTS that has increased the conversion efficiency to 6.7 %. However, many problems remained that include detailed physical features of CZTS for improving the conversion efficiency [8]. In this paper, a new structure of DJ CZTS/CIGS solar cell with two ZnTe and CdS anti-reflectors is designed, and the characteristics and parameters of this structure such as fill factor and efficiency have been optimized to achieve the most efficient structure. The key parameter of solar cell such as efficiency and fill factor has been increased in the proposed structure. 2 The structure and simulation of double junction CZTS/CIGS solar cell Solar cells are the solid state components that work based on the photovoltaic effect. The phenomenon of the conversion of solar light spectrum energy into electrical energy is called photovoltaic effect. Many semiconductors can convert the solar energy into electrical energy. Various procedures and materials are employed to use the photovoltaic effect, but in practice, almost every photovoltaic energy conversions use semiconductors in the form of p-n junction. The spectral light radiation on the solar cells provides the current and voltage needed for electric power production. Sunlight contains the complex spectrum with different wavelengths each of which has the specific energy of its own. Ideal spectral response of solar cell is limited in long wavelengths because of semiconductor’s disability to absorb photons with energy lower than band gap energy. Similarly, short wavelengths with higher energy than band gap energy are not utilized by solar cells but pass through them. These wavelengths transform to heat and increase solar cells’ temperature. Mentioned disability in full use of different energies of the solar light spectrum shows a significant loss of power in single p-n junction solar cells [9–12]. The use of different material with different band gaps energy in the structure of multi-junction solar cells result in the absorption of different wavelengths. Therefore, in multi-junction solar cells light absorption is more, and thus the efficiency is higher, and this has brought multi-junction solar cells a special attention. In this regard, the double junction CZTS/CIGS solar cell with two ZnTe and CdS anti-reflector layers is simulated with ATLAS simulator of Silvaco software. AM1.5 spectrum is used to radiate to the double junction solar cell model. The amount of total reflections of the multi-junction solar cell of the whole energy of AM1.5 solar spectrum is called total reflection as shown in Fig. 1 for the proposed double junction CZTS/CIGS solar cell with two ZnTe and CdS anti-reflector layers. The proposed structure of the double junction CZTS/CIGS solar cell is illustrated in Fig. 2 . It contains following layers from top to bottom: a ZnTe layer with 0.2509μm thickness as an anti-reflector layer, a CdS layer with 0.1491μm thickness as another anti-reflector layer, a p-CZTS layer with 0.15μm thickness as an absorber layer (p=1×1020 cm−3), a n-CZTS layer with 0.5μm thickness as a buffer layer (n=6×1021 cm−3), a vacuum layer with 0.15μm thickness as a tunnel junction, a p-CIGS layer with 0.1μm thickness as an absorber layer (p=2×1020 cm−3), a n-CIGS layer with 4.69μm thickness as a buffer layer (n=1×1014 cm−3). Photovoltaic parameters of the components of the proposed solar cell structure are presented in Table 1 . The mesh structure of the double junction CZTS/CIGS solar cell with two ZnTe and CdS anti-reflector layers simulated with ATLAS simulator of silvaco software is shown in Fig. 3 . Optimizing the efficiency of the double junction CZTS/CIGS solar cell with two CdS and ZnTe anti-reflector layers is carried out in several steps. First; the advantage of applying CIGS in the structure of solar cells is due to the variation of the band gap energy from 1.07ev to 1.69ev, which gives the opportunity to consider adequate band gap energy for each specific application. As shown in Fig. 4 , changing CIGS band gap energy from 1.07 ev to 1.69 ev, efficiency of the solar cell changes, and the most amount of efficiency, which is 45.37 %, is achieved in 1.69 ev band gap energy. At second step of the efficiency optimization, we follow current matching of the sub-cells in the proposed structure. By establishing current matching, the short-circuit current of the top and bottom cells will become equal, and the maximum efficiency occurs. The curves related to the changes of the top and bottom cells short circuit currents based on the changes of CdS and ZnTe thicknesses are shown in Figs. 5 and 6 , respectively. As shown in Figs. 5 and 6, the curves of the top and bottom cells short-circuit currents cross each other respectively at the point in which CdS thickness is 0.149μm and ZnTe thickness is 0.251μm that corresponds to the short-circuit current of 3.074×10−8 A, and therefore, the current matching is established. 3 Discussions and results In this part, we express a series of applicable parameters such as maximum power, fill factor and efficiency of solar cell, and the results obtained from the simulation of the proposed DJ solar cell. When a semiconductor is exposed to a source of light, its conductivity enhances by production of electron-hole pairs. This event is called photoconductive effect. One of the main parameters in solar cells is photo-generation rate. Photo-generation rate of the proposed solar cell is illustrated in Fig. 7 . Also, doping of semiconductors enhances its conductivity. The amount of net doping in every one of the constituent layers of the solar cell is presented in Fig. 8 . Density of acceptor impurity ions is obtained as follows: (1) N A − = N A 1 + g e ε A − E F K B T where, N A (cm−3) is acceptor concentration, ε A is acceptor level energy, g is ground state degeneracy equal to 4, E F is Fermi level energy, T is Kelvin temperature, and KB is Boltzmann constant equal to 1.38×10−23 J/K. Also, density of donor impurity ions is obtained as follows: (2) N D + = n 0 + N A − − p 0 Where, p 0 and n 0 are density of holes and electrons in intrinsic semiconductors, respectively. Created electron-hole pairs in a semiconductor cause electric potential energy which in turn cause an electric field in each layer. The potential and electric field of each layer of the proposed DJ CZTS/CIGS solar cell is illustrated in Figs. 9 and 10 , respectively. If an electron loss its energy, it returns to the valence band. Combining with one hole in the valence band leads to recombination process to take place. Each recombination process leads to reduction of one hole. Recombination process in each material depends on its lifespan. Therefore, recombination rate is different in materials with various lifespan. Fig. 11 illustrates the recombination rate of different layers of the proposed solar cell. Each solar cell has a specific current-voltage curve which starts at zero voltage, where the current is Isc (the short-circuit current of the cell), and ends at Voc voltage (the open-circuit voltage of the cell), where the current is zero. As shown in Fig. 12 , the short-circuit current of the top, bottom and total cells are equal, and it shows the current matching in the two sub-cells and the high quality of the solar cell. One of the main parameters of solar cell is maximum power of solar cell(P max ) which is achieved V max somewhere between V=0 and V=V oc called ThevoltageVmax is an optimum point, and corresponding current of Vmax is called Imax. ThePmax is obtained as follows: (3) P m a x = V m a x × I m a x Another parameter of a solar cell is the fill factor (FF) that determines the quality factor of a solar cell. It is considered as a significant factor in comparing the efficiency of solar cells. The fill factor is obtained as follows: (4) F F = I m a x × V m a x I s c × V o c However, efficiency is the most important parameter of a solar cell and is obtained as follows: (5) η % = V o c × I s c × F F × 100 P i n Where, P in is the power of AM1.5 solar spectrum which is1000w . m −2. Following relation is used to change its unit to watt: (6) P i n = A × 1000 Where A is the area of the surface of solar cell. The comparison of performance of the proposed solar cell structure with others solar cells is summarized in Table 2 . As shown in Table 2, the proposed DJ CZTS/CIGS solar cell has the highest fill factor (86.37 %) and the highest conversion efficiency (45.37 %) among the previous suggested solar cells, which shows the proposed solar cell has better energy conversion efficiency. Also, the proposed DJ CZTS/CIGS solar cell has the highest amount of Isc and Voc among the referred solar cells. 4 Conclusion A novel double junction CZTS/CIGS solar cell with two ZnTe and CdS anti-reflector layers, is simulated using ATLAS simulator silvaco software. The effect of CIGS band gap changes on the efficiency, resulted in obtaining a maximum efficiency of 45.37% at Eg =1.69ev. The effect of changing the thickness of ZnTe and CdS anti-reflectors layers for obtaining current matching resulted in an optimum CdS thickness of 0.149μm and the ZnTe thickness of 0.251μm, where the short-circuit current was equal in both top and bottom cell; and the current matching occurred with obtained short-circuit current of Isc =3.074×10−8 A. The proposed solar cell’s fill factor is excellent with the amount of 86.37 %. Finally, the proposed solar cell with such characteristics has better energy conversions performance compared with other works reported so far.

column2: Deriving the geocentric vector and the solar vector from the atmospheric polarization pattern on LEO satellites
column3: Abstract Using the polarimetric imaging sensor on LEO (Low-Earth Orbit) satellites to photograph the atmospheric polarization pattern derived from the polarized light backscattered by the atmospheric particles is proposed in this paper. First, the formation of polarization pattern and its measurement principle are introduced based on Rayleigh scattering, and the extraatmospheric polarization pattern is analyzed. Afterwards, it is presented that how to attain the geocentric vector and the solar vector simultaneously from the polarization pattern through the least squares method, which is verified by simulation subsequently. The simulation results show that it is feasible to derive the two vectors from the captured image.
column5: Keywords Solar vector Geocentric vector Polarimetric sensor Polarization pattern Rayleigh scattering Least squares 1 Introduction The atmospheric polarization pattern formed after the sunlight is scattered by atmospheric molecules and aerosols, is exploited by many wild animals and insects to derive compass information. Bees can sense the polarization pattern through their compound eyes. After finding the honey source, they need an azimuth reference determined by E-vector of the polarization pattern to give its direction by means of dancing [1–5]. Many migratory songbirds, such as Savannah sparrows, also have the capability to use polarized light cues, especially the region of sky near the horizon, to recalibrate the compass in the course of migration every year [6]. Monarch butterflies in North America sense the polarization pattern of ultraviolet band and regard E-vector as the reference direction to aid navigation when they migrate to Mexico [7,8]. Desert ants could utilize the polarization pattern as a compass to return to their nest on the shortest path possible after performing a large-scale foraging excursion [9–11]. Certainly, other animals such as spider and shrimp, can also use the polarization pattern for orientation [12,13]. Imitating polarization navigation of insects, kinds of bio-polarization sensors are designed to measure the polarization pattern, and various methods are proposed to obtain compass information from the polarization pattern. Kane Usher puts forward that the scanning method with a digital camera is used to measure polarization pattern. Meanwhile, the image information attained is analyzed preliminarily to obtain the degree of polarization and polarization angle [14]. CMOS image sensor is designed, which outputs light intensity information of different polarized directions to achieve the degree of polarization and polarization angle [15–19]. Daobin Wang designs a real-time bionic camera-based polarization navigation sensor to measure polarization pattern through three images of different polarized directions (0°, 45° and 90°), the accuracy of which can obtain 0.3° [20]. Jinkui Chu has implemented a metal grid polarization sensor, whose accuracy is superior to 0.1° [21–23]. Zhiwen Xian designs a bio-inspired polarization navigation sensor and gives a new method of calculating polarization angle [24,25]. Based on these sensors, different calibration methods of polarization sensors are proposed including the variable substation and curve fitting, the multi-objective optimization and Non-Dominated Sorting Genetic Algorithm, and the least squares [26–28]. In addition, some researchers are also trying to apply the new information derived from the polarization pattern to positioning and attitude determination [29–31]. Although more and more people are studying bio-polarization navigation, they primarily focus attention on polarimetric studies in the atmosphere while the extraatmospheric polarimetric characteristics research is still situated in the exploratory phase. In contrast to the endo-atmosphere polarization pattern formed due to the polarized light forescattered by the atmospheric particles and aerosols, the polarization pattern outside the atmosphere is derived from the polarized light backscattered by these particles. The backscatter polarization pattern photographed outside the atmosphere contains the azimuth information of the earth and the sun. Thus, it is put forward in this paper that the geocentric vector and the sun vector could be extracted from polarization pattern, which can provide relevant measurement information for the LEO satellite’s orbit determination and attitude determination. Jun Zhou has studied the extraatmospheric polarimetric characteristics initially, and presented the idea of applying the new navigation information derived from the polarization pattern to satellite navigation [32,33]. To demonstrate the feasibility of obtaining the geocentric vector and solar vector based on the polarization pattern, this paper is organized as follows. In Section 2, we give a brief overview of the polarization pattern and principles of the polarimetric imaging sensor. In Section 3, the least square method of obtaining the geocentric vector and the solar vector is put forward. In Section 4, the simulation is carried out to demonstrate the feasibility of obtaining the geocentric vector and the solar vector simultaneously by means of least squares and the results are analyzed. Some conclusions are drawn in Section 5. 2 Polarization pattern description and its measurement 2.1 Measurement of polarization pattern Rayleigh scattering occurs when the atmospheric molecule is much smaller than the wavelength of the incident light, which results in the polarization pattern. Fig. 1 shows the 3D polarization pattern formed based on the single scattering Rayleigh model. O is the observation position. O S ⇀ , O Z ⇀ and O P ⇀ represent the solar direction, the zenithal direction and the observing direction respectively. The width of the dashed line indicates the degree of polarization (DOP) while its tangent direction indicates the E-vector orientation observed from the center of hemisphere. Then, the DOP of O P ⇀ is (1) D O P ( γ ) = 1 − cos 2 γ 1 + cos 2 γ × D O P max where γ is the angle between the solar direction and the observing direction. DOP max is the maximum value of DOP, which is smaller than 1.0 generally due to the interference of many kinds of factors like the weather. The polarization characteristic of light is generally expressed by the Stokes vector S = ( I , Q , U , V ) , in which I represents the total light intensity, Q represents the linearly polarized light intensity of 0° direction, U represents the linearly polarized light intensity of 45° direction, and V represents the circularly polarized light intensity. V is negligible, generally speaking. Then, the DOP can be calculated according to I, Q and U. (2) D O P = Q 2 + U 2 I The residual three Stokes parameters can be measured by the polarimetric imaging sensor, the schematic representation of which is shown in Fig. 2 . O ′ f X s Y s Z s is the pixel reference frame. The center O ′ f of the imaging focal plane is taken as the origin, O ′ f X s and O ′ f Y s are established in the focal plane parallel with the row and column of the pixels of the CCD sensor respectively, and O ′ f Z s is the optical axis. F is the center of the convex lens. The three linear polarizers are installed at 0°, 60° and 120° with the respect to the reference direction of the sensor. Then, the sensor can attain three pictures by means of collecting the light intensity from three different polarizing directions. Consequently, according to the three images collected, the computer will calculate the three Stokes parameters (I, Q and U) of each pixel P i , j ( x i , y j ) . Finally, we could obtain the DOP of each corresponding observing directions through Eq. (2). Assume that the angle between the linear polarizer and the reference direction of the sensor is α. Then, the polarized light intensity of α direction is the function of I, Q and U, which can be expressed as follows: (3) I ′ ( α ) = 1 2 ( I + Q cos 2 α + U sin 2 α ) where I ′ ( α ) is the measured polarized light intensity of the α direction. Then, the three unknown variables I, Q and U in Eq. (3) can be solved according to the measured light intensity of the chosen three directions (namely α=0°, 60° and 120°). (4) I = 2 3 ( I ′ ( 0 ° ) + I ′ ( 60 ° ) + I ′ ( 120 ° ) ) Q = 2 3 ( 2 I ′ ( 0 ° ) − I ′ ( 60 ° ) − I ′ ( 120 ° ) ) U = 2 3 ( I ′ ( 0 ° ) − I ′ ( 120 ° ) ) According to Eqs. (2) and (4), we can calculate the DOP of each pixel of the image. 2.2 Extraatmospheric polarization pattern According to Rayleigh scattering, it can be known that the distribution of the forescattered light is symmetrical to that of the backscattered light when the incident light is natural light. As shown in Fig. 3 , the angle between the forescattered light and the incident light is less than 90° while the angle between the backscattered light and the incident light is greater than 90°. Therefore, the polarization pattern in the atmosphere is formed mainly due to the forescattered polarized light while the polarization pattern out of atmosphere is derived from the backscattered polarized light primarily. As shown in Fig. 4 , the green thin dashed circle indicates the atmospheric boundary, and it is divided into four regions by the red thick dashed line, namely I, II, III and IV. II and III indicate the atmosphere illuminated by the sun, called the atmospheric illumination region while I and IV represent the atmospheric shadow region; II and I represents the atmospheric region visible from the satellite while III and IV indicates the invisible atmospheric region. Then, it can be attained that II is the observable area of the polarization pattern from the satellite. The observable region of the polarimetric imaging sensor on the satellite can be described mathematically as follows: Assume that the geocentric vector is r , and the solar unit vector is s . r e is the position vector of any point on the boundary of the atmosphere. Then, two conditions must be satisfied to make r e point to the observable region II. (5) { arccos ( − ( r e − r ) ⋅ r ∥ r e − r ∥ r ) ≤ arcsin ( r e r ) arccos ( r e ⋅ s r e ) ≤ π 2 All the points meeting the two conditions above compose the observable region of the extraatmospheric polarization pattern. The polarimetric imaging sensor can be used on LEO satellites to photograph the observable region of the atmosphere. Suppose that the optical axis O ′ f Z s points to the center of the earth and the solar vector is in the plane O ′ f X s Z s . α is the angle between the solar vector and the optical vector. Suppose that the orbit altitude of the satellite is 400km. Then, the DOP image of the observable atmospheric pattern changing with α is shown in Fig. 5 . The value of DOP is expressed in different colors. 3 Obtaining the geocentric vector and solar vector Through the polarimetric imaging sensor on the Low-Earth Orbit satellite, we can not only get the earth contour image, but also get the DOP image. In this section, we present the method of using least squares to deal with the earth contour image and the DOP image of the observable atmospheric pattern to derive the geocentric vector and the solar vector simultaneously. 3.1 Calculating the geocentric vector As shown in Fig. 6 , O ′ f X s Y s Z s is the pixel reference frame; the blue sphere indicates the earth and the point O e represents the center of the earth; The green dotted circle indicates the atmospheric boundary; F is the lens center, and O ′ f F ⇀ represents the focal vector, denoted by f ; O ′ e indicates the position of the geocenter on the imaging focal plane, and O ′ e O e ⇀ is the geocentric vector, denoted by r . Assuming that the angle between r and f is θ. The green ellipse represents the earth contour image in the focal plane. In Fig. 6, P k is a pixel of the earth edge, the coordinates of which are ( x k , y k ) ( k = 1,2 , ⋯ , n ) . β is the angle between F P k ⇀ and F O ′ e ⇀ . The modulus of O ′ f F ⇀ is the focal length, denoted by f. Obviously, P k ( x k , y k ) is always in the cone surface, the central axis of which is F O ′ e ⇀ with the half cone angle β. The coordinates of F and P k are noted as ( 0,0 , f ) and ( x k , y k , 0 ) respectively. Assume that the coordinates of O ′ e are ( x , y , 0 ) , then F P k ⇀ = ( x k , y k , − f ) F O ′ e ⇀ = ( x , y , − f ) Select n pixels from the earth contour image at equal intervals, then we can get that (6) x 1 x + y 1 y + f 2 x 1 2 + y 1 2 + f 2 = x 2 x + y 2 y + f 2 x 2 2 + y 2 2 + f 2 = ⋯ = x n x + y n y + f 2 x n 2 + y n 2 + f 2 = c 1 Where c 1 is a constant. Eq. (6) can be simplified to the following matrix equation, (7) [ x 1 y 1 − x 1 2 + y 1 2 + f 2 x 2 y 2 − x 2 2 + y 2 2 + f 2 ⋯ x n y n − x n 2 + y n 2 + f 2 ] [ x y c 1 ] = [ − f 2 − f 2 ⋯ − f 2 ] ⇒ A x = b The least square solution of which is, x = ( A T A ) − 1 A T b Therefore, it can be attained that the coordinates of the geocentric unit vector in O ′ f X s Y s Z s are ( x , y , f ) x 2 + y 2 + f 2 . 3.2 Calculating the solar vector In this section, we propose the method of using least squares to deal with the DOP image to obtain the solar unit vector. As shown in Fig. 7 , O ′ f X s Y s Z s is the pixel reference frame. γ i and γ j represent the angles between the solar vector and the observing directions. P i ( x i , y i ) and P j ( x j , y j ) denote the coordinates of any two pixels of the DOP image. P i O f ⇀ and P j O f ⇀ represent the corresponding observing directions, the DOPs of which are D O P ( P i ) and D O P ( P j ) respectively. According to Eq. (1), if D O P ( P i ) = D O P ( P j ) , we can obtain that (8) γ i = γ j Choose n pixels from the DOP image, the coordinates of which are P i ( x i , y i ) ( i = 1,2 , ⋯ , n ) . Their DOPs are D O P ( P i ) , all of which satisfy ( d 0 − ε ) < D O P ( P i ) < ( d 0 + ε ) . ε is a small quantity. d 0 is a constant chosen, and satisfies 0< d 0 <1. According to Eq. (1), it can be obtained that, (9) γ 1 = γ 2 =⋯= γ n As P i F ⇀ = ( − x i , − y i , f ) and S ′ F ⇀ = ( − x , − y , f ) , then (10) x 1 x + y 1 y + f 2 x 1 2 + y 1 2 + f 2 = x 2 x + y 2 y + f 2 x 2 2 + y 2 2 + f 2 = ⋯ = x n x + y n y + f 2 x n 2 + y n 2 + f 2 = c 2 Where c 2 is a constant. Eq. (10) can be simplified to the following matrix equation, (11) [ x 1 y 1 − x 1 2 + y 1 2 + f 2 x 2 y 2 − x 2 2 + y 2 2 + f 2 ⋯ x n y n − x n 2 + y n 2 + f 2 ] [ x y c 2 ] = [ − f 2 − f 2 ⋯ − f 2 ] ⇒ A x = b The least square solution of which is, (12) x = ( A T A ) − 1 A T b Therefore, the coordinates of solar unit vector in O ′ f X s Y s Z s are s = ( − x , − y , f ) x 2 + y 2 + f 2 . This method can also be applied to calculating the solar vector for the polarization pattern in the atmosphere. 4 Simulation and analysis Assume that the earth is photographed with a polarimetric imaging sensor at an orbital altitude of 400km. Let f =1. Then, two cases are simulated as the following. Case 1: As shown in Fig. 8 , suppose that the optical axis points to the geocenter and the angle between the solar vector and the geocentric vector is 180°. In this case, the coordinates of the geocentric unit vector in O ′ f X s Y s Z s are R = ( 0 0 1 ) T , while the coordinates of the solar unit vector are s = ( 0 0 − 1 ) T . The white Gaussian noise ( u = 0 , σ = 0.005 ) is added to the earth contour image and the DOP image. Let d 0 =0.5, ε =0.005. According to Eqs. (7) and (12), we can get the estimated coordinates of the geocentric vector in O ′ f X s Y s Z s are R ˆ = ( 0.000047 − 0.000011 1 ) T , and the estimated coordinates of the solar vector are s ˆ = ( 0.00038 0.00014 − 1 ) T . According to the simulation results, we can get the error angle δ e of the geocentric vector and the error angle δ s of the solar vector are (13) { δ e = arccos ( R ⋅ R ˆ | R | ⋅ | R ˆ | ) = 0.003 ∘ δ s = arccos ( s ⋅ s ˆ | s | ⋅ | s ˆ | ) = 0.023 ∘ Case 2: As shown in Fig. 9 , suppose that the coordinates of the geocentric vector and the solar vector in O ′ f X s Y s Z s are R = ( 0.06186 0.06186 1 ) T and s = ( − 1.7321 0 − 1 ) T respectively. The white Gaussian noise ( u = 0 , σ = 0.005 ) is added to the earth contour image and the DOP image. Let d 0 =0.5, ε =0.005. According to Eqs. (7) and (12), we can get the estimated coordinates of the geocentric vector in O ′ f X s Y s Z s are R ˆ = ( 0.06179 0.06183 1 ) T , and the estimated coordinates of the solar vector are s ˆ = ( − 1.7298 − 0.0003 − 1 ) T . According to the simulation results, we can get the error angle δ e of the geocentric vector and the error angle δ s of the solar vector are (14) { δ e = arccos ( R ⋅ R ˆ | R | ⋅ | R ˆ | ) = 0.004 ° δ s = arccos ( s ⋅ s ˆ | s | ⋅ | s ˆ | ) = 0.034 ° According to the simulation results and analysis, it can be concluded that the least square method of attaining the solar vector and the geocentric vector is feasible. 5 Conclusions The polarimetric imaging sensor is proposed to be applied to the Low-Earth Orbit satellite to photograph the atmospheric polarization pattern. Then, the least squares method is presented to derive the geocentric vector from the earth contour image and the solar vector from the DOP image, which is verified by simulation. The simulation results show that it is feasible to derive the geocentric vector and the solar vector simultaneously from the polarized image by least squares method. In the future work, we will study how to use the new navigation information on LEO satellites. Acknowledgement This work is supported by the National Natural Science Foundation of China under Grant Nos.61304238.
