column2: Temperature sensor and fiber laser based on optical microfiber knot resonator
column3: Abstract An easy method to fabricate microfiber-knot resonator (MKR) is designed and its application as a temperature sensor and multi-wavelength fiber laser (MWFL) is demonstrated. The MKR has a temperature sensitivity of 14.5pm/°C over a temperature range of 27–95°C, and experimental results show good linearity between the temperature and resonant wavelength shifts. As an MWFL on the other hand, up to four lasing lines with a channel spacing of 4.29nm are obtained. These results confirm that the MKR could be employed as a high performance comb filter to realize compact optical sensor and MWFL designs.
column5: Keywords Temperature sensor Microfiber-knot resonator Erbium-doped fiber laser 1 Introduction Microfiber resonators have recently gained increasing research interest for their potential applications in integrated photonic circuits designs to serve a multitude of applications ranging from wavelength conversion and modulation [1,2], tunable laser outputs [3,4] and to create optical time delays [5], as well as in sensing applications such as temperature [6–8] and magnetic fields [9]. As a result of its flexibility and wide range of applications, multiple microfiber resonators designs and configurations have been explored, including micro-ring resonators [10–12], Mach-Zehnder interferometers [13] and micro-knot resonators (MKRs) [14–26] among others. However, it is the MKR in particular that shows the highest potential for manipulation and configuration due to its firm structure, as well as being able to support single-mode transmissions and exhibiting stable light coupling, thus making it a highly preferred microfiber design. MKR based sensors excel in the measurement of temperature, as even a minor change in temperature will see a major shift of the output spectrum from the MKR. The MKR has been successfully operated as a temperature sensor, exhibiting a responsivity of 0.27nm/°C [27], while a microfiber loop resonator was shown to have a linear extinction ratio reduction against temperature at a rate of approximately 0.043dB/°C when embedded in low refractive index polymer [22]. Though higher temperature resolutions can be achieved using other fiber based sensor designs, such as a photonic crystal fiber with a sensitivity of 54.3nm/°C [28], the corresponding measurement windows are typically narrow, thus rendering these sensor designs only useful for measurements of short temperature ranges. Furthermore, the fabrication process of the afore-mentioned sensors are more-often than not highly complex, require intensive processes such as femtosecond laser micromachining [29] as compared to the MKR which can easily fabricated and therefore at a much lower cost. In this work, an MKR designed to operate as both a temperature sensor and fiber laser is proposed and demonstrated. The primary advantage of the proposed MKR is that it can be easily fabricated, thus allowing for significant cost-savings to be realized as well as allowing for a compact and rugged sensor and laser system to be developed. Furthermore, MKR based sensors also enjoys significant advantages over conventional temperature sensors through passive operation and electromagnetic immunity, thus giving it significant potential for real-world applications. 2 Background The MKR’s theory of operation is similar to that of a loop resonator in a single loop. In this manner, the microfiber in the loop is represented by the two arms, which represent the in-going and out-going signals as shown in Fig. 1 . L is the length of the microfiber in which the electromagnetic field propagates along, and can be described by the equation [30–33]: (1) F ( r ) = e xp [ ( i ∫ ∫ 0 1 β ( L ) d L ( r ) ] where β(L) represents the propagation constant and F(r) is the local transverse mode that corresponds to the propagation constant. The coupling region has a coefficient of k and represents the mode interaction loss between the coupled microfiber arms. Thus, k =0 indicates no cross-coupling interaction between the two arms while k =1 indicates complete cross-coupling between the modes propagating in the MKR’s two arms. The transmission amplitude of the MKR can be expressed as [10]: (2) T = e − α L / 2 e i β L − sin ( K ) 1 − sin ( K ) e − α L / 2 e i β L where sin(K) is represent the intensity of coupling ratio. K can be defined as K=kl, where k and l are the coupling coefficient and the length of the coupling region respectively. The factor e−αL/2 represents the round-trip attenuation, with α being the intensity attenuation. The spacing between two resonant wavelengths, otherwise known as the free spectral range (FSR) is defined as: (3) Δλ ≈ λ 2/neffπD where λ is the wavelength resonance, neff is the effective refractive index and D is the diameter of the MKR. 3 Fabrication of the MKR The MKR is fabricated from a commercially available single mode fiber (SMF) using the flame brushing technique. The details of the fabrication process used in this work has been described in detail in reference [34]. The SMF-28 fiber was fixed onto the linear stages of the fabrication rig, with the middle portion creating a ‘loop’. This allows the middle portion, which will be tapered, to be fully exposed to the flame, without any obstructions. The transmission through the MKR during the fabrication process was monitored using an amplified spontaneous emission (ASE) source and an optical spectrum analyzer (OSA). A microfiber with the diameter of 8μm was formed in this work, with a loss after tapering of about 2.5dB. The transmission spectra of the injected ASE signal before and after it passes through the MKR is given in Fig. 2 . Once tapered, the microfiber is carefully removed from the stages, and a ‘loop is formed by gently bending the microfiber so that the tapered part overlaps. The “loop” being held between the thumb and finger, and the fiber is gently pulled to reduce the loop’s diameter. Initially, this is done by hand, and once a diameter of about 8cm is obtained, the loop is then secured again between the stages so that the diameter of the loop can be further reduced. The entire fabrication process is completed in less than 15min, including tapering time. The advantage of this technique is that a high quality MKR can be produced through just minute movements of the stages and monitored by the transmission spectra, thus eliminating the need for complex setups and expensive equipment such as high-resolution microscopes. 4 MKR as a temperature sensor To demonstrate the temperature sensing capabilities of the fabricated MKR, a knot resonator with a diameter of 1.3mm is assembled using an 8-μm diameter silica microfiber. The optical image of the microfiber is shown in Fig. 3 , while the setup used to measure the temperature response of the MKR is given in Fig. 4 . The MKR insertion loss is 17.6dB, which is attributed to both absorption loss and also bending loss [35]. The MKR is placed on a hotplate with a range of 20–100°C, while an ASE light source is placed at the input of the fiber. An OSA is connected to the output end of the microfiber to check the change in the comb spectrum as a result of the shifting temperature. The initial temperature of the hotplate is set to 27°C and the temperature is increased gradually. Fig. 5 shows the transmission spectrum of the resonator. As can be seen from the figure, the resonant wavelength shifts towards the longer wavelength region as the temperature increases. Due to the detection range of the OSA, a temperature sensing range of between 27–95°C can be obtained. The peak values of resonant wavelength at different temperatures are plotted in Fig. 6 . It can be seen that the wavelength increases in an almost linear fashion as the temperature increases, giving a slope value of about 0.0145pm/°C, while the power of the transmitted spectrum has an inverse response, decreasing at a rate of −224pm/°C. The measured sensitivity of the MKR is approximately −224dB/°C, in terms of change of power against temperature, or 14.5pm/°C as a function of the variation of wavelength as the temperature increases. 5 MKR as a fiber laser The MKR is also characterized for its ability to generate a multi-wavelength output from a conventional fiber laser cavity. In this regard, the fabricated MKR is integrated into a conventional erbium doped fiber laser (EDFL) cavity, as shown in Fig. 7 . The proposed laser uses a 3-m-long erbium-doped fiber (EDF) as the linear gain medium, and is pumped by a 980nm laser diode (LD) through a 980-nm/1550nm wavelength division multiplexer (WDM), with the 980nm port of the WDM connected to the pump LD and the common port of the WDM connected to one end of the 3m long EDF. The other end of the EDF is connected to the fabricated MKR, which acts as a comb filter in the proposed laser cavity and subsequently to a polarization controller (PC), which is used to adjust the polarization state of circulating light. The output from the PC is now tapped by a 90:10 output coupler, in which approximately 10% of the propagating signal is tapped for further analysis. The remaining 90% of the signal is emitted through the coupler’s 90% port, which is connected to a polarization dependent isolator (PDI) to ensure unidirectional signal propagation in the cavity as well as induce spectral filtering in combination with the PC and intra-cavity birefringence. Finally, the output of the PDI is connected to the 1550nm port of the WDM, thus completing the cavity. A Yokogawa AQ6370C OSA is used to perform a spectral analysis of the obtained signal. The lasing threshold of the fiber laser is determined to be about 20mW. For this work, the maximum pump power is set to 250mW to prevent possible damage to the components of the cavity. Fig. 8 (a) shows a dual wavelength output obtained at lasing wavelengths of 1564.72 and 1569.01nm with the same peak power of 19.622dBm. The wavelength spacing between the lasing wavelengths is about 4.29nm. It is worthwhile to observe that the lasing peaks overlap with the peaks observed from the ASE comb. Furthermore, fine adjustments to the polarization of the propagating signal in the cavity allows three lasing wavelengths to be obtained at 1564.62, 1568.88 and 1573.08nm and with all three wavelengths having the speak powers of 19.51dBm and channel spacing of 4.26nm. This is shown in Fig. 8(b). In addition, further refinements of the PC enable the generation of quadruple wavelength laser at 1564.62, 1568.83, 1573.04 and 1577.25nm shown in Fig. 8(c), with equal peak powers of around 17.28dBm and channel spacing of 4.29nm between each lasing wavelength. The channel spacing between the dual-, triple- and quadruple-lasing wavelengths are a result of the FSR of the MKR. The lasing wavelengths can be generated over a range of 25nm and centered at 1565nm. To verify the stability of the proposed MKR based multiwavelength fiber laser at room temperature, the output is measured repeatedly at 2-min intervals for a period of 20min. These results are presented in Fig. 9 (a)–(c). Fig. 10 shows the of power fluctuation details on the left hand side (LHS) and wavelength shifting on the right hand side (RHS) for dual, triple and quad wavelength lasing. As can be seen, the maximum power fluctuation is less than 0.6dBm while the wavelength shift is less than 0.01nm. These minor fluctuations can be attributed to physical perturbations of the fiber, such as temperature changes or vibrations, as well as due to minor instability caused by the light travelling within the cladding instead of being confined solely within the core. This however can be easily overcome by more stringent control of the environment. Thus, the proposed fiber laser is capable of generating a highly stable output that will have multiple applications in telecommunications and sensing. 6 Conclusion A single MKR is successfully fabricated by the flame brushing technique in this paper. The MKR shows remarkable stability as a sensor and is capable of measuring a temperature range of 27–95°C. In addition, a stable multiwavelength EDFL is also demonstrated using the MKR as a compact comb filter. Up to four lasing lines with a channel spacingof 4.29nm is obtained, as a result of the MKR’s FSR. The multiwavelength fiber laser shows good stability at room temperature and demonstrates that the MKR could be employed as a high performance comb filter to realize a compact multiwavelength fiber laser. Acknowledgement Funding for this work was provided for by the University of Malaya under the grants RP 029B - 15 AFR, RU 001-2017 and BR 002-2016.

column2: Time domain transport equations of light in multilayered rectangular biological tissue with semi-infinite medium
column3: Abstract In the study of tissue optics, physical models with the boundary of finite size are rarely established. Based on the diffusion equation, under the rectangular boundary conditions, this paper adopts extrapolation boundary conditions to establish a frequency domain model of multilayer medium diffusion equation, according to Fourier transform of frequency domain, turns the frequency domain solution into time domain model. On the basis of the deduced equation, the corresponding calculation process is written and the time resolved diffuse reflectance is calculated. The established model is compared with Monte Carlo simulation of time domain and the traditional medium with semi-infinite thickness, the result shows that our theory is correct. Concurrently, the effects of different boundary conditions on the diffusion equation are compared, it shows that our equations can not only solve the finite boundary problems, when the boundary is infinite, it can replace multilayer medium diffusion model.
column5: Keywords Diffusion equation Monte Carlo simulation Tissue optics Time resolved diffuse reflectance 1 Introduction Diffusion equations are widely used in biomedical optics, which can retrieve the optical characteristics of tissues and can perform noninvasive detection of biological tissues. Therefore, the diffusion model is one of the most widely used models, the diffusion model of medium with semi-infinite thickness is widely applied therein, for example, Haskell [1] established the time domain and steady-state model of partial flow boundary conditions, zero boundary conditions and extrapolation boundary conditions. But these studies are single layer medium models, while many different parts of the human body show a layered structure, such as head or limbs, Monte Carlo model can solve multilayered media, but it costs time. Liemer et al. [2,3] established biological tissue model of double layered medium with semi-infinite thickness, gave the exact solutions to diffusion equation in steady-state, time domain and frequency domain. We established multilayered medium model and the exact solutions to the steady-state, time domain and frequency domain [4,5]. Martelli et al. [6–9] presented the characteristic function method and perturbation model to solve two-layer and three-layer problems. Based on our studies, Liemer et al. [10,11] gave the exact solutions to the steady state, time domain and frequency domain of multilayer flat model of biological tissues, their solutions are very close to ours, the difference is that we give the model of multilayered medium with semi-infinite thickness, Liemer et al. give multilayer flat medium model. On this basis, someone [12] gives a mixed medium model, which uses a parameter of P3 approximation instead of the diffusion coefficient. These models only solved issues on multilayer medium infinite in horizontal (X or Y) coordinate. In fact, the medium is finite on horizontal coordinate, so Liemer et al. [13,14] established a diffusion equation of cylindrical medium, while we need to build a cube diffuse model. First, the cube structure is often used in experiments, and corresponding solutions are needed. Second, for in vivo experiments, cube geometry can be used to describe most parts of the human body, such as arms, legs, or fingers. Of course, these examples are not completely described by the cube, but surely, the cube geometry assumption is more accurate than the mainstream semi-infinite geometry. To this end, a rectangular tissue frequency domain transmission equation of medium with semi-infinite thickness is formed. Fourier transform of different frequency domain converts into time domain, in order to check correctness of the equation, it is verified by Monte Carlo simulation and compared with the traditional models, and the result shows that our theory is correct. 2 Theory In the following, we establish and give the frequency domain transmission equations of light in multilayered biological tissue. Let a beam of light vertically irradiate rectangular biological medium, its circular frequency isω, as shown in Fig. 1 . The rectangular biological tissue is 2a long, 2b wide, the medium has n-layers and the thickness of the last layer (Layer n) is infinite, rectangular coordinate system is used. When the beam is irradiating vertically, the light scatters in the tissue at a depth of z=z0 (=1/(μ′s1 +μa1)). Here, μ′si is reduced scattering coefficient of Layer i, μai is absorption coefficient of Layer i, μ’si =μsi(1-gi), μsi is scattering coefficient of Layer i, g is isotropic factor, Axis Z is direction of incident light wherein, Li is thickness of each layer, Di =1/3(μ′si +μai) is diffusion coefficient. The incident point of light source isδ(x − x 0)δ(y − y 0)δ(z − z 0), assume it is matching medium, so the multilayer diffusion equation can be changed to (1) D 1 Δ Φ 1 ( r ) − ( μ a 1 + j ω c ) Φ 1 ( r ) = − δ ( x − x 0 ) δ ( y − y 0 ) δ ( z − z 0 ) , 0 ≤ z < L 1 (2) D i . Δ Φ i ( r ) − ( μ a i + j ω c ) Φ i ( r ) = 0 , L i − 1 ≤ z < L i 2 ≤ i ≤ n We use the extrapolation boundary conditions, that is, at the side, the boundary of the square, the boundary conditions are (3) Φ ( a + z b i , y , z , ω ) = 0 , Φ ( − a − z b , y , z , ω ) = 0 Φ ( x , − b − z b , z , ω ) = 0 , Φ ( x , − b − z b , z , ω ) = 0 At the junction of the upper surface and the medium boundary, it satisfies the equations (4) Φ i ( x , y , − z b 1 , ω ) = 0 (5) Φ i ( x , y , L i , ω ) Φ i + 1 ( x , y , L i , ω ) = 1 i = 1 , 2 , … .. , n − 1 (6) D i ∂ Φ i ( x , y , L i , ω ) ∂ z | L i = D i + 1 ∂ Φ i + 1 ( x , y , L i , ω ) ∂ z | z = L i i = 1 , 2 , … .. , n − 1 (7) Φ n ( x , y , ∞ b , ω ) = 0 Here, zbi can be calculated according to literatures. After detailed derivation, we can derive the diffuse model of N-layered tissue as (8) Φ i ( ω , x , y , z ) = ∑ n = 0 ∞ ∑ m = 0 ∞ f i ( x ) f i ( y ) f ( z , ω ) W h e r e f i ( x ) = 2 a cos ( n + 0 0.5 ) π b + z b i ) 2 ] + μ a i + j ω c ) / D i We can get fi(z,ω) of Layer i (10) f 1 ( z ) = sinh a 1 ( z b + z 0 ) D 1 a 1 × D 1 a 1 l 1 cosh a 1 ( L 1 − z ) + D 2 a 2 m 1 sinh a 1 ( L 1 − z ) D 1 a 1 l 1 cosh a 1 ( L 1 + z b ) + D 2 a 2 m 1 sinh a 1 ( L 1 + z b ) − sinh [ a 1 ( z 0 − z ) D 1 a 1 0 ≤ z < z 0 (11) f 1 ( z ) = = sinh a 1 ( z b + z 0 ) D 1 a 1 × D 1 a 1 l 1 cosh a 1 ( L 1 − z ) + D 2 a 2 m 1 sinh a 1 ( L 1 − z ) D 1 a 1 l 1 cosh a 1 ( L 1 + z b ) + D 2 a 2 m 1 sinh a 1 ( L 1 + z b ) z 0 ≤ z < L 1 f i + 1 ( z ) = sinh a 1 ( z b + z 0 ) D 1 a 1 ∐ ( D i a i l i ) ∐ ( h i ) × [ D i + 1 a i + 1 l i + 1 cosh ( a i + 1 ( L i + 1 − z ) ) + D i + 2 a i + 2 m i + 1 sinh ( a i + 1 ( L i + 1 − z ) ) ] D i + 1 a i + 1 l i + 1 cosh a i + 1 ( L i + 1 − L i ) + D i + 2 a i + 2 m i + 1 ( sinh a i + 1 ( L i + 1 − L i ) (12) 2≤i +1≤n-1 (13) f n ( z ) = cos ( sinh a 1 ( z b + z 0 ) D 1 a 1 × ∐ ( D n − 1 a n − 1 l n − 1 ) ∐ ( h n − 1 ) × exp ( a 3 ( L n − 1 − z ) (14) Where mn–1 = 1, ln–1 = 1 (15) m n − 2 = D n a n cosh a n − 1 ( L n − 1 − L n − 2 ) + D n − 1 a n − 1 sinh a n − 1 ( L n − 1 − L n − 2 ) (16) l n − 2 = D n a n sinh a n − 1 ( L n − 1 − L n − 2 ) + D n − 1 a n − 1 cosh a n − 1 ( L n − 1 − L n − 2 ) (17) m i = D i + 1 a i + 1 l i + 1 sinh a i + 1 ( L i + 1 − L i ) + D i + 2 a i + 2 m i + 1 cosh a i + 1 ( L i + 1 − L i ) (18) l i = D i + 1 a i + 1 l i + 1 cosh a i + 1 ( L i + 1 − L i ) + D i + 2 a i + 2 m i + 1 sinh a i + 1 ( L i + 1 − L i ) ] (19) ∐ ( D i a i l i ) = ( D 1 a 1 l 1 ) × ( D 2 a 2 l 2 ) × ( ⋯ ) × D i a i l i (20) h 1 = D 1 a 1 l 1 cosh a 1 ( L 1 + z b ) + D 2 a 2 m 1 sinh a 1 ( L 1 + z b ) (21) h i = D i a i l i cosh a i ( L i − L i − 1 ) + D i + 1 a i + 1 m i ( sinh a i ( L i − L i − 1 ) (22) ∐ h i = h 1 × h 2 × ( ⋯ ) × h i Thus, the frequency domain diffusion equation of rectangular biological tissue with semi-infinite thickness is established and its exact solutions are given. 3 Time domain studies are compared with Monte Carlo simulation and related models The diffusion equation is converted into reflectance to verify the correctness of the equation. The method [1] of Haskell is adopted, that is, Formula (23) (23) R ( x , y ) = C 1 Φ ( x , y , z = 0 ) + C 2 D ∂ Φ ( x , y , z = 0 ) ∂ z Here, if refractive index of the biological tissue is 1.4, C1 =0.118,C2 =0.306 3.1 Comparison with Monte Carlo simulation Calculate the diffuse reflectance of various frequencies and carry out Fourier transform, that is, the method and the frequency of Kienle [5] are adopted. At the same time, Monte Carlo simulation [15] is used for verification. In order to verify correctness of the model, we verified the diffusion equations of two-layer, three-layer, four-layer and five-layer media separately, each location selected is y=0mm, x=10.5mm. Assume rectangular boundary of a=45mm and b=45mm. From Figs. 2–5 , the solid line is calculation result of the model, and the dotted line is the result of Monte Carlo simulation. Fig. 2 is a comparison between two-layer medium diffusion equation and Monte Carlo simulation, the parameters of two-layer medium areL 1 =2mm, μ ′ s 1 = 1.3 m m − 1 , μ ′ s 2 = 0.5 m m − 1 , μ a1 =0.02mm −1,μ a2 =0.01mm −1. Fig. 3 is a comparison between three-layer medium diffusion equation and Monte Carlo simulation, the parameters of three-layer medium areL 2 =2mm,L 1 =2mm, μ ′ s 1 = 1.3 m m − 1 , μ ′ s 2 = 0.7 m m − 1 , μ ′ s 3 = 0.5 m m − 1 ,μ a1 =0.02mm −1, μ a2 =0.01mm −1,μ a3 =0.01mm −1. Fig. 4 is a comparison between four-layer medium diffusion equation and Monte Carlo simulation, the parameters of four-layer medium areL 1 =2mm,L 2 =2mm,L 3 =2mm, μ ′ s 1 = 1.3 m m − 1 , μ ′ s 2 = 1.0 m m − 1 , μ ′ s 3 = 0.7 m m − 1 , μ ′ s 4 = 0.5 m m − 1 , μ a1 =0.02mm −1, μ a2 =0.01mm −1,μ a3 =0.01mm −1,μ a4 =0.01mm −1. Fig. 5 is a comparison between five-layer medium diffusion equation and Monte Carlo simulation, the parameters of five-layer medium are, L 1 =2mm,L 2 =2mm,L 3 =2mm,L 4 =2mm, μ ′ s 1 = 0.7 m m − 1 , μ ′ s 2 = 1.0 m m − 1 , μ ′ s 3 = 1.3 m m − 1 , μ ′ s 4 = 0.7 m m − 1 , μ ′ s 5 = 0.5 m m − 1 ,The absorption coefficient of each layer μ ai =0.01mm −1. From Fig. 2–5, there are four graphs, we can see that our diffuse model is matched with Monte Carlo simulation completely, which proves that our diffuse model is correct. 3.2 Comparison with model of multilayer medium with semi-infinite thickness We have published a model of multilayer medium with semi-infinite thickness [4,5]. In the model of medium with semi-infinite thickness, assume the medium is infinitely long in X direction and Y direction, and cylindrical coordinates are used. We calculate rectangular medium model at y=0 and x=10.5mm, compare it with the model of medium with semi-infinite thickness when ρ=10.5, assume the rectangular medium boundary of a=60mm, b=60mm, when measuring time resolved diffuse reflectance at y=0, x=10.5mm, the boundary can be deemed infinite. We calculate time-resolved diffuse reflectance of the two models; the parameters of Fig. 5 are selected. At the same time, we calculate the relative error. In Fig. 6 , the solid line is the rectangular medium model, the dashed line is the model of medium with semi-infinite thickness, we can see the two graphs are coincident, hardly see the difference. Among relative errors in Fig. 7 , except for the first 3 points, other relative errors are less than 0.1%, indicating the model of multilayered medium with semi-infinite thickness can be replaced by our rectangular medium model. In addition, we calculate the effects of different boundaries on time domain diffusion equation, the parameters of Fig. 5 are utilized. We employ rectangular boundaries of a=b=30mm, a=b=20mm, a=b=15mm, and a=b=13mm respectively, calculate time resolved diffuse reflectance at y=0, x=10.5mm, the result is shown in Fig. 8 , which proves that different boundaries heavily affect time resolved diffuse reflectance in the same position. It also indicates that our equation can not only replace the equation of medium with semi-infinite thickness, but also solve the problems which the equation of medium with semi-infinite thickness can not solve. 4 Conclusions Under extrapolation boundary conditions, we establish a frequency domain model of multilayer medium diffusion equation of rectangular boundary conditions. With Fourier transform of various frequency domains, it is converted to time domain and verified by Monte Carlo simulation, the method is proved to be correct. A.Liemer et al. proposed a diffusion equation of cylindrical tissues, but the form of the solutions is more complex, while our equation is simpler in form than those of Liemer et al. and the application range will be more extensive. Compared with the model of medium with semi-infinite thickness, it shows that the model of medium with semi-infinite thickness can be replaced by the rectangular medium model, so the rectangular media model is more comprehensive. In some diffusion equation models, one layer medium models or multilayered medium models are infinite in both X and Y directions, up to now, no diffusion model of rectangular boundary conditions has been established. Our model can solve the problems which the equation of medium with semi-infinite thickness can not solve. column2: Field intensity of a perfect electromagnetic conductor circular reflector coated with a plasma layer under oblique incidence
column3: Abstract A theoretical analysis to study the effects of plasma layer on the field intensity distribution of electromagnetic wave in the focal region of perfect electromagnetic conductor (PEMC) circular reflector under oblique incidence is carried out. The reflection and transmission coefficients at dielectric-plasma and plasma-PEMC boundaries are solved systematically using electromagnetic boundary conditions. Maslov’s method have been used to obtain in focal region of plasma coated PEMC circular reflector. The numerical computations has been applied using MATHEMATICA to solve the analytical integral. The effects of angle of incidence, effective collision frequency, the plasma frequency and the width of plasma coating layer on the fields in image space or focal region have been studied. The obtained computed results are compare with the already published literature under special conditions which confirm the correctness of presented data.
column5: Keywords PEMC Image field Plasma layer Circular reflector 1 Introduction Research based on electromagnetic waves propagation in ionized gases such as plasma material has received much attention in the recent years. Many researchers studied the plasma materials for applications in optical devices such as absorbers, waveguides and mirrors [1,2]. Hereafter, use of plasma for advanced technologies in optical device applications, millimeter-wave, and microwave, is imperious [3–9]. Furthermore, abundant of research has been carried out in the previous five decades relevant to transmission and reflection of from plasma based antenna and their uses by many scientist [10,11]. This visible investigations explored many features of reflector or transmitter for example intensity, polarization, power, and apparent inaccuracies in demand to improve the efficiency of these devices for high frequencies spectrum and applications [12,13]. In last years the knowledge of focusing of electromagnetic waves in the focal region by plasma coated antenna as reflector or absorbers is vital in the current arena of advanced technologies for communication applications. The study of image space is useful for optical devices, medical investigations and treatment [14–16]. This field can be also useful to produce pictures of the internal body with the help of high frequency. When space vehicles with high speed along with metallic antennas enter from space into the Earth’s atmosphere encounter plasma influence. Thus, space vehicles’ antennas are covered with plasma layer that upsets the electromagnetic properties of such antennas [10,17]. In the same way, the presence of a plasma layer on targets can affects the transmitted and reflected power energies. The research is very important to obtain the factors of plasma, which mainly affect the reflected, absorbed, and transmitted power energy of the electromagnetic wave for contact with curvy metallic interfaces. It is theoretically proved that the perfect electromagnetic conductor PEMC material behaves as reflector of electromagnetic energy but it is different from the perfect electric conductor PEC and the perfect magnetic conductor PMC having additional reflected cross polarized components [18]. The perfect electromagnetic conductor (PEMC) is a general arrangement of both the perfect electric conductor (PEC) and the perfect magnetic conductor (PMC). Many researchers carried out research on PEMC materials [19–21]. The geometrical optics (GO) is a famous procedure used to obtain the high frequency field. However, in numerous cases, such as relating electromagnetic field in the region of the image space, the said technique does not provide suitable outcomes [22]. To remove this error of GO, Maslov’s method is used, which combine the asymptotic ray theory (ART) and Fourier transform method [23–26]. Maslov’s method, expresses the ray in terms of components of wave vectors and space coordinates with mixed six coordinates. The conventional ray expression may be considered as its projection in the space coordinates. At the singular point of the ray-expression in space coordinates, the six-component expression is employed. The expression in the hybrid coordinates may be transformed into that of space coordinates through Fourier transform. This technique has been used to study high frequency fields in the focal region successfully by many authors [27–33]. In this paper, we consider a long metallic circular reflector coated with a collision plasma layer on its surface under oblique incidence. The reflection and transmission coefficients at free space-plasma and plasma-perfect electromagnetic conductor interfaces have been derived analytically. The electromagnetic field intensity in the caustic or focal region of this circular reflector has been derived using Maslov’s method. The effects of angle of incidence, plasma’s parameters such as the, admittance parameter, plasma frequency and effective collision frequency and the thickness of plasma layer on the focal regions field transmitted and reflected from plasma layer have been studied. The results of the presented formulations have been compared with the published results of some special cases which confirm the accuracy of the presented analysis. 2 Methods and formulation Consider a circular reflector made of perfect metal in the presence of plasma layer as shown in Fig. 1 , equation of surface of metallic circular reflector is given as (1) ζ = a 2 − ξ 2 where a is the radius of the metallic circular reflector. Then, the equation of the circular plasma layer placed on the metallic circular reflector is defined as follows: (2) ζ = p 2 − ξ 2 where p = a 2 − d 2 is the radius of the circular plasma layer, a is the radius of the circular metallic circular reflector and d is the thickness of the plasma layer. According to the mathematical concept, coordinates of a point on the circular surface of the plasma layer P ( ξ 0 , ζ 0 ) in terms of a point on the metallic circular reflector Q(ξ, ζ) are defined as [7] (3) ξ 0 = ξ − d sin α (4) ζ 0 = ζ − d cos α Now, we consider a monochromatic electromagnetic wave polarized in y-axis obliquely incident with an angle θ0 on the circular plasma layer, parallel to its symmetry axis as [6,15] (5) E 0 i = E i e ˆ y exp [ − j k i ( x sin θ 0 + z cos θ 0 ) ] As a plane wave is made incident obliquely on the plasma circular reflector, the wave vector of the reflected wave and transmitted wave can be worked out by using Snell’s laws of whose mathematical expression is described in the following form (6) P r = P i − 2 ( P i . N ) N (7) Q r = P i + n 2 − 1 + ( P i . N ) 2 N − ( P i . N ) N where Pi is the wave vector of the incident wave, n is refractive index of plasma medium and N is unit normal to the surface of the circular reflector coated with plasma layer can be written as (8) N = e ˆ z cos α + e ˆ x sin α By applying Snell’s law of reflection and refraction the wave vector P1 of the reflected wave from plasma circular layer, the wave vector Q1 of the refracted wave into plasma circular layer, the wave vector P2 of the reflected wave from metallic circular reflector and the wave vector Q2 of the refracted wave from plasma circular layer in to free space are given by [11] (9) P 1 = − e ˆ x sin ( 2 α − θ 0 ) − e ˆ z cos ( 2 α − θ 0 ) (10) Q 1 = e ˆ x ( sin α ( − cos ( α − θ 0 ) + n 2 − sin 2 ( α − θ 0 ) ) + sin θ 0 ) − e ˆ z ( cos α ( − cos ( α − θ 0 ) + n 2 − sin 2 ( α − θ 0 ) ) + cos θ 0 ) (11) P 2 = − e ˆ x ( K 1 sin α + cos α sin ( α − θ 0 ) ) − e ˆ z ( K 1 cos α − sin α sin ( α − θ 0 ) ) (12) Q 2 = − e ˆ x ( K 2 sin α + ncos α sin ( α − θ 0 ) ) − e ˆ z ( K 2 cos α − nsin α sin ( α − θ 0 ) ) where K 1 = ( − 1 + 2 n 2 + cos ( 2 α − 2 θ 0 ) ) / 2 K 2 = ( 2 + n ( − 1 + 2 ( − 1 + n ) n ) + n cos ( 2 α − 2 θ 0 ) ) / 2 . The Jacobian associated with wave reflected by the circular plasma layer is obtained (13) J 1 ( τ 1 ) = D 1 ( τ 1 ) D 1 ( 0 ) = τ 1 − cos α 2 p The Jacobian associated with wave refracted by the plasma circular layer after reflection from metallic circular layer is obtained (14) J 2 ( τ 2 ) = D 2 ( τ 2 ) D 2 ( 0 ) = 1 2 a K 2 2 ( 2 a ( 2 + n ( − 1 + 2 ( − 1 + n ) n ) ) + K 2 ( − 2 + n + n 2 − 2 n 3 ) τ 2 − 2 2 n ( 1 + ( − 1 + n ) n 2 ) τ 2 cos ( α − θ 0 ) + n ( 2 a + K 2 ( − 1 + n ) τ 2 ) cos ( 2 α − 2 θ 0 ) ) The fields expressions for the reflected and transmitted rays out of the plasma layer in geometric optics are obtained as under [13–18] (15) E r ( x , z ) = E i [ J 1 ( τ ) ] − 1 2 e x p [ − j k ( Ψ 0 + τ 1 ) ] (16) E t ( x , z ) = E i [ J 2 ( τ ) ] − 1 2 e x p [ − j k ( Ψ 0 + τ 2 + t ) ] where Ψ 0 = p cos ( α − θ 0 ) , τ 1 and τ 2 are parameter along the ray reflected from circular plasma layer and transmitted ray out of circular plasma layer to focal point respectively and t is the distance between the P(ξ0,ζ0) and Q(ξ, ζ). It is observed that the GO field the reflected and the transmitted wave becomes infinity at the Caustic points as is expected when J(τ)=0. We can derive the expression which is valid at the focal point using the Maslov’s method. The exact location of focal or caustic point may also be obtained at J(τ)=0. According to Maslov’s method valid field expressions in focal region can be written as below [9–18]. (17) E r ( r ) = k j 2 π ∫ − ∞ ∞ [ D ( τ ) D ( 0 ) ∂ ( p z ) ∂ ( z ) ] − 1 2 exp { − jk [ S 0 + τ − z ( p x , z ) p z + p z z ] } d p z Integrand and phase function of integral for transmitted field from plasma layer is obtained as (18) Q = D ( τ ) D ( 0 ) ∂ ( p x ) ∂ ( x ) = 1 2 a K 2 ( 2 n 2 cos α ( K 2 + cos ( α − θ 0 ) sin 2 ( α − θ 0 ) + K 2 sin α ( 4 K 2 n sin ( α − θ 0 ) + n ( 1 + n ) sin ( 2 α − 2 θ 0 ) + 2 K 2 ( K 2 + n cos ( α − θ 0 ) ) Tan α ) ) S = S 0 + τ 2 + t − z ( x , p z ) p z + p x x = S 0 + τ 2 − ξ 0 p x − ζ 0 p z + p x x + p z z (19) S = p cos ( α − θ 0 ) + a K 2 − d K 2 − K 2 r cos ( α + θ ) + a cos ( α − θ 0 ) + n r sin ( α + θ ) sin ( α − θ 0 ) + ( ξ 0 − ξ ) 2 + ( ζ 0 − ζ ) 2 Similarly the integrand and phase function for the integral of field reflected from plasma coated circular reflector can be obtained easily. The final reflected field expression from plasma coated circular reflector valid at the focal point is obtained using Maslov’s method can be written as (20) E ( x , z ) E i = k a π ∫ − l / 2 l / 2 cos ( α − θ 0 ) × e x p [ − j k ( 2 acos ( α − θ 0 ) − rcos ( θ + 2 α − θ 0 ) − d sin ( 2 α 1 − α 2 − θ 0 ] ) ) ] d α To obtain initial value of reflected field E r 0 ( x , z ) on PEMC circular reflector we applied PEMC boundary conditions. The boundary conditions at the surface of the PEMC (21) n × ( H + M E ) = 0 n ⋅ ( D − M B ) = 0 } where n is the unit normal, and M is the admittance parameter characterizing the PEMC. The values M=0 and M →±∞, correspond to PMC and PEC respectively. The electromagnetic energy cannot enter into the PEMC region because that the pointing vector is complex and imaginary [19]. Using above boundary conditions we get (22) E r 0 ( x , z ) = [ 1 − ( Mη 0 ) 2 ( Mη 0 ) 2 + 1 e ˆ x − 2 Mη 0 ( Mη 0 ) 2 + 1 e ˆ y ] E i The reflected field from PEMC circular reflector incident to plasma curve. The initial value of the transmitted field is related with the incident field from PEMC circular reflector by the relation (23) E t ( x , z ) = T ˜ ⋅ E r o = [ T ∥ i ∥ t i ∥ i + T ⊥ i ⊥ t i ⊥ i ] ⋅ E r o The unit vector corresponding to these components are obtained using following relations i ⊥ i = P i × n | P i × n | = e ˆ y , i ∥ i = i ⊥ i × P i = cos θ 0 e ˆ x − sin θ 0 e ˆ z , i ⊥ t = q i × n | q i × n | = e ˆ y , i ∥ t = i ⊥ i × q i = − ( K 2 cos α + n sin α sin ( α − θ 0 ) ) e ˆ x − ( K 2 sin α + n cos α sin ( α − θ 0 ) ) e ˆ z T ∥ = 2 ncos α cos α + n 1 − n 2 sin 2 α T ⊥ = 2 ncos α ncos α + 1 − n 2 sin 2 α Using above equations the co polarized transmitted field from plasma coated circular reflector at the focal point are obtained (24) E x ( x , z ) E i = − k a π ∫ − l / 2 l / 2 E x ( x , z ) E i = − k a π ∫ − l / 2 l / 2 2 ncos α ( K 2 cos α + n sin α sin ( α − θ 0 ) ) cos α + n 1 − n 2 sin 2 α 1 − ( Mη 0 ) 2 ( Mη 0 ) 2 + 1 cos θ 0 1 q 2 x d q 2 z d α cos ( α − θ 0 ) × e x p [ − j k ( p cos ( α − θ 0 ) + a K 2 − d K 2 − K 2 r cos ( α + θ ) + a cos ( α − θ 0 ) + n r sin ( α + θ ) sin ( α − θ 0 ) + t ) ] d α (25) E z ( x , z ) E i = k a π ∫ − l / 2 l / 2 2 ncos α ( K 2 sin α + n cos α sin ( α − θ 0 ) ) cos α + n 1 − n 2 sin 2 α 1 − ( Mη 0 ) 2 ( Mη 0 ) 2 + 1 sin θ 0 1 q 2 x d q 2 z d α cos ( α − θ 0 ) × e x p [ − j k ( p cos ( α − θ 0 ) + a K 2 − d K 2 − K 2 r cos ( α + θ ) + a cos ( α − θ 0 ) + n r sin ( α + θ ) sin ( α − θ 0 ) + t ) ] d α The cross polarized transmitted field from plasma coated circular reflector at the focal point is obtained as (26) E y ( x , z ) E i = − k a π ∫ − l / 2 l / 2 2 ncos α ncos α + 1 − n 2 sin 2 α 2 Mη 0 ( Mη 0 ) 2 + 1 1 q 2 x d q 2 z d α cos ( α − θ 0 ) × e x p [ − j k ( p cos ( α − θ 0 ) + a K 2 − d K 2 − K 2 r cos ( α + θ ) + a cos ( α − θ 0 ) + n r sin ( α + θ ) sin ( α − θ 0 ) + t ) ] d α l = s i n − 1 ( d / a ) is the angle which subtends the aperture. 3 Numerical result and discussion In this paper, optical focused electromagnetic field from a perfect electromagnetic conductor circular reflector coated by magnetized plasma is obtained under oblique angle of incident. Then the effects of admittance parameter, angle of incident, plasma frequency and effective collision frequency of plasma on the optical focused fields are discussed. The incident frequency of electromagnetic wave is taken as f=5×107 Hz and Mη0 =MZ throughout the manuscript. The numerical results are compared with the published literature to check the correctness of analytical calculations and also as well the working of software pack. By using MATHEMATICA software, the computations are made of Eqs. (20), (24) and (25). Fig. 2 shows the comparison at ka=4, MZ=∞, kd=0.5, θ0 =1°, ωp =1.7829×108 Hz and V=6.0×109 Hz for the focused fields from PEMC circular reflector coated with plasma layer, our study and previous study [24]. When plasma medium is replaced by the dielectric free space then the present work transforms into the published work as in [24] and good agreement is found between analytical and then numerical calculations. It is also noted that reflected field intensity decreases due to plasma coating. Fig. 3 a and b shows the comparison of the co polarized field intensity distribution of PEMC circular reflector coated with plasma material along x-axis and z-axis for the different values of admittance parameter respectively at ka=4, kd=0.5, θ0 =1°, ωp =1.7829×108 Hz and V=6.0×109 Hz. The solid, dotted, thick dashed, dashed and thick dotted lines show the result at MZ=∞, MZ=5.0, MZ=3 and MZ=0.5 for the co polarized field intensity distribution of PEMC circular reflector coated with plasma material along x-axis and z-axis respectively. Fig. 3a and b it is observed that at MZ=∞ co polarized focused the field intensity corresponds to reflect from PEC circular reflectors and at intermediate values of admittance parameter the focused the field intensity corresponds to PEMC elliptical reflectors. It is also observed that field intensity shifts to a smaller value as we decrease the admittance parameter. Fig. 4 a and b shows the comparison of the cross polarized field intensity distribution of PEMC circular reflector coated with plasma material along x-axis and z-axis for the different values of admittance parameter respectively at ka=4, kd=0.5, θ0 =1°, ωp =1.7829×108 Hz and V=6.0×109 Hz. The solid, dotted, thick dashed, dashed and thick dotted lines show the result at MZ=∞, MZ=5.0, MZ=3 and MZ=0.5 for the co polarized field intensity distribution of PEMC circular reflector coated with plasma material along x-axis and z-axis respectively. Fig. 4a and b it is observed that at MZ=∞ and MZ=0 cross polarized focused field intensity vanishes. It is also observed that field intensity shifts to a higher value as we increase the admittance parameter. Fig. 5 shows the comparison of the co polarized field intensity distribution of PEMC circular reflector coated with plasma material along z-axis around the focal point for the different values of plasma frequencies at ωp =3.08808×108 Hz(solidline),ωp =1.7829×108 Hz(dashed line) ωp =1.38103×108 Hz (dotted line), and ωp =7.63803×107 Hz(thick dotted line) respectively. From Fig. 4 it is observed that the field intensity shifts to a slightly smaller value as we increase the values of plasma frequency. In Figure it is assumed that at ka=4, kd=0.5, θ0 =1°, MZ=0.1 and V=6.0×109 Hz. Fig. 5 shows the comparison of the co polarized field intensity distribution of PEMC circular reflector coated with plasma material along z-axis at ka=4, kd=0.5, θ0 =1°, ωp =1.7829×108 Hz and MZ=0.1 around the focal point for the different values of collision frequencies V=6.0×109 Hz(solidline),V=2.0×109 Hz(dashed line) V=8.0×108 Hz (dotted line), and V=4.0×108 Hz(thick dotted line) respectively. From Fig. 5 it is observed that the field intensity shifts to a slightly smaller value as we decrease the values of plasma frequency. Fig. 6 a and b shows the comparison of the co polarized field intensity distribution of PEMC circular reflector coated with plasma material at ka=4, kd=0.5, ωp =1.7829×108 Hz and V=6.0×109 Hz. along x-axis and z-axis for the different values of angle of incidence respectively. The solid, dotted, thick dashed, dashed and thick dotted lines show the result atθ0 =1°, θ0 =5°, θ0 =10° and θ0 =15° for the co polarized field intensity distribution of PEMC circular reflector coated with plasma material along x-axis and z-axis respectively. Fig. 6a and b it is observed that if angle of incidence increases the value of transmitted field decrease for both axes whereas focal point shift away from curved surface for x-axis and focal point shift toward curved surface for z-axis. Similarly result for cross polarized filed intensity can be obtained by same procedure. 4 Conclusion In this paper, the focusing of electromagnetic field through a PEMC circular reflector coated with plasma material for oblique incidence is analyzed numerically by using Maslov’s method. The field distribution is presented in the form of numerical results for different parameters to clarify the focusing behavior of PEMC circular reflector coated with plasma material. It is observed that the cross polarized field component appeared for PEMC circular reflector. It is clear from analysis of co polarized field component that at infinite value of admittance parameter PEMC circular reflector coated with plasma material approaches to PEC circular reflector coated with plasma material. It is also observed that at null value of admittance parameter PEMC circular reflector coated with plasma material approaches to PMC circular reflector coated with plasma material. In case of cross polarized field component at infinite value and null value of admittance field cross polarized field component disappear. It is also observed that field intensity increases with decrease in angle of incidence. The focal point shift away and toward curved surface oppositely with the increase in angle of incidence. column2: Self-focusing of Hermite-cosh-Gaussian laser beam in semiconductor quantum plasma
column3: Abstract Self-focusing of Hermite-cosh-Gaussian (HchG) laser beam in semiconductor quantum plasma (ScQP) has been presented by considering the decentred parameter and quantum effect. We drive the equation of beam width parameter by using parabolic wave equation and solved it numerically by using WKB approximation. Our simulation results show that HchG beam gives freedom to source parameters that influence the self-focusing significantly. Additional self-focusing has been observed in ScQP than that of classical case of reference. The quantum plasma also adds pinching effect to laser propagation in semiconductor like germanium which further enhances the self-focusing more and more in ScQP.
column5: Keywords Hermite-cosh-Gaussian (HchG) laser beam Semiconductor Self-focusing Quantum plasma 1 Introduction High power lasers interactions with plasmas and semiconductors have been a fascinating area of research during last few decades [1–4] due to its potential applications such as particle accelerations, laser-driven fusion, radiation generations, generation of magnetic fields etc. [5–7]. The effectiveness of laser beam in such applications is determined by the extended propagation without loss of energy. The penetration of laser beams in plasma generates various nonlinear phenomena’s (self-focusing, harmonic generation, electron acceleration etc.). Among these phenomena self-focusing is an important nonlinear phenomenon. In semiconductors the nonlinearities that are important in self-focusing appear through the redistribution of carriers and energy dependence mass of carriers. However, at low lattice temperatures, the rise in random energy of carriers is much greater than the drift energy. Therefore, the nonlinearities are mainly due to the redistribution of carriers [3]. Further, the semiconductors provides a platform to model nonlinear phenomena like self-focusing effectively due to its compact size and as a less expensive medium which ensures their practical applicability and possibilities of optical limiting devices [4]. There are two main mechanisms for the occurrence of nonlinear self-focusing of laser in semiconductors, non-parabolicity of conduction band and nonlocal effects. Apart from these two mechanisms, there is another mechanism which is due to intervallic transfer of carriers. This mechanism is however unimportant in Ge and in InSb but, is significant in semiconductors like GaAs which has been studied by Guha and Tripathi [8]. However, the self-focusing of electromagnetic beams due to free carrier nonlinearities is possible in a sample lengths for easily obtainable powers (P ≥20Win n-InSb at ω =1014 rad/sec). But, for the focusing of high frequency beams, the power of the beam has to be enhanced considerably. The temperature change of the carriers is important effect influencing self-focusing of laser in semiconductors because of their sensitiveness towards the change in carriers effective mass [9]. The laser (beam spot size and Rayleigh length) and plasma parameters (mainly density) are crucial for enhanced self-focusing in plasma [10–15]. Kant and Wani [16] studied the density transition on laser’s self-focusing in plasma. The effect of linear absorption in plasma weakens the effect of self-focusing whereas a density transition induces an earlier and effective self-focusing of laser. At small values of intensity and decentered parameters the self-focusing of HcosG laser beam in collisionless plasma becomes more focused [17]. Self-focusing is also sensitive to decentered parameter [18] and with a magnetic field of a few MG the self-focusing capacity of laser beam increases in rippled density plasma. With a suitable wavelength of density ripple in plasma, stronger and earlier self-focusing is achieved [19]. Frequency chirp also influences the self-focusing. The variation in chirp parameter from optimized values decreases the effect of defocusing and hence, increases the ability of self-focusing in collisional plasma [20]. Habibi and Ghamari [21] presented the higher order paraxial theory for the focusing of a cosh-Gaussian (chG) laser beam in quantum plasma. By choosing the suitable value of decentered parameter, better self-focusing is observed for chG laser beams in comparison with Gaussian beams. Furthermore, the quantum effect plays a pivotal role during laser interaction in plasma and effectively adds self-focusing in comparison to a classical relativistic case [22,23]. A plasma profile with upward density ramp causes a much higher oscillation and enhanced focusing in cold quantum plasma which includes the quantum effects [24]. In this investigation, we have analyzed the self-focusing of HchG laser beam propagating in semiconductor quantum plasma (ScQP). We consider a wave equation in paraxial approximation using HchG beam. Such beams can be generated experimentally by the interaction of two decentred HG beams as chG ones. Effects of decentred parameter, laser intensity and plasma density parameters are seen on the self-focusing of HchG laser beam in ScQP. We have found that a HchG laser beam when incident on ScQP, earlier self-focusing appears which becomes much stronger as quantum effect gives stronger beam localization to add the self-focusing. The paper is structured as follows: section 2 presents the equations governing the nonlinear dielectric constant and the characteristics of beam width parameter functioning the distance of propagation. Section 3 includes the results and discussions on the basis of considered parameters. Final conclusion is presented in Section 4. 2 Self-focusing Laser beam propagating through a dielectric medium is written in terms of a wave equation as: (1) ▽ 2 E ¯ + ( ω 2 c 2 ) ε E ¯ + ▽ ( E ¯ ▽ ε ε ) = 0. assuming k −2 ∇ 2(lnε)˂˂ 1, where, k is the wave number of the laser beam. Therefore, neglecting the last term on in Eq. (1). The wave equation becomes: (2) ▽ 2 E ¯ + ω 2 c 2 ( ε E ¯ ) = 0. The effective dielectric constant in ScQP can be defined as: (3) ε = ε 0 + Φ ( E E * ) , where, ε 0 = ε L − ω p 2 / ω 2 is the linear and Φ ( E E * ) ≈ ( 1 / 2 ) ε 2 A 0 2 is the nonlinear term of respectively, ε L is the lattice dielectric constant, ω p = ( 4 π N e e 2 / m * ) 1 / 2 is the plasma frequency, N e represents the concentration of electrons, m* is the effective electron mass, ω is the incident angular frequency of laser beam and e is the charge on electron. In semiconductors, the nonlinearities are due to the relative dependence of electron’s effective mass and temperature. The dielectric constant for quantum plasma is expressed as [25]: (4) ε = 1 − ω p 2 γ ω 2 ( 1 − δ q γ ) − 1 , With δq =4π 4 h 2/m 2 ω 2 λ 4, h is the Plank’s constant and γ = ( 1 + α E E * ) 1 / 2 is the relativistic factor. Further, α= e 2/m 2 ω 2 c 2, where, c is the speed of light in vacuum. Following [2], Φ(EE *) can be expressed as: (5) Φ ( E E * ) = ω p 2 ω 2 [ 1 − 1 γ ( 1 − δ q γ ) ] , Now, introducing, E = A(r, z)exp[i(ωt − kz)], where, A(r, z) representing the complex amplitude of electric field vector and its behaviour is described by the parabolic equation derived from Eq. (2). Employing the WKB approximation and considering the slow variations along longitudinal axis than that in radially, one obtains (6) − 2 i k ∂ A ∂ z + ∂ 2 A ∂ r 2 + 1 r ∂ A ∂ r + ω 2 c 2 Φ ( E E * ) A = 0 , In order to solve Eq. (6), we express A as (7) A ( r , z ) = A 0 ( r , z ) exp [ − i k S ( r , z ) ] , where, k = ( ω / c ) ε 0 1 / 2 , A 0 and S are real functions r and z (S represents the eikonal of the laser beam). Substituting Eqs. (5) and (7) in Eq. (6). Then the real and imaginary parts are separated as follow: (8) 2 ∂ S ∂ z + ( ∂ S ∂ r ) 2 = 1 k 2 A 0 2 [ 1 2 ∂ 2 A 0 2 ∂ r 2 − 1 4 A 0 2 ( ∂ A 0 2 ∂ r ) 2 + 1 2 r ∂ A 0 2 ∂ r ] + 1 ε 0 ( ω p 2 ω 2 ) [ 1 − 1 γ ( 1 − δ q γ ) ] , and (9) ∂ A 0 2 ∂ z + ( ∂ S ∂ r ) ( ∂ A 0 2 ∂ r ) + A 0 2 ( ∂ 2 S ∂ r 2 + 1 r ∂ S ∂ r ) = 0 , where, S =(r 2/2)β(z)+ ϕ(z),β(z)=(1/f)(∂f/∂z), β −1 is the radius of curvature of the laser beam and f(z) is the normalized beam width parameter. Further, for an HchG beam at z =0, (10) A 0 2 = E 0 2 4 f 2 exp ( b 2 2 ) [ exp { − 2 ( r r 0 f + b 2 ) 2 } + exp { − 2 ( r r 0 f − b 2 ) 2 } + 2 exp { − ( 2 r 2 r 0 2 f 2 + b 2 2 ) } ] , Substituting for S and A 0 2 in Eq. (8). Solving and equating the coefficients of r 2 in resulting equation. The second order differential equation functioning the nonlinear dependence of beam width parameter is obtained as follows: ∂ 2 f ∂ ξ 2 = 16 − b 2 ( 76 − 17 b 2 + 94 b 4 ) 4 f 3 − α E 0 2 ρ 0 2 4 f 3 ( ω p ω ) 2 exp ( b 2 2 ) × (11) × [ 4 − 8 δ q + 2 δ q ( 2 − b 2 ) ( α E 0 2 ) f 2 exp ( b 2 2 ) ] , where, ξ = z/R d is the normalized distance representing propagation, R d = k r 0 2 represents the diffraction length, ρ 0 = r 0 ω 0/c is the equilibrium beam radius. Hence, Eq. (11) represents the laser’s spot size variation with the propagation distance. 3 Results and discussion Eq. (11) is the second order differential equation regulating the nonlinear function of beam width parameter f with the propagation distance ξ for HchG laser beam in ScQP. Eq. (11) has been numerically solved by considering the initial condition at ξ =0, f =1, ( ∂ f / ∂ ξ ) = 0 and ( ∂ 2 f / ∂ ξ 2 ) = 0 for Nd: glass laser; angular frequency of laser ω =2×1015 rad/sec, laser wavelength λ =1.06μm. In semiconductor the energy transfer mechanism is dependent on the optical mode of scattering, thus we choose a case of non-parabolic semiconductor like n-InSb (n-type Indium Antimonide). By optimizing the plasma and laser parameters, the self-focusing has been investigated for HchG laser beam in ScQP. Fig. 1 shows the variation plots of beam width parameter f functioning normalized propagation distance ξ for distinct values of decentred parameter b. The other parameters are δq =0.52, α E 0 2 = 0.7 and ω p /ω =0.9. The self-focusing effect for beam is shown forb =0, 0.5 and 1. We depict that on increasing the values of decentred parameter in gradual steps a sharp self-focusing occurs for b =1 at shorter propagation distance of about ξ =0.01. This is due to the fact that in case of semiconductors, the decentred parameter when increased results in the reduction of self-focusing length. Consequently, the phenomenon of self-focusing gets enhanced more in ScQP. Fig. 2 shows the variation plot of beam width parameter f as a function of the normalized distance of propagation ξ for distinct values of relative plasma density ω p /ω. The decentred parameter is fixed at b =1 and the other parameters are same as taken in Fig. 1. It is observed that the laser beam converges in the region where plasma density is high. On increasing ω p /ω, the value of f decreases strongly with ξ and touches its minimum at ω p /ω =0.9, corresponding to ξ =0.01, thereby decreasing the amplitude of laser beam gradually closer to the axis of propagation. Hence, stronger self-focusing is observed at smaller ξ values. This is due to the fact that quantum effects are highly prominent in the region of higher plasma density. These results can be compared with the results presented by Kaur et al. [26]. Wherein, they considered that the two scale length makes the periodic oscillations of laser beam with a constant amplitude for a long distance of propagation. Thus, quantum effects offer stronger self-focusing than classical ones. Fig. 3 shows the variation plot of beam width parameter f vs normalized propagation distance ξ with various values of α E 0 2 for ScQP. The decentred parameter is fixed at b =1 and the rest of the parameters are same as taken in Fig. 1. The Fig. 3 demonstrates that the convergence of laser beam starts earlier with increase in α E 0 2 of the beam. Further, it is observed that the length for self-focusing decreases with the increase in intensity of the laser beam. This is on account of relativistic intensity that the beam having more and more electrons travelling with the laser pulse. This generates a higher current and resulting a high quasi-stationary magnetic field which in turn enhances the self-focusing and thus favours the results of Hauser et al. [27] who investigated the self-focusing of laser under classical relativistic nonlinearity. Fig. 4 shows the variation plot of beam width parameter f vs normalized propagation distance ξ with various values of δq for ScQP. The other parameters are α E 0 2 = 7 ω p /ω =0.9 and b =1. On setting δqto zero, we regain the classical case i.e. we are ignoring the quantum effects. But, Fig. 4 reveals that on increasing the values of δq (taking in to account the quantum effect), the self-focusing appears earlier and much stronger. This is because of the fact that quantum effect gives stronger beam localization which adds the self-focusing. Comparing the results with those of Patil et al. [4], wherein by considering the classical case, the parameter expressing the beam width attains its minima at ξ =0.18 and small focusing takes place. But, in our case the beam width parameter attains minima at ξ =0.0009 and hence gives rise to stronger self-focusing of laser beam. Thus, quantum effect gives a relative stronger self-focusing effect in ScQP than that in classical relativistic case. Fig. 5 shows the plot for variation of f with ξ for the intensities, I =1.3×1016 W/cm 2,I =3.9×1016 W/cm 2, I =6.5×1016 W/cm 2 and I =9.1×1016 W/cm 2. The rest of the parameters are same as taken in Fig. 3. From Fig. 5, we observe that the beam width parameter f decreases with increase in laser intensity and is minimum (corresponding to ξ =0.0009) at optimized laser intensity I =9.1×1016 W/cm 2. In other words, at higher intensities, earlier and stronger self-focusing is achieved in ScQP. Thus, we have found that the study of HchG beams is very relevant for analysis of various parameters in ScQP. It is interesting to find that the parameters like decentered parameter, intensity of the laser beam and plasma density are found to influence the self-focusing of the laser beam in a significant manner. 4 Conclusion The self-focusing of Hermite–cosh-Gaussian (HchG) laser beam in semiconductor quantum plasma (ScQP) has been studied. The differential equation governing the evolution of the laser spot size in semiconductor quantum plasma is derived. Our formulation is based on the approximation of parabolic equation under paraxial approach and incorporates the strong desirability of self-focusing effect by exploiting the beams decentred parameter. The decentred parameter plays a crucial role in deciding the nature of self-focusing of HchG beam. It is seen that additional self-focusing is observed in ScQP than classical case of reference. Further, the quantum plasma adds pinching effect to laser propagation in semiconductors as a result the self-focusing is enhanced more and more in ScQP. Again, we have found that HchG beams give freedom to source parameters like decentred parameter that changes the nature of self-focusing significantly. Thus, quantum effect plays a vital role in laser-plasma interaction and significantly adds to self-focusing in semiconductor quantum plasma. The results of present investigation may be useful in high power laser − driven fusion and laser plasma based accelerators.

column2: Study of fiber optic code division multiple access Code families for Application in Optical Communication based on weight and bit error rate
column3: Abstract This paper investigates on fiber optic code division multiple access (FOCDMA) code families using different sets of parameter. The different code families considered here are generalized multi-wavelength Reed-Solomon code (GMWRSC), complete row-wise orthogonal pairs (CRWOP), row-wise orthogonal pairs (RWOP) and Multiwavelength Optical Orthogonal Code (MWOOC). The parameters under investigation in this work chosen to be number of maximum users (Nmax),Bit error rate(BER),Spreading Factor(Sf),Weight(K’),Number of Wavelengths(WI) and number of time chips(T). By using suitable mathematical formula, computation is made for above said parameters using aforementioned methods At the end a healthy comparison was made to identify efficient one among them just by estimating cardinality of each result. The comparison result revealed that row wise orthogonal pairs (RWOP) code family gives high performance.
column5: Keywords FOCDMA MAI Orthogonal codes 1 Introduction Now a day’s communication network acts on important issue for the sake of development of society, security and economical growth. Recently the improvement of communication network in the world mostly depends on fiber optic communication with appropriate signals. The intrinsic characteristics of transmitted signal through fiber relies on the concept of fiber optic code division multiple access (FOCDMA), which is based on widely used code division multiple access (CDMA)[1] technology in microwave wireless communications. It is just a code assigned to each user with less cross correlation which is simply known as spreading codes or signature sequences. Fiber optic code division multiple access (FOCDMA) is a common optical communication channel which shared among multiple users [2–5]. The bit error rate (BER) is the majority important presentation factor of any digital communications system. It is a gauge of the probability that any given bit will have been arriving in error. For example a standard greatest bit error rate (BER) for several systems is 10−9 [6–10]. This indicates that the recipient is approved to produce an utmost of 1 error in every 109 bits of information transmitted or putting it in a different way, the chance that any inward bit is in error of 10−9. The bit error rate (BER) depends chiefly on the signal to noise ratio (SNR) of the arriving signal which in turn is evaluated by the transmitted signal power, the decrease of the link, the link dispersion and the recipient noise [11–15]. Bit error rate (BER) measurement is not an easy process and it requires expensive and sophisticated apparatus to attain accuracy, particularly at high bit rates. However, the effects of noise and other signal degradation processes can be found qualitatively and perhaps even in a pseudo quantitative and bit error rate (BER) degradation trends which can be enthusiastically calculated due to the effects of signal dispersion and attenuation [16,17]. Though above references dealt with fiber optic code division process, this paper shows a comparative study of performance analysis for different sets of parameters. The different parameters considered are cardinality, spreading factor, number of wavelengths, temporal length and weight. The performance criterion of these code families is bit error rate (BER) due to multiple access interference (MAI) as a function of number of active users. The effect of one parameter to other is analysed by entertaining four type of codes such as generalized multi-wavelength Reed-Solomon code (GMWRSC), row-wise orthogonal pairs (RWOP), complete row-wise orthogonal pairs (CRWOP) and Multiwavelength Orthogonal Optical Code (MWOOC)[18]. The comparisons are designed in the form of tables and figures. In the tables rows are labelled with cardinality (Nmax), bit error rate (BER) due to multiple access interference (MAI), spreading factor (Sf), weight (K’), number of time chips (T) and number of wavelengths (Wl), where as each column is assigned one parameters corresponding to each of the four code families. The objective is to find optimum code family with which maximum number of users should use the spectrum with less bit error rate (BER) due to multiple access interference (MAI)[19]. As number of users increases bit error rate (BER) also increases. The code families which show less increase in bit error rate (BER) are better. For the sake of same comparison, we use generalized bit error rate (BER) form, which given by [20–23] (1) BER ' = 1 2 ∑ i = K ′ N N C i ( K' 2 2 WT ) i ( 1 − K' 2 2 WT ) N − i (2) BER ' = 1 2 ∑ i = 0 K' ( − 1 ) i K' C i ( 1 − qi K' ) N − 1 Where W is the integer number of wavelengths, T is the number of time chips, K’ is number of weights, N is number of active users q = 1 p K ′ 2 ( Nmax ) p − 1 2 ToocNmaxp 2 − 1 + p − 1 ( p K ′ 2 ( Nmax ) p − 1 ) + ( K ′ − 1 ) 2 2 ToocNmaxp 2 − 1 Nmax is the cardinality, Tooc is the temporal length. Eqs (1) and (2) are representing the bit error rate (BER) for GMWRCs and Multiwavelength Optical Orthogonal Code (MWOOC). The bit error rate (BER) due to multiple access interference (MAI) is quite similar to wavelengths of wi and wj. Since the two 1D OOCs along with wavelengths wi and wj are observed concurrently for any user, Hence the overall response for BER can be evaluated by equation 3 which as follows. an error is occurred due to interference wavelengths wi and wj are bit coinciding (T), so the bit error rate (BER) due to multiple access interference (MAI) for the two dimensional (2D) code families is (3) B E R ′ = B E R ( N w i ) × B E R ( N w j ) T Eq. (3) represents the bit error rate (BER) for row-wise orthogonal pairs (RWOP) and complete row-wise orthogonal pairs (CRWOP). Section 2 illustrates performance analysis of different code families(RWOP, CRWOP, MWOOC, GMWRC) with respect to (cardinality (Nmax), bit error rate (BER) due to multiple access interference (MAI), spreading factor (Sf), weight (K’), number of time chips (T) and number of wavelengths (Wl). In addition figures and tables have been suitably placed for proper explanation. Finally conclusions are drawn in section 3. 2 Result and discussion To get the optimized result, we have focussed to vary two crucial parameter as BER and weights (number of bits) pertaining to all code families. The efficiency each variations were studied deeply, to maximize the number of user with less BER. The detail analysis was available in 2.1 and 2.2, which explains the nobility of this work. 2.1 Analysis of code family based on equivalent bit error rate The simulation result is available in Fig. 1 , where x axis takes independent variable as number of active users, where as bit error rate are plotted in y-axis. To have better comparison we set a fixed bit error rate of 10−4. From the graph we have inferred other parameter like (Nmax), Spreading Factor (Sf), Weight (K’), Number of Wavelengths (WI) and number of time chips (T). Keeping BER range of 10−4, the inferred result suitable placed in Table 1 . We reach to a conclusion that RWOP is showing better performance as compared other code families. If we take GMWRSC alone, it is supporting very large number of active users, which is good prospective for us. By on other hand interference level is quite high, which is not welcome factor. Here K and wi posses high values, which are responsible for causing interference. If we consider RWOP, the cardinality may be less but we are achieving very low interference rate which is our goal. MWOOC is not considering for up to the mark because it has high time chip, which ultimately enhance the interference level. As CRWOP is fetching average result, we are simple reject. In the next iteration/attempt, we have started with a bit error rate of 10−7 and proceeded to examine the difference between current and previous output. Though we have chosen similar kind of approach for both the cases, but the latter case result in terms of number of users is enhanced significantly. Decrement of bit error rate may increase the no of users but in reality interference level has been given more priority and showing better performance. Here also all the results in terms of (Nmax), Spreading Factor (Sf), Weight (K’), Number of Wavelengths (WI) and number of time chips (T) with code families are reflected in Table 2 and Fig. 2 . The tabular data confirms that RWOP code again going to be powerful one compared other. 2.2 Analysis of code family based on equivalent weights In last section the importance of bit error rate was thoroughly investigated. Alike the bit error rate, another crucial parameter in terms of weight can potentially influence the result. Hence it is customary to set a fixed weight for all the families to check out the difference. By fixing K=4 other parameter are extracted and recorded in the Table 3 . According to Table 3 the value of Nmax are 55, 56, 60 and 54 for the code families (GMWRSC), (CRWOP), (RWOP) and (MWOOC) respectively. Using data from Table 3, a graph is plotted between bit error rates (BER) and active users. From the graph it is seen that the complete row-wise orthogonal pairs (CRWOP) and row-wise orthogonal pairs (RWOP) code families are of similar kind of nature with less deviation and also have least bit error rate (BER). BER of CRWOP and RWOP are almost with increase the number of active users in Fig. 3 . BER of MWOOC is more as compared to RWOP and CRWOP which exponentially increases with respect to the number of active users. But other hand highest BER is observed in GMWRC which also follow similar kind of increment with respect to the number of active users. But performance wise RWOP is efficient one in comparison to other family due to lower BER. As in all cases RWOP give better result we intentionally took another value of K=6 and proceeded and corresponding Table 4 and Fig. 4 . Finally we reach to the conclusion that RWOP is efficient one in comparison to other code families with respect to above said parameters. 3 Conclusion Different types of code family are analysed for investigating the performance of FOCDMA. It is found that parameters such as cardinality (Nmax),Bit error rate(BER),Spreading Factor(Sf),Weight(K’), number of time chips(T) and Number of Wavelengths(WI) play vital role for the above analysis. In conclusion, simulation result revealed that row-wise orthogonal pairs (RWOP) code family gives high performance than others. For the bit error rate of 10−4 and 10−7, GMWRSC families present better performance up to 170 numbers of users. But when we include weights along with bit error rate RWOP turned out to be the best one.
