column2: Improve atmospheric visibility accuracy with the divergence angle correction of the probe beam
column3: Abstract The probe beam is the important part of the visibility meter. And the divergence angle size of the probe beam affects the accuracy of visibility. In the paper, the relation between the divergence angle and the visibility relative error was established by the experiment model. The aerosol generator produced different concentration atmosphere, which was measured as atmospheric sample under the different visibility. The relationship between the divergence angle of the probe beam and the different atmospheric samples was established. The detection values and correction function were obtained at different divergence angles under various atmospheric samples. The experimental result shows that the divergence angle of the probe beam affects the visibility measurement. And the larger the divergence angle is, the greater the measurement error is. The measurement of the divergence angle must be corrected. Using the measurement method with the divergence angle correction, under the low visibility conditions, the relative error of the visibility is reduced from 25% to 10% at least, in the divergence angle range of 25mrad. When the allowable error is 5%, the allowable value of the divergence angle is increased by one time.
column5: Keywords Divergence angle Atmosphere visibility Correction Optical power 1 Introduction According to the definition, visibility could be presented by the meteorological optical visual range. Meteorological optical visual range refers to the distance that the luminous flux weakens to 5% of initial value through the atmosphere, and the flux comes from the parallel beam of incandescent light which color temperature is 2700K [1]. In the definition, there is explicit requirement that the probe beam should be parallel. For transmissive visibility meter, when the probe beam is parallel, the transmittance T could be calculated that T = I I 0 , in the detection channel [2]. And the visibility R ∝ 1 I n T . The actual beam is not strict parallel in the measurement channel due to scattering, especially multiple scattering effects [3–5]. The visibility basic equation [6], Lambert-Beer law I = I 0 e −βL , has ignored multiple scattering effects. β is extinction coefficient, and Lis distance of measurement channel. When βL gets to a certain degree, multiple scattering effects cannot be ignored[7], which reduces the accuracy of Lambert-Beer law. Deepak and Zardecki had studied the relationship between the multiple scattering correction and the field of view in detail[8]. For scattering visibility meter, the receiving value is also affected by the emission angle of probe beam and the receiving field angle of detector. Xiao S et al. [9] used the combination of lens and fiber to constrain the viewing angle. The measurement value was near double compared to the unconstrained. However, due to the presence of the probe beam divergence angle [10–16], the detector’s sampling volume changes, which will cause the detection value to change. At the same time, during the installation and movement of the visibility meter, the divergence angle of the light source is likely to change. It will affect the detection value [17,18]. In order to study the influence of divergence angle on visibility, we took the different concentration aerosol as the atmospheric sample, and measured them. The visibility measurement model with different divergence angle was established. The accuracy of visibility measurement was improved by correcting the divergence angle. 2 Principle In the transmission visibility measuring device [19,20], the change of the position and the size of the divergence angle will cause the collimation error of the receiver [21,22]. When the divergence angle is too large, the spot cannot fall in the receiving plane completely. It will make the measurement error. When the collimation system corrects the collimation error in real time and the receiver has the lens, the spot can be ensured to fall in the center of the detector, and the collimation error is the smallest. From the aspect of the detector receiving light intensity and particle scattering, the scattering particles increases with a certain divergence angle. The secondary scattering and multiple scattering of the particles cause the widening of the brightness direction. Especially in the case of low visibility, multiple scattering cannot be ignored and its effect is significant. The impact on the detector receiving value also tends to be significant [2,3]. In the transmission visibility measurement device as shown in Fig. 1 , the probe beam divergence angle affects the receiver to determine the volume of the sample directly. At the same time, the detection value is also affected by wavelength, medium particle size, density, optical thickness and other factors. For a random medium volume V, in the direction of e S , a certain point r, its radiation brightness can be divided into two parts. One part is the brightness of the incident radiation in the direction, known as the reduction brightness. The other part is the contribution of other scatters in the direction of e S , known as the diffuse brightness. For the transmission visibility measurement device, the radiance received by the detector is the sum of the average reduced brightness and the average diffuse brightness in the whole range of the solid angle. They are (1) U r i ( r ) = 1 4 π ∫ 4 π L i ( r 0 , e S ) e − τ ( r ) d ω (2) U d ( r ) = 1 4 π ∫ V [ γ ∫ 4 π p ( e S , e S ′ ) L i ( r 1 , e S ′ ) d ω ′ + ε ( r 1 , e S ′ ) ] exp [ − τ ( r ) + τ ( r 1 ) ] | r − r 1 | 2 d V 1 The size of the probe beam divergence angle changes the volume of the medium V, which affects the average diffuse brightness directly, and also affects the detector's receiving value. However, when using Lambert-Beer law to calculate the visibility (3) R = L ln ε ln T = L ln ε ln I I 0 Where Llnε is the constant, I 0 is emitting light intensity, Iis receiving light intensity. I reflects the reduced brightness of the light source only. This needs to be measured at a very narrow angle in the direction of light advance [4,5]. When the probe beam has a certain divergence angle, the larger the angle, or the larger the size of particles in the detection channel, the greater the proportion of the diffuse brightness received by the receiver. Thus, it is necessary to correct the detector receiving value by the relationship between the divergence angle and the radiation brightness when calculate the visibility with Lambert-Beer's law. For transmissive measurement, the optical power can be analyzed by the relationship between the divergence angle of probe beam and the receiving value of the optical power. It is expressed as, (4) I t ′ = I t f ( θ ) where I t ′ is the theoretical value，I t is the measured value. The visibility is (5) R = L ln ε ln T = L ln ε ln I t ′ I 0 = L ln ε ln I t f ( θ ) I 0 = L ln ε ln U t f ( θ ) U 0 For the scattering visibility measurement, in the scattering direction, the integral volume is also affected by the divergence angle. The detector receiving value is also expressed as I t ′= I t f(θ). The visibility is (6) R = L ln ε K ⋅ ln I t f ( θ ) I 0 = L ln ε K ⋅ ln U t f ( θ ) U 0 where K is the constant. The Eq. (5) and (6) show that the visibility could be affected by the divergence angle of the probe beam directly. The equation (3) should be corrected with θ. 3 Experimental setup The experimental structure is designed. It is shown in Fig. 2 . The aerosol generator model is TDA-4B. There are the PAO oil, six nozzles and three control valves in the TDA −4B. The aerosol output flow can been controlled by adjusting the three control valves. The gas with the single particle is generated. The gas would be taken as the sample under the different visibility after the gas moves stably in the container. High pressure pure argon’s pressure was 13Mpa. It was pressed into the aerosol generator, adjusted by the control valve, and then went into the cylindrical closed container. The light source was adjusted to the parallel beam by the collimator lens. The parallel beam was divided into two groups by the beam splitter. One went through the aerosol directly. The other became the detection beam with a certain divergence angle under the convex lens adjustment. The size of the divergence angle was measured by the divergence angle measurement device. The two beams were received by the detectors and measured the optical power. A standard sample with an extinction coefficient of 0.003 m-1(μ =0.003m−1) was produced by the aerosol generator. The sample concentration can be increased by adjusting the control valves. The extinction coefficient also increased to 2μ, 3μ……9μ. Then, the standard aerosol samples were formed with the concentration from 1 time to 109 times. Took the laser diode as the detection beam light source, the divergence angle changed within 40 mrad. The adjusting effect of the convex lens in Fig. 2 is tested by the divergence angle measurement device [13]. 15 probe beams with a certain divergence angle were obtained, as shown in Table 1 . Adjusted the aerosol concentration at different beam divergence angles, or adjusted the beam divergence angle at each aerosol concentration in a state where the detector was always able to receive a complete spot. Multiple sets of optical power detection signals can be obtained 4 Experiment analysis 4.1 Divergence angle correction The probe beam was transmitted into the standard extinction coefficient sample. The control valves of the aerosol generator were adjusted to increase the sample concentration. In each concentration sample, the divergence angle of the probe beam was adjusted. And as the divergence angle changed step by step, the received optical power also changed, as shown in Fig. 3 . In Fig. 3, the sample concentration is from 1 to 9 times. When the sample concentration is low, the optical power is strong, the sample concentration is high, the optical power is weakened. When the concentration is above 5 times, the optical power is weak and the optical power values are close. As the divergence angle increases, the optical power decreases. The decrease in the low concentration is lower than the high concentration slightly. When the divergence angle is small, at each concentration, the optical power decrease is 5mw. With the divergence angle increasing, the optical power decrease expands to 7mw slightly. Each optical power value is normalized in Fig. 4 . By comparison, the polynomial g(θ)= p 1 θ 2 + p 2 θ + p 3is chosen as the fitting function. C1∼C9 are used to express the 1∼9 times concentration. After the polynomial fitting, the relation between the divergence angle and the optical power is shown in Fig. 5 . In Fig. 5, when the aerosol concentration is 1∼5 times, with the divergence angle increasing, the optical power decreases. The greater the divergence angle, the greater the optical power decreases. When the concentration is above 6 times, with the divergence angle increasing, the optical power decreases significantly. When the divergence angle is within 10mrad, the change of optical power is not significant at each concentration. At the same time, the parameters of the fitting curve are very close, and the average fitting function is obtained (7) g ( θ ) = p ¯ 1 θ 2 + p ¯ 2 θ + p ¯ 3 The coefficients p ¯ 1 、 p ¯ 2 、 p ¯ 3 are the divergence angle correction parameters. The parallel beam transmittance is expressed asT //, then (8) T / / = U t / / U 0 = U t g ( θ ) ⋅ U 0 By the Lambert-Beer's law I = I 0 e −βL , the extinction coefficient is (9) β = - ln T / / L = − ln U t g ( θ ) ⋅ U 0 L The visibility is (10) R = − ln ε β = L ln ε ln U t g ( θ ) ⋅ U 0 Contrast Eq. (5), there is g ( θ ) = 1 f ( θ ) . 4.2 Uncorrected result If the divergence angle do not be corrected, then (11) R = L ln ε ln T = L ln ε ln U t U 0 The visibility relative error is (12) Δ R R = ln T / / ( 1 ln T / / − 1 ln ( T / / ⋅ g ( θ ) ) The fitting result is shown in Fig. 6 . The greater the aerosol concentration, the greater the relative error of the visibility. When the relative error is 5%, the maximum allowable is 7∼12mrad at different aerosol concentrations. In order to ensure the effective visibility in different environments, the maximum value is 7mrad. When the relative error is 10%, the maximum allowable is 8∼15mrad at different aerosol concentrations. In order to ensure the effective visibility, the maximum value is 8mrad. And the divergence angle of the emission beam of the visibility instrument is often greater than the maximum allowable value, which will make the relative error of the visibility measurement greater. 4.3 Corrected result Using the aerosol as the measured atmospheric sample, when the real-time visibility was measured, the Eq.10 was used and the divergence angle was used to correct the result. After the calculation, the visibility relative error is (13) Δ R R = ln T / / ( 1 ln T / / − 1 ln ( U t U 0 ⋅ g ( θ ) ) ) It compared with the result that didn’t consider the divergence angle. The result was shown in Fig. 7 . There are two sets of curves in Fig. 7. The upper group is the relative error of the visibility at different divergence angles calculated from the measured values directly. The lower group is the relative error of the visibility obtained by adding the divergence angle correction. The relative error of the lower set of curves is smaller than the upper set of curves significantly. The upper set of curves don’t join the divergence angle correction, and the curve flat interval is 0–10mrad. When the divergence angle is more than 10mrad, the relative error is increased significantly. At 25mrad divergence angle, 9 times the concentration of aerosol, the relative error is the highest, reaching 60%, that is, the measurement error of low visibility value is very big. When the aerosol concentration decreases gradually, that is, the visibility increases gradually, the measurement error is reduced slightly. But the value is still high. At 7–8 times the concentration, the relative error is 48%. At 6 times concentration, the relative error is about 35%. At 1–5 times the concentration, the relative error is about 30%. In the lower set of curves, which were corrected with the divergence angle, the overall value of the relative error of the visibility is small relatively, and the curves overlap each other. It indicates that the relative error is close numerically. In the range of the divergence angle, the correction effect is consistent. When divergence angle is within 25mrad, the visibility of the relative error are relatively flat. At 25mrad, the error of the concentration of 1 times and 5 times is about 10%, and the error of other concentration is not more than 5%. However, it is 25%∼60% without divergence angle correction. At least, under the low visibility conditions, the relative error can be reduced to 40%. When the divergence angle is greater than 25mrad, the relative error increases. For the lower set of curves in Fig. 7, when the relative error is taken as 5%, under different aerosol concentration that is different atmospheric visibility, the transmitter divergence angle of the maximum allowable is 12mrad. For the upper set of curves, the maximum allowable angle is 7mrad. The lower value is nearly doubled from the upper value. When the relative error is taken as 10%, under different aerosol concentration, the transmitter divergence angle of the maximum allowable is 28mrad for the lower set of curves. For the upper set of curves, the maximum allowable angle is 8∼9mrad. The lower value increases by 2 times than the upper value. 5 Conclusion In this paper, the influence of atmospheric scattering on the detection beam and the influence of the divergence angle of the beam on the visibility measurement are discussed. Atmospheric samples with different concentrations are generated by the aerosol generator. The relationship between the probe beam divergence angle and the different atmospheric samples is established. Under various samples, the correction function of the detection value is obtained. The function takes the divergence angle as the parameter. The experimental results show that the divergence angle of the probe beam has the influence on the visibility measurement. The larger the divergence angle is, the greater the uncertainty of the visibility measurement. The divergence angle must be corrected. Using the measurement method with the divergence angle correction, the relative error of the visibility measurement can be reduced from 25% to 10% at least, under the low visibility conditions and the 25mrad divergence angle. Acknowledgments This work was supported by the Technology Support Program Foundation Projects of Jiangsu Province under Grant No.BE2010733, and the Public Welfare (meteorological) Industry-Specific Foundation Projects of Ministry of Science under Grant No.GYHY201166047.

column2: Theoretical analysis and experiments of pulsed laser circular-viewing system
column3: Abstract To realize detection of moving vehicles, the pulsed laser circular-viewing system is proposed. The principle of system is described. The scanning detection model of laser circular-viewing system is established based on best matching principle. The maximum range and minimum motor speed are deduced. Laser ranging system and azimuth detection system are designed. The system is fabricated to test. The experiments demonstrate that emission system is adjustable, and laser ranging error is within ±0.2m. The system possesses overload capacity at a certain degree.
column5: Keywords Pulse laser Circular-viewing detection Two-dimensional scan Laser ranging 1 Introduction Pulse laser circumferential detection system is a kind of 2D laser radar, which has been widely used in civil and military applications, such as outdoor unmanned navigation, indoor laser navigation, UAV barrier and laser imaging [1–6]. In autonomous navigation, it is critical for mobile robot to realize SLAM technology. Compared with other distance sensor, the laser radar can both consider the precision and speed requirements. Therefore, it can effectively improve the state estimation and moving target recognition, which becomes gradually a significant component to realize the robot's autonomous navigation. Laser pulse circumferential detection system is the single emission and received system for synchronous scanning detection. Laser divergence angle is small, short pulse duration, energy concentration with large instantaneous power. It can ensure the effective detection range [7]. However, in laser navigation, the laser pulse frequency and the scanning speed of the motor will directly affect the correct acquisition of the moving target. Gan [8–10] established target acquisition model and analyze target capture situation. The matching relation between the pulse frequency and scanning speed of motor and the capture rate were obtained. However, the model will appear in the case of leak scanning, which could not guarantee the effective detection of moving targets. Therefore, the best matching model should be established according to the moving target in the actual laser navigation. In laser navigation, not only the pulse frequency and the scanning speed of the motor affect the detection performance, but also the distance measurement accuracy will affect the whole map. Aiming at the problem of pulse laser ranging, KOU studied the influence of atmospheric turbulence on ranging accuracy [7]. ZHAO derived the Cramer-Rao lower bound of the ranging accuracy [11,12]. M.S. Oh reduced the walk error to improve the ranging accuracy [13]. In this paper, the principle of pulsed laser circular-viewing system is introduced in Section 2. In Section 3, the scanning detection model is established based on best matching principle, the maximum range and minimum motor speed are deduced. In Section 4, laser ranging system and azimuth detection system are designed according to deduced parameters. Finally, the experiments of laser emission system, laser ranging and anti overloads are verified the system performance. 2 Principle of laser circular-viewing detection system Laser circular-viewing system working principle: The control system produce periodic pulse signal to trigger driving power. The driving power generates narrow pulse current to drive LD. The laser beam is converted into parallel light through the collimating lens. The drive control system controls the motor, and the motor speed and azimuth information are acquired in real time through the encoder. The laser beam is incident on a flat mirror fixed on the motor. With the rotation of the motor, the measured object is irradiated by laser beam. Some scattered light from the reflection mirror incident on laser focusing lens. The light generates photon once into photoelectric detector. Then, the echo signal is obtained by photoelectric amplifier module. After time discrimination system, laser ranging is realized. The working principle of the pulse laser circumferential detection system is shown in Fig. 1 . 3 Scanning detection model The laser circumferential scanning detection model is drawn in Fig. 2 . In Fig. 2(b), if the divergence of laser through a collimating lens output angle is bigger, repetition point more likely appears. The dense scanning model will affect the imaging quality. As shown in Fig. 2(c), if the laser divergence through the collimating lens output angle is smaller, the leakage point phenomenon more likely occurs. Therefore, it is easy to leak the point with sparse scanning model in the actual detection target. The best scan detection model is shown in Fig. 2(a). We have the optimum matching model when the laser divergence angle after the collimated lens is the same as the encoder resolution. Therefore, the matching of motor speed, encoder resolution, and laser emission frequency and laser divergence angle is vital. According to the scanning matching model, the equation is available. (1) 2 π φ / 1000 = δ (2) 1 n / 60 = 2 π φ / 1000 1 f Where, n(r/min) is the motor speed, f(kHz) is pulse laser emission frequency，φ(mrad) is laser divergence angle, and δ is the encoder resolution. The laser system detects vehicle after acquiring the matched scanning model. vr is relative velocity. Based the principle of scanning vehicle at least twice, the relationship between motor speed and the relative velocity could be calculated after motion estimation. (3) d 1 = x 1 sin ( π - α ) The distance of moving target is: (4) Δ x = R max 2 − d 1 2 + l Where R max is maximum detection range, l is target length. The motor speed is: (5) 1 n / 60 ≤ Δ x v r The motor speed can be calculated by substituting Eqs. (3) and (4) into Eq. (5): (6) n ≥ 60 v r R max 2 − x 1 2 sin 2 α + l Based on the properties of inequality, the minimum motor speed is (7) n min = 60 v r l The laser ranging equation can be used to estimate the maximum detection range and its influence factors, and the lateral area of target is much larger than laser facula area. Therefore, we can obtain the received power by changing equation form: (8) P R = ρ P k T e T r T f D 2 cos β 4 R 2 × e − 2 σ R Where ρ is the reflectivity of target, Pk is the peak power, Te is optical transmittance for emission optical system, Tr is transmittance for focusing lens, Tf is transmittance of narrowband filter, β is the angle between the target reflection surface normal to the optical axis, D is the optical system aperture diameter of the receiver, R is the detection range, σ is atmospheric extinction coefficient. According to the Eq. (7), we can obtain the maximum detection range is: (9) R max = ρ P k T e T r T f D 2 cos β 4 P R × e − 2 σ R The basic parameters of simulation are as follows: ρ=0.1, PR=100nW, Te =0.8, Tr =0.8, Tf =0.8, β=0, D =15mm, Pk=20W, vr=60km/h, l =2m.We can obtain the Required parameters: Rmax = 24m, nmin = 500 r/min. 4 The system design 4.1 The design of laser system The SPLPL90-3 is used in the system, whose wavelength is 905nm. The pulse width is adjustable, and the supply voltage is 20V. The maximum peak power reaches 70W. Photoelectric detector uses APD avalanche photodiode, which type is AD500-9 TO52S1. Its rise time is 0.55ns. When the amplify gain is 100, 905nm wavelength response of APD is 60A/W. APD comes with filter. The external amplification circuit uses OPA657 transimpedance amplifier to carry out two stage amplification, and the gain bandwidth product of the OPA657 is 1.6GHz, and the amplification capability can be effectively improved under the condition that the received bandwidth is guaranteed. In optical system design respect, the optical collimation system and the optical received system don’t adopt the multistage optical system in general. The single stage single optical lens is used. Compared with the spherical optical system, aspheric optical system has great advantages of improving the relative aperture ratio of the system, expanding the viewing angle, improving the beam quality, miniaturizing lens shape, and reducing system weight. Based on transmitting and receiving optical isolation in physical structure, the laser collimation lens and laser focusing lens were designed employing aspheric technology in the laser circular-viewing system. Two lenses are coated to improve the transmittance of laser beam. The system circuit is mainly composed of laser ranging circuit, azimuth calculation circuit and power circuit. The threshold method in laser ranging circuit is utilized to realize the time discrimination of the APD received laser echo signal. Combining C8051F310 and TDC-GP21, the laser flight time is calculated to estimate range. C8051F310 is LQFP package, small size, and low power consumption. TDC-GP21 possesses small size and high accuracy with time resolution of 22ps. Both of them meet the requirements of the circuit system miniaturization design. Azimuth angle is achieved by azimuth calculation circuit combining with motor encoder, which is mainly realized by single chip microcomputer. The power circuit is composed of low voltage boost circuit and high voltage boost circuit. The low voltage boost circuit is designed with the boost chip as the core. However, the high voltage boost circuit is constructed by discrete components, which is realized by PFM modulation using discontinuous inductor mode. 4.2 The design of azimuth detection system The system adopts stepping motor with closed-loop control. The high precision optical incremental encoder is installed in the traditional two-phase stepper motor on rear axle. The encoder has real-time characteristics of rotor position, driver can real-time monitor the motor shaft position to compensate the displacement error, which ensures accurate positioning. When the load changes suddenly, the traditional open-loop stepper motor without encoder feedback will appear lost step. The principle of encoder is shown in Fig. 3 . The DSP control circuit acquires the encoder signal. As signal of Z phase is measured, the output signal is recorded as 0°. When signal of B phase is measured, DSP control circuit counts 1. Then we can convert the count value to angular position information. The minimum speed of the motor is 500r/min. In order to guarantee the stable encoder information, the stability control of the motor must be guaranteed, Then, PI regulation control, the speed and current double closed loop control, is adopted. The mathematical model of the algorithm is shown in Fig. 4 : 5 Experiments 5.1 Experiments of laser emission system In the design processing of laser driving circuit, the IXDD409 MOSFET driver is used with 1nF charging capacitor. The power supply voltage is 200V, and test resistances were 0Ω, 1Ω, 2.5Ω and 5Ω. SPLPL90-3 voltage waves are in Fig. 5 . With the increase of resistance of laser driving circuit, the current value is reduced, the peak current are 30A, 25A, 10A and 8A. The pulse width of test current waveform is also reduced, pulse width are 6.4ns, 8.6ns, 14.82ns, 16ns. Due to the adoption of IXDD409 MOSFET driver, the current of MOSFET tube is large, and the rising edge time is short. The rising edges are 4ns, 5ns, 10ns and 12ns respectively. The designed circuit can realize the control function of pulse width, power and waveform. 5.2 Laser ranging experiments Measurement experiment of 10m at different angles was done. The experimental results statistics is shown in Fig. 6 . After removing the outliers, the ranging results are lower than 10m. With the increase of tilt angle, the average distance measurement increases. In order to quantify the distance measurement results, the mean and standard deviations of different tilt angles are calculated, and the results are shown in Table 1 . It can be seen from the table that the standard deviation of ranging is lower than 0.04m. The error of single range measurement is not only affected by time interval, but also affected by many factors, such as comparator time jitter and noise. Meanwhile, the system error is corrected. The distance measurement results from different angles show that the ranging result is between 9.200m and 9.510m. 5.3 Anti overloads experiments In the running process of the system, system usually need to bear huge overload, due to the and structure precision and material particularity of laser optical system and rotary scanning system, the focal distance and coaxiality may change after bearing high overload. The accuracy and reliability of the laser circumferential detection are seriously affected. In order to improve high overload capacity of optical module, integrated design method of mechanical structure is applied. The polycarbonate is adapted to fabrication of optical lens. The commonly used cushion gasket materials are tetrafluoroethylene, rubber, industrial felt and aluminum, and their wave impedance values are small. The tetrafluoroethylene cushion gasket is used to reduce the overload of the impact on the laser transmitting and receiving optical system and the whole anti plane mirror. The anti overloads ability of the motor in the rotating scanning module is reduced by the encapsulation technology. The rotating scanning module is integrally arranged in the motor seat, and the motor seat is encapsulated from the outside. The fixture structure is shown in Fig. 7 . The acceleration sensor is connected by thread on the fixture. The fixture is assembled on the principle prototype of laser circular-viewing detection system. The acceleration value of the acceleration sensor is recorded with hammer tests and air cannon experiments. The measured acceleration curves are shown in Fig. 8 and Fig. 9 . From Fig. 8, the acceleration peak reaches about 5000g and the pulse width is about 500us. As can be seen from Fig. 9, the acceleration peak reaches 34000g, and the pulse width is about 300us. After the anti high overload test of the optical system, the mechanical structure of the prototype has not been damaged, the motor can still operate normally, and the principle prototype can still carry out the target detection experiment. 6 Conclusions To realize detection of moving vehicles, the pulsed laser circular-viewing system is described. The scanning detection model of laser circular-viewing system is established based on best matching principle. Laser ranging system and azimuth detection system are designed and fabricated to test. The emission system is adjustable. It provides a favorable guarantee for laser navigation.

column2: Optical solitons in monomode fibers with higher order nonlinear Schrödinger equation
column3: Abstract The article studies the dynamics of optical single and combined solitons in monomode optical fibers which are described by higher order nonlinear Schrödinger equation. As a result, the bright, dark and singular optical 1-solitons and dark-singular, combo singular optical solitons have been extracted. The beauty of this research work is, one can obtain single and combined optical solitons using five parameters in a single integration technique. Moreover, the graphical representations are also depicted.
column5: Keywords Higher order nonlinear Schrödinger equation Optical solitons Monomode fibers Integrability 1 Introduction In dispersive medium, the propagation of nonlinear waves is of great interest in the recent era of contemporary science and technology. The nonlinear transformation of dielectric of the fiber termed as the Kerr effect, is applied to neutralize the dispersion effect, in this state the optical pulse form a steady nonlinear pulse termed as optical soliton. The bit rate of transmission is limited by the dispersion of the fiber material. The fiber loss is the only factor that contributes to the drop of the pulse quality by expansion in the pulse width which are caused by microdeformations such as microbends of the fiber axis and random fluctuations of the fiber core diameter, for details see [1–6]. In last some decades, both mathematician and physicist have made much efforts in finding the analytic solutions to a number of nonlinear models. As a result, many powerful techniques are introduced to deal with problems involving nonlinear complex phenomena of nature, which play a vital role in physical sciences, such as inverse scattering scheme [7], B a ¨ cklund transform method [8], homogeneous balance scheme [9], Painlev e ´ expansion [10], sine-cosine method, Darboux transformation, Lie group analysis, mapping method and extended mapping method [11,12], Exp-function method [13], rational expansion method [14], Adomian decomposition method [15,16], homotopy perturbation method [17], homotopy analysis method [18], differential transform method, reduced differential method, tanh-coth method [20–22], simplified Hirota's method, extended homoclinic test approach [19], transformed rational function method [21], Hirota's bilinear method [23], Bernoulli's equation approach [26], semi-inverse variational principle [27], ansatz scheme [28], complex envelope function ansatz method [29], generalized Kudryashov method [30] and many more. In the literature, a variety of suitable methods are adopted to investigate the behavior of the nonlinear equations. The study about solutions, structures, interaction and further properties of soliton abstracts is given much more attention in the recent past. A strong relation is found among the general elliptic equation and most of the existing sub-equations like the Riccati equation, auxiliary equation [31], first kind elliptic equation, and generalized Riccati equation [32], but also helps us to find more and new exact solutions to NPDEs. As a result, some new and more general exact traveling wave solutions are obtained, see also [33–38]. The extended Fan Sub-equation method is successfully applied to construct travelling wave solutions of higher order nonlinear Schrödinger (HNLS) equation illustrating the linear and the nonlinear dispersion as well as dissipation effects in monomode fibers [4]. The HNLS model reduces to the integrable nonlinear Schrödinger equation by eliminating the last three expressions. Mathematica 10.4 is used to carried out simulations and contour plot have been applied to visualize the behavior of optical waves. The governing systems are read as: (1) ∂ Φ ∂ z = i ς 1 ∂ 2 Φ ∂ t 2 + ς 2 | Φ | 2 Φ + ς 3 ∂ 3 Φ ∂ t 3 + ς 4 ∂ ∂ t | Φ | 2 Φ + ς 5 Φ ∂ ∂ t | Φ | 2 where the coefficients ς j for j =1, 2, 3, 4, 5; are real constants. This article has been devised as follows: in Section 2, the solutions to the HNLS equation is presented while in Section 3, the physical behaviour of the solutions is discussed. In last Section 4, the conclusions have been drawn. 2 Solitons for HNLS equation In order to extract optical solitons, one may have the following starting hypothesis, the wave profile is split into amplitude and phase components, respectively, as (2) Φ ( z , t ) = e i ψ Ω ( ξ ) , where ξ = β ( ν t + z ) , The Ω(ξ) is the amplitude components of the wave profiles, while the phase factor is given by (3) ψ = k z + ω t + θ , where k, ω and θ represent the frequency of the solitons, the wave number and the phase constant respectively. By using (10) into (1), and comparing the real and imaginary parts (4) 3 β ς 4 ν + 2 ς 5 ν β Ω 2 Ω ′ − β 3 ς 3 ν 3 Ω ( 3 ) + 3 β ς 3 ν ω 2 + 2 β ν ς 1 ω + β Ω ′ = 0 (5) 3 ς 4 ω + 2 ς 5 ω − ς 2 Ω 3 − 3 β 2 ς 3 ν 2 ω + β 2 ς 1 ν 2 Ω ″ + k + ς 3 ω 3 + ς 1 ω 2 Ω = 0 integrating (4), and neglecting the constant of integration (6) 1 3 3 β ς 4 ν + 2 ς 5 ν β Ω 3 + β 3 ς 3 − ν 3 Ω ″ + 3 β ς 3 ν ω 2 + 2 β ν ς 1 ω + β Ω = 0 from (5) and (6), we have the relation between the coefficients (7) ς 1 = − 3 ς 2 ς 3 3 ς 4 + 2 ς 5 and for any arbitrary constant α, the parameters (8) β = 1 4 α η 3 ς 3 ( 3 ς 4 + 2 ς 5 ) ν 2 − 9 η 3 ς 2 ς 3 ν − 9 η 3 ς 4 ν ς 1 − 6 η 3 ς 5 ν ς 1 − 3 η 2 / 3 − 3 ς 2 2 ς 3 2 ν 2 − 3 ( 3 ς 4 + 2 ς 5 ) 2 ν ς 1 2 + 6 ς 3 ( 3 ς 4 + 2 ς 5 ) ν ( − ς 2 ν ς 1 + 3 ς 4 + 2 ς 5 ) , (9) ω = 1 4 η 3 ς 3 ( 3 ς 4 + 2 ς 5 ) ν ς 2 2 ς 3 2 ( − ν 2 ) − 2 ς 2 ( 3 ς 4 + 2 ς 5 ) ς 3 ν ν ς 1 + ( 3 ς 4 + 2 ς 5 ) 2 ( 2 ς 3 ν − ν ς 1 2 ) + η 3 ( − η 3 + ς 2 ς 3 ν − ( 3 ς 4 + 2 ς 5 ) ν ς 1 ) where η = 1 216 ( 46656 ( ( 3 ς 4 + 2 ς 5 ) 3 ( 4 k ς 3 2 ν 3 + 3 ς 3 ν ν ς 1 − ν ς 1 3 ) + ς 2 3 ς 3 3 ν 3 + 3 ς 2 2 ( 3 ς 4 + 2 ς 5 ) ς 3 2 ν 2 ν ς 1 + 3 ς 2 ( 3 ς 4 + 2 ς 5 ) 2 ς 3 ν ( 3 ς 3 ν − ν ς 1 2 ) ) 2 + ( 72 ς 3 ( 3 ς 4 + 2 ς 5 ) ν ( − 2 ς 2 ν ς 1 + 3 ς 4 + 2 ς 5 ) − 36 ( ς 2 ς 3 ν − ( 3 ς 4 + 2 ς 5 ) ν ς 1 ) 2 ) 3 ) 1 2 − ς 3 2 ν 3 ( 4 k ( 3 ς 4 + 2 ς 5 ) 3 + ς 3 ς 2 3 ) − 3 ς 2 ς 3 2 ( 3 ς 4 + 2 ς 5 ) ν 2 ( ς 2 ν ς 1 + 9 ς 4 + 6 ς 5 ) + ( 3 ς 4 + 2 ς 5 ) 3 ν ς 1 3 − 3 ς 3 ( 3 ς 4 + 2 ς 5 ) 2 ν ν ς 1 ( − ς 2 ν ς 1 + 3 ς 4 + 2 ς 5 ) Eq. (6) can be re-written as (10) δ 1 Ω ″ + δ 2 Ω 3 + δ 3 Ω = 0 where δ 1 = β 3 ς 3 − ν 3 , δ 2 = 1 3 3 β ς 4 ν + 2 ς 5 ν β , δ 3 = 3 β ς 3 ν ω 2 + 2 β ν ς 1 ω + β By applying the homogeneous balance to (10), we have n =1. Suppose (10), have the solution of the form (11) Ω = a 0 + a 1 ϕ ( ξ ) where ϕ satisfies the following general elliptic equation, (12) d ϕ ( ξ ) d ξ 2 = ζ 0 + ζ 1 ϕ ( ξ ) + ζ 2 ϕ 2 ( ξ ) + ζ 3 ϕ 3 ( ξ ) + ζ 4 ϕ 4 ( ξ ) , ζ i (i =0, 1, 2, 3, 4) are real constants. Substituting (11) along (12) in (10) and collecting the coefficients of ϕ j ϕ (k), 1 3 a 0 3 δ 1 + a 0 δ 3 + 1 2 a 1 δ 2 ζ 1 = 0 , a 1 a 0 2 δ 1 + a 1 δ 3 + a 1 δ 2 ζ 2 = 0 , a 0 a 1 2 δ 1 + 3 2 a 1 δ 2 ζ 3 = 0 , 1 3 a 1 3 δ 1 + 2 a 1 δ 2 ζ 4 = 0 we select variables suitably, to have the most of ζ i , (i =0, 1, 2, 3, 4). ζ 1 = − 2 a 0 3 δ 1 + 3 a 0 δ 3 3 a 1 δ 2 , ζ 2 = − a 0 2 δ 1 + δ 3 δ 2 , ζ 3 = − 2 a 0 a 1 δ 1 3 δ 2 , ζ 4 = − a 1 2 δ 1 6 δ 2 therefore, (13) Φ ( x . t ) = ( a 0 + a 1 ϕ ( ξ ) ) e i ψ We have following soliton solutions, for more details see also [24,25]. Case I. If ζ 0 = ϑ 3 2 , ζ 1 = 2 ϑ 1 ϑ 3 , ζ 2 = 2 ϑ 2 ϑ 3 + ϑ 1 2 , ζ 3 = 2 ϑ 1 ϑ 2 , ζ 4 = ϑ 2 2 , there may exist parameters ϑ 1, ϑ 2, satisfy ϑ 3, the solutions of (1) are q η I , ( η = 1 , 2 , … , 24 ) . Some of important optical solitons are listed below. Type I: when ϑ 1 2 − 4 ϑ 2 ϑ 3 > 0 , ϑ 1 ϑ 2 ≠0, ϑ 2 ϑ 3 ≠0. The following dark optical soliton is obtained. For ζ 0 =1− m 2, ζ 2 =2m 2 −1, ζ 4 = m 2, the solutions of (1) is of the form Φ 3 IV ( ξ ) = cn ξ gives the combined wave solutions for m →1, Φ 3 IV ( ξ ) = − 3 β ς 3 ν ω 2 − 2 β ς 1 ν ω − β + β 3 ς 3 − 1 − 2 m 2 ν 3 2 β ς 5 ν + 3 β ς 4 + i 6 m 2 sech ( ξ ) − β 3 ς 3 ν 3 2 β ς 5 ν + 3 β ς 4 × e i ψ and the periodic singular solutions for m →0, Φ 3 IV ( ξ ) = − 3 β ς 3 ν ω 2 − 2 β ς 1 ν ω − β + β 3 ς 3 − 1 − 2 m 2 ν 3 2 β ς 5 ν + 3 β ς 4 + i 6 m 2 cosh ( ξ ) − β 3 ς 3 ν 3 2 β ς 5 ν + 3 β ς 4 × e i ψ for ζ 0 = 1 4 , ζ 2 = 1 − 2 m 2 2 , ζ 4 = 1 4 , the solutions of (1) is of the form Φ 13 IV ( ξ ) = ns ξ ± cs ξ gives the combined wave solutions for m →1, Φ 13 IV ( ξ ) = − 3 β ς 3 ν ω 2 − 2 β ς 1 ν ω − β − 1 2 β 3 ς 3 2 m 2 − 1 ν 3 2 β ς 5 ν + 3 β ς 4 + i 3 2 − β 3 ς 3 ν 3 ( coth ( ξ ) + csch ( ξ ) ) 2 β ς 5 ν + 3 β ς 4 × e i ψ and the periodic singular solutions for m →0, Φ 13 IV ( ξ ) = − 3 β ς 3 ν ω 2 − 2 β ς 1 ν ω − β − 1 2 β 3 ς 3 2 m 2 − 1 ν 3 2 β ς 5 ν + 3 β ς 4 + i 3 2 − β 3 ς 3 ν 3 ( cot ( ξ ) + csc ( ξ ) ) 2 β ς 5 ν + 3 β ς 4 × e i ψ 3 Physical description The graphical representation of solitons have been illustrated in the following figures, for various values of the parameters. Fig. 1 illustrates the optical solutions produced in Case I, whereas Fig. 2 describes the optical solutions produced in Case II, and Fig. 3 represents the optical solutions produced in Case III, while Fig. 4 visualizes the optical solutions produced in Case IV respectively. 4 Conclusions In this study, the traveling wave solutions to higher order nonlinear Schr o ¨ dinger equation have been extracted with the help of the extended Fan Sub-equation method and symbolic computation. The solutions are obtained with the help of five different parameters which are explicit, periodic and combined solutions to analyse the propagation of short light pulses in an optical fiber, see Figs. 1–4. These results are new and very auspicious for further investigation and stances on a strong basis for the solution of many complex nonlinear models arising in contemporary physics.

column2: Synthesis and luminescence properties of Ca5-x (PO4)3Br: xEu2+—A novel blue-emitting bromapatite phosphor for near-ultraviolet-pumped white light-emitting diodes
column3: Abstract A series of novel Ca5-x (PO4)3Br: xEu2+ (x =0.01–0.10) blue phosphors were synthesized via the conventional solid state reaction and their luminescence properties were reported. The Ca5-x (PO4)3Br: xEu2+ phosphors could be excited efficiently in the wavelength range of 320–440nm and displayed an intense asymmetric blue emission band around 458nm under 365nm excitation. The concentration quenching of Eu2+ in the Ca5(PO4)3Br host was investigated in detail. The optimum doping concentration of Eu2+ was determined to be 0.07 and the energy transfer mechanism was certified to be the dipole–dipole interaction. Moreover, the CIE chromaticity coordinates for the composition-optimized Ca4.93(PO4)3Br: 0.07Eu2+ were located in the blue region at (x =0.1450, y =0.0840), whose color purity was close to that of the commercial blue phosphor BaMgAl10O17: Eu2+. All these results gave an indication that Ca5-x (PO4)3Br: xEu2+ phosphors could serve as a promising blue-emitting candidate for near-UV-pumped white light-emitting diodes.
column5: Keywords Phosphors Luminescence Ca5-x(PO4)3Br: xEu2+ White LEDs 1 Introduction Compared with the conventional fluorescent and incandescent lamps, solid state lighting based on white light-emitting diodes (LEDs) shows superior properties such as the low energy consumption, high efficiency, and environmental friendliness [1–3]. White LEDs can be successfully fabricated by combining a yellow-emitting phosphor (Y1-a Gd a )3(Al1-b Ga b )5O12: Ce3+ (YAG: Ce3+) with a blue light gallium nitride (GaN) LED chip. However, due to the limitation of red spectral power distribution, the resulting cool and glare white light restricts the application of general illumination [4–6]. Alternatively, the white light can be generated to couple tricolor phosphors [BaMgAl10O17: Eu2+ (BAM: Eu2+) for blue, ZnS: (Cu+, Al3+) for green, and Sr2Si5N8: Eu2+ for red] with near-ultraviolet (near-UV, 360–400nm) light chips in order to obtain warm-white LEDs with adequate correlated color temperature (CCT <4000K) and sufficient color rendering indexes (CRI >80) [7]. Unfortunately, the commercial blue phosphor BAM: Eu2+ is known to be unsatisfactory for the rigorous synthesis condition (its synthetic temperature is 1623K) as well as the loss of radiation efficiency and color during thermal treatment, which inspirits us to explore desirable blue-emitting phosphors to meet the requirement for near-UV-pumped white LEDs [8]. Attributing to the 4f-5d electric-dipole allowed transitions, the luminescence of the bivalent europium (Eu2+) ion usually covers wide electro-magnetic range from the ultraviolet to the red region, depending on the different host matrices. Thus, the emission color can be tailored by the choice of the host matrix [9]. Thereinto, apatites with alkline-earth metal ions whose radii are comparable to that of Eu2+ ions are considered as potential matrices owing to their low synthesis temperature, high luminous efficiency and good stability [10]. For instance, Eu2+-doped Sr5(PO4)3Cl [11], Ba5(PO4)3Cl [12], and Ba2Y3(SiO4)3F [13] phosphors have been reported to be efficient luminescence materials for LEDs. In 1974, the calcium bromapatite Ca5(PO4)3Br was successfully prepared by Dykes [14]. Afterwards, Elliott et al. further pointed out it is a typical hexagonal apatite structure with lattice constants a =9.761(1)Å, c =6.739(1)Å, V =556.06 Å3, Z =2 [15]. In 2016, the luminescence properties of M5(PO4)3X: Eu2+ (M=Ca, Sr, Ba; X=F, Cl, Br) are discussed systematically by Donghyeon Kim et al. [16]. However, in that paper, no detailed research, such as the relationship between Eu2+ emission peaks and its occupied sites, and the concentration quenching as well as the energy transfer process, has been done to the Eu2+-doped Ca5(PO4)3Br phosphors. Therefore, in this study, the luminescence characteristics of Ca5-x (PO4)3Br: xEu2+ phosphors have been investigated detailedly. Moreover, the crystallographic site-occupations of Eu2+ ions were inferred to further understand the luminescence mechanism and energy transfer process from Eu(1)2+ to Eu(2)2+. As shown in this paper, Ca5-x (PO4)3Br: xEu2+ phosphors are expected to be the possible blue-emitting luminescent materials for near-UV white LEDs. 2 Experimental A series of Ca5-x (PO4)3Br: xEu2+ (x =0.01, 0.03, 0.05, 0.07, 0.09, 0.10) samples were prepared by the solid state reaction method using CaO (analytical reagent, A.R.), NH4H2PO4 (A.R.), CaBr2·2H2O (A.R.), Eu2O3 (99.99%) as the raw materials. The required stoichiometric amounts of these reagents were weighed and thoroughly mixed in an agate mortar. Then the homogeneous mixtures were sintered at 500°C for 2h and subsequently sintered at 800°C for 6h in CO reducing atmosphere. After cooling to ambient temperature, the samples were ground again to give the final phosphors. The crystallization process of the complex precursor was examined by thermogravimetry-differential thermal analysis (TG-DTA, SDT-600), using a sample weight of about 5.52mg and a heating rate of 10°C/min in air atmosphere. The scanning electron morphology (SEM) of the phosphor particles was examined using a field-emission electron microscope (Nova Nano SEM450). The phase structure of the prepared powder samples was characterized using a X-ray powder diffraction spectroscopy (XRD, D8 Advance) with Cu Kα radiation (λ=0.15405nm) at 40kV, 30mA, and a scan speed of 12.0° (2θ)/min from 10° to 70°. Diffuse reflection spectra of as-synthesized phosphors were measured on a UV–vis spectrophotometer (U-3900H, Hitachi) attached to an integral sphere. BaSO4 was used as a reference standard. The photoluminescence (PL) and photoluminescence excitation (PLE) spectra were recorded on a fluorescence spectrophotometer (F-7000, Hitachi) with a 150W xenon lamp under a working voltage of 400V. The fluorescence lifetime were determined on a HORIBA Jobin Yvon fluorolog (FL3-22) by monitoring the given emission from the samples under the 370nm pulsed laser excitation. 3 Results and discussion To understand the pyrolysis behavior and crystallization process, the TG-DTA profile of Ca5(PO4)3Br precursor is displayed in Fig. 1 a. When the temperature is raised at a rate of 10°C/min from 20°C to 830°C, a total weight loss of nearly 36% and four endothermic peaks (at 113°C, 200°C, 386°C and 515°C) are given in TG-DTA curve. Accordingly, the pyrolysis and crystallization process of the precursor can be roughly divided into three stages. The first stage, corresponding to a mass loss of 13.92% starting from 20°C to 200°C shown in the TG curve which is evidenced by two strong endothermic peaks around 113°C and 200°C in the DTA curve, originates the beginning of dehydration of CaBr2·2H2O and decomposition of NH4H2PO4. The second stage shows a mass loss of 21.23% from 200°C to 675°C, which is corresponding to two relatively weak endothermic peaks around 386°C and 515°C. In this stage, the mass loss is attributed to the process of continuous dehydration of CaBr2·2H2O and decomposition of NH4H2PO4. The endothermic peak around 386°C is assigned to the phase formation such as calcium pyrohosphate Ca2P2O7 and calcium phosphate-tribasic Ca3(PO4)2, which has been proved by our testified XRD pattern in Fig. 1b. Another endothermic peak around 515°C should correspond to the beginning of the new Ca5(PO4)3Br phase formation, which has also been confirmed by XRD characterization in Fig. 1c. In the third stage, the weight remains invariable as the temperature over 675°C in the TG curve, indicating that the processes of precursor decomposition and reaction have been finished. Therefore, the cystallization of the Ca5(PO4)3Br precursor entirely completes at 675°C. The XRD patterns of the representative Ca5-x (PO4)3Br: xEu2+ (x =0.01, 0.10) samples, together with the JCPDS card for Ca5(PO4)3Br (no. 74-0672), are presented in Fig. 2 . It is observed that all the diffraction peaks of the samples are in good agreement with those of the Ca5(PO4)3Br host. Besides, the same results are also found in Ca5-x (PO4)3Br: xEu2+ (x =0.03, 0.05, 0.07, 0.09) samples, indicating that the doping of Eu2+ ions between 0.01 and 0.10 does not induce any remarkable structure changes of the pure Ca5(PO4)3Br. As Fig. 3 shows, the bromapatite Ca5(PO4)3Br belongs to the hexagonal crystal structure with space group P 63/m. The structure is composed of six PO4 groups surrounded by ten Ca atoms with two Br ions. The ten Ca atoms are arranged on two non-equivalent sites Ca1 and Ca2. Each Ca1 cation with six coordination numbers is surrounded by PO4 groups only, while each Ca2 cation with seven coordination numbers is located at the periphery of c-axis-oriented tunnels that also accommodate Br anions in a central position. On the basis of the effective ionic radii of cations with different coordination numbers, the Eu2+ ions are expected to substitute Ca2+ ions in the Ca5(PO4)3Br host since the radii of Eu2+ (r =1.17Å for CN=6 and r =1.20Å for CN=7) are similar to those of Ca2+ (r =1.00Å for CN=6 and r =1.06Å for CN=7) [17]. Furthermore, the morphology of the Ca4.93(PO4)3Br: 0.07Eu2+ phosphor was studied using imaging techniques such as SEM. As shown in Fig. 4 , the SEM image of the phosphor reflects the inherent nature of the adopted solid state method. The particles are aggregated and show the irregular shapes with less than 7μm size. It is inferred that the phosphor is polycrystalline that consists of many single crystallite units. The diffuse reflection spectra of the Ca5(PO4)3Br host and Ca4.93(PO4)3Br: 0.07Eu2+ phosphor are illustrated in Fig. 5 . For the undoped sample, the onset of the diffuse reflection curve is around 310nm and it rapidly increases until up to 450nm, which results from the valence-to-conduction band transitions of the Ca5(PO4)3Br host lattice [18]. For the Ca4.93(PO4)3Br: 0.07Eu2+ sample, however, a strong and broad absorption band can be seen from the reflection spectrum. Due to the absence of such a band in undoped Ca5(PO4)3Br, the very broad absorption band from 310 to 450nm is assigned to the 4f7(8S7/2)–4f65d transitions of the Eu2+ ions [9]. Furthermore, a high and similar reflectance platform appears in the wavelength range of 450–800nm for both samples. Based on the above analysis, we can conclude that doping Eu2+ in the Ca5(PO4)3Br host can enhance optical absorption in near-UV region. In addition, the fundamental absorption edge of the Ca5(PO4)3Br host can be determined by the following equation [19,20] (1) Αhʋ=A(hʋ−Eg)n where h is Planck’s constant, A is the absorption constant, Eg is the optical bandgap energy, n is a constant exponent which determines the type of optical transitions. In this paper, for this Ca5(PO4)3Br host, n=0.5. α is absorption coefficient and is proportional to F(R), which can be expressed by the following equation [21] (2) F(R)= ( 1 − R ) 2 2R where R can be considered as the experimental reflectance in our sample. F(R) is the Kubelka-Munk function. The inset of Fig. 5 shows the plot of {[F(R)]hʋ}2 versus hʋ. A tangent line is drawn in the near edge region of the curve which is converted from Fig. 5. Hence, the bandgap energy Eg is determined to be 3.795eV by the crossing point of the tangent line and the horizontal axis. Fig. 6 depicts the PLE (λem =458nm) and PL (λex =365nm) spectra of the representative Ca4.93(PO4)3Br: 0.07Eu2+ phosphor. The PLE spectrum contains two broad absorption bands from 320 to 440nm originating from the 4f7(8S7/2)–4f65d transitions of Eu2+ ions, indicating that the excitation wavelength of Ca5-x (PO4)3Br: xEu2+ phosphors matches well with the output wavelength of near-UV light chips [9]. The PL spectrum exhibits a 38.2nm full width at half-maximum (FWHM) asymmetric broad emission band located at 458nm, which can be ascribed to the 4f65d-4f7(8S7/2) transitions of Eu2+ ions [9]. It is well known that the emission of the Eu2+ activator is quite related to its lattice site occupation, and thus often gives the different emission wavelengths. Therefore, the asymmetric emission band of Ca4.93(PO4)3Br: 0.07Eu2+ phosphor indicates that there may exist different types of Eu2+ luminescent centers. As demonstrated in Fig. 6, the asymmetric emission hump can be deconvoluted into two Gaussian bands (short-dot lines in Fig. 6) with peaks at 456 and 467nm, respectively. As given in the former crystallographic coordination information of the Ca5(PO4)3Br lattice, we can infer that the Eu2+ ions substitute two Ca2+ crystallographic sites with different coordination numbers 6 and 7, which results in two luminescence centers corresponding to two fitted emission bands in Ca5-x (PO4)3Br: xEu2+ phosphors. Van Uitert provides us the relationship between the crystallographic site and the emission position of Eu2+ as follows [22] (3) E = Q [ 1 − ( V / 4 ) 1 V × 10 − ( n ⋅ E a ⋅ r ) / 80 ] where E stands for the position for the Eu2+ ion emission peak (cm−1), Q represents the position in energy for the lower d-band edge for the Eu2+ ion (cm−1), V denotes the valence of the “active” Eu2+ ion, n is the number of anions in the immediate shell around the Eu2+ ion, Ea is the electron affinity of the atoms that form anions (eV), and r is the radius of the host cation occupied by the Eu2+ ion (Å). In the same host, Q, V and Ea have the same value for two substituted sites. Hence the value of E has a positive relationship with the product of n and r from Eq. (3). Here, the radius of Ca2+ is 1.00Å when the coordination number is 6, whereas that is 1.06Å when the coordination number is 7. Therefore, we can conclude that the deconvoluted Gaussian curve centering at 456nm (21930cm−1) is attributed to the substitution of 7-coordinated Eu2+ ions (denoted as Eu(1)2+) while another deconvoluted Gaussian curve centering at 467nm (21413cm−1) is due to the substitution of 6-coordinated Eu2+ ions (denoted as Eu(2)2+). The above luminescence properties of Eu2+ ions in different sites are also elucidated according to the schematic configuration coordination model. As represented in Fig. 7 , the schematic configuration coordination model involves two following key factors: the electron-vibrational coupling and the interaction between the neighboring Eu(1)2+ ions and Eu(2)2+ ions in the Ca5(PO4)3Br lattice. In the process of absorption, the electrons are vertically excited from the equilibrium ground state to the non-equilibrium excited state by absorbing energy. Subsequently, the electrons arrive at the equilibrium excited state by means of releasing relaxation energy (Er) to the Ca5(PO4)3Br lattice. The radiation process is the opposite of the absorption process. The electrons located at equilibrium excited state can plummet to the non-equilibrium ground state, and then revert to the equilibrium ground state location by relaxation. Due to the different crystal field strengths of Eu(1)2+ ions and Eu(2)2+ ions, their electrons in the 4f65d1 excited states are located at different energy levels, which in turn leads to the transition to the ground state with different energy values and different optical properties between Eu(1)2+ ions and Eu(2)2+ ions [23]. Meanwhile, some excited electrons are easily transferred from Eu(1)2+ ions to Eu(2)2+ ions through the intersection of the S point by overcoming the energy barrier (Es) and finally revert to the ground state to give the longer wavelength emission. Notably, as seen in Fig. 6, there is a significant spectral overlap between its excitation and emission spectra, which can be regarded as the evidence of the energy transfer from Eu(1)2+ to Eu(2)2+ ions in the Ca4.93(PO4)3Br: 0.07Eu2+ phosphor. According to Dexter’s report, the principle of energy transfer can be expressed as follows [24,25] (4) P SA = 2 π h | 〈 S,A ∗ | H SA | S ∗ ,A 〉 | 2 ∫ g S ( E ) g A ( E ) dE where PSA represents energy transfer rate and HSA is the interaction Hamiltonian. The matrix elements demonstrate the interaction between the initial state | S ∗ ,A 〉 and the final state 〈 S,A ∗ | . The integral indicates the overlap between the PL spectra of a sensitizer and the PLE spectra of an activator. Based on the above consideration, there consequently exists the resonance-type energy transfer in Ca4.93(PO4)3Br: 0.07Eu2+. Meanwhile, Fig. 8 gives the luminescence decay curves of the Ca4.91(PO4)3Br: 0.09Eu2+ phosphor for Eu(1)2+ (456nm) and Eu(2)2+ (467nm) emission under 365nm excitation, respectively. The decay curves can be well fitted with the second-order exponential decay model as [26] (5) I = I 0 + A 1 exp ( − t / τ 1 ) + A 2 exp ( − t / τ 2 ) where I and I0 are the luminescence intensities at time t and 0 respectively, A1 and A2 are the constants, τ 1 and τ 2 are two exponential components for decay time. Thus, the average decay times (τ ∗) can be calculated as follows [27] (6) τ ∗ = A 1 τ 1 2 + A 2 τ 2 2 A 1 τ 1 + A 2 τ 2 Hence, the average decay times of Eu(1)2+ and Eu(2)2+ are calculated to be 442 and 476ns for Ca4.91(PO4)3Br: 0.09Eu2+ phosphor, respectively. It is clear that the average decay times of Eu(1)2+ and Eu(2)2+ are distinct, which further certifies there are two luminescence centers in the Eu2+-doped Ca5(PO4)3Br phosphors. Fig. 9 illustrates the PL spectra of Ca5-x (PO4)3Br: xEu2+ (x =0.01, 0.03, 0.05, 0.07, 0.09, 0.10) phosphors upon 365nm excitation. With increasing the Eu2+ ion concentration, the emission intensity of Ca5-x (PO4)3Br: xEu2+ phosphors initially increases and reaches a maximum at x =0.07, then decreases due to the concentration quenching. The occurrence of concentration quenching is mainly caused by the energy transfer from an activator to another. It is known that two kinds of mechanisms can be explanatory for the energy transfer: exchange interaction or electric multipolar interaction [28]. To further understand the concentration quenching process, the critical distance (Rc) for energy transfer among Eu2+ ions can be given by the Blasse equation [29] (7) R c = 2 [ 3 V 4 π x c N ] 1 / 3 where x c is the critical concentration, N means the number of available sites for the dopant in the unit cell, and V is the volume of the unit cell (Å3). In this case, x c is determined to be 0.07, N =2, and V =556.05Å3. Thus, the critical distance is calculated to be 19.65Å. Considering that the typical critical distance of the exchange interaction is normally around 5Å [30], the mechanism of exchange interaction may play little role in the energy transfer between Eu2+ ions in Ca5-x (PO4)3Br: xEu2+ phosphors. Therefore, the electric multipolar interactions should dominate the energy transfer process in these samples. To further understand the type of electric multipolar interaction, Dexter has pointed out the relationship between the emission intensity per activator ion (I/x) and the concentration of the activator (x) which is not less than the critical concentration [31]. (8) I / x = K [ 1 + β ( x ) Q / 3 ] − 1 where K and β are constants under the same excitation conditions for a given host lattice, and Q is a function of multipole–multipole interaction, while Q equals 6, 8 or 10 corresponding to dipole-dipole, dipole-quadrupole, and quadrupole–quadrupole interactions, respectively. Assuming that β ( x ) Q / 3 » 1, Eq. (8) can be simplified as follows (9) lg ( I / x ) = K ′ − Q 3 lg ( x ) The inset of Fig. 9 shows the linear dependence of lg I/x on lg x. The slope of the straight line is −1.688. Thus, the calculated value of Q is roughly approximate to 6, meaning that the energy transfer among Eu2+ ions takes place mainly via the dipole–dipole mechanism. On the basis of the dipole–dipole interaction, an alternative critical distance Rc 6 for energy transfer can be estimated by using the Dexter formula [30] (10) R c 6 = 0 .63 × 1 0 28 Q a E 4 ∫ f s ( E ) F a ( E ) dE (11) Q a = 4 .8 × 1 0 − 16 fd where Qa is absorption coefficient of Eu2+ ion, fd is electric dipole transition oscillator strength, E is energy of maximum spectral overlap, fs(E) and Fa(E) are normalized excitation and emission spectrum functions, respectively. fd is taken as 0.02 for Eu2+, and the values of E and ∫fs(E)Fa(E)dE are determined from the normalized excitation and emission spectrum to be 5.96eV and 0.72eV−1 for Ca4.97(PO4)3Br: 0.07Eu2+. Therefore, the critical distance Rc 6 of 18.04Å for energy transfer from Eu(1)2+ to Eu(2)2+ can be obtained, which is consistent with the result by Blasse equation. Additionally, Commission Internationale de L’Eclairage (CIE) chromaticity coordinates of Ca4.93(PO4)3Br: 0.07Eu2+ and commercial BAM: Eu2+ (NICHIA, NP-107) phosphors under 365nm excitation are shown in Fig. 10 . Their color coordinates are calculated to be (x =0.1450, y =0.0840) and (x =0.1449, y =0.0590), respectively. The color purity of a dominant color is the weight average of the emission color coordinates relative to the coordinates of the dominant wavelength and the CIE white illumination coordinates, which can be calculated by the following equation [32] (12) Color purity = ( x − x i ) 2 + ( y − y i ) 2 ( x d − x i ) 2 + ( y d − y i ) 2 × 100 % where (x, y) are the color coordinates of the as-prepared phosphors, (xi =0.3333, yi =0.3333) represent the CIE white light source coordinates, and (xd , yd ) are the coordinates of the dominant wavelength point. Finally, the color purities of Ca4.93(PO4)3Br: 0.07Eu2+ and commercial BAM: Eu2+ (NP-107) phosphors can be calculated to be 89.77% and 94.49%, respectively, meaning that the color purity of Ca4.93(PO4)3Br: 0.07Eu2+ phosphor is close to that of the commercial BAM: Eu2+ phosphor. Meanwhile, the inset of Fig. 10 provides the digital photograph of the Ca4.93(PO4)3Br: 0.07Eu2+ phosphor under 365nm UV lamp. 4 Conclusions In summary, we have presented the synthesis, structure, morphology and luminescence properties of Ca5-x (PO4)3Br: xEu2+ phosphors. The phosphors offered a broad excitation band extending from 320 to 440nm and a broad blue emission band peaking at 458nm upon 365nm excitation. It was indicated that Eu2+ randomly substituted two Ca2+ crystallographic sites with different coordination environments. The optimized concentration of Eu2+ was determined to be 0.07 in the Ca5(PO4)3Br host and the energy transfer mechanism among Eu2+ ions in our phosphors was certified to be dipole–dipole interaction by theoretical calculation. Due to the strong absorption in the near-UV region as well as the intense blue emission, our phosphor is expected to be the potential candidate as blue component for near-UV-pumped white LEDs.
