column2: Optical and photocatalytic properties of lysozyme mediated titanium dioxide nanoparticles
column3: Abstract Titanium dioxide nanoparticles using lysozyme (L:TiO2) were prepared through a facile synthesis. Structural, morphological and optical properties of L: TiO2 were compared with synthesized TiO2 nanoparticles prepared without lysozyme. X-Ray Diffraction (XRD) patterns showed dominance of anatase phase in L:TiO2 whereas rutile phase in TiO2. Their grain size was reduced from 38 to 17nm on using lysozyme. Fourier Transform Infra Red (FTIR) study revealed the existence of chemical bonding of Titanium and Oxygen in both phases. The band gap energy was decreased from 3.3 to 3.1eV on employing lysozyme. L:TiO2 nanoparticles showed better performance than TiO2 in photocatalytic degradation of Methylene Blue (MB) and Methyl Orange (MO) under ultraviolet irradiation.
column5: Keywords TiO2 Lysozyme Band gap Languir-Hinshelwood kinetics Photocatalytic degradation 1 Introduction Dyes are widely used in the industry. Now a days, industrial dye pollutants are one of the main reasons of water contamination. Most dyes are very hard to degrade because of their chemical structures and stability. These dyestuffs are colored and their presence block the sunlight and oxygen, which in turn affecting the aquatic life [1]. For the sake of the environment, there is a high demand of treating these colored effluents before discharging them. Therefore, new cheap and more efficient methods are being searched. For this purpose, photocatalytic effect of TiO2 has drawn much attention because it is one of the promising materials for the photocatalytic degradation of pollutants. TiO2 is applied for treating wastewater containing organic contaminants due to its ability to achieve complete mineralization of the organic contaminants under mild conditions such as ambient temperature and pressure [2]. Furthermore, TiO2 is stable, relatively low cost and non-toxic material [3] that exists in three main crystalline forms: anatase, rutile and brookite [4]. Rutile is the most thermodynamically stable phase [5] whereas anatase and brookite are metastable phases [6]. However, due to large surface area per unit mass and volume, anatase TiO2 has greater photo-catalytic activity compared to rutile [7]. Many papers concerning different methods of synthesizing TiO2 nanostructured materials have been published such as reverse micelle method [8], hydrothermal method [9], solvothermal method [10], microwave method [11], anodizing method [12], chemical vapor deposition [13], electrophoretic deposition [14], sonochemical method [15], and sol-gel method [16]. To the best of our knowledge, the synthesis of TiO2 nanoparticles using lysozyme has not been reported so far. Therefore, we have reported simple and low cost sol-gel method for the synthesis of TiO2 nanoparticles with lysozyme for the first time. The sol–gel method has many advantages with respect to the other methods in terms of purity, homogeneity, low processing temperature and stoichiometry control. Lysozyme, which occurs naturally in human tears, saliva, egg white, and other body fluids, is capable of destroying the cell walls of certain bacteria and thereby acting as a mild antiseptic [17]. In this work, lysozyme is used as a representative of enzyme. The purpose of employing lysozyme is getting free from agglomeration during nanoparticles formation and particle size reduction in order to enhance the efficiency of the photocatalytic effect. Here, we found particle size reduction on using lysozyme in the synthesis of TiO2 nanoparticles. And we investigated photocatalytic degradation of the product TiO2 nanoparticles with and without lysozyme in decomposing MB and MO under ultraviolet light. 2 Experimental 2.1 Synthesis of L:TiO2 nanoparticles Chemicals used in this research work were of analytical reagent grade and used without any further refinement. All aqueous solutions were made using deionized water. For TiO2 nanoparticles preparation, Titanium (IV) isopropoxide (TTIP) of Sigma-Aldrich was used as a starting material. 20mL of TTIP was mixed with 60mL of ethanol and 200mL of deionized water along with few drops of concentrated HNO3 under constant magnetic stirring for 4h at 80°C. The mixture solution was kept in a standstill position for 120h for decantation. The decanted particles were filtered and washed with ethanol and then dried at 100°C for 4h. The dried mass was grinded and calcined in a muffle furnace at 500°C for 2h. And the dried crystals were transferred to a mortar and finally grinded to a fine powder of TiO2 nanoparticles. In the same fashion as mentioned above, L:TiO2 nanoparticles were prepared by dissolving 0.02g of lysozyme from chicken egg white (Sigma-Aldrich) with 200mL of de-ionized water, 20mL of TTIP, 60mL of ethanol and few drops of concentrated HNO3. All the other processes of stirring, drying, calcining and grinding were same as described in the former case. Stable L:TiO2 nanoparticles were synthesized without any noticeable precipitation. The schematic diagram in Fig. 1 represents the experimental process. 2.2 Photocatalytic activity investigation The photocatalytic activities of the prepared samples were investigated in the degradation of MB and MO dyes in aqueous solution. In each case, 0.1g of photocatalyst was suspended in 50mL of dye solution (10ppm concentration). The solution was continuously stirred for 10min in dark to ensure the establishment of an adsorption-desorption equilibrium among the photocatalyst, dye and water. Then the solution was exposed to UV- irradiation (λ =365nm) from 250W high pressure Hg lamp. Aliquots were taken at 30min time interval and centrifuged to remove the residual photocatalyst and then the concentration of dye solution was measured by recording the optical absorbance using a UV–vis spectrophotometer. 3 Characterization X-ray diffraction analysis of the synthesized nanoparticles were carried out using CuKα radiation of D2 phaser Bruker at room temperature, ranging 2θ value from 20° to 80° with a scanning rate of 0.01° per second. Field emission scanning electron microscopy (FESEM) images were captured using Carl Zeiss AG – SUPRA 55VP, Germany. Fourier transform infrared spectroscopy studies were performed from 400 to 4000cm−1 with SHIMADZU IR Tracer-100 FTIR spectrometer. Similarly, the optical absorption spectra were measured between 300 and 800nm by Cary 60 UV–vis spectrophotometer (Agilent Technologies). 4 Results and discussion 4.1 Morphological and structural properties Fig. 2 shows the typical FESEM images results of all samples. The morphologies and the particle sizes of L:TiO2 and TiO2 are shown respectively in Fig. 2(a) and (b). Fig. 2(a) shows a well-defined L:TiO2 nanoparticles with an average size of 20nm. The particles of TiO2 particles are nearly spherical shaped with size of 40nm (Fig. 2b). Fig. 3 shows the XRD pattern of the synthesized samples. It can be seen that all the XRD peaks are clear and sharp. This evidence suggests that as prepared samples are well crystallized. Since the photocatalytic activity depends considerably on the crystallinity and crystalline phases of TiO2, it is ensured from this result. The XRD pattern of L:TiO2 nanoparticles indicates the dominance of anatase phase as shown in Fig. 3(a). The peak position at 25.56° is in accordance with anatase phase of (101) diffraction plane. This peak does not overlap with any other peaks of rutile. Similarly the peaks of TiO2 as shown in Fig. 3(b) depict the dominance of rutile phase with intense peak at 27.67° corresponding to (110) plane. These experimental XRD patterns agree with JCPDS card number 21-1272 (anatase) and 21-1276 (rutile). From the XRD analysis, it can be clearly stated that the synthesized samples are a mixture of anatase and rutile in both cases. The crystallite size was calculated by the Debye Scherer’s formula given below [18], (1) D =(0.9λ)/βcosθ Where, λ is the wavelength of X-ray radiation, β is the Full Width at Half Maximum (FWHM), θ is the diffracting angle. The average crystalline size of TiO2 and L:TiO2 nanoparticles synthesized are 38nm and 17nm respectively. This fact is in good agreement with FESEM results. The size of L:TiO2 nanoparticles is reduced to more than half. It could be because of role of lysozyme in squeezing the colloidal suspensions and thereby limiting agglomeration. 4.2 Optical properties 4.2.1 FT-IR spectra analysis To confirm the presence of Ti-O stretching bond, FTIR spectra were measured at room temperature. Fig. 4 (a) and (b) show the FT-IR spectra of L:TiO2 and TiO2 nanoparticles respectively. Both spectra show the peak over the range of 400–700cm−1 which are attributed to the Ti-O-Ti bending and stretching vibration and characteristic of well-ordered TiO6 octahedra [19]. Peak at 2362cm−1 corresponds to CH stretching vibration. Peaks around 1625 and 3450 corresponds to the stretching mode of the OH group and bending mode of molecular water respectively [20]. 4.2.2 Band gap measurement The band gap of TiO2 and L:TiO2 nanoparticles were measured by studying the optical absorption spectra from the UV–vis spectrophotometer. Fig. 5 shows the absorption spectra of (a) L:TiO2 and (b) TiO2 in the wavelength range from 300 to 800nm. Fig. 6 shows the absorption edge of the spectra is shifted to a lower energy (red shift) on using lysozyme, where a reduction of particle size is observed. This red shift of band edge of TiO2 could be due to the overlapping of conduction band Ti(3d) with d levels of the transition metals [21]. The optical band gap of synthesized TiO2 nanoparticles was estimated by the extrapolation of the linear portion of (αhν)2 versus photon energy (hν) plots. For the allowed direct transition, the variation in α with the photon energy obey Tauc’s plot method [22] (2) ( α h υ ) 2 = A ( h υ − E g ) Where A is a constant, Eg is the optical band gap, h is the plank constant and α is the absorption coefficient. The plot of (αhν)2 versus photon energy for TiO2 nanoparticles is shown in Fig. 6. The extrapolation at (α)2 =0 yields the optical band gap energy. Their band gap energy calculated by UV–vis spectroscopy were 3.3 and 3.1eV for TiO2 and L:TiO2 respectively. The practicable photocatalysts should have a band gap energy comparable to the energy of photons of visible or ultraviolet light (less than 3.5eV). The rutile has a band gap of 3.00eV and that of anatase has 3.21eV [23]. Moreover, there are many papers mentioning the band gap energy of anatase in the range of 2.86 and 3.34eV. The differences are due to variations in the stoichiometric of synthesis, impurities present, crystalline size and type of electronic transition [24,25]. As the particle size gets smaller and reaches nano scale, the number of overlapping orbitals or energy levels decrease and the width of the band starts to narrow. As a result, the gap between the valence and the conduction bands increases with the decrease in particle size. Here it seems the reverse case. The particle size has reduced using lysozyme and the band gap energy has also decreased. The reason could be nanoparticles were in the mixed states of anatase and rutile. Another reason could be attributed by mild delocalization of molecular orbitals on the surface, which in turn creates deep and shallow traps near the band edge of its electronic state and hence brings reduction in the band gap [26]. Photocatalytic performances of the prepared samples under UV-light irradiation towards the photocatalytic degradation of MB and MO dye solution are shown in Fig. 7 (a) and (b). The degradation is represented as the variation of (C/Co) with irradiation time, where Co and C are the concentrations of dye solutions at the initial time and at time t, respectively. From these results, it is clear that more than 90% degradation of MB dye solution and more than 80% degradation of MO solution was occurred in 180min in case of utilizing L:TiO2 nanoparticles. Contrastingly, TiO2 nanoparticles showed less performances within this time. Here, we believe that the higher photocatalytic activity of L:TiO2 nanoparticles is due the smaller particle size with large surface area, which are preferable for photocatalysis under UV-light irradiation. In this case the solid L-TiO2 is more active not only because of the small particle size and high specific surface area, but also because of its crystallographic composition. The absorbance variations of MB and MO dye solution utilizing L:TiO2 nanoparticles under UV-light irradiation at different time are shown in Fig. 7(c) and (d). The absorption peaks corresponding to MB at 665nm and MO at 464nm are diminished gradually with increase in irradiation time. Moreover, in this work the maximum absorption peaks were not shifted, which indicated that benzene/heterocyclic rings were decomposed rather than simple decolorization process [27]. The kinetics of photocatalytic degradation of MB and MO solutions utilizing L:TiO2 and TiO2 nanoparticles were evaluated by using Languir-Hinshelwood model. (3) r = − d c d t = k r K C 1 + K C Because the initial concentration of reactant was very low (C0 =10mg/L for MB and MO), Eq. (3) could be reduced to the pseudo first-order kinetics equation [28] as, (4) l n C 0 / C = k a p p t Where, C0 and C are the initial concentration and concentration at time (t), respectively and kapp is the apparent rate constant (min−1) determined by plotting ln (C0/C) versus reaction time. Using Eq. (4), the photocatalytic degradation kinetics of MB and MO solutions were investigated and results are depicted in Fig. 8 . As shown in the figure the relationship of ln (C0/C) versus reaction time was almost linear, suggesting the photocatalytic degradation reaction could follow pseudo-first order kinetics. According to the results the apparent rate constant of MB and MO degradation over L:TiO2 nanoparticles were determined to be 0.014min−1 and 0.011min−1. At the same time the rate constant over TiO2 nanoparticles were determined to be 0.009min−1 and 0.008min−1. This indicated that the photocatalytic degradation rate of L:TiO2 nanoparticles was distinctly higher than that of TiO2 nanoparticles. From this fact it can be concluded that lysozyme had a vital role to enhance the photocatalytic activity of L:TiO2 nanoparticles under UV-light irradiation. In addition, it is supposed that the formation of phase junction between TiO2 nanoparticles is responsible for the higher photocatalytic activity as the synthesized samples were in the mixed phases of anatase and rutile, which might have contributed their synergistic effect for dye degradation [29]. Based on these results, the mechanism for photocatalytic degradation of dye solution utilizing phase-junction TiO2 nanoparticles under UV-light irradiation is proposed in Fig. 9 . As shown in the figure, photo excited electrons (e−) flow from rutile to anatase, where as the holes (h+) move from anatase to rutile. Thus the recombination of hole and electron is prevented [30]. During photo degradation process, the photo excited and transferred electrons on the surface of TiO2 nanoparticles get trapped by dissolved oxygen to form O2 −, HO2 and H2O2, where O2 or electrons can further react with H2O2 to generate OH. At the same time, photo generated holes react with water or OH− to produce HO radicals. Hence, in both cases OH radicals are responsible for the photocatalytic degradation of dye solutions [31]. 5 Conclusions A facile method has been developed to synthesize TiO2 nanoparticles using lysozyme. From X-ray diffraction measurement, the synthesized samples were found in the mixed phases of anatase and rutile both in L:TiO2 and TiO2 nanoparticles, where L:TiO2 showed dominance of anatase phase. In contrast, TiO2 nanoparticles depicted the dominance of rutile phase. Their grain size estimated from Scherrer equation was found to be decreased from 38 to 17nm on using lysozyme. FTIR study revealed the existence of chemical bonding of Ti and O. The band gap energy calculated by UV–vis spectroscopy was decreased from 3.3 to 3.1eV on employing lysozyme. L:TiO2 nanoparticles showed better performance in photocatalytic degradation of MB and MO under ultraviolet irradiation than TiO2 particles prepared without lysozyme. The photocatalytic degradation reaction of both MB and MO followed the pseudo-first-order reaction kinetics. The kinetic data showed the synthesized L:TiO2 are more effective for photocatalytic applications than the conventional TiO2 nanoparticles. Acknowledgements This work was supported by the TWAS (the world academy of sciences for the advancement of science in developing countries). We would like to acknowledge Prof. Andrzej Huczko, Laboratory of Physics and Chemistry of Nanomaterials, University of Warsaw for the FESEM images.

column2: The color tunability and mechanism of upconversion emissions in Yb3+ and Er3+ co-doped Y2Ce2O7 phosphors
column3: Abstract Y2Ce2O7 powders doped with different Yb3+ and Er3+ concentrations were synthesized via the sol-gel method. The structure and upconversion properties were investigated. The results indicated that a single phase was obtained and that the structure was cubic. The green and red upconversion emissions were detected with excitation at 980nm, and the emission intensities could be tuned by the Yb3+ and Er3+ concentrations. The mechanism of the upconversion process was evaluated on the basis of the emission intensities and lifetimes of the 4S3/2, 4F9/2 and 4I13/2 levels. The results demonstrated that cross-relaxation was responsible for the dependence of green and red upconversion emissions on the dopant concentration.
column5: Keywords Upconversion Color tunability Mechanism Y2Ce2O7:Yb3+,Er3+ 1 Introduction Upconversion is an anti-Stokes process in which a substance absorbs two or more low-energy photons and emits a higher-energy photon [1]. The upconversion of luminescent materials can be used in many fields, including optical temperature sensing, laser cooling and cell imaging [2–4]. Recently, explorations of the application of upconversion in solar cells and white-light emission have attracted much attention [5–7]. Lanthanide rare-earth (RE) ions are suitable candidates for the upconversion process because of their abundant energy levels and narrow emission spectral lines [8]; The Er3+ ion is the most efficient and popular RE ion for this application. To enhance the efficiency of upconversion emission of Er3+ ions, the Yb3+ ions are often co-doped into materials doped with Er3+ as a sensitizer. Furthermore, the fluorescent color of upconversion can be tuned by the concentration of the Yb3+ ion [9,10], which is useful for fluorescent labels or biological images. Host materials with low phonon energy are necessary to achieve efficient upconversion emissions. Such materials enable the multi-phonon relaxation rate to be reduced and the lifetime of excited levels to be increased [11]. Fortunately, Re2Ce2O7 with a pyrochlore structure or a defect fluorite-type structure has a low phonon energy (approximately 464cm−1 [12]) and excellent chemical stability [13] and is therefore a potential upconversion material. However, the literature contains few reports of the photoluminescence properties of RE-doped Re2Ce2O7 compounds. In this paper, we focus on the upconversion properties of Y2Ce2O7 phosphors co-doped with Yb3+ and Er3+. The mechanism of upconversion emission and the effects of the dopant concentrations on the color tunability are studied. 2 Experiment Y2Ce2O7 samples co-doped with Yb3+ and Er3+ were prepared by the sol-gel method. Y2O3 (99.99%), Yb2O3 (99.99%), Er2O3 (99.99%) and CeO2 (99.99%) were used as starting materials. According to the formula, (YbxEryY1-x-y)2Ce2O7 (y=0.02, x=0, 0.02, 0.04, 0.06, 0.08, 0.1 and x=0.04, y=0.02, 0.04, 0.06, 0.08, 0.1), stoichiometric amounts of the starting materials were dissolved in nitric acid, and citric acid was then added into the solution as the chelating agent. The molar ratio of metal ions and citric acid was 1:2.5. H2O2 was added when CeO2 is dissolved using nitric acid. The mixture was stirred at approximately 90°C for 4h until a sol was formed. The sol was transformed into a sticky gel by evaporating the sol over several hours. The gel was dried at approximately 100°C in air. After being fully ground, the dried powders were sintered at 1200°C in a muffle furnace in air atmosphere for approximately 4h, and white powder samples were obtained. X-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns of the samples in the range of 10°≤2θ≤90° were recorded on a Bruker D8 Advance X-ray diffractometer with high-intensity CuK α radiation (λ=1.54178Å). The upconversion emission spectra were detected using a spectrophotometer (FL980, Edinburgh) with a laser diode (LD) as the pump source; the excitement wavelength was 980nm. The fluorescence decay curves, at a wavelength of 547, 677 and 1535nm, were also excited at 980nm by an optical parametric oscillator (OPO) in the same instrument. The signal was detected using an NIR PMT (R5509, Hamamatsu). All measurements were carried out at room temperature, and the spectra were corrected. 3 Results and discussion Fig. 1 (a)–(d) shows the XRD patterns of samples doped with different concentrations of Yb3+ and Er3+. From the figure, the diffraction peaks of Y2Ce2O7 agree with those of the standard card (JCPDS 09-0286), which indicates that the crystal structure belongs to the cubic system with space group Fm3m. No diffraction peaks from impurities were observed in the XRD patterns, indicating that pure, single-phase Y2Ce2O7 was obtained and that Yb3+ and Er3+ ions were incorporated into the Y2Ce2O7 lattice. Fig. 1(b) and (d) shows the 2θ range from 28.5° to 29.1° in the XRD patterns. With increasing concentrations of Yb3+ and Er3+, the (111) diffraction peaks at approximately 28.696° shift slightly toward higher angles, indicating that the lattice parameters of Y2Ce2O7:Yb,Er decrease. The unit-cell parameters were calculated on the basis of the XRD patterns; the results are summarized in Table 1 . The decrease in lattice parameters is attributed to the radii of the Er3+ (8.81nm) and Yb3+ (8.58nm) ions being smaller than the radius of the Y3+ ions (8.93nm) they replace [14]. These results further demonstrate that Yb3+ and Er3+ ions had entered the host lattice. Furthermore, in the case of the Y2Ce2O7 sample doped with 4 at% Yb3+ and 4 at% Er3+, the (111) diffraction peak shifts to a higher angle than the corresponding peak in the XRD patterns of the other samples, which may be due to the random distribution of Yb3+ and Er3+ ions in the host. Fig. 2 (a) demonstrates the dependence of upconversion emissions on the Yb3+ concentration when excited by 980nm light. Two upconversion emission bands are observed in the range 500–750nm: a green one at approximately 547nm and a red one at approximately 677nm, corresponding to the 2H11/2/4S3/2 → 4I15/2 and 4F9/2 → 4I15/2 transitions of the Er3+ ion, respectively. The upconversion emission intensities (green and red) in samples doped only with Er3+ can be neglected in comparison to those in samples doped with both Yb3+ and Er3+. The green emission intensities decrease with increasing Yb3+ concentration, whereas the red emission intensities increase with increasing Yb3+ concentration. Fig. 2(b) demonstrates the CIE chromaticity coordinates of samples doped with different Yb3+ concentrations; the values are listed in Table 1. The upconversion emissions range from yellowish-green to red, depending on the Yb3+ concentration, when excited with 980-nm light, which indicates that the color of emissions can be tuned by the Yb3+ concentration. However, the color cannot be efficiently tuned via the Er3+ concentration. Fig. 2(c) demonstrates the dependence of upconversion emissions on the Er3+ concentration under excitation at 980nm. The green and red emission intensities decrease with increasing Er3+ concentrations. The color coordinates are located at the yellow region for samples doped with different concentrations of Er3+, as shown in Fig. 2(d) and Table 1. Our previous work demonstrates that the mechanism for green and red upconversion emissions is a two-photon process [15]. Because of the large absorption cross-section of the Yb3+ ion at 980nm and the resonance between the 2F5/2 → 2F7/2 transition of Yb3+ ion and the 4I15/2 → 4I11/2 transition of Er3+ ion, the energy-transfer (ET) process dominates samples co-doped with Yb3+ and Er3+. The Er3+ ion can be excited to the 4I11/2 level from the 4I15/2 level via the ET process from Yb3+ to Er3+ (ET process in Fig. 3 ) or via direct excitation. The proportion of Er3+ ions at the 4I11/2 level will be excited to the 4F7/2 level after absorbing another pump photon. The Er3+ ion at the 4F7/2 level will nonradiatively decay to the 4S3/2 and then the 4F9/2 level; the green and red emissions can be derived when the Er3+ ions on these two levels relax to the ground 4I15/2 level, respectively. Another portion of Er3+ ions on the 4I11/2 level will nonradiatively relax to the 4I13/2 level and then be populated to the 4F9/2 level by the cross-relaxation (CR) process, 2F5/2 (Yb)+ 4I13/2 (Er)→ 2F7/2(Yb)+4F9/2 (Er); thus, the red emission can be derived from the 4F9/2 → 4I15/2 transition. Therefore, the 4F9/2 level can be populated via two channels: nonradiative transition process (4S3/2 → 4F9/2) and CR process (4I13/2 → 4F9/2). The CR process is dominant for the upconversion red emission. Because the radiative and nonradiative transitions are intrinsic transitions, they are independent of the dopant concentration. If the nonradiative transition process is dominant, the ratio of upconversion of red-to-green emission (R) cannot be changed by varying the Yb3+ concentration. Actually, the ratio R increases from 0.38 to 46.67 with increasing Yb3+ concentration, as shown in Fig. 4 . Therefore, upconversion green emission competes with the red emission. When the Yb3+ concentration is increased, the distance between the Yb3+ and Er3+ ions is shortened, and the CR process becomes more efficient, resulting in a decrease in the upconversion green emissions and enhancement of the upconversion red emissions. This process can be confirmed by the various lifetimes of the 4I13/2 level of the Er3+ ion, as shown in Fig. 5 . The lifetime decreases with increasing Yb3+ concentration in samples doped with both Yb3+ and Er3+, which indicates that an additional decay channel is introduced by Yb3+. The distance between the Yb3+ and Er3+ ions decreases with increasing Yb3+ concentration, and the probability of the CR process increases. Thus, the lifetime of the 4I13/2 level decreases with increasing Yb3+ concentration. In contrast to the declining tendency of lifetimes of the 4I13/2 level with increasing Yb3+ concentration, the emission intensity of the 4I13/2 → 4I15/2 transition increases and then decreases with increasing Yb3+ concentration, as shown in Fig. 6 . This behavior may be due to the following effects: (1) The distance between the Yb3+ and Er3+ ions decreases with increasing Yb3+ concentration, and the ET becomes more efficient; thus, the population of the 4I13/2 level increases. Although the CR process can depopulate the 4I13/2 level, the net population still increases and the emission intensity increases. (2) Another CR occurs, 4S3/2 (Er)+ 2F7/2 (Yb)→ 4I13/2 (Er)+ 2F5/2 (Yb) (marked as CR1 in Fig. 3) [16]. This CR1 process can be confirmed by the variety of lifetimes of the4S3/2 level of the Er3+ ion shown in Fig. 7 . In samples doped with higher Yb3+ concentrations, the CR process is dominant, and the emission intensity of the 4I13/2 → 4I15/2 transition decreases. In addition, the lifetimes of the 4F9/2 level of Er3+ in samples doped with different Yb3+ concentrations are also shown in Fig. 7. These lifetimes increase with increasing Yb3+ concentration when the Yb3+ concentration is not higher than 4 at%, which is caused by the greater probability of the CR process because of the shorter distance between Yb3+ and Er3+ as Yb3+ concentration increases. If the Yb3+ concentration is higher than 4 at%, the lifetime will decrease. Some authors have speculated that the Er3+ ion will be excited to the 2H9/2 level with phonon assistance in samples doped with high Yb3+ concentrations [17,18]. However, in our work, the upconversion emissions in the range from 400 to 500nm were not observed. Therefore, the pairing or aggregation of Yb3+ ions may turn some of those ions into quenchers [19]. However, the reverse CR process, 2F7/2(Yb)+ 4F9/2 (Er)→ 2F5/2 (Yb)+ 4I13/2 (Er), may be responsible for this result. Higher Er3+ concentrations adversely affect the upconversion emission. Fig. 2(b) demonstrates that the green and red upconversion emissions, along with the lifetimes of the 4S3/2 and 4F9/2 levels, decrease with increasing Er3+ concentration (shown in Fig. 8 ). The results demonstrate that interactions between Er3+ ions become stronger with decreasing distance between Er3+ ions due to increasing Er3+ concentrations. Therefore, the CR process among Er3+ ions cannot be neglected. The CR2 process, 4S3/2 (Er)+ 4I15/2 (Er)→ 4I9/2(Er)+ 4I13/2 (Er), which depends on the Er3+ concentration, reduces the population at the 4S3/2 level and the lifetime of this level in samples doped with high Er3+ concentrations [20]. Furthermore, the back energy transfer (BET) from Er3+ to Yb3+ ions will induce reduced intensities of upconversion emission [21]. The reduced lifetimes of the 4F9/2 level are due to the formation of clusters of Er3+ ions [22]. 4 Conclusions Single phases of Y2Ce2O7 phosphors doped with different Yb3+ and Er3+ concentrations were obtained in this work. Green and red upconversion emissions were observed under excitation by 980nm light. The intensities of the green emissions decrease with increasing Yb3+ concentration, whereas the red emission intensities increase with increasing Yb3+ concentration. However, the green and red upconversion emissions decrease with increasing Er3+ concentration. The color of emissions can be tuned from yellowish to red by changing the Yb3+ concentration, whereas the color is in the yellow region for samples doped with different Er3+ concentrations. The green upconversion emission competed with that of the red. The mechanisms for the green and red upconversion were investigated and confirmed by the emission intensities and lifetimes. In samples doped with different concentrations of Yb3+ or Er3+, the CR processes (CR, CR1, and CR2) between dopants were dominant. In brief, the upconversion process in Y2Ce2O7 phosphors doped with Yb3+ and Er3+ is very complicated and should be investigated further. column2: Relativistic self-focusing of finite Airy-Gaussian beams in collisionless plasma using the Wentzel‐Kramers‐Brillouin approximation
column3: Abstract In this paper, we present a preliminary study of relativistic self-focusing of finite Airy-Gaussian beams in collisionless plasma taking into consideration the relativistic nonlinearity in the dielectric constant. The differential equation for the beam width parameter of the finite Airy-Gaussian beam is derived by using Wentzel-Kramers-Brillouin (WKB) and paraxial approximations through parabolic wave equation approach. The behavior of beam width parameter with distance of propagation is investigated at different parameters of plasma and those of the considered beams family. Our results detect that the beam is more focused at higher values aperture coefficient and higher intensity parameter. Furthermore, a strong oscillatory behavior of the beam width parameter and better focusing during laser propagation in plasma is apparent.
column5: Keywords Relativistic self-focusing Finite Airy-Gaussian beam Collisionless plasma 1 Introduction Over the past several decades the interaction of high power laser beams with plasma has paved the way in various directions due to its large applications like, laser-electron acceleration [1], laser driven fusion [2], X-rays lasers [3], optical harmonic generation [4], etc. These applications required that the beam is very powerful intense and propagates for prolonged distances with convergence, resulting in different nonlinear phenomena such as relativistic and pondermotive self-focusing, etc. It’s known that self-focusing effect is principally due to the change of dielectric constant when intense laser beam propagates through plasma. The high intensity of laser supply sufficient energy to the electron of plasma and produces an increase of the relativistic mass of electron. This gives rise to non-linearity caused the relativistic self-focusing effect. In the plasma, the self-focusing of laser beams has been theoretically studied by Akhmanov et al. [5], Hora [6], Litvak [7], Max et al. [8], Sodha et al. [9], and Brandi et al. [10], etc. Lately, the relativistic self-focusing has been discussed by several authors. Sharma [11], Nanda and Kant [12], and Wani and Kant [13] have theoretically investigated the relativistic self-focusing of Hermite-Gaussian beam, Hermite-cosh-Gaussian beam, Hermite-cosine-Gaussian beam, respectively. Patil et al. have examined many works of the relativistic self-focusing for Gaussian laser beam in plasma [14–16], and other theoretical and experimental works concern the relativistic self-focusing have been treated [17–24]. On the other hand, curved laser beams have attracted the attention of several researchers in the lasers physics from the introduction of the Airy wave packets for the first time by Berry and Balazs [25] in 1979 within the context of quantum mechanics. But, these beams require truncation because they take infinite energy. Concerning the last type of beams, the finite energy Airy beam [26,27] has known a great of interest because of their unique properties among them self-acceleration [26], self-healing [28], and even large applications in many domains such as in optically clearing particles [29], plasma guidance [30,31], vacuum electron acceleration [32,33], trapping and guiding microparticles [34,35]. Many authors have been interested to the finite Airy-Gaussian beams. Ez-zariy et al. [36] have studied propagation characteristics of Airy-Gaussian beams passing through a misaligned optical system with finite aperture. Deng et al. have discussed the propagation of the Airy-Gaussian beams in Kerr media [37], strongly nonlocal nonlinear media [38], and uniaxial crystals [39]. The properties of Airy-Gaussian beams in the fractional Fourier system have been treated by Zhou et al. [40]. Recently, Shi et al. have investigated the interaction of Airy-Gaussian beams in defected photonic lattices [41]. For all these reasons, we are interesting to the study of the relativistic self-focusing for finite Airy-Gaussian laser beam in collisionless plasma. By using WKB and paraxial approximations through the parabolic equation, a mathematical expression for the beam width parameter in plasma will be derived from the wave equation and its variation with the distance of propagation will be presented. The results of this study will be illustrated in the form of graphs where each parameter of the plasma and the considered beam family has a great importance for change the nature of self-focusing. The planning of the paper is as follows: After a brief introduction, we present the essential equations and we derive the nonlinear differential equations governing the beam width parameters in Section 2. In Section 3, the analytical expression for dimensionless initial beam with her graph is given. We discuss numerically results of finite Airy-Gaussian laser beam in collisionless plasma in details in Section 4. Finally, a simple conclusion is provided in Section.5. 2 Theory phenomenological The field distribution of finite Airy-Gaussian laser beam propagating in collisionless plasma along z direction is of the following form (1) E ( x , y , z ) = E 0 f 1 ( z ) f 2 ( z ) A i ( x r 0 f 1 ( z ) ) exp ( a 0 x r 0 f 1 ( z ) ) exp ( − x 2 r 0 2 f 1 2 ( z ) ) A i ( y r 0 f 2 ( z ) ) exp ( a 0 y r 0 f 2 ( z ) ) exp ( − y 2 r 0 2 f 2 2 ( z ) ) , where E 0 is the constant amplitude of the electric field, A i ( . ) is the Airy function of the first kind, r 0 is the waist width, a 0 is the modulation parameter (aperture coefficient), f 1 ( z ) and f 2 ( z ) are the dimensionless beam width parameters in the x and y directions, respectively. Fig. 1 illustrates the intensity distributions of finite Airy-Gaussian beam for different values of the modulation parameters a 0, with the transverse scale is ω 0 =0.8 mm. Depicted plots show that the Airy-Gaussian beam (with a 0 =0) carry an infinite energy. Intensity oscillations vanish gradually with the increase of a 0 and totally disappear when this modulation parameter approaches to 1. The propagation of finite Airy-Gaussian laser beam in plasma is characterized by the dielectric function which can, in general, be expressed as [42] (2) ε = ε 0 + φ ( E E ∗ ) , where ε 0 and φ are the linear and nonlinear parts of the dielectric function respectively and (3) ε 0 = 1 − ω p 2 / ω 2 , with ω is the angular frequency of laser beam, ω p is plasma frequency, given by ω p =4π n 0 e 2/m, n 0is the equilibrium electron density, e is the charge of the electron, m = m 0 γ, with m 0 is the rest mass, and γ is the relativistic factor which expressed by γ = 1 / 1 − υ 2 / c 2 . υ is the oscillatory velocity of electron and c is the speed of light in vacuum. The nonlinear dielectric constant for collisionless plasma is derived by Sodha [6], and represents by (4) φ ( E E ∗ ) = ω p 2 γ ω 2 [ 1 − exp ( − 3 4 m 0 γ M α E E ∗ ) ] , where α = e 2 M / 6 m 0 2 γ 2 ω 2 k B T , M is the mass of scatter in the plasma, k B is the Boltzmann constant, and T is the equilibrium plasma temperature. The wave equation governing the electric field E of the beam in plasma can be written as (5) ∇ 2 E + ( ω 2 c 2 ) ε E + ∇ ( E ∇ ε ε ) = 0 . The last term of Eq. (5) on the left hand side can be neglected provided that k − 2 ∇ 2 ( ln ε ) < < 1 , where k is the wave number of the laser beam. Thus (6) ∇ 2 E + ( ω 2 c 2 ) ε E = 0 . Now, E = A ( x , y , z ) exp ( − i k z ) is introduced, where A ( x , y , z ) is the complex function of its argument. The behavior of A ( x , y , z ) is described by the parabolic equation in the WKB approximation, as (7) 2 i k ∂ A ∂ z = ∂ 2 A ∂ x 2 + ∂ 2 A ∂ y 2 + k 2 ε 0 φ ( A A ∗ ) A = 0 . To solve Eq. (7) we write A ( x , y , z ) as (8) A ( x , y , z ) = A ( x , y , z ) 0 exp [ − i k S ( x , y , z ) ] , where k = ( ω / c ) ε 0 A 0 and S are real function of x, y and z (S being the eikonal of the beam). By substituting A ( x , y , z ) given by Eq. (8) into Eq. (7), one obtains (9) 2 ( ∂ S ∂ z ) + ( ∂ S ∂ x ) 2 + ( ∂ S ∂ y ) 2 = 1 k 2 A 0 ( ∂ 2 A 0 ∂ x 2 + ∂ 2 A 0 ∂ y 2 ) + φ ( A 0 2 ) ε 0 , (10) ∂ A 0 2 ∂ z + ∂ S ∂ x ∂ A 0 2 ∂ x + ∂ S ∂ y ∂ A 0 2 ∂ y + A 0 2 ( ∂ 2 S ∂ x 2 + ∂ 2 S ∂ y 2 ) = 0 . Following the approach given by Sodha et al. [6,42], the solutions of Eqs. (9) and (10) can be expressed as (11) S = x 2 2 f 1 ( z ) d f 1 ( z ) d z + y 2 2 f 2 ( z ) d f 2 ( z ) d z + φ ( z ) , and (12) A 0 2 = E 0 2 f 1 ( z ) f 2 ( z ) A i ( x r 0 f 1 ( z ) ) exp ( a 0 x r 0 f 1 ( z ) ) exp ( − x 2 r 0 2 f 1 2 ( z ) ) A i ( y r 0 f 2 ( z ) ) exp ( a 0 y r 0 f 2 ( z ) ) exp ( − y 2 r 0 2 f 2 2 ( z ) ) , where φ ( z ) is the axial phase. Finally, after some calculations, the dimensionless beam width parameters f 1 and f 2 are expressed by the following differential equations (13-a) d 2 f 1 ( z ) d ξ 2 = 1 f 1 3 − 3 4 ( ω 2 r 0 2 c 2 ) ω p 0 2 γ ω 2 m 0 γ M ( α E 0 2 ) c 1 5 f 1 2 f 2 ( a 0 g 1 + g 2 ) exp [ − 3 4 m 0 γ M α E 0 2 f 1 f 2 g 2 4 ] , and (13-b) d 2 f 2 ( z ) d ξ 2 = 1 f 2 3 − 3 4 ( r 0 2 ω 2 c 2 ) ω p 0 2 γ ω 2 m 0 γ M ( α E 0 2 ) c 1 5 f 1 f 2 2 ( a 0 g 1 + g 2 ) exp [ − 3 4 m 0 γ M α E 0 2 f 1 f 2 g 2 4 ] , with (14-a) g 1 = 1 / ( 3 3 Γ ( 1 / 3 ) ) , and (14-b) g 2 = 1 / ( 3 3 Γ ( 2 / 3 ) ) . In Eqs. (13), ξ = z/R d is the normalized propagation distance and R d = kr 0 is the Rayleigh length. The first term on the right hand side of Eqs. (13-a) and (13-b) is due to the diffraction effect and the second term is the nonlinear term that is responsible for relativistic self-focusing in collisionless plasma. Eqs. (13-a) and (13-b) can be solved numerically with appropriate boundary conditions. On the other hand, if the value of a 0 is equal to zero, Eqs. (13-a) and (13-b) reduce to the case of Airy-Gaussian beam, and thus the dimensionless beam width parameters f 1 and f 2 are expressed by the following differential equations (15-a) d 2 f 1 ( z ) d ξ 2 = 1 f 1 3 − 3 α E 0 2 4 ( ω 2 r 0 2 c 2 ) ω p 0 2 γ ω 2 m 0 γ M c 1 5 g 2 f 1 2 f 2 exp [ − 3 4 m 0 γ M α E 0 2 f 1 f 2 g 2 4 ] , and (15-b) d 2 f 2 ( z ) d ξ 2 = 1 f 2 3 − 3 α E 0 2 4 ( r 0 2 ω 2 c 2 ) ω p 0 2 γ ω 2 m 0 γ M c 1 5 g 2 f 1 f 2 2 exp [ − 3 4 m 0 γ M α E 0 2 f 1 f 2 g 2 4 ] , 3 Self-trapped mode For an initial plane wavefront at ξ =0, ( f 1 ) ξ = 0 = 1 , ( ∂ f 1 / ∂ ξ ) = 0 and ( f 2 ) ξ = 0 = 1 , ( ∂ f 2 / ∂ ξ ) = 0 , when ( ∂ 2 f 1 / ∂ ξ 2 ) = 0 and ( ∂ 2 f 2 / ∂ ξ 2 ) = 0 the initial beam width does not change along the propagation in the plasma and so-called self-trapped mode. These conditions and its corresponding graph are known as critical condition and the critical curve, by putting ( ∂ 2 f 1 / ∂ ξ 2 ) = 0 and ( ∂ 2 f 2 / ∂ ξ 2 ) = 0 in both Eqs. (13-a) and (13-b) respectively, the expression of dimensionless initial beam width ρ 0 ( = r 0 ω / c ) is given by (16) ρ 0 = 1 3 4 m 0 M ( α E 0 2 ) c 1 5 ( a 0 g 1 + g 2 ) exp [ 3 8 m 0 γ M α E 0 2 c 1 4 ] . The propagation of finite Airy-Gaussian beam in relativistic plasma can be explain by analyzing the dependence of dimensionless initial beam width ρ 0 as a function of intensity parameter α E 0 2 for the plasma under self-trapped condition. The results are given in Fig. 2 which illustrates the dependence of dimensionless beam width as a function of intensity parameter for four values of the aperture coefficient: a 0 =0.0, 0.1, 0.5 and 0.9. It can clearly see that the decrease of ρ 0 is observed with the increase of α E 0 2 for relativistic plasma and tends to be larger when the aperture coefficient is greater. Finally, the dimensionless initial beam width becomes independent of α E 0 2 . We indicate that when the value of a 0 is equal to zero, Eq. (16) reduces to the case of Airy-Gaussian beam. 4 Results and discussion In this section, Eqs. (13-a) and (13-b) are solved simultaneously by using the fourth-order Runge-Kutta technique, with a set laser-plasma parameters: r 0 =4×10−3 cm, n 0 =1.1×1019 cm −3, ω =3.75×1014 rad/s, ω p =1.87×1014 rad/s, γ =1.25, m 0/M =0.02, and maximum laser intensity is I 0 =5×1018 W/cm 2. We note that when we use the high power laser beam, the relativistic nonlinear effect arises from the relativistic mass adjustment and depends on the both parameters the intensity factor α E 0 2 and the relativistic plasma density ω p /ω. The relativistic effect leads to the self-focusing of the laser beam on account of nonlinear term while the diffraction term is responsible of the diffractional divergence of the beam. The variation of the beam width parameters f 1 and f 2 as a function of the normalized propagation distance ξ for different values of modulation parameter (a 0 =0.0,0.1, 0.5 and 0.9) with ω p /ω =0.6, and α E 0 2 = 42 is illustrated in Fig. 3 . It can be seen from this figure that strong self-focusing happens at ξ =2.98, ξ =2.26, ξ =1.41, and ξ =1.10 for a 0 =0.0, 0.1, 0.5 and 0.9, respectively. Consequently, by increasing the modulation parameter a 0, self-focusing of finite Airy-Gaussian beam becomes better and shifted towards lower values of propagation distance ξ. Fig. 4 shows the variation of the beam width parameters f 1 and f 2 as a function of the normalized propagation distance ξ with various relative plasma density (ω p /ω =0.5, 0.6 and 0.7) where α E 0 2 = 60 . From Fig. (4-a), it is obvious that the strong self-focusing of Airy-Gaussian beam occurs at ξ =3.22, ξ =1.31, and ξ =0.94 for ω p /ω =0.5, 0.6 and 0.7, respectively. In the case of finite Airy-Gaussian beam Fig. (4-b), the self-focusing is stronger at ξ =1.42, ξ =0.94, and ξ =0.72 for ω p /ω =0.5, 0.6 and 0.7 respectively. It is also noted that the stronger and previous self-focusing of laser beam products with increase of plasma density. We can explain this result that when the plasma density becomes larger at relativistic intensities, the beam possess very large number of relativistic electrons will be carried by the laser pulse and hence a higher magnetic field is generated which increases the self-focusing. In Fig. 5 , the behavior of the beam width parameters f 1 and f 2 with the normalized propagation distance ξ is presented for three values of intensity parameter ( α E 0 2 = 40 ,60 and 100) at ω p /ω =0.6. It is observed that by increasing the value of intensity parameter the laser self-focusing tends to converge strongly and moved towards smaller value of normalized propagation distance, and becomes stronger for Airy-Gaussian beam (Fig. 5-a) at ξ =3.98, ξ =1.31, and ξ =0.80 for α E 0 2 = 40 , 60 and 100, respectively, and at ξ =1.49, ξ =0.93, and ξ =0.63 for α E 0 2 = 40 , 60 and 100, respectively for finite Airy-Gaussian beam (Fig. 5-b). This result is due to the dominance of self-focusing beam term over the diffraction term which caused by the relativistic nonlinearity. We can mentioned, for all presentations of beam width parameters as function normalized propagation distance, that the frequency of the oscillations and the amplitude increase with the aperture coefficient, the relative plasma density and the intensity parameter. Fig. 6 shows the dependence of beam intensity distributions with x / r 0 and the normalized propagation distance for different values of modulation parameter: a 0 =0.0, 0.1, 0.5 and 0.9. From this figure, it’s shown that the intensity laser beam presents oscillations dues to the oscillatory behavior of beam width along the propagation distance. The number of oscillations increases with the modulation parameter, which explains that the modulation parameter favors self-focusing of the laser beam. Therefore the oscillatory self-focusing mode for finite Airy-Gaussian beam is enhanced than that of the Airy-Gaussian beams. This result confirms the previous discussion. 5 Conclusion In the present investigation, the analytical equation of beam-width parameter for finite Airy-Gaussian beam is derived by using Wentzel-Kramers-Brillouin and paraxial approximations. From our numerical results, one can conclude that various parameters affect the behavior of the considered beams family which plays essential role in the self-focusing process, indeed the finite Airy-Gaussian beam becomes focuses stronger and earlier with larger plasma and beam parameters. In additionally, we are deduced the result of Airy-Gaussian beam from our analytical and numerical results as a special case. The comparison between both finite Airy-Gaussian beam and Airy-Gaussian beam are discussed and shows the better oscillatory self-focusing mode for finite Airy-Gaussian beam than Airy-Gaussian beam. It is predicted that the results of the present study are useful in understanding the physics of high power laser driven fusion and clarifying the mechanisms engaged in beam propagation in technological applications and in the laboratory.

column2: Estimating the height of wetland vegetation using airborne discrete-return LiDAR data
column3: Abstract Several studies have been conducted to estimate wetland vegetation height using airborne LiDAR data. However, no studies have been conducted to explore the influence of vegetation cover on vegetation height estimation models. The objective of this research is to estimate vegetation height in wetlands with varying vegetation cover for further analyzing the effects of vegetation cover. First, we performed both linear and logarithmic regression analyses between field-measured heights and each LiDAR-derived metric in wetlands with different vegetation cover. Then LiDAR-derived metrics were combined through multiple regression analysis to estimate wetland vegetation height. The height estimates were finally validated by leave-one-out cross-validation method. The results showed that the logarithmic regression analysis performed better than the linear regression analysis in estimating wetland vegetation height for almost all LiDAR-derived metrics regardless of vegetation cover. The max height of LiDAR returns (Hmax) provided the best agreement with field-measured heights in wetlands with high vegetation cover. In contrast, the strongest correlation was observed using the standard deviation of LiDAR heights (H SD ) for low vegetation cover. Results of multiple regression analysis indicated that the best model was based on Hmax and 90 percentile height of LiDAR returns (H90) in wetlands with high vegetation cover, while the best model can be expressed as a function of H SD and H90 for low vegetation cover. Therefore, our study concluded that vegetation cover is an important factor of vegetation height models. Additionally, our study will provide valuable guidance for field-measured data collection and vegetation height estimation using LiDAR data.
column5: Keywords Airborne LiDAR Wetland vegetation Vegetation height 1 Introduction Wetland vegetation is a core component of wetland ecosystems and plays an important role in the ecological functions of wetlands. The quantitative description of wetland vegetation structure characteristics is critical for sustainable ecosystem management and preserving biological diversity [1–4]. Vegetation height, one of the most important structural variables, is a key input required by wetland ecosystem models [3,5,6]. Therefore, it is essential to accurately estimate the height of wetland vegetation. Advances in airborne light detection and ranging (LiDAR) have made it a good data source for accurately estimating vegetation canopy height over large areas [7–10]. Over the past decade, many studies have demonstrated the capability of airborne discrete-return LiDAR data for forest height estimation [11–13]. LiDAR-derived metrics, such as the mean and max height of LiDAR normalized returns, have usually been used to estimate forest canopy height [9,14,15]. However, the estimation accuracy of these metrics derived from airborne discrete-return LiDAR data is usually limited in environments with short, dense vegetation for two reasons [16,17]. First, the laser penetration to the ground is greatly affected by dense vegetation, making terrain estimates and thus vegetation height estimates less accurate [18–20]. Second, airborne discrete-return LiDAR data provide limited information about vegetation vertical structure because they only record one return for each emitted pulse in areas with short vegetation [21]. Regardless of these limitations, a list of previous studies has proven that airborne LiDAR is a valuable tool for estimating short vegetation height across a range of vegetation species [14,22–24]. Simultaneously, these studies indicated that vegetation species has a substantial effect on vegetation height estimation models [14,20]. Both LiDAR-derived metrics and types of models varied greatly under environments with different vegetation species. For example, Davenport et al. (2000) indicated that the standard deviation of detrended LiDAR heights is the best predictor of vegetation height for agricultural crops [23], while Hladik, Schalles, and Alber (2013) showed that height metrics are more suitable for estimating vegetation height in salt marsh [25]. Kulawardhana, Popescu, and Feagin (2014) predicted vegetation height using a linear regression analysis in salt marsh environments [17], while Luo et al. (2015) reported that a logarithmic regression analysis performs better than a linear regression analysis in estimating the height of wetland vegetation [26]. Additionally, these studies also showed that vegetation height prediction models may be different even for the same vegetation species [22,25]. This situation may be caused by the different vegetation cover. However, no studies have been conducted to explore the effects of vegetation cover on the estimation models of vegetation height. Therefore, in this paper, we aimed at estimating the vegetation height in wetlands of varying vegetation cover using airborne discrete-return LiDAR data to investigate the influence of vegetation cover on vegetation estimation models. To fulfill this goal, the following three objectives were used: (1) to conduct linear and logarithmic regression analyses of field-measured heights against each LiDAR-derived metric in wetlands with different vegetation cover, (2) to evaluate the combined use of LiDAR-derived metrics for height estimation through multiple regression analysis, (3) to assess the accuracies of wetland vegetation height estimates using the leave-one-out cross-validation method. 2 Materials and methods 2.1 Study area The study area is located in Zhangye City, Gansu Province of northwest China (Fig. 1 ). The terrain of the experiment site is relatively flat, with a mean elevation of 1410m above sea level. The dominant vegetation is reed (Phragmites australis), representing approximately 95% of all wetland vegetation, and there are a few other plant species such as Amorpha fruticosa L., Salix saposhnikovii A. Skv. and Lycium chinese Mill. The vegetation across the study area is short, and the maximum vegetation height is generally less than 2.0m. 2.2 Airborne LiDAR data The airborne discrete-return LiDAR data used in this study were from the “Heihe Watershed Allied Telemetry Experimental Research (HiWATER)” project [27] and were collected in July 2012 using a Leica ALS70 system. The nominal flying height was 1300m above the ground level, and the average point density was approximately 6.7points/m2. Raw point clouds were processed to extract LiDAR-derived metrics in this study. Outliers were first eliminated using an elevation frequency histogram method [28].Then, the LiDAR point clouds were classified as canopy and ground returns using the adaptive triangulated irregular network (TIN) filtering algorithm embedded in the TerraScan software [29]. A digital elevation model (DEM) was finally created using ground returns with a grid cell size of 0.5m. Additionally, the accuracy of the DEM was assessed using differential Real-time kinematic Global Positioning System (RTK GPS) points, and the mean error (ME) and root mean squared error (RMSE) of the DEM are 0.05m and 0.12m, respectively. Using this DEM, we can remove the influence of topography and obtain DEM-normalized LiDAR point clouds. The LiDAR-derived metrics were calculated based on the DEM normalized LiDAR point clouds. 2.3 Field measurements The field measurements were conducted on July 11–13, 2012. There were a total of 208 sample plots, with a radius of 1m, across the whole study area. Nine representative measurements of vegetation height were randomly collected within each plot, and the mean value of these nine vegetation heights was calculated and referred to as the reference height value of each plot. Table 1 shows the statistics of the measured vegetation height in the field plots. The geographic coordinate of each plot center was measured with high accuracy using a differential RTK GPS. Additionally, only the field plots in areas with homogeneous vegetation were selected to reduce the effect of positioning accuracy on the height estimation. The coordinate system of these plot center coordinates is 47N/WGS-84, corresponding to that of airborne discrete-return LiDAR data. 2.4 Wetland vegetation height estimation and accuracy assessment In this study, a wide range of LiDAR-derived metrics, which have been successfully used for characterizing vegetation height in previous studies, were used to estimate wetland vegetation height [17,30–33]. These metrics included 1) selected height measures, i.e., the percentile height (H75, H80, H90), max height (Hmax) and mean height (H mean ) of the LiDAR returns, and 2) variability of height measures, i.e., the standard deviation (H SD ) and coefficient of variation (H CV ) of the detrended LiDAR heights. These LiDAR-derived metrics were calculated based on DEM-normalized LIDAR point clouds. However, only the results for the best metrics are discussed further in this paper. These metrics for each plot were estimated using the following formulae: (1) H max = max ( h i ) , 1 ≤ i ≤ N (2) H m e a n = 1 N ∑ i = 1 N h i (3) H S D = ∑ i = 1 N ( h i − H m e a n ) 2 N − 1 (4) H C V = H S D H m e a n (5) CC = N c a n o p y N c a n o p y + N g r o u n d where h i is the height of the ith point in the plot, and N, N canopy , and N ground are the total number of LiDAR points, number of canopy points and number of ground points in each plot, respectively. To analyze the influence of the vegetation cover on vegetation height predication models, this study compared different LiDAR-derived metrics and types of models for quantifying vegetation height in wetlands of varying vegetation cover. In detail, both the linear and logarithmic regression analyses between the field-measured heights and each LiDAR-derived metric were conducted. These models were examined in wetlands with high vegetation cover and low vegetation cover, respectively. In this study, low vegetation cover was differentiated from high vegetation cover according to the vegetation cover (CC) calculated from the airborne discrete-return LiDAR data. The CC was calculated as the ratio between the number of vegetation returns and the number of all returns within each plot. Therefore, a height threshold was set as 0.1m to separate vegetation returns from all returns for calculating the CC according to the study of Luo et al. (2015) [26]. In addition, a threshold of the vegetation cover was set as 0.8 to separate low from high vegetation cover in this study. However, this study did not divide all field plots into a high vegetation cover class and a low vegetation cover class. The high vegetation cover class contains all the field plots (CC=0–1.0), and the low vegetation cover class only includes the field plots for which the value of the vegetation cover is less than 0.8 (CC=0–0.8) in this study. Thus, the numbers of plots that belong to high and low vegetation cover classes are 208 and 138, respectively. Furthermore, to evaluate the combined use of LiDAR-derived metrics for the height estimation of wetland vegetation under various vegetation cover, multiple regression analysis was performed using all LiDAR-derived metrics as explanatory variables [34,35]. The procedure of the multiple regression analysis includes three main steps. First, the initial model is fitted using all the LiDAR-derived metrics as selected predictors. Second, the selected predictors with a p-value of greater than 0.05 (p>0.05) were regarded as being not significant and were removed; then, the model was refitted. Finally, the two steps were iterated until all the selected predictors were statistically significant. In this study, the coefficient of determination (R2) and the root mean squared error (RMSE) were calculated to evaluate the fitness degree of the height estimation models. Additionally, leave-one-out cross-validation (LOOCV) was performed to assess the reliability of these models. The LOOCV method is an effective method for evaluating the generalization capability of regression models, being particularly useful for models with a small number of samples [36,37].The root mean square error (RMSECV) from the cross-validation analysis was calculated and adopted as an indicator of the model predictive power [37]. 3 Results The results of both the linear and logarithmic regression analyses between the field-measured heights and each LiDAR-derived metric are listed in Table 2 . From Table 2, due to the higher R2 and lower RMSE values of the logarithmic regression analyses, we can conclude that logarithmic regression analyses perform better in estimating vegetation height than linear regression analyses for almost all LiDAR-derived metrics in wetlands regardless of vegetation cover. Among all the LiDAR-derived metrics, the max height of the LiDAR returns Hmax provided the best agreement with the field-measured heights, as indicated by the highest R2, lowest RMSE and RMSECV (R2 =0.600, RMSE=0.219m, RMSECV =0.221m) in environments with high vegetation cover. The best-constructed model was H=0.580*ln(Hmax)+1.467 (Fig. 2 a). However, the strongest relationship was observed between the standard deviation of the detrended LiDAR height H SD and the field-measured heights in wetlands with low vegetation cover, and the best-constructed model in this environment was H=0.513*ln(H SD )+2.205 (Fig. 2b). This model had the highest R2 and the lowest RMSE and RMSECV (R2 =0.692, RMSE=0.209m, RMSECV =0.212m). Additionally, multiple regression analysis was employed to estimate the height of the wetland vegetation using the LiDAR-derived metrics as explanatory variables. In this study, multiple regression analysis was only conducted for the case of logarithmic transformations because the logarithmic regression analyses perform better in estimating the wetland vegetation height compared to the linear regression analyses. The p-values of all the LiDAR-derived metrics were simultaneously calculated during the multiple regression analysis process (as shown in Fig. 3 ). Only the LiDAR-derived metrics with p-values of less than 0.05 were considered in this study. In this case, the best-constructed model of the multiple regression analysis was built based on Hmax and H80 in wetlands with high vegetation cover; the equation is H=0.336*ln(Hmax)+0.140*ln(H80)+1.522 (Fig. 4 a). However, multiple regression analysis returned H90, H SD , and H CV as the significant variables in the model for low vegetation cover, and the best model is H=0.661*ln(H SD )−0.271*ln(H CV )−0.222*ln(H90)+2.242 (Fig. 4b). To summarize, the results of both the simple regression analysis and multiple regression analysis indicated that the height estimation models are quite different in wetlands with different vegetation cover. Thus, we can conclude that vegetation cover is an important factor of height estimation models. 4 Discussion The results of our study indicated that the logarithmic regression analyses performed better than the linear regression analyses in estimating the height of wetland vegetation for almost all LiDAR metrics regardless of vegetation cover. This is in agreement with many previous studies. Cobby, Mason, and Davenport (2001) showed that a logarithmic regression analysis can better explain the relationship between field crop height with LiDAR-derived metrics [22]. In addition, Luo et al. (2015) indicated that logarithmic regression analysis (R2 value of 0.85 with an RMSE of 0.14m) achieves a higher estimation accuracy than does linear regression analysis (R2 =0.74 and RMSE=0.19m) in estimating wetland vegetation height [26]. This can be mainly explained as the result of the varying degrees of laser pulse penetration into the foliage under different vegetation cover. Although we assume that the laser pulses were returned from the top of the canopy surfaces, the laser pulses were usually returned from inside the canopy. The degree of laser pulse penetration is closely related to the vegetation cover of each plot. For example, in dense vegetation areas, most laser pulses are returned from the top of the canopy surfaces, whereas the laser pulses are returned from inside the canopy in sparse vegetation areas. Given that the vegetation cover varied greatly in our study area, the degree of laser pulse penetration may be different in different plots. For example, the LiDAR-derived metrics present a large difference in two plots with the same vegetation heights but different vegetation cover. In this case, linear regression analysis cannot ideally represent the relationship between the vegetation height and the LiDAR-derived metrics for our experiment site. In this analysis, a range of LiDAR-derived metrics were used for the height estimation of wetland vegetation. The standard deviation of the detrended LiDAR height showed the strongest correlation with the vegetation height in wetland environments with low vegetation cover. H SD represents the variation in the vertical laser point height distribution, which has been proven to be a good predictor for estimating the height of short vegetation in previous studies [17,22,23,26]. More importantly, this metric does not rely on a certain fraction of return pulses hitting the ground, short vegetation usually presents a small standard deviation, and tall vegetation results in larger values. Therefore, H SD was a good choice to estimate short vegetation in wetlands of low vegetation cover in our study. However, our findings revealed Hmax, which is the max height of the LiDAR returns, as the best predictor of the vegetation height in wetland environments with high vegetation cover. This corresponds with the study of Hopkinson et al. (2006) [14]. Their study reported that Hmax is a better indicator of vegetation canopy height over homogeneous vegetation. In addition, Hmax provided the best agreement with field-measured heights in salt marshes, as indicated by Kulawardhana, Popescu, and Feagin (2014) [17]. The high accuracy of the LiDAR-derived DEM in our study may have contributed to the smaller errors in the vegetation height estimates using Hmax. Moreover, almost all laser pulses will reflect from the top of the canopy in dense vegetation areas, thereby limiting the variation in the vertical distribution and thus greatly affecting the height estimation using H SD . Therefore, Hmax is the best LiDAR-derived metric to estimate the wetland vegetation height in environments with dense vegetation cover. Additionally, we found that multiple regression analysis can improve the height estimation accuracy of wetland vegetation regardless of vegetation cover. Additionally, the height estimation models of the multiple regression analysis are different in wetlands with different vegetation cover. To summarize, our study concluded that the vegetation cover is a key factor that greatly affected the height prediction models of wetland vegetation. This conclusion can help to explain the phenomenon whereby height estimation models may be different even for the same vegetation species. More importantly, this study contributes to field-measured data collection and vegetation height estimation using LiDAR data. In future studies, field measurements must be collected at experiment sites with both high and low vegetation cover to build a good height estimation model, which would have wider applicability for predicting vegetation height. 5 Conclusions Airborne discrete-return LiDAR data were used to estimate the short vegetation height in wetlands of varying vegetation cover in this study. The results indicated that logarithmic regression analyses perform better than linear regression analyses in estimating the short vegetation height in wetlands regardless of vegetation cover. The best-constructed model is the logarithmic regression analysis using the max height of the LiDAR returns (Hmax) in environments with high vegetation cover. However, the standard deviation (H SD ) of the detrended LiDAR heights is the best predictor of the short vegetation height in wetland environments with low vegetation cover. Additionally, the combined use of LiDAR-derived metrics in multiple regression analysis can improve the estimation accuracy for wetland vegetation regardless of vegetation cover, and the results of the multiple regression analysis indicated that the height estimation models are quite different in wetlands with different vegetation cover. Our study concluded that vegetation cover strongly affects vegetation height estimation models for wetlands. Although the types of models remain unchanged, the LiDAR-derived metrics were different under an environment with different vegetation cover. To summarize, this work contributes to collecting field-measured data and finding a good model for estimating the height of short vegetation, although it has a limitation. The vegetation height estimation in this research was only conducted in wetland of varying vegetation cover. Future works should focus on vegetation height estimation under specific environments with varying vegetation species and vegetation cover. Author Contributions Sheng Nie and Cheng Wang conceived of and designed the experiments; Sheng Nie performed the experiments, analyzed the data and wrote the paper; Xiaohuan Xi, Shihua Li and Jianlin Tian provided valuable suggestions and revised the paper; and Shezhou Luo collected the field data. Conflicts of interest The authors declare no conflict of interest. Acknowledgments This work was supported by the National Natural Science Foundation of China (41471294 & 41671434 & 41371350).
