column2: Influence of Cd on optical and photoluminescence behavior of Zn0.98-xCdxMn0.02S quantum dots under Ar atmosphere
column3: Abstract In the present study, Zn0.98-xMn0.02CdxS (x=0, 0.02 and 0.04) quantum dots have been successfully synthesized using co-precipitation method. X-ray diffraction (XRD) study confirmed substitution of Cd, Mn well in ZnS host with existing cubic structure. The average size of the particles was measured from XRD pattern and it was ∼2nm. The SEM study was taken to reveal the surface morphology of the samples. EDX spectra evidenced the existence of Cd, Mn, Zn and S in the samples as per the targeted stoichiometry. FTIR spectra confirmed the presence of peaks which corresponding to molecules present in the samples. UV–visible absorption and transmission spectra were studied and high intensity of absorption was received for the higher composition of Cd. A huge suppression was noticed in transmission peaks during Cd addition. When 2% of Cd added with Mn: ZnS, A small blue shift was identified and got redshift for higher concentration of Cd. Band gap values were tuned from 3.79eV to 3.98eV and discussed based on the quantum confinement effect. From this tailoring of band gap and optical property, these materials shall be selected for optoelectronic device applications. A room temperature photoluminescence study was carried out and sharp as well as strong UV band emissions were observed. Blue and green emission bands were also exhibited by Cd doping. The variations in luminescence intensities were discussed in terms of the crystallite size and defect state formation.
column5: Keywords Cd Mn doped ZnS Co-precipitation method Energy gap Photoluminescence 1 Introduction Fabrication of compound semiconductors from II–VI group is most fascinating one because of its diverse applications. In this trend, people give high priority to the ZnS since it possesses many imperative aspects in structural, luminescence, visible optical properties than the same expressed by ZnO [1]. ZnS is the first semiconductor material and it possesses two structures. ZnS is a wide band gap semiconductor and it can be doped by either by p-type semiconductor or n-type semiconductor. Cubic structure has the band gap of 3.72eV and wurtzite structure has a band gap of 3.77eV [2]. The ZnS material is a suitable material for electronic applications since it offers many optimum roles in Field effect transistors, solar, display and opto-electronic applications. The process of doping with transition metals will yield desired structural, optical and magnetic properties for various industrial applications [3,4]. Better luminescence was observed by Bhargava et al. in Mn doped ZnS [5]. Mn is having attractive optical and photoluminescence properties, Mn doped ZnS find solar cell applications [6]. The Mn composition ratio was confined as 2% because of its excellent optical properties especially better transmittance was observed from the earlier studies [7,8]. The process of Co-doping will help to fine tune the properties of nano particles for the specific selected applications in engineering sector. Doping of Cd divalent impurity (II column element) with ZnS was carried out by several researchers for harvesting the structural, optical, photo catalysis and photoluminescence properties towards solar, imaging and opto-electronic devices applications [9–13]. We can able to find some of the applications of Cd doped ZnS QDs as drug carrier and in bio-labelling process [14]. A unique role of Cd doped ZnS QDs selected for tuning of color emission in LEDs [15]. Some of the work was carried out on the separate preparation of Mn and Cd doped ZnS QDs and analyzed their optical and photoluminescence properties for opto-electronic device applications [16–19]. As the dual doping of Mn and Cd with ZnS was limited Cd was taken as the second doping material. Even though the Mn and Cd were having different ionic sizes, they attract more attention in characterizing better optical and electronic properties of the materials. Synthesis was successfully carried out by the simple co-precipitation method because of its ability for mass production in low cost. In the present work, an investigation was made for the preparation of dual doped ZnS QDs by Cd, Mn. The structural, morphological, optical and photoluminescence properties of Zn 0.98-xMn0.02CdxS QDs (x=0, 2 and 4) were discussed and results were reported. 2 Materials and methods 2.1 Preparation of Zn0.98-xMn0.02CdxS (x=0, 2 and 4) QDs Co-precipitation method was used to synthesize Zn0.98-x Mn0.02 Cdx S (x=0, 2 and 4) quantum dots in room temperature. Zinc acetate (Zn(CH3 COO)2), Manganese acetate (Mn(CH3COO2·2H2O)), cadmium acetate (Cd (CH3COOH)2·2H2O) and sodium sulfide (Na2S) were used as precursors for the preparation of Cd doped Mn:ZnS QDs. All the chemicals were in analytical grade (Merck, >99%) and hence further purification process was evaded. Ultra- pure de-ionized water was utilized throughout the preparation process. Quantity of (Zn(CH3 COO)2)·2H2O was taken as per the stoichiometry expected ratio and Mn doping percentage was fixed as 2% and Cd doping was varied from 0% to 4%. All the chemicals were weighed using electronic balance and dissolved in distilled water to prepare separate solutions. 0.5M of (Zn (CH3 COO)2)·2H2O dissolved in 50ml de-ionized water and 2% of Manganese acetate, different solutions of (0–4%) Cadmium acetate dissolved in 25ml de-ionized ultra-pure distilled water. Na2S was taken in equal molar amount of (Zn (CH3 COO)2). Each solution was added drop-wise in a common beaker under the continuous magnetic string for 6h. The rotating speed of magnetic stirrer was fixed as 1000rpm. The pH value was standardized at 9.5 using liquid ammonium. Due to the formation of Cd doped Mn:ZnS structure brownish precipitations were received at the end of the process. To get end product, precipitate was taken and washed by distilled water in order to ensure the purity. Finally it was kept in micro-oven for 6h at 65°C. After that the samples were kept in oven for 3h at 100°C under Ar atmosphere to enhance the quality of structural parameters and the nature of adherence. Final compound was powdered properly to get homogeneity in size. This process was repeated for getting Cd=0%, 2% and 4% with Mn (2%): ZnS QDs. 2.2 Experimental characterization techniques The crystal structure of the prepared samples was taken by using powder x-ray diffractometer (XRD). The diffracted patterns were registered by RigaKuC/max-2500 diffractometer using Cu Kα radiation (λ=1.506Å) at 40kV. XRD peaks recorded from 2θ=20° to 70° with scan rate 0.2° per min. Surface morphological studies were taken using SEM, (JEOLJSM 6390). The topology and element’s composition were analyzed by energy dispersive X-ray spectrometer (EDS) using K and L lines. UV–visible optical absorption spectra were observed to express the optical properties using UV–visible spectrometer (Model: Lambda 5, Make: Perkin Elmer). The spectra due to chemical composition were studied by FTIR spectrometer (Model: Perkin Elmer, Make: spectrum RX I) ranged from 400 to 4000cm−1. The KBr at 1wt% mixed with samples to make pellets for the FTIR measurement. The photoluminescence studies were analyzed using PL measurement (Hitachi, F-2500) at excitation energy of 325nm wavelength to study the radiative recombination properties. All the experimental studies were taken at room temperature. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Structural study (XRD) X-Ray Diffraction patterns are used to study the structure of the crystalline material, size, phase and inter planar distance. This is also used to provide information of the unit cell parameters. From Fig. 1 , It was clearly observed that all the three samples had well defined major peaks corresponding to (111) (220) (311) without formation of secondary peaks. These results confirmed the cubic structure of Mn+Cd+ZnS QDs with different composition of Cd (0%, 2% and 4%). Joint committee of powder diffraction standards value (JCPDS card No. 80-0020) supported the peaks received for cubic structure. Owing to the incorporation of Cd2+ ion in the Mn doped ZnS QDs, the original structure of ZnS was not disturbed and 2θ value pertaining to primary peak shifted towards higher angle side for 4% doping of Cd and it was returned to lower angle side slowly for 2% addition of Cd. This movement of 2θ values was ascribed to the change in particle size. Peak intensity was gradually increased for the every increase of Cd composition rate. When Cd2+ (0.78Å) ion was compared with Mn2+ (0.80Å) and Zn2+ (0.78Å) ions Cd2+ ion possess larger ionic radius. Due to this parameter the obtained crystallite size was increased lightly [19]. This evidenced the substitution of Cd2+ ion into Mn:ZnS host lattice. Devadoss et al. reported similar increase of crystallite size due to the addition of Cd composition into ZnS QDs [9]. Average crystallite size of all the three samples was determined by using Debye – Scherrer’s formula [20]. (1) A v e r a g e c r y s t a l l i n e s i z e ( D ) = 0.9 λ β cos θ Where, λ is the wavelength of X-ray used (1.5406Å), β denotes the full width at half maximum along primary axes (111) and θ indicates the Bragg’s diffraction angle. Micro-strain of the crystal structure was determined by using the formula given below [21]. (2) M i c r o - s t r a i n ( ε ) = β cos θ 4 Where, β is the full width at half maximum value of XRD primary peak and θ is Bragg’s diffraction angle. Micro strain value was slightly increased for 2% addition of Cd and got reduced for further rise of Cd doping. Lattice parameters were slightly varied for every incorporation of Cd with Mn:ZnS. The crystal parameters like lattice constant, FWHM value, crystallite size, inter-planar distance and micro-strain were listed in Table 1 . 3.2 Morphological analysis (SEM) SEM plays an effective role on the study of surface morphology by fetching actual information concerning the process behind in the growth of the structure, size and shape of crystalline material. Fig. 2 a–c revealed the SEM picture of Mn:ZnS and Cd doped M:ZnS QDs. The small size spherical shaped particles were identified in Fig. 2a. It confirmed the Mn doping into ZnS host. When Cd was introduced in the composition, a large aggregation of small particles was received and agglomeration was started slowly. Cd2+ ion replaced Zn2+ ion from the ZnS layout and small particles are mainly migrated from the inner portion to surface, and hence agglomeration was received at higher degree after doping with Cd. For the higher composition of Cd produced a highly agglomerated particles and which was shown in Fig. 2c. undoped Mn:ZnS, the compositional analysis is given below. 3.3 Elemental analysis (EDX) The EDS spectrum is an essential tool to explore the chemical composition present in the sample. The EDS spectra of Zn0.98-x Mn0.02 Cdx S (x=0, 0.02 and 0.04) quantum dots were shown in Fig. 3 a–c. The results obtained from the EDX analysis, confirmed the presence of Zn, Mn, Cr and S in samples as per the target ratio. The well-defined peaks related to the elements identified at equivalent energy values. The Cd atomic percentage was increased as 0%, 1.21% and 2.28% corresponding to 0%, 2% and 4% addition of Cd into Mn:ZnS QDs. The composition rate of Zn decreased gradually as the function of Cd incorporation and this proven that the replacement of Zn was done by Cd during doping. No other elements were traced and purity was evidenced. The derived elemental compositions are nearly equal to their stoichiometric ratios. Small fractional deviation may be occurred due to the experimental error. 3.4 UV–visible optical studies The tailoring of optical bandgap and absorption behavior of material will play a vital role for the utilization of opto-electronic device applications. Optical absorption and transmittance phenomena usually expressed the optical nature of the samples. Fig. 4 illustrates the UV–visible absorption behavior of Cd doped Mn:ZnS QDs within the range of 300nm to 600nm at room temperature. The intensity of absorption was increased around double time for 4% composition of Cd. The absorption intensity was enhanced as the function of Cd incorporation. The reason may be due to agglomeration of the particles and size growing effect. The inset picture depicts the variation in wavelength (red shift) and peak intensities clearly. The role of Cd was the high absorption of energy in UV region and their atoms got transition from lower energy state to higher energy state. From the room temperature transmittance study, it was observed that the transmittance got highly suppressed as the function of Cd doping. Mn doping into ZnS caused better transmittance and Cd incorporation diminished the transmittance intensity gradually. All the transmittance peaks have sharp increase in UV band due to their inter-band transitions from valence band to conduction band transitions. Fig. 5 shows the variation of transmittance of three samples within the range of 300nm to 600nm. The optical bandgap is the energy difference between the top of the valence band to the bottom of the conduction band. By varying the size of the QDs the tailoring of band gap is possible and it leads optimum outcome for band gap engineering. The band gap of cd doped Mn:ZnS was calculated by using the Tauc’s relation which relates absorption coefficient (α) and the incident photon energy (hν) of semiconductors as given below [22]. (3) α h ν = A ( h ν − E g ) n Where, A is a constant, Eg is an optical band gap of the semiconductor and the exponent value n denotes the type of transition. n=½ for direct allowed, n=2 for indirect allowed and n=3/2 for direct forbidden transition. The band gap of the prepared samples obtained by making a plot between energy (hν) and (αhν)2, extrapolation of the linear portion of the absorption edge as shown in Fig. 6 . Through doping, we can tune the bandgap of semiconductor for wide range based on the material composition and the size of the particles which appropriate for application orient. By increasing the Cd from 0% to 2% the bandgap was slightly blue shifted (from 3.92eV to 3.97eV). The reason for the blue shift was ascribed to quantum confinement effect since the size of the particle was reduced for this (2%) addition of Cd into Mn:ZnS. The similar blue shift in band gap was observed by Virpal et al. [23]. Band gap value was received a red shift (3.79eV) for further addition of Cd (4%). The valence and conduction bands of CdS are existed in the energy level of ZnS itself. Hence electron – hole pairs tried to appear with CdS which leads decrement in the energy levels [12,24]. This may also be due to direct energy transfer between semiconductor- excited states and 3d levels of Mn2+ and 4d shells of Cd2+. It supported the size increment concept of samples. All the samples exhibited the band gap larger than the bulk form (3.6eV) of ZnS is due to quantum confinement effect. 3.5 FTIR studies The room temperature FTIR spectra of Zn0.98-x Mn0.02 Cdx S (x=0, 0.02 and 0.04) quantum dots were taken from 400cm−1 to 4000cm−1 as shown in Fig. 5a. The strong absorption peaks observed from 3300cm−1 to 3500cm−1 were attributed to OH stretching vibrations of water molecule since chemicals were dissolved in distilled water earlier [25]. Vibrations due to CO2 stretching were identified near 2300cm−1 [26]. The relaxed peaks with higher transmittance intensity were received after CO2 vibrations. The bands noticed around 1500cm−1 were ascribed to HOH molecule bending vibrations in the samples [27]. The peaks appeared near 1400cm−1 were endorsed to CO stretching vibrations [28]. The extended FTIR spectra of Zn0.98-x Mn0.02 Cdx S (x=0, 2 and 4) quantum dots from 400cm−1 to 1000cm−1 were shown in Fig. 5b for the sake of clear visibility of microstructure formation. The sharp peaks located near 832cm−1 and 932cm−1 were due to Cd addition with Mn: ZnS QDs. Strong absorption bands at 618cm−1 and 671cm−1 were appeared because of the Mn and Cd incorporation into ZnS lattice [29]. Weak bands around 705cm−1 and 740cm−1 were appeared only in the IR spectra corresponding to Cd doping. Small and distinct shifts in intensity as well as wave number were owing to the addition of Cd and they were ranged from 400cm−1 to 1000cm−1. 3.6 Photoluminescence studies Photoluminescence study is an important tool to examine the light emitting property of the materials. We have taken room temperature PL study for Cd doped Mn:ZnS QDs. The PL spectra of the three samples were shown in Fig. 6a. Here the intensity of Mn doped ZnS was gradually decreased and a sharp increase was observed around 392nm. This UV emission peak evidenced a strong PL emission of the Mn doped ZnS in UV region. An incorporation of Cd produced a sudden and distinct peak in the UV region. All the peaks corresponding to Cd doped samples were blue shifted and their values were 389nm and 390nm. This shift in wavelength and peak intensity confirmed the presence of Cd2+ ions in the Mn:ZnS QDs. This UV band emission near 390nm in ZnS can be ascribed to recombination process between the Sulphur vacancy related donor and Zinc vacancy related acceptor levels [30]. The PL spectra of Cd doped Mn:ZnS QDS were shown in Fig. 6b. Here the wavelength was ranged from 450nm to 600nm (visible range). In this section two strong peaks were observed corresponding to blue emission (≈480nm) and green emission (≈520nm). For higher percentage of Cd doping, the green emission got red shift. This green and blue emission clearly evidenced the formation of Zn0.98-x Mn0.02 Cdx S (x=0, 2 and 4) QDs. The transition from extended Cdi band to valence band is responsible or the blue emission [31]. The strong green emission peaks were due to the recombination of surface states. This involved the recombination phenomena of electrons trapped inside a Sulphur vacancy with a hole existing in valence band of CdS [32]. The Fig. 6c shows the band diagram for PL emission. A transition from Vs to De provides blue emission near 480nm, Due to radiative transition between E and De was ascribed to green emission near 520nm and transition from 4T1 to 6A1 was attributed to increase in PL intensity near yellow emission. These results were evidenced by Mall et al. [19]. 4 Conclusions Zn0.98-xMn0.02CdxS (x=0, 2 and 4) QDs were successfully synthesized by coprecipitation method. All the samples were exhibited cubic structure without formation of secondary phase which was evidenced from XRD results. Crystallite size was increased for higher doping concentration of Cd. SEM results confirmed the presence of Cd on the surface of Mn doped ZnS QDs. EDX analysis report confirmed the presence of Zn, Mn, Cd and S elements in samples as per the expected ratio. A strong absorption was observed for the higher composition of Cd doping and lower transmittance was noticed for higher percentage of Cd addition. This material shall be selected for solar and opto-electronic device applications. Band gaps were tuned with wide range from 3.79eV to 3.98eV. FTIR spectra evidenced the presence of doped chemicals as per stoichiometry ratio. A strong UV emission was exhibited and firm blue and green emissions were traced from the PL study and it was discussed based on transition of electrons between states. These materials shall be selected for imaging applications also.

column2: An alternate method to extract performance characteristics in dye sensitized solar cells
column3: Abstract Modeling the electrical properties of dye-sensitized solar cells (DSSCs) can fill the gap between the experimental and ideal performance observations for a reliable device diagnosis, design and optimization. The complex physical and chemical reactions between nanocrystalline semiconductor, electrolyte ions and dye molecules make their simulation an open issue to the researchers. Compared to the research works presented in literature, here, we provide a simpler, but more meaningful fit of current −voltage curves by developing a simulation model. The present work provides a reliable framework to extract electrical transport properties of the device, namely, diffusion coefficient, transport time, diffusion length, series resistance and performance parameters from steady state current–voltage curves without using interpretable frequency dependent methods, as well as transient characteristics. The model versatility makes it also capable of predicting the dye regeneration efficiency under short circuit, mid-voltages and high voltage ranges. The simulation method can be also implemented to compare the effect of different electrolytes as well as their species concentrations on regeneration efficiency and overall DSSCs performance. The whole model is designed in a flexible framework to be adapted to various kind of solar cells such as quantum dot and perovskite solar cells.
column5: Keywords Dye-sensitized solar cell Current–voltage characteristics Dye regeneration Electrical properties 1 Introduction Solar cell technology has been vigorously tracking the dye sensitized solar cell (DSSCs) research findings due to their low cost production, easy fabrication and high efficiency from the time they were first introduced [1]. Meanwhile, several dyes as sensitizers [2–5], nanocrystalline metal oxide semiconductors namely, TiO 2, ZnO and etc. as electron transport medium [6,7] and electrolyte material as dye regenerator have been investigated [8,9]. In practice, the incident photon excites the dye molecules, followed by injection of an electron into the conduction band (C . B) of the nanocrystalline metal oxide semiconductor, and then the electron is diffused towards transparent conducting oxide (TCO) layer experiencing trapping/detrapping phenomena. At the same time, the oxidized electrolyte species are reduced by counter electrode (TCO/Pt) after regenerating the oxidized dye molecule. This cycle continues as long as the cell is under illumination. Optimization strategies concerning electron transport, recombination of electrons in C.B with electrolyte ions and oxidized dye molecules have been extensively investigated in literature. As one of the most basic works, Södergen et al. [10] assumed diffusive current to model the J − V characteristics of nanoporous semiconductor films in DSSC neglecting electrolyte species transport. Papageorgiou et al. [11] investigated the transport of electrolyte ions to clarify its impact on the performance of the DSSC. Ferber et al. [12] extended an electrical model including drift-diffusion equations in a system of pseudo-homogeneous TiO 2 layer intermixed with electrolyte active layer to study the internal cell properties. Bisquert et al. [13] presented a comprehensive model-based analysis to connect the different trap distribution regimes in semiconductor band gap to recombination processes in DSSCs. Salehi et al. [14] developed a model to show the improved performance of DSSC by employing flexible substrate. In other similar works, the effect of blocking layer application in DSSC [15] and dynamic doping by using heterointerface layers are discussed [16]. Anta et al. [17,18] developed a single carrier- based model to extract the transport characteristics of the DSSC. Nevertheless, a lack of realistic methodology incorporating the minimum experimental data and simulation- based interpretation under steady and transient state, for device diagnosis and optimum design can be still felt. Previous works by the authors [15,19] introduced a semi-empirical methodology by developing an integrated modeling method to investigate transport properties in DSSC. In the present work, this model is further extended to verify its applicability to investigate, the crucial factors such as (i) shape of the current–voltage curve, (ii) transport properties (lifetime, transport time and diffusion length), and (iii) applied voltage dependent behavior of dye regeneration efficiency ( η r e g ) which controls the electron injection from dye lowest unoccupied molecular orbital (LUMO) to semiconductor conduction band. The model is also fitted to experimental photocurrent and voltage transient responses for providing both steady state and transient interpretations. The proposed modeling strategy enables us to determine the capacitance characteristics and transport properties as well as underlying factors controlling the DSSC performance with minimum experimental workload. 2 Experimental 2.1 Fabrication of DSSCs The TiO 2 paste was prepared as reported by Ito et al. [20]. Briefly, 6g of commercial TiO 2 (average size ∼25nm, P25 Degussa) nanoprticles was ground in mortar and with 20ml DI water, 3ml of ethanol, 1ml acetic acid, 3g of ethyl cellulose and, finally 6g of terpinoel was added, to the mixture and stirred for 30min. In order to make a slurry TiO 2 paste, rotary evaporator was used to remove the solvents. To prepare the DSSC working electrodes, the Fluorine-doped tin oxide (FTO) glasses (Solaronix) at first cleaned in a diluted hydrochloric acid, detergent solution, acetone, and methanol using an ultrasonic bath and then rinsed by deionized water. After treatment in 40mM aqueous TiCl4 solution at 70°C for 30min, the FTO glass was again washed with water and methanol. The TiO 2 paste was deposited on the substrate by doctor blading. Active area thicknesses were controlled by adhesive tape and to repeat the deposition the number of tapes was increased. After each coating, the cells were left horizontal to relax in clean box and dried at 125°C in air. Finally, all cells were sintered at 500°C in a programmable furnace to make the films porous. The TiO 2 films were again treated with 40mM TiCl4 solution, as previously described, then rinsed with water and methanol and heated at 450°C for 15min and 500°C for 15min. The electrodes were immersed into a 0.4mM N-719 dye ((ruthenium (2, 2′-bipyridyl-4,4′-dicarboxilate)2(NCS)2, Dyesol, Australia) solution in a mixture of acetonitrile and tert-butyl alcohol (volume ratio: 1:1) and kept at room temperature for 24h to complete dye loading. Pre-holed FTO glasses were cleaned and Pt catalyst was deposited on the them by spincoating applying a drop of H2PtCl6 solution (2mg Pt in 1ml 2-propanol) and repeating the heat treatment at 500°C for 15min. The dye-covered TiO 2 electrode and Pt-counter electrode were assembled into a sandwich type cell and sealed with a hot-melt 25μm thick thermoplastic sealing film made of Surlyn (SX-1170-25, Solaronix). The electrolyte was prepared by a solution 0.60M PMII, 0.03M I2, 0.10M LiI and 0.50M 4-tert- butylpyridine(TBD) in the mixture of acetonitrile and valeronitrile (volume ratio: 75:25) was introduced into the holes in the back of the counter electrode. 2.2 Electrical measurements The current–voltage (J − V) characteristics were measured using Linear Sweep Voltammetry mode of potantiostat (Em Stat2, PalmSens BV, Netherlands) and solar simulator (Prova, Taiwan). The illumination intensity was adjusted using a built-in Si solar cell to AM1.5. Incident light intensity and active cell area were 100mWcm−2 (1 sun) and 0.25cm−2, respectively. The open circuit photovoltage decay (OCVD) was measured by switching off the light source at steady state. The short circuit photocurrent versus time was measured by switching on and off the light source at steady state. 3 Simulation model The simulation model considers steady state and transient transport characteristics of electrons (e), iodide (I −) and tri-iodide ( I 3 − ) in porous photoanode film in one dimension. Fig. 1 plots the relationship between the various processes considered in the model. Firstly, the dynamic equations controlling each particle are established, then their density profiles are calculated considering proper initial and boundary conditions and finally, current density is calculated at each applied voltage from zero to V oc . The main driving force for collecting electrons results from electron density gradient in the vicinity of x =0, ie the diffusive current has the only significant role in electron transport. The contribution of drift in electron and ion transport is neglected because of a short Debye length the electrical field is not significant [20,21]. Fig. 2 depicts the computational algorithm to reproduce the J − V curve fitting. 3.1 Electronic transport The transport model is based on well-known concepts; (i) quasi-Fermi level (QFL) which states that when a semiconductor is illuminated, electrons are injected into the C.B, raising the Fermi level and establishing density gradient. (ii) multi-trap model (MTM) in which the electron transport is assumed to happen via extended states E c and is slowed down by trapping and detrapping of electrons to and from localized trap centers. The result of this model is an effective diffusion coefficient and recombination constant that are electron density dependent (Fig. 1). (iii) is the quasi static approximation (QSA) which assumes that the trapping and detrapping processes are much faster than the transport and recombination processes [22]. The continuity equation for electrons in the photoanode is (1) ∂ n ( x , t ) ∂ t = ( 1 + D ( n ) D 0 ) − 1 ( Γ ξ 2 ∂ ∂ x D ( n ) ∂ n ( x , t ) ∂ x + ( G e ( x , λ ) − R e ( x , t ) ) ( 1 − Θ ) + d n t c o d x ) with (2) D ( n ) = D 0 ∂ n c ∂ n t where D 0 is the diffusion coefficient and n, n t and n c are total, trapped and free electron densities, repectively. Θ is the porosity of the TiO 2 film, Γ and ξ are constrictivity and tortuosity, respectively [23]. Γ can narrow the carriers pathway and ξmakes them pass through a more indirect route. G e ( x , λ ) and R e ( x , t ) are the electron generation and recombination terms, respectively. The derivation of Eq. (1) is given in Appendix A. n tco is the electrons density profile that contribute to FTO/electrolyte recombination. The last term on the right hand side of Eq. (1), is the recombination current from TCO to the electrolyte which can be calculated from Butler-Volmer equation (3) J t c o = J t c o 0 { e x p [ − ( 1 − σ ) e V K b T ] − e x p [ σ e V K b T ] } where J tco0 and σ are the exchange current density and cathodic electron transfer. e is the electron charge, Kb is Boltzmann constant, T is the temperature and V is the applied bias. It describes how the electrical current on an electrode depends on the electrode potential, considering that both a cathodic and an anodic reaction occur on the same electrode. It should be emphasized here that Eq. (3) is only valid in this simple form if the current is really kinetically controlled, i.e. if diffusion of the redox species toward the electrode surface is sufficiently fast [24]. However, by TiCl 4 treatment of the substrates, this term can be neglected. 3.2 Iodide and tri-iodide transport By assuming the reaction processes in a typical DSSC, the generation of two electrons always gives the generation of one tri-iodide ion and the loss of three iodide ions i.e.: (4) 1 2 ( G e ( x , λ ) − R e ( x , t ) ) = ( G t r i ( x , λ ) − R t r i ( x , λ ) ) = − 1 3 ( G i ( x , λ ) − R i ( x , λ ) ) where G i ( x , λ ) , G t r i ( x , λ ) , R i ( x , λ ) , R t r i ( x , λ ) are the iodide and tri-iodide generation and recombination rates, respectively. Therefore the corresponding dynamic continuity equations for the iodide, n i ( x , t ) , and tri-iodide, n t r i ( x , t ) , in electrolyte becomes (5) ∂ n i ( x , t ) ∂ t = Γ ξ 2 D i ∂ 2 n i ( x , t ) ∂ x 2 − 3 2 Θ e d ( G e ( x , λ ) − R e ( x , t ) ) (6) ∂ n t r i ( x , t ) ∂ t = Γ ξ 2 D t r i ∂ 2 n t r i ( x , t ) ∂ x 2 + 1 2 Θ e d ( G e ( x , λ ) − R e ( x , t ) ) where D i and D tri are the iodide and tri-iodide diffusion coefficients of the photoanode. Θ ed is the porosity available for the electrolyte when dye molecules are adsorbed to the surface of nanoparticles [14]. 3.3 Dye cations For dye cations we can write (7) ∂ [ D + ] ( x , t ) ∂ t = G e ( x , λ ) − k 1 ( n c ( x , t ) − n 0 ) γ [ D + ] ( x , t ) − k 2 n i δ ( x , t ) [ D + ] ( x , t ) where k1 is the electron recombination with dye cations, [ D + ] ( x , t ) is density of cation dyes and k 2 is the dye regeneratin rate. δ is the reaction order in iodide density. γ is the nonlinearity factor in reaction between electrons in TiO 2 C.B and dye cations. Under steady state, ∂ [ D + ] ( x , t ) ∂ t = 0 and iodide density is constant under homogenous conditions, so we can write (8) [ D + ] ( x ) = G e ( x , λ ) k 1 ( n c ( x ) − n 0 ) γ − k 2 ( n i ) δ The regeneration efficiency can be defined as the ratio of regeneration rate of dye cations to the total addition of regeneration rate of dye cations and recombination rate of electrons and dye cations i.e. (9) η r e g = k 2 n i δ [ D + ] ( x , t ) k 1 ( n c ( x ) − n 0 ) γ + k 2 ( n i ) δ 3.4 Initial & boundary conditions The set of time dependent partial differential equations, Eqs. (1) (5) and (6) can be solved simultaneously by applying proper initial and boundary conditions for the carriers as follows 3.4.1 Electron (10a) n ( 0 , t ) = n ( x , 0 ) = n 0 e x p ( α e V K b T ) (10b) d n ( d , t ) d x = 0 α is the depth of traps with respect to the conduction band edge. The first boundary condition states that the initial electron density at the beginning of photoanode, where thickness d =0, is assumed voltage- dependent and the second assures zero current density at the end of photoanode. For electrolyte species we have 3.4.2 Iodide (11a) ∂ n i ( 0 , t ) ∂ x = − 3 2 J t c o e D i (11b) ∫ 0 d n i ( x , t ) d x = n i 0 Θ d (11c) n i ( x , 0 ) = n i 0 3.4.3 Tri-iodide (12a) ∂ n t r i ( 0 , t ) ∂ x = 1 2 J t c o e D t r i (12b) ∫ 0 d n t r i ( x , t ) d x = n t r i 0 Θ d (12c) n t r i ( x , 0 ) = n t r i 0 The first two boundary conditions in Eqs. (11a) and (12a) show that the electrolyte ions current at the beginning of photoanode is associated with the TCO/electrolyte back transfer. The second boundary conditions (Eqs. (11b) and (12b)) assure ions conservation through the photoanode thickness. Finally, by determining the electron density, the diffusion current is calculated at x =0 for different applied voltages by (13) J ( x , t ) = e D ( n ) d n ( x , t ) d x The power conversion efficiency (PCE) of a solar cell is determined by (14) η = P M P P i n where P MP = V OC J SC FF, FF ( = V M P J M P / V o c J s c ) and P in are fill factor and input power, respectively. The set of partial differential equations (Eqs. (1) (5) and (6)) are solved by applying the Method of Lines and spatial discretization of 100 points in Mathematica 9 medium. 3.5 Transient voltage response, electron lifetime and chemical capacitance Transient LASER spectroscopy is capable of directly giving the density of injected electrons [25]. An alternative way is to analyze the transient current and/or voltage arising from a changing light or voltage impulse. The main amplitude methods are electrical impedance spectroscopy (EIS) [26,27], intensity modulated photovoltage spectroscopy (IMVS) [28] and stepped light-induced transient measurement [29]. The lifetime from EIS is so to say “a voltage-dependent time constant,” which needs extra interpretation in order to obtain a reliable lifetime. Under OC condition, the injected electrons recombine with I 3 − ions. The OCVD technique has certain advantages over frequency or steady state based methods. The first is that this technique provides a continuous reading of the lifetime as a function of V oc at high-voltage resolution, the second is that being experimentally much simpler, and finally the data treatment is outstandingly simple. In the following, we present an analytical relation for interpretation of experimental OCVD data assuming a nonlinear recombination process to estimate the carrier’s lifetime. Walker et al. [30] showed that the OCVD should display a ln ( t ) dependence at longer times if recombination involves C.B electrons that are detrapped from an exponential distribution of trapping states and a quasi-static state is maintained between free and trapped electrons. Under OCVD condition, in the absence of diffusion and generation terms the continuity equation for electron density profile becomes (15) ( ∂ n c ∂ n t + 1 ) ∂ n t ∂ t = ( 1 − Θ ) − 1 k ( n ( t ) − n 0 ) β k here is the recombination rate and β is the nonlinearity parameter in recombination. Assuming that ∂ n c ∂ n t ≈ n c n t ≪ 1 and inserting the Boltzmann apporximation into Eq. (15) under open circuit (OC) voltage, we arrive at (16) d V o c ( t ) d t = ( ( 1 − Θ ) α e K b T ) − 1 k n 0 β − 1 [ e x p [ ( β − 1 ) α e V o c ( t ) K b T ] − 1 n 0 e x p [ α e V o c ( t ) K b T ] ] The last term on the right is negligible and by integration we obtain (17) V o c ( t ) = − ( α e ( 1 − β ) ( 1 − Θ ) ) − 1 K b T ln [ α k ( 1 − β ) n 0 β − 1 t ] By inserting the modeled V oc from Eq. (17) into Boltzmannn approximation the total electron density profile is calculated which enables us to find the carrier lifetime τ by a simple relation derived from Eqs. (15) and (17), (18) τ = − ( n ( t ) − n 0 ) β ( 1 − Θ ) − 1 ( ∂ n ∂ t ) − 1 The change of electron density under a small variation of the Fermi level is described by the chemical capacitance, [31] which takes the following form (19) C = e 2 ∂ ( n c + n t ) ∂ E f The chemical capacitance is a very crucial concept for solar cell development, since it adequately describes the splitting of Fermi levels caused by excitation of carriers in the light absorbing material [32]. In experiment, by EIS measurement under different voltages one can obtain C which can be used to measure the C.B shifts in the presence of different electrolytes. 4 Results and discussion 4.1 Steady state and transient current- voltage characteristics analysis and transport parameters extraction Fig. 3 c shows the spatial dependent behavior of electron density profile under short circuit condition throughout the photoactive layer for all DSSCs labeled as D1, D2, D3 and D4 with different thicknesses. The measured J-V data of D2 and D4 with thickness of about 15.7 and 24 μm (Figs. 3a and b) are also shown with model-fitted curves in Fig. 4 a for model evaluation. The simulated curves of 2 more devices, D1 with 10μm and D3 with 20μm thicknesses, are also included in Fig. 4a. At each spatial point, the electron density profile increases with time and reaches its steady state value. The electron density increases by reaching deeper into the photoanode. It is clearly seen that the electron density gradient is much larger at points close to x =0, resulting in higher diffusive current of electrons. It means that the first micrometers of photoanode mainly contributes to total current density. The trap parameter and diffusion coefficient are adjusted to obtain the best J − V curves fits for all cells under short circuit condition. The electron density profile for D3 gives the largest values by choosing α=0.35 and D 0 =2.2×10−4 cm2s−1 to obtain the best fit and a convergent current density for the voltages within the zero to V OC . The fitted values of diffusion coefficient for DSSCs D1, D2 and D4 are 1.3×10−4, 1.3×10−4 and 1.2×10−4 cm2s−1, respectively, and the continuity equation produces convergent values for current density values within the open circuit voltage by inserting α=0.29. The larger trap parameter means more effective contribution of shallower surface traps with respect to C.B edge [17]. The dependence of diffusion coefficient on thickness arises from the change in trap densities. At a same light intensity, electrons undergo more trapping/detrapping process in thicker films, so the charge transport rate is faster. The dependence of diffusion coefficient on light intensity arises from the change in trap occupancy with intensity. At low light intensity, electrons are exchanged between deep traps and the C.B, and the transport rate is slowed down. At high illumination intensities, deep traps are filled, and electron trapping/detrapping involves shallower levels, so that the electron experiences a faster transport rate [33]. The simulated J − V curves for D1 and D3 and measured J − V curves with their fitted curves for D2 and D4 with various photoanode thicknesses under 1 Sun illumination intensity are plotted in Fig. 4a. The experimental and simulated results are in good agreement for D2 and D4. As can be noticed, no specific behavior is observed from film thickness dependence behavior of open circuit voltages. The values of V oc strongly depends on the input values of k R (recombination rate defined in equation A1.16). Best fits to experimental J − V curves return the values of 5.5×10−10 and3×10−9s−1 for k R for C1 and C3, respectively, and 3×10−9s−1 for D2 and D4. These values are similar to pervious reports [55,43]. The V OC decrease means that the CB edge of TiO 2 shifts positively. The positive shift with respect to dye energy narrows the energy difference between TiO 2 and the dye which allows lower excited states of the dye to inject electrons, leading to a rise in short circuit current [34]. The decrease in V oc by varying the thickness can be associated to back electron transfer to tri-iodide ions. Increasing the surface area of the electrode as a result of increasing film thickness leads to an increase in surface trapping states which can cause back electron transfer. On the other hand, J SC increases by increasing the active layer thickness and suddenly experiences a drop for D4 with thickness of 23μm. The J SC increase is a result of incident photon to current efficiency ( I P C E ) improvement implying uniform charge generation throughout the film [35]. In addition, the improvement of J SC is related to the increase in injecton current from the excited dyes to the C.B of TiO 2 arising from the increased surface area and more dye adsorption. For D4 an additional simulated curve (Fig. 4a, red circle) is plotted which is the result of zero series resistance (R s =0). Considering a fitted value of R s =17Ωcm 2 to the experimental data of J − V curves for D2 and D4 by application of the relation V Exp = V ideal − J ideal R s A, one can easily reproduce the DSSCs final J − V curves (Table 1 ). Thicker films give a higher total amount of traps and hence a larger fraction of electrons being trapped/detrapped, and a longer time for the electron transport gives a larger probability for the electron to be lost to the electrolyte. The experimental values of current densities for D1 and D3 at low voltages (<200mV.) show a nonideal behavior which might be related to low charge-collection efficiency or even low dye regeneration efficiency [36]. Table 2 shows the calculated and fitted transport and performance parameters of the DSSCs with various active layer thicknesses. Fig. 4b plots the PCE of the cells with different photoanode thicknesses under different illumination intensities. Optimum film thickness of about 20μm was also reported in other works [37–40]. However, optimum thickness of 14μm can be found in literature as well [41]. The J SC enhancement with increasing thickness is a direct consequence of the IPCE improvement [42]. Since the J − V curves of the studied DSSCs show a quiet significant difference around short circuit voltages, the investigation of the electrolyte density profiles seems to be useful. Figs. 3c show the spatial dependence behavior of I − / I 3 − density profiles under short circuit condition. As expected, under short circuit condition the I −density decreases at points close tox =0 and increases at points closer to the counter electrode where they are mainly generated. The I 3 − density increases in the vicinity of the working electrode and decreases towards counter electrode due to recombining with electrons. Under short circuit condition the gradient of I 3 − density profile increases at points closer to x =0. As one can see, the I 3 − density increases by electron concentration increase for thicker films. It can be concluded that deeper traps in D4 leads to lesser electron and I 3 − densities. On the other hand, higher electron density, by increasing the film thickness, means more oxidized dye molecules to regenerate which brings about lesser I −density along the photoanode layer. 4.2 Diffusion length estimation with relevance to photoanode thickness, applied bias and illumination side Electron diffusion length (L) is the average distance an electron can move from the point of generation until it recombines. Determining Lin DSSCs has been the subject of some recent studies [19,43,44]. L is calculated by assuming the relation L = ( D ( n ) / k ( n ) ) 1 / 2 . In experiment the transport and interfacial transfer of electrons in dye-sensitized solar cells are measured using intensity modulated photocurrent (IMPS) and photovoltage spectroscopy (IMVS). IMPS provides information about the dynamics of charge transport and back reaction under SC conditions, whereas the IMVS response is determined by the electron lifetime under OC conditions [45]. Interpretation of the behavior of the diffusion length is ambiguous from a fundamental point of view. The result of our calculations indicates that L shows a weak dependence on light intensity due to the compensation for the decrease in the carrier life time and the increase in diffusion length [46]. The result of calculations for the thickness dependence of L under SC is shown in Fig. 5 a. Higher values of L for thicknesses less than d=20μm are obtained. For thicker films, the electron diffusion is more difficult and large number of photogenerated electrons recombine without reaching the front electrode leading to a decrease in L. Fig. 5b shows the variation of L throughout the film under SC, the maximum power point (MPP) and OC for both working electrode (WE) and counter electrode (CE) side illumination. Under OC, the diffusion lengths for both illumination sides, which almost overlap, are higher than L values for SC and MP conditions throughout the photoanode. The values of L is much higher compared to photoanode thicknesses which indicates a collection efficiency of 100% for all DSSCs. This important result is also reported previously [19,43,55]. 4.3 Photocurrent and photovoltage transient response The model is capable of easily reproducing the transient photocurrent response of DSSCs for investigation of traps distribution. Figs. 6 a and b show the measured and simulated fit of photocurrent transient response for D2 and D4 under illumination and dark. Under illumination, a proper fit is resulted by using the α values extracted from J − V curve fittings. The fit is obtained by using Eq. (13) at x =0 by varyingα. The model is fitted to D2 and D4 photocurrent rise, under illumination, by α values of 0.3 and 0.29, respecticely. Under dark, the transport times (τ tr ) are obtained by fitting the experimental data to the Exp(-t/τ tr ). At short circuit and for homogeneously absorbed light, the electron diffusion coefficient can be estimated from the relation D 0 = d 2/2.35τ tr , where d is the layer thickness of the active layer. The calculated τ tr for D1, D2, D3 and D4 are 2.6, 8, 9 and 19ms. The transport parameters are summarized in Table 2. Thicker films give a higher total amount of traps and hence a larger fraction of electrons being trapped/detrapped, and a longer time for the electron transport gives a larger probability for the electrons to be lost to the electrolyte. In experiment, IMPS measurements or dark current decay are used to estimate the electron transport time. τ tr is influenced by the total number of surface states in the film, the position of the Fermi level, and the electrical connectivity of the nanoparticle network [28]. 4.3.1 Voltage transient behavior, lifetime and chemical capacitance The model fitting results and measured OCVD of D2 and D4 vs time are plotted in Fig. 7 a using Eq. (17). The best fit gives the values of α to be 0.48 and 0.45 and of β to be 0.75 and 0.77 for D2 and D4, respectively. The fitted values for both cells are assumed to be constant while variableβ values vs Fermi level can be interpreted as different traps contributions in recombination [19]. The explanation for the latter might arise from the different effective electron population regions of the two cells contributing in recombination. For D2 and D4, for voltage values between 0.45–0.8 and less than 0.45, respectively, V oc decay vs time deviates from the fitting model. These observations suggest a direct reaction of trapped electrons with the I 3 − [45]. The TCO/electrolyte reaction can be neglected due to the applied TiCl 4 treatment of the substrates, as a result the nonlinearity can be mainly attributed to the direct transfer of the trapped electron to the I 3 − . The simulated values for electron lifetimes vs Fermi level variations are plotted in Fig. 7b. Bisquirt et al. [13] explained that the exponential and parabolic shape of the logarithmic τ vs Fermi level variations can be assumed as different electron transfer pathways, from CB to electrolyte accompanying the change of the rate of trapping/detrapping and from surface trap states to electrolyte, respectively. The obtained τ vs Fermi level represents different regimes of behavior. At high Fermi levels in which the lifetime of the electrons in CB is observed without the traps involvement. At mid-Fermi level where charge transfer is still dominated by CB states. However, it is controlled by electron trapping/detrapping. At low Fermi levels, the charge transfer is mainly governed by the distribution of surface traps. The mentioned classified regions can be obviously distinguished for D2 and D4. For both of them, lifetime values below 0.7eV increases exponentially, corresponding to the second region and the C.B capacitance becomes dominant. For D4 with Fermi level below 0.4eV the lifetime shows the parabolic shape, which implies the dominant transfer through surface states at the Fermi level. The same parabolic shape is seen below 0.45eV for D4, which can be interpreted as a longer tail of trap states. These evidences lead to the fact that the lower trap density in D2 is the main reason for higher transport rate of electrons to substrate comparing to D4. There are several ways to determine the capacitance of nanoporous semiconductor films: cyclic voltammetry [47], EIS [48,49]. Several physical aspects can be assumed contributing to the measured capacitance. First, polarization at the interface of TCO and the electrolyte, and second, the Helmholtz layer formed at the metal oxide/electrolyte interface. When the electron density is low in the semiconductor the first effect is important and the latter when the density is very high and the semiconductor enters the state of band unpinning. Both of these contributions can be considered as ordinary electrostatic capacitors. However, for the intermediate range of Fermi levels, a different kind of capacitive effect emerges. When the semiconductor bands are pinned, and the charge accumulation is related to the displacement of the Fermi level position with respect to the C.B edge or more accurately, to a variation of chemical potential of electrons. Therefore, the increment of electronic and ionic charges occurs in the volume of the nanostructured electrode with no significant electrical field variation in the volume, because the electrical field is screened near the TCO [50]. The simulated capacitance for D2 and D4 presents an exponential variation with Fermi level (Fig. 7c), corresponding to a trap energy distribution below the C.B edge [51]. Chemical capacitance data can help to detect shifts in the C.B edge [52]. Taking this shift into account for photoanode structures with similar tap distributions (i.e. DSSCs with identical parts) allows us to compare the electron properties of DSSCs based on different sensitizers and electrolytes [53]. 4.4 The dye regeneration efficiency (η reg ) and its relevance to applied bias As mentioned earlier, after photoelectrons are injected from the excited dye molecules into the C.B of TiO 2, the resulting oxidized dye molecules are reduced by I −in the electrolyte for regeneration or by electrons in TiO 2 C.B for recombination. Here, we investigate the effect of different applied voltages and I −concentrations on η reg . Fig. 8 depicts the steady state density profile of dye cations resulted from Eq. (8) for D3 under SC. Fig. 9 a–c plot the calculated results of the η reg for different voltage ranges and electron density profiles. The electron density profiles at steady state, resulted from solution of Eqs. (1), (5) and (6) at different voltages from zero to open circuit, are used to calculated the η reg . Under SC, the values of η reg are maximum and it undergoes a negligable drop (vs electron density) by decreasing [I −] concentrations (1.5–0mol). It is clearly seen that by increasing the [I −]. concentration the η reg increases. However, higher [I −] concentrations results in a larger drop of η reg . by increased electron density profile. Besides, for low [I −] concentrations, η reg remains almost constant. For voltages less than the voltage at maximum power point (V mpp ), 100≤ V ≤500, η reg experiences a more significant drop of about 10–20% for [I

It can be assumed that η r e g = η r e g 0 E x p ( − V ( n ) / C ) ≈ η r e g 0 ( 1 + ( V / C ) ) − 1 where C is a constant to determine the decrease rate. This relation can be useful while model-fitting the experiment to determine the rate of regeneration efficiency of the sensitizers by electrolyte redox. Anta et al. [55] and Jennings et al. column12: giving rise to poor regeneration efficiency. 5 Conclusion A modeling simulation based on multi-trap formalism and a standard electrochemical approach is developed to investigate the transport properties of charged species involved in DSSC operation under steady state and transient behavior. The model- fitting presents a reliable estimation of DSSC underlying factors such as series resistance
column13: diffusion and recombination coefficients and trap parameters which control the shape of J − V curves and current and voltage time dependent responses. The dependence of charged carrier densities
column16: diffusion length and efficiency on film thickness
column17: light intensity were investigated. An efficiency limiting film thickness of 20 μm was also predicted. The model also enables us to calculate chemical capacitance which is used to estimate the shift in band gap of TiO 2 under contact with electrolyte and dye molecules. Finally
column18: the dye regeneration efficiency dependence on applied voltage is discussed considering the modeling framework. The findings highlight the negative role of applied voltage on the regeneration efficiency particularly for voltages close to maximum power point where the role of series resistance is also dominant on overall DSSC performance. The presented modeling process can be used for obtaining a meaningful fit to experimental data for a particular manufactured cell in order to find the parameters influencing device performance. Further development of the present work for optimization of parameters involves introducing more fundamental parameters such as LUMO-TiO 2 C.B gap
column20: and temperature and electron density dependent injection efficiency. Also
column21: exploiting the model’s potential to explain the recent improvement of the performance in cobalt-based electrolyte DSSCs is our current challenge. Appendix A Derivation of continuity equation for electrons In a semiconductor when the Fermi level is separated from the CB by more than 3K b T

column2: Influences of oceanic turbulence on Lorentz Gaussian beam
column3: Abstract Based on the extended Huygens-Fresnel integral, the propagation of a Lorentz Gaussian beam in oceanic turbulence is investigated. The influences of oceanic turbulence parameters (the rate of dissipation of turbulent kinetic energy per unit mass of fluid, the rate of dissipation of mean square temperature, and the relative strength of temperature and salinity fluctuations) on average intensity of a Lorentz Gaussian beam are analyzed by using the numerical examples. The results show that a Lorentz Gaussian beam propagating in stronger oceanic turbulence will spread faster.
column5: Keywords Oceanic turbulence Lorentz gaussian beam Laser propagation Average intensity 1 Introduction Laser beams propagating in random media such as atmospheric turbulence and oceanic turbulence are required in applications of underwater and atmosphere laser wireless communication [1]. In recent years, the propagation properties of various kinds of laser beams in oceanic turbulence have been widely investigated, such as stochastic electromagnetic beam [2], partially coherent radially polarized doughnut beam [3], Gaussian Schell-model vortex beam [4], stochastic electromagnetic vortex beam [5], partially coherent Hermite-Gaussian linear array beam [6], Gaussian array beam [7,8], multimode laser beams [9], partially coherent cylindrical vector beam [10], flat-topped vortex hollow beam [11,12], chirped Gaussian pulsed beam [13], Lorentz beam [14], partially coherent four-petal Gaussian beam [15] and partially coherent four-petal Gaussian vortex beam [16]. With the development of diode lasers, the model of diode laser source called Lorentz beam has been introduced [17]. Since then, the propagating properties of Lorentz and Lorentz Gaussian beams propagating through free space, optical system and turbulent atmosphere have been widely investigated [18–20]. However, to the best of our knowledge, the influences of oceanic turbulence on the average intensity of a Lorentz Gaussian beam propagating in oceanic turbulence have not been investigated and reported. In this work, based on the extended Huygens-Fresnel integral formula, we obtained the expression of a Lorentz Gaussian beam propagating in oceanic turbulence, and studied the influences of the parameters of oceanic turbulence such as the rate of dissipation of turbulent kinetic energy per unit mass of fluid, the rate of dissipation of mean square temperature, and the relative strength of temperature and salinity fluctuations on average intensity properties of a Lorentz Gaussian beam by using numerical examples. 2 Theory analysis In this work, the propagation direction of laser beam in oceanic turbulence can be taken to z axis, the Lorentz Gaussian beam in the source plane can be expressed as [19]: (1) E ( r 0 , 0 ) = 1 w 0 x w 0 y [ 1 + ( x 0 w 0 x ) 2 ] [ 1 + ( y 0 w 0 y ) 2 ] exp ( − r 0 2 w 0 2 ) where r 0 = ( x 0 , y 0 ) is the position vector at the source plane; w0x and w0y are the parameters related to the beam widths of Lorentz part in the x and y directions, respectively. w 0 is the waist of the Gaussian part. Utilizing the relationship of Lorentz distribution and Hermite-Gaussian function [21] (2) 1 ( x 0 2 + w 0 x 2 ) ( y 0 2 + w 0 y 2 ) = π 2 w 0 x 2 w 0 y 2 ∑ m = 0 N ∑ n = 0 N σ 2 m σ 2 n H 2 m ( x 0 w 0 x ) H 2 n ( y 0 w 0 y ) × exp ( − x 0 2 2 w 0 x 2 − y 0 2 2 w 0 y 2 ) where N is the number of the expansion. σ2m and σ2n are the expanded coefficients and are given in Ref. [21], with the increasing the even number 2m and 2n, the value of σ2m and σ2n dramatically decrease. Therefore, N will not be large in the calculations, in this work, N is set as N=5. H2m and H2n are the 2m and 2n order Hermite polynomial, and the Hermite polynomial H 2 m ( x ) can be expressed as [22]: (3) H 2 m ( x ) = ∑ l = 0 m ( − 1 ) l ( 2 m ) ! l ! ( 2 m − 2 l ) ! ( 2 x ) 2 m − 2 l By substituting Eq. (2) into Eq. (1), we can obtain, a Lorentz Gaussian beam in the source plane can be rewritten as: (4) E ( x 0 , y 0 , 0 ) = π 2 w 0 x w 0 y ∑ m = 0 N ∑ n = 0 N σ 2 m σ 2 n H 2 m ( x 0 w 0 x ) H 2 n ( y 0 w 0 y ) × exp ( − x 0 2 u x 2 − y 0 2 u y 2 ) with (5a) 1 u x 2 = 1 w 0 2 + 1 2 w 0 x 2 (5b) 1 u y 2 = 1 w 0 2 + 1 2 w 0 y 2 Within the framework of paraxial approximation, the propagation of Lorentz Gaussian beam in oceanic turbulence can be investigated by using the extended Huygens-Fresnel diffraction integral [1–14]: (6) E ( r , z ) = − i k 2 π z exp ( − i k z ) ∫ − ∞ + ∞ ∫ − ∞ + ∞ E ( r 0 , 0 ) exp [ − i k 2 z ( r- r 0 ) 2 ] exp [ ψ ( r 0 , r , z ) ] d r 0 where r = ( x , y ) is the position vector at the output plane; k = 2 π / λ is the wave number; ψ ( r 0 , r , z ) is the solution to the Rytov method that represents the random part of the complex phase for the turbulent media; Then the average intensity of a Lorentz Gaussian beam propagating in oceanic turbulence in the receiver plane can be given as: (7) 〈 I ( r , z ) 〉 = k 2 4 π 2 z 2 ∭ ∫ − ∞ + ∞ E ( r 10 , 0 ) E * ( r 20 , 0 ) exp [ − i k 2 z ( r- r 10 ) 2 + i k 2 z ( r- r 20 ) 2 ] × 〈 exp [ ψ ( r , r 10 ) + ψ ∗ ( r , r 10 ) ] 〉 d r 10 d r 20 Where the angle bracket indicates the ensemble average over the medium statistics covering the log-amplitude and phase fluctuations due to oceanic turbulence, and the asterisk denotes the complex conjugation. And the last term in Eq. (7) can be expressed as follows: (8) 〈 exp [ ψ ( r , r 10 ) + ψ ∗ ( r , r 20 ) ] 〉 = exp [ − M ( r 10 − r 20 ) 2 ] with (9) M = π 2 k 2 z 3 ∫ 0 ∞ d κ κ Φ ( κ ) and (10) Φ ( κ ) = 0.388 × 10 − 8 ε − 11 / 3 [ 1 + 2.35 ( κ η ) 2 / 3 ] f ( κ , ς , χ T ) In the Eq. (10), the rate of dissipation of dissipation of turbulent kinetic energy per unit mass of fluid ε may vary in the rage from 10−1m2s−3 to 10−10m2s−3. And η is the Kolmogorov micro scale (inner scale), in this work we choose η =10−3. The last term in Eq. (10) has the form (11) f ( κ , ς , χ T ) = χ T ς 2 [ ς 2 exp ( − A T δ ) + exp ( − A S δ ) − 2 ς exp ( − A T S δ ) ] and χT is the rate of dissipation of mean square temperature taking value in the range from 10−4K2s−1 to 10−10K2s−1 for oceanic turbulence, AT =1.863×10−2, AS =1.9×10−4, ATS =9.41×10−3, δ = 8.284 ( κ η ) 4 / 3 + 12.978 ( κ η ) 2 , ς is the relative strength of temperature and salinity fluctuations, which in the ocean waters can vary in the range from −5 to 0. By substituting Eq. (4) into Eq. (7), and recalling the following equations [20]: (12) ∫ − ∞ + ∞ H 2 m ( x ) exp [ − a ( x − y ) 2 ] d x = π a ( 1 − 1 a ) m H 2 m [ y ( 1 − 1 a ) − 1 / 2 ] (13) ∫ − ∞ + ∞ x n exp ( − p x 2 + 2 q x ) d x = n ! exp ( q 2 p ) ( q p ) n π p ∑ k = 0 [ n 2 ] 1 k ! ( n − 2 k ) ! ( p 4 q 2 ) k We can obtain (14) 〈 I ( r , z ) 〉 = k 2 4 π 2 z 2 ( π 2 w 0 x w 0 y ) 2 I ( x , z ) I ( y , z ) I ( x , z ) in Eq. (14) can be written as: (15) I ( x , z ) = ∑ m = 0 N ∑ m ′ = 0 N σ 2 m σ 2 m ′ w 0 x π a x ( 1 − 1 a x ) m exp [ w 0 x 2 a x ( i k 2 z x ) 2 ] × ∑ d = 0 m ( − 1 ) d ( 2 m ) ! d ! ( 2 m − 2 d ) ! ∑ l = 0 m ′ ( − 1 ) l ( 2 m ′ ) ! l ! ( 2 m ′ − 2 l ) ! [ 2 ( 1 − 1 a x ) − 1 / 2 w 0 x a x ] 2 m − 2 d × ∑ s = 0 2 m − 2 d ( 2 m − 2 d ) ! s ! ( 2 m − 2 d − s ) ! M s ( i k 2 z x ) 2 m − 2 d − s ( 2 w 0 x ) 2 m ′ − 2 l × π b x 2 − 2 m ′ + 2 l − s i 2 m ′ − 2 l + s ( 1 b x ) 2 m ′ − 2 l + s exp ( c x 2 b x x 2 ) H 2 m ′ − 2 l + s ( − i c x b x x ) with (16a) a x = ( 1 u x 2 + i k 2 z + M ) w 0 x 2 (16b) b x = 1 u x 2 − i k 2 z + M − w 0 x 2 a x M 2 (16c) c x = w 0 x 2 a x ⋅ i k 2 z M − i k 2 z I ( y , z ) in Eq. (14) can be written as: (17) I ( y , z ) = ∑ n = 0 N ∑ n ′ = 0 N σ 2 n σ 2 n ′ w 0 x π a y ( 1 − 1 a y ) n exp [ w 0 y 2 a y ( i k 2 z y ) 2 ] × ∑ d = 0 n ( − 1 ) d ( 2 n ) ! d ! ( 2 n − 2 d ) ! ∑ l = 0 n ′ ( − 1 ) l ( 2 n ′ ) ! l ! ( 2 n ′ − 2 l ) ! [ 2 ( 1 − 1 a y ) − 1 / 2 w 0 y a y ] 2 n − 2 d × ∑ s = 0 2 n − 2 d ( 2 n − 2 d ) ! s ! ( 2 n − 2 d − s ) ! M s ( i k 2 z y ) 2 n − 2 d − s ( 2 w 0 y ) 2 n ′ − 2 l × π b y 2 − 2 n ′ + 2 l − s i 2 n ′ − 2 l + s ( 1 b y ) 2 n ′ − 2 l + s exp ( c y 2 b y y 2 ) H 2 n ′ − 2 l + s ( − i c y b y y ) with (18a) a y = ( 1 u y 2 + i k 2 z + M ) w 0 y 2 (18b) b y = 1 u y 2 − i k 2 z + M − w 0 y 2 a y M 2 (18c) c y = w 0 y 2 a y ⋅ i k 2 z M − i k 2 z Eqs. (14)–(18) are the obtained formula for the average intensity of a Lorentz Gaussian beam propagating in oceanic turbulence. 3 Graphical results and discussions In this section, as numerical examples, the average intensity properties of a Lorentz Gaussian beam propagating in oceanic turbulence are illustrated by using the formulas derived above. In the following numerical calculations, the parameters of beam and oceanic turbulence are chosen as follows: λ =532nm, w 0 =1cm, ς =− 2.5, χ T = 10 − 9 K 2 / s , ε =10−7m2s−1 in the whole work without specifying in captions. The normalized average intensity distribution and corresponding contour graphs of a Lorentz Gaussian beam propagating in oceanic turbulence at the different propagation distance z for the different w0x and w0y are illustrated in Figs. 1 and 2 , respectively. In Fig. 1, the waist of Gaussian part is larger than the related width of the Lorentz part; in Fig. 2 , the waist of Gaussian part is equal to the related width of the Lorentz part in x direction of the beam, and the waist of Gaussian part is smaller than the related width of the Lorentz part in y direction of the beam. From Figs. 1 and 2, it is observed that the Lorentz Gaussian beam with the different w0x and w0y will keep its initial profile under the short propagation distance (Figs. 1 and 2a and b); and with the propagation distance z increases, the initial profile of Lorentz Gaussian beam will gradually change, and the spot of Lorentz Gaussian beam will change to be a Gaussian-like beam in the x and y direction (Figs. 1 and 2d). By comparing Figs. 1 and 2, it is shown that Lorentz Gaussian beam with w0x =w0y =2mm will spread smaller than the Lorentz Gaussian beam with w0x =10mm and w0y =20mm with the propagation increases; and the reason is that the spreading of the Lorentz distribution in oceanic turbulence is higher than that the Gaussian distribution with the propagation increases. In order to investigate the influences of oceanic turbulence parameters (the rate of dissipation of mean square temperature χT , the rate of dissipation of turbulent kinetic energy per unit mass of fluid ε and the relative strength of temperature and salinity fluctuations ς) on the average intensity of a Lorentz Gaussian beam. Due to the x and y parts of Lorentz Gaussian beam propagating in oceanic turbulence are separate (see Eq. (14)), then Figs. 3–5 give the cross line (y=0) of normalized average intensity for a Lorentz Gaussian beam with w 0x =w 0y = 2mm propagating in oceanic turbulence for the different χT , ε and ς, respectively. It is shown that the parameters of oceanic will affect the spreading propagating of a Lorentz Gaussian beam in Figs. 3–5. It is found that a Lorentz Gaussian beam will spread into the Gaussian-like beam faster with the larger oceanic parameter xT (Fig. 3) as the propagating distance z increases, and the larger oceanic parameters xT means that the oceanic turbulence is stronger. And the oceanic turbulence strength will increase with the oceanic turbulence parameters ε (Fig. 4) and ς (Fig. 5) decrease, so it is also found that a Lorentz Gaussian beam will spread faster with ε or ς decreases. So from Figs. 3–5, it is found that the stronger oceanic turbulence (the increase of oceanic parameter xT or the decrease of oceanic parameters ε and ς) will spread into Gaussian-like beam faster due to the influence of stronger oceanic turbulence. 4 Conclusion In this paper, the spreading properties of a Lorentz Gaussian beam propagating in oceanic turbulence are examined by using numerical examples in detail. The influences of oceanic parameters χT , ε and ς on the average intensity and spreading of a Lorentz Gaussian beam are analyzed. As the Lorentz Gaussian beam propagates in oceanic turbulence, the spot of a Lorentz Gaussian beam will change to be a Gaussian-like beam. And the beam propagates in stronger oceanic turbulence (the increase of oceanic parameter xT or the decrease of oceanic parameters ε and ς) will spread into Gaussian-like beam faster due to the influence of stronger oceanic turbulence.
