column2: A stepped Mach-Zehnder interferometric humidity sensor based on lateral offset fusion splicing
column3: Abstract A novel optical fiber relative humidity (RH) sensor based on a Mach-Zehnder interferometer (MZI) is proposed and demonstrated in this paper. The sensor head is formed by a single-mode-multimode-single-mode-single-mode(SM-MM-SM-SM) fiber structure through lateral offset fusion splicing. The intermodal interference is achieved by two lateral offset points. The change of relative humidity will cause the optical path difference changed of the core mode and cladding modes, which gives rise to the interference pattern change. The ambient RH change can be determined by monitoring the energy variation of the interference pattern. The experimental results show the dip energy of the transmission spectrum changes with respect to surrounding RH with good linearity. The MZI with a interferometer length of 15mm offers the enhanced RH sensitivity of −0.0487dB/%RH in the range of 35–95%RH with linearity of 0.9966. The proposed humidity has compact size, simple fabrication procedure and does not need any functional coating, making it a good candidate for RH measurements.
column5: Keywords Optical fiber sensor Multimode fiber Relative humidity Mach-Zehnder interferometer 1 Introduction With the rapid development of wind power industry, wind power generation has been become a new and mature power generation technology. However, the majority of wind turbines are installed in outdoor area, high relative humidity and low temperature are a common problem faced by these wind farms, which leads to negative effect of wind turbines, including the unit corrosion, blade loading and lubricating oil and electronic components, parts of the performance, aerodynamic performance and load, unit operation and maintenance. Therefore, relative humidity measurement is particularly important [1]. Fiber-optical sensors have the unique advantages, such as small size, high sensitivity and good remote operation. Once these fiber sensors are inserted into the inside of each wind turbine by the way of parallel system, it can be achieved constant monitoring the operation of the wind turbine. Recently, Many fiber sensors with different types and structures have been proposed to measure relative humidity, including Fabry-Perot (F-P) fiber sensor [2–4], fiber Bragg gratings (FBGs) [5,6], Mach-Zehnder interferometer (MZI) [7,8], long period gratings (LPGs) [9,10]. Fu et al. [11] proposed a microfiber RH sensor based on PM-elliptical fiber. The sensor with a thinner diameter of 4.7μm provides the sensitivity of 114.7pm/(%RH) in the range from 30 to 90%RH and has good linearity between wavelength and RH. Shohei et al. [12] proposed humidity sensor based on a section of hetero-core fiber sandwiched between two pieces of MMF. However, the sensitivity of the sensor remained low despite being coated with hygroscopic polymer layers. Nan et al. [13] proposed a hollow-core fiber (HCF) sandwiched between two single-mode fibers (SMFs) with a sensitivity of 1.29pm/%RH. Owing to the silica hardly show good response to humidity, these various additionally functionalized materials are coated onto the fiber surface to enhance humidity sensitivity. Yulianti et al. [14] proposed the sensor which is Fabry–Perot cavity formed by two identical uniform fiber Bragg gratings and polyimide is coated on the FBG. Li et al. [15] proposed an tapered MMF coated with polyvinyl alcohol film cascading with fiber Bragg Grating to measure RH. Liu et al. [16] proposed S-taper fiber which is fabricated as the sensitive element by using simple fusion spicing and the S-tapered region is coated with a layer of hydrophilic material. Coating kinds of functionalized material can improve RH sensitivity, but the surface of sensor is very difficult to control material uniformity. In this paper, a new RH sensor based on a Mach-Zehnder interferometer (MZI) is proposed. The stepped sensor is fabricated by using fusion splicer. Due to large fiber core lateral offset, making the proposed sensor that is sensitive to external RH. Relative humidity measurement is realized by monitoring the energy variation of the interference pattern. Experimental results show that the sensor has high sensitivity, simple fabrication and compact structure. 2 Sensor fabrication and principle The proposed MZI consists of an uncoated SMF section sandwiched between a short piece of MMF and output SMF in a way of fiber core lateral offset, which are employed as mode couplers due to the lateral offset point to split and recombine light, thus form an in-fiber MZI, as shown in Fig. 1 . The MMF length, the SMF length and the distance of fiber core lateral offset are represented by L1, L2, d1 and d2, respectively. The operating principle can be described as follows: When light is injected into the MMF core through an input SMF and partly coupled to the cladding of the sensing SMF (centre section) at the first lateral offset point, and some cladding modes are excited. Then the core mode and cladding modes of the sensing SMF separately propagate along the fiber with an effective index difference and finally recombined at the second lateral offset point, where the two modes interfere with each other due to the accumulated phase difference. Thus through another output SMF, it gives rise to the intermodal interference. The expression of transmission intensity of a stepped MZI can be expressed as [17]: (1) I = I c o r e + ∑ m I c l a d d i n g m + ∑ m 2 I c o r e I c l a d d i n g m ⋅ cos ( Δ φ ) Where I core and I c l a d d i n g m are the intensity of the core mode and cladding modes, respectively. Δφ is defined as the phase difference and can be expressed as [18]: (2) Δ φ = 2 π ( n c o r e − n c l a d d i n g m ) λ ⋅ L 2 Where n core and n c l a d d i n g m are the effective refractive index of the core mode and cladding modes, respectively. When the interference spectrum reach minimum, the phase difference is written as [18]: (3) Δ φ = ( 2 k + 1 ) π Where k is an integer. And according to the interference theory, the wavelength spacing between two adjacent transmission minimums Δλ can be written as [19]: (4) Δ λ = λ 2 Δ n e f f L 2 where Δ n e f f = ( n e f f c o r e − n e f f c l a d d i n g , m ) . As seen from Eq. (4), the wavelength spacing can be decreased with the length of interferometer arm L2 increases. When the external RH is applied on the sensor, the effective refractive index of cladding modes will be changed, which leads to the energy of the transmission spectrum changed. When the outside temperature is constant, Eq. (1) is taken the derivative with respect to RH, the RH sensitivity of the sensor can be expressed as: (5) d I d ( R H ) = d ∑ m I c l a d d i n g m ( R H ) d ( R H ) + ∑ m I c o r e I c l a d d i n g m ( R H ) − 1 2 × I c o r e d I c l a d d i n g m ( R H ) d ( R H ) × cos 2 π λ n e f f c o r e − n e f f c l a d d i n g , m ( R H ) ⋅ L + ∑ m I c o r e I c l a d d i n g m ( R H ) × sin 2 π λ n e f f c o r e − n e f f c l a d d i n g , m ( R H ) ⋅ L × 4 π λ ⋅ L ⋅ d n e f f c l a d d i n g , m ( R H ) d ( R H ) From Eq. (5), it can be seen that the RH sensitivity will be calculated. As the RH increases gradually in the environment, the refractive index of the air can be increased, which cause the cladding effective refractive index increased. According to the evanescent-wave principle, outward radiant energy will increase, which leads to the intensity of cladding modes reduced, but the intensity of the core mode is unchanged, thus, the transmission spectrum intensity of the sensor can be reduced. By monitoring transmission spectrum energy change, the external RH can be determined. The stepped Mach-Zehnder interferometer is fabricated by using SMF (OPEAK, S9/125) and MMF (OPEAK, S105/125). The MMF is removed from its jacket, and the two fiber ends are cleaved by using fiber cleaver (Furukawa, S325). The SMF and prepared MMF are put on the optical adjusting bracket of a commercial fusion splicer. The first welding point is fabricated by employing the SM–MM fusion program. A section of SMF is sandwiched between SMF and MMF, and formed the structure of SMF-MMF-SMF-SMF. The length of MMF is controlled in 700μm, and the lateral offset d1 is 58μm. The sensing SMF (centre section) and the output SMF have a small core dislocation d2. Experimental result shows that the quality of the interference spectrum is determined by d2. Thus the lateral offset d2 must be needed two conditions: one is that the interference spectrum has been displayed a clear fringe pattern with high extinction ratio over 10dB. Other is that the interference spectrum should be presented more periodicity in order to observe obviously the power change in the process of actual measurement. After many tries, the lateral offset d2 is set to be 3μm. All welding loss caused by arc discharge is controlled within 0.05dB, therefore, the fabrication process of the sensor has good repeatability. The transmission spectra of the stepped MZI with different interferometer lengths L2 are shown in Fig. 2 . It can be found from Fig. 2 that the interference spectrum has good periodicity and large extinction ratio, which contents the requirements of actual measurement. It can be seen from Fig. 2 that the period of the interference patterns increases with increasing of the length of L2, and the free spectral range (FSR) decreases, which is in agreement with Eq. (4). For further theoretical analysis, the fast Fourier transform (FFT) of the transmission spectrum can be taken to obtain the spatial spectrum, as shown in Fig. 3 . The spatial spectrum ε can be given as [20]: (6) ε = 1 λ 0 2 Δ m e f f ⋅ L Where λ 0 is the center wavelength; Δ m e f f = Δ n e f f − λ 0 ∂ ∂ λ Δ n e f f represents the differential modal group index; L is the length of the sensor. As can be seen from Eq. (6), the spatial frequency ε is directly proportional to the length of the interferometer L and the effective refractive index difference Δm eff . As shown in Fig. 3, the spatial frequency spectra shows several peaks, which indicates that many modes participate in the interference, but one peak dominates for every interference spectrum. The spatial frequency corresponding to the lower peak amplitude is bigger than the spatial frequency of the dominant peak amplitude, which shows that the interference pattern is very stable. The dominant peak amplitudes have been marked and are located at 0.0866nm−1 and 0.0998nm−1, respectively. Compared to the spatial frequency of sensor S-1, sensor S-2 is bigger, the main reason is that sensor S-2 is longer interferometer length than sensor S-1, according to Eq. (6), the spatial frequency of sensor S-2 is bigger than sensor S-1, which is in agreement to experimental result. Owning to the high-order modes corresponding to the higher spatial frequency, so the main contribution of intermodal interference is the low-order modes, therefore, it can be considered that the interference pattern is mainly formed by the low-order modes and the fundamental mode. 3 Experimental results and discussion The schematic diagram of the RH measuring system is shown in Fig. 4 . Sensor S-1 and sensor S-2 are selected as measuring RH. The sensor is placed in a programmable constant temperature and humidity testing machine (RH chamber, We-won, WHTH-225L). Two ends of sensing head are connected to the broadband light source (BBS, Lightcomm, ASE-CL) and optical spectrum analyzer (OSA, Anritsu, MS9740A) by single-mode fibers, respectively. The optical spectrum analyzer has a minimum resolution of 20pm. Due to bending can cause transmission energy loss of this type MZI, thus the sensor is carefully fixed on plexiglass that has a distribution of holes for moisture to pass through. When the sensor is exposed to humidity environment, the water molecules in the air will be absorbed by silica, which causes interference modes effective refractive index changed and leads the these modes to induce phase difference, so it causes interference spectrum drift. The RH can be determined by monitoring the change of the interference spectrum. Accurate measurement of RH and temperature can be achieved by using this control measurement system. The maximum available measurement range of humidity and temperature is 20–98% RH and −20–150°C, and the measurement error is ±1%RH and ±0.2°C, respectively. In the experiment, the temperature is controlled at 35°C in the RH measurement process. The RH is changed from 35%RH to 95%RH with a step of 10%RH. The dip at the wavelength of 1565.41nm and 1561.54nm of the sensor S-1 and S-2 are selected as the monitoring point. When the transmission spectrum reached a stable value at each RH point, the interference patterns are recorded, as shown in Fig. 5 . In Fig. 5, with RH increases, the transmission spectrum dip energy of sensor S-1 and S-2 occur obvious decreasing, and the maximum change of intensity reach 2.42dB and 2.96dB, respectively. The wavelength occur red-shift, and the maximum drift of wavelength reach 0.07nm and 0.12nm at the monitoring point, which is in agreement with theoretical analysis. The variation of dip energy of interference spectrum is more obvious than the shift of wavelength, and it is more sensitive and easier to measure. Sensor S-2 is selected to investigate the time response for the purpose of practical applications. In this experiment, the close chamber is initially at 66%RH. Fig. 6 shows the temporal profile of intensity as the change of the RH condition from 66%RH to 85%RH by automatically regulating the proportion of dry air and humid air for RH chamber. It can be seen from Fig. 6 that the rise time of the sensor corresponding to a 19%RH change is 14.1s; When RH is decreased from 85%RH to 66%RH, the sensor takes about 10.5s. The intensity reaches the transient dip of 1.15dB and stays a stationary state because of the flow equilibrium process. Since the humid air need take time to be filled with the RH chamber, thus we believe the actual response time of the sensor should be less than experimental result. This proves that the proposed sensor in this work has a fast time response. For further theoretical analysis the relationship between the energy of the dip and RH, the energy variation of the dip at 1565.41nm and 1561.54nm are fitted to the RH, as shown in Fig. 7 . Fig. 7(a) and (b) illustrates the intensity respect to surrounding RH change, respectively. The dots are measured values. The different straight line is the linear fit. It is clear that energy shift shows a good linear relationship with the RH change, and the sensor has a high reversibility in RH increasing and decreasing process. The sensitivity of sensor S-1 and S-2 are −0.0396dB/%RH and −0.0487dB/%RH in the RH range of 35–95%RH with the linear correlative coefficients of 0.9904 and 0.9966, respectively. Compared with sensor S-1, the sensitivity of sensor S-2 is obviously improved. This is because that sensor S-2 is longer sensing length than sensor S-1, which leads to more energy coupled to external environment to strengthen humidity interaction. The temperature change also causes the drift of the transmission spectrum. When the RH is constant, the content of water molecules in the air will decrease gradually as the temperature increases. Therefore, temperature should also be considered in the RH measurement process. Sensor S-1 and S-2 are conducted temperature test. The RH is controlled at 35%RH conditions. The temperature is gradually increased from 35°C to 75°C with a step of 10°C, and the transmission spectrum is recorded when the transmission spectrum is reached a stable value at each temperature point, as shown in Fig. 8 . The dips at the wavelength of 1565.41nm and 1561.54nm of the sensor S-1 and S-2 are selected as the monitoring point. It can be seen from Fig. 8 that with temperature increases, the transmission spectrum occur obviously redshift, and the maximum change reached 1.45nm and 1.97nm, respectively. Owing to the thermo-optical coefficients and thermal expansion effect, the interference length and effective refractive index difference of the sensor increase with the external temperature rise, which induce the transmission spectrum towards long-wave direction. But the intensity of the monitoring point barely moves. Fig. 9 is the transmission spectral response of sensor S-1 and S-2 at different temperatures, which shows that the transmission spectrum energy remains almost constant in the case of temperature change. Compared with previous RH response characteristics, the sensor can be used to measure simultaneously relative humidity and temperature by respective monitoring energy and wavelength change. The actual measurement environment is always worse, so the stability of sensor is very important to the accuracy of the measurement results. Sensor S-2 is selected to test its stability. The sensor is placed in RH chamber under constant RHs of 45%RH, 65%RH and 95%RH for a long-time measurement, respectively. Temperature is controlled at 35°C. The intensity of the selected interference dip is selected to record its change and plotted every 10min, as shown in Fig. 10 . In the test time of 120min, the maximum intensity fluctuation does not exceed ±0.01dB, thus the standard deviation of the RH reaches about 21%RH. The deviation of intensity may be the vibration of the machine or airflows itself. 4 Conclusion In this paper, a new relative humidity sensor based on a MZI is proposed and experimentally demonstrated. A section of SMF is sandwiched between MMF and SMF, and fabricated a large fiber core lateral offset, which forms the stepped MZI. Experimental result shows that the lateral offset distance between the sensing SMF and output SMF can affect the quality of transmission spectrum. The proposed sensor has a good reversibility with the increasing and decreasing of relative humidity. The RH sensitivity is −0.0487dB/%RH in the range of 35–95%RH with linearity of 0.9966 for the MZI with a 15mm interferometer length. Moreover, temperature response characteristics are investigated. Experimental results suggest that the transmission spectrum intensity of the sensor is insensitive to temperature, which demonstrates its potential for measuring simultaneous RH and temperature by respective monitoring intensity and wavelength change. Additionally, the proposed sensor has the advantages of simple structure, easy manufacture process and low cost, which make it a good candidate for relative humidity measurement in worse environment. Acknowledgments This work was supported in part by the Research Foundation of Science and Technology Board of Yulin City, China, under Grant 2015cxy-22, and in part by the Fundamental Research Funds of Yulin University under Grant JG-1527.

column2: Optical soliton solutions of higher order nonlinear Schrödinger equation in monomode fibers and its applications
column3: Abstract In this article, we have discussed the analytical solution to the higher order nonlinear Schrödinger equation representing the propagation of short light pulses in the monomode optical fibers. A simple transformation is introduced to convert the nonlinear partial differential equation into an ordinary differential equation. A verity of traveling solutions are obtained by employing the auxiliary equation method. The technique can also be functional to other sorts of nonlinear evolution equations in contemporary areas of research.
column5: Keywords Higher order nonlinear Schrödinger equation Auxiliary equation method Soliton solutions 1 Introduction In dispersive medium, the propagation of nonlinear waves is of great interest in the recent era of contemporary science and technology. The nonlinear transformation of dielectric of the fiber termed as the Kerr effect, is applied to neutralize the dispersion effect, in this state the optical pulse may tend to form a steady nonlinear pulse known as optical soliton. The bit rate of transmission is limited by the dispersion of the fiber material. The fiber loss is the only factor that contributes to the drop of the pulse quality by expansion in the pulse width, for details see [1–7]. In last some decades, both mathematician and physicist have made much efforts in finding the analytic solutions to a number of nonlinear models. As a result, many powerful techniques are introduced to deal with problems involving nonlinear complex phenomena of nature, which play a vital role in physical sciences, such as inverse scattering scheme [9], Bäcklund transform method [10], homogeneous balance scheme [11], Painlevé expansion [12], sine–cosine method, Darboux transformation, Lie group analysis, mapping method and extended mapping method [13,14], Exp-function method [15], rational expansion method [16], Adomian decomposition method [17,18], homotopy perturbation method [19], homotopy analysis method [20], differential transform method, reduced differential method, tanh–coth method [22–24], simplified Hirota's method, extended homoclinic test approach [21], transformed rational function method [23], Hirota's bilinear method [25] and many more. In the literature, a variety of suitable methods are adopted to investigate the behavior of the nonlinear equations. The study about solutions, structures, interaction and further properties of soliton abstracts is given much more attention in the recent past. A strong relation is found among the general elliptic equation and most of the existing sub-equations like the Riccati equation, auxiliary equation [27], first kind elliptic equation, and generalized Riccati equation [26], but also helps us to find more and new exact solutions to NPDEs. As a result, some new and more general exact traveling wave solutions are obtained, see also [28–46]. The auxiliary equation method is successfully applied to construct travelling wave solutions of higher order nonlinear Schrödinger (HNLS) equation illustrating the linear and the nonlinear dispersion as well as dissipation effects in monomode fibers [8]. The HNLS model reduces to the integrable nonlinear Schrödinger equation by eliminating the last three expressions. The governing systems are read as: (1) ∂ Φ ∂ z = i ς 1 ∂ 2 Φ ∂ t 2 + ς 2 | Φ | 2 Φ + ς 3 ∂ 3 Φ ∂ t 3 + ς 4 ∂ ∂ t | Φ | 2 Φ + ς 5 Φ ∂ ∂ t | Φ | 2 where the coefficients ς j for j =1, 2, 3, 4, 5; are real constants. This article has been devised as follows: in Section 2, the solutions to the HNLS equation is presented while in Section 3, the physical behaviour of the solitons is discussed. In the last Section 4, the conclusions have been drawn. 2 The description of the auxiliary equation method We will briefly present the AEM in the following steps: Step 1. Let us have a general form of nonlinear PDE (2) F ( u , u t , u x , u y , u xx , u yy , … ) = 0 . where F is a polynomial function with respect to the indicated variables. Step 2. The following wave variable is presented to solve (2) (3) u ( x , t ) = F ( ξ ) , The transformations (3) convert the PDE (2) to an ODE (4) O i ( F , F ξ , F ξ ξ , F ξ ξ ξ , … ) , where F = F(ξ) is unknown function. Step 3. The main idea of the auxiliary equation method based on expanding the traveling wave solution F(ξ) of Eqs. (4) as a finite series (5) F ( ξ ) = ∑ i = 0 n a i ψ i ( ξ ) , ψ satisfies (6) d ψ d ξ = C 0 + C 1 ψ ( ξ ) + C 2 ψ 2 ( ξ ) + C 3 ψ 3 ( ξ ) + C 4 ψ 4 ( ξ ) , (7) ξ = β ( z + ν t ) where C i (i =0, 1, 2, 3, 4) are constants. Step 4. Applying the homogenous balance to (2), the parameters n in (5) can be obtained. Step 5. Substituting (5), (6) and (7) in (2) and collecting the coefficients of ψ j ψ (k), then solving the system for C i . Step 6. Substituting C i and ψ(ξ) obtained in step 5 into (5), to obtain the solutions for (1). 3 Solitons for higher order nonlinear Schrödinger equation In order to extract optical solitons, one may have the following starting hypothesis, the wave profile is split into amplitude and phase components, respectively, as (8) Φ ( z , t ) = e i ψ Ω ( ξ ) , where ξ = β ( ν t + z ) , The Ω(ξ) is the amplitude components of the wave profiles, while the phase factor is given by (9) ψ = k z + ω t + θ , where k, ω and θ represent the frequency of the solitons, the wave number and the phase constant respectively. By using (8) into (1), and comparing the real and imaginary parts (10) 3 β ς 4 ν + 2 ς 5 ν β Ω 2 Ω ′ − β 3 ς 3 ν 3 Ω ( 3 ) + 3 β ς 3 ν ω 2 + 2 β ν ς 1 ω + β Ω ′ = 0 (11) 3 ς 4 ω + 2 ς 5 ω − ς 2 Ω 3 − 3 β 2 ς 3 ν 2 ω + β 2 ς 1 ν 2 Ω ″ + k + ς 3 ω 3 + ς 1 ω 2 Ω = 0 integrating (10), and neglecting the constant of integration (12) 1 3 3 β ς 4 ν + 2 ς 5 ν β Ω 3 + β 3 ς 3 − ν 3 Ω ″ + 3 β ς 3 ν ω 2 + 2 β ν ς 1 ω + β Ω = 0 from (11) and (12), we have the relation between the coefficients (13) ς 1 = − 3 ς 2 ς 3 3 ς 4 + 2 ς 5 and for any arbitrary constant α, the parameters (14) β = 1 4 α η 3 ς 3 ( 3 ς 4 + 2 ς 5 ) ν 2 − 9 η 3 ς 2 ς 3 ν − 9 η 3 ς 4 ν ς 1 − 6 η 3 ς 5 ν ς 1 − 3 η 2 / 3 − 3 ς 2 2 ς 3 2 ν 2 − 3 ( 3 ς 4 + 2 ς 5 ) 2 ν ς 1 2 + 6 ς 3 ( 3 ς 4 + 2 ς 5 ) ν ( − ς 2 ν ς 1 + 3 ς 4 + 2 ς 5 ) , (15) ω = 1 4 η 3 ς 3 ( 3 ς 4 + 2 ς 5 ) ν ς 2 2 ς 3 2 ( − ν 2 ) − 2 ς 2 ( 3 ς 4 + 2 ς 5 ) ς 3 ν ν ς 1 + ( 3 ς 4 + 2 ς 5 ) 2 ( 2 ς 3 ν − ν ς 1 2 ) + η 3 ( − η 3 + ς 2 ς 3 ν − ( 3 ς 4 + 2 ς 5 ) ν ς 1 ) where η = 1 216 46656 ( ( 3 ς 4 + 2 ς 5 ) 3 ( 4 k ς 3 2 ν 3 + 3 ς 3 ν ν ς 1 − ν ς 1 3 ) + ς 2 3 ς 3 3 ν 3 + 3 ς 2 2 ( 3 ς 4 + 2 ς 5 ) ς 3 2 ν 2 ν ς 1 + 3 ς 2 ( 3 ς 4 + 2 ς 5 ) 2 ς 3 ν ( 3 ς 3 ν − ν ς 1 2 ) 2 + 72 ς 3 ( 3 ς 4 + 2 ς 5 ) ν ( − 2 ς 2 ν ς 1 + 3 ς 4 + 2 ς 5 ) − 36 ς 2 ς 3 ν − ( 3 ς 4 + 2 ς 5 ) ν ς 1 2 3 1 / 2 − ς 3 2 ν 3 ( 4 k ( 3 ς 4 + 2 ς 5 ) 3 + ς 3 ς 2 3 ) − 3 ς 2 ς 3 2 ( 3 ς 4 + 2 ς 5 ) ν 2 ( ς 2 ν ς 1 + 9 ς 4 + 6 ς 5 ) + ( 3 ς 4 + 2 ς 5 ) 3 ν ς 1 3 − 3 ς 3 ( 3 ς 4 + 2 ς 5 ) 2 ν ν ς 1 ( − ς 2 ν ς 1 + 3 ς 4 + 2 ς 5 ) By applying the homogeneous balance to (12), we have n =3. (47) ψ 11 ( ξ ) = − 2 a 2 δ 1 δ 3 + δ 3 e 2 δ 3 ξ δ 2 e 2 2 δ 3 ξ δ 2 − a 2 2 δ 1 where δ 1 = β 3 ς 3 − ν 3 , δ 2 = 1 3 3 β ς 4 ν + 2 ς 5 ν β , δ 3 = 3 β ς 3 ν ω 2 + 2 β ν ς 1 ω + β The parameters C i and a j become C 1 = − 3 β ς 3 ν ω 2 + 2 β ν ς 1 ω + β 2 β 3 ς 3 ν 3 , C 2 = 0 , C 3 = − a 2 1 3 ( 3 β ς 4 ν + 2 ς 5 ν β ) 2 2 β 3 ς 3 ν 3 , a 0 = 3 β ς 3 ν ω 2 + 2 β ν ς 1 ω + β 1 3 ( 3 β ς 4 ν + 2 ς 5 ν β ) , a 1 = λ , a 2 = 0 , a 3 = 0 where λ is arbitrary constant, hence the solution of (1) will be (48) Ω 11 ( ξ ) = − 4 2 3 β ς 3 ν ω 2 + 2 β ν ς 1 ω + β 2 e 2 3 β ς 3 ν ω 2 + 2 β ν ς 1 ω + β ξ β 3 ς 3 ν 3 β 3 ς 3 ν 3 e 2 3 β ς 3 ν ω 2 + 2 β ν ς 1 ω + β ξ β 3 ς 3 ν 3 − 1 3 3 β ς 4 ν + 2 ς 5 ν β 2 therefore (49) Φ 11 ( z , t ) = e i ( − α z + ω t + γ ) Ω 11 ( β ( z + ν t ) ) . 4 Discussions and results The graphical representation of solitons has been illustrated in the following figures, for various values of the parameters. Mathematica 10.4 is used to carried out simulations and contour plot have been applied to visualize the behavior of optical waves. Figs. 1–3 illustrate the optical solutions produced in Case I for C 4 =0, whereas Figs. 4 and 5 describes the optical solutions produced in Case II for C 3 =0, C 4 =0. Similarly Figs. 6–8 represents the optical solutions produced in Case III for C 0 =0, C 4 =0, while Figs. 9–11 visualizes the optical solutions produced in Case IV for C 0 =0, C 2 =0, C 4 =0. 5 Conclusion In this study, the soliton solutions to the higher order nonlinear Schrödinger equation have been extracted. It is observed that the auxiliary equation method is one of the most powerful tools to find a variety of analytical solutions for more complex problems. A sort of new traveling wave solutions are observed to analyse the propagation of short light pulses in an optical fiber, depending on the real parameters, see Figs. 1–11. These results are very auspicious for further investigation and stances on a strong basis for the solution of NPDEs.

column2: Structures and nonlinear optical properties of alkali atom/superalkali doped pyridinic vacancy graphene
column3: Abstract A new series of alkali atom/superalkali doped pyridinic vacancy graphene, M/pyridinic vacancy graphene and M3O/pyridinic vacancy graphene (M=Li, Na, K), have been theoretically designed and investigated by means of density function theory. It is revealed that all M/pyridinic vacancy graphene compounds can present high NLO with considerable first hyperpolarizability in the range of 7923–8523au. Moreover, it is found that employing the concept of superalkali unit M3O as the source of the electron can significantly increase the first hyperpolarizability than doping alkali atom. The results show that M3O/pyridinic vacancy graphene exhibit the larger first hyperpolarizability (12199–16553au), which can be attributed to the lower transition energies. Especially, heavier superalkali can be more powerful in increasing the first hyperpolarizabilities of M3O/pyridinic vacancy graphene. Therefore, M3O/pyridinic vacancy graphene are expected to be potential candidates for NLO materials. We hope that this study could provide a new idea for designing nonlinear optical materials using superalkali clusters.
column5: Keywords Pyridinic vacancy graphene Superalkali First hyperpolarizability, 1 Introduction Over the past twenty years, continuous studies have been carried out to design the novel high-performance nonlinear materials with large first hyperpolarizability because of potential applications in many areas such as optical information processing and optical computing [1–4]. Up to now, scientists proposed different strategies to construct excellent NLO materials with considerable NLO responses. For example, prolonged π-electron molecules [5,6], distorted π-electron molecules [7], donor-π bridge-acceptor framework [8–10], the metal-ligand structures [11–13], octupolar molecules [14,15]. In previous work, it was revealed that alkali atom doping on complexants can bring about a large nonlinear optical response, where loosely bound excess electrons is decisive factor in increasing the first hyperpolarizability value. Using this effective approach, several new kinds of excess electron compounds were successfully designed as a candidate for exhibiting large first hyperpolarizability [16–24]. For example, the interaction between Li atom and a fluorocarbon chain lead to excellent NLO materials. The calculated result indicate that the LinH-(CF2-CH2)3-H can exhibit large first hyperpolarizability up to76978au, which is dramatically larger than that of undoped fluorocarbon chain. The analysis of NBO as well as molecular orbital indicate valence electron of alkali atom is pulled out by complexant, forming new electrides [18]. By doping two Na atoms into pyridazine, the compounds can also present considerable first hyperpolarizabilities up to 1.5×104 au, which can be considered as a new type of electride because of containing diffuse excess electrons [19]. Moreover, previous study have shown that a number of complexants were used to construct new electrides, including π-conjugated aromatic ring [25,26], all-metal polyanions [27], multicage [28], graphenes [29], nanotubes [30,31]. Such as, He et al. proposed a new concept, which is the all-metal electride [27]. It is found that the all-metal polyanion pushes the valence of the Ca atoms to form excess electrons, which bring about large first hyperpolarizability. Liu et al. investigated the interaction of k atom with multicage and found that multicage strategy is effective to increase first hyperpolarizability [28]. Superalkali [29], which is a dominant subset of superatoms [30,31], exhibits much lower ionization potentials than that of alkali atom. Compared with alkali atom, Superalkali can donate one electron to the complexants more easily. It has been proved that superalkali cluster as building block was successfully used to design new kinds of compounds with large NLO responses [32–35]. In this paper, we intend to design of novel NLO materials by introducing alkali atom/superalkali cluster into pyridinic vacancy graphene, in which alkali atom/superalkali cluster provide electronic (See Fig. 1 ). We mainly focus on the following questions. (1) How does alkali atom/superalkali cluster affect the electronic property of pyridinic vacancy graphene? (2) How does alkali atom/superalkali cluster affect the absorption spectrum of pyridinic vacancy graphene? (3) How does alkali atom/superalkali cluster affect the first hyperpolarizability of pyridinic vacancy graphene? (4) Are the first hyperpolarizability of the compound rely on the alkali atomic number (Li, Na, K). In order to clarify these questions, we study the equilibrium geometries, electronic property, absorption spectrum and nonlinear optical responses of M/pyridinic vacancy graphene and M3O/pyridinic vacancy graphene (M=Li, Na, K). We expect that such a theoretical study can provide helpful information for further experimental studies about nonlinear optical materials of pyridinic vacancy graphene. 2 Computational details The geometric structures of M/pyridinic vacancy graphene and M3O/pyridinic vacancy graphene (M=Li, Na, K) were optimized using the M062X method with the 6-31+G(d, p) basis set. In order to confirm whether geometric structures is minima in global scope, frequency analysis were carried out at the same level. The polarizability (α0) is defined as follows: (1) α 0 = 1 3 ( α x x + α y y + α z z ) The first hyperpolarizability is obtained as (2) β 0 =(β x 2 + β y 2 + β z 2)1/2 In which β i = 3 5 ( β i i i + β i j j + β i k k ) , i , j , k = x , y , z The first hyperpolarizability of system were calculared by a finite-field approach in this work. It is of greatest importance to calculate the (hyper)polarizability by employing the appropriate method. BhandHLYP includes higher percentages of HF exchange than the B3LYP, which reproduce the MP2 result. CAM-B3LYP was proposed by Yanai et al., which is a new Coulomb-attenuated hybrid exchange-correlation functional. The method dependence was tested in this work. The first hyperpolarizability of M3O/pyridinic vacancy graphene (M=Li, Na, K) were calculated by BhandHLYP and CAM-B3LYP methods. From Table 1 , the two methods give a similar result. So, BhandHLYP was chosen for the materials investigation. The crucial transition energies were calculated by time-dependent density functional theory (TD-DFT). Electronic properties, including density of states (DOS), the energy of highest occupied molecular orbital (HOMO), the energy of lowest unoccupied molecular orbital (LUMO), were calculated at M062X/6-31+G(d, p) level. Natural bond orbital (NBO) was calculated at B3LYP/6-31G(d, p). All of the calculations are carried out by using the GAUSSIAN 09 program package [36]. The density of states (DOS) results were conducted by using Multiwfn 3.3.7 software [37]. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Equilibrium geometries and natural bond orbital charges Alkali atom/superalkali cluster added to pyridinic vacancy graphene, over the center of three nitrogen atoms, were systematically investigated using density functional method. Six geometrical structures without imaginary frequency were obtained at the M062X/6-31+G(d, p) level. The molecules system were classified into two groups by the differently doping patterns and were labeled as M/pyridinic vacancy graphene and M3O/pyridinic vacancy graphene (M=Li, Na, K). The six structures were given in Fig. 2 . The molecular geometry parameters are listed in Table 2 . The Alkali-N bond length of M/pyridinic vacancy graphene are defined the MN bond length (see Fig. 3 ). The bond length change in the order of Li-3NG<Na-3NG<K-3NG. Among structures, the bond length of K-3NG is largest, which is larger by about 0.784–0.815Å than that of Li/pyridinic vacancy graphene and Na/pyridinic vacancy graphene. The results indicate that the MN bond length of M/pyridinic vacancy graphene increase with increasing atomic radii. Similarly, MN bond length of M3O/pyridinic vacancy graphene change in the order of Li3O/3NG < Na3O/3NG < K3O/3NG. In addition, The MN bond length of M3O/pyridinic vacancy graphene is larger than that of corresponding MN bond length of M/pyridinic vacancy graphene. For example. 1.956Å (Li3O/3NG)>1.829Å (Li/3NG). The natural bond orbital (NBO) charges of the compounds are displayed in Table 3 . When alkali atom is introduced to pyridinic vacancy graphene, q(Li+) values of Li/pyridinic vacancy graphene, Na/pyridinic vacancy graphene, K/pyridinic vacancy graphene are 0.706, 0.894, 0.946, respectively. The charge on Li, Na and K enhance with increase of atomic number. Similarly, when superalkali unit M3O is doped into pyridinic vacancy graphene, q(M3O+) values of M3O/pyridinic vacancy graphene also enhance with increasing atomic number of alkali atom. The results indicate that doping alkali atom and superalkali unit M3O can cause the occurrence of charge transfer from alkali atom/superalkali cluster to pyridinic vacancy graphene, which are beneficial to obtained large first hyperpolarizability. 3.2 Electronic structures and absorption spectra The electronic structures of the compounds were calculated at M062X/6-31+G(d, p) level and the results are given in Fig. 4 and Fig. 5 . As shown in Table 3, when alkali atom is introduced to pyridinic vacancy graphene, the energy gaps Egap between HOMO and LUMO of M/pyridinic vacancy graphene are found to be 2.323ev for Li/pyridinic vacancy graphene, 2.323ev for Na/pyridinic vacancy graphene, 2.308 ev for K/pyridinic vacancy graphene, respectivly. When superalkali unit M3O is doped into pyridinic vacancy graphene, the energy gaps Egap between HOMO and LUMO of M3O/pyridinic vacancy graphene are found to be 2.313ev for Li3O/pyridinic vacancy graphene, 2.289ev for Na3O/pyridinic vacancy graphene, 2.269ev for K3O/pyridinic vacancy graphene, respectively. The results show that the effect of Alkali atom/superalkali cluster on the gap is not obvious. The absorption spectra were calculated using time-dependent density functional theory (TD-DFT) at the B3LYP/6-311+G (d) level of theory. The absorption spectra of the compounds have been plotted in Fig. 6 . It is shown that the maximum absorption wavelengths of compounds Li/3NG, Na/3NG, and K/3NG are in the visible spectral region, at 533.74, 546.62, and 559.93nm, respectively. From Fig. 6, for compounds Li3O/3NG, Na3O/3NG, K3O/3NG, the maximum absorption wavelengths change in the order of Li3O/3NG<Na3O/3NG<K3O/3NG. Among structures, the maximum absorption wavelength of K3O/3NG is largest in contrast to other compounds. Especially, all compounds are transparent in the deep-ultraviolet spectrum range, which is of great importance in practice. 3.3 Linear and nonlinear optical properties The polarizabilities of M/pyridinic vacancy graphene and M3O/pyridinic vacancy graphene compounds were obtained at BhandHLYP/6-31+G (d) level and the results are given in Table 4 . When alkali atom is introduced to pyridinic vacancy graphene, the polarizabilities of the compounds are 899, 904, 913au, respectively. When superalkali unit M3O is introduced to pyridinic vacancy graphene, the polarizabilities of the compounds are 919, 943, 969au, respectively. Through the analysis of the above data, it is clear that alkali atom/superalkali cluster doped effect on the polarizability is not great. In this work, we focus on how to build excellent nonlinear optical material by means of interaction between alkali atom/superalkali cluster and 3N-doped graphen. It is previously reported that N atoms with long pair are able to polarize the alkali atom to form an excess electron, leading to improvement of first hyperpolarizability, suggesting the great potential of this material for future applications as nonlinear optical materials. In this work, M/pyridinic vacancy graphene and M3O/pyridinic vacancy graphene compounds are designed for the first time. We look forward to these compounds possessing large NLO response. The dependence of first hyperpolarizabilities on atomic number is illustrated and the results are obtained from Table 4. First of all, when alkali atom is introduced to 3N-doped graphen, first hyperpolarizabilities of M/pyridinic vacancy graphene is 8523au for Li/pyridinic vacancy graphene, 8038au for Na/pyridinic vacancy graphene, 7923au for K/pyridinic vacancy graphene, respectivly. In other words, these compounds increase in the order of K/pyridinic vacancy graphene < Na/pyridinic vacancy graphene < Li/pyridinic vacancy graphene, which exhibit large first hyperpolarizability. In order to enhance first hyperpolarizability, we construct new nonlinear optical materials using superalkali unit M3O with a smaller vertical detachment energy value as the source of the electrons. The results are given in Table 4. When superalkali unit M3O is doped into pyridinic vacancy graphene, two interesting results are found. (1) The first hyperpolarizabilities of M3O/pyridinic vacancy graphene are larger than that of M/pyridinic vacancy graphene. For example, 8523au (Li/pyridinic vacancy graphene) <12199au (Li3O/pyridinic vacancy graphene). (2) In order to investigate the dependence of nonlinear optical property on atom number, we compared first hyperpolarizabilities of M3O/pyridinic vacancy graphene. The first hyperpolarizabilities of M3O/pyridinic vacancy graphene increase in the order of 12199au (Li3O/pyridinic vacancy graphene) <15910au (Na3O/pyridinic vacancy graphene) <16553au (K3O/pyridinic vacancy graphene), which indicates that superalkali unit M3O adsorption on pyridinic vacancy graphene enhance the first hyperpolarizabilities with increasing atomic radii. Among these structures, the largest first hyperpolarizabilities are found to be 16553au, which is close to that of Li+(calix[4]pyrrole)K− [38], which is famous alkalide compound with the cuplike complexant. To understand the origin of the large first hyperpolarizabilities of these compounds, two-level model is widely employed [39–41]. (3) β 0 ∝ Δ μ ⋅ f 0 Δ E 3 Where ΔE, f0 and Δμ are, respectively, the transition energy, oscillator strength, and the difference in dipole moment between the ground state and the most relevant excited state. The third power of the transition energy is inversely proportional to the β 0 value. Therefore, the transition energy is the decisive factor in calculation of the β 0 value. The transition energies ( Δ E ) of these compounds were calculated by the TDDFT method (B3LYP/6-311+G (d)) and the corresponding results are listed in Table 4. From Table 4 the ΔE values of M/pyridinic vacancy graphene are 2.323ev for Li/pyridinic vacancy graphene, 2.268ev for Na/pyridinic vacancy graphene, 2.214ev for K/pyridinic vacancy graphene, respectively. We also discuss the trend of first hyperpolarizabilities of M3O/pyridinic vacancy graphene using two-level model. The results are listed in Table 4. From Fig. 7 , the ΔE values of M3O/pyridinic vacancy graphene are 2.250ev for Li3O/pyridinic vacancy graphene, 2.201ev for Na3O/pyridinic vacancy graphene, 2.148ev for K3O/pyridinic vacancy graphene, respectively. The ΔE value decreases in the order of 2.148 ev (K3O/pyridinic vacancy graphene) <2.201ev (Na3O/pyridinic vacancy graphene) <2.250 ev (Li3O/pyridinic vacancy graphene, which is opposite to the order of 12199au (Li3O/pyridinic vacancy graphene) <15910au (Na3O/pyridinic vacancy graphene) <16553au (K3O/pyridinic vacancy graphene). It is obvious that transition energy values provide a good explanation for the variation in first hyperpolarizability values. To further study the electronic properties of M/pyridinic vacancy graphene and M3O/pyridinic vacancy graphene, the density of states (DOS) for M/pyridinic vacancy graphene and M3O/pyridinic vacancy graphene were calculated and are given in Fig. 8 . From Fig. 8, it is found that energy gap of M/pyridinic vacancy graphene is similar when alkali are introduced into pyridinic vacancy graphene. The result indicate that Alkali atom contribution to HOMO is not seen. However, M3O segment contribution to HOMO is obvious, which may lead to small transition energy. 4 Conclusions A series of M/pyridinic vacancy graphene and M3O/pyridinic vacancy graphene have been theoretically designed and investigated by means of density function theory. Doping alkali atom can cause considerably large first hyperpolarizabilities, which range from 2011 to 8524au. When alkali atom is introduced into pyridinic vacancy graphene, employing the K atom can more effectively enhance the first hyperpolarizability of M/pyridinic vacancy graphene (M=Li, Na, K) compounds. In contrast to M/pyridinic vacancy graphene, M3O/pyridinic vacancy graphene (M=Li, Na, K) show larger first hyperpolarizabilities. Among M3O/pyridinic vacancy graphene compounds, the largest first hyperpolarizability are found to be 16553au for K3O/pyridinic vacancy graphene, which is about 2 times larger than that of K/pyridinic vacancy graphene. Clearly, doping the superalkali cluster is advantageous for obtaining excellent nonlinear optical materials. It is our expectation that the present work may give new knowledge about designing NLO material based on superalkali cluster.
