column2: Study on bruising degree classification of apples using hyperspectral imaging and GS-SVM
column3: Abstract Bruising degree can affect the end use and sales price of apples directly. In order to identify the bruising degrees of apples quickly and accurately, using hyperspectral imaging technology, this study proposed a method combining successive projections algorithm (SPA) with support vector machine based on grid search parameter optimization (GS-SVM) to classify and identify apple samples with different degrees of bruising. In the process of research, firstly, random forest method was used to extract spectral data of bruised areas of apples with a high accuracy, then Kennard-Stone algorithm was performed to partition sample set reasonably to improve performance of the model. After comparing different pretreatment methods, standard normal variate (SNV) transformation method with the best performance was selected to process the spectral data. Finally, in order to reduce the time required to build the model, the GS-SVM models were set up based on the characteristic variables selected by SPA and competitive adaptive reweighted sampling (CARS), and the classification results were compared with the results of the model constructed with the full spectra. The experimental results showed that the SNV-SPA-GS-SVM model had the best prediction effect, and the prediction accuracy of apples with four kinds of bruising degrees was 95%.
column5: Keywords Apple Hyperspectral imaging GS-SVM Bruising degree classification 1 Introduction Apple is one of the main fruits in our country, which is favored by the majority of the consumers because of its good edible quality and high nutritional value, but the apple will inevitably suffer different extent mechanical damage such as collision, extrusion, and vibration during the process of picking, packing and transporting. Mechanical damage can cause fruit physiological metabolic disorder and microbial infection, prompting the accelerated aging and decay of apples, which causes serious losses of nutrition in apples. Bruising is the main type of mechanical damage. Moreover, objective and quantitative description of bruising degree is not only the important foundations of evaluating apple quality for producers and purchasers, but also has important implications for research on improving postharvest handling and storage operations of apples [1]. Therefore, it is very necessary to identify bruise and quantify bruising degrees of apples before storage in time. So far, some scholars have conducted researches on evaluation index and measuring method of bruising degrees of apples, having discussed effective evaluation indexes such as bruised area, depth, volume and average area value, and a series of measuring methods that include bulk density, respiratory rate, optical property, staining method, X-ray exploration and electrical impedance [2]. Zhulian Wu et al. [3] quantified severity of mechanical damage based on its volume ratio, then analyzed on the relations between damage degree and storability of apple fruits under different mechanical damage treatments. Results proved that effect of the same type of mechanical damage on postharvest storage property of fruits increases with the increasing of intensity of the damage, and the relation between damage degree and storability of fruits varies with the type of mechanical damage under different mechanical damage treatments. Taking bruised length and depth as evaluation indicators of the extent of bruising, Zhongyu Yuan et al. [4] compared the extent of bruising of Qingguan and red Fuji apples after falling from 60cm height and the impact of bruising on physiological reaction and storage quality of these two types of apples, only to find that red Fuji apples are more sensitive to bruising than Qingguan ones, and effects of the same degree of bruising on physiological reaction and storage quality of Qingguan apples are larger than red Fuji ones. All of the above researches evaluate bruising degree based on geometric parameters, manipulate simply and quickly, but bruising degree is not always positively correlated with geometric parameters especially for the apples whose external bruise characteristics are not obvious, so it is necessary to quantify bruising degrees of apples from the perspective of internal composition changes. Shu Zhang et al. [5] measured the optical properties of apples with varying degree bruises in 400–1050nm, then established a discriminant model that combined principal component analysis (PCA) with support vector machine (SVM) to classify and predict the bruising degrees. Results showed the accuracy of the model was as high as 92.5%. However, this solution needs to prepare the flesh of the bruised area cut off with a microtome for observation, which causes damage to the integrity of apples, hence there is an urgent need to develop a new method for non-destructive and more accurate classification of bruising degrees of apples. In recent years, as the hyperspectral imaging technology can obtain spectral information as well as image information of agricultural products, the image information can reflect external features, surface defects and contamination, and the spectral information can be used for the analysis of internal physical structure and chemical composition of objects, hyperspectral imaging technology has been rapidly developed and widely used in quality detection of agricultural products [6–8]. Taking Jonagold apples bruised less than two hours before scanning as study object, Janos C. Keresztes et al. [9] used reflectance calibration and several pre-processing techniques to improve the signal-to-noise ratio of spectra at first, then applied the particle filter algorithm to complete the image post-processing, finally, constructed the pixel based early apple bruise detection model by using partial least squares-discriminant analysis (PLSDA) method. The research showed that the actual rate for accurately recognizing fresh bruises in thirty apples was 98%. Through artificial simulated experiment, Wenqian Huang et al. [10] damaged apples at the equatorial area by dropping a steel ball weighing 33g from a fixed height about 500mm, then designed a bruise identification system for apples based on hyperspectral imaging technology and segmented principal component analysis. Results of static and online tests showed that the developed system could be used for online detection of bruises on apples. Juan Xing et al. [11] used principal component analysis to process hyperspectral images of ‘Golden Delicious' apples, selecting four characteristic bands for bruise detection, and developed an image processing and classification algorithm based on moments thresholding, which obtained satisfactory classification results of bruise detection with an accuracy of about 86%. Thus, it can be seen that the application of hyperspectral imaging technology to the detection and recognition of bruises on apples has achieved good performance, however few further studies have been done on the classification of bruising degrees of apple. In view of this, this experiment obtained red Fuji apples with different bruising degrees through artificial simulated mechanical damage, then used hyperspectral imaging technology combined with support vector machine based on grid search parameter optimization (GS-SVM) method to realize the automatic classification of apples with different bruising degrees. The specific steps were as follows: 1. utilizing random forest method to extract spectral data of bruised areas on four kinds of samples 2. taking advantage of Kennard-Stone (KS) algorithm to divide spectral data into training set and prediction set 3. comparing the performance of models under different pretreatment methods to select the best pretreatment method 4. using successive projections algorithm (SPA) and competitive adaptive reweighted sampling (CARS) to select characteristic variables and establishing the corresponding GS-SVM models to classify different bruising degree apples 5. repeating the above steps until completing the identification of five, six and seven categories of bruising degrees 2 Materials and methods 2.1 Materials The experiment selected “red Fuji” apple as the research object, and experimental samples were purchased from ordinary farmer’ market nearby on September 21st, 2016. After careful selection, 40 apple samples without pests and mechanical damage which were similar in their size, diameter and shape were chosen. Each apple had a diameter of approximately 7–8cm. All the chosen apples were carried back to our laboratory with caution, labeled in turn and then placed side by side in a prepared carton. 2.2 Apples' quantitative damage experiment The simulation device of mechanical damage on apple is shown in Fig. 1 . Through a light aluminum rod with 80m length falling from a fixed height with approximate simple pendulum motion, a 22g steel ball fixed on the rod damaged an apple at the equatorial area (in order to prevent damage to the opposite side, a foam pad was placed in the rear of the apple to increase buffer), then the hyperspectral image of this bruised apple was acquired by hyper-spectrometer immediately. After completing the acquisition of the hyperspectral image, the apple was bruised again, and then the apple with second bruise was scanned for the acquisition of the second hyperspectral image, and so on, until eight damage experiments as well as the acquisition of eight corresponding images of each apple were finished. Making sure that the apple was bruised in the same position each time. The above experiment was repeated until the hyperspectral image data acquisition of 40 apples with the first bruise, second bruise, third bruise, fourth bruise, i.e. altogether 8 kinds of bruising degrees was completed finally. For illustrative purposes, the eight types of bruising degrees of apple samples were recorded as Bruise I, II, III, IV, V, VI, VII, VIII in sequence. 2.3 Hyperspectral image acquisition A schematic diagram of the hyperspectral imaging system and form of three-dimensional hyperspectral data are illustrated in Fig. 2 . As can be seen in the figure, the system is mainly composed of portable hyperspectral imager (SOC710VP, USA), light source, computer (including spectral analysis software) and other devices. The hyperspectral imager, which has an array imaging charge-coupled device (CCD) with a new built-in scan design and 12-bit dynamic range, can obtain high quality data in the wavelength range of 400–1000nm (128 spectral bands); its spectral resolution is about 4.68nm; scanning speed is 32s per cube. The light source system used in the experiment is composed of four 75W halogen lamps (Philips, Holland) which are fixed around the experimental box. In order to reduce the influence of ambient light, the main devices of the system were placed in the sealed experiment box (120×120×160cm) covered by shading cloth, besides, in order to avoid the interference coming from background, black background with low reflectivity was chosen as the shooting background. Before the acquisition of hyperspectral image data, the intensity of the light source and the distance need to be adjusted in order to ensure that the collected image is clear. Obtaining dark current and reflectivity reference data for each scan imaging. In order to eliminate the influence of the uneven illumination intensity, nonlinearity of CCD detector and dark current on the acquisition of spectral images, the original images should be calibrated. The formula for correction [12] is as follows: (1) ρ x y ( λ ) = ρ r e f ( λ ) R x y ( λ ) − R d a r k ( λ ) R ref ( λ ) − R d a r k ( λ ) In the formula (1), ρ xy (λ) is the corrected image, ρ ref (λ) is the reflectivity of the U.S. National Institute of Standards and Technology (NIST) traceable calibration board, R xy (λ) is the original uncorrected hyperspectral image, R ref(λ) is the scanning image of the calibration board obtained by the hyperspectral image acquisition system in this experiment, R dark (λ) is the completely black image collected after turning off the light source and screwing on the lens cap. Subsequent processing and analysis of image data are all carried out on ρ xy (λ). 2.4 Apple bruised region extraction Random forest, one kind of ensemble learning algorithm, can be carried out for identification and classification of data using multiple classification trees, and has many advantages such as a few adjusted parameters, do not worry about overfitting and fast classification speed. In order to extract the bruised areas of apples accurately, a random forest classification model was established in this study, which was implemented in the PyCharm integrated development environment based on the Python language. Through selecting a region of interest on corrected hyperspectral image, as shown in Fig. 3 , the basic idea was to select the part of spectra in the bruised area (B) and non-bruised area (S) to constitute the data set, then make use of the random forest method to build a bruise identification model, finally, utilize the established model to forecast the spectra of the transition area (X) between the bruised area and non-bruised area which is not easy to get good segmentation. The sum of the spectra of the bruised area predicted by the above method and area B were both that's required. 2.5 Classification and identification of bruising degrees After the extraction of bruised areas, the average spectrum in the bruised region of each sample was achieved by calculation, then the research was conducted with the value of corrected reflectance as the independent variable x and the variety of bruising degree as the dependent variable y. 2.5.1 Regional spectral data preprocessing Under normal circumstances, due to the influence of the heterogeneity of the sample, high-frequency random noise, baseline drift, light scattering and other factors during the process of sampling, the collected spectral signals will inevitably exist a variety of distortion and noise information which will affect the prediction effect of the model, therefore, it is important to preprocess the original hyperspectral data with different pretreatments before modeling. In commonly used spectral pretreatment methods, first derivative (1D) can be used to correct the baseline drift and spectral rotation in the background of this system, Savitzky-Golay (SG) smoothing can filter out the high-frequency noise in the spectral data and well preserve the authenticity of the original signal, and standard normal variate (SNV) is mainly used for the scattering correction of spectra. This study adopted the SNV, 1D, SG smoothing and their combination methods to preprocess the original hyperspectral data, and then investigated the difference of GS-SVM models established by different pretreatment methods to choose the optimal one for the classification of bruising degrees. 2.5.2 Spectral variable selection Since the original hyperspectral data with a total of 128 bands contain a large amount of information, if spectral data of the whole wave-band are taken as independent variables into the model, the execution efficiency of the program will be greatly reduced. Accordingly, it is necessary to discover valuable information from full spectra (FS) and select the wavelength variables contributing the most to the performance of the model, which not only reduces the complexity of the model but also improves the performance of the model [13]. In this study, successive projections algorithm and competitive adaptive reweighted sampling were applied to select effective spectral variables from the FS to predict apples with varying degree bruises. Successive Projections Algorithm Successive projection algorithm is a method of obtaining the minimum linear variable set by using vector projection operation in vector space, is a kind of multivariate calibration method based on positive variable selection [14]. The principle of variable selection by SPA is that candidate variables which have the maximum projection value on the orthogonal subspace of the previously selected variables are firstly chosen, then the optimal number of variables is determined on the basis of the smallest root mean square error (RMSE) obtained from validation set of multiple linear regression (MLR) calibration, and then the uninformative variables are deleted through a variable elimination procedure without significant loss of prediction capability. Many successful applications have proven SPA to be an outstanding variable selection approach [15–17]. Competitive Adaptive Reweighted Sampling CARS is a novel and useful method for selecting effective variables which mimics the principle of “survival of the fittest” from Darwinian evolution theory. Through adaptive reweighted sampling (ARS) technique, CARS preserves the wavelength variables with large absolute values of regression coefficients of PLS model, and removes the ones with small absolute values of regression coefficients, so as to obtain a series of wavelength variable subsets. Subsequently, each of those variable subsets is verified by using cross validation models, and the optimal variable subset is chosen according to the lowest root mean square error of cross validation (RMSECV) criterion of the model. More details on the steps involved in CARS application can be found in previous studies [18–20]. 2.5.3 Bruising degree classification based on GS-SVM The support vector machine method is a method to improve the generalization ability of the learning machine according to the principle of structural risk minimization, which is characterized in that the decision rules obtained by limited training samples can guarantee a high accuracy for an independent test set. Fig. 4 shows the schematic of support vector machine network structure, its basic idea was to use the kernel function to map the infrared spectra of apples as input data into a high dimensional feature space, and then structure an optimal linear classification hyperplane in the space, which can separate different kinds of samples accurately, so as to achieve the purpose of classification of bruising degrees. However, SVM can only deal with a binary classification problem and many practical bruising degree classification problems are multi-classification ones usually, so it is necessary to structure a multi-class SVM classifier. The study employed LIBSVM library developed by Lin Chih-Jen, a professor of Taiwan University, to deal with classification problems of bruising degrees of apples, according to “one versus one” classification strategy, designed a SVM between any two classes of apple samples, and then classified the unknown samples by voting, thus constructing a multi-class classifier to identify the bruising degrees of apples. In the experiment, the kernel function of support vector machine is based on radial basis function (RBF), yet the determination of the kernel parameter g and the penalty factor C in the kernel function has a great influence on the performance of support vector machine system, thus grid search algorithm (GSA) is applied in this research to find the optimal parameters of C and g. The underlying principle of GSA is to make C and g value all the points in the grid partitioned in a certain space, then use k-fold cross validation method to determine the classification accuracy of the training set for each given group of C and g, and make the final selection of a group of parameters which make the classification accuracy rate of the training set the highest for SVM classification [21]. Compared to other SVM parameter optimization methods (such as k-fold cross validation method, genetic algorithm), GSA is more intuitive, can obtain the optimal parameters through exhaustive search and apply parallel computing, thus saving the time required for parameter optimization [22]. The flow chart of the whole algorithm based on the GS-SVM model for bruising degree classification of apples is shown in Fig. 5 . 3 Results and discussion In the course of the damage simulation experiment, apple peel began to break out after being damaged five times, at that point the naked eye could well distinguish its bruising degree, therefore this article first carried out classification experiment on the first four relatively light bruising degrees, and then repeated the above experiment to complete the classification of more than four types of bruising degrees. 3.1 Classification of four types of bruising degrees 3.1.1 Bruised area spectra extraction Whether employing manually selected region of interest or threshold segmentation method, it is difficult to obtain a complete bruised area of an apple, the edge of the bruised area is particularly prone to be misjudged. To avoid this, this experiment obtained a high-precision classification model based on random forest by training part of spectra in the bruised area and non- bruised area in a supervised way, then used the established model to predict the spectra of the transition area between the bruised area and non- bruised area, so as to achieve the purpose of extracting the spectral data of bruised area accurately. The results of bruise identification of the hyperspectral images obtained by scanning the twenty-sixth apple with Bruise I–IV are shown in Fig. 6 (a)–(d), respectively. 3.1.2 Spectral analysis of bruised area As shown in Fig. 7 , the average spectra of bruised areas of apples with four levels of bruising were drawn with MATLAB 9.0 (MathWorks, USA) software in different colors and lines. As this figure shows, hyperspectral curves of apples with different bruising degrees had a similar tendency in the range of 400nm–1000nm, and all had strong absorption peaks located around 500nm, 680nm, and 960nm. The strong absorption peaks around 500 and 680 represent carotenoids and chlorophyll pigments which reflect the surface color information of the apple, the strong absorption peak in the near infrared reflection (NIR) at 960nm represents water absorption bands, which is affected by moisture absorption on the surface of the apple tissue. It is difficult to distinguish the bruising degrees of apples only from the spectral characteristics of hyperspectral data, so modeling method of chemometrics can be applied to analyze and process the spectral data. 3.1.3 Sample set partitioning In KS algorithm, all samples are considered as candidate samples of calibration set, first of all, two vectors whose Euclidean distance is the farthest are chosen into the calibration set, then, the distance from each sample in the remaining candidate samples to each selected calibration sample is calculated, at last, the minimum distance sample and the maximum distance sample are found to be added to the calibration set, this procedure is repeated until the required amount of samples is reached. In order to make the distribution of the calibration set in each category sample space more uniform, this experiment classified sample data in each category into calibration and prediction set according to 3:1 by KS method, finally merged all the obtained calibration sets and prediction sets separately. As a consequence, altogether 120 representative spectra (including 30 spectra with Bruise I–IV) singled out from 160 spectra of apples with varying degree bruises were used as the calibration set to build model and the remaining 40 spectra (including 10 spectra with Bruise I–IV) were used as prediction set to test the reliability of the model. The category numbers of the samples in the calibration set and the prediction set were uniformly distributed in the sample space, which had relatively good representation. 3.1.4 Spectral data preprocessing This experiment used different pretreatment methods including SNV, SG smoothing, 1D and their combinations to eliminate the noise of original hyperspectral data, thus obtaining higher signal-to-noise ratio spectra, which could contribute to the robustness of subsequent prediction model and the extension of the forecast results. Therefore, it is necessary to select the most effective preprocessing method from various pretreatment methods for following modeling research. A preliminary prediction model of bruising degrees based on spectral data processed by each pretreatment method was established by using GS-SVM, and then the influence of different pretreatment methods on the prediction accuracy of models was discussed. The identification results of the models under different pretreatment methods are shown in Table 1 . As Table 1 shows, standard normal variate transformation as the pretreatment method achieved the best result which was that the accuracy of the GS-SVM classification model was the highest and the number of error samples was the least. Moreover, the classification accuracy of the combination method of standard normal variable transformation and other methods was also significantly higher than that of other methods alone. This may because there are great differences between apples and apple's surface is not flat, resulting in the variations of the measured sample spectra. Meanwhile, for some samples, spectral changes due to scattering may be greater than that caused by variation of internal composition. However, the standard normal variable transformation can eliminate the influence of scattering disturbance through correcting spectra with the mean and standard deviation of each spectrum [23], so as to yield fairly ideal spectra. Accordingly, in this study, the standard normal variate transformation method was used to process the spectral data of the apple samples, and the raw and processed spectra of all samples are shown in Fig. 8 a, b respectively. 3.1.5 Spectral variable selection Spectral Variables Selected by SPA As mentioned above, this paper tried the SPA method to select the effective spectral variables from the FS pretreated by SNV to predict apples with varying degree bruises. During performing the SPA, a MLR analysis procedure was applied for the calculation of a sequence of RMSE values using the selected variable subsets [24]. Fig. 9 obtained by applying SPA illustrates a graph of RMSE changing with increasing number of selected variables. It can be observed that when 33 wavelength variables were selected, the RMSE reached its optimal value (0.25968) for prediction of bruising degrees of apples, and the number of selected variables was relatively less. Fig. 10 shows the distribution of these selected spectral variables (marked by rectangles) on the raw spectral curve. Later, in next part, the prediction results of the model will be used to illustrate the effectiveness of the 33 variables selected by SPA. The aim of the CARS method is to eliminate the useless variables and improve the model’s performance. Fig. 11 shows the variable selection results of the CARS algorithm (the number of Monte Carlo sampling runs is set to 50). Fig. 11a–c gives the changing trend of the number of sampled variables, 10-fold cross validation RMSECV values and regression coefficient of each variable with the increasing of Monte Carlo (MC) sampling runs in a CARS run, respectively. In Fig. 11a, the number of sampled variables decreases fast at first and then slowly, which displayed that in this algorithm the whole variable selection process was divided into two phases: coarse selection and refined selection. Fig. 11 b reflects when the number of Monte Carlo sampling runs reached 23 (signed by asterisk vertical in Fig. 11c), the PLS model obtained the minimum RMSECV, which demonstrated the best performance of the model at this point. Therefore, the optimal variable subset, which consists of 396, 500, 626, 631, 647, 719, 724, 734, 808, 882, 887, 898, 903, 908, 914, 967, 973, 978, 983, and 989nm, was determined for predicting the bruising degrees of apples, while the corresponding number of sampled variables was 20. 3.1.6 Classification of bruising degrees The spectrum data corresponding to characteristic variables selected by SPA and CARS were set as input to establish SVM models for predicting the bruising degrees of apple samples respectively. In addition, the optimal combinations of parameters C and g of the models were obtained by grid search algorithm, where the value range of C and g were both set between 2-5 and 25, the value of K was set to 3, and the step size of parameters C and g were both set to 1. The prediction results of these two models established ultimately, compared with that of another model based on full spectra, are shown in Table 2 . As can be seen from Table 2, the GS-SVM model based on the spectral data corresponding to the characteristic variables selected by SPA offered the best performance, which was that the prediction accuracy of the model for bruising degrees of apples reached 95%. Though the number of selected spectral variables by SPA was bigger than that by CARS, much smaller than 128 by FS, SPA-GS-SVM was without doubt the best prediction model. Fig. 12 displays the classification results of the GS-SVM model based on SPA variable selection algorithm. It showed that only two samples were incorrectly classified in 40 prediction samples, one of which was an apple with Bruise III, another was an apple with Bruise IV. The reason why these two samples were misclassified may be: in gathering image, light spot on the surface of apple formed by light scattering and the variation in curvature of apple surface exactly coincided with bruised area at a particular point of view, so that spectral information of bruised area was covered. 3.2 Classification of more than four categories of bruising degrees Based on the above experiment, the spectral data of apples with Bruise V were extracted in the same way and then 40 average spectra were obtained by calculation. The 40 average spectra were still divided into calibration set and prediction set according to 3:1 by the KS method, then the resulting sample sets were merged with previously obtained sample sets. Finally, we compared the accuracy of the GS-SVM model to identify five kinds of bruising degrees under different pretreatment methods. By comparison, the prediction accuracy of the model was the highest under SNV pretreatment, which reached 80% (10 samples were incorrectly sorted). And so on, until the experiments on the classification of six categories, seven categories and eight categories of bruising degrees were completed, and the highest recognition accuracy obtained in each group of experiment is shown in Fig. 13 . 1–4: Classification of four kinds of bruising degrees (from Bruise Ⅰ to Bruise Ⅳ); 1–5: Classification of five kinds of bruising degrees (from Bruise Ⅰ to Bruise Ⅴ); and so on. It can be illustrated that the accuracy of classification was getting lower and lower with the gradual increase in the number of categories, which meant that severely bruised samples which were later added to the model were hard to be identified correctly. This may because apple peel began to break out after being bruised five times, at this point epidermal cell wall was broken, which had certain effects on the mechanical properties of apples [5]. And then cytoplasmic, sugar and pectin overflowed, phenolic compounds released were oxidized to quinone compounds, which would make an enormous impact on spectral data. 4 Conclusions Adopting hyperspectral imaging technology, this study proposed a method for classification and identification of the bruising degrees of apple samples by combining successive projections algorithm used for dimension reduction with support vector machine based on grid parameter optimization. In the course of the study, firstly, random forest method was used to extract the spectral data of the bruised region accurately, then, the KS method was used to partition 40 spectra of each type of samples reasonably, and the representative samples were selected to build the model to improve the performance of the model. The best pretreatment method was selected to process the spectral data by comparison. Finally, in order to reduce the time required for the model, the spectrum data corresponding to characteristic variables selected by SPA and CARS were set as independent variables to establish the GS-SVM models, classification results of which were compared with that of another model based on the FS. The results showed that the SNV-SPA-GS-SVM model had the best prediction effect, the prediction accuracy of four kinds of bruising degrees amounted to 95%, that is, the result of the prediction set containing 40 samples was only wrong in 2 samples. Afterwards, the said experimentation process was repeated, and classification experiments on five classes, six classes, seven classes and eight classes of bruising degrees were completed, obtaining that the classification accuracy was 80%, 78.3%, 67.1%, 62.5%, respectively. It can be found that the identification accuracy of severely bruised samples was far lower than that of the first four categories of bruised samples. On the whole, the model can realize the classification of apples with four kinds of bruising degrees quickly and accurately, which can be put into practical applications. Acknowledgements The authors gratefully acknowledge the financial support from Harbin Special Research Fund Program in Young Innovative Talents of Science and Technology (2012RFQXN119), and Task Book Project of National Modern Agricultural Industry Technology System (CARS316).

column2: Accurate regulation of circular dichroism signal in double-layer nanostructure
column3: Abstract Chiral plasmonic systems have been shown to exhibit stronger circular dichroism (CD) because of strong interaction between light and noble metals. In this study, we utilize double-layer chiral plasmonic nanostructures composed of achiral nanoplate and two achiral nanodisks to produce a chiroptical response. The chiroptical response is due to the twisted electric dipoles and the phase between them. In addition, the CD signal of the plasmonic nanostructure can be accurately regulated when plasmonic nanostructure parameters are tuned. Overall, results will allow further tuning of the optical responses in plasmonic systems to tailor chiral light–matter interaction.
column5: Keywords Chirality Plasmonic Circular dichroism Localized surface plasmon 1 Introduction Chiral structures are those that cannot be superposed with their mirror images [1–4]. Chiral metamaterials have revealed several novel electromagnetic phenomena, such as negative refraction [5,6], asymmetric transmission effect [7–10], linear or/to circular polarization conversion [11,12], circular dichroism (CD) effect [13–16] and others. In particular, the CD of circularly polarized light through chiral metamaterials has attracted significant attention in recent years. This effect is due to different transmission intensities between the left circularly polarized light (LCP) and right circularly polarized light (RCP). Chiral structures with CD are always related to circular polarizers for optoelectronic conversion [17,18], polarization conversion [19,20], and molecular analysis [21–24]. In recent years, the CD effect of nanoscale plasmonic systems was widely studied. The nanoscale plasmonic systems have shown significantly enhanced CD because of the strong interaction between light and noble metals [25,26]. These significant interactions between electric and magnetic resonance cause large CD signals in 3D helix or helix-like chiral plasmonic nanostructures [27–32]. Thus, a layer-by-layer chiral nanostructure is designed considering that the helix-like chiral structure is complex and not easy to tune. In addition, the layer-by-layer chiral plasmonic nanostructure can generate larger CD signals because of the coupling between two layers [33–41]. Various approaches have been used to create plasmonic nanostructures and tune chiroptical responses. Changing parameters are often applied to tune the magnitude of a CD signal or shift the wavelength of the aforementioned chiral structures; however, the CD signals cannot be regulated individually. This phenomenon provides a hint to design nanoscale plasmonic systems to accurately regulate optical response without affecting another response. In this study, a double-layer chiral mental nanostructure that consists of an achiral nanoplate and two achiral nanodisks were designed to generate a CD effect. The results show that the double-layer chiral mental nanostructure generates two CD signals, and one CD signal can be tuned by varying the parameter without affecting the other CD signal. This process enables investigating plasmonic analog and studying optical response when the resonances of the constituents are intentionally tuned. In addition, the Born–Kuhn model has been used to analytically interpret the observed CD spectrum, providing insight into the underlying coupling mechanisms. This study can guide the design to accurately tune chiroptical response for practical application in biosensing. 2 Structure and computational method Fig. 1 (a) shows the proposed nanostructure arrays, and each unit is composed of two layers. The bottom layer is two nanodisks and the top layer is a nanoplate. The rotational symmetry centers of the two nanodisks coincide with the center of the nanoplate in the z-direction. The period is Px =300nm and Py =300nm in the x and y direction, respectively. Fig. 1(b) depicts the cell of nanostructure in x-z plane. The radius of nanodisk is labeled as R. The nanoplate has a length of L. The width and height of nanoplates are indicated as W =60nm and H =20nm, respectively. The gap between two layers is G. Fig. 1(c) shows the cell of nanostructure in x-y plane. And the twist angle between the line of center of two nanodisks is α in the x-y plane. The distance between the centers of the two nanodisks is D =120nm. The 3D finite-element method software COMSOL Multiphysics is used to calculate the transmittance of nanostructure arrays. The refractive index of gold is taken from Ref. [42]. The excitation sources are RCP light and LCP light along the −z direction and the magnitude of the incident electric field is set at 1V/m. Transmittance was defined as T = P out/P in, which is the ratio of output power to incident power. The transmittance spectrum of RCP light and LCP light are represented by T ++ and T –, respectively. Therefore, the chirality of structures is represented by CD= T ++ − T –. 3 Results and discussion Fig. 2 (a) shows the transmission spectra of plasmonic arrays under RCP and LCP light illuminations. The structure parameters of the arrays are L =180nm, R =30nm, α=45°, and G =20nm. Two evident resonant modes, namely, modes I and II of approximately 860 and 550nm, respectively, are observed in the transmission spectra. Fig. 2(b) is the CD spectra of the nanostructure arrays. One CD peak and valley appear at the resonance wavelengths. In mode I, the transmittance under LCP illumination is larger than those under RCP illumination. In mode II, the transmittance under RCP illumination is larger than those under LCP illumination. Around the resonance wavelengths, the spectra of T ++ and T −− correspondingly present different responses, thereby leading to a large CD effect. The charge distributions were examined to investigate the transmission mechanism of the nanostructure arrays under circular illumination. Fig. 3 shows the top view of the normalized charge distributions of the nanodisk and nanoplate, where red and blue indicate positive and negative charges, respectively. Fig. 3(a) and (b) shows the normalized charge distributions of the nanoplate at modes I and II, respectively. The green arrows represent the equivalent electric dipole moments of nanoplate (upper layer). Fig. 3(c) and (d) shows the normalized charge distributions of the nanodisks at modes I and II, respectively. The light-blue arrows represent the equivalent electric dipole moments of the nanodisk (lower layer). At λ I =860nm, the equivalent electric dipole moment of the nanoplate along the long axis direction is presented. The effective dipoles P I-D1 and P I-D2 constitute P I-D. In Fig. 3(e), P I-D and P I-U form a bonding mode in the Born–Kuhn oscillator model [43,44]. At λ I =550nm, the effective dipole P I-U represents the equivalent electric dipole moment of the nanoplate along the short axis direction. P II-D1 and P II-D2 represent the equivalent electric dipole moments of nanodisks and can also constitute P II-D. In Fig. 3(f), P II-D and P II-U form a bonding mode in the Born–Kuhn oscillator model. Most importantly, the resonance mode of the nanodisks occurs at approximately 550nm and that of the nanoplate is at 860nm. In addition, we sequentially investigate the influence of varied α, L, R, and G of nanostructure arrays on CD where other parameters are fixed as in the control group. The angle between the two layers was tuned to explore the influence of asymmetry of nanostructure on CD. Fig. 4 (a) depicts the simulated CD spectra in different angle α with fixed L =180nm, G =20nm, and R =30nm to investigate the effects of angle α on CD. At α=0° and 90°, the structure is achiral, and the two peaks disappear. When α is increased from 0° to 150°, modes I and II do not shift. With an increase in α, every equivalent electric dipole moment of components is not changed; thus, modes I and II do not shift. Fig. 4(b) shows the simulated CD spectra for different length of nanoplate with fixed G =20nm, R =30nm, and α=45° to investigate the effects of length L on chiroptical response. As we can see in Fig. 4(b), mode I red shifted whereas mode II unchanged with the length of nanoplate increased. With an increase in L, the equivalent electric dipole moments P I-U on the nanoplate increased, resulting in red shift of the resonance wavelength. But the equivalent electric dipole moments P II-D and P II-U both unchanged, resulting in mode II does not shift. Thus, mode II can be individually tuned by length of the nanoplate. In Fig. 4(c), the CD spectra is shown for G =20nm, α=45°, and L =180nm with different radius of nanodisk. With an increase of R, mode II blue shift, but mode I does not shift. In the near field, the component of P I-D and P II-D increased with an increase of R, thereby resulting in the red shift of mode II. However, the equivalent electric dipole moments P I-U and P II-U both unchanged, resulting in mode I does not shift. Thus, mode II can be individually tuned by radius of the nanodisk. Finally, the distance of two layers was tuned to investigate the influences of the coupling of the chiroptical response. Fig. 4(d) shows the CD spectra of different gap G between two layers with fixed L =180nm, R =30nm, and α=45°. At mode I and II, CD spectra undergo a continuous blue-shift for the increasing gap G. Given that modes I and II are ascribed to the bonding mode between the electron oscillations on the nanodisk and nanoplate, this finding indicates that attraction exists between nanodisk and nanoplate. An increased G will decrease the attraction between them, leading to a decrease in the equivalent electric dipole moments and resulting in the blue shift of the resonant wavelength. Experimentally, the middle dielectric layer was considered in the design of chiral plasmonic nanostructure. When the middle SiO2 dielectric layer was added, the resonance modes red shifted. 4 Conclusions A double-layer chiral plasmonic nanosystem with two nanodisks and a nanoplate is proposed to generate a chiral response. The two CD signals can be regulated individually in the nanostructure. Mode I is mainly due to the resonance of the nanoplate along the long axis. Mode II is mainly due to the resonance of the nanodisks. The CD mechanism of the double-layer nanostructure satisfies the Born–Kuhn model for CD effects. Overall, these results are useful for designing a chiral plasmonic nanosystem for a tailored light–matter interaction. This system is expected to be widely applied in biological monitoring, analytical chemistry, and negative refractive-index media. Acknowledgements This work was supported by National Natural Foundation of China (Grant No.11004160), the Fundamental Research Funds for the Central Universities (GK201603015), and Innovation Funds of graduate Programs, Shaanxi Normal University (2017CSZ002).

column2: Two and three-input all-optical logic gates on a planar three-core photonic crystal fiber
column3: Abstract In this paper, we numerically demonstrate the acquisition of two all-optical devices that perform the OR and AND logic operations using a solid core Photonic Crystal Fiber (PCF) with three symmetrical cores in planar array using solitonic pulses modulated in PAM-ASK. We numerically simulated the propagation of 100 femto-second (fs) solitonic pulses through the PCF and solved the coupled-mode equations using the 4th order Runge-Kutta method. For the first device, we obtained the passive three-input OR and AND all-optical logic gates, which operated with high performance, so they could be used to replace more complex optical circuits (in which the occurrence of Boolean expressions like the three-input OR and three-input AND are very common) without the need for concatenation therefore saving space and eliminating problems regarding the cascading of logic gates. For the second device, we obtained the active two-input OR and AND all-optical logic gates, which operated with exceptionally high contrast ratios and could therefore be used in optical signals processing.
column5: Keywords All-Optical logic gate Nonlinear directional coupler (NLDC) Photonic crystal fiber (PCF) Pulse amplitude modulation (PAM) 1 Introduction The photonic crystal fiber (PCF), also known as micro-structured fiber, is made of non-doped silica and it is, externally, very similar to the conventional optical fiber. Its main structural difference consists of air holes that cross it from end to end and form a matrix. The holey matrix has as its main physical parameters d, the diameter of the holes (usually filled with air) and Λ, which represents the distance between the holes. The enhanced nonlinear response in the PCF appears as a combination of its strong mode confinement and altered dispersion properties. The dispersion in these fibers is adapted (customized) by altering its geometric parameters: fiber length, air hole diameter, hole-to-hole distance, hole pattern, number of cores, core arrangement (planar, triangular, etc.), distance between cores, etc. [1–3]. A strong light confinement field can be obtained with a high contrast between the refractive indexes of the core and the holey cladding [4], which allows for improved nonlinear optical interactions with lower light energies if compared to conventional fibers. Several theoretical studies have shown that, in comparison to two-core nonlinear directional couplers (NLDCs), three-core couplers have more output states, sharper switching characteristics and greater sensitivity to the input states, being these characteristics of great importance in all-optical switching schemes [5–8]. As shown in Refs. [9,10] and [11], a PCF can act as a nonlinear directional coupler (NLDC) made entirely of fiber. The coupler model investigated here consists of a PCF with three symmetrical solid cores in a parallel equidistant arrangement (planar symmetrical arrangement), as shown in Fig. 1 . In the PCF, the holey matrix has three parallel solid cores separated by a distance C, distance between holes Λ and hole diameter d. The coupler is a six-ports device, three inputs (S 1, S 2, and S 3) and three outputs (S 4, S 5, and S 6), whose function is to coherently divide the optical beam inserted into one of the input ports and direct it to the output ports. The cores are quite close so that the fundamental modes of propagation of each core partially overlap in the cladding region between the two cores over the entire coupling length LC. For the modulation of the input pulses in the coupler we use 3 amplitude modulators, ɛ, and 2 phase controllers, Δϕ, arranged as shown in Fig. 2 . Although the OR, AND and NOT gates are sufficient for the creation of any logic circuit, it is worth noting that obtaining some of the more commonly used logical expressions, such as the three-input AND and OR gates, is also of great interest since we can save on resources, space, power losses and processing time by using ready-made expressions instead of a set of other concatenated logic gates. There are, up to date, several studies on the acquisition of all-optical logic gates, either by using couplers, interferometers or waveguides [12–15]. Most optical devices proposed for logic operations using conventional fiber couplers have coupling lengths that can range from a few units up to tens of meters [6,16,17], and can therefore occupy large spaces in the construction of complex circuits. Thus, the utilization of PCFs offers a considerable reduction in coupling lengths, achieving the same results with only a few centimeters of fiber [13]. These coupling lengths may be even smaller depending on the physical parameters and the pattern of the holey matrix in the PCF [11,18]. In this paper, we numerically demonstrate the acquisition of all-optical logic gates based on a planar three-core PCF coupler operating with 100fs solitonic pulses modulated on PAM-ASK (Pulse Amplitude Modulation with Amplitude Shift Keying). We obtained two devices with lengths of L=1.08cm and L=1.2cm, being both less than half of the coupling length for pulses inserted into cores 1 or 3 on this specific coupler. For the first device, L=1.08cm, we found two of the most common Boolean expressions in logic circuits, the passive three-input OR and AND logic gates. For the second device, L=1.2cm, we found the active two-input OR and AND logic gates. For both devices the desired logic operation (AND or OR) is selected by adjusting the phases of the input pulses. All logic gates have high contrast ratios in the worst case, so these are of high performance. In particular, the three-input OR and AND logic gates (which are now being demonstrated for the first time when using PCF with PAM-ASK modulation) are an interesting result for allowing us to save on space and avoid problems regarding the cascading of logic gates in the creation of more complex optical circuits. This work is organized as follows: in Section 2, we present the theoretical model of the planar three-core PCF coupler based on the three coupled-mode equations; in Section 3, we present the PAM-ASK modulation, the PCF parameters and the details of the numerical method used in the solution of the coupled-mode equations; in Section 4, we present an analysis of the obtained results; finally, in Section 5, we present the conclusion of this work. 2 Theoretical model For typical applications of nonlinear characteristics in optical communications, small solid core PCFs with high nonlinearity are preferred. Due to the large difference between the refractive indexes of the silica core and the air-holes cladding, these PCFs allow for a much stronger mode confinement and, therefore, much higher nonlinearities [4]. The effective nonlinearity γ of a fiber is given by: (1) γ = 2 π n 2 λ A eff where Aeff is the effective area, λ is the wavelength and n2 is the nonlinear index coefficient [19]. So, one way of increasing the nonlinearity is to reduce the effective area [4]. By properly choosing the size and pattern of the air holes in the holey matrix, the effective area can be reduced thereby increasing the nonlinear phase variation during the pulse propagation in the fiber. The effective nonlinear modal area of a PCF is given by: (2) A eff = n 2 [ ∫ ∫ E ( x , y ) · E * ( x , y ) dxdy ] 2 ∫ ∫ n ¯ 2 ( x , y ) [ E ( x , y ) · E * ( x , y ) ] 2 dxdy where E ( x , y ) is the transverse electric field and n ¯ 2 ( x , y ) is the nonlinear index of the material at position (x, y) [4]. In PCFs, the group velocity dispersion (GVD) is determined both by the dispersion of the silica itself and by the parameters of hole diameter, d, hole-to-hole distance, Λ, and the pattern of the holey matrix, which allows for greater flexibility in the dispersion design to suit the application required. The dispersion coefficient of a fiber is given by: (3) D = − 2 π c λ 2 β 2 = − λ c d 2 n eff ( λ ) d λ 2 where β 2 is the group velocity dispersion, neff is the effective refractive index of the mode, given by n eff ( x , y ) = β [ λ , n m ( λ ) ] / k 0 , β is the propagation constant, k0 =2π/λ is the free space wave number and n m ( λ ) is the chromatic dispersion of the material [19]. So, the fiber dispersion is determined by two types of dependence of β with regard to λ: The geometric dispersion, Dg , given by D g = − ( λ c ) d 2 n g ( λ ) / d λ 2 , that originates from the explicit dependence of β on λ, which is produced by the refractive index distribution geometry n g ( λ ) in the PCF; And the material dispersion, Dm , given by D m = − ( λ c ) d 2 n m ( λ ) / d λ 2 , that originates from the implicit dependence of β on λ through the chromatic dispersion of the material. The total dispersion D is then calculated as the sum of the geometric dispersion Dg and the material dispersion Dm in the first order approximation [20]: (4) D ≈ D g + D m So, we can clearly see that the problem in designing the dispersion of a PCF is to design Dg . The effective refractive index n g ( λ ) depends on the cladding parameters (d and Λ) and the wavelength λ. Thus, the group velocity dispersion (GVD) can be projected from (3). This property has been extensively numerically investigated [2,20–23]. For the analyzed coupler model, the optical power transfer between the three cores can be described by three coupled-mode equations. Due to the planar arrangement of the cores, the modes of the pulses in cores 1 and 3 do not interact with each other. The nonlinear coupled-mode equations, obtained from the Nonlinear Schrödinger Equation (NLSE) for the planar three-core nonlinear directional coupler are given by: i ∂ a 1 ∂ z − β 2 2 ∂ 2 a 1 ∂ t 2 − i β 3 6 ∂ 3 a 1 ∂ t 3 + γ ( | a 1 | 2 + η | a 2 | 2 ) a 1 + i γ ω ∂ ( | a 1 2 | a 1 ) ∂ t (5) − γ a 1 T R ∂ | a 1 | 2 ∂ t + κ 0 ( a 2 ) + i κ 1 ∂ ( a 2 ) ∂ t = 0 i ∂ a 2 ∂ z − β 2 2 ∂ 2 a 2 ∂ t 2 − i β 3 6 ∂ 3 a 2 ∂ t 3 + γ ( | a 2 | 2 + η | a 1 + a 3 | 2 ) a 2 + i γ ω ∂ ( | a 2 2 | a 2 ) ∂ t (6) − γ a 2 T R ∂ | a 2 | 2 ∂ t + κ 0 ( a 1 + a 3 ) + i κ 1 ∂ ( a 1 + a 3 ) ∂ t = 0 i ∂ a 3 ∂ z − β 2 2 ∂ 2 a 3 ∂ t 2 − i β 3 6 ∂ 3 a 3 ∂ t 3 + γ ( | a 3 | 2 + η | a 2 | 2 ) a 3 + i γ ω ∂ ( | a 3 2 | a 3 ) ∂ t (7) − γ a 3 T R ∂ | a 3 | 2 ∂ t + κ 0 ( a 2 ) + i κ 1 ∂ ( a 2 ) ∂ t = 0 where a 1, a 2 and a 3 are the amplitudes envelopes of the pulses inserted into cores 1, 2 and 3 respectively; z is the distance along the fiber; t is the time coordinate with regard to the transit time of the pulses; β 2 is the group velocity dispersion (GVD) and β 3 is the third order dispersion (TOD); γ is the nonlinearity parameter referring to self-phase modulation (SPM); TR is the Raman scattering coefficient; η is the ratio of cross-phase modulation (XPM) with regard to SPM; κ 0 is the coupling coefficient and κ1 is the coupling coefficient dispersion, given by κ 1 = dκ0/dω [9]. 3 Methodology The pulses inserted into inputs ports S 1, S 2, and S 3 were modulated in PAM-ASK as bits 1 or 0 and passed through the coupler then resulting in output ports S 4, S 5, and S 6. By inserting a low intensity pulse and neglecting the dispersion in small propagation lengths we have then that the transmission is periodic with the fiber length. In linear regime, for pulses inserted into cores 1 or 3 on planar three-core couplers, the transmission T is given by T 2 = 1 4 ( cos ( 2 κ z ) + 1 ) 2 . The coupling length LC is where the light reaches the lowest intensity in the input core. Thus, for pulses inserted into cores 1 or 3, L C = π / 2 κ ≅ 2.54 cm [8]. In order to find logic gates in the shortest possible length we tested coupler lengths limited by LC and found logic gates at L=1.08cm and L=1.2cm. 3.1 PAM-ASK modulation Most lightwave digital systems employ ASK because the pulses transmitted in optical fibers must have a wavelength of λ=1.55μm (and hence a fixed frequency) to minimize losses. Using a hyperbolic secant A ( z , t ) with amplitude AREF and offset parameter ɛ as the reference pulse, the pulse is modulated into the form A b ( 0 , t ) = [ A REF + ( − 1 ) 1 − b ε ] sech ( t ) , where b is the desired bit (0 or 1). Like this, the zero pulse (representing bit b =0) is given by A 0 ( 0 , t ) = ( A REF − ε ) secht and the one pulse (representing bit b =1) is given by A 1 ( 0 , t ) = ( A REF + ε ) secht . The reference pulse is given by A REF ( 0 , t ) = A REF secht . For the output pulses analysis we observe the output amplitude AOUT of each signal. We consider as bit 1 signals whose amplitude is greater than the reference amplitude AREF and as bit 0 signals whose amplitude is smaller than AREF . In the situation that the output signal has an amplitude equal to AREF we then consider this signal to have an indefinite logic level. 3.2 Numerical method The system consists of a single three-core PCF with three PAM-ASK modulators and two phase controllers. The coupler physical parameters are: hole diameter of d=2μm, hole-to-hole distance of Λ = d/0.9, core separation of C =2Λ, wavelength near the region of λ=1.55μm and effective area of Aeff =41μm2. The PCF parameters used were β2 =−47ps2/km, β3 =0.1ps3/km, γ=3.2×10−3Wm−1 and γ/ω=2.6×10−18s/Wm [11,18]. The coupled-mode equations were solved using the 4th order Runge-Kutta method. We used a step of h=0.00001 and a time window of 7385.254fs divided into 512 temporal grid points. The reference frame moves with the pulse at the group velocity ( v g ) and the time is given by t=t′−z/vg. We used the fundamental soliton propagation [ L ND = L D ] with a full temporal width at half maximum (TFWHM) of the input pulse of Δt=100fs. We neglected the fourth-order dispersion and fiber losses due to the small propagation length (negligible loss regime). In the modulation, we used an offset parameter of | ε | = 6 W 1 / 2 . The peak power of the reference pulse is PREF =4.64kW and the reference amplitude is given by A REF = P REF . We analyzed all the output signals for all possible input combinations. From these, we highlighted the two and three-input OR and AND gates and chose the best ones based on the contrast ratio (CR) between the 0 and 1 bits in the worst case. 4 Results and discussions With an offset parameter of | ε | = 6 W 1 / 2 , couplers with lengths of L=1.08cm and L=1.2cm and the phase controllers Δϕ1 and Δϕ2 ranging from 0 to 2π in 41 points, the pulses inserted into input ports S 1, S 2, and S 3 are modulated in PAM as bits 1 or 0, then passing through the coupler and resulting in output ports S 4, S 5, and S 6. In the output signals demodulation, we analyzed the amplitudes AOUT for all possible input combinations in the truth table. We considered as bit 1 signals with an amplitude greater than the reference amplitude AREF and as bit 0 signals with an amplitude smaller than AREF . We obtained two devices: the first one, with L=1.08cm, resulting in the three-input passive OR(A, B, C) and AND(A, B, C) logic gates, and the second one, with L=1.2cm, resulting in the active two-input OR(A, B) and AND(A, B) logic gates. Here, A, B and C represent the logic states of the input signals in the coupler for cores 1, 2 and 3 respectively. 4.1 First device: three-input passive OR and AND logic gates For the first device, a planar three-core PCF with a length ofL=1.08cm, hole diameter of d=2μm, hole-to-hole distance of Λ≅2.22μm and core separation (between two adjacent cores) of C≅4.44μm, we obtained, as the output of core 3, the passive three-input OR(A, B, C) and AND(A, B, C) logic gates (which are now being demonstrated for the first time when considering PCF with PAM-ASK modulation), where the desired logic operation (AND or OR) is selected by adjusting the phases of the input pulses. The passive three-input OR(A, B, C) logic gate, whose output signals are shown in Fig. 3 a), is obtained with the parameters Δϕ1 =1.0495π and Δϕ2 =0.0975π. Note that the output pulse for input 000 is the only one that is below the reference line, as expected from this logic gate’s truth table. The passive three-input AND(A, B, C) logic gate, whose output signals are shown in Fig. 3b), is obtained with the parameters Δϕ1 =0.901π and Δϕ2 =0.799π. Note that the output pulse for input 111 is the only one that is above the reference line, as expected from this logic gate’s truth table. Both logic gates were obtained at output S 6 (core 3). Table 1 contains some data for the analysis of the AND(A, B, C) and OR(A, B, C) logic gates: the truth table, the offset parameters of the output signals and the contrast ratio, CR, for each output. The output pulse modulation parameter εOUT is the difference between the amplitude of the analyzed output signal and the reference amplitude. εOUT is negative for logic state 0 and positive for logic state 1. The contrast ratio is calculated by CR = 10 log 10 ( P / P R ) , where P is the peak power for each case and PR is the peak power for comparison, which depends on the analyzed logic gate type. For the OR gate, PR is the peak power of the case whose output is bit 0 whereas for the AND gate, PR is the peak power of the case whose output is bit 1 [24]. In the worst case, the contrast ratio between the 0 and 1 output signals is 0.553dB for the OR(A, B, C) gate and 0.364dB for the AND(A, B, C) gate. As in both logic gates worst cases the CR is greater than 0.3dB, there is enough margin for distinguishing the logic signal from the noise in optical detectors. 4.2 Second device: two-input active OR and AND logic gates As we are dealing with a coupler with 3 inputs and 3 outputs, besides the three-input logic gates it is also possible to obtain two-input logic gates. In these gates, only two inputs will be effectively used, the third one being an enable input (or control signal, as seen in Refs. [6] and [12]), which is very common in electronic integrated circuits. The logic gates shown below receive the input pulses into cores 1 and 2 whereas the enable pulse is inserted into core 3. Here, the enable pulse is a hyperbolic secant with a peak power of 4.676kW and a TFWHM of 100 fs (similar to the input pulses). So, for the second device, a planar three-core PCF with a length of L=1.2cm, hole diameter of d=2μm, hole-to-hole distance of Λ≅2.22μm and core separation of C≅4.44μm, we obtained, as the output of core 3, the active two-input OR(A, B) and AND(A, B) logic gates, where the desired logic operation (AND or OR) is selected by adjusting the phases of the input pulses. The active two-input OR(A, B) logic gate, whose output signals are shown in Fig. 4 a), is obtained with the parameters Δϕ1 =2π and Δϕ2 =0.4545π. Note that the output pulse for input 00 is the only one that is below the reference line, as expected from this logic gate’s truth table. The active two-input AND(A, B) logic gate, whose output signals are shown in Fig. 4b), is obtained with the parameters Δϕ1 =0.297π and Δϕ2 =0.4525π. Note that the output pulse for input 11 is the only one that is above the reference line, as expected from this logic gate’s truth table. Both logic gates were obtained at output S 6 (core 3). Table 2 contains some data for the analysis of the AND(A, B) and OR(A, B) logic gates: the truth table, the offset parameters of the output signals and the contrast ratio “CR” for each output. For the OR gate, P R is the peak power of the case whose output is bit 0 whereas for the AND gate, PR is the peak power of the case whose output is bit 1 [24]. In the worst case, the contrast ratio between the 0 and 1 output signals is 1.387dB for the OR(A, B) gate and 1.109dB for the AND(A, B) gate. As in both logic gates worst cases the CR is greater than 0.3dB, there is a significant margin for distinguishing the logic signal from the noise in optical detectors. 5 Conclusion In this work, we numerically demonstrated the acquisition of two all-optical devices that perform the OR and AND logic operations using a planar three-core PCF coupler with solitonic pulses modulated in PAM-ASK. In the first device, L=1.08cm, we found the passive three-input OR(A, B, C) and AND(A, B, C) logic gates, obtained in Δϕ1 =1.0495π, Δϕ2 =0.0975π and Δϕ1 =0.901π, Δϕ2 =0.799π, respectively. In the second device, L=1.2cm, we used core 3 as an enable port, which received an enable input signal, resulting in the active two-input OR(A, B) and AND(A, B) logic gates, obtained in Δϕ1 =2π, Δϕ2 =0.4545π and Δϕ1 =0.297π, Δϕ2 =0.4525π, respectively. All of the logic gates were obtained at output S 6 (core 3) of the coupler. Since most digital light-wave systems employ ASK, due to the need to keep the wavelength of the pulses at λ=1.55μm to minimize losses, the acquisition of optical devices that work using the PAM-ASK modulation is of great interest. All logic gates shown here have contrast ratios greater than 0.3dB, thus having a significant margin for distinguishing the logic signal from the noise in optical detectors. The active two-input logic gates obtained in the second device showed exceptionally high contrast ratios, with 1.3869dB for the OR gate and 1.1091dB for the AND gate. Due to its high contrast ratios, these logic gates are more efficient if compared to other works in literature where the PAM-ASK modulation is used to obtain all-optical logic gates made of PCF [12,13]. The three-input logic gates obtained in the first device are an interesting result for being smaller than the two-input logic gates obtained in this and several other works in literature where conventional fibers and PCFs are used [6,12,13,16,17,25]. This smaller length allows for saving resources and physical space in the creation of more complex optical circuits (in which the occurrence of Boolean expressions like OR(A, B, C) and AND(A, B, C) are very common). For example, using only two-input OR gates, we need 2 cascaded OR gates to obtain the logical expression OR(A, B, C) as output, which takes up more space and has a considerable power loss due to the transition through the two gates. So, by using a three-input OR logic gate we can save space and avoid the problems that come with the cascading of logic gates in the construction of more complex optic circuits. Acknowledgment This work was supported by Brazilian Agencies FUNCAP and CAPES.

column2: Impact of multiple usages of digital filters on speckle contrast and phase maps
column3: Abstract Various digital filters have been use to remove unwanted noise in speckle pattern used in the field of Electronic speckle pattern interferometer (ESPI). However, multiple usages of these digital filters can contribute to significant drop in speckle contrast leading to loss of phase information. This paper reports effect of multiple usages of various digital filters namely, Median, Gaussian and Average on the speckle contrast and ultimately on the phase maps. This study also compares effectiveness of these three digital filters in removing noise from speckle patterns.
column5: Keyword Electronic speckle pattern interferometer Digital filtering Speckle contrast Wrapped and unwrapped phase map 1 Introduction Electronic speckle pattern interferometer (ESPI) is a widely used technique to quantify roughness/deformation of the object. It was first developed by J. Butters, J. Leendertz in 1970 [1]. Nowadays, ESPI technique is used widely to remotely quantify the roughness/deformation of an object. Wide varieties of objects, from soft condensed matter to metallic disk to thin films are probed using the ESPI technique [2–4]. By knowing the phase of the correlation fringe pattern, amplitude of deformation can be calculated. There are various ways developed over the years to determine the phase of the correlation fringe pattern. Among all the ways, temporal phase shifting techniques are popularly used by many researchers [5]. For determining the phase information, high quality speckle patterns are required. Quality of a speckle pattern is generally measured in terms of speckle contrast which is defined as following [6], (1) C = 〈 I 2 〉 − 〈 I 〉 2 〈 I 〉 Where, C is the speckle contrast and I is the intensity. Numerator is the root mean square deviation of the intensity fluctuations and the denominator is average intensity. Value of C lies between 0 and 1, where 0 means no speckle and 1 means image full of speckles. Depending on the usage of imaging system speckle pattern are called objective and subjective. When the imaging system is used then the pattern is called as subjective otherwise it is called as objective. In this paper, speckle patterns are subjective. Generally, difference between speckle patterns obtained from the object with and without deformation is taken into consideration for obtaining correlation fringe pattern. However, speckle pattern obtained directly from the experiment contains noise which can badly influence correlation fringe pattern’s contrast [7]. Various digital filters are used to remove the noise from the speckle pattern [8]. Phase calculation algorithms require digitally filtered speckle pattern before extracting the phase information from the deformed object. Multiple usages of these filters can have adverse effect on the overall speckle contrast. This paper explores the effect of multiple usages of digital filters namely; Median, Gaussian and Average on the speckle contrast and on the phase map. This study also reveals the effectiveness of above mentioned digital filters in removing noise from speckle pattern. Digital filters: Workings of various filters used in this paper are discussed below in brief. Median filter: In the median filter [9,10], a pixel matrix of suppose 3×3 is chosen. Then the middle pixel’s gray value is readjusted according to the rest of the elements in that matrix. For example, below (Eq. (2)) is the 3×3 window containing ‘6′ as a middle pixel’s gray value. After application of median filter it is now changed to 5. As it is clear from the working of this filter it does not changes the image area. (2) [ 7 3 4 8 6 _ 1 5 9 2 ] M e d i a n f i l t e r ⇒ [ 7 3 4 8 5 _ 1 5 9 2 ] This filter is very useful to filter out the unwanted speckle noise from the digital speckle pattern. Gaussian filter: This filter is described by the Gaussian distribution curve (Eq. (3)) [9]. Digital image is nothing but two dimensional arrays of x and y pixel elements. Two dimensional Gaussian distribution can be expressed as: (3) G ( x , y ) = 1 2 π σ e x 2 + y 2 2 σ 2 where, σ is a standard deviation. Average filter: This filter averages pixel to pixel gray value variations. In the average filtering, we have used convolution operation which depends on the kernel size. Kernel represents the shape and sizes of the neighborhood pixels to calculate the mean [11]. Larger kernel is used if more blurring is required. In general kernel sizes vary from 3×3, 5×5, and 7×7 and so on. This paper explores the effect of multiple usages of digital filters namely; Median, Gaussian and Average on the speckle contrast. This study also reveals the effectiveness of above mentioned digital filters in removing noise from speckle pattern. 2 Experimental setup Experimental set up of ESPI is as shown in Fig. 1 . Light from the laser was first divided into two half using a beam splitter. One beam is used to illuminate the object surface in the full-field manner using spatial filter assembly. The illuminated object thus forms speckle pattern which contains information about the surface of object (Stainless Steel Plate). The speckle pattern was then collected with a zoom lens and imaged on to the digital camera. The digital camera is having following specifications; 1/4-inch CMOS sensor, Array element: 1280×1024, Pixel sizes: 2.8×2.8μm and Maximum frame rate: 7.5fps. Second beam (reference beam), after reflecting from series of mirrors whose paths are matched with the first beam, was made to diverge and superimposed with the light reflected from the object via beam splitter on the camera. Both wave fronts back scattered from the object and of the reference beam interfere and form a speckle pattern. This speckle pattern of object is digitized and stored in a computer. 3 Result and discussion Digital filters namely, Median, Gaussian and Average (with kernel as 3×3 and 7×7) were applied to the speckle pattern obtained in the experiment. Speckle pattern was converted into grayscale for further processing. Speckle contrast of unfiltered speckle pattern was calculated using Eq. (1). Various digital filters as mentioned above were applied to the speckle pattern individually and repeatedly. Speckle contrast, after every application of respective filtering, was calculated. Speckle contrast of speckle images is found to be decreasing after every application of digital filters. Fig. 2 shows the effect of various digital filters on speckle contrast. Fig. 3 shows the modulation in intensities of pixel values due to application of Median, Gaussian and Average (with kernel as 3×3 and 7×7) filter. Fig. 4 clearly shows substantial decrease in the speckle contrast after application of digital filters fifteen times. Among the three filters used, Gaussian filter yield least decrease in speckle contrast with multiple usages. After approximately 5th iteration of each filter, speckle contrast assumes a nearly constant value which does not change further with iterations. After Gaussian, Median is the second best in keeping high value of speckle contrast followed by average filter using 3×3 kernel. Fig. 5 shows the wrapped and unwrapped phase map obtained from the unfiltered speckle images via five step phase shifting algorithm [12] of electronic speckle pattern interferometer. After unwrapping this phase map, one can calculate the amount of deformation of the object. As it can be seen from Fig. 5, large amount of noise is present in wrapped and unwrapped phase maps. Hence it is very difficult to obtained authenticate phase information from it. In fact, unwrapped phase map is totally blinded by noise as seen from Fig. 5. Hence it very necessary to remove noise from it. For this multiple digital filters such as Gaussian, median and average digital filters which are discussed above can be used to remove this unwanted noise from the wrapped phase map. Fig. 6 shows the wrapped and unwrapped phase map after applying the various digital filters such as Gaussian filter, median digital filter and average digital filters with different kernals on it. As it is seen from Fig. 6 when the average filter with kernel 3Χ3 is applied on the speckle images prior to applying five step phase shifting algorithm to get wrapped and unwrapped phase map, then it clearly shows improvement as compared to Fig. 5. After applying the same filter five times on the speckle images, improvement is clearly visible compared to Fig. 6a on the wrapped and unwrapped phase map as shown in Fig. 6b. This is in tune with the speckle contrast decrease as shown in Fig. 4. Similar results are for average filter with 7×7 kernal size as shown in Fig. 6c and d. Fig. 6e and f shows the wrapped and unwrapped phase map after deploying Gaussian filter once and five times to clean speckle images respectively. It certainly shows improvement over Fig. 5 but if it is compared with results of average filter then it can be concluded that Gaussian filter is less effective in removing noise. But Gaussian filter is more effective in maintaining ‘speckleness’ of the images as compared to average and median filter. This can also be concluded from Fig. 4. Similar results are for median filter as shown in Fig. 6g and h which shows wrapped and unwrapped phase map after deploying the filter once and five times on the speckle images. Using median filter once reduces the noise more efficiently compared to Gaussian filter as it is obvious from Figs. 6 e,g and 4. However after five iterations of the respective filters, noise reduction is almost same as visible from Figs. 6f,h and 4. Hence all the results shown in Fig. 4 correlates to Fig. 6. 4 Conclusion Different filters were compared by calculating speckle contrast and wrapped and unwrapped phase maps. Effectiveness of various filters in removing noise and maintaining speckleness were compared. Results obtained in this context from speckle constrast calculation and after application of filters prior to calculation of phase maps correlates with each other. We found that Gaussian filter works best among the median and average filter in keeping the speckleness of the pattern along with removing the unwanted noise. Median filter also scores well along with Gaussian filter after multiple usages. Whereas it is found that average filter gives the best result among these removing unwanted noise from the speckle pattern but it largely affect the speckle contrast. Speckle contrast hovers around a constant value after approximately five applications of every filter.
