column2: Numerical modeling of pulse propagation through a double-negative metamaterial with adjacent absorptive and gain Lorentz dispersions: A comparison
column3: Abstract The state-of-the-art time-domain numerical techniques, the finite-deference time-domain (FDTD) method and the pseudospectral time-domain (PSTD) method, are applied to simulate the physical propagation process of a pulse through a double-negative metamaterial with adjacent absorptive and gain Lorentz dispersions. The algorithmic feasibility and modeling accuracy of the two numerical methods combined with the common techniques for Lorentz dispersion implementation are demonstrated from the obtained simulation results and compared with the analytical solution. It is shown that the FDTD method with material parameters averaged at the slab’s two interfaces works better than that without averaging and also better than the case of PSTD method with the same time and space discretization parameters. The proposed techniques are useful for the ultra-accurate modeling of pulse interaction with metamaterials.
column5: Keywords Finite-deference time-domain method Pseudospectral time-domain method Metamaterial Pulse propagation 1 Introduction A sufficient requirement for a negative refractive index is that both the permittivity and permeability are simultaneously negative [1]. A medium having such a property is often called a double-negative material or, more traditionally but less rigorously, a left-handed material. Although a negative-index material is not naturally available, electric and magnetic dipoles in the artificial materials operating in the effective medium limit have been shown to exhibit an effective negative refractive index [2]. Of great interest, a negative index media with zero loss at a specific operating frequency would potentially allow a perfect imaging [3], which foreshows its wide applications in microscopy, semiconductor device processing, and optical memories [4]. There has been reported to use gain to offset loss and therefore it is possible to achieve a zero loss operating condition through a mixture of two semiconductor quantum dots and with the permittivity and permeability both being real and negative [5]. In this work, both the finite-deference time-domain (FDTD) method [6] and the pseudospectral time-domain (PSTD) method [7] are applied to accurately modeling a type of Lorentz metamaterials with adjacent loss and gain resonances. The PSTD method seems superior to the FDTD method in view of the fact that in the former algorithm, both electric and magnetic field components locate at the same location within a cell. This advantage circumvents the ensuing problems, such as the artificial transition layers at the object’s boundaries [8] due to the staggering field components applied in the algorithms like the FDTD method. Unfortunately, the PSTD method is weak in representing the abrupt change of electromagnetic field at an interface, say, between the free space and a double-negative metamaterial. It would introduce spurious aliasing errors on the electromagnetic field on all cells within the computational space, which is also the reason why a spatially smoothed source is required in order to excite electromagnetic waves in the PSTD method [9]. The FDTD algorithm doesn’t have such a phenomenon due to the fact that the spatial derivatives are calculated from the field values on two adjacent cells. Furthermore, the artificial transition layer occurring in the FDTD algorithm can be efficiently alleviated by using smaller size of spatial cells or applying spatial averaging at the boundaries [10]. Therefore it is of interest to investigate whether the FDTD method with or without material parameter averaging at the two interfaces outperforms the PSTD method in modeling this special type of metamaterials. For the negative vales of permittivity and permeability cannot be directly assigned into the FDTD or PSTD updating equations, the dispersion-implementation approach must be incorporated into them to model such a highly-dispersive metamaterial and herewith we utilize the piecewise linear recursive convolution (PLRC) algorithm as it is accurate in simulating various metamaterials with multiple Debye or Lorentz dispersions [11]. 2 System configuration The configuration of the system studied is shown in Fig. 1 , where Regions I and III are the free space with ε1 =ε3 = 1, and μ1 =μ3 = 1. A flat slab of thickness d occupies Region II between the interfaces x = x 1 and x=x1 +d, and infinitely extends in both y and z directions. The source is placed in the left part of Region I to generate the incident pulse. Detector 1 is placed in the right-hand side of the source to record the temporal waveform of incident pulse when the slab is removed, which avoids the influence of the reflected pulse from the slab’s interfaces. As an accurate reference, this detector is set at the origin of x axis for the sake of mathematical convenience. Detector 2 is utilized to record the waveform of pulse transmitting through the plane x = x2 . The whole computational space is truncated by the uniaxial perfectly-matched layers (UPML) at both ends to absorb the outgoing waves [12]. The flat slab is made from the type of special metamaterial with the material parameters proposed in Ref. [5], whose relative permittivity and permeability has an identical dispersion model with impedance matched to free space and given by (1) ε r ( ω ) = μ r ( ω ) = 1 + ∑ m = 1 2 ( − 1 ) m + 1 ω p m 2 ω 0 m 2 − j 2 ω δ m − ω 2 , where ω p1 and ω p2 are the two plasma angular frequencies, ω 01 and ω 02 are the resonance angular frequencies; δ 1 and δ 2 are the damping or gain coefficients, respectively. The other material parameters in the numerical simulations are f 01 = ω 01/2π = 3GHz, f 02 = ω 02/2π = 1.5f 01, δ 1 = δ 2 = ( ω 02 − ω 01 ) 2 / 8 , ω p 1 = ω p 2 = ( ω 02 3 − ω 01 3 ) / ( ω 01 + ω 02 ) . Under this set of material parameters, the ‘perfect’ frequency for this metamaterial is (2) f p = ω p / 2 π = ( ω 01 2 + ω 02 2 ) / ( 8 π 2 ) = 3.8243 GHz , at which frequency the condition εr(ωp) = μr (ωp) =−1 for a perfect lens is satisfied [3]. The relative permittivity and the permeability, as well as the complex refractive index, share the same expression given by (1) and are illustrated in Fig. 2 as functions of frequency, where the ‘perfect’ frequency fp is exclusively marked. Apparently, such a metamaterial is absorptive in the frequency range below fp , while active at the frequencies above f p. In the frequency region near fp , the imaginary part is nearly linear but quite steep, implying a dramatic transition of the property of medium from loss to gain. The analytical solution to the complex transmission coefficient in frequency domain is given by (3) T ( ω ) = exp { j ω [ n ( ω ) d + ( x 2 − d ) ] / c 0 } , where c 0 is the speed of light in free space, n(ω) = Re[n(ω)] + jIm[n(ω)] is the complex refractive index of metamaterial. On the other hand, based on the simulation results about the waveforms recorded by Detector 1 and Detector 2, the numerical counterpart of T(ω) can be calculated by dividing the discrete spectrum of transmitting pulse E 2 (t) by that of incident pulse E 1 (t), (4) T ˜ ( ω ) = DFT { E 2 ( t ) } / DFT { E 1 ( t ) } , where DFT represents the discrete Fourier transform. Combing Eq. (4) with Eq. (3), we have the real and imaginary parts of the numerical refractive index, (5) Re [ n ˜ ( ω ) ] = { A r g [ T ˜ ( ω ) ] c 0 / ω − ( x 2 − d ) } / d , (6) a n d Im [ n ˜ ( ω ) ] = − ln ( | T ˜ ( ω ) | ) c 0 / ( ω d ) . As the refractive index is a crucially important parameter that would affect the slab’s performance in subwavelength imaging, the difference between the numerical refractive index calculated from each of numerical techniques and its exact analytical solution given by Eq. (1) is emphasized in the following discussions. 3 Simulation results To evaluate the accuracy of the aforementioned numerical techniques in modeling the type of metamaterial described by Eq. (1), we should calculate the numerical refractive index according to Eqs. (5) and (6) from the simulation results by simulating the pulse propagation through a flat slab made of such a metamaterial and then compare it with the analytical exact refractive index. Because the amplification coefficient assigned for the metamaterial is relatively large, the slab is set with a relatively small thickness, say, one-tenth of the ‘perfect’ wavelength, d= 0.1λp . The other parameters used in the simulations are cell size Δx = λp/410 and time step size Δt = Δz/(2c0 ), as to meet the Courant stability conditions both for the FDTD and PSTD algorithms. The total number of cells is N = 1024 and the number of time steps performed is 30,000. The incident wave is a Gaussian-derivative pulse with a wide frequency spectrum having a maximum value at 2.5GHz and down to 0.001 of the maximum amplitude at 10.5GHz. The spatially smoothed source is spanning across five cells indexed from 298 to 302, while the flat slab occupies cells indexed from 700 to 740 with a thickness of 41Δx. Detector 1 is placed at the 679th cell and Detector 2 at the 761st cell, both being 20.5Δx far away from the flat slab’s front and back interfaces, respectively. Further suppose that the incident pulse propagates in the positive x-axis direction and passes through Detector 1 with a temporal waveform of z-polarized electric field as depicted in Fig. 3 (a) with a solid line. Based on Eqs. (3)–(5), the temporal waveform of the transmitted pulse received by Detector 2 can be analytically calculated and shown in Fig. 3(a) by a dashed line up to time step 12,000, which is equivalent to 3.83ns in physical time. The spectrum magnitudes of the incident pulse and the analytically calculated transmitting pulse are plotted in Fig. 3(b). As expected, the components of waves pertaining to the frequency range of gain resonance are amplified while absorbed in the frequency range of loss resonance. In Fig. 4 , we show the errors of the real and imaginary parts of the complex refractive index obtained by using the FDTD method with and without averaging of permittivity at the slab’s interfaces and the PSTD method, respectively, as compared to the analytical exact solution. The magnitudes of amplitude of error from the FDTD method are at the order of 10−4, while it is at the order of 10−3 from the PSTD method. Relatively larger values of error are notified around the maximum gain and loss resonance frequencies, 3GHz and 4.5GHz, respectively for all the numerical schemes. The primary error of the FDTD method comes from the wave reflection on the slab’s interfaces as a result of the spurious transition layers due to the staggering field components in the Yee lattices. The averaging of permittivity at the slab’s interfaces alleviates this situation and it is evident, as we can see from Fig. 4, that the error is greatly suppressed to a level about one-fifth of that without averaging, especially in the frequency range near the gain resonance. In a common sense, the PSTD method performs better than the FDTD method in modeling the conventional media given that the same cell size is applied [7]. However, it may be not very suitable for modeling a double-negative metamaterial like the one we discussed in this work as we can see from Fig. 4. The magnitude of error from the PSTD is even larger than that from the FDTD method without averaging on the slab’s boundaries. Although the reflectionfrom the slab’s interfaces is removed under the PSTD formulation, the discrete Fourier transform algorithm it based to calculate the spatial derivatives is quite questionable in representing an abrupt change of the slopes of the electromagnetic fields. In Fig. 5 , we illustrate the introduced aliasing errors upon the electric field in the whole computational region at time step 3300 under the PSTD simulation and this fact contaminates the correct simulation results. Thus, for a fine sampling of time and space such as at the order of about 200 cells per shortest wavelength, the PSTD method is worse than the FDTD method in modeling this type of double-negative metamaterial. Although the aliasing errors can be suppressed by using a larger computational domain for the PSTD algorithm, the stringent requirement of memory and computing time would be prohibitive for practical applications. Moreover, the PSTD method is also problematical in constructing a sharp and compact object that contains fine and detailed information ready to be imaged by a flat metamaterial slab to evaluate its ability in subwavelength imaging. 4 Conclusion In this work, both the FDTD and PSTD methods are applied to accurately modeling the pulse propagation through a flat slab made of a double-negative metamaterial with adjacent Lorentz absorptive and gain dispersions. We find that for a relatively fine discretization of time and space, the PSTD scheme loses its superiority over the FDTD scheme due to the aliasing errors caused by its incompetent representation of electromagnetic fields as the result of the abrupt change of the electromagnetic fields’ slopes at the slab's two interfaces. We also conclude that the FDTD method with material parameter averaging at the slab’s interfaces would be a good choice of the time-domain numerical techniques developed so far for modeling this type of double-negative metamaterials. Acknowledgments This work was supported in part by the National Natural Science Foundation of China (No. 61101007), the Fujian Province Science Fund for Distinguished Young Scholars (No. 2015J06015), the Program for New Century Excellent Talents of Fujian Provincial Universities (No. MJK201554), the Incubation Program for Outstanding Young Researchers of Fujian Provincial Universities (No. JA14011), and the Promotion Program for Young and Middle-Aged Teachers in Science and Technology Research of Huaqiao University (No. ZQN-YX203).

column2: Novel singular solitons in optical metamaterials for self-steepening effect
column3: Abstract We consider the evolution of ultrashort pulses in metamaterials wherein the pulse propagation is governed by the generalized nonlinear Schrödinger equation with higher-order effects such as pseudo-quintic nonlinearity and self-steepening effect. We present three new types of exact singular soliton-like solutions for the model in the presence of the self-steepening term, whose phase chirping varies as a function of the pulse intensity. The obtained results indicate that the parameters of solutions are directly related the self-steepening parameter. Parametric conditions on physical parameters for the existence of the novel structures are also presented. Particular cases are discussed.
column5: OCIS 060.2310 060.4510 060.5530 190.3270 190.4370 Keywords Singular solitons Metamaterials Self-steepening 1 Introduction Propagation of soliton pulses in optical fibers has received a great deal of attention in recent years [1–6]. In particular, exact soliton-like or quasi-soliton solutions including bright and dark quasi-solitons, dark-like-bright solitons and double-kink solitons have been shown to exist under certain parametric conditions on the fiber parameters [1–6]. However, the study of quasi-solitons dynamics in metamaterials (MMs) with dispersive permittivity and dispersive permeability has received little attention. Regarding such a problem, Yang et al. [7] considered a generalized nonlinear Schrödinger equation (NLSE) describing the propagation of ultrashort pulses in MMs and present three new types of exact bright, dark, bright-grey quasi-solitons in the very specific condition of the vanishing self-steepening parameter. But when the soliton pulse width becomes ultrashort (<100fs) and subsequently the higher-order effects can not be neglected, the effect of self-steepening on solitons becomes an important issue in optical systems [8]. We mention that the self-steepening, otherwise called the Kerr dispersion, is due to the intensity dependence of group velocity [9]. In practice, such a physically important effect causes an asymmetrical spectral broadening of the pulse and distort the wave forms. Furthermore, self-steepening can develop an optical shock, perceived as an extremely sharp near edge [10]. However, in the presence of both dispersion and the Kerr nonlinear effect, solitons can be found that are robust against the shock formation [8]. In most of the problems of practical interest, the self-steepening effect plays a significant role in the propagation of femtosecond pulses. Thus, it is important to investigate the propagation properties of optical solitons in the presence of this effect since the latter will essentially influence the physical features of propagating pulses. In this paper, we investigate for the first time to our knowledge the propagation characteristics of singular soliton-like in metamaterials under the influence of the self-steepening effect. It is remarked that the self-steepening term has profound influence on the parameters of solitons. We also show that the nonlinear chirp associated with these optical solitons is directly proportional to the pulse intensity. We further discuss the properties of solitons in the absence of self-steepening term. 2 Governing model The generalized NLSE with higher-order effects governing the propagation of ultrashort pulses in MMs is given by [7] (1) i ∂ ψ ∂ z + k 2 2 ∂ 2 ψ ∂ t 2 + p 3 ψ 2 ψ − p 5 ψ 4 ψ − is 1 ∂ ∂ t ψ 2 ψ = 0 , where ψ(z, t) is the complex envelope of the electric field, t = cT/λ p and z = Z/λ p are the respective normalized time and propagation distance, where λ p is the plasma wavelength. k 2 stands for the group-velocity dispersion (GVD), while p 3, p 5 and s 1 denote the cubic, pseudo-quintic nonlinearity and the self-steepening effect, respectively. Eq. (1) for p 5 = s 1 =0 reduces to the NLSE which has only the terms describing lowest order dispersion and self-phase modulation [11,12]. In the limit p 5 =0, Eq. (1) describes the derivative NLSE [8]. In absence of the self-steepening term s 1 = 0 , Eq. (1) becomes the well-known cubic–quintic NLSE [13]. It is of interest to find propagating envelope solutions in metamaterials governed by the model (1). To obtain the exact soliton solutions of Eq. (1), we consider a solution of the form (2) ψ ( z , t ) = ρ ξ e i κ z − Ω t − θ ξ , where ξ = t − χt is the traveling coordinate, while ρ and χ are real functions of the traveling coordinate ξ. It is worth noting that when θ ξ = 0 , the phase function in (2) [i.e., κ z − Ω t − θ ξ ] reduces to the same form as in Ref. [7], which leads to quasi-soliton solutions found under the condition of the vanishing self-steepening term. If we put Ω=0 in Eq. (2), the solution reduces to the complex envelope traveling-wave solution used by Alka et al. [1], to find chirped dark, bright and double-kink solitons in optical fibers. For the present work, we are interested by singular soliton-like solutions in metamaterials which have nontrivial phase structure depending on the wave intensity. Notice that, with introducing the general solution (2), we have established a unifying representation for searching exact solutions with nontrivial phase chirping for higher-order NLS models. Obviously, the corresponding chirping is given by δ ω ( z , t ) = − ∂ / ∂ t κ z − Ω t − θ ξ = Ω + θ ′ ξ . Substituting Eq. (2) into Eq. (1) and separating the real and imaginary parts, we find the pair of coupled equations in ρ and θ, (3) − κ + χ θ ′ ρ + k 2 2 ρ ′ ′ − Ω + θ ′ 2 ρ + p 3 ρ 3 − p 5 ρ 5 − s 1 Ω + θ ′ ρ 3 = 0 , and (4) − χ ρ ′ − k 2 Ω + θ ′ ρ ′ − k 2 2 ρ θ ′ ′ − 3 s 1 ρ 2 ρ ′ = 0 , where the prime indicates differentiation with respect to ξ. Eq. (4) can be exactly integrated to yield: (5) θ ′ = − Ω + χ k 2 − 3 s 1 2 k 2 ρ 2 , The corresponding chirping takes the form: δ ω z , t = − ( χ / k 2 ) − ( 3 s 1 / 2 k 2 ) ρ 2 . This shows that the chirp associated with propagating pulses is an intensity dependent function (with I = ψ 2 = ρ 2 being the intensity) and includes both linear and nonlinear contributions. We also see that δ ω z , t depends essentially on the self-steepening parameter s 1 in addition to the group velocity dispersion coefficient k 2. Further substitution of the expression (5) into Eq. (3) gives a dynamical equation describing the evolution of the wave amplitude in the metamaterial as (6) ρ ′ ′ − 2 κ k 2 + Ω 2 − Ω + χ k 2 2 ρ + 2 p 3 k 2 + s 1 χ k 2 2 ρ 3 − 2 p 5 k 2 − 3 s 1 2 8 k 2 2 ρ 5 = 0 , Multiplying (6) by ρ′ and integrating with respect to ξ, we get (7) ρ ′ 2 = b 0 + b 2 ρ 2 − b 4 ρ 4 + b 6 ρ 6 , where (8a) b 2 = 2 κ k 2 + Ω 2 − Ω + χ k 2 2 , (8b) b 4 = p 3 k 2 + s 1 χ k 2 2 , (8c) b 6 = 2 3 p 5 k 2 − 3 s 1 2 8 k 2 2 . and b 0 being an arbitrary integration constant. Eq. (7) is an elliptic equation which is known to admit a variety of solutions including periodic, kink, and solitary-wave-type solutions. In this paper, we report new types of singular soliton-like solutions under different parametric conditions. 3 Singular solitons in MMs In this section, we present three new types of singular soliton-like solutions of the model (1) in the presence of self-steepening term, based on solving Eq. (7) under certain parametric conditions. The explicit solutions and corresponding chirping are given below. 3.1 TYPE-I For b 0 =0, we have find a first new singular soliton-like solution of Eq. (7) of the form (9) ρ ξ = A csch η ξ 1 + B csch 2 η ξ , where (10a) A = 12 B ( 1 − B ) p 3 k 2 + s 1 χ ( 1 − 2 B ) 8 p 5 k 2 − 3 s 1 2 , (10b) η = A − p 3 k 2 + s 1 χ ( 1 − 2 B ) k 2 2 , (10c) κ = k 2 2 η 2 − Ω 2 + Ω + χ k 2 2 , provided that B ( 1 − 2 B ) p 3 k 2 + s 1 χ 8 p 5 k 2 − 3 s 1 2 > 0 and ( 1 − 2 B ) p 3 k 2 + s 1 χ < 0 , with the necessary condition B <1. Based upon the above finding, we obtain a first nonlinearly chirped singular soliton-like solution of Eq. (1) in the presence of self-steepening effect of the form (11) ψ ( z , t ) = A csch η t − χ t 1 + B csch 2 η t − χ t e i κ z − Ω t − θ ξ , where the soliton parameters A, η and κ obey relations (10), while the frequency shift Ω is an arbitrary constant. From Eq. (10) which represent analytical relations among parameters of the singular soliton, one can see that these parameters are directly related to the self-steepening coefficient s 1. The corresponding chirping is given by (12) δ ω z , t = − χ k 2 − 3 s 1 A 2 csch 2 η t − χ t 2 k 2 1 + B csch 2 η t − χ t . 3.1.1 Chirp-free singular quasi-solitons (TYPE-I) Here, we study particular solutions of Eq. (1) when the parameter of the phase modification θ ξ = 0 in (2). For this case, the phase function reduces to κz −Ωt, which has been used in Ref. [7]. By putting θ ξ = 0 in Eq. (4), we obtain the relation χ =−Ωk 2 and the condition s 1 =0. The latter implies that propagating envelopes in the metamaterial will be found in the limit of the vanishing self-steepening effect. Under this condition, the formulas in Eq. (10) can be reduced to the form: (13a) A = 3 B ( 1 − B ) p 3 2 ( 1 − 2 B ) p 5 , (13b) η = A − p 3 ( 1 − 2 B ) k 2 , (13c) κ = k 2 2 η 2 − Ω 2 , Then a direct substitution of these results in (11) provides a new solution describing an unchirped singular quasi-soliton solution for Eq. (1) as follows: (14) ψ ( z , t ) = A csch η t − χ t 1 + B csch 2 η t − χ t e i κ z − Ω t , where A, η and κ satisfy relations (13). From Eqs. (13a) and (13b), one must require B(1−2B)p 3 p 5 >0 and (1−2B)k 2 p 3 <0 together with the condition B <1 for the solution (14) to exist. 3.2 TYPE-II For an arbitrary integration constant b 0 ≠0, Eq. (7) admits another new singular soliton-like solution of the form (15) ρ ξ = A coth η ξ 1 + B csch 2 η ξ , where (16a) A = 12 B p 3 k 2 + s 1 χ ( 2 B + 1 ) 8 p 5 k 2 − 3 s 1 2 , (16b) η = A B − 1 p 3 k 2 + s 1 χ ( 2 B + 1 ) k 2 2 , (16c) κ = k 2 2 B + 2 B − 1 η 2 − Ω 2 + Ω + χ k 2 2 , provided that B ( 2 B + 1 ) p 3 k 2 + s 1 χ 8 p 5 k 2 − 3 s 1 2 > 0 and ( 2 B + 1 ) p 3 k 2 + s 1 χ > 0 , with the necessary condition B >1. Making use of these findings, we can present the second family of singular soliton-like solution with nonlinear chirp of Eq. (1) as (17) ψ ( z , t ) = A coth η ξ 1 + B csch 2 η ξ e i κ z − Ω t − θ ξ , where A, η and κ are given by the relations (16). The corresponding chirping takes the form (18) δ ω z , t = − χ k 2 − 3 s 1 A 2 coth 2 η t − χ t 2 k 2 1 + B csch 2 η t − χ t . 3.2.1 Chirp-free singular quasi-solitons (TYPE-II) In the case of θ ξ = 0 in (2), Eq. (4) yields the relation χ =−Ωk 2 and the condition s 1 =0. Under these conditions, Eq. (17) simplifies to the following singular quasi-soliton solution: (19) ψ ( z , t ) = A coth η ξ 1 + B csch 2 η ξ e i ( κ z − Ω t ) , where the parameters A, η, and κ are now (20a) A = 3 Bp 3 2 ( 2 B + 1 ) p 5 , (20b) η = A B − 1 p 3 ( 2 B + 1 ) k 2 , (20c) κ = k 2 2 B + 2 B − 1 η 2 − Ω 2 , From Eqs. (20a) and (20b), necessary conditions for the existence of the preceding solution can be obtained as B(2B +1)p 3 p 5 >0 and (2B +1)p 3 k 2 >0. 3.3 TYPE-III For an arbitrary nonzero integration constant b 0, we have found an exact singular soliton-like solution of Eq. (7) as (21) ρ ξ = A 1 + B coth 2 η ξ , where (22a) A = 12 1 + B p 3 k 2 + s 1 χ ( 3 + B ) 8 p 5 k 2 − 3 s 1 2 , (22b) η = A − B p 3 k 2 + s 1 χ ( 1 + B ) 3 + B k 2 2 , (22c) κ = − k 2 2 2 η 2 + Ω 2 + 3 η 2 B − Ω + χ k 2 2 , provided that p 3 k 2 + s 1 χ 8 p 5 k 2 − 3 s 1 2 > 0 and B p 3 k 2 + s 1 χ < 0 with the primary requirement B >−1. We then obtain the following chirped singular soliton-like solution for Eq. (1): (23) ψ ( z , t ) = A 1 + B coth 2 η ξ e i κ z − Ω t − θ ξ , The corresponding chirping is given by (24) δ ω z , t = − χ k 2 − 3 s 1 A 2 2 k 2 1 + B coth 2 η t − χ t . where A, η and κ are given by the relations (22). 3.3.1 Chirp-free singular quasi-solitons (TYPE-III) If we set θ ξ = 0 in (2), then Eq. (4) yields the relation χ =−Ωk 2 and the condition s 1 =0. In this case, Eq. (23) simplifies to the following unchirped singular quasi-soliton solution: (25) ψ ( z , t ) = A 1 + B coth 2 ( η ξ ) e i ( κ z − Ω t ) where the parameters A, η and κ are given by (26a) A = 3 ( 1 + B ) p 3 2 ( 3 + B ) p 5 , (26b) η = A − Bp 3 ( 1 + B ) 3 + B k 2 , (26c) κ = − k 2 2 2 η 2 + Ω 2 + 3 η 2 B , (26d) χ = − Ω k 2 Necessary conditions for the existence of this solution can be obtained from Eqs. (26a and 26b) as p 3 p 5 >0, Bp 3 k 2 <0, and B >−1. 4 Conclusion We have investigated a generalized nonlinear Schrödinger equation with higher-order effects such as pseudoquintic nonlinearity and self-steepening, describing the propagation of ultrashort pulses in metamaterials. We analytically solved the model by means of the coupled amplitude-phase formulation in the presence of self-steepening term. This is of great importance because ultrashort optical pulses propagation in nonlinear media necessarily require the self-steepening term in the governing equation. Three new types of exact singular soliton-like solutions having nontrivial phase chirping which varies as directly proportional to the pulse intensity are presented. Furthermore, the nonlinear chirp associated with each of these newly envelope solutions is also determined. Exact unchirped singular quasi-soliton solutions have been found under the condition of vanishing self-steepening parameter. Conditions for the existence of these structures are reported. Acknowledgements The second author (QZ) was funded by the National Natural Science Foundation of China under the grant number 11547149. The third author (SPM) would like to thank the research support provided by the Department of Mathematics and Statistics at Tshwane University of Technology and the support from the South African National Foundation under Grant Number 92052 IRF1202210126. The research work of sixth author (MB) was supported by Qatar National Research Fund (QNRF) under the grant number NPRP 8-028-1-001. The authors also declare that there is no conflict of interest.

column2: Effect of Fe substitution on optical and magnetic properties of CeO2 nanoparticles
column3: Abstract Pure and iron doped cerium oxide nanoparticles (Ce1-xFexO2) at x=0.00, 0.01, 0.03 and 0.05 were synthesised using ball milling method and subjected to their microstructural, optical and magnetic properties. Face centred cubic structure was found for (Ce1-xFexO2) nanoparticles at x=0.00, 0.01, 0.03 and 0.05 and no evidence of impurities were found from X-ray diffraction patterns. The surface morphology and chemical compositions of the nanoparticles were studied using FE-SEM attached with EDAX and found that the nanoparticles were almost in spherical shape with nearly stoichiometric ratios. The optical band gap of the nanoparticles were calculated and found increase with Fe doping concentration. The pure CeO2 nanoparticles exhibited a magnetization of 0.0043 emu/g and coercivity of 400Oe. The magnetic moment is found to increase with increase of doping. The (Ce1-xFexO2) nanoparticles at x=0.05 exhibited the magnetization of 0.07 emu/g and coercivity of 491Oe which are far higher values when compared with that of undoped CeO2 nanoparticles.
column5: Keywords X-Ray diffraction Transparent conducting oxides Solid state reaction 1 Introduction Oxide semiconductors such as indium oxide, tin oxide, zinc oxide, titanium oxide, etc were studied extensively for their suitable applications in many of the optoelectronic applications. These oxide semiconductors possess peculiar properties such as wide band gap, high stability, high carrier density, high conductivity along with transmittance. Since Dietl et al. [1] and Mastumoto et al. [2] proved the existence of ferromagnetism in dilute magnetic semiconductors at room temperature, intensive interest has been initiated on magnetic properties of different oxide semiconductors. These oxide semiconductors find numerous applications in spintronic devices [3–5]. Hence intensive interest has been put on the wide band gap oxide semiconductors synthesised either in the bulk form or in thin films form. They are found to exhibit ferromagnetism at room temperature, also the proper reason for the origin of the room temperature ferromagnetism in these materials have been explained [6–11]. One of the most important oxide semiconductor falls under rare earth category namely, Cerium Oxide. They are wide band gap material exhibiting cubic structure of fluorine type possessing with a lattice constant a=0.5411nm. It finds application in silicon based microelectronic devices along with other spintronics devices [12,13]. It has the unique feature of maintaining its cubic structure during switching over of its oxidation states. It exhibit ferromagnetism with Curie temperature above the room temperature with moderate electrical conductivity. Hence CeO2 gathers more interest as an alternative of other wide band gap oxide semiconductors for spintronics applications of dilute magnetic oxides. Moreover, CeO2 nanomaterials exhibited peculiar physical and chemical properties which are quite different from their bulk counterparts. Hence CeO2 in different nano structures have attracted much attention recently. It find applications in gas sensors, radiation detectors, electrochromic devices catalysis, hybrid solar cells, oxygen storage capacity, solid state electrolytes, abrasives for chemical–mechanical planarization, sun screens for ultraviolet absorbents, the adsorption and reaction of formaldehyde, UV blockers and filters, glass polishing materials, acts as antioxidants [14–19] etc. Hence in order to prepare the nanostructured CeO2, different physical and chemical synthesis method such as microemulsion, sol-gel, so no chemical, low temperature solution combustion method, electrochemical, solvothermal and hydrothermal synthesis methods have been applied to synthesize CeO2 nanostructures [20–29]. Each of the method has its own advantage and limitation. As the magnetic properties are depend on synthesis method, dopant, doping concentration, defects, oxygen vacancies it is very important to take care of all these aspects. These aspects were taken into the account during synthesis of nanoparticles such that no unintentional impurities are present in the material [30]. Hence in order to prepare the impurity free CeO2 nanoparticles, here we have adopted simple ball milling method and studied the microstructural, optical and magnetic properties of undoped and Fe doped CeO2 nanoparticle. 2 Experimental Commercially available CeO2 and Fe2O3 (M/S Sigma-Aldrich 99.99% pure) are taken in accurate quantity to convert it into fine powders using ball milling method. Pure and irondoped CeO2 nanoparticles (Ce1-xFexO2) at x=0.00, 0.01, 0.3 and 0.05 concentrations has been prepared by a simple mechanical milling method. The millings were carried out for two and half hours continuously at 360 r.p.min planetary Mono mill (PULVERISETTE 6 Classic line) with 5mm grinding balls. After that, the samples were sintered at 800°C for 6h. A detailed study on structural aspects has been done by X-ray diffraction (X-ray diffractometer, D8 Advance, BRUKER). The elemental studies were carried out with the help of FE-SEM and Energy dispersive analysis spectroscopy(EDS) (OXFORD instrument incapenta FET X3). In order to divulge into the optical properties, UV–vis-NIR Spectrophotometer (JASCO V-670) has been used in diffuse reflectance mode. Vibrating sample magnetometer (Lake Shore-7410) helped in understanding the magnetic behaviour of the samples. 3 Results and discussions 3.1 Structural properties Fig. 1 (a) shows the X-ray diffraction profile of the Fe2O3 and of Ce1-xFexO2 nanoparticles. In the figure, the bottom layer indicates the XRD profile of Fe2O3. The diffraction peaks such as (0 1 2), (1 0 4), (1 1 0), (1 1 3), (0 2 4), (1 1 6), (1 2 2), (2 1 4) and (3 0 0) were found in their respective diffraction angles. These are in good agreement with that of standard XRD pattern of α-Fe2O3 derived from the JCPDS Card No. 33-664 [31]. From this the structure of the nanoparticles was found to be in rhombohedral structure. No other diffraction peaks related to either FeO or Fe3O4 were found in the profile indicating that the source material is pure from any kind of impurities. From the second layer onwards in Fig. 1(a) shows the XRD profiles of Ce1-xFexO2 nanoparticles at different Fe doping concentrations. The diffraction peaks such as (1 1 1), (2 0 0), (2 2 0), (3 1 1), (2 2 2), (3 3 1), (2 0 0) and (4 2 0) were observed at 28.57°, 33.05°, 47.49°, 56.09°, 59.23°, 69.49°, 76.79°, 79.11° and 88.34° respectively. All the diffraction peaks observed here were coincided with face centred cubic structure of CeO2 [JCPDS34-0394]. The diffraction peaks sharp indicating good crystallinity of the prepared samples. Diffraction peaks related to Fe2O3 were not observed here even if the doping concentration of Fe increased from x=0.00 to x=0.05. The intensity of the diffraction peaks decreased with increase of doping concentration. The decrease in intensity of the diffraction peaks might be due to obstructing the growth of CeO2 nanoparticles. Fig. 1(b) shows the X-ray diffraction patterns of the Ce1-xFexO2 nanoparticles at different Fe doping concentration in the diffraction angle range of 28°–34°. From the figure it is clear that the diffraction peak positions slightly differ from pure CeO2 and Fe doped CeO2. The difference is the shifting of diffraction peaks towards higher angles with increase of doping concentration but at x=0.05 the diffraction peak again shifts towards lower diffraction angle. The lattice parameter was calculated and found that it decreased from 3.62Å to 3.57Å with increase of Fe doping concentration from 0 at.% to 1 at.%. The reason behind this is the smaller ionic radius of Fe3+ (0.65Å) in comparison to that of Ce4+ (0.97Å). But from x=0.03 to x=0.05 the lattice parameter increased from 3.58Å to 3.60Å. These results indicate that Fe has substituted into CeO2 host lattice. Similar results were also observed in Cr doped CeO2 nanoparticles synthesised by microwave refluxing method [32]. The crystallite size (G) was calculated by using the Debye-Scherer formula [30], (1) G=kλ/βcos θ where, k is particle geometry dependent constant (for spherical shape k ∼1), λ is the wavelength of used (λ=1.5406Å), β is the full width-at-half maximum (FWHM) and θ is the diffraction angle, respectively. The estimated average crystallite size is found to decrease from 47nm to 30nm with increase of doping concentration from x=0.00 to x=0.05. A summary of grain size, lattice parameter, strain and dislocation density for Fe doped CeO2 nanopowders were shown in Table 1 . 3.2 Chemical composition and surface morphology The Fig. 2 (a)–(c) shows the chemical composition and the inset shows the respective surface morphology of the synthesised nanoparticles. From the figure it is confirmed that the undoped CeO2 exhibited higher crystallite size as evidenced from XRD. The crystallite size is found to decrease with increase in doping concentration as shown in Fig. 2(b). The particles are almost spherical in shape and uniformly distributed in Ce1-xFexO2 nanoparticles. The elements such as Ce, Fe and O were in desired ratios and no other elements were found from XRD as evidenced by XRD data. 4 Optical properties Fig. 3 (a) and (b) show the optical absorbance and reflectance spectra of pure and Fe doped CeO2 nanoparticles at different Fe doping concentrations. The optical bang gap Eg was obtained by extrapolating the linear region (α=0) of the graph plotted between (αhυ)2 versus the photon energy (hυ). The optical band gap was estimated using the Tauc equation [33] (3) αhν=A(Eg-hν)1/2 Where hν is the photon energy, α is the absorption coefficient and n is either 1/2 for a direct transition or 2 for an indirect transition. The optical band gap of semiconductor can be estimated from the intercept of the extrapolated linear fit for the plotted experimental data of (αhν)n versus incident photon energy hν near the absorption edge as shown in Fig. 3(c). An optical band gap of 3.22eV was observed for pure CeO2 nanoparticles whereas a band gap of 3.34eV was observed for Ce1-xFexO2 nanoparticles. The observed optical band gap is in comparable with that of band gap of bulk CeO2 powder [34]. The inconsistency in band gap was observed here. The pure CeO2 exhibited a band gap of 3.2eV whereas the band gap increased to 3.34eV, 3.36eV for Ce1-xFexO2 nanoparticles at x=0.01, 0.03 and it decreased to 3.32eV at x=0.05. The reason for the inconsistency in band gap of Ce1-xFexO2 nanoparticles is unclear here and need further study in future. This kind of inconsistent behaviour has been observed in band gap of Co doped CeO2 nanoparticles [35]. But the increase in bang gap with Fe doping concentration can be explained using Burstein-Moss band filling effect [36]. 4.1 Magnetic properties Fig. 4 (a) shows the M-H loop of the pure Fe2O3 at room temperature. From the figure it is clear that the iron oxide exhibit hysteresis loop with high coercive field. Fig. 4(b) shows the M-H loops of the undoped and Fe doped CeO2 nanoparticles obtained from the vibrating sample magnetometer on Ce1-xFexO2 nanoparticles at room temperature in the applied field range of+15000gauss. All the samples exhibited a clear hysteresis loop with large coercivity. In general the stoichiometric CeO2 exhibits diamagnetic nature in bulk form and can become ferromagnetic when it is prepared at nanoscale. This behaviour was predicted theoretically and observed experimental studies on CeO2 and suggested that the origin for the existence of ferromagnetism at room temperature was due to exchange interactions between Ce+3 and oxygen vacancies or BMPs bounded electrons [37,38]. If these BMPs are large in number, high magnetization will be observed due to localized coupling of Ce+3 ions with electrons magnetically. In addition to this oxygen vacancies will be present in the CeO2 host lattice and the density of these oxygen vacancies can be increased doping and/or other aspects of synthesis procedure [39]. From the figure it is clear that the undoped CeO2 nanoparticles also exhibited ferromagnetism. The magnetic moment of 4.79memu/g, coercive field of 476G and retentivityof 1.55memu/g were observed. In the recent studies it was reported that the ferromagnetism in undoped CeO2 nanoparticles was due to conversion from Ce+4 to Ce+3 ions leading to creation of oxygen vacancies. This leads to enhancement of density in Ce 4f orbital state inducing superexchange interaction between Ce ions [40]. Similar results were reported earlier for CeO2 nanoparticles by Sundaresan et al. [41] observing an RT-FM with an Ms value of approximately 1.9 memu/g and by Ge et al. [42] observing weak ferromagnetic behaviour with an Ms value of approximately 0.7 memu/g. The observed magnetic moment in the present study is better than that of reported values. Fig. 4(c) shows the field dependent magnetization of Ce1-xFexO2 nanoparticles x=0.00, 0.01, 0.03, 0.05 under the influence of magnetic field range of +5000Oe. The enhancement of magnetic moment on increasing the dopant concentration has been observed from the figure shown above. Remarkably, all the samples report high quality of ferromagnetism. Also the rate of increase in the enhancement of different magnetic parameters varies linearly in all Fe-doped CeO2 with concentration of Fe. Even the observed MsValues are enhanced when compared to the datas reported for pure CeO2 and transition metal doped CeO2 nanoparticles in previous reports. The Ce1-xFexO2 nanoparticles at x=0.01 exhibited a magnetization of 20.2 memu/g at+15000G. A magnetic moment of 80.09 memu/g was observed for Ce1-xFexO2 nanoparticles at x=0.05. The enhancement in the creation of oxygen vacancies, which is helpful in maintaining charge neutrality, is done by doping the host CeO2 with Fe+3 ions. As the dopant concentration is increased, the Fe+3 fractions also increased leading to enhancement of vacancy coupling pairs/Ce+3ions. This as whole results in the enhancement of MS in the Ce1-xFexO2 nanoparticles. For doped CeO2 nanomaterials, the development of excess of oxygen vacancies leads to exhibition of ferromagnetism at room temperature. The enhancement in the creation of oxygen vacancies is occurring due to doping in CeO2 host lattice by Fe3+ ions. It has been suggested that Fe3+–V0–Ce3+ interaction is predominant at lower Fe doping concentration, while the Fe3+–V0–Fe3+ are predominant when Fe doping concentration is increased to a maximum level. However, the increase in the Fe concentration increases the creation of oxygen vacancies. This plays a significant role in the increase of the MS values as no signature of secondary phases were observed here. A summary of saturation magnetization, coercivity and retentivity for Fe doped CeO2 nanopowders were shown in Table 2 . 5 Conclusions Pure and Fe doped CeO2 nanoparticles were prepared by using ball milling method and different characterization techniques were used to have an overview about their structural, optical and magnetic properties. Cubic structure was observed for both undoped and Fe doped CeO2 nanoparticles. High magnetization with high coercive fields was observed for Fe doped CeO2 nanoparticle. The magnetic moment is found to increase along with Fe doping concentration suggesting that increase in doping concentration increases the number of oxygen vacancies. The observed magnetization is intrinsic in nature as no other phases related to impurities were identified. Acknowledgments Authors are grateful to VIT-SIF for providing XRD and UV–vis-NIR spectrophotometer facilities. Authors are also grateful to Dr. C. Krishnamoorthi, Assistant professor, CNR, VIT University, Vellore for his scientific discussions.

column2: Fabrication and characterization of rutile-phased titanium dioxide (TiO2) nanorods array with various reaction times using one step hydrothermal method
column3: Abstract Rutile titanium dioxide nanorods array were fabricated on fluorine-doped tin oxide by using hydrothermal method. The influences of hydrothermal reaction time on morphology, structure property, crystallization, and Raman spectra have been investigated. The hydrothermal treatment was conducted by varying the reaction time at 4, 10, 16, and 24h with temperature of 150°C. The nanostructure samples were analyzed using field emission-scanning electron microscope, X-ray diffractometer, and micro-Raman spectroscopy. The resulting nanorods array shows increasing diameter as the reaction time increased. Meanwhile, the growth of the nanorods stop at one point as can be seen in its thickness, x-ray diffraction, and Raman spectra. This behavior can be attributed to hydrolysis rate of the precursor titanium butoxide (TBOT) as the reaction time increased.
column5: Keywords TiO2 Nanorods array One-step hydrothermal method Raman 1 Introduction Titanium dioxide (TiO2) exists in three known crystalline that is anatase, rutile, and brookite with polymorphs tetragonal for both anatase and rutile, and orthorhombic for brookite [1]. TiO2 have received significant notice these past few decades after the discoveries of photoelectrochemical cell (PEC) and dye sensitized solar cell [2,3]. Major drawbacks of TiO2 nanoparticles related to its recombination process during cell performance [4]. To overcome the drawback, TiO2 nanostructures such as nanorods, nanoflowers, and nanowires were introduced, as its exhibit excellent electron transport due to its well-defined crystalline structure and unique optical properties, which minimizes the recombination process and have been considered as a substitute in the solar cells and electronic devices [5–11]. As TiO2 nanostructures exhibit high crystallinity properties, the electron mobility is also high, thus indirectly enhanced the electron transport and minimize the recombination losses in the thin film [12–14]. There are several methods to produces these nanostructures such as sol-gel, chemical bath deposition (CBD), chemical vapor deposition (CVD), and hydrothermal method. In this study, TiO2 was fabricated by using hydrothermal method. Other methods were at disadvantages such as CBD and CVD methods that usually use an elevated temperature around 300–400°C, while for sol-gel, there is often a cracking and large volume shrinkage during drying process [15–19]. Hydrothermal synthesis method uses a low temperature for mass production of well aligned TiO2 nanostructures directly on substrates, which in this study are using a fluorine-doped tin oxide (FTO) substrate. By using FTO, the preparation for seed layer can be eliminated. In this study, the thin film TiO2 fabricated were in rutile-phase. Highly crystalline TiO2 were intensively investigated due to its advantages such as easily controllable diameter and thickness [20], as well as high electron mobility and chemical stability [21,22] compared to anatase and brookite. These features make it suitable for applications such as photocatalyst and ultraviolet photodetector [23,24]. 2 Experimental Titanium dioxide nanorods array were synthesized using the hydrothermal process in a chemical solution. 120mL of concentrated hydrochloric acid was dissolved in 120mL of deionized (DI) water. After vigorously stirred for 5min, 3.5mL of titanium butoxide (TBOT) was added dropwise using capillary tube. After that, the solution was poured into the autoclave with Teflon-made liner for hydrothermal process to begin. Hydrothermal reaction takes place at 150°C with reaction times of 4, 10, 16 and 24h. After that, the autoclave was taken out from the oven and was let to cool to room temperature. The sampe was then rinsed with DI water and left to dry in oven with 60°C for 10min. Field emission scanning electron microscope (FESEM) JEOL JSM-7600F model operated at 15kV was used to characterize the morphology and thickness of the samples. Meanwhile, the crystal structure and crystallite size are defined by an X-ray diffractometer (XRD) PANalytical X-Pert3 Powder model. The scan axis used was 2h with range of 20θ − 60θ and the type of slit used were fixed divergence slit. Finally, Raman spectra were obtained using a Micro-Raman Spectroscope (Renishaw InVia microRaman System) operated with 514nm wavelength of argon (Ar+) laser. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Field-emission scanning electron microscopy Fig. 1 shows the FESEM image of the nanorods array grown on top of the FTO layer at different reaction times ranging from 4h to 24h. Fig. 1(a)–(d) showed the surface of the nanorods with reaction times of 4h, 10h, 16h, and 24h, respectively. It can be clearly seen that the nanorods grew in decent shape after the reaction time of 16h. Fig. 1(a) shows that the nanorods can barely be seen as the reaction time was too short for growth of the nanorods with diameter produced ranging from 30 to 45nm. The rods are in slanting position with large gaps between each other. However, the nanorods started to grow with increasing reaction time, as can be observed in Fig. 1(b) and (c), with size ranges from 250 to 450nm and 250–300nm, respectively. It can be seen on the surface structure of Fig. 1(b) that the nanorods started to develop in tetragonal shape and a gap between the nanorods has started to form. Meanwhile, from Fig. 1(c), it can be seen that the TiO2 nanorods have grown in decent tetragonal shape with a flat-end facets and obvious gap between them. As the reaction time further increase, the nanorods agglomerate to each other, thus eliminating the gap between the nanorods and the rods also lose their tetragonal forms resulting diameter ranges from 200 to 450nm as shown in Fig. 1(d). A cross-sectional image of the synthesized TiO2 nanorods array is shown in Fig. 1(i), (ii), (iii), and (iv) for 4, 10, 16, and 24h reaction time, respectively. For Fig. 1(i), the cross sectional image shows only of FTO substrate as the nanorods were too small and almost invisible as can be seen in Fig. 1(a). Overall image shows that the nanorods grew perpendicular to the substrate with length of the nanorods to be 0.79μm for Fig. 1(ii), 1.61μm for Fig. 1(iii), and 2.73 for Fig. 1(iv). It can be concluded that the lengths of TiO2 nanorods increase with increasing reaction time [1]. 3.2 X-ray diffraction The XRD patterns of the nanorods TiO2 prepared with different reaction times are shown in Fig. 2 (a)–(d) for 4h, 10h, 16h and 24h, respectively. Clear diffraction peaks are recorded between 20° and 60° consisting of rutile TiO2 and FTO peaks. The rutile peaks are indexed to (101), (200), and (111) planes of TiO2 with tetragonal structures. Fig. 2(a) shows dominant peaks of FTO at 26°, 34°, 37°, 51°, 55° and a rutile TiO2 peak at 39° of plane (200). This is confirmed with FESEM image which shows mostly FTO surface and nanorods only starting to grow on it. XRD diffraction for nanorods prepared in 10 and 16h reaction times as shown in Fig. 2(b) and (c), respectively, were a mixed of FTO and rutile peaks. Both samples prepared have two rutile peaks correspond to planes (101) and (111) with insignificant change in their intensity. In the meantime, intensity for FTO peaks have decreased due to the thickness of the thin film that increased with increasing time as stated in FESEM analysis. In Fig. 2(d), it can be seen that there is no FTO peaks produced leaving only rutile TiO2 peaks as the diffraction with a slight drop in its intensity. Fig. 2 shows that the (101) plane orientation peak centred at 36° gave the highest intensity for rutile TiO2 compared to the others. This indicates that the nanorods growth occurred preferentially vertically to the FTO substrate. Overall peaks observed gave either a strong, sharp diffraction, or a weak, sharp diffraction. There is no broad peak produced thus showing good crystallinity of the samples. During the growth of TiO2 nanorods on FTO substrates, the SnO2 act as a nucleation layer. In order to reduce the surface energy by terminating high energy facets, attachment always takes place at the high energy surfaces. As both rutile and SnO2 have tetragonal structure where the surface energy of (101) plane is high, growth of titania crystal occurs instantly. While the thermodynamically stable crystal structure of SnO2 is rutile, the very small lattice mismatch of both TiO2 and FTO substrate were the driving force for the epitaxial growth of TiO2 nanorod arrays [25]. Table 1 shows the obtained crystallite size for each sample. Different reaction times gave quite a significant change in the crystallite size, except for 16 and 24h reaction time where the crystallite sizes are the same. The crystallite size increases when time increases as increasing time allowing greater coalescence of the particles [26,27]. 3.3 Raman spectroscopy Raman spectra of TiO2 nanorods with different reaction times are shown in Fig. 3 (a)–(d) for 24h, 16h, 10h and 4h, respectively. Peak position produced for Fig. 3(a) are normalized as shown in Fig. 4 , which shows only the peaks of FTO at 570cm−1 and 1087cm−1. Starting from Fig. 3(b) to (c), all peaks produced are of rutile TiO2 Raman shifts at 122cm−1, 241cm−1, 441cm−1, and 620cm−1 which confirmed the result of XRD peaks. Three of the peaks, 122cm−1, 441cm−1, and 620cm−1 are the dominant peaks of rutile single crystal expressed as A1g +B1g +Eg. There is also a second-order scattering peak at 241cm−1 which is also a characteristic of rutile TiO2. The weak and broad peak produced at 241cm−1 was likely because of phonon confinement effect [1]. The samples show increasing intensity of the Raman peaks with increasing reaction time at its prominent maxima which are at 441cm−1 and 620cm−1. This indicated that the nanorods prepared with longer reaction time have better crystallinity as had been in agreement with XRD patterns shown in Fig. 2. This result also suggests that thickness of the sample increase with increasing reaction time. 4 Conclusions Titanium dioxide thin films have been successfully fabricated on top fluorine-doped tin oxide by using hydrothermal method. The reaction time was varied from 4 to 24h. FESEM image of the resulting thin films shows that the diameter of the nanorods increased with increasing reaction time, and the crystalline structure shows rutile phase in all sample fabricated according to XRD pattern and Raman spectra. Acknowledgements The authors would like to thank the Ministry of Education (MOE) Malaysia, Microelectronic and Nanotechnology-Shamsuddin Research Centre (MiNT-SRC) and Universiti Tun Hussein Onn Malaysia (UTHM) for financial support using Vot STG U347.

column2: Research on characterization and modeling for ultraviolet degradation of imidacloprid based on absorbance change
column3: Abstract Absorption spectrum of imidacloprid was measured using spectrophotometer and the most intensive characteristic peak (269nm) was found. The function relationship between imidacloprid concentration and absorbance was obtained with a good linear relationship(R >0.99). The hardware platform for pesticide degradation was designed and built based on ultraviolet light technology, and imidacloprid degradation experiments were conducted based on the platform. It was proposed to describe degradation effect using absorbance change, and prediction model of pesticide residues degradation was obtained according to the relationship between degradation time and absorbance. The results showed that it was feasible to characterize ultraviolet degradation effect according to absorbance change, degradation rate was 4.71% after ultraviolet irradiation for 1minute, and it was 98.43% after 10minutes.
column5: Keywords Ultraviolet light Absorbance Pesticide degradation Imidacloprid 1 Introduction Imidacloprid is a kind of insecticide, which is widely used in agricultural production [1,2]. Pesticide residues will bring potential risk to consumers, and the research methods of pesticide residues have been reported in the literature. For example, P. Karthik conducted a study on imidacloprid residue dynamics in okra under open field conditions [3], Huanan Guan carried out experimental study on dynamics and degradation method of imidacloprid residues in soyabean fields [4], Ji Rendong studied fluorescence spectral method to detect the Imidacloprid residues of apple juice [5], Bahareh Jamshidi implemented the detection of pesticide residues in agricultural product based on Vis/NIR spectroscopic technology [6]. On the other hand, the degradation of pesticide residues is also an important research field. At present, the main degradation technology includes physical method, chemical method and biological method. The physical method mainly contains ultrasonic wave and ionization irradiation [7–9]. Chemical method is one of the most studied degradation technologies, which includes photochemical degradation, chemical oxidation, photocatalysis method and so on [10–12]. Microorganism including bacteria, fungi and actinomycetes are used to degrade pesticide residues in biological method [13,14]. The principle of ultraviolet irradiation degradation of pesticide residues is consistent with the photochemical degradation [15], ultraviolet irradiation can break the double bond of pesticide and destroy the combination of organic carbon that constitute the pesticide, and then, organic matter will be decomposed into small molecular substances. The degradation of imidacloprid residue using ultraviolet light was proposed in this paper, degradation effect was characterized through the change of absorbance, and the relationship between degradation time and degradation rate was derived at last. Research results have some reference value on the selection of detection and degradation technology of pesticide residues. 2 Experiments 2.1 Materials Imidacloprid purchased from Shanghai pesticide research institute (Shanghai, China) was selected as experiment sample. 2.2 Experimental apparatus UV3600 ultraviolet visible spectrophotometer (Shimadzu, Japan) was used to measure the absorption spectrum of imidacloprid pesticide sample. The equipment structure of ultraviolet irradiation degradation was shown in Fig. 1 , which contained 6 parts. The numerical label 1 represented closed system, 2 represented switching device of closed system, 3 was ultraviolet light source module, 4 was module support, 5 was sample pool and 6 was the time control switch of power supply, which can control the irradiation time of ultraviolet irradiation. Low-voltage and high intensity ultraviolet lamp of quartz type was selected as the ultraviolet light source, and its light transmittance was greater than 90%. The lamp was controlled by a electronic ballast with variable power output, the emission wavelength was set to be 253.7nm, the power was set as 3W, the tube voltage was 9.5∼13V, and the pipe flow was 300mA. Ultraviolet lamp was connected to 220V alternating current through a capacitor (4.7F/400V), and ultraviolet irradiation time was controlled by the time control switch. The closed system also contained a cavity and a bracket to place the sample pool. 2.3 Procedures First, a right amount of imidacloprid pesticide was measured using electronic balance which was then configured as standard pesticide solution of different concentrations, and the solution with different concentrations was placed in the cuvette and its absorption spectrum was detected by using UV3600, respectively. And then, 3ml imidacloprid solution was placed in the sample pool of ultraviolet degradation device using cuvette, the absorption spectrum of pesticide was recorded by using UV3600 after the solution was irradiated under ultraviolet light for different time. And the relationship between illumination time and characteristic peak absorbance of the pesticide was deduced at last. 3 Results and analysis 3.1 The absorption spectrum of imidacloprid The absorption spectrum of imidacloprid solution detected by UV3600 was shown in Fig. 2 , and it showed that the spectrum range was from 220nm to 700nm. In Fig. 2, four curves represented corresponding absorbance spectrum of four different concentrations of imidacloprid solution, and the solution concentration was 0.072mg/ml, 0.036mg/ml, 0.018mg/ml and 0.009mg/ml from curve 1 to curve 4, respectively. There was a strong absorption peak at 269nm, and the peak was reduced from 5.2 to 0.9 with the decrease of solution concentration. Therefore, 269nm can be used as the characteristic peak of imidacloprid absorption spectrum. This molecular absorption spectrum was generated by the electronic transition between valence electron and electron in molecular orbital, which belonged to n→π* transition, from nonbonding atomic orbital to molecular antibonding orbital with high level [16]. To analyze the relationship between imidacloprid solution concentration and absorbance, unitary linearity regression method was applied. The results were shown in Fig. 3 , it was found that the relationship between imidacloprid concentration and absorbance was linear when wavelength was at 269nm, the correlation coefficient is 0.9961, and the function of concentration prediction was derived as bellow: (1) y = 67.6095 x + 0.2258 3.2 Imidacloprid degradation using ultraviolet Imidacloprid solution(0.0255mg/ml)was degraded using ultraviolet irradiation for different time, absorption spectrum was detected using UV3600 after each degradation, the absorption spectrum results were shown in Fig. 4 , in which, the spectrum range was from 220nm to 360nm. The degradation time of imidacloprid solution was set to 0, 1, 2, 3, 5, 10, 15 and 20minutes from curve 1 to curve 8, separately. It was obvious that there was a strong absorption peak at 269nm for all the eight absorption spectrum curves. And with the increase of degradation time, the peak value was correspondingly reduced from 1.95 to 0.26, but the peak position remained stable, which further indicated that 269nm was the characteristic peak of imidacloprid absorption spectrum. For further analysis of imidacloprid degradation trend, regression modeling method was applied between ultraviolet irradiation time and absorbance at 269nm. The results were shown in Fig. 5 , the correlation coefficient of polynomial model function was 0.9964, and the function equation was: (2) Y =1.9726−0.0944x −0.0053x 2 +0.0003x 3 The equivalent concentration of imidacloprid solution after degradation was obtained according to Eq. (1), and the degradation rate could be calculated further based on the imidacloprid concentration before and after degradation. The degradation rate was calculated according to Eq. (3): (3) D = ( C 0 − C t ) C 0 × 100 % where D represented degradation rate, C0 represented initial concentration of imidacloprid solution, and Ct represented concentration after degradation using ultraviolet irradiation for time t. The calculation results were shown in Table 1 , it showed that imidacloprid concentration was decreased from 0.0255mg/ml to 0.0243mg/ml after ultraviolet irradiation for 1minute, and the corresponding degradation rate was 4.71%, this meant ultraviolet irradiation had some effect on degradation, but the effect is not very well. When ultraviolet irradiation time was increased to 10minutes, the degradation effect is obvious with the degradation rate up to 72.16%, when ultraviolet irradiation time was set to 20minutes, imidacloprid concentration was decreased to 0.0004mg/ml and the degradation rate reached up to 98.43%, this indicated that imidacloprid was almost completely degraded. 4 Conclusions Absorbance spectrum of imidacloprid solution with different concentration was detected using UV3600 in this paper, and analysis results showed that 269nm was its characteristic peak. Unitary linearity regression method was applied between concentration of imidacloprid solution and absorbance at 269nm, and the function equation of imidacloprid concentration prediction model was deduced with correlation coefficient of 0.9961. The platform for pesticides degradation with ultraviolet irradiation was designed, and imidacloprid degradation experiment was conducted based on the platform. The degradation process was characterized by the change of absorbance, and degradation model function and degradation rate were obtained at last. The results showed that the characteristic peak absorbance was decreased with the degradation time increasing, and the degradation rate was increased accordingly. When the degradation time was set to 20minutes, the degradation rate can reach up to 98.43%. This showed that pesticides degradation can be realized by using ultraviolet irradiation and this provided a reference value for the selection of pesticide degradation technology. Acknowledgements This work was supported by the National Natural Science Foundation of China (61401173), the Science Project of the National Ministry of Housing and Urban-Rural Development (2016K4069), the Spark Program Project of Ministry of Science and Technology (2015GA690010), the Natural Science Research Project of Higher Education Institutions in Jiangsu Province (16KJB510003 and 17KJA510001), and the Natural Science Foundation Project of Huaiyin Institute of Technology (16HGZ004).
