column2: Observation of high photocatalytic activity by tuning of defects in chemically synthesized ethylene glycol capped ZnO nanorods
column3: Abstract In this work, we have reported the tuning of defects by simple thermal annealing of as-synthesized ethylene glycol capped ZnO nanorods at 200–600°C temperatures. X-ray diffraction (XRD) data has confirmed the formation of Wurtzite structure of ZnO and the presence of a small amount of tensile strain is confirmed by Williamson – Hall analyses of XRD data. The lattice strain is found to increase with increasing temperature up-to 400°C and on further increase in temperature it is decreased. To study the influence of defects on photo-catalytic properties of the samples, the degradation of a test dye, namely Methylene Blue (MB) under UV–vis light irradiation has been carried out and the reaction kinetics has been determined by Langmuir-Hinshelwood model. It has been found that 400°C annealed sample exhibits the highest photo-catalytic dye degradation efficiency of ∼83%, within only 20min. The effect of initial MB dye loading on photo-catalytic efficiency of 400°C annealed sample has also been tested and reported an optimum value of dye concentration. The successful introduction of defect states in 400°C annealed sample, as confirmed by PL measurement, has played an important role to achieve the high photo-catalytic activity in the samples.
column5: Keywords Optical properties Photo-catalytic Photoluminescence ZnO Defect tuning Thermal annealing Chemical synthesis Nanorod 1 Introduction The uses of hazardous dyes in textile industry have been a ubiquitous problem of human civilization and efforts are required to counter its effect on environment. The use of semiconductor photo-catalyst for the degradation of dye molecules dissolved in water is an age-old technique [1–3]. When a photo-catalyst is illuminated with the light of appropriate wavelength, electron–hole pairs diffuse out to the surface of the photocatalyst and participate in the photochemical reaction. Those free electrons and holes transform the surrounding oxygen or water molecules into OH radicals having strong oxidizing ability. These radicals are responsible for the effective decomposition of harmful organic dyes into its less hazardous simpler forms. Among different kinds of semiconductors and its composites nanomaterial of TiO2, ZnO, ZnS, CdS, WO3 etc. have been considered extensively due to their useful properties [3,4]. TiO2 is the most commonly used effective photo-catalyst. However, recently it has been found that ZnO with a wide band gap of ∼3.2eV is a good and an alternative semiconductor material for its high efficiency, photochemical stability, non-toxic nature and low cost preparation technique [5]. It has been reported earlier that due to lower exciton recombination rate and greater surface area ZnO has showed promise to achieve a high photo-catalytic efficiency [6]. Several researchers in the past have also reported the benefits of using a smaller sized nanostructure with various microstructures for the degradation of organic dyes [7–9]. They have demonstrated that a larger surface to volume ratio and use of some specific shapes of ZnO elevates the rate and efficiency of dye adsorption at active sites and thus dye degradation rate is improved [7]. Different methods have been tried by earlier researchers to enhance the photocatalytic activity of ZnO by tailoring its size, facets, and surface area [7–9]. Recently, Jang et al. have reported the relationship between the crystal growth plane of ZnO nanocrystals and their photocatalytic efficiency [8]. They have found that the availability of greater proportion of polar surfaces (001) led to a greater photocatalytic activity [8]. They reported that OH ions prefer to adsorb onto polar (001)-Zn surface due to its positive charge, which can react with hole (h+ ) to generate OH radicals and thus enhances the photo-catalytic activity of the sample. The e−/h+ pair is the key factor in determining the photocatalytic reaction rate. Amongst other techniques, thermal annealing is a simple technique as it may effect on the electron-hole recombination rate in ZnO nanostructure and thus photocatalytic dye degradation efficiency of the photo-catalyst may be tailored [8–12]. The effect of annealing and aspect ratio of ZnO and TiO2 nanostructures on photo-degradation of MB dye has been dealt with previously by several researchers [8–12]. Lv et al. reported that ZnO shows 88% degradation of dye in 180min due to annealing at 800°C [11] as compared to 73% for annealed sample at 400°C. Yu et al. has reported that TiO2 shows good photo-catalytic activity at 700°C [9] compared to room temperature sample. In all above reports we have observed that the annealing temperature is quite high to obtain a reasonable photo-catalytic performance. Besides the aspect ratio, shape and size, the presences of surface defects on ZnO are another very important factor for prompting its photo-catalytic performance. In fact, the defects on ZnO have been extensively characterized by various techniques, and their roles in adsorption and surface reactivity have been considered and shows that different oxygen defects (oxygen vacancies and interstitial oxygen) and zinc defects (zinc interstitial) that formed in a solvothermal process has an impact on the photo-catalytic activity of ZnO [10]. Zinc interstitials and oxygen vacancy both play very important roles in photo-catalytic activity [10]. However, in this work we have reported the synthesis of ZnO nanorod by solvothermal technique and then we have demonstrated the tuning of surface defects by simple thermal annealing the as-synthesized sample at 200°, 400° and 600°C temperatures and we could achieve high photo-catalytic degradation efficiency. FESEM, TEM and XRD techniques have been used to obtain the microstructure and phase of the samples. Optical absorption and photoluminescence (PL) emission spectroscopies have been used to confirm the band gap and the presence of defects in the samples. Photo-catalytic property of all the samples have been investigated and found that the sample which has been annealed at 400°C showing the highest MB dye degradation efficiency of 83%. The Langmuir−Hinshelwood (L-H) model has been used to evaluate the kinetics of dye degradation. The optimized degradation efficiency for different dye concentration has been evaluated and is found to be highest for MB-dye of concentration 20mg/L. The effect of particle shape and defect states on kinetics of photo-catalytic degradation has been investigated. A generalized mechanism of chemical reaction of MB dye on photocatalysis has also been reported in this work. 2 Experimental 2.1 Synthesis of samples We have synthesized the ZnO nanorods with varying aspect ratio in two steps. At first ZnO nanoparticles have been freshly synthesized by solvothermal route and then the as-synthesized samples have been isochronally annealed for 2h at various temperatures within the temperature range of 200–600°C. For the synthesis of ZnO nanoparticle by solvothermal technique, 0.016M of Zinc acetate dehydrate [Zn (CH3COO)2] 2H2O is dissolved in 40ml of EG under vigorous stirring for 90min. Then the solution is transferred into a Teflon-lined autoclave maintained at 160°C for 8h. Then the autoclave is left for cooling at room temperature and the precipitate is collected by centrifugation and washed several times with DI water. The precipitate is then dried in our laboratory oven at 100°C for 2h to obtain the final ZnO powder. The obtained sample is divided into four parts, one part is annealed in air ambient at 200°C denoted hereby as S#200, another part at 400°C denoted as S#400, another at 600°C denoted as S#600 and the fourth part is as-synthesized sample denoted as S#RT. All the samples are further characterized for determining their nanostructures and measurement of their optical properties. 2.2 Characterization The XRD patterns have been recorded using a PAN Analytical X-Pert Pro Diffractometer using Cu Kα radiation in the scan range 20–65°. The formations of ZnO nanorod have been confirmed by using TEM and FESEM. TEM images have been recorded in a TEM (JEOL JEM 2100) after dispersing the samples in a carbon coated copper grid. FESEM (ZEISS SIGMA) has been used for structural analysis. The optical absorption spectra of all the samples have been recorded after dispersion in de ionized (DI) water using an UV–vis spectrophotometer (HITACHI U-3010). The PL spectra have been measured at RT by using a PL spectrofluorometer (Perkin Elmer LS 55) by keeping them in a four side polished cuvette of path length 1cm. 2.3 Photo-catalytic dye degradation experiments Photo-catalytic activity of the samples are investigated by observing photo degradation of aqueous solutions of a test dye, namely MB dyes, in the presence of the samples kept inside a cylindrical photo chemical reactor (M/S Lelesil Systems, India). The solution is magnetically stirred for 40min to attain the adsorption equilibrium and then it is irradiated by a 125W UV–vis lamp. Equal amounts of the solution have been collected after each 5min interval and the photo-catalytic degradation of MB solution is monitored by analyzing the UV–vis absorption spectra of the collected solution. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Structural analysis XRD pattern of all samples have been collected to find out the effect of annealing temperature on the synthesized samples. The XRD pattern of S#RT, S#200, S#400 and S#600 samples are shown in Fig. 1 . From Fig. 1(a) it has been found that all samples are consisting of hexagonal wurtzite (WZ) phase of ZnO and all XRD peaks are well matched with standard JCPDS data (Card no: 00–001–1136). The value of lattice parameters (a, b and c) of the hexagonal ZnO has been calculated using Eq. (1) [13]. (1) 1 d 2 = 4 3 ( h 2 + h k + k 2 ) a 2 + l 2 c 2 . Where, a and c are the lattice constants. The calculated values of lattice parameter are summarized in Table 1 . It has been observed that with increasing annealing temperature, the values of the lattice parameter are increased with increasing annealing temperature up-to 400°C, indicating the presence of tensile strain in our samples. Further increase in annealing temperature up-to 600°C shows the reduction in tensile strain in the sample. This strain may be originated from the displacements of the unit cells, dislocation, lattice vacancies, surface restricting, interstitials, doping etc. [13–16]. UV–vis absorption spectra of the RT and annealed samples have been depicted in Fig. 1(c). It has been observed that the absorption spectra of RT sample has a well-defined excitonic peak at∼372nm (∼3.33eV) and the excitonic peak of the annealed samples are red shifted and S#600 sample shows a detectable shift of 8nm in compared with that of RT sample. Also it has been observed that the value of band gap energy of annealed samples has decreased from 3.33eV (for S#RT) to 3.26eV (for S#600) with increasing the temperature and this may be due to the change in defects concentration, particle size, morphology and broken surface layer bonds [17,18]. Zak et al. [17] have reported that the band gap energy has decreased with increasing the annealing temperature and this may be due to the increase in particle size. Recently, Ma et al. [18] have theoretically investigated the effect of annealing condition on the band gap of ZnO crystallites and also provided the experimental verification of it. They have [18] reported that thermal and the cohesive energy of the under coordinated atoms in the surface skin of ZnO induce local strain and quantum entrapment due to annealing which in turn perturb the Hamiltonian. And as a result of that the change in band gap takes place due to annealing. The tensile lattice strain is defined as the ratio of the incremental change of the lattice parameter to its initial value as a result d-spacing of the crystallographic planes also changes. According to Bragg’s law, the Bragg angles should either decrease or increase when d-spacing of the crystallographic lattice plane is changed. For uniform tensile strain the position of the Bragg’s peak shifts to a lower diffraction angle (θ) with the increasing lattice parameter [15]. Since, the lower angle shifts observed in all of our samples with increasing the annealing temperature up-to 400°C which is shown in Fig. 1(b), we believe that a uniform tensile strain has been developed in the perpendicular direction to the lattice plane. To investigate the tensile strain developed in our samples during annealing we have used Williamson-Hall (W-H) plot and uniform deformation model (UDM) which are shown in Fig. 2 (a–d). In the W-H method, it has been suggested that the observed XRD line broadening is due to crystallite size and strain contribution and it can be written as [13], (2) β = β t + β ε . Where, βt is crystallite size broadening, βε is strain induced broadening and β is the full-width at half maximum (FWHM) of instrumental corrected broadening. Strain induced broadening generally arises due to crystal imperfection and distortion which is given by the following relation [13], (3) β ε = 4 tan θ . By considering both of these broadenings, as discussed above, we can rewrite Eq. (3) as, (4) β = k λ D cos θ + 4 ε tan θ . Or, (5) β cos θ = k λ D + 4 ε sin θ . Eqs. (4) and (5) represent the W-H UDM in which the isotropic nature of the crystal is assumed [15]. The slopes of the graphs give the values of strain (ε) and the intercept gives the particle size (D). The positive values of the slope for all samples indicate the tensile strain and it has been attributed due to lattice vacancies, interstitials etc. [14]. The magnitude of the strain is almost two times in case of 400°C annealed sample than that of RT sample and for better viewing the values of strain for all samples has been shown in Table 1. 3.2 FESEM and TEM analyses FESEM and TEM investigations have been carried out to investigate the changes in shape and size of the samples after thermal annealing at different temperatures. The FESEM images of all samples are shown in Fig. 3 (a–d). Fig. 3(a) shows FESEM image of S#RT sample which is clearly showing the presence of nanorod like morphologies along-with some near spherical shapes at RT. Fig. 3(b–d) show the FESEM images of all annealed samples. The TEM images of S#200, S#400 and S#600 samples have been shown in Fig. 4 (e–h) which revealed that the aspect ratio (major axis/minor axis) of the nanorods has been reduced and there is a gradual shift in the particle morphology from nanorod like to spherical has been occurred with the increase in annealing temperature. From the TEM images we have observed that aspect ratio of the synthesized nanorods has decreased with the increase in annealing temperature up-to 400°C and then it has increased as we further increase the temperature to 600°C. As can be seen from Fig. 4(e), the average length and diameter of the nanorods in as-synthesized samples have been calculated by fitted with log normal distribution and get∼120nm and ∼ 35–45nm, respectively. When the temperature is increased to 200°C, as can be seen from Fig. 4(f), the diameter of the nanorods has increased to ∼48nm but the length has reduced. Therefore, it is found that as the annealing temperature is increased, the particle morphology tend to change from rod to near spherical in shape. From the above TEM investigations it is clear that the annealing temperature is playing an important role in the synthesis of ZnO nanorods with various morphologies. From the SEM images of S#400, shown in Fig. 3(c), it can be seen clearly that the particles shapes are spherical in nature with the diameter of ∼51nm, as a results of annealing. After increasing the annealing temperature to 600°C, a significant change in shape and diameter size (∼100nm) are observed, as shown in Fig. 3(d) and Fig. 3(h). The FESEM image of S#600 samples shows the presence of well-defined crystalline planes of ZnO nanocrystals. Due to the high annealing temperature, tensile strain has been released and thus the crystallinity has been improved, this has also been confirmed earlier from W-H analyses. 3.3 Formation mechanism In this section we shall discuss about the mechanism of formations of ZnO nanorods with various morphologies. We have used the EG as the liquid media during solvothermal process. Here, nanorod shaped ZnO has been formed through a homogeneous nucleation and growth process [19–21]. When zinc acetate dehydrate react with EG at RT, zinc glycolate (Zn(OCH2 CH2 O)) capped ZnO nanorods has been formed as an intermediate product [21] and which are confirmed from TEM images. This layer is transformed into ZnO due to increasing the annealing according to the following endothermic reaction which has given below, (6) Z n ( − O − C H 2 − C H 2 − O − ) → Annealing Z n O . Here, EG acts as a modifying agent and the modification occur through nucleophilic substitution reaction (SN) between EG and zinc glycolate. Hydrolysis is another crucial factor which controls the shape and size of ZnO nanoparticles during nucleation process [22]. The presence of thin layer of EG at the surface of as-synthesized ZnO nanorods is clearly visible in the TEM images shown in Fig. 4(e). The boiling point of EG is ∼198°C [19], so when we annealed the samples at 200°C–400°C temperature, EG will come out and the effective particle diameter is enhanced. Also as we increased the annealing temperature tensile strain is developed on (100) and (010) crystallographic planes of nanorods of ZnO. The developed tensile strain plays a key role in the transformation of ZnO nanorods present in as synthesized sample to spherical and nearly spherical shape in annealed sample as observed earlier in our TEM study. After that when we increased the annealing temperature up to 600°C, the agglomeration [23] of small particle has been occurred, which is hindered previously due to the presence of EG layer on ZnO nanostructure in RT. 3.4 Optical properties The photo-catalytic degradation activity of semiconductor nanoparticles can be understood by careful investigations on its linear optical properties. In principle ZnO has number of defect states within the band gap, and the presence of such defect energy states can be easily recognised by simple measurements of PL emission characteristics of the sample [24–27]. The role of defects in determination of photo-catalytic efficiency of nanomaterial has been studied earlier [10]. The donor type and acceptor type defect states present in ZnO are zinc interstitials (Zni ++, Zni + and Zn i x) and oxygen vacancy (Vo ++, Vo + and Vo x) and zinc interstitial and oxygen vacancy are known to be the predominant ionic defects [28]. Zinc interstitial defects come from the Frenkel reaction and then ionized to form Zni ++, Zni +, Zn i x. Oxygen vacancies are also get ionized, the formation mechanism of such defect states are given below; (7) Z n Z n ↔ Z n i x + V Z n x . (7.a) Z n i x ↔ Z n i + + e − . (7.b) Z n i + ↔ Z n i + + + e − . (7.c) V 0 x ↔ V 0 + + e − . (7.d) V 0 + + ↔ V 0 + + h + . Zinc interstitial defects have been regarded as one of the origin of blue emission in ZnO nanoparticles and Zni related blue emission has also been observed by Zeng et al. [24]. The extended Zni defects can be formed according the defect ionization reaction (Eqs. 7a and b). Another set of major defects has been observed in ZnO nanoparticles which are oxygen vacancy states. Among all these defects, some defects are more sensitive to temperature and can only survive at low temperatures. Recently, Vlasenko et al. has shown experimentally that Zni are very unstable and decreases rapidly with increasing the annealing temperature beyond 400°C [26]. These Zni defects are responsible for effective capturing of the e-h pair which induces a delay in e-h pair recombination, which is also evident from the observation of highest photo-catalytic activity of our S#400 sample and decrease in photo-catalytic activity in S #600 samples, which are presented later. In order to find out the collective information about the different defect states and vacancies present in the sample, PL emission spectra of all samples have been collected and those are shown in Fig. 4, measured at an excitation wavelength of 325nm. To find out exact peak position of PL emission spectra of S#RT sample it has been de-convoluted by Gaussian fitting function and it has been shown in Fig. 4(a). The presence of strong near band edge (NBE) emission peak at 386nm (∼3.22eV) and the deep level emission (DLE) peaks at 423nm (∼2.93eV), 451nm (∼2.75eV), 477nm (∼2.60eV), 485nm (∼2.56eV) and 523nm (∼2.37eV) are evident from Fig. 4(a) and which are denoted by numerical numbers (1–6). The NBE peak at 386nm has been assigned to free excitonic recombination in the sample. The peak appeared in the blue region, i.e. at 423nm is assigned to the transition from Zn i to valence band and the series of blue emission peaks are attributed to the transition from extended Zn i states to the valence band [24,27]. These extended Zni states can be formed during the annealing of the sample up to the temperature of 400°C and decreases beyond 400°C, this type of defects formation have been described earlier by Xu et al. [28]. Fig. 4(b) shows the PL emission spectra of S#RT, S#200, S#400 and S#600 samples. From Fig. 4(b) the red shift of NBE PL peak has occurred in the sample annealed at 400°C, this has perhaps aroused due to increase in particle size with increase in annealing temperature [29]. In the S#400 sample, PL emission intensity is found to be enhanced in comparison to that of the RT sample and other annealed samples which can be explained in terms of the energy level diagram given in the inset of Fig. 4(b). The dependence of DLE (485nm) with different excitation wavelength are depicted in Fig. 4 (c) and it is observed that the increase in PL emission intensity occurs with increase in annealing temperature up to 400°C and then it is decreased at higher annealing temperature. From these results it can be concluded that low annealing temperature supply the sufficient ionization energy and generates more amount of Zni defects [24], but at higher annealing temperature DLE intensity is reduced due to outward diffusion of Zni [24,30]. Therefore, the defect states in ZnO nanostructures can be tuned by simple adjustment of the annealing temperature and induce a large amount of defects in the ZnO structures which is responsible for high photo-catalytic degradation activity, as presented in the next section. 3.5 Photo-catalytic dye degradation The photo-catalytic dye degradation efficiencies of the samples have been evaluated by UV–vis light driven photo-catalytic degradation of MB dye solution. The value of large specific surface area coupled with high visible PL emissions from the samples produced after thermal annealing motivate us to optimize the photo-catalytic activity of the annealed and RT samples. According to the researchers, the photo-catalytic performance of a photo-catalyst depends on its morphology, specific surface area, presence of open polar surfaces and defect sites [31–36]. The presence of a large amount of oxygen vacancies in the sample can also increase the number of active sites and stimulate the e-h separation activity. It has been reported earlier that the photo-catalytic activities of ZnO nanorods and nanoflowers are very high due to their large surface area, composites with metal nanoparticle and defects [33]. ZnO nanodisks are also shown to have very high photo-catalytic degradation efficiency [34]. The UV–vis absorbance spectra of MB dye in presence of S#RT, S#200, S#400 and S#600 samples with irradiation time are shown in Fig. 5 (a). From the plots, the absorbance maxima of MB dye has been found at 664nm and the absorption intensity is found to decreases with increasing time for all samples but with different rate of decay. From Fig. 5(a), it is found that S#400 sample shows the high photocatalytic degradation activity because of the presence of a large amount of defect states, which has also been confirmed by the PL emission and XRD data analyses. To investigate the reaction kinetics of the MB dye degradation in the presence of the samples, we have fitted the experimental data using a simple L-H kinetic model and calculated the degradation efficiency which are given below [37,38], (8) D y e deg r a d a t i o n e f f i c i e n c y ( η ) = A 0 − A A o × 100. (9) ln ( C 0 C ) = ln ( A 0 A ) = k t . Where, C and C0 are the concentration and A and A0 are the absorbance at any time t and at the starting time t =0, respectively and k is the reaction rate constant. The fitted curves along-with the experimental data have been shown in Fig. 6 (a). Fig. 6(a) shows that all samples are showing pseudo first order kinetics for the degradation of MB dye under UV–visible light irradiation. The values of k are found out to be 0.063min−1, 0.070min−1 0.077min−1 and 0.012min−1 for S#RT, S#200, S#400 and S#600 samples, respectively. Fig. 6(b) shows the comparison of dye degradation efficiencies (η in%) for all samples and it can be seen that S#400 sample shows the highest value of 83% in 20min only, whereas, S#600 shows the lowest degradation efficiency of 20% under the same experimental conditions. The reason behind this high photo-catalytic efficiency of S #400 samples is presence of a large amount of Zni , extended-Zni and oxygen defect states, as confirmed by PL measurement, as discussed earlier. Moreover, the photo-generated holes trapped by surface defects are ready to react with electron donors and the photocatalytic reaction can be greatly stimulated. 3.5.1 Effect of initial dye concentration The effect of initial concentration of dye on its degradation has been studied with varying concentration of dye from 10 to 40mg/L, keeping the catalyst (viz. S#400 sample) concentration fixed at 12mg/L. The obtained results are shown in Fig. 7 (a) and (b). It is found that the degradation efficiency of S#400 samples has been increased initially for dye concentration up to 20mg/L. However, on increasing further the dye concentration, the degradation efficiency is decreased, which can be seen from Fig. 7(b). Saikia et al. recently found similar trends with ZnO nanostructures [38]. At higher dye concentration more dye molecules are adsorbed on ZnO surface, causing reduced exposure of the defect states to O2 molecules, thus dye degradation efficiency is decreased [38]. 3.5.2 Photo-catalytic degradation mechanism The ZnO based photo-catalytic oxidation mechanism in water solution has been discussed here. In the following we have presented the degradation mechanism of MB dye in the presence of catalyst. MB dye is a nitrogen (N) and sulphur (S) containing aromatic compound (C16H18N3SCl). The photo-catalytic activity is started when the photon is incident on the catalyst surface. It can create an e-h pair i.e. excitons in ZnO photocatalyst [39]. Mainly two oxidative agents are considering here which are h+ (photo-induced hole) and OH radicals. This electron hole pair produces some intermediates products like, HOO. and H2O2 which finally produced the OH radicals in the presence of dissolved O2 [40]. This OH radicals are very strong oxidizing agent which can break the aromatic rings of the dye molecules and h + are mainly involved in decarboxylation reaction [41] (Photo-Kolbe reaction) and produced CO2. The possible oxidation mechanism is given below, (10) H 2 O ↔ ( H + + O H − ) + h + → H + + O H . (10.a) Z n O + h v → h + + e − . (10.b) O 2 + e − → O 2 • − . (10.c) O 2 • − + e − + 2 H + → H 2 O 2 . (10.d) H 2 O 2 + e − → O H − + O H • . (10.e) O H • + M B → C O 2 + H 2 O + S O 4 2 − + N H 2 − . The pathways of degradation of MB dye have also been shown in Fig. 8 . In the presence of UV–vis light irradiation the OH radicals first attack the CS+ C group with central aromatic ring of MB dye. The sulfoxide group are polar functional group and it can react with second OH radicals which produce sulfone and this sulfone finally separate the benzene rings [40]. Again sulfone group attached with the OH radical and produce sulfonic acid and finally produces SO4 2− ions. This SO4 2− ion reacts with OH radical and produces phenolic compound and H+ radical. However, the central aromatic ring is open due to the conversion from CS+ C to CS (O)C and two amino groups are converted into (-NH2 ) group due to the attack of OH radicals. The origin of H+ atoms is necessary for CH and NH bond formation and that can be formed by photo-generated electrons. Sulfonic acid and hydrated amino group further react with OH radicals and is finally converted into phenol, CO2, SO4 2− , NH2 − etc. [39–42]. Zinc interstitials (Zni, Zni +, Zni ++ ) and oxygen vacancies (Vo +, Vo ++ ) related defects have played important roles in the formation of OH. radical which has helped to degrade the MB dye in the presence of UV–vis light. The variation of the defects in the samples can be assessed from the observation of PL emission spectra. It has been found that S#400 samples shows the highest PL emission intensity confirming the presence of a large amount of defects in the sample. 4 Conclusions In conclusion, in this work we have demonstrated the tuning of defects by simple thermal annealing technique in as-synthesized EG capped ZnO nanostructures. It has been observed that, characteristics of different zinc interstitials and oxygen vacancy related PL emissions as well as the shape of the sample have been changed with the annealing temperatures. By increasing the annealing temperature from 200°C to 600°C, the shape of the synthesized materials has been changed from rod like to nearly spherical. The lattice strain present in the samples has been determined by using the Williamson – Hall (W-H) analyses of XRD data and a 2 fold increase in lattice strain is observed in 400°C annealed sample in comparison with that of as-synthesized sample. To study the influence of defects on photo-catalytic properties of the samples the degradation of a test dye, namely MB, under UV–vis light irradiation, has been carried out and the reaction kinetics has been determined by Langmuir–Hinshelwood model. It is found that there is a need of appropriate calcination temperature, in our case it is 400°C, at which ZnO maintained a quasi-spherical structure with tensile strain and large amount of defects which is favourable to improve the photo-catalytic degradation efficiency. At this annealing temperature, ZnO has exhibited more than 83% degradation efficiency within 20min only. The successful tuning of high defect states in 400°C annealed sample, as confirmed by PL measurement, has played an important role to achieve the high photo-catalytic activity in the samples. The photo-generated holes are trapped by surface defects which react with electron donors and the photocatalytic reaction can be greatly enhanced. The simple annealing technique at an optimum temperature induces large amount of zinc interstitials and oxygen vacancies on ZnO materials and that can be utilized as an effective photo-catalyst for the complete photodegradation of various organic dyes and is helpful for the management of industrial waste water.
